site_title: Sri Lanka central bank leaves key policy rates unchanged, as expected
summary: Sri Lanka's central bank maintained its key interest rates at 7.00% and 8.00% for the standing deposit facility rate and standing lending facility rate, respectively. The decision was in line with market expectations following the new government's tax cuts to boost economic growth. The central bank has cut rates twice since May to bolster the economy after the Easter Day bomb attacks. The rates remain unchanged after the previous cut of 100 basis points in May.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, China Everbright, Cromwell E-Reit, Accordia Golf Trust, POSH
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering scrapping the minimum trading price (MTP) rule, affecting about 100 companies. China Everbright Water plans to sell up to S$58.2 million in secured bonds. Cromwell E-Reit acquired a freehold office property in Italy for S$26.6 million. Accordia Golf Trust received a non-binding proposal to sell its golf courses. POSH's recommended directors advised shareholders to accept a cash offer at S$0.215 per share. Duty Free International plans to return surplus capital to shareholders through a cash distribution.

site_title: Japan's factory output posts biggest fall in almost 2 years
summary: Japan's factory output fell 4.2% in October, the largest decline in almost two years, exceeding market forecasts. This marks the fastest decline since January 2019. The decline is attributed to a combination of domestic and foreign demand issues. Japan's economy faces significant challenges, with the data exposing widening cracks in the economy. This decline is the latest in a series of economic concerns for Japan, highlighting the need for policymakers to address these issues.

site_title: UAE property mogul buys Roberto Cavalli fashion label
summary: Dubai billionaire Hussain Sajwani has acquired the struggling Italian fashion house Roberto Cavalli through his private investment company Vision Investment. The luxury fashion brand has faced repeated financial crises in recent years. A Milan court had previously upheld the company's restructuring agreement with creditors, allowing Sajwani to acquire the firm. Sajwani stated that he believes the brand resonates with his idea of luxury, marking a new chapter for the luxury fashion label. The acquisition amount was not specified.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop as trade jitters return
summary: European shares dropped 0.1% after concerns about a US-China trade truce resurfaced, amid a diplomatic standoff between the two nations. The Stoxx 600 index retreated from a four-year peak, with trade-sensitive auto parts makers leading declines. Investors are cautiously optimistic about a possible partial trade deal by year-end, but remain cautious due to uncertainty. Economic indicators, including German inflation and euro zone economic sentiment, showed mixed signals, with no clear indication of a slowdown ending.

site_title: Vancouver approves ban on plastic straws, bags from next year
summary: Vancouver has voted to ban plastic straws and bags starting April 2020 and January 2021, respectively. The move aims to reduce plastic pollution and follows Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's announcement of a nationwide ban on single-use plastics by 2021. Plastic bags account for 3% of shoreline litter on Vancouver's beaches annually, while almost 90% of plastic products in Canada end up in landfills or the environment. Businesses must provide flexible straws upon request and may charge for paper bags after the ban is enacted.

site_title: Net migration to UK falls to lowest in almost six years
summary: Net migration to the UK fell to its lowest level in nearly six years, with 212,000 more people moving to Britain than left between June 2018 and June 2019. This decline was driven by a decrease in EU citizens moving for work, with a net 48,000 EU citizens arriving, the lowest since 2009. Non-EU net migration increased, with 229,000 immigrants arriving. The UK government welcomed the drop but said more needed to be done to stem the flow of foreigners.

site_title: Broadway Industrial in M&A talks with 2 prospects
summary: Broadway Industrial Group is in discussions with two potential partners for a merger and acquisition, as part of its strategic review aimed at diversifying its business and enhancing shareholder value. The company's board will disclose details once definitive agreements are signed. The review follows recent key appointments, including a CEO and COO, responsible for diversification projects. Shares closed unchanged at S$0.044, with the company advising caution to shareholders and investors.

site_title: Facebook and Instagram report outage
summary: Facebook suffered a software outage on November 28, 2019, affecting its social platform and Instagram apps, with users experiencing trouble accessing the platforms. The outage, which started at 1345 GMT, was attributed to a central software issue. Facebook reported that it had restored access and was monitoring for full recovery. The outage impacted 2.45 billion active monthly users across Facebook's products, with some regions affected and others not. The cause of the outage was a software problem, which was quickly investigated and addressed by the company.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit buys office building in Italy for 17.7m euros
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (CEREIT) has acquired a 17.7 million-euro office building in Italy's Colleoni Business Park, about 30 minutes north-east of Milan. The property, built in 1982, was refurbished and valued independently by Colliers International at the same price. The purchase price includes capital expenditure works and vendor incentives, with the deal expected to contribute to CEREIT's expansion in Europe.

images.alt_text: The office building at Via Paracelso 22-24-26 is made up of three adjoining blocks. Three principal tenants contribute to just over 50 per cent of its total income.

site_title: Hong Kong to allow airlines to keep airport slots despite cutting capacity
summary: Hong Kong's Civil Aviation Department has temporarily suspended the "use-it-or-lose-it" rule for airlines to keep airport slots despite cutting capacity due to weak travel demand. This move allows airlines, including Cathay Pacific, to maintain their slots until March 2020, providing greater flexibility in aircraft deployment. The suspension is in response to the ongoing anti-government protests, which have led to a sharp decline in tourist and business travel demand. The rule change aims to support airlines during this challenging period.

images.alt_text: Airlines that fly to and from Hong Kong will be able to keep their prized airport slots even if they temporarily cut capacity due to weak travel demand through March, according to the Hong Kong Civil Aviation Department.

site_title: Far East Consortium said to mull S$500m Singapore Reit IPO
summary: Far East Consortium International, a Hong Kong developer, is considering a Singapore Reit IPO that could raise up to S$500 million. The company, led by CEO David Chiu, owns 28 operating hotels with 7,500 rooms and 15 properties in development. The IPO could take place in the first half of 2020, following Singapore's successful track record of property trust listings. This move would capitalize on the city-state's growing real estate market, with an index of Reits rising 19% this year.

site_title: Hong Kong sets record in HK$42b land sale
summary: Hong Kong's government sold a plot of land for a record HK$42 billion (S$7.32 billion), beating lower-than-expected estimates. The site, located near the high-speed railway station in Kowloon, was won by Sun Hung Kai Properties. The sale comes after six months of pro-democracy protests that have impacted the city's real estate market.

site_title: China Everbright proposes up to 300m yuan bond sale in China
summary: China Everbright Water is proposing to sell up to 300 million yuan (S$58.2 million) of secured bonds in China through an asset-backed securities scheme. The company has applied to the Shanghai Stock Exchange for approval, subject to market conditions and regulatory approval. Details of the scheme and bond terms will be disclosed if the issue proceeds. The move is intended to raise funds, but the company advises shareholders and potential investors to exercise caution when dealing in its shares.

site_title: Clean Eating
summary: A UK-based organic food company, Daylesford, has partnered with a Singaporean online shop, Queer Beets, to launch a pop-up store in Scotts Square. The store features a curated selection of Daylesford's gourmet staples, including organic Christmas food items such as elderflower orange ham, fruitcake, and chocolates. This marks Daylesford's entry into the Singapore market, offering a quintessential English dinner experience for the holiday season.

site_title: Oil ends mixed, pressured by US tensions with China over rights bill
summary: US oil prices rebounded modestly after President Trump signed a bill backing Hong Kong protesters, fuelling tensions with China. Brent crude lost 14 cents, while West Texas Intermediate crude closed up 13 cents. China warned the US of "firm countermeasures" in response to the legislation. Investors fear the move may delay a US-China trade agreement, which could impact oil demand. Oil prices are expected to remain volatile, with Opec+ likely to roll over production cuts for three to six months.

site_title: Big four auditors face investor calls for tougher climate scrutiny
summary: European investors managing assets worth over $1.75 trillion are pressing top auditors, the Big Four (EY, Deloitte, KPMG, and PwC), to take urgent action on climate-related risks. The investors claim auditors are not giving enough weight to a low-carbon future and are ignoring climate change in accounting and audits. The investors are calling for auditors to challenge assumptions about long-term oil and gas prices and to report on environmental and societal issues. The International Accounting Standards Board has said its standards address climate change risk, but investors want auditors to be more proactive in addressing the issue.

site_title: Hyflux bank lenders said to oppose adviser fees for Utico deal
summary: Hyflux's unsecured bank lenders are reportedly opposing the company's new restructuring agreement with Utico due to a potential success fee of up to S$25 million for adviser nTan Corporate Advisory. The fee is capped at S$40 million, leaving it "highly unlikely" that creditors' advisers will receive any additional funds. The lenders' opposition raises concerns about fairness, as subordinated creditors and retail investors have expressed resistance to the deal, citing lower recovery rates and unfair treatment.

images.alt_text: Some of Hyflux's unsecured bank lenders are reportedly objecting to the new restructuring agreement (RA) inked by the troubled water treatment firm and white knight Utico.

site_title: Brazil revises up Nov exports by US$3.8b
summary: Brazil's Economy Ministry revised up November exports by $3.8 billion, or 40%, citing data inconsistencies. This boosts the country's trade surplus to around $2.7 billion, reversing a possible deficit. The revision boosted the Brazilian real, leading to its largest daily gain against the dollar in over a month. The move is viewed positively, as a widening trade surplus indicates demand and capital inflows from overseas.

site_title: RHT Health Trust manager advises unitholders to adjourn Dec 3 EGM on winding-up action
summary: RHT Health Trust's trustee-manager is proposing to adjourn its Dec 3 EGM to consider whether to proceed with a voluntary winding-up, following India's Supreme Court's guilty verdict against Fortis Healthcare's founders for contempt of court. Fortis had purchased RHT's healthcare assets and advised against proceeding with the winding-up due to potential contempt risks. The trustee-manager has requested an adjournment until the court's contempt proceedings are resolved or the Supreme Court allows the winding-up process to proceed.

site_title: Chile central bank says might sell up to US$20b in interventions
summary: Chile's central bank announced a plan to sell up to US$20 billion in foreign currency interventions through May 29, 2020, to stabilize the peso, which reached a new all-time low amid protests and economic instability. The intervention program includes US$10 billion in dollar sales and US$10 billion in exchange hedging instruments. The decision was made in response to the impact of recent protests on the country's economy.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Nam Lee Pressed Metal Industries reported a 18.3% drop in full-year earnings to S$9.8 million, with earnings per share down 18.4%. Keong Hong Holdings posted a 30.6% drop in full-year net profit to S$16.3 million, due to impairment losses and estimated credit losses. Both companies proposed final dividends, with Nam Lee's at 1 Singapore cent and Keong Hong's at 1.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: The hoodie now a museum piece
summary: A hoodie, once a staple of streetwear and high fashion, has become a symbol of fear and panic. It has been a linchpin of social and cultural identity, representing affiliation with a school, team, or subculture. The garment's versatility and comfort have made it a wardrobe essential. However, its potential to trigger fear and panic has led to a shift in perception, with some viewing it as a "museum piece." The hoodie's significance is a reflection of its complex role in contemporary culture.

site_title: Free Play
summary: The annual Playfreely experimental music festival, themed "The Transparency of Turbulence," will take place on November 29 at 72-13 Mohamed Sultan Road. The festival features a diverse lineup of musicians, including Malaysian composer Yii Kah Hoe, Japanese multi-instrumentalist Keiji Haino, and Korean singer Park Minhee. The Observatory, a trio of musicians, will also perform. Tickets are available for S$35 from playfreely2019.peatix.com.

site_title: Zimbabwe facing 'man-made' starvation, UN expert warns
summary: Zimbabwe is facing "man-made" starvation with 60% of its population failing to meet basic food needs, according to a UN special envoy. Eight million people will be affected by the end of the year, with 5.5 million in rural areas and 2.2 million in urban areas facing severe food shortages. The country is plagued by economic crisis, corruption, and poverty, with hyperinflation and drought exacerbating the issue. The government and international community are urged to come together to address the crisis, which could lead to civil unrest and insecurity if left unresolved.

site_title: World's first urban veg and fish garden in a hotel opens in Singapore
summary: The Fairmont Singapore and Swissôtel The Stamford in Singapore have opened the world's first urban aquaponics garden within a hotel. The 450-square-metre garden produces leafy vegetables and fish, with a goal to provide 30% of the hotels' vegetables and 10% of their fish by 2030. The garden uses less water, reduces carbon footprints, and eliminates plastics, aligning with Singapore's "30 by 30" goal to produce 30% of the country's nutritional needs locally.

site_title: Money FM podcast: A non-profit aims to eliminate homelessness in the world
summary: A non-profit organization, billionBricks, aims to eliminate homelessness worldwide through innovative solutions. In a podcast discussion, the CEO, Prasoon Kumar, discussed the organization's efforts to address the issue, one "brick at a time." While no specific timeline or milestones were mentioned, Kumar emphasized the importance of collaboration and community engagement in achieving this goal. The initiative seeks to provide a comprehensive and sustainable approach to tackling homelessness globally.

site_title: Winning Architecture
summary: Singapore's shortlisted projects for the World Architecture Festival's Building of the Year award include the National University of Singapore School of Design & Environment, Oasis Terrace, and Novena Church. Jewel Changi Airport by Safdie Architects is also in the running, following Singapore's previous wins in 2012, 2015, and 2018. Notably, Qatar's Hamad International Airport was excluded from the competition after Qatar Airways chief Akbar Al Baker accused Jewel of copying its design. The WAF awards recognize exceptional architectural achievements globally.

site_title: MAS flags leverage risk in businesses tied to trade, building sectors
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has flagged increased corporate debt in Singapore, mainly driven by the property and commerce sectors, with risks for businesses exposed to trade-related sectors and construction. While corporate balance sheets are broadly resilient, MAS warns that weak revenue growth and high leverage could catch companies unawares. The regulator has identified the construction sector as a concern, with negative interest coverage ratios, but expects improvement in the sector going forward. MAS also notes that the trade-related sectors, including hotels and restaurants, have higher non-performing loan ratios.

site_title: German inflation holds steady in November
summary: German inflation remained steady at 1.1% in November, according to preliminary data from Destatis. This rate is the same as in October. The European Central Bank's Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices showed a slightly higher inflation rate of 1.2% in November, up from 0.9% in October. The data suggests that the bank's recent stimulus efforts may not be having the desired effect on price growth.

images.alt_text: German inflation remained stuck at the low level of 1.1 per cent in November, preliminary data showed on Thursday, despite fresh stimulus from the European Central Bank to stoke price growth.

site_title: Will Trump get China deal wrapped up in time for Christmas?
summary: US President Donald Trump has reaffirmed that US-China trade negotiators are in the "final throes" of a phase one deal, despite bilateral differences over Hong Kong. A deal by Christmas would address tariffs and demonstrate economic stability for China, while a delay would allow Trump to focus on his re-election campaign. However, tensions between the two countries remain, with concerns over Hong Kong, security issues, and Trump's unpredictable behavior. A phase one deal could provide stability for the global economy and limit the damage from the US-China trade war, but a "grand bargain" extending beyond economics is unlikely.

site_title: China's crackdown on cryptocurrencies claims first victims
summary: China's crackdown on cryptocurrencies has resulted in at least five local exchanges halting operations or refusing to serve domestic users this month. Regulators issued warnings and notices as part of a cleanup of digital currency trading. This move is part of a broader effort to curb the growth of cryptocurrencies in the country. The crackdown is expected to have a significant impact on the cryptocurrency market in China.

site_title: US sparks overnight risk-off move with HK bill
summary: The US sparked an overnight risk-off move in financial markets due to its passage of a bill supporting pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong, prompting China to threaten "firm counter-measures." The US dollar index was down less than 0.1% and the Japanese yen rose 0.2% against the US dollar. The move heightened concerns about the impact on US-China trade negotiations, with traders waiting for China's response. Markets were muted due to record-low volatility and the US Thanksgiving holiday.

site_title: Operators brace for bird calls on the Butterball Turkey hotline
summary: The Butterball Turkey Talkline, a seasonal hotline launched in 1981, provides assistance to over 100,000 nervous cooks on Thanksgiving, offering expert advice on turkey cooking, thawing, and preparation. The 50 experts, mostly with culinary or nutritional backgrounds, field calls from 6am to 6pm on Thanksgiving Day, using a mix of phone, text, email, and live chat sessions. Despite the rise of online resources, the talkline remains a trusted and beloved American tradition, with competitors and media outlets adopting its concept. The hotline has become a cultural phenomenon, fostering friendships and memorable calls among its experts.

site_title: Hiap Seng calls for trading suspension amid going concern uncertainty
summary: Hiap Seng Engineering has requested a trading suspension due to uncertainty over its ability to operate as a going concern. The company is undergoing a restructuring and realignment exercise to dispose of assets, which may include land and buildings in Thailand and leasehold properties in Singapore. Hiap Seng narrowed its net loss to S$8.5 million in Q2 2020, but faces a challenging operating environment with intense competition. The company's current liabilities exceeded current assets by S$30.1 million as of September 30.

site_title: Malta PM calls emergency meeting as murder probe escalates
summary: Malta's Prime Minister Joseph Muscat called an emergency cabinet meeting amid escalating murder probe into investigative journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia. The probe has led to the resignation of several high-ranking officials, including chief of staff Keith Schembri and tourism minister Konrad Mizzi. Businessman Yorgen Fenech, the prime suspect, has fingered Schembri as the mastermind behind Caruana Galizia's 2017 murder. Muscat has vowed to resign if links are found between himself and the murder, as the European Parliament prepares to send a mission to investigate allegations of corruption and judicial independence.

images.alt_text: Maltese Prime Minister Joseph Muscat called an emergency cabinet meeting on Thursday night as a intensifying probe into the murder of investigative journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia threatened to further destabilise the government.

site_title: Israel's military experience gives it an edge in global drone industry
summary: Israel's drone industry has a significant advantage over global competitors China and the US due to its extensive military experience. Israel's military uses drones daily in its borders, monitoring and striking enemy positions. This experience translates to a competitive edge in the global drone industry, allowing Israel to develop and deploy advanced drones that meet the needs of its military. As a result, Israel is poised to capture a larger market share in the global drone industry.

images.alt_text: Mini unmanned aerial vehicles by Israeli company BlueBird on display at a recent conference on drones at Airport City, an industrial zone close to the airport in Tel Aviv. The global drone market is expected to be worth around US$12 billion in 2019, and double that number in a decade.

site_title: Fashion Plate
summary: Designer Priscilla Shunmugam is expanding her brand from dresses to homeware, launching a tableware collection called Ong Shunmugam Suvarnabumi. The 11-piece collection features porcelain items with Southeast Asian-inspired designs, such as flora and fauna, and will be available starting December 5. Shunmugam aims to bring high-end design and production value to the homeware market in Singapore, which she believes is underdeveloped. The collection will be priced from S$59 to S$149, with plans to expand into soft furnishings and other home decor items in the future.

site_title: Post-cooling measures, property prices 'closer to fundamentals'
summary: Singapore's property market has shown modest price movements since July 2018, with accommodative financial conditions moderating growth. The Monetary Authority of Singapore attributes this to cooling measures, such as adjusting Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty rates and tightening loan-to-value limits, which have brought prices "closer to fundamentals". Foreigners' purchases have had the largest impact on growth, exhibiting 'economically significant' effects.

site_title: JustCo, Daito Trust to operate flexible workspaces in Japan
summary: JustCo, a Singapore-based co-working space operator, has secured a $50 million investment from Japanese construction and real estate firm Daito Trust Construction. The joint venture will build and operate flexible workspaces in Japan, with plans to open seven to nine centers in Tokyo between 2020 and 2021. This partnership marks JustCo's entry into Japan, bringing the total number of markets it operates in to eight. The JV will be 49% owned by JustCo and 51% owned by Daito Trust.

site_title: Countries need to take urgent action on climate change
summary: Countries must take urgent action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, failing to meet the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C temperature target. The latest Emissions Gap Report reveals a 10-year period of procrastination has led to collective emissions cuts of less than 1% per year. The report calls for a "dramatic" strengthening of country commitments to achieve a 2°C target, or a fivefold increase to meet the 1.5°C target. The world's wealthiest countries, including the US and China, are largely responsible for emissions, with only five G-20 members committed to long-term zero emissions targets.

site_title: Shareholder vs employee: Who counts more?
summary: A conversation about the relative importance of shareholders versus employees in companies is sparking debate. The focus on shareholder rights and value often overshadows the needs and rights of workers, leading to inequitable pay and benefits distribution. Companies, such as Royal DSM, are being called to reevaluate their priorities and make the world a better place. Meanwhile, issues like dual-class shares, pawnbroker investments, and sustainable practices are also being discussed in various sections of the article.

site_title: Amazon's cloud unit readies more potent data centre chip
summary: Amazon's cloud computing unit is developing a second, more powerful data centre processor chip using technology from Arm Holdings, with the potential to reduce its reliance on Intel and AMD. The new chip is expected to be at least 20% faster than Amazon's first Arm-based chip, Graviton, and will use newer Arm technology, including the Neoverse N1 technology with at least 32 cores. The chip's release could challenge Intel's dominance in the server processor market and make Arm-based offerings more competitive in the data centre chip market.

site_title: More help for businesses, PMETs in manufacturing sector
summary: Singapore is increasing support for businesses in the manufacturing sector, aiming to attract more professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) with a new program. The Professional Conversion Programme (PCP) will provide 1,000 additional places for PMETs to transition into the sector, with a focus on reskilling for roles such as operations management and marketing. Since 2016, 1,400 people have benefited from the program, with 600 companies supported. The move aims to boost businesses and prepare workers for economic growth, with 90% of participants remaining in employment.

site_title: Investment income gain pushes up Maybank's Q3 profit
summary: Maybank's Q3 net profit rose 2% to RM2 billion, driven by investment income gains and higher net interest income and earned insurance premiums. Revenue increased 14.7% to RM13.83 billion. Despite this, the lender expects its home markets in Malaysia, Singapore, and Indonesia to be impacted by moderate growth projections in South-east Asian countries, particularly Singapore, which is exposed to the US-China trade war.

site_title: US mortgage rates rebound slightly heading into Thanksgiving weekend
summary: US mortgage rates rose slightly to 3.68% for a 30-year fixed rate, up from 3.66% the previous week and 4.81% a year ago. The 15-year fixed rate remained unchanged at 3.15%. Despite concerns over the US-China trade talks, lower mortgage rates are supporting the housing market, with housing starts and permits increasing, and home builder sentiment showing a strong second-best showing of the year.

site_title: Tung Lok plates up a taste of sustainability
summary: TASTE by Tunglok, a restaurant in Park Regis Singapore, aims to promote sustainability through its menu and practices. The restaurant features organic, free-range ingredients, including a slow-cooked chicken dish with fish maw and goji berries. However, the food can be pricey, with dishes starting at S$28. Despite some good initial signs, the restaurant lapses into familiar territory, and the definition of responsible eating is sometimes fudged. To achieve its sustainability goals, TASTE needs to work on consistency and transparency.

site_title: First Sponsor sells Amsterdam office building to associate
summary: First Sponsor, a Singaporean property developer, has sold its entire share capital in a Dutch subsidiary to an associate firm, FSMC NL Property Group, becoming an indirect 33% owner. The subsidiary, FS NL Zuidoost Property 15 BV, has a perpetual leasehold interest in a land parcel in the Netherlands. This transaction results in First Sponsor's indirect association with the Dutch company.

images.alt_text: First Sponsor says the sale of the site and the office building, Oliphant, will generate development profit while retaining a "meaningful" stake for future capital appreciation and recurrent income.

site_title: Raffles Place: Then and Now
summary: Raffles Place, Singapore's commercial district, has undergone significant transformation over nearly 200 years. Originally a bucolic hill, it was leveled in 1822 to build trade and commerce, becoming Commercial Square and later Raffles Place. The area was home to various businesses, including the oldest department store in Singapore, which boasted an underground carpark and rooftop garden. A special exhibition, Curiocity: Raffles Place, showcases the area's transformation through photographs, archival footage, and oral histories, available until March 22, 2020, at the National Library Building.

site_title: TikTok reinstates video on China's treatment of Muslims
summary: TikTok has reinstated a video criticizing China's treatment of Muslims after it was temporarily removed due to a "human moderation error". The video, viewed 1.6 million times, featured a tutorial on eyelash curling while discussing the treatment of Muslims. The app apologized to the user, Feroza Aziz, and clarified that the content did not violate its community guidelines. The incident comes as TikTok's Chinese owner faces scrutiny over its handling of personal data and potential censorship of politically sensitive content.

site_title: Music, murder & meatpies
summary: Sondheim's musical Sweeney Todd is being staged in Singapore for the first time, starring Lea Salonga as a pie-maker and Jett Pangan as the demon barber. The story follows the barber's revenge on the man responsible for his downfall, with the pie-maker helping him turn victims into meat pies. The production runs at the Sands Theatre from November 28 to December 8.

site_title: Harmony of Old and New
summary: Chinese luxury brand Shang Xia, backed by Hermès, opens its first pop-up store in Singapore. Founded by designer Jiang Qiong Er, the brand combines centuries-old Chinese craftsmanship with modern materials and French style. Shang Xia's collections include ready-to-wear, home accessories, and furniture, with a focus on balance and harmony between tradition and modernity. The brand's repertoire appeals to a wide range of clients, from young adults to seniors, and is characterized by its emphasis on craftsmanship and emotional connection.

images.alt_text: Cashmere Shawl.
Interior of Shang Xia Shanghai store.
Bridge Bamboo Weaving Teaware.
Jiang Qiong Er.
(Left) Lan Yue Bag in sandstone. (Right) Da Tian Di Carbon Fiber Chair.

site_title: Frasers Logistics, Frasers Commercial Trust make plans to merge: sources
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust and Frasers Commercial Trust are planning to merge, creating a combined entity with over 100 properties worth US$4 billion across Singapore, Australia, and Europe. The deal could be announced within days, with the combined company managing commercial and industrial assets under one entity, allowing for increased size and financing capabilities. This is the fourth consolidation among Singapore-listed Reits this year, following previous deals by CapitaLand, OUE Commercial Reit, and Ascott Residence Trust and Ascendas Hospitality Trust.

site_title: Malaysian motormouth
summary: Ronny Chieng, a Malaysian comedian known for his humor on The Daily Show, is set to perform a live stand-up show at the Esplanade Theatre in Singapore on Nov 29. This marks a homecoming for Chieng, who spent 10 years in Singapore for his secondary school and junior college education. The show, titled "Ronny Chieng: Tone Issues Tour," is rated M18 and available for tickets through Sistic.

site_title: Special Feature: Korea's Medley of MICE venues
summary: Korea offers a diverse range of unique MICE venues, from the Korea Furniture Museum in Seoul, featuring traditional Korean furniture, to the Asia Culture Centre in Gwangju, with its large outdoor plaza and arts theatre. The Jeondeungsa Temple in Incheon offers a traditional experience and stunning views, while the DMZ Museum in Gangwon provides insight into the country's history and relationship with North Korea. Other options include the Just Kpop restaurant in Seoul, the Korean Stone Art Museum in Seoul, and the Korea Furniture Museum, making it easy to find a venue that suits any event.

images.alt_text: Korea Furniture Museum.
Korea Furniture Museum.
Asia Culture Centre
Jeondeungsa Temple
DMZ Museum
Just Kpop
Korean Stone Art Museum

site_title: Luke Bailes
summary: Luke Bailes, founder of Singita Safari Lodges, is a conservationist who has made luxury tourism a means to support wildlife protection and land conservation. His company owns 15 properties across Africa, generating revenue to buy and rehabilitate land, fund anti-poaching efforts, and support community development projects. Bailes' conservation efforts have led to significant success stories, including the protection of rhinos and other endangered species, and his influence has inspired a new wave of philanthropists to prioritize environmental causes.

site_title: Singapore resident employment rate up, income growth slows
summary: Singapore's resident employment rate rose to 80.8% in June, higher than the previous year, despite economic headwinds. Workers' income grew, but at a slower pace. The top hiring sectors were community services, professional services, and financial services. The unemployment rate for professionals and managers held steady, while non-PMETs rose slightly due to the US-China trade war's cyclical effects. Real median income grew 2.2% this year, lower than last year, but wage growth in the last five years was higher than the preceding five years.

site_title: In nod to market, SGX seeks to scrap minimum trading price rule
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is seeking to scrap its minimum trading price (MTP) rule, which has affected around 100 companies since its implementation in 2016. The rule requires companies to maintain a six-month volume-weighted average share price of at least 20 Singapore cents and a six-month average daily market capitalization of at least S$40 million. The proposal will be put up for public consultation until December 27, with a decision expected in the first half of 2020. The move is seen as a response to the unanticipated consequences of the rule, which has led to companies struggling to meet the criteria.

site_title: Global economy dodges bullets, but is sluggish
summary: The global economy has dodged major shocks, but remains sluggish, with many experts attributing the slowdown to factors such as inequality, automation, and a lack of demand. The US economy ended 2019 with a 1.1% annual rate of GDP growth, while the world economy is slowing, with China's official growth rate at 6% but potentially lower. Consumers are keeping spending afloat, but business investment is stagnant, and the monetary authorities have eased rates to a near-zero level. Political gridlock is hindering necessary measures to address these challenges, including infrastructure spending and addressing climate change, which could further mute growth prospects.

images.alt_text: One perspective is tied to the population profile. In an ageing population, for example, spending is lower than among new families that are having children and buying their first home.

site_title: Plastic Pandemic
summary: An 11m tall sculpture, "Skyscraper (The Bruges Whale)," made from ocean plastic and steel, has been installed outside the ArtScience Museum in Singapore. Designed by StudioKCA, the installation is a physical representation of the massive amount of plastic waste in the ocean, with 8 million tonnes added annually. Created from collected plastic waste, including hangers, bowls, and car bumpers, the sculpture serves as a warning about the need to change plastic disposal habits. The installation is on display until December 19.

site_title: Japan retail sales dip the most since 2015 as tax hike hits demand
summary: Japan's retail sales plummeted 7.1% in October, the largest decline since 2015, due to a sales tax hike to 10% from 8%. The drop was sharper than predicted by economists, raising concerns over domestic demand and the economy's strength. A weak consumer sector, poor weather, and structural pressures such as declining real wages also contributed to the decline. The government's efforts to offset the tax hike's impact through cashless payment rebates may exacerbate deflation and threaten small retailers.

site_title: URA launches two Canberra Drive residential sites for tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched two residential sites, Parcel A and Parcel B, along Canberra Drive in Singapore for public tender. The sites, on 99-year leases, can potentially yield 675 units, with Parcel A yielding 220 units and Parcel B yielding 455 units. Tenders for the sites close on March 3, 2020, and analysts expect strong demand due to the lack of new condo launches in the area. The average sale price is expected to be around S$1,250 per square foot, with top bids of S$135 million for Parcel A and S$280 million for Parcel B.

site_title: China speeds up 1 trillion yuan bond sale to boost slowing economy
summary: China has ordered local governments to rapidly issue 1 trillion yuan in debt earmarked for infrastructure projects to boost its slowing economy. The Ministry of Finance requires localities to allocate the funds as soon as possible to specific projects, potentially starting as early as December. This move is aimed at injecting stimulus into the economy and ensuring funding for infrastructure projects in 2020. Analysts predict the issuance may exceed 2.15 trillion yuan, and the decision reflects the government's willingness to support the economy through policy measures.

site_title: Supply-side global food inflation and central bank policies
summary: Global food inflation is surging in emerging markets, with China's pork prices doubling and India's onion prices rising 26% year-over-year. This is driving up consumer prices and threatening inflation, but central banks remain focused on boosting economic growth amid a global slowdown. While food inflation is a concern, economists believe it may be transitory and not drive up longer-term inflation expectations. Central banks face a policy dilemma, balancing the need to ease monetary policy with the risk of supply-side driven inflation.

site_title: Trump signs Bill in support of HK protesters
summary: US President Donald Trump signed legislation supporting Hong Kong protesters, which requires annual reviews of Hong Kong's special trade status and sanctions against officials responsible for human rights abuses. China warned the US against meddling in Hong Kong's affairs, threatening retaliation and straining ties. The bill's passage was seen as a sign of US support for Hong Kong's protesters, who are demanding greater autonomy. The move has raised concerns about the impact on trade talks between the US and China, which are nearing a phase one deal.

site_title: Tackling the climate crisis needs data, not dreams
summary: Business leaders must focus on facts, not romantic ideas, when tackling climate change. Researchers from INSEAD and Sorbonne University Alliance discussed the importance of data in finding innovative solutions. They highlighted examples such as olive groves in Spain, ecological accounting, carbon sequestration, and the circular economy. Key findings include the need for updated accounting methods, the importance of biodiversity, and the potential for natural systems to adapt to climate change. Experts emphasized the need for a systemic view of biodiversity with costs and benefits, and the importance of shifting from a romantic to a scientific view in addressing climate change.

site_title: Labour of Love
summary: Missoni, an Italian family-owned fashion label, has opened its first flagship boutique in Asia at Singapore's Marina Bay Sands. The brand, known for its colorful chevron-patterned clothing, sold 41.2% of its stake to FSI Mid-Market Growth Equity Fund to expand profitability. Vice Chairman Michele Norsa aims to transform the brand into a global player, focusing on international retail expansion, particularly in the US and Asia. The Singapore store is the second Missoni store in the city and marks the brand's direct expansion in Asia.

site_title: La Dolce Vita
summary: Da Paolo, an Italian restaurant group, has opened a new 5000 sq ft restaurant in Dempsey, featuring a trattoria-cum-retail shop with homemade pasta, cold cuts, and desserts. The restaurant offers all-day dining, including breakfast items like spicy Italian meatballs, and lunch and dinner options like braised beef cheek pappardelle. It also serves vermouth-based cocktails and has a wood-fired oven for making sourdough and pizza. The new space is located at #01-13, Block 8, Dempsey Road, and can be contacted at 6261-3128.

site_title: Musical Wonderland
summary: The Analog Girl, a local electronic musician, has released an album's worth of new material that can only be experienced in person at ALICE, a tech space in one-north. The album is looped for two hours at various times of the day, featuring three tracks each, inspired by morning, noon, and evening. The music is available for viewing at the North and South lobby of ALICE, located at 29 Media Circle. The Analog Girl also has a new album slated for release in 2020. For more information, visit alice@mediapolis.com.sg or follow The Analog Girl on social media.

images.alt_text: ALICE is located at 29 Media Circle.

site_title: China Merchants breaks Reit-listing drought for HK
summary: Hong Kong is set to welcome its first Reit listing in five years with China Merchants Commercial Reit seeking to raise up to $400 million. The Reit plans to issue 750 million units priced between HK$3.42 and HK$4 each, with a market value of around $575 million. This is the first Reit listing in Hong Kong since Dalian Wanda raised $4 billion in 2014, and is seen as a significant boost to the city's IPO market, which has raised $21.8 billion this year.

site_title: Something to talk about
summary: Conversation starter games, such as deck cards or apps, aim to break awkward silences and promote meaningful connections. US Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez uses a deck in her staff meetings, while celebrities like Jennifer Aniston and musicians like Eric Hutchinson have also utilized these games. The games address a deeper issue: when conversation topics run out, what are you supposed to say. Experts believe these games foster emotional knowledge and self-expression, encouraging players to verbalize subconscious ideas and connect with others on a more human level.

site_title: European Parliament declares symbolic 'climate emergency' ahead of summit
summary: The European Parliament declared a "climate emergency" in a symbolic vote ahead of a UN summit in Spain, with 429 lawmakers in favor and 225 against. The move aims to pressure governments to take urgent action against global warming. The declaration is seen as a step towards making the EU's first "climate neutral" continent by 2050, with billions of euros to be invested in reducing emissions. However, scientists and activists warn that more drastic action is needed to meet the Paris Agreement target of limiting temperature rises to 1.5-2°C.

images.alt_text: The EU's incoming executive head, Ursula von der Leyen, who assumes office on Dec 1 is slated to speak on the first day of the Madrid summit. She wants to see billions of euros invested into making Europe the first "climate neutral" continent - adding no greenhouse gases beyond what can be absorbed - by 2050.

site_title: Yuletide Feasts
summary: Mandarin Orchard Singapore is offering luxurious Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve feasts at its restaurants, including Triple Three and Shisen Hanten. Triple Three's international buffet features Japanese-inspired dishes, including roasted turkey, foie gras, and seafood, while Shisen Hanten offers a Michelin-starred Chinese experience. The spreads are priced at S$108++ for lunch and S$148++ for dinner on Christmas Eve and S$148++ for lunch and dinner on Christmas Day.

site_title: China holds out carrot ahead of Taiwan election, but few are convinced
summary: China is offering better treatment to Taiwanese in China ahead of Taiwan's January 11 elections, urging the island to "come home". However, many Taiwanese see this as a thinly veiled threat. China denies interfering in the elections, but has historically tried to influence the result by supporting politicians with more positive views on China ties. The move is part of a larger effort to pressure Taiwan into reconsidering its democratic identity and potential independence from China.

site_title: Dyson to move HQ to St James Power Station
summary: Dyson, a British consumer electronics company, is moving its Singapore headquarters to the 110,000 square feet St James Power Station, a national monument, in 2021. The move aims to double the company's research and engineering footprint in the country, focusing on power electronics, energy storage, and AI. Dyson employs 1,200 people in Singapore, with 350 engineers and scientists. The expansion demonstrates the company's long-term commitment to Singapore and creates opportunities in technology areas. The project will be restored by landlord Mapletree Investments.

site_title: Cash offer of S$0.215 per share for POSH 'fair and reasonable': IFA
summary: Independent financial adviser PROVENANCE Capital advises PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) directors to accept a cash offer of S$0.215 per share, deemed "fair and reasonable". The offer, made by Quetzal Capital, represents a 97.2% premium over the last traded price and a 35.3% premium over the 12-month volume-weighted average price. The offeror has secured irrevocable undertakings for 77.6% of shares and is conditional on 90% acceptance by Dec 18.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish on negative note
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day with losses, falling 0.22% due to Donald Trump's decision to sign a bill supporting the city's protests, sparking anger in Beijing and fueling concerns about China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng index dropped to 26,893.73, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined.

site_title: Ditching MTP rule is about listening to the market
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGXRegco) has reversed its decision to keep the minimum trading price (MTP) rule, citing market feedback that highlighted its shortcomings as an "unintended consequence" for issuers and shareholders. The rule, implemented just a few years ago, aimed to deter market manipulation but instead created new problems. SGXRegco chief Tan Boon Gin acknowledged the MTP as a "blunt tool" and will scrap it, marking a reversal of a rule deemed necessary just a few years back.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 0.5% as HK bill fuels trade deal worries
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 0.5% to close at 3,200.61, amid concerns over US President Donald Trump's signing of the Hong Kong pro-democracy bill, fueling worries about a potential trade deal. The bill's passage has investors questioning China's next move in the ongoing trade standoff. Oil prices fell, impacting local oil and gas firms, and companies with exposure to the offshore and marine sector also saw share prices decline.

site_title: There's no reason workers can't be corporate owners
summary: US companies have no legal reason to be owned by their workers, but worker cooperatives are rare due to financing and incentive issues. Currently, corporate profits represent 6.6% of US GDP, while labor compensation is 43.2%, suggesting a 15% potential raise if profits flowed to workers. Cooperatives might reduce inequality, improve worker morale, and increase productivity. Despite mixed data on productivity, they could also benefit from more direct worker input and lower asset-stripping by short-term investors. A plan to promote worker-owned businesses has been introduced by US legislators, which includes low-interest loans and training support.

site_title: Banking on Baby
summary: Serene Lim, a content and communications professional, started her business Chalk and Chakras in October 2019 to sell child-centric yoga mats. The mats cater to kids' unique needs, being shorter, thicker, and featuring whimsical designs. Lim created the product after realizing that traditional yoga mats were unsuitable for her 6-year-old daughter due to their length and color. Her business addresses concerns about the toxicity of PVC in traditional yoga mats, making them a safer option for children.

site_title: Norway's US$1.1t wealth fund to deepen climate risk work
summary: Norway's US$1.1 trillion sovereign wealth fund plans to expand its climate risk assessment, including better company reporting and flood analysis for real estate assets. The fund aims to support global standards for climate reporting, having already cut coal exposure and implemented ethical guidelines. Since 2017, over a third of contacted companies have improved climate reporting, and the fund will analyze 4,000 company reports this year. Additionally, it will expand flood-risk analysis for its real estate assets. This move aims to better evaluate climate risks and opportunities in various industries.

site_title: 20 to 35% of banks' quarterly profit at risk in direct cyber attacks
summary: A recent stress test by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) found that a direct cyber attack on a bank could cost between 20-35% of its quarterly profits, with the cost increasing to 65% if no contingency measures are in place. Deposits could also decline by 1-5%. The MAS highlighted the need for banks to consider the systemic financial stability implications of cyber risks, citing theft and disruption-related attacks as the most significant threats.

site_title: Indian refinery workers protest over Modi's privatisation plans
summary: Thousands of Indian refinery workers protested against the planned privatisation of state-owned Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd (BPCL) and other state-run companies, fearing job losses and benefits. The protests, joined by unions from other state-run companies, aim to block the sale and urge the government to revoke the decision. The privatisation is seen as a way to plug India's widening fiscal gap, with the government aiming to raise $14.6 billion by March 2020. Moody's has reviewed BPCL's rating for possible downgrade due to the sale.

site_title: Europe: Stocks deflate at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trading on Thursday, with the FTSE 100 index down 0.5% and the DAX 30 index shedding 0.5%. The Paris CAC 40 lost 0.4% compared to Wednesday's closing levels. The decline was attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were in focus.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.41 points to 1,583.77. The decline was attributed to a higher number of losers (501) compared to gainers (305). Volume reached 2.1 billion lots worth RM1.4 billion.

site_title: Duty Free to return S$41.94m to shareholders if EGM approves
summary: Duty Free International plans to return S$41.94 million to shareholders through a cash distribution of S$0.035 per ordinary share, pending approval at an extraordinary general meeting (EGM). This would reduce the company's issued and paid-up share capital by S$41.94 million, improving shareholders' return on equity. The move aims to achieve a more efficient capital structure.

site_title: After US$13b levy ruling, future of India telecom sector hinges on government aid
summary: India's telecom sector is facing a crisis after the government's $13 billion ruling on telecom fees, with two major carriers, Vodafone Idea and Bharti Airtel, struggling to pay the debt. The government has deferred payments for two years, but analysts say the carriers still need significant financial support to survive. Vodafone Idea, the largest carrier, has booked a $7 billion quarterly loss and has written down the value of its stake in the company to zero. Analysts warn that if one carrier fails, it could lead to a monopoly, harming competition and access to government services.

site_title: Oil proxies among main laggards in market
summary: Oil prices fell for a second day after US inventories unexpectedly rose, leading to a decline in upstream oil and gas firms. Companies like Rex International and GSS Energy dropped 3.2% and 3.4%, respectively. The decline was attributed to a rise in oil prices, which was the opposite of market expectations.

site_title: Germany aims to shield tech firms from foreign takeovers
summary: Germany's economy ministry plans to tighten rules on non-EU takeovers of hi-tech firms, particularly those in robotics, AI, semi-conductors, biotechnology, and quantum technology. The proposed amendment would allow the government to review or block foreign purchases of stakes as low as 10% in "critical technology" companies, amid growing alarm about Chinese firms buying up German know-how. The move aims to shield German tech firms from foreign takeovers and protect sensitive information.

images.alt_text: In Germany, the 2016 takeover of industrial robotics Kuka by Chinese household goods maker Midea sparked an outcry with critics saying vital technologies were being sold off to Beijing.

site_title: Indonesia car sales should recover in 2020, association says
summary: Indonesia's car sales are expected to recover in 2020, but only by 5%, according to Gaikindo, an automotive industry association. Sales plummeted 12% in the first 10 months of 2019 due to economic slowdown and political campaigns. The association attributes the decline to consumers' focus on other issues and lower interest rates, which may lead to cheaper car loans. Indonesia's central bank has trimmed interest rates to counter the global economic slowdown, and the government targets 5.3% growth in 2020, despite a predicted 5.05% growth this year.

images.alt_text: Car sales in Indonesia are likely to recover next year, but not by much, after plunging this year during an economic slowdown, an industry association executive said on Thursday.

site_title: Thai central bank chief says worried about rapid baht gains
summary: Thailand's central bank governor, Veerathai Santiprabhob, expressed concern over the rapid strengthening of the baht, driven by the country's current account surplus. The baht has gained 7.7% against the US dollar this year, posing pressure on Thailand's trade-dependent economy. Santiprabhob warned the currency will remain volatile due to external uncertainty and high global liquidity, with Thai banks' net interest margins being high. The central bank may consider allowing non-banks to compete in the market to reduce these margins.

site_title: Keong Hong posts 38% fall in Q4 net profit to S$6m
summary: Keong Hong Holdings' net profit declined 37.9% to S$6 million in Q4, driven by impairment losses and increased administration expenses. Revenue fell 20.6% to S$37.9 million, mainly due to lower recognition of revenue from construction projects. The company's full-year net profit dropped 30.6% to S$16.3 million. Despite this, the construction sector showed a 2.9% improvement in the third quarter. Keong Hong recommended a final dividend of 1.5 cents, slightly lower than last year's.

site_title: Taiwan pushes anti-infiltration bill, opposition cries foul
summary: Taiwan's government is pushing for an anti-infiltration law to prevent China's interference in its politics, amid ongoing efforts to combat perceived Chinese influence. The Democratic Progressive Party is renewing its push for the legislation ahead of presidential and parliamentary elections on January 11. The main opposition party fears the law will "paint them red," while China claims Taiwan as its territory and seeks to bring it under Beijing's control by force if necessary. The legislation aims to establish legal means to prevent China's interference in Taiwan's politics.

site_title: Differentiating unicorns from asses
summary: The article discusses the recent decline of "unicorns" in the financial market, companies valued at $1 billion or more. Despite initial hype, companies like Uber, Lyft, and WeWork have seen their share prices plummet. Research suggests that the reported valuations of unicorns are often 51% above their true worth, with one in 10 being overvalued by at least 100%. The market is demanding profitability, and companies with sound business models and a clear pathway to profitability are more likely to succeed. The article concludes that the distinction between unicorns and "asses" is crucial in determining investment success.

site_title: Drugmakers cut prices 61% to get on coveted China list
summary: Drugmakers, including AstraZeneca and Roche Holding, have agreed to cut prices of innovative drugs in China by an average of 61% to get on the national insurance list, which covers over 2,700 medicines. The move aims to bring affordable treatments to China's growing middle class and meet consumer demand. The price cuts made imported drugs "the cheapest in the world," with some treatments dropping by over 85%. The move is seen as a strategic move to gain access to China's $132 billion pharmaceutical market.

site_title: Malaysian companies lead in corporate disclosure practices in Asia
summary: Malaysian companies lead in corporate disclosure practices in Asia, followed by India and Singapore, according to FTI Consulting's Asia Disclosure Index 2019. Malaysian companies achieved an average composite disclosure score of 8 out of 10, while Indian and Singaporean companies scored 7.3. Indian companies excelled in board composition and risk disclosure, while Hong Kong companies led in sustainability reporting. However, many companies, particularly in the food and beverage/agribusiness and real estate/construction sectors, scored low on disclosure practices. Only 23 companies, or 7%, achieved a full composite disclosure score.

site_title: North Korea launches two missiles in new test for Trump
summary: North Korea launched two short-range ballistic missiles from its east coast, traveling 380km and reaching 100km in height, according to Japanese and South Korean officials. The launches come as the country has threatened to end nuclear talks unless US President Donald Trump offers concessions by year end. The move is a significant escalation of North Korea's missile testing, which has resumed after a brief freeze following a 2017 intercontinental ballistic missile test. The launches have been described as "regrettable" by South Korea's Defence Ministry.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on Sept 10, 2019 shows a test firing of a "super-large multiple rocket launcher" at an undisclosed location in North Korea.On Thursday, North Korea fired what appeared to be two short-range ballistic missiles, a move that comes as it has threatened to walk away from sputtering nuclear talks unless President Donald Trump offers up concessions by year end.

site_title: Asean's share of global GDP may overtake eurozone's in 5 years
summary: HSBC predicts ASEAN's share of global GDP may surpass the eurozone's by 2030, reaching 5% in nominal terms and 8% in PPP terms, driven by investment, trade, and demographic growth. The region's openness to FDI and trade integration are key factors, with electronics being its largest industry. However, regional integration and slow reforms pose challenges, and policymakers must enact necessary reforms to achieve this growth, which could lead to increased employment opportunities and a stronger regional influence.

site_title: SGX seeks public feedback on scrapping minimum trading price
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is seeking public feedback on a proposal to scrap its minimum trading price (MTP) rule, which requires listed companies to maintain a minimum share price and market capitalization. The rule, introduced in 2016, aims to prevent market manipulation, but has been criticized for its unintended consequences, including difficulties for companies to exit the list. SGX RegCo chief executive Tan Boon Gin says the proposal would allow up to 54 companies to avoid delisting, and notes that the regulator has developed more effective tools to detect and prevent manipulation. A decision is expected by mid-2020.

site_title: Singapore and Australia property fund managers in shareholder spat
summary: Singaporean property fund manager Cromwell Property Group narrowly defeated ARA Asset Management's attempt to install Gary Weiss on its board, with 51.3% of shareholders voting against him. The move comes as ARA seeks to change Cromwell's business strategy and boost its stock value. ARA, which owns over 24% of Cromwell, claims the company's investments have been destructive to shareholder value, while Cromwell argues ARA is trying to exert control without paying for the privilege. ARA has vowed to continue its campaign despite the setback.

site_title: UK transport firm Go-Ahead sees lower annual financial performance from regional buses
summary: UK transport firm Go-Ahead Group lowered its annual financial performance expectations for its regional bus division due to rising driver and engineering costs. The company is working to integrate a new Manchester bus company and address underperforming areas. Like-for-like revenue rose 2.5% in the regional bus unit, while London and international buses saw 8% growth. Go-Ahead maintains unchanged expectations for its rail business, which has been impacted by the loss of franchises in London and Germany. The company faces cost pressures and a threat from the Labour Party's plan to nationalise the rail industry.

site_title: Facing US sanctions, Venezuela offers suppliers payment in yuan: sources
summary: Venezuela's government and oil company PDVSA have offered suppliers payment in yuan, a move aimed at circumventing US sanctions. The proposal, made to at least four companies, would allow Venezuela to use funds available in China without touching the US financial system. This comes as the country faces hyperinflation and US sanctions, which prohibit American companies from doing business with Venezuela's public sector. The process of opening accounts at Chinese banks is proving complicated, but analysts expect China to continue importing Venezuelan crude, despite some Chinese entities distancing themselves from the sanctioned country.

site_title: Saudi Aramco IPO's retail tranche oversubscribed says lead manager
summary: Saudi Aramco's retail tranche of its initial public offering (IPO) has been oversubscribed, with orders reaching 38.1 billion Saudi riyals ($13.8 billion). The IPO, valued at up to 96 billion riyals, aims to sell 3 billion shares, with retail investors accounting for at least one-third of the sale. The IPO is seen as a key part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's plans to diversify the Saudi economy, and is expected to be the world's biggest IPO if it tops China's Alibaba in 2014.

images.alt_text: The retail portion of Saudi Aramco's initial public offering (IPO) has been oversubscribed, with orders reaching 38.1 billion Saudi riyals (S$13.8 billion), lead manager Samba Capital said on Thursday.

site_title: Man City owners snap up Mumbai City as global empire grows
summary: Manchester City's parent company, City Football Group (CFG), has acquired a majority stake in Mumbai City FC in the Indian Super League, expanding its global football empire. CFG, which also owns Manchester City, Melbourne City, and others, will hold 65% of the shares, with existing shareholders holding the remaining 35%. The move aims to deliver transformative benefits to Mumbai City FC and Indian football, according to CFG chairman Khaldoon Al Mubarak. This acquisition marks CFG's entry into Indian football and further solidifies its position as a global football powerhouse.

site_title: Indian govt wants RBI to buy out stressed assets of shadow banks
summary: India's federal government wants the Reserve Bank of India to set up a fund to buy out stressed assets of the country's top 25 shadow lenders, aiming to revive the financial sector. The move comes after the sector's biggest firm, Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services, collapsed in 2018 amid fraud allegations. A bailout plan similar to the US Troubled Asset Relief Programme is proposed to address a deep slump and credit crunch in the economy. The plan seeks to restore credit flow into a weak economy.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks fall as Hong Kong tensions rekindle trade deal worries
summary: South Korean stocks fell 0.43% as investors worried about US-China trade deal prospects after President Trump signed a bill supporting Hong Kong protesters. The KOSPI dropped 9.25 points, marking the 16th straight session of selling. Foreigners sold S$95.82 million worth of shares, despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records. The US-China trade deal remains uncertain, with China's Foreign Ministry warning of unspecified countermeasures.

site_title: Utico rescue deal may fail as Hyflux lenders oppose nTan adviser fees: Debtwire
summary: Hyflux's restructuring agreement with Utico may fail due to opposition from the company's unsecured bank lenders over the adviser fees. The lenders are opposed to a success fee of up to S$25 million payable to Hyflux adviser nTan Corporate Advisory, which is part of a S$40 million cap on all advisory fees. This has raised concerns that there may be insufficient funds to cover remaining fees for creditors' advisers, making the deal "highly unlikely" to succeed.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) released its annual Financial Stability Review, highlighting risks in corporates exposed to trade, construction, and property sectors. Corporate debt in Singapore has built up amid loose financial conditions. Meanwhile, the IMF study found Singapore property prices decoupled from global yield chase, driven by macroprudential measures targeting foreign buyers and speculators. JustCo, a co-working space operator, plans to expand to Japan with a $74 million investment. Singapore shares dropped 0.5% due to trade deal worries, while the US and China prepare for a potential trade deal.

site_title: JustCo to expand to Japan with US$74m investment from Daito Trust
summary: JustCo, a Singapore-based co-working space operator, has secured a US$74 million investment from Daito Trust Construction Co. to expand into Japan. The joint venture will build and operate flexible workspaces in Tokyo, with plans to open 7-9 centers between 2020 and 2021. This marks JustCo's entry into Japan, bringing the total number of markets it operates in to eight. The partnership aims to capitalize on Japan's growing demand for flexible workspace, with JustCo already operating in eight cities across Asia.

site_title: 20-65% of banks' quarterly profit at risk from full-blown direct cyberattacks: MAS study
summary: Singapore banks face significant financial risk from direct cyberattacks, with 20-65% of quarterly profits at risk, according to a Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) study. A full-blown attack could cost banks 20-35% of quarterly profits, with deposits potentially declining by 1-5%. The MAS highlights the need for banks to consider systemic financial stability implications of cyber risks, citing theft and disruption-related attacks as major concerns.

site_title: US startup Robinhood withdraws application to become a bank
summary: Robinhood Markets Inc has withdrawn its application to become a bank, just months after starting the process. The decision underscores the challenges for startups trying to enter the highly regulated world of finance. Robinhood, a no-fee stock trading company, would have offered banking products if granted a charter. The company cited regulatory blowback from a failed product launch in 2018 as a factor in its decision. Robinhood will continue to focus on increasing financial system participation and challenging the industry to better serve everyone, without pursuing a bank charter.

site_title: Slovakia bans single-use plastics from 2021
summary: Slovakia has banned single-use plastics as of 2021, joining the European Union's efforts to reduce marine pollution. The new law makes it illegal to sell plastic plates, cups, cutlery, and other items, aiming to motivate people to separate waste and manufacturers to produce recyclable products. Experts expect a boom in the use of biodegradable packaging, citing the need for sustainable alternatives to reduce plastic waste that clogs the world's oceans and harms marine life.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down on concerns over US-China row
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Thursday due to profit-taking amid US-China trade deal uncertainty. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.12% to close at 23,409.14, snapping a four-day winning streak, following US President Donald Trump's decision to sign a bill supporting Hong Kong's rights. The broader Topix index declined 0.17%. The move cast doubts on the US-China trade deal, causing investors to sell stocks.

site_title: China's crackdown on cryptocurrencies claims first victims
summary: China's crackdown on cryptocurrencies has claimed its first victims, with at least five local exchanges halting operations or announcing they will no longer serve domestic users. Regulators issued warnings and notices as part of a cleanup of digital currency trading, citing excesses in the market. The crackdown, which began after President Xi Jinping declared support for blockchain technology, has led to a surge in investors transferring their money to safer places. Bitcoin prices have plummeted to their lowest level in six months, while the largest cryptocurrency rebounded with a 6% gain.

site_title: Citigroup president Jane Fraser to get US$12.5m after promotion
summary: Citigroup President Jane Fraser received a US$12.5 million bonus after her promotion to the No 2 job, with half in cash and half in stock. The award aims to enhance leadership continuity and management succession planning. Fraser's promotion makes her a likely candidate to become the first woman to lead a major US bank, following a congressional hearing on diversity in the industry. The bonus is part of her total compensation, which includes a previous US$9 million in 2018.

site_title: Investment income pushes up profit for Maybank
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank) reported a 2% increase in quarterly net profit to RM2 billion, driven by investment income, higher net interest income, and earned insurance premiums. Revenue rose 14.7% to RM13.83 billion, with a net gain in investment income of RM805.6 million. The bank expects its three home markets to be affected by moderate growth, with Singapore more exposed to the US-China trade war.

images.alt_text: Malayan Banking Bhd's (Maybank) quarterly net profit rose as it swung to a gain from investment income and turned in higher net interest income as well as earned insurance premiums, helping offset costs.

site_title: Cautious optimism pulls Australian, NZ shares off record peaks
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares retreated from record levels but closed firmer, driven by cautious optimism over a potential US-China trade deal. China's Foreign Ministry warned the US of unspecified countermeasures after President Trump signed pro-democracy legislation in Hong Kong. Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.2% higher, while New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.8% to a record high. Investors remain hopeful despite a looming increase in US tariffs on Chinese goods on December 15.

images.alt_text: Australian and New Zealand shares retreated from record levels touched earlier on Thursday, but closed firmer as investors hope Washington and Beijing can work around differences on Hong Kong and sign a highly anticipated trade deal.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher tracking US rallies, cheap yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, tracking US rallies and a cheap yen. The Nikkei 225 index edged up 0.08% to 23,456.61, while the Topix index inched up 0.03%. Analysts attribute the gains to solid US economic data, including revised third-quarter US growth to 2.1% and durable goods orders topping expectations. However, trade is subdued due to a US market holiday for Thanksgiving, and some investors are taking profits off the table.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon down 0.42% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.42% to 3,202.12 on Thursday, with 158 losers outnumbering 135 gainers. P5 Capital shares rose 12.5% after 103.4 million shares were traded. Other Asian stocks fell, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index rose 0.4%. The decline was partly attributed to concerns over an interim trade deal with the US, following US President Donald Trump's signing of a bill backing Hong Kong protesters.

site_title: Singapore resident employment rate edges up but income growth slows: MOM
summary: Singapore's resident employment rate rose to 80.8% in June, up from 80.3% last year, despite economic headwinds. Income growth slowed to 2.2% for full-time employed residents, lower than 4.4% last year. The unemployment rate for non-PMETs increased to 4.7%, attributed to cyclical effects from the US-China trade war. The ministry attributed the rise in employment rate for older workers to sustained efforts to increase their employability.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks start day on back foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day sharply lower on November 28, 2019, after US President Donald Trump signed a law backing the city's rights, despite warnings from China. The Hang Seng index fell 0.71% to 26,763.63, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index were barely moved. The move fueled concerns about ongoing trade talks, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Singapore shares dip at Thursday's open; STI down 0.02%
summary: Singapore stocks opened slightly weaker on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.02% to 3,214.93. Losers outnumbered gainers 53 to 50, with notable movers including Rex International, Singtel, and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust. Banking stocks were mixed, while US and European markets rose on better-than-expected economic data, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average hitting a new high.

site_title: Frasers Logistics, Frasers Commercial Trust planning to merge: sources
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust and Frasers Commercial Trust are planning to merge, creating a combined entity managing nearly 100 properties worth US$4 billion across Singapore, Australia, and Europe. The deal, if successful, would be the fourth among Singapore-listed Reits this year, following similar mergers by CapitaLand, OUE Commercial Reit, and Ascott Residence Trust. Shares of both Reits were halted pending an announcement, with Frasers Property, backed by Thailand's TCC Assets, as the main sponsor for both Reits.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slip, yen higher on Hong Kong bill concern
summary: Asian stocks slipped as US President Donald Trump signed a bill backing Hong Kong protesters, raising concerns about China's retaliation and the prospect of an interim trade deal. The yen rose and the yuan fell, while Hong Kong shares declined modestly. US futures fell, and the S&P 500 hit a fresh record high earlier in the day. Markets are cautious ahead of the Thanksgiving break, with analysts warning of a prolonged trade war and no substantial progress on trade with China.

site_title: MAS flags leverage risk in businesses tied to trade, properties
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has warned that corporate debt in Singapore, particularly in sectors tied to trade, properties, and construction, poses risks due to weak revenue growth and loose financial conditions. The MAS' annual Financial Stability Review found that corporate balance sheets are broadly resilient, but businesses may be vulnerable to debt issues. The review highlighted the property and commerce sectors as key contributors to corporate debt growth, with median interest coverage ratios indicating a risk of leverage catching businesses unawares.

site_title: Amazon's cloud unit readies more powerful data centre chip: sources
summary: Amazon's cloud computing unit has designed a new, more powerful data centre chip using technology from Arm Holdings. The chip is expected to be at least 20% faster than Amazon's first Arm-based chip, the Graviton, and will use newer Arm technology, including a "fabric" to connect with other chips. The new chip is designed to challenge Intel's dominance in the server processor market and could lessen Amazon's reliance on Intel and AMD. Analysts expect Amazon's cloud unit to generate $34.9 billion in sales in 2019.

site_title: US legislation on Hong Kong: What does it mean?
summary: US President Donald Trump has signed two bills backing Hong Kong protesters and threatening China with possible sanctions. The bills, passed by the Senate and House, put Hong Kong's autonomy under US law scrutiny and ban exports of crowd-control munitions to the Hong Kong police force. The move could upend relations between the US and Hong Kong and change the territory's status, potentially harming US businesses. Beijing has denounced the legislation as a gross interference and violation of international law, increasing tensions between Washington and Beijing.

site_title: URA launches 2 Canberra Drive residential sites for tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched two residential sites, Parcels A and B, at Canberra Drive for public tender. The sites can potentially yield 675 residential units and have 99-year leases. Parcel A spans 13,315.3 sq m and can yield 220 units, while Parcel B spans 27,566.1 sq m and can yield 455 units. The sites are near the Canberra MRT station and Sembawang Shopping Centre, with the tender closing on March 3, 2020.
