The loan deadline extension also waives all breaches and events of default under the project by a year. The move comes after Hydro Tasmania restricted Basslink's operation at full capacity in October due to a dispute over a 2015 cable outage. Basslink's loan of A$694.4 million matures in November, but the extension is not expected to have a material impact on the distribution per unit of KIT for the financial year ending December 31, 2019.

site_title: Hong Kong authorities appeal for calm as major highway reopens
summary: Hong Kong authorities have appealed for calm as the Cross-Harbour Tunnel reopened after nearly two weeks of protests. The Polytechnic University, where protesters had barricaded themselves, is still being searched for remaining protesters. Despite a landslide victory for pro-democracy candidates in local elections, fresh protests are planned for the weekend. The city's turmoil has drawn China's attention, with a crisis command center set up in Shenzhen to deal with the protests. Authorities hope the lull in clashes will translate into more calm, but demonstrators remain angry about perceived Chinese meddling in Hong Kong's freedoms.

images.alt_text: One of Hong Kong's main highway links, the Cross-Harbour Tunnel, reopened early on Wednesday as a lockdown of the nearby Polytechnic University appeared to be drawing to a close with teams still combing the campus for remaining protesters.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Keppel Infra Trust, Kimly, Jumbo, mm2 Asia, United Global, Biolidics
summary: OCBC priced A$500 million of senior floating-rate green notes, while Keppel Infrastructure Trust extended a loan for its undersea electricity cable. Kimly reported a 6% fall in net profit, and Jumbo Group saw a 5.9% rise in net profit. mm2 Asia launched a free-to-use video streaming service, and United Global completed the partial disposal of its unit. Biolidics inked a deal with Sysmex to develop a liquid biopsy cancer diagnostic test.

site_title: New Zealand central bank plans to ramp up oversight of banks
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank of New Zealand plans to increase oversight of banks and insurers ahead of a decision on raising bank capital requirements. The move comes after high-profile censures of Australian institutions and concerns over anti-money laundering law breaches. The bank has been reviewing institutions for shortcomings in governance and risk management, and will take a more intensive approach to financial supervision, including increasing staff and scrutinizing compliance. A decision on raising capital requirements is expected on December 5, with a proposed doubling of the top banks' capital ratio to 16%.

site_title: Xerox launches shareholder fight for control of HP
summary: Xerox is launching a shareholder fight for control of HP after the company rejected its $33 billion hostile takeover offer. Xerox CEO John Visentin claims the benefits of a combination between the two companies are self-evident and will create an industry leader. HP has rejected the offer, citing it undervalues the company and is clouded by uncertainty regarding Xerox's ability to raise the cash portion. The move sets up a proxy fight for control of HP, with Xerox making its case to shareholders.

images.alt_text: Xerox said on Tuesday it would take its hostile takeover offer for HP to shareholders after the computer and printer maker rejected the US$33 billion offer.

site_title: mm2 launching video streaming service in April 2020
summary: mm2 Asia is launching a free-to-use video streaming service called mPlay Asia in April 2020, targeting key Chinese-speaking markets in Singapore, Malaysia, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. The platform will generate revenue through advertising and branded content, featuring short-form content in Mandarin, live streaming, and video-on-demand viewing. mm2 plans to acquire more titles and leverage its regional production capabilities to cater to the growing demand for quality online Chinese content.

site_title: Next phase of Trump impeachment hearings set for Dec 4
summary: The House Judiciary Committee has scheduled its next phase of impeachment hearings for December 4, inviting President Donald Trump and his lawyer to attend. The hearings will address the constitutional basis of impeachment and whether Trump's alleged actions warrant articles of impeachment. Democrats have already presented evidence of Trump's wrongdoing, including pressuring Ukraine to launch investigations to help his 2020 reelection campaign. The committee will consider whether to draft articles of impeachment against the president, with Chairman Jerry Nadler stating the committee will fulfill its constitutional duties.

site_title: NYSE looks to allow capital raise through direct listings
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) has filed with the US Securities and Exchange Commission to allow companies to raise capital through direct listings, a hybrid model that differs from traditional initial public offerings (IPOs). This move comes after criticism from venture capital investors of the traditional IPO process, which can result in lower share prices and higher fees. Direct listings allow existing investors to monetize their shares and offer an opportunity to save on investment banking fees. The NYSE is the latest to adopt this model, following Spotify and Slack, which had successful market debuts but struggled with share prices.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday's open following Wall St rally; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% on Wednesday, closing at 3,211.12, following a Wall Street rally and investor hopes for a US-China trade agreement. Gainers outnumbered losers 60 to 42, with banking stocks and telecommunications companies making gains. The rally on Wall Street came amid optimism over US-China trade talks, with Chinese online e-commerce giant Alibaba surging 8% on its Hong Kong debut.

site_title: Trump cracks impeachment jokes at turkey pardoning
summary: President Donald Trump joked about the impeachment process during the annual White House turkey pardoning ceremony, saying two turkeys, Butter and Bread, had been subpoenaed to testify in Adam Schiff's basement. Trump granted Butter a pardon, ignoring questions about potential pardons for associates. He also made a dig at the media, suggesting they would like the story because turkeys are related to vultures. The ceremony came as Trump faced impeachment proceedings in the House of Representatives.

site_title: Investing in agents, tech for the future
summary: Huttons Asia, the fourth-largest property agency in Singapore, plans to hire more agents despite a decline in its agent strength. CEO Goh Kee Nguan emphasizes the importance of training and leveraging technology to add value to clients, as more buyers and sellers opt to transact on their own. The agency has increased spending on agent training and technology development, with a focus on developing an all-in-one platform to help agents manage and grow their businesses efficiently.

site_title: UK car body warns output will slump if Brexit leads to tariffs with EU
summary: A UK car body warns that British annual car production will drop by a third to 1 million by 2024 if Brexit leads to tariffs with the EU. This would result in lost output to other countries. The warning comes as the UK prepares to elect a new government, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson promising to pass his Brexit deal and the opposition Labour Party seeking to renegotiate terms and hold a referendum in 2020.

site_title: Funds worth US$37t failing to meet climate goals: analysis
summary: The world's largest investment funds, controlling $37 trillion in assets, are failing to align their portfolios with the Paris climate goals, according to a new analysis. Experts found $8.2 trillion of holdings in oil and gas, coal mining, and car manufacturing, putting them "significantly at odds" with the goal of limiting global warming to below 2°C. This is despite the funds controlling a fifth of the total value of world capital markets. The analysis highlights the need for greater scrutiny of investment funds and their environmental impact.

site_title: United Global completes partial disposal of unit
summary: United Global, a lubricant manufacturer and trader, has completed the partial disposal of its 40% stake in United Oil Company to Repsol Downstream Internacional for US$32.9 million. The deal marks the end of United Oil Company's status as a subsidiary, and it will be jointly controlled by United Global and Repsol.

site_title: Tesla and Ford trade challenges in macho truck world
summary: Tesla and Ford engaged in a public feud over their electric pickup trucks, with Tesla's CEO Elon Musk claiming his Cybertruck is stronger than the Ford F-150. Ford responded with a challenge, and Musk accepted. The exchange began after a video of the Cybertruck towing an F-150 went viral, with Musk boasting about the truck's capabilities. Meanwhile, Tesla has secured over 150,000 pre-orders for the Cybertruck, despite a recent embarrassing demonstration of its design flaws.

site_title: South Africa to create extra space for nuclear waste
summary: South Africa's nuclear power plant Koeberg will reach capacity for radioactive waste storage by 2020, prompting the power utility Eskom to create extra space. To address the issue, Eskom plans to transfer used fuel to dry storage casks, which have already been procured and are currently on site. The decision comes as environmental campaigners have warned against the nuclear project, citing concerns over safety and the lack of a long-term solution for high-level radioactive waste. The Koeberg plant is set to operate until 2044, despite initial plans to mothball it in 2024.

site_title: Straco Corp's Singapore Flyer suspends operations again after technical glitch
summary: The Singapore Flyer, operated by Straco Corp, has suspended operations again due to a technical issue involving a spoke cable. The incident occurred on November 19 and prompted the evacuation of all 39 customers. The ride is undergoing inspection, repairs, and rectification works with the assistance of a specialist professional engineer and the Building and Construction Authority. This is not the first time the Flyer has suffered a breakdown, with previous incidents including a fire in 2008 and a lightning strike in 2010. The cause of the current issue is unclear, and the ride's reopening is pending completion of the necessary works.

site_title: Latest bridge collapse shows Italy's failure to tackle aging infrastructure
summary: A highway viaduct in Italy collapsed after a landslide, highlighting the country's failure to address aging infrastructure. The government has made new pledges for safety, but similar promises have been made before. Italy's regions are using only a fifth of funds allocated for protection from hydro-geological risks due to bureaucratic red tape. A proposed oversight agency to monitor bridges and tunnels remains stalled. Experts say the country needs to monitor not just the infrastructure but also the surrounding area to prevent similar disasters.

site_title: Ex-Barclays banker taken aback by fees Qatar demanded, court hears
summary: A former senior Barclays banker, Roger Jenkins, testified in a London fraud trial that he was surprised by the 3.75% fee demanded by Qatar's negotiator, Dr Hussain Al-Abdullah, for participating in the bank's 11 billion pound fundraising in 2008. Jenkins stated he had expected a smaller fee, around 2-2.5%, and was taken aback by the magnitude of the ask. The trial revolves around whether Barclays lied to the market by not disclosing 322 million pounds paid to Qatar as "bogus" advisory services agreements.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges higher as dealers await trade agreement
summary: US stocks edged higher on Tuesday, reaching record highs, as investors awaited developments in the China-US trade talks. Chinese Vice Premier Liu He spoke with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, agreeing to maintain communication on remaining issues. US President Donald Trump also suggested progress in the talks, citing a "very important deal." Alibaba surged 7.7% on its Hong Kong debut, while Europe's main stock markets finished narrowly mixed.

site_title: Agorae bags top honours at E50 Awards 2019
summary: Agorae Pte Ltd, the holding entity for the Teledirect group of companies, took home the top honours at the Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards 2019, beating out Soilbuild Group and Valency International Trading. The awards recognize the 50 most enterprising, privately-held local companies in Singapore for their accomplishments, innovation, and sustainable business models. Agorae was recognized for its highly scalable and profitable fintech business, enabling cross-border transactions at cheaper, guaranteed exchange rates.

images.alt_text: The top three winners are (centre) Agorae Pte Ltd (represented by its CEO Laurent Junique), (left) Soilbuild (represented by director Lim Han Qin) and Valency International Trading (its chairman Praveen Kumar Jain).
Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, the evening's guest of honour, with the award winners at the Enterprise 50 Awards 2019 gala event on Tuesday.

site_title: Europe: Positive trade sentiment nudges stocks higher
summary: European stocks rose for the third consecutive session, driven by hopes of a US-China trade truce and positive earnings reports from companies such as Vifor Pharma and CRH. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.1% as major US stock indexes hit record highs. The US and China discussed phase one trade agreement issues and agreed to maintain communication on remaining issues. The market's optimism was fueled by a better-than-expected third-quarter earnings report and the ongoing negotiations between the two countries.

site_title: Canada's biggest rail strike in a decade ends, backlogs could nag shippers
summary: Canada's eight-day railroad strike, the country's longest in a decade, has ended with Canadian National Railway reaching a tentative agreement with workers. The deal must still be ratified by union members within eight weeks. Industry groups celebrated the end of the strike, which had cost them sales and raised expenses, and CN shares rose 2% following the news. Thousands of unionized workers began returning to their jobs, with operations expected to be normal by Wednesday.

site_title: Tunisia's state airline to axe 400 jobs in cost-cutting plan
summary: Tunisair, Tunisia's state airline, plans to lay off 400 full-time employees in 2020 as part of a cost-cutting plan to ease financial difficulties. The airline, which operates 27 aircraft, has struggled with flight delays, declining services, and a lack of spare parts due to a bloated workforce of 8,000. The layoffs were approved by the government, which aims to curb losses incurred by large state-owned companies, which totaled about US$2 billion last year. The move is part of broader reforms to reduce financial burdens on the airline.

images.alt_text: Tunisair plans to lay off 400 of its full-time employees in 2020 as part of plans to ease financial difficulties at the state-owned Tunisian airline, its chief executive said on Tuesday.

site_title: Oil gains, bolstered again by US-China trade talks
summary: US and Chinese officials discussed trade talks, bolstering oil prices. Brent crude futures rose 62 cents to $64.27 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude rose 40 cents to $58.41 a barrel. The US and China are close to agreeing on the first phase of a trade deal, according to US President Donald Trump. Oil prices gained support from predictions of a weekly draw on US crude stockpiles and discussions of a potential easing in the trade war. Opec's upcoming meeting on December 5 will also impact oil prices.

site_title: India must clean up or clear out dodgy brokers
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi) has banned Karvy Stock Broking Ltd, a middleman for nearly 250,000 clients, from taking on new customers due to allegations of misusing investor funds. The regulator claims the broker diverted up to $150 million to its real-estate business. This move is part of a broader effort to clean up India's financial system, which has seen over $200 billion in bad loans emerge since banks were forced to disclose their assets. Sebi must now target other brokers suspected of similar practices to restore market integrity.

site_title: FAA says it will be the sole issuer of new Boeing 737 Max airworthiness certificates
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has notified Boeing that it will be the sole issuer of airworthiness certificates for all new 737 Max aircraft, a role previously shared with the aircraft maker. The agency has also reiterated that it has not completed its review of the aircraft design changes and associated pilot training.

images.alt_text: The Federal Aviation Agency said on Tuesday that it notified Boeing that the agency will be the only issuer of airworthiness certificates for all new 737 Max aircraft, a role that it had shared with the aircraft maker in the past.

site_title: Obscure private credit has some investors on edge
summary: Private equity firms are increasingly using unitranches, a type of loan that combines senior and junior debt, to finance larger buyouts. The demand for unitranches has surged, reaching a record $10.7 billion in the third quarter, as borrowers bypass conventional financing sources for speed and simplicity. However, analysts and investors warn that the debt may be riskier than it appears, particularly in the face of a potential economic downturn and increase in restructurings. The complexity of the debt and the lack of testing in distressed scenarios have raised concerns among investors, who are seeking more compensation for the underlying risk.

site_title: Showa Denko considering deal for stake in Hitachi Chemical
summary: Showa Denko, Japan's third-largest diversified chemicals maker, is considering buying a stake in Hitachi Chemical Co. Hitachi Chemical shares surged 18% after the deal was reported, with the Nikkei newspaper stating a potential sale of around 900 billion yen (S$11.2 billion). The acquisition would boost Showa Denko's revenue from advanced automotive batteries and functional materials, and would be its largest yet. If successful, the deal would follow recent merger announcements, including Asahi Kasei Corp.'s acquisition of Veloxis Pharmaceuticals A/S for US$1.3 billion.

site_title: Australia's central bank does not expect to take QE plunge
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank Governor Philip Lowe stated he does not expect to implement quantitative easing (QE) in the near future. The central bank has already cut interest rates three times to a record low of 0.75% and is monitoring the economy's performance. Lowe set a high bar for QE, considering it only if the cash rate reaches 0.25% and the economy fails to meet its medium-term targets on full employment and inflation. He emphasized that QE would involve buying government bonds and may have positive effects, but also potential side effects, including reliance on monetary policy.

site_title: Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier to prioritise UK trade deal post-Brexit: FT
summary: EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier plans to prioritize a post-Brexit trade deal with the UK, according to a meeting in Strasbourg. This comes after the UK's departure from the EU on January 31, 2020. Barnier's focus on a UK trade deal may help alleviate concerns about economic disruption. However, no specific details on the proposed deal have been released, and its implications for the UK and EU economies remain uncertain.

images.alt_text: The European Union's Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier, has told EU politicians that he will make Britain's new trade deal with the EU a priority after Brexit, the Financial Times reported, citing people briefed on a closed-door meeting in Strasbourg on Tuesday.

site_title: Cashless is the new king for S-E Asia
summary: The adoption of digital payments in South-east Asia is rapidly increasing, with the region's digital payments expected to cross US$1 trillion by 2025. This accounts for nearly half of all transactions in the region. Vietnam leads the charge, with a 24% increase in mobile payment users from 37% in 2018 to 61% this year. Companies such as Grab are driving the shift towards a cashless future. The trend is expected to continue, with digital payments becoming the new norm in the region.

site_title: Westpac CEO resigns amid money-laundering scandal
summary: Westpac CEO Brian Hartzer has resigned amid a money-laundering scandal, following 23 million breaches of anti-money laundering laws. The Australian government had called for his resignation, and chairman Lindsay Maxsted will bring forward his retirement. Hartzer had previously downplayed the issue, but the sudden change of heart is seen as an abrupt response to the crisis. Chief financial officer Peter King will take over as acting CEO, effective December 2, as Westpac shares have fallen 1.3% in the past four days due to the scandal.

site_title: Snowstorm in central US snarls Thanksgiving travel plans
summary: A powerful snowstorm swept across Colorado and into the US Midwest, blocking roads and causing hundreds of flight cancellations. The storm dumped 30cm of snow in parts of Colorado and buffeted the Denver area with wind gusts of 72 kmh, leading to nearly 500 flight cancellations and over 350 delays at Denver International Airport. The storm is expected to push northeast, with treacherous conditions forcing the closure of several highways and advising drivers to stay off the roads. Many Thanksgiving travelers' plans are threatened, with 55 million expected to fly or drive for the holiday.

site_title: Google fires four employees active in labour organising
summary: Google has fired four employees who were actively involved in labor organizing at the company, citing "clear and repeated violations of our data security policies". The firings come amid escalating tensions between Google's management and a vocal group of workers who have protested the company's handling of sexual harassment, treatment of contract employees, and its work with the US Defense Department and Chinese government. The dismissals are seen as a crackdown on employee activism, following recent changes to Google's work culture and policies.

site_title: China's solar 'wobble' drags down global growth: BNEF
summary: China's solar sector slump has dragged down global growth, with BloombergNEF lowering its global solar installation forecast by 6% due to a delayed decision on subsidies that failed to materialize. China is expected to install 28 gigawatts of solar capacity this year, a 37% drop from last year. Despite this, solar exports from Chinese firms reached $13.2 billion from January to August, and other countries like Brazil, Vietnam, and some European nations are experiencing growth.

site_title: Hyundai Motor to invest US$1.55b in first Indonesia car plant
summary: Hyundai Motor has signed a preliminary deal to build its first car plant in Indonesia, investing US$1.55 billion until 2030. The plant, in Bekasi, east of Jakarta, will start production in late 2021 with an annual capacity of 150,000 vehicles, planned to grow to 250,000 vehicles per year. The facility aims to cater to Indonesia's largest car market and other Asean countries, avoiding import tariffs. This move follows Hyundai's struggles with a sales downturn in China, and aims to combat slowing global demand.

site_title: Maybank Kim Eng stays positive on aviation services firms with SATS as top pick
summary: Maybank Kim Eng maintains a positive outlook for Singapore's aviation services firms, with SATS as its top pick. The brokerage cites growth in passenger arrivals and cargo volumes, despite headwinds from weak visitor arrivals and the US-China trade war. Analysts expect cargo volumes to recover in the next few quarters, driven by biennial trade events in 2020, and recommend "buy" calls for SATS, SIA Engineering, and ST Engineering, with target prices of S$6.10, S$3.00, and S$4.50 respectively.

site_title: Three hours of exercise a week may lower depression risk
summary: A new study found that engaging in three hours of exercise per week can lower the risk of developing clinical depression, even for those with a genetic predisposition to the condition. The study showed that any type of physical activity, whether strenuous or light, can offset genetic risk, with greater benefits from more frequent exercise. The results suggest that regular physical activity can help mitigate the risk of depression, regardless of the intensity or type of exercise.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: OCBC Bank priced A$500 million of senior floating rate green notes due 2022, part of its US$30 billion global medium term note program. The notes, issued by OCBC's Sydney branch, are expected to be repo eligible by the Reserve Bank of Australia.

site_title: M-DAQ is riding the fintech high
summary: M-DAQ, a Singaporean fintech startup, has won the Digital Economy Award, recognizing it as a potential "next billion-dollar company." The 10-year-old company has overcome financial struggles, including CEO Richard Koh going without a salary for 12 months, and is now valued and poised for a public listing. M-DAQ's Aladdin platform allows customers to shop in their home currency on e-commerce platforms, a unique feature that sets it apart.

site_title: Enterprise 50's winning ways
summary: A fresh cohort of 50 local businesses was recognized at the E50 gala dinner for their accomplishments, innovation, and sustainable business models. This year's top-ranked businesses include Agorae, Soilbuild Group, and Valency International Trading. The E50 Awards, now in its 25th year, is jointly organized by KPMG and The Business Times and sponsored by OCBC Bank. This year also saw the introduction of the first-ever Digital Economy Award, given to fintech start-up M-DAQ for its decade-long contributions to the industry.

site_title: Slash emissions or miss 1.5 deg C goal: UN
summary: The UN Environment Programme's annual Emissions Gap report warns that nations must halve their 2018 pollution levels by 2030 to meet the 1.5-degree Celsius climate goal. Current emissions levels are rising, and without drastic cuts, the world will miss its chance to avert climate disaster. The report calls for rapid and transformational action, including a ban on new coal-fired power plants and significant investments in renewable energy and carbon pricing. A total of $1.6 trillion in annual energy-sector investment is estimated to be needed through 2050 to meet the goal.

images.alt_text: Emissions have risen on average 1.5 per cent annually over the last decade, hitting a record 55.3 billion tonnes of CO2 or equivalent greenhouse gases in 2018 - three years after the Paris treaty.

site_title: Olam peeling away property assets of US onion and garlic processing plant
summary: OLAM International is selling its US onion and garlic processing facility in California to Mesirow Financial for $110.3 million as part of its six-year strategic plan. The deal includes a 25-year revenue sharing arrangement between the two firms, where they will share annual revenue from operating the assets. This move is part of OLAM's efforts to focus on its core business and optimize its assets.

site_title: Kimly's Q4 profit falls 6% on lower revenue, higher income tax
summary: Kimly, a Singapore-based coffeeshop operator, reported a 6% fall in net profit to S$5.4 million for Q4 2019 due to lower revenue (0.9% decline) and higher income tax expense. Gross profit also fell 2.7% to S$10.7 million. The company's revenue and gross profit margins declined in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Ease of e-shopping needs to be answered by responsibility
summary: E-commerce's convenience comes with significant real-world costs, including the exploitation of workers who rely on gig economy jobs for income. Delivery riders and drivers face grueling conditions, pressure to work long hours, and lack of benefits. The industry's reliance on self-employment and business models without employee protections exacerbates these issues. E-commerce also has a substantial environmental impact, with massive waste generation from packaging material and returned goods. To mitigate these problems, worker protections can be improved, e-commerce firms can adopt eco-friendly packaging, and consumers must engage in sustainable consumption, accepting greater responsibility for their purchasing power.

site_title: Watching out for the next high-tech solution in security
summary: Ademco Security Group, an Enterprise Transformation Award winner, has successfully leveraged technology to surpass competitors. 10 years ago, the company was seen as an outcast for adopting cloud and wireless systems in the workplace, with founder Toby Koh being mocked in the security industry. However, today, Ademco is recognized as a pioneer in the security sector, embracing cutting-edge technology and achieving widespread acceptance.

images.alt_text: Ademco has recently invested in two blockchain startups. "I'm a firm believer that blockchain is going to be the future of security in one form or another," group managing director Toby Koh predicts.

site_title: Values, vision form Soilbuild's foundation
summary: Soilbuild Group, a construction and real estate company, was founded on honesty and hard work by executive chairman Lim Chap Huat in 1976 with an initial investment of $25,000. The company has since grown to house three business verticals and has employed a strategy of innovation, technology, and diversification to weather several recessions. Lim Chap Huat emphasizes the importance of being sincere and doing honest work, and the company has secured several green loans and certifications for its sustainable projects. Despite challenges, Soilbuild Group continues to expand into emerging markets and diversify its businesses, with a focus on talent attraction and retention to ensure growth.

images.alt_text: Lim Chap Huat (right), executive chairman, and Lim Han Qin, director of Soilbuild Group. "Be sincere. Don't go around cutting corners. With hard work, with sincerity, I think eventually people should recognise it. Everything should fall in place when you are honest and you do honest work, " says the elder Mr Lim.

site_title: D-Team Engineering brings its 'A game'
summary: D-Team Engineering, a Singapore-based air-conditioning contractor, has secured 10 projects for the coming year, matching the number won in 2019. Despite a tough year, the company is exploring new clients and income streams, including the Australian student housing market and community institutions. D-Team is also looking to expand its services to include maintenance and electrical works, aiming for recurring income from full-service maintenance packages. The company's revenue is expected to improve to S$20 million-S$25 million for the next financial year, driven by a pipeline of upcoming contracts and a growing presence in the public sector.

site_title: Godfather horse-head mansion enters bankruptcy protection programme
summary: A US$125 million mansion in Beverly Hills, featured in The Godfather movie, has entered bankruptcy protection. The Beverly House, built in 1927, has $75 million in liabilities and was purchased by William Randolph Hearst in 1946. A hearing is scheduled to determine if a receiver should be appointed to manage the property, which includes 19 bedrooms and 29 bathrooms, after a dispute with private lenders who claim they were manipulated into a loan agreement. The lawsuit may be put on hold due to the bankruptcy filing.

site_title: Famed Tokyo sushi restaurant Jiro left dreaming of Michelin stars
summary: Tokyo's renowned sushi restaurant Jiro, famous for its Michelin-starred dishes and former US President Barack Obama's dining experience, has been excluded from the Michelin Guide Tokyo 2020 due to its policy of not accepting public reservations. The restaurant, run by chef Jiro Ono, only seats 10 guests at a time, making it inaccessible to the general public. This policy disqualifies it from receiving Michelin stars, despite its consistent three-star rating since 2007.

site_title: Energising enterprises for 2020 and beyond
summary: Analysts predict continued disruption and adversity in 2020, but companies can stay ahead by embracing the experience economy and relentless innovation. The Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards recognize local businesses for their excellence, innovation, and sustainable models. Winners like Agorae Pte Ltd, M-DAQ Pte Ltd, and Ademco (Far East) Pte Ltd demonstrate the importance of offering memorable and personalized customer experiences, turning innovation into a business-as-usual function, and adopting initiatives to stay relevant and scale globally. Companies must adapt to changing market dynamics and invest in staff knowledge and skills to thrive in the coming year.

site_title: S-Reits advance amid weaker market
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a mixed performance, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 12.78 points or 0.4% to 3,207.85. Despite a cautious tone, Reits advanced amid weaker market sentiment, with the iEdge S-Reit Index rising 14.4 points or 1% to 1,437.13. The US Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell expressed confidence in holding interest rates, supporting inflation.

site_title: Commodity trader Valency sees opportunity in volatility
summary: Valency International Trading's managing director, Praveen Kumar Jain, views volatility in commodity trading as an opportunity for profit. Founded in 2007, the company has grown to operate in 38 markets, with a presence in Asia, Africa, Europe, and the Americas. Jain believes that correctly pricing commodities can yield profits during periods of high volatility. Despite increased volatility, the company remains optimistic about its business, leveraging its global reach and expertise to capitalize on market fluctuations.

site_title: Hyflux inks S$400m rescue deal with utilities group Utico
summary: Hyflux, a Singaporean water treatment firm, has signed a rescue deal with Emirati utilities group Utico. Under the agreement, Utico will subscribe for S$300 million in new Hyflux shares, gaining a 95% stake, and grant Hyflux a working capital line of up to S$100 million. This deal comes three days before Hyflux was set to update the Singapore High Court on its progress. The rescue plan aims to provide Hyflux with the necessary funds to avoid insolvency.

site_title: Why London has banned Uber - again
summary: London has banned Uber for a second time, citing operational failures and engineering errors. The ban comes after Uber's technology allowed unregistered drivers to pick up passengers, resulting in at least 14,000 uninsured trips. Despite efforts to cooperate with regulators, Uber's focus on market share and cost-cutting has raised concerns about customer safety. The ban will not affect Uber's service during the appeal process, and the company has pledged to continue working with Transport for London.

site_title: Japan is surprise bright spot for India's Paytm
summary: Paytm, India's largest payments platform, has secured fresh funding from Ant Financial, SoftBank's Vision Fund, and others, valuing it at $16 billion. This comes as SoftBank's CEO Masayoshi Son plans to restructure Japan's top chat app, Line. Paytm's QR code technology has gained popularity in both India and Japan, with 350 million users in India and 20 million registered users in Japan's PayPay service. The funding and success of Paytm in Japan could prove lucrative for the Indian group, with potential for global expansion and growth.

site_title: Singapore IPO value jumps four times to US$2.2b in 2019
summary: Singapore's initial public offering (IPO) market raised a total of US$2.26 billion in proceeds from 11 deals in 2019, a fourfold increase from the previous year. Thailand's IPO market, led by the listing of Asset World Corp, raised US$2.63 billion and contributed 39% to regional funds. The Stock Exchange of Thailand was the biggest IPO market in South-east Asia, surpassing Singapore and Vietnam. Deloitte analysts attributed the success to Singapore investors' preference for stable, yield-based counters, while Thailand's stable economy and low interest rates contributed to its growth.

site_title: Jumbo full-year profit up 5.9% at S$11.7m
summary: Jumbo Group, a Singaporean seafood restaurant operator, reported a 5.9% increase in net profit to S$11.7 million for the full year ended September 30, despite a 0.1% decrease in revenue. The group's cost-control measures led to a 1.4% rise in gross profit. Revenue from Singapore operations rose by S$4 million, while China revenue declined by S$4.1 million. The company declared a final dividend of 0.7 Singapore cent per share, unchanged from last year.

site_title: SoftBank's Oyo projects losses in India, China until 2022: valuation report
summary: SoftBank-backed hotel chain Oyo Hotels and Homes reported a six-fold rise in losses in fiscal year 2019, with net losses reaching 23.85 billion rupees (S$455 million) in India. The company projects losses in India and China until 2022, with potential profits of US$45.2 million and US$1.65 billion in 2022 and 2024, respectively. Oyo's revenue from operations surged to 64.57 billion rupees, but operating expenses grew nearly five-fold. The company's major investor SoftBank, which has invested nearly US$1 billion in Oyo, reported its first quarterly loss in 14 years.

site_title: Oil prices slip on US-China deal agreement concerns
summary: Oil prices dropped on Tuesday due to concerns over the US-China trade deal, which could impact fuel demand. Brent crude futures fell 5 cents to $63.60, while West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 9 cents to $57.92. The uncertainty surrounding a potential trade agreement between the world's two largest oil users has led to a bearish outlook for the energy market.

site_title: Distilling a model of continuous improvement
summary: KH Roberts, a Singaporean flavour house, has completed its new factory on a greenfield plot, designed to meet food safety requirements and provide space for upgrades. The company has adopted international food safety management systems, including ISO 22000, ISO 9001, and GMP certificates. KH Roberts is now gearing up for automation, with plans to deploy automated guided vehicles (AGVs) and RFID technologies. The company is also exploring clean labels and natural ingredients, and is a resource partner under FoodInnovate, a multi-agency initiative to equip Singapore-based companies with knowledge and resources. KH Roberts is participating in the Scale-up SG programme, a two-and-a-half-year initiative to help high-growth local companies scale rapidly.

site_title: V3 Smart Technologies all set to grow global
summary: V3 Smart Technologies, a Singapore-based tech developer, aims to establish itself as a global brand. The company has made significant strides in India, its first focus market outside of Singapore, by adapting to the country's demanding customer base. V3 has expanded its presence to Malaysia, Vietnam, Indonesia, and the Philippines, and is now investing in user experience redesign and digital marketing. With a scalable business model and debt-free status, V3 is exploring options for growth, including an initial public offering (IPO) and strategic mergers or acquisitions, to build capacity and create a strong brand.

site_title: Over 20 more unicorns on S-E Asia horizon
summary: A growth equity firm, Asia Partners, predicts that over 20 unicorns will emerge in Southeast Asia over the next decade, with up to eight from fintech and specialty e-commerce sectors. At least half of these unicorns are expected to pursue initial public offerings (IPOs), generating an additional $400 billion of public equity value. The region's "golden age" of exponential growth has reached, with catalysts such as rising education levels and trade flows, mirroring China's tech industry growth a decade ago.

site_title: eBay to sell ticketing unit StubHub for US$4.05b
summary: eBay will sell its ticketing unit StubHub to Viagogo Ltd for $4.05 billion in cash, nearly a year after activist investors urged the e-commerce major to hive off some businesses. The deal comes after eBay faced intense competition from Amazon.com and Walmart Inc. and forecast its holiday quarter revenue below estimates. The sale is expected to close by the end of the first quarter of 2020, with eBay focusing on its core business and providing an update on its classified ad business next year.

site_title: New Fed reports fall short on risks
summary: The Federal Reserve's latest financial stability report provides a broadly positive assessment, with asset prices showing a mixed picture and household balance sheets remaining healthy. However, business borrowing, especially among riskier firms, is high, and banks' leverage to non-bank sectors is rising. The report also highlights concerns about corporate borrowing, hedge fund leverage, and the potential impact of increased reach for yield, volatility, or interest rates. Despite the report's strengths, it fails to offer prescriptions for addressing identified challenges and weaknesses, and the Fed's analyses could dig deeper into systemic risks.

site_title: Restoring the human touch in a digital world
summary: Agorae, a top-ranked company in the Enterprise 50 Awards 2019, has successfully navigated the digital economy by focusing on velocity, agility, and visibility. In a world where chatbots and algorithms often fail to provide complex solutions, Agorae's CEO, Laurent Junique, recognized the need for human interaction, leading the company to pivot and capitalize on this trend. As a result, Agorae remains relevant to digital economy clients, emphasizing the importance of human touch in the digital age.

site_title: Climate change is happening sooner rather than later at Pimco
summary: Pimco, a major bond giant, is reassessing its approach to climate change due to its impact on municipal bonds. Analysts now consider factors such as Wildland Urban Interface (WUI) risks, fire danger, and human ignition sources when evaluating local governments. This shift acknowledges that climate change poses a shorter-term risk to local governments, with some analysts predicting impacts within 3-5 years. Pimco is taking a more nuanced approach to climate risk, evaluating traditional metrics with a "different lens" and considering offsetting factors such as state and local government support.

site_title: Are money market rate spikes warning signs?
summary: Recent spikes in US and Hong Kong money market rates, including the US repo rate and HIBOR, have raised concerns about potential market dislocation. However, experts argue that these events are largely driven by temporary and structural factors, such as increased demand for liquidity and competition for deposits. The Federal Reserve's actions to address these issues, including expanding its repo operations, suggest that overall financial conditions are supportive. Despite some near-term volatility, the balance of risk is shifting towards a positive direction, and markets are likely to remain broadly supported, with growth continuing to slow but stabilize in mid to late 2020.

images.alt_text: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd's listing ceremony was held at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in HK, China, on Tuesday. It raised about US$11 billion in a long- awaited HK stock sale.

site_title: Strong winds, heavy snow to mar Thanksgiving travel plans for Americans
summary: Two powerful storms are expected to sweep across the western US, causing significant travel disruptions on Thanksgiving Day. Heavy snow is expected in Denver, with 2 inches of snow per hour, and blizzard-like conditions in the Pacific Northwest. Over 500 flights have been cancelled at Denver International Airport, and dozens of winter storm watches and warnings are in effect. Hazardous weather is also expected on the East Coast, with wind gusts up to 45 mph possible. The storms are expected to impact 55 million travellers, with many flights and road trips potentially disrupted.

site_title: Thinner interest margins, worsening assets, slowing loans weighing on Singapore banks
summary: Singapore banks are expected to continue facing compressed net interest margins, deteriorating asset quality, and slowing loan growth, according to Fitch Ratings. The rating agency notes that the earnings of DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank may have peaked in this cycle. Rising asset-quality risks, including downgraded corporate accounts, and moderate exposure to Hong Kong SME loans are expected to drag on earnings. Despite sound capital profiles and comfortable liquidity positions, the banks' credit costs are likely to increase in 2020.

site_title: Over 13% of China's banks are highly risky: central bank
summary: China's banking sector is showing signs of strain, with over 13% of 4,379 lenders deemed "high risk" by the central bank. The high-risk category includes 586 banks and financing firms, mostly smaller rural institutions. This increase from last year's 10% is attributed to the exclusion of consumer finance firms from the previous calculation. The high-risk banks pose a challenge to policymakers as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, adding to pressure on the government to implement economic stimulus measures. The People's Bank of China has urged a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus package to counter US tariffs.

site_title: Daikin Singapore buys building management systems firm BMS for S$12.9m
summary: Daikin Singapore has acquired local building management systems firm BMS for S$12.9 million, aiming to provide full solutions for energy-efficient tracking and optimization. The deal allows Daikin to tap BMS's expertise and client base, with plans to integrate offerings and expand services. Daikin Singapore expects growing demand from building owners, particularly in line with Singapore's sustainability push, and aims to grow sales by 50% in five years. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to expand services and fend off low-cost competitors from China.

site_title: Thailand sees latest stimulus stoking spending
summary: Thailand's latest stimulus package aims to boost spending by over $4.5 billion, aiming to sustain the economy amid global uncertainty caused by a weakened currency and the US-China trade war. Finance Minister Uttama Savanayana stated that the measures will have a positive impact for the rest of 2019 and 2020. The stimulus is part of efforts to combat an economic slowdown.

site_title: Alibaba shares surge 6.6% on HK debut
summary: Alibaba's Hong Kong listing surged 6.6% on its first trading day, raising at least $11 billion in the largest IPO in nearly a decade. The company, described as a vote of confidence in the embattled city, listed at HK$176, below its original ceiling of HK$188. Alibaba's CEO, Daniel Zhang, said the listing marks an important milestone and a "new starting point" for the company, which has been pushing to list in Hong Kong for years. The listing comes as a major boost to Hong Kong, which has been struggling with protests and economic recession.

images.alt_text: Chinese online retail giant Alibaba surged Tuesday as it drew back the curtain on a Hong Kong listing the firm described as a vote of confidence in the embattled city.

site_title: Fighting and fixing cyber threats at sea
summary: A new book, "Cyber Security Workbook for On Board Ship Use," has been published by BIMCO and International Chamber of Shipping to support ship crews in managing cyber security risks. The guide provides detailed checklists and step-by-step procedures for identifying and responding to cyber threats. The book aims to equip ship crews with practical skills to protect vulnerable onboard systems and detect, respond, and recover from cyber attacks. This resource is designed to help shipping organizations and their crews stay ahead of emerging cyber threats at sea.

site_title: Collective effort needed to ensure implementation of Paris treaty
summary: World leaders are gathering for the UN climate summit in Spain, amid a growing recognition of the urgent need for action on climate change. A report by the UN shows that the world is on track to produce more than twice the amount of coal, oil, and gas that can be burned without exceeding a 1.5°C temperature rise, threatening "runaway" climate change. The Paris treaty, signed four years ago, aims to keep global heating below 1.5°C, but critics argue it is not ambitious enough. Despite this, the treaty has kept the process "alive" and provides a framework for countries to toughen their response to climate change in the future.

site_title: Building a clear future
summary: Seiko Architectural Wall Systems, a Singapore-based firm, is poised for growth in the next decade, driven by automation and expansion into the overseas market. Managing Director Rodney Cheong, 50, attributes his long work hours to his commitment to delivering exceptional results and investing in his team. The company, founded by Cheong's family in 1978, is now seeking to increase productivity and output through automation and developing new products, including lift and slide doors. Cheong aims to achieve at least 50% of the company's revenue from overseas projects and is planning for a successor to take over the leadership role.

images.alt_text: Managing director Rodney Cheong: "We want to move away from being contractor to more of a manufacturing outfit. There is less business risk and higher profit margins."

site_title: China's house price growth to hit five-year low in 2020
summary: China's house prices are expected to grow just 3.1% in 2020, the lowest over a calendar year since 2015, according to a Reuters poll. Tightening policies continue to cool the market, but some easing is expected to prevent a sharp slowdown. Analysts predict a further moderation in the market, with nationwide property sales expected to contract by 3% in 2020. Despite this, some cities are expected to relax purchase restrictions, providing a floor for the sector.

images.alt_text: Latest official data showed growth in the prices of new homes remained steady in October.

site_title: OCBC looking from within for next CEO
summary: OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien has expressed a preference for internal candidates to succeed him when he steps down, but maintains that external candidates should not be excluded. Tsien, who is in his eighth year as CEO, has identified internal candidates such as COO Ching Wei Hong and CFO Darren Tan as potential successors. OCBC is also considering digital banking opportunities, including a potential virtual bank license, to expand in the South-east Asian market and compete with Chinese technology giants.

site_title: Tesco follows Amazon playbook with paid loyalty card
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest retailer, has introduced Clubcard Plus, a subscription-based loyalty plan with a monthly fee of £7.99, offering customers 10% off in-store purchases and exclusive deals. The move follows Amazon's playbook, aiming to boost sales in a market dominated by online shopping and discounters. The rollout has faced some backlash, including a social media campaign by former Spice Girl Mel B, but analysts believe the subscription model can foster customer loyalty and encourage positive brand perception.

site_title: Winning by a hair's breadth
summary: Akribis Systems, a precision motion control specialist, has achieved significant growth and international expansion. Founded by Leow Yong Peng and his co-founders, the company provides direct drive motors and precision systems for industries such as biomedical equipment and semiconductor manufacturing. Akribis has established a strong presence in 10 markets, including China, Germany, and the US, with a focus on customizing motion control solutions for big players. The company aims to become a Singaporean multinational corporation and is investing in R&D and automation to improve product quality and scalability. Despite the economic downturn in 2019, Akribis has continued to grow, with plans to expand its product line and increase production capacity.

site_title: US dollar gives up gains as trade deal optimism fades
summary: The US dollar gave up its gains against the Japanese yen as optimism over a US-China trade agreement faded. The euro remained steady against the US dollar, despite rising consumer spending in Germany. Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He, US Trade representative Robert Lighthizer, and US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin discussed phase one of the trade agreement, but no major progress was made. The US dollar was trading at 108.98 yen, down from a two-week high, while the euro remained flat at US$1.1017.

site_title: Jessye Norman honoured with starry Met Opera memorial
summary: A star-studded memorial was held at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York to honor the life and legacy of soprano Jessye Norman, who died in September at 74. The event featured video clips of Norman's performances, tributes from friends and colleagues, and performances by dancers and singers, including Latonia Moore, Lise Davidsen, and Renée Fleming. Speakers recalled Norman's pathbreaking role as an African American soprano, her fight for justice, and her ability to "sing through" her experiences. The memorial marked a rare honor for a deceased artist at the Met, joining a select group of composers and singers who have been recognized in this way.

site_title: Singapore Oct factory output beats expectations with 4% growth
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 4% year-over-year in October, defying economists' expectations of a 1.4% decline. Excluding the biomedical manufacturing sector, output rose 0.2%. Analysts see this as a positive sign for fourth-quarter growth momentum. Key sectors driving growth include biomedical manufacturing, pharmaceuticals, and general manufacturing, with electronics emerging from decline. Economists predict manufacturing could emerge from recession earlier than expected, with some forecasting a 2.1% growth in industrial production in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Knowledge workers beware, future automation could take over your job
summary: A new study by Stanford University economist Michael Webb suggests that high-paying white-collar workers, including knowledge workers, may be more impacted by automation than previously thought. The study analyzed AI patents and job descriptions to identify jobs that could be automated. Market research analysts, despite being highly educated and paid well, are more likely to have overlap with AI patents, but they also emphasize the importance of human intuition and nuance in their work. The study's findings raise concerns about the impact of automation on high-paying white-collar jobs and potentially exacerbate wealth inequality.

site_title: 36 companies make it to SGX's nice list in time for Christmas
summary: 36 Singapore companies have made it to the SGX Fast Track list for its corporate governance and compliance standards. The list, launched in April 2018, recognizes companies with high corporate governance standards and good compliance track records. This year, 36 new companies joined the list, bringing the total to 95, and they will remain on it for two review cycles. Selection is based on internal and external criteria, including the Singapore Governance and Transparency Index. The list aims to reward good corporate governance and encourage companies to maintain high standards.

site_title: US consumer confidence slips
summary: US consumer confidence fell for a fourth consecutive month in November, reaching a reading of 125.5, down from 126.1 in October. The decline was attributed to concerns over current business conditions and employment prospects, but the index remains above levels that would support steady consumer spending. The 16-month trade war with China has contributed to the slide in consumer confidence, but the index remains relatively high.

site_title: High-tech housekeeping
summary: Chye Thiam Maintenance (CTM), a Singapore-based environmental services firm, leverages technology to improve its services delivery. The company uses autonomous cleaning robots to manage labor crunch in the cleaning services industry and has implemented a smart toilet system that reduces the need for on-site staff. CTM has also developed an innovation trial for the Autonomous Airside Scrubber (AAS) and has received the 2019 Enterprise 50 (E50) Award for its outstanding growth through innovation and corporate social responsibility efforts.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat after mixed retail earnings
summary: Wall Street opened flat on Tuesday after a record-high close the previous day, amid mixed retail earnings. The Dow Jones rose 0.05%, the S&P 500 gained 0.04%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.03%. The mixed results came ahead of consumer confidence data, with no significant impact on the markets.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose just 14.28 points, or 0.05 per cent, at the open to 28,080.75.

site_title: Govt and businesses 'should be more collaborative'
summary: Singapore Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for a collaborative relationship between the government and businesses to create a conducive business environment. He introduced "Progressive, Enabling and Pioneering" (PEP 2.0) - an evolution from the previous PEP 1.0, which aims for protective, efficient, and predictable regulation. The new approach encourages active conversation and co-creation to solve problems, rather than relying on one party to solve the other's challenges. This aims to generate a competitive advantage for Singapore by facilitating business growth through risk-managed and timely facilitation.

site_title: China trade deal close, sticking points remain - White House adviser
summary: The US and China are close to a trade agreement, according to White House adviser Kellyanne Conway, but three sticking points remain: forced technology transfers, intellectual property theft, and a $500 billion trade imbalance. Conway emphasized that these issues "make no sense" to the public.

site_title: Bernard Arnault just bought Tiffany. Who is he?
summary: Bernard Arnault, the founder, chairman, and largest shareholder of LVMH, has acquired Tiffany & Co in the largest-ever luxury deal. As one of the richest men in the world, worth $106.9 billion, Arnault is credited with revolutionizing the luxury industry. LVMH, under his leadership, owns 75 luxury brands, including Dior, Vuitton, and Hennessy, and has a market capitalization of over $200 billion. Arnault's success has earned him the nickname "the wolf in the cashmere coat" for his aggressive business tactics.

site_title: Doing well, quietly but surely
summary: Chye Thiam Maintenance, a Singapore-based environmental services firm, is thriving in the competitive cleaning industry despite challenges from manpower costs and falling tender prices. The company, which employs over 1,600 staff, has managed to retain most of its existing contracts and secure new ones, including contracts for Jewel Changi Airport and Gleneagles Hospital. Chye Thiam's success is attributed to its focus on technology and innovation, investing up to 5% of its budget in new equipment and training staff to handle the new technology. The company is also exploring international growth opportunities through the Scale-up SG program, aiming to expand abroad without relying on foreign manpower.

images.alt_text: There is still a "very imbalanced mindset between price and quality," says Mr Tan.
Sharil Falindi Ismail, an assistant manager at Chye Thiam Maintenance, buffing floor tiles to get Jewel Changi Airport ready for the public preview ahead of its official opening on April 17, 2019.

site_title: Enterprise transformation journey: changes, challenges, battles
summary: Three companies, Mao Sheng Quanji Construction, FotoHub Holdings, and Mr Bean International, successfully embarked on their enterprise transformation journeys. They faced challenges such as complacency, resistance to change, and fear of the unknown, but overcame them by prioritizing low-hanging fruits, retraining staff, and leveraging partnerships. The companies benefited from changes by expanding customer bases, improving efficiency, and staying competitive. Key to success was a clear vision, continuous innovation, and transformation, as well as government support. To embark on a similar journey, companies should engage with stakeholders, observe other industries, and allocate resources and time.

site_title: Merger mania hits US$70b as investors pile in
summary: US$70 billion worth of mergers and acquisitions were announced this week, with Charles Schwab's US$26 billion buyout of TD Ameritrade Holding leading the way. The deals, including luxury goods giant LVMH's purchase of Tiffany & Co and Swiss drugmaker Novartis AG's acquisition of Medicines Co, reflect economic optimism as companies take advantage of cheap financing. Global stocks reached record highs, with the MSCI World Index closing at an all-time high, driven by low inflation, low unemployment, and tentative signs of progress in US-China trade talks.

site_title: Inspiration to scale greater heights
summary: Singaporean companies recognized for their growth and excellence, including Leacov, D-Team Engineering, Ya Kun, Executive Ship Management, M-DAQ, Victory Shipping, MLION Corporation, Adam Khoo Learning Technologies Group, HSF Global, Mr Bean International, RMA Contracts, SMJ Furnishings, JS Creates, and Kaer, won the Enterprise 50 (E50) award for 2019. The award acknowledges the companies' efforts to innovate, expand, and grow in their respective industries. Winners plan to diversify and expand their services, explore new markets, and adopt digital transformation strategies to achieve continued success.

site_title: US new home sales fall in Oct; Sept revised higher
summary: US new home sales fell 0.7% in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 733,000 units, down from the revised 738,000 units in September. Despite a 31.6% year-over-year surge, sales were held down by decreases in the South and Northeast regions. The median new house price dropped 3.5% to $316,700, while sales were concentrated in the $200,000-$400,000 price range. The housing market remains supported by lower mortgage rates, with the 30-year fixed mortgage rate at 3.66%.

site_title: 'Green shoots' for Singapore as electronics start to recover
summary: Singapore's economy is showing signs of recovery, with electronics manufacturing cluster bottoming out in mid-2019, according to OCBC Bank's chief economist Selena Ling. Despite a muted International Monetary Fund outlook for global growth in 2020, Singapore's economy is expected to grow between 1-2% year-on-year, with a midpoint of 1.5%. However, the US-China trade war remains unresolved, and the bank's baseline is that a "phase one" deal will get signed, but with uncertainty over the economic slowdown's nature.

images.alt_text: For 2020, Ms Ling expects Singapore GDP growth to be between 1% and 2% year-on-year, with a midpoint of 1.5% y-o-y.

site_title: Compass points to job cuts as Europe economic slowdown bites
summary: Compass Group, the world's largest catering firm, warns of hundreds of job cuts in Europe amid economic slowdown. Deteriorating consumer and business confidence in Europe has hurt volumes and margins, with shares falling 8% due to the impact. Roles in Britain, France, Germany, Japan, and Brazil are at risk, according to CEO Dominic Blakemore. The company aims to stem costs to maintain profitability.

site_title: Transformation a key element for E50 winners
summary: Ademco Security Group has won the Enterprise Transformation Award at this year's Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards, recognizing its early adoption of technology and business model transformation. The company, which tapped into cloud and wireless systems a decade ago, has made significant productivity gains and sustainable growth. Other winners include Agorae Private Limited, which pivoted its business to ride the digital economy wave, and Soilbuild Group, which has diversified into industrial development and overseas markets. The E50 Awards also introduced a Digital Economy Award, given to M-DAQ Pte Ltd, a fintech start-up with a highly scalable business model.

site_title: Order for IndiGo to ground some Airbus planes may hit carrier's expansion
summary: IndiGo, one of the world's fastest-growing airlines, may be forced to ground some of its Airbus A320neo planes due to engine issues, preventing expansion. The Directorate General of Civil Aviation has ordered the carrier to ground an A320neo plane for every addition to its fleet unless the Pratt & Whitney engines are modified. This order may impede IndiGo's plans to add new routes or increase frequencies until the engine issues are resolved. The issue has arisen following a series of problems on the carrier's jets, including in-flight shutdowns.

site_title: Online sales assemble growth at Ikea unit
summary: Ikea's main retail unit, Ingka Group, reported a 24% net profit increase to 1.8 billion euros in its fiscal year that ended in August, with sales rising 5.3% to 39 billion euros. Online sales grew 50% over the previous year, accounting for 10% of total sales. Ingka plans to open three new stores in China by 2024, as part of its commitment to investing in the country.

site_title: Report shows high injury rate at Amazon warehouses
summary: A report by Reveal found that Amazon warehouses in the US have a serious injury rate nearly double the national average, with 9.6 injuries per 100 full-time workers in 2018. The investigation suggested Amazon's speed and efficiency push may lead employees to break safety rules, such as hoisting heavy items without proper precautions. The report also linked the introduction of robots in Amazon facilities to a significant increase in injuries. Amazon disputed the findings, stating it is "aggressive" in reporting workplace injuries and that the high rate may be due to under-recording across the industry.

site_title: London court allows public hearings between 1MDB and Abu Dhabi state fund
summary: A London court has allowed public hearings in a dispute between Malaysia's 1MDB and Abu Dhabi's state investment fund IPIC, backing Malaysia's arguments that private arbitration proceedings were unsatisfactory. The court granted a temporary injunction halting a second round of arbitration, allowing the UK's Commercial Court to scrutinize the case as part of an open and transparent process. The decision comes in a case where Malaysia seeks to recover $3.5 billion paid by 1MDB subsidiaries to IPIC, alleging a "conspiracy to defraud" by former Prime Minister Najib Razak.

site_title: Bank of England hits Citigroup with biggest fine to date
summary: The Bank of England fined Citigroup £43.9 million for failing to provide accurate regulatory returns between 2014 and 2018. The Prudential Regulation Authority found Citigroup's UK framework for reporting data was not designed or operating effectively, resulting in unreliable returns that did not accurately reflect the bank's capital or liquidity position. The US bank has settled the matter and cooperated fully with the PRA, with the fine being the largest imposed by the BoE to date.

site_title: Xerox prepares to take HP buyout bid hostile
summary: Xerox is planning to take its $33.5 billion buyout bid directly to HP Inc shareholders after HP rejected the offer, saying it undervalues the company. Xerox initially threatened to take the bid hostile if HP didn't agree to a friendly discussion and open its books. HP is open to exploring a bid for Xerox, but has expressed concerns about the offer. Xerox plans to engage with HP shareholders to solicit their support and urge the HP board to pursue the opportunity.

site_title: Audi to cut 9,500 jobs by 2025
summary: Audi plans to cut 9,500 jobs in Germany by 2025 as part of a restructuring plan to save billions by 2029. The job cuts will be achieved through early retirement programs and natural turnover, while hiring in areas like electromobility and digitization. The move aims to optimize production capacities and secure a strategic return corridor of 9-11% through a €6 billion investment. Audi's restructuring comes as the company transitions to an electric fleet and recovers from the dieselgate scandal.

site_title: Kimly Q4 net profit dips 6% on lower revenue, higher income tax
summary: Kimly, a CATALIST-listed coffeeshop operator, reported a 6% dip in Q4 net profit to S$5.4 million, driven by lower revenue and higher income tax expense. Revenue fell 0.9% to S$52.5 million, while gross profit decreased 2.7% to S$10.7 million. Despite this, the company proposed a final dividend of 0.84 Singapore cent per share, its highest since listing in 2017. Kimly aims to acquire more long-term asset ownership to boost revenue streams and reduce risks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares ended Tuesday with losses, despite Alibaba's surge on its trading debut. The Hang Seng index eased 0.29% to 26,913.92, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained unchanged. Investors await details on China-US trade talks, which have been a major concern for markets.

site_title: Biolidics ties up with Japan's Sysmex to develop cancer diagnostic test
summary: Biolidics, a cancer diagnostics company, has partnered with Japan-based Sysmex to develop a liquid biopsy cancer diagnostic test. The test, using a small blood sample, will be clinically validated by SAM Laboratory and marketed in Asia and outside of Japan. This collaboration is the latest in a research and development partnership between the two companies since 2016. The jointly-developed test aims to provide an accurate and efficient cancer diagnostic solution, expanding Biolidics' presence in the Asian market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher for third consecutive session
summary: Tokyo stocks rose for a third consecutive session, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.35% to close at 23,373.32, and the Topix index climbing 0.16% to 1,705.71. The gains were driven by revived hopes for US-China trade progress, adding to investor confidence.

site_title: China faces biggest state-firm offshore debt failure in 20 years
summary: China's Tewoo Group, a state-owned enterprise, is poised to become the biggest SOE to default in the US dollar bond market in 20 years. The company, which operates in various industries, has offered a debt restructuring plan that could result in deep losses for investors or lower returns on new bonds. This move signals a shift in Beijing's willingness to allow SOE failures, a departure from its typical support of state-owned companies. Tewoo Group's annual revenue was $66.6 billion and assets were worth $38.3 billion as of 2017.

site_title: Jumbo Group FY2019 net profit rises 6% to S$11.7m
summary: Jumbo Group reported a 6% increase in net profit to S$11.7 million for FY2019, despite a 0.1% decline in revenue to S$153.6 million. The group's cost-control measures led to a 1.4% rise in gross profit to S$97.7 million. Revenue from Singapore operations rose S$4 million, while a decrease in revenue from China outlets was offset by new restaurant openings. The company attributed a S$1.2 million loss to a renovation at the Jumbo Seafood Gallery outlet.

site_title: Agorae Pte Ltd emerges top in E50 Awards 2019
summary: Agorae Pte Ltd, the holding entity for Teledirect, won top honors at the 2019 Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards, beating out Soilbuild Group and Valency International Trading. The awards recognize the 50 most enterprising local businesses in Singapore, with Agorae's CEO, Laurent Junique, expressing confidence in expanding the business overseas. The event was attended by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat, who praised digital technology for transforming businesses and creating new opportunities.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 0.4% on Tuesday amid cautious sentiment
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.4% on Tuesday, weighed down by Singtel and Jardine counters, amid cautious sentiment over US-China trade talks. Despite US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments suggesting interest rate holds, markets struggled for direction, with investors awaiting details on trade progress. However, Singapore's manufacturing sector beat expectations with a 4% year-on-year growth in October factory output, lifting Reit counters and boosting overall market sentiment.

site_title: Australian police to probe 'Chinese spy' claims
summary: Australian police will investigate claims by self-styled Chinese spy Wang Liqiang, who defected with sensitive intelligence, including allegations China tried to recruit a Melbourne businessman to get him elected to parliament. Wang allegedly knew identities of China's senior military intelligence officers in Hong Kong and Taiwan, and was found dead in a motel room after rebuffing the offer. Prime Minister Scott Morrison described the allegations as "deeply disturbing and troubling", while China accused Wang of being an unemployed fraudster and fugitive. An AFP investigation is expected to be announced.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.48 points to 1,583.87. The index saw 3.4 billion lots traded worth RM4.2 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 529 to 352.

site_title: Corbyn campaign hit by fresh storm over anti-Semitism
summary: UK Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn is facing a fresh storm over anti-Semitism, with the UK's chief rabbi calling him unfit for high office. The controversy comes as Labour trails in the polls ahead of the Dec 12 election. Corbyn has denied any wrongdoing, calling anti-Semitism "vile and wrong" and pledging to protect places of worship. The timing is particularly damaging for Corbyn, who needs to boost his party's image. The row is likely to further erode support for Labour, already trailing Boris Johnson's Conservatives in the polls.

images.alt_text: Jeremy Corbyn is again embroiled in a row over anti-Semitism, after the UK's chief rabbi suggested the Labour leader is unfit for high office and said a "new poison - sanctioned from the very top - has taken root" in his party.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Hyflux signed a S$400m rescue deal with Middle Eastern utility firm Utico. Singapore's factory output grew 4% in October, excluding the biomedical sector, while Daikin Singapore acquired a building management systems firm for S$12.9m. Thunes, a payments network, secured a remittance licence from MAS, expanding its services. The Straits Times Index dropped 0.4% amid cautious sentiment, while other international news includes Vietnam's reaction to the US tariff announcement, China's slowing GDP growth, and the UK economy's contraction.

site_title: OCBC to issue A$500m of senior floating-rate green notes due 2022
summary: OCBC Bank priced A$500 million of senior floating-rate green notes due 2022, with interest rates set at the three-month Australian bank bill swap rate plus 63 basis points. The notes are expected to be repo eligible by the Reserve Bank of Australia and will be listed on the Singapore Exchange on Dec 6, 2019. Net proceeds will go towards financing or refinancing qualifying assets and projects. The issue was led by joint lead managers and bookrunners from Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, BNP Paribas, Commonwealth Bank, OCBC Bank, and Westpac Banking Corporation.

site_title: Daikin Singapore buys building management systems firm for S$12.9m
summary: Daikin Singapore has acquired BMS Engineering and Trading for S$12.9 million, integrating its offerings to provide full solutions for building owners to track and optimize energy efficiency. The acquisition aims to capitalize on Singapore's push towards sustainability and Daikin's growth in the mature market. Daikin Singapore plans to grow sales by 50% in five years and fend off low-cost competitors from China by leveraging its established networks and technology. The deal also sets the stage for further acquisitions in this area, with Daikin Singapore not ruling out further acquisitions.

site_title: Besieged Hong Kong university finds only one person in search
summary: A Hong Kong Polytechnic University team searching for protesters after a 10-day police siege found only one person, a woman older than 18, after six hours. The team, comprising counselors, medical staff, and security personnel, will continue the search on Wednesday. Chief Executive Carrie Lam urged the remaining protesters to leave the campus peacefully, without giving a concrete figure. Police have adopted a "humanity-oriented approach" and will not arrest those with medical needs immediately. The siege, which initially raised fears of a crackdown, has paralyzed parts of the city.

site_title: S'pore economy shows 'green shoots' as electronics bottoms out: OCBC
summary: Singapore's economy is showing signs of recovery, with the electronics manufacturing cluster bottoming out in mid-2019, according to OCBC Bank's chief economist Selena Ling. Despite the US-China trade war uncertainty, Ling expects 2020 GDP growth to be between 1-2% year-on-year, with a mid-point of 1.5%. The labour market is expected to soften, with a focus on professionals and managers who may be displaced by technological advancements. OCBC's growth forecast has been pushed up to 0.7% and 0.6% for Q4 and full-year 2019, respectively.

site_title: Greenhouse emissions hit new record, could bring 'destructive' effects
summary: Greenhouse gas emissions reached a record high in 2018, exceeding 55.3 gigatonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent. If left unchecked, temperatures could rise by 3.2°C, causing widespread and destructive climate impacts. However, the UN report suggests that limiting temperature rises to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels is still achievable, requiring annual emissions cuts of 7.6% between 2020-2030. Countries must set more ambitious emissions reduction targets by 2020 to meet the goal, with some nations, such as the US, falling short of their own targets.

site_title: 36 companies make debut on 2019's SGX Fast Track programme
summary: 36 companies debuted on the 2019 SGX Fast Track programme, a corporate governance incentive launched by the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) in April 2018. The programme rewards companies with good governance through prioritised clearance for corporate-action submissions. A total of 95 companies are now on the Fast Track, with 36 new entrants and 59 remaining since April last year. Companies will stay on the list for two review cycles, with new entrants reviewed in 2021 and existing entrants reviewed in 2020 and 2021.

site_title: JTC launches Woodlands Industrial Park site for tender
summary: JTC has launched a 0.77-hectare Woodlands Industrial Park site for tender under its 2019 Industrial Government Land Sales programme. The site has a 20-year tenure, is zoned B2 for industrial purposes, and has a 2.5 gross plot ratio. This is the third of four confirmed list sites for the second half of 2019. The tender will close on January 21, 2020.
