site_title: Thailand and Singapore emerge top performers in total funds raised via IPOs in South-east Asia: Deloitte
summary: Thailand and Singapore topped South-east Asia's IPO market in 2019, with Thailand raising US$2.63 billion and Singapore contributing US$2.64 billion. Thailand's Asset World Corp Public Company Limited listed for US$1.38 billion, marking the third consecutive year it raised over US$2 billion. Singapore's market saw a four-time increase in funds raised despite deferrals due to economic uncertainty.

site_title: Mergers and acquisitions hit US$70b in 24 hours with investors piling in
summary: In a record-breaking 24-hour period, US$70 billion in mergers and acquisitions were announced, fueled by low financing costs and economic optimism. Key deals include Charles Schwab's US$26 billion acquisition of TD Ameritrade, LVMH's US$9.7 billion purchase of Tiffany & Co, and Mitsubishi Corp's US$1.3 billion buyout of Veloxis Pharmaceuticals. The deals reflect a surge in industry consolidation and diversifying revenue, with investors seeking opportunities in a buoyant market.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets dip at open
summary: European stock markets dipped at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.1% to 7,388.07 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also declined 0.1% to 13,236.88 and 5,921.45 points, respectively. Market fluctuations were attributed to mining and healthcare sectors, while US-EU trade talks were also a focus.

site_title: Indonesia government aims to hand over labour law revision bill by January: minister
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati announced plans to finalize a draft of the country's labor law revision by the end of the year and submit a bill to parliament by January. The revised law aims to address rigid hiring and firing terms, making it easier for new workers to enter the labor force.

images.alt_text: Indonesia Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati said on Tuesday the government aims to finalise a draft to labour law revision this year and hand over a bill to parliament by January as it seeks to reform the labour market.

site_title: Demonstrators call on Thai government to delay pesticides ban
summary: About 2,000 demonstrators in Thailand marched to Government House on November 26, 2019, to demand a delay in the December 1 ban on three pesticides due to concerns over health risks and economic impact on farmers. The protesters, led by the Thai Agricultural Innovation Trade Association, asked Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha to assess scientific evidence and consider alternatives. The ban, spearheaded by Bhum Jai Thai, has sparked resistance from the US, which has also called for a delay. The Health Minister stated that there can be no compromise on health policies.

site_title: 'Godfather' horse-head mansion enters bankruptcy protection programme
summary: The "Godfather" mansion, a $125 million Beverly Hills estate, has entered bankruptcy protection after real-estate investor Leonard Ross filed for Chapter 11 protection. The mansion, built in 1927, has $75 million in liabilities and is the site of a separate lawsuit seeking a receiver. The property, which has been featured in the 1972 Francis Ford Coppola movie, includes 19 bedrooms, 29 bathrooms, and a 50-foot entry hall. Ross was embroiled in a dispute with private lenders over a mortgage, claiming they manipulated him into a loan agreement after a personal tragedy.

images.alt_text: A storied US$125 million mansion in Beverly Hills that was featured in "The Godfather" is in bankruptcy protection.

site_title: SolarGy, SolarPVExchange and Sunseap lend weight to UOB's solar financing plan
summary: UOB has partnered with three homegrown solar companies - SolarGy, SolarPVExchange, and Sunseap Group - to launch the U-Solar programme in Singapore, connecting businesses and individuals with solar power systems. The programme offers financing options and zero-interest instalment plans to help clients adopt solar energy. The partnership aims to make solar power more accessible and economically viable, despite initial concerns about high upfront investment. The collaboration is part of UOB's regional solar financing plan, which was previously launched in Malaysia and Indonesia.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE still positive on aviation services firms with SATS top pick
summary: Maybank Kim Eng maintains a positive outlook for Singapore's aviation services firms, with SATS as its top pick, despite weak visitor arrivals and trade war-related headwinds. The brokerage expects cargo volumes to rebound and recommends "buy" calls on SATS, Singapore Technologies Engineering, and SIA Engineering. SATS shares were trading at S$5.01, while SIA Engineering traded at S$2.84 and ST Engineering at S$4.20.

site_title: Investors bet on rising demand from China's ageing population
summary: Venus MedTech, a Chinese developer of cardiovascular devices, is set to list in Hong Kong with a US$331 million IPO. The company's listing is part of a boom of healthcare IPOs in the city, driven by investors betting on rising demand from China's ageing population. Since January, healthcare IPOs in Hong Kong have raised a record US$4.4 billion, with several other Chinese companies, including Alphamab Oncology and Pharmaron Beijing Co, also planning listings. The sector's new stocks have jumped 35% on average since their listings, with vaccine developer CanSino Biologics Inc seeing a 130% rally.

site_title: Tencent boosts Argentine fintech bet, leading US$150m round
summary: Tencent has led a $150 million Series C funding round for Argentine fintech company Ualá, joined by SoftBank Group Corp and other investors. The funding will be used to triple Ualá's team, expand its loans product, and develop new business units. This investment marks Tencent's increased bet on Ualá, which has issued 1.3 million prepaid cards since 2017. SoftBank's investment also marks its first venture in Argentina, with both companies to have a representative on Ualá's board of directors.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon down 0.26% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.26% to 3,212.20 on Tuesday, with 620.1 million securities changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 159 to 145, and Singtel, Mapletree Commercial Trust, and Golden Agri-Resources were among the most active index stocks. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while other Asian markets were mixed due to the ongoing China-US trade talks.

site_title: India must clean up or clear out dodgy brokers
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi) has banned Karvy Stock Broking Ltd, a middleman for nearly 250,000 clients, from taking on new customers due to allegations of misusing investor funds and securities. The regulator claims that Karvy may have diverted up to $150 million to its real-estate business. The move is part of a broader effort to clean up the country's financial system, which has seen over $200 billion in bad loans since banks were forced to open their attics to regulators four years ago.

site_title: How China CFA applicants keep beating finance's hardest exam
summary: Chinese applicants have consistently high pass rates on the Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) exam, with many completing the three-level program on their first try. Despite a significant language barrier, applicants from China have been flooding into the exams, overtaking interest from other regions. Many Chinese test-takers have a background in top universities in China and are willing to spend more than the recommended 300 hours studying. Pass rates in Asia are comparable to the global average, with some prep schools reporting pass rates of 70-80%. The CFA Institute attributes the trend to a growing demand for financial talent in the region.

site_title: ComfortDelGro adding buses with auto emergency braking to private fleet
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore transport operator, has added four Volvo buses with auto emergency braking to its private fleet. The buses, equipped with collision warning and automatic braking systems, will start operating on December 1 as part of unscheduled services. This move aims to enhance road safety and reduce the risk of accidents. The Volvo B8R buses are the first of their kind in Singapore, providing a safer transportation option for commuters.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks inch down as foreigners offload equities over MSCI rebalancing
summary: South Korean shares dropped 0.10% on Tuesday, closing at 2,121.35, as foreigners sold equities amid the MSCI index rebalancing, capping earlier gains from a potential US-China trade deal. The KOSPI has risen 3.93% this year, with 2.7% of gains coming in the last 30 trading sessions. Foreigners sold US$727.53 million worth of shares, marking the longest decline since January 2016. Analysts attribute the selloff to the MSCI rebalancing, rather than external risks, as Chinese stocks are set to increase in weight.

images.alt_text: The Seoul stock market's main KOSPI closed down 2.15 points, or 0.10 per cent, to 2,121.35.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Tuesday, driven by optimism over a potential partial trade agreement between China and the US. The Hang Seng index rose 0.71%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. Alibaba surged 6% on its debut, contributing to the market's rally.

site_title: Hyflux inks S$400m rescue deal with Utico
summary: Hyflux, a Singaporean water treatment firm, has entered into a restructuring agreement with Utico for a S$400 million rescue package. Utico will subscribe for new Hyflux shares, grant a working capital line, and pay S$250 million to unsecured creditors. Hyflux's preference shareholders and perpetual securities holders can choose from two options, with the first option providing an upfront cash payment and the second option offering a cash payout over two years with an additional payment if Utico's shares are listed within two years.

site_title: Showa Denko says considering deal for Hitachi Chemical stake
summary: Japan's Showa Denko is considering buying a stake in Hitachi Chemical, sending the target's shares soaring 18% in early Tokyo trading. The potential deal, valued at $8.2 billion, would boost Showa Denko's revenue from advanced automotive batteries and functional materials. This would be the largest acquisition for Showa Denko, and would help Hitachi Chemical shed non-core businesses to focus on manufacturing equipment and services.

site_title: Indonesia government wants more private sector investment in infrastructure: minister
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati announced plans to increase private sector investment in infrastructure over the next five years. The government will provide US$159 billion, while state-owned companies will contribute US$90 billion. The private sector is expected to invest US$180 billion, with state enterprises directed to divest infrastructure assets or make them tradable to open them to private sector participation. This move aims to address the estimated US$430 billion needed for infrastructure development.

site_title: Singapore fintech Osome raises US$3m to expand to UK, Hong Kong
summary: Singapore-based fintech startup Osome has raised US$3 million to expand to the UK and Hong Kong, following a US$2 million investment in December 2019. The company, which offers a cloud-based virtual assistant for entrepreneurs, aims to simplify corporate paperwork and reporting. With the fresh capital, Osome will launch in Hong Kong and the UK, and has already started testing these markets. The startup is also enrolled in the SG:D Spark Programme, which simplifies access to grants and allows Osome to pitch to reference customers, expected to significantly increase SME efficiency.

site_title: Japan and Australia to boost Asia M&A activity in 2020, UFP says
summary: Mergers and acquisitions in Asia are expected to increase in 2020 due to rising shareholder activism in Japan and a weakening Australian currency. In Japan, companies with high cash or cross-shareholdings will face increased scrutiny from activist investors, while Australian companies will attract foreign interest. Key themes for Asia in 2020 include corporate governance reforms in Japan, inbound acquisitions in Australia, and restructuring at China's state-run companies. Additionally, privatizations in Hong Kong and consolidation in Singapore's real estate investment trusts are also expected to continue.

site_title: Imax bets on Chinese blockbusters as Hollywood's appeal fades
summary: Imax Corp is shifting its focus from Hollywood blockbusters to Chinese-language films, aiming for half of its screened films to be local. This move comes as Hollywood's appeal fades in China, with the country's cinema market projected to surpass the US as the world's largest next year. Imax's mainland China ticket sales grew 30% this year, while box-office for Chinese local-language films reached a record $108 million. The company plans to add 286 theaters in mainland China by 2022, aiming to capitalize on the growing spending power of Chinese cinema-goers.

site_title: In US, plant-based diet easier than ever, even at Thanksgiving
summary: A shift in eating habits in the US is evident, with more Americans adopting a plant-based lifestyle. The term "plant-based" has become more palatable, and companies are embracing it, with fast food giants like Burger King and McDonald's introducing plant-based options. In 2019, 248 million plant-based burgers were sold, with 95% bought by meat-eaters. Experts believe this trend is here to stay, with benefits including improved health, reduced costs, and environmental advantages. While the US still has a long way to go in terms of adoption, the stigma surrounding plant-based diets is slowly fading away.

site_title: Government and businesses need to move towards Partnership 2.0: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for the government and businesses in Singapore to evolve into a Partnership 2.0, where both parties collaborate to create a conducive business environment. This approach, called PEP 2.0, involves progressive, enabling, and pioneering regulations that facilitate business growth, minimize compliance costs, and adopt a consistent logic in rule-making. Chan believes this collaborative approach is essential for Singapore to generate a competitive advantage and achieve a "risk-managed and timely facilitation of business growth."

images.alt_text: Sharon See

site_title: Tallgrass Energy CEO leaves amid Blackstone takeover proposal
summary: Tallgrass Energy LP CEO David Dehaemers resigned amid a proposed takeover by Blackstone Group Inc. Blackstone's offer included a 30% premium for management, sparking criticism from retail investors. Dehaemers defended the provision but ultimately stepped down. He will retire as a board member on December 31. Operations head Bill Moler, 53, will take over as CEO, receiving a $750,000 annual salary and up to $1.5 million in bonuses under the Blackstone take-private agreement.

site_title: Dell to explore sale of RSA Cybersecurity unit
summary: Dell Technologies is exploring the sale of its RSA Cybersecurity unit, a business that helps companies detect and respond to security risks, for at least $1 billion, including debt. The discussions are at an early stage and no guarantee of a sale exists. Dell acquired RSA in 2016 as part of its takeover of EMC Corp, which had purchased RSA for $2.1 billion in 2006. The unit faces stiff competition from rivals like Okta and Ping Identity.

site_title: Canada's biggest rail strike in a decade hits exports, sparks layoffs
summary: A strike at Canadian National Railway Co, the country's largest railroad, entered its seventh day, affecting grain shipments and causing layoffs at fertilizer producers and an auto shipment terminal. The Teamsters Canada union, representing 3,200 striking employees, remains at an impasse with the company over improved working conditions. Industry leaders and farmers have called on the government to intervene, with at least 35 vessels waiting to load grain shipments. The strike is estimated to have a significant impact on Canada's economy, with economists warning of potential losses to economic growth.

images.alt_text: A strike at Canadian National Railway Co, the country's largest railroad, entered a seventh day on Monday, sending further shocks through the economy with grain shipments scuttled and layoffs planned at fertilizer producers and an auto shipment terminal.

site_title: China, US to continue talks on 'phase one' trade deal: Xinhua
summary: US and Chinese top negotiators held phone talks, agreeing to keep in touch on "remaining issues" for a "phase one" trade deal. The deal, initially agreed upon by US President Donald Trump last month, remains unfinished. Chinese Vice Premier Liu He discussed core concerns and reached consensus with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. Global stocks were boosted by optimism over the potential partial deal, which could address major sticking points such as intellectual property protection.

images.alt_text: Chinese Vice Premier Liu He spoke on the phone Tuesday morning with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, the official Xinhua news agency reported.

site_title: Singapore banks' earnings may have peaked, to see rising credit costs: Fitch Ratings
summary: Singapore's Big Three banks, DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank, may have peaked in earnings due to rising credit costs and asset-quality risks, according to Fitch Ratings. Despite this, their capital and liquidity profiles remain sound, and they are likely to see higher credit costs in 2020, particularly in Hong Kong SME loans. The banks' net interest margins are expected to narrow further, and asset-quality stresses could drag on their earnings.

site_title: Alibaba shares surge more than 6% on Hong Kong debut
summary: Alibaba's Hong Kong shares surged more than 6% on their debut, reaching HK$187 after raising at least $11 billion. The company, already listed in the US, cited a vote of confidence in Hong Kong despite ongoing protests and economic challenges. Alibaba's listing comes after a delayed initial public offering due to market headwinds, with shares offering a 6.25% jump from the initial price of HK$176.

site_title: Singapore factory output surprises with 4% growth in October
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output unexpectedly grew 4% year-on-year in October, defying economists' expectations of a 1.4% decline. Biomedical manufacturing was the main driver of growth, with pharmaceuticals and medical technology output rising 29.6% and 13.1%, respectively. General manufacturing output rose 7.3%, driven by growth in food, beverages, and tobacco, while electronics output rebounded with a 0.4% gain. Despite this, the electronics cluster's output was still down 6.5% for the year. Economists are optimistic about the manufacturing recovery, with some predicting it may emerge from recession earlier than expected.

site_title: Going whole hog: US tells exporters to report pig carcass sales as China buying soars
summary: The US Department of Agriculture announced that exporters must report sales of hog carcasses, amid a surge in Chinese pork imports. China's pork imports have nearly doubled this year due to a fatal pig disease, driving up global meat markets. The USDA published a rule requiring exporters to report sales of pork and beef carcasses, effective immediately, to provide officials and traders with more insight into the sales. This move comes as China seeks to replace millions of pigs killed by African swine fever.

site_title: Japan is surprise bright spot for India's Paytm
summary: Paytm, India's largest payments company, has raised $1 billion in fresh funding from investors including SoftBank's Vision Fund and Alibaba's Ant Financial, valuing the firm at $16 billion. This comes as SoftBank plans to merge Yahoo Japan with messaging app operator Line, potentially benefiting Paytm's technology. Meanwhile, Japan's PayPay, a joint venture with SoftBank, has registered 20 million users in over a year. The investments and mergers could help Paytm expand globally and capitalize on its cost-effective digital payment infrastructure.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam admits vote revealed 'unhappiness' with government
summary: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam acknowledged public dissatisfaction with her government after a weekend poll showed pro-democracy candidates winning an overwhelming majority of seats in district councils. Lam pledged to "seriously reflect" on the result and improve governance, but sidestepped calls for direct popular elections and a probe into police brutality. The poll outcome has re-energized pro-democracy calls, with opponents dismissing Lam's proposal for community dialogue as "too little, too late."

site_title: Three hours of exercise a week may lower your depression risk
summary: A new study published in Depression and Anxiety found that engaging in at least 3 hours of exercise per week can lower the risk of developing clinical depression, regardless of genetic predisposition. The study of 8,000 participants found that any type of physical activity, from strenuous to gentle, helped offset genetic risk for depression. Those who exercised regularly had a 17% lower risk of depression for each additional 30 minutes of daily activity, and exercise "neutralized" the added risk for people born with a propensity for depression.

images.alt_text: Those of us who walk, dance, run, ease into a downward dog, or glide and churn on ellipticals at least a few times a week are much less likely to develop clinical depression than sedentary people, even if we inherited an elevated risk for the condition, according to a large-scale new study of exercise, genetics and mental health. The study found that almost any type of physical activity, whether strenuous or light, helped to offset people's genetic propensity for depression, though the benefits were greater when people exercised more often.

site_title: Firings spark dissent in Google ranks
summary: Google fired four employees who allegedly violated data security policies, prompting concerns of retaliation for worker organizing. The firings come amid a year of employee protests against the company's top-level decisions, including handling of sexual misconduct allegations and working with the US immigration and border patrol agency. A Medium account linked to a massive Google walkout last year claims the firings were an attempt to crush efforts to unionize staff, citing tightened data security policies as a cover for retaliation. Google has not commented on the matter.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday's open tracking Wall St rally; STI up 0.36%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.36% or 11.68 points to 3,232.31 at 9:02am on Tuesday, driven by Wall Street's overnight surge amid upbeat trade news. Gainers outnumbered losers 82 to 26, with banking stocks, such as DBS and UOB, and retail counters, including ComfortDelGro, leading the gains. The rally follows a 5-day streak of gains ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: OCBC ready for Chinese digital banking invasion, CEO says
summary: OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien says the bank is well-prepared to compete with Chinese technology giants entering Singapore's digital banking market, citing high regulatory costs and restrictions on unfair business practices. OCBC is exploring digital banking options, including joining consortia to apply for a wholesale license, and its insurance arm may also join a digital banking consortium to expand its customer base.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.78 points to 1,589.057. The market saw 77.2 million lots traded worth RM35.11 million, with gainers beating losers 118 to 75.

site_title: Oil climbs on US-China trade talks optimism
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as US-China trade talks optimism boosted market sentiment. Brent crude futures gained 26 cents to $63.65 a barrel and WTI crude settled up 24 cents to $58.01. Analysts expect prices to oscillate around $60 a barrel for the next two years. US national security adviser Robert O'Brien expressed hope for an initial trade deal by the end of the year, while Chinese experts cited a broad consensus on the first phase of the trade deal.

site_title: More space needed at sea, European wind industry says
summary: The European offshore wind industry requires an area equivalent to Ireland's size to install 230-450 GW of turbines by 2050 to meet EU's carbon neutrality target. Currently, there are 20 GW of offshore wind in Europe. WindEurope CEO Giles Dickson stated that the industry needs to increase production to achieve this goal, despite the European Commission setting the target. The EU's "Green Deal" aims to achieve climate neutrality by 2050, and the industry must work to meet this target.

images.alt_text: The European offshore wind industry needs an area equivalent to the size of Ireland to install enough turbines to reach carbon neutrality by 2050, a target for most EU members, a leading industry group said in a report.

site_title: IMF approves smaller US$61b credit line for Mexico
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has approved a two-year lending arrangement for Mexico worth $61 billion, replacing a previous flexible credit line of $74 billion. The new arrangement aims to bolster market confidence amid trade uncertainty, capital outflows, and increased risk premiums. The Mexican government plans to treat the arrangement as "precautionary" and may request further reductions in the credit line as external risks recede. The IMF has praised Mexico's efforts to set strong fiscal policies and maintain a tight monetary policy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on trade deal optimism
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by revived hopes for US-China trade progress, adding to investor confidence. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.62% and the Topix index climbed 0.54%. The rally follows a similar trend on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Retail mall foot traffic picks up ahead of Thanksgiving
summary: US retail mall foot traffic increased 2.5% for the four-week period leading up to Thanksgiving, according to the Thasos Mall REIT Foot Traffic Index. This growth reverses the slowdown in September and October, ahead of the key shopping season. The S&P 500 gained 2.9% over the same period, while the SPDR S&P Retail ETF fell 1.2%. The Thasos Index shows a 0.66 correlation with the ETF from August 2016 to March 2019.

site_title: China's BAIC willing to raise Daimler holding after 5% stake buy: sources
summary: BAIC Group, China's main joint venture partner with Daimler, is willing to increase its stake in the German luxury car manufacturer after acquiring a 5% holding in July. BAIC's intentions were confirmed by company officials, stating both parties are open to increasing stakes. Daimler welcomed BAIC as a long-term shareholder and investor, citing the benefits of such partnerships in strengthening the company's capitalization. The move comes after BAIC built its stake to surpass 5% through partnerships with HSBC, while Geely, Daimler's largest shareholder, expressed support for the company's strategies.

site_title: Biggest LNG producer targets 64% jump in capacity by 2027
summary: Qatar, the world's largest LNG supplier, plans to boost its output capacity by 64% by 2027, expanding to 126 million tonnes per year. The expansion will be fueled by newly discovered reserves in the North Field, allowing Qatar to produce 110 million tonnes annually by 2024. This increase is likely to intensify a global glut in LNG, potentially eroding Qatar's dominance in the market. The expansion will also enable Qatar to produce 6.7 million barrels of oil equivalent per day by 2027.

site_title: Australia: Westpac, oil prices drive stocks higher; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Monday, driven by optimism over a potential Sino-US trade deal and a rebound in Westpac Banking Corp's shares after its CEO resigned amid a money-laundering scandal. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,783.90. Oil prices lifted the energy sub-index, while heavyweights in the sector, including Woodside Petroleum and Oil Search, gained. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.6%.

site_title: OCBC chief favours internal candidates for bank's next CEO
summary: OCBC's CEO Samuel Tsien, 65, has expressed a preference for internal candidates to succeed him when he steps down, citing the bank's internal talent pool. He noted that internal candidates, such as COO Ching Wei Hong and CFO Darren Tan, have the potential to take over the bank. OCBC won't rule out external candidates but is currently focusing on its internal options. Tsien also mentioned the bank's interest in expanding in Indonesia and growing its insurance arm, which may impact future acquisition strategies.

site_title: SIIC to build 3.04b yuan waste treatment project in Shanghai
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings is building a waste treatment project in Shanghai's Baoshan district with an expected investment of 3.04 billion yuan. The project, called the "Baoshan Renewable Energy Utilization Center Project," will integrate dry waste incineration and wet waste disposal in one facility, treating 3,800 tonnes of waste per day. It is expected to be the first innocuous domestic waste treatment facility after Shanghai's mandatory waste sorting practices. The project is a joint venture between SIIC Yangtze Delta and Baowu Group Environmental Resources Technology.

site_title: Chinese woman sentenced to 8 months for trespass at Trump resort: report
summary: A Chinese woman, Zhang Yujing, 33, was sentenced to 8 months in prison for trespassing at President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida. Zhang, who was carrying multiple mobile phones and a malware-spiked thumb drive, was arrested in March 2019 and found guilty of trespassing and lying in September. The sentencing occurred on Monday, according to US media reports. Zhang's actions sparked fears of espionage, but no espionage charges were filed.

site_title: China sets up Hong Kong crisis centre in mainland, considers replacing chief liaison
summary: China has set up a crisis command centre in a mainland villa to manage the Hong Kong crisis, bypassing the formal Liaison Office in Hong Kong. The villa, Bauhinia Villa, is used to plot strategy and issue instructions, with top leaders receiving daily briefings from Beijing. Beijing is considering replacing the Liaison Office's director, Wang Zhimin, amid criticism of the office's handling of the crisis. The establishment of the crisis centre reflects China's growing dissatisfaction with the Liaison Office and its desire for greater control over Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Tightening control over efforts to manage the upheaval in Hong Kong, the Chinese leadership has set up a crisis command centre on the mainland side of the border and is considering replacing its official liaison to the restive semi-autonomous city, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: China's house price growth to hit five-year low in 2020
summary: China's house prices are forecast to grow 3.1% in 2020, the lowest over a calendar year since 2015, according to a Reuters poll. Tightening policies are expected to continue to cool the market, but some easing is anticipated to prevent a sharp slowdown. Analysts predict a further contraction in property sales, with nationwide sales expected to decline by 3% in 2020, and a year-on-year price growth of 3% by mid-2020. Local governments may relax purchase restrictions in smaller cities to support the sector.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, SIIC Environment, Frasers Hospitality, MindChamps, OCBC
summary: Olam International sold its California onion and garlic processing facility to Mesirow Financial for $110.3 million. SIIC Environment Holdings is building a waste treatment project in Shanghai with an expected investment of $590.1 million.

site_title: New Facebook app pays people to take part in surveys
summary: Facebook introduced a new app, "Viewpoints," that pays users for participating in surveys. The app, available only to US members, aims to gather insights to improve Facebook's products. Users can earn points by completing surveys, which can be redeemed for payments via PayPal. Personal information collected will be used for the app only and not sold to third parties. The app is part of Facebook's efforts to address criticism of the company's data use and is planned to expand to other countries in 2020.

site_title: Virtual goldmine: In-game goods fuel debate over digital ownership
summary: A growing number of gamers are spending thousands of dollars on virtual goods in online games, fuelling debate over digital ownership. Players can buy and sell in-game property, such as virtual real estate and outfits, with some making tens of thousands of dollars a month. However, most games do not offer legal ownership rights, instead providing a license to use the items under terms dictated by the game developers. As the video games market is expected to reach $300 billion by 2025, players and consumer rights groups are lobbying for greater rights over their virtual goods, with some court cases challenging the broad legal principle that digital items cannot be re-sold.

site_title: US interest rates 'well positioned' for growth: Federal Reserve's Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that US monetary policy is well-positioned to support a strong labor market and return inflation to the 2% objective. Despite global growth concerns and President Trump's trade wars, Powell noted a healthy labor market and wage gains supporting household spending. The Fed is set to hold its final policy meeting of the year, with no predicted rate cut until September 2020, according to futures markets. Powell expressed optimism, saying the glass is "more than half full," and that with the right policies, the economy can continue to grow.

site_title: Payments network Thunes to expand services with remittance licence from MAS
summary: Thunes, a cross-border payments startup, has obtained a remittance licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), allowing it to onboard corporates and expand its payment services. The licence enables Thunes to facilitate faster, more efficient, and cost-effective fund movements across 80+ countries and 60 currencies. The approval is conditional on fulfilling procedural formalities. Thunes' executive chairman, Peter de Caluwe, expressed delight at the approval, stating the company is poised to expand its services to better serve financial institutions and corporates.

site_title: Over 13% of China's banks are highly risky: central bank
summary: China's banking sector shows signs of strain, with over 13% of 4,379 lenders deemed "high risk" by the central bank, according to the 2019 China Financial Stability Report. Most high-risk banks are smaller rural institutions, and some have received poor ratings due to the slowing economy and government efforts to boost growth. The central bank has notified each bank of its rating and required some to increase capital and reduce bad loans. Despite progress in containing financial risks, the central bank warns that some threats require more time to eliminate, and policymakers will "fine-tune" their policies to balance economic growth and risk control.

images.alt_text: China's banking sector is showing signs of strain, with more than 13 per cent of 4,379 lenders now considered "high risk" by the central bank.

site_title: Greece completes partial IMF debt repayment: officials
summary: Greece has completed an early repayment of 2.7 billion euros in loans from the International Monetary Fund, reducing borrowing costs and improving market confidence. The move, valued at 70 million euros, was part of a 289-billion-euro EU-IMF bailout that ended in August 2018. Athens expects its economy to grow 2.8% in 2020 while respecting fiscal pledges to creditors.

site_title: Briton who drove truck in which 39 Vietnamese died admits plot
summary: A British man, Maurice Robinson, 25, admitted plotting to assist unlawful immigration after 39 Vietnamese migrants were found dead in a truck he was driving. Robinson pleaded guilty to assisting unlawful immigration and acquiring criminal property, but not to manslaughter charges. Thirty-one victims were men or boys, with eight women and three under 18. The case has highlighted the illicit human smuggling trade. Another suspect, Christopher Kennedy, and Eamon Harrison, 22, from Northern Ireland, have also been charged in connection with the deaths.

site_title: Westpac CEO folds as money-laundering scandal weighs
summary: Westpac Banking Corp's CEO Brian Hartzer has stepped down amid a money-laundering scandal, with chairman Lindsay Maxsted bringing forward his retirement. The bank faced 23 million breaches of anti-money laundering laws, including allowing payments between known child exploiters. The scandal has led to calls for Hartzer's resignation, with Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison and other stakeholders criticizing the bank for enabling the payments. Chief financial officer Peter King will take over as acting CEO.

site_title: Surbana Jurong to design 15,000 homes in India with Singapore public housing features
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Temasek-owned urban and infrastructure consultancy, has secured an affordable housing project in Gujarat, India. The project will see 15,000 homes designed with Singapore public housing features. This marks Surbana Jurong's expansion of affordable housing expertise beyond Singapore.

site_title: UK's Labour to launch race manifesto to tackle inequality
summary: The UK's Labour Party has unveiled a manifesto focused on tackling inequality, particularly for ethnic minority and faith-based communities. The party proposes teaching children about colonialism, injustice, and the British empire in schools, as well as creating an emancipation educational trust to ensure historical injustices are taught in the National Curriculum. This aims to reduce significant inequalities in employment, education, and representation in public life.

site_title: Texas, Nevada drop out of state AG group suing to block Sprint, T-Mobile merger
summary: Texas and Nevada dropped out of a lawsuit to block the US$26.5 billion merger between T-Mobile and Sprint, with Texas agreeing to a settlement in exchange for a commitment to 5G network deployment and 450 jobs. The remaining 13 Democratic state attorneys general and the District of Columbia will continue the case, which is set to begin on December 9 in Manhattan federal court. Despite the dropouts, the lawsuit remains a formidable challenge to the merger, with New York and California attorneys general expressing concerns about reduced competition and negative impacts on consumers and workers.

site_title: France vows tougher action as world protests abuse against women
summary: France has introduced new measures to combat the abuse and killing of women by their partners or ex-partners, following a surge in protests worldwide to mark the International Day for Eliminating Violence against Women. The measures aim to broaden the definition of violence, including harassment leading to suicide, and include changes to the law to make it easier for doctors to report potential victims of violence. The country has seen 117 women killed by their partners or ex-partners since the start of 2019, with 213,000 women experiencing physical or sexual violence.

site_title: UK PM Johnson's Conservatives see lead over Labour narrow to 7 points: ICM poll
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Conservative Party saw its lead over the opposition Labour Party narrow to 7 points, according to a recent ICM poll. The poll found that 41% of voters support the Conservatives, while 34% support Labour. The Liberal Democrats remained unchanged at 13%, and the Brexit Party decreased to 4%. The poll was conducted between November 22-25 and surveyed 2,004 people online.

site_title: ECB has made government borrowing 1 percentage point cheaper: Lane
summary: The European Central Bank's Asset Purchase Programme has made borrowing for Germany, France, Italy, and Spain one percentage point cheaper, according to ECB chief economist Philip Lane. The programme's effect on bond yields has been significant, with staff estimates suggesting a 100 basis point reduction in the euro area sovereign ten-year rate. This has led to a flatter bond curve, with the weighted average of the four largest euro zone economies experiencing a distinctly flatter curve. The programme's impact highlights the effectiveness of the ECB's monetary policy.

site_title: Olam to sell real estate assets of US onion, garlic processing plant for US$110.3m
summary: Olam International is selling its US onion and garlic processing facility's real estate assets to Mesirow Financial for $110.3 million. The transaction, expected to be completed in December, will allow Olam to redeploy capital into product innovation and value-added services. As part of the deal, Olam will also enter into a 25-year revenue sharing arrangement with Mesirow. The sale is part of Olam's "strategic plan" and is expected to result in a one-time pre-tax capital gain of approximately $97 million.

site_title: Victory Point at Balestier up for sale at S$14.7m guide price
summary: Victory Point, a two-storey conservation shophouse and six-storey rear apartment block in Singapore, is up for sale at S$14.7 million, translating to about S$1,390 psf. The property, held under a single title, has a land area of 3,463 sq ft and is zoned for commercial and residential use. The sale is expected to appeal to investors such as boutique real estate funds and high net worth individuals, given its prime location near major amenities and potential for strong capital value and rental upside.

images.alt_text: Situated in the Balestier Conservation Area, the freehold site has a land area of 3,463 sq ft and is zoned for commercial and residential use under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Draft Master Plan 2019.

site_title: Israel can help Singapore tackle food import vulnerability
summary: Israel can assist Singapore in boosting its food security by leveraging their existing business ties and Israel's expertise in agricultural innovation. SIFOOD, an investment fund, suggests that Israeli companies can help Singapore reduce its food import vulnerability. Strong links between the business communities of both countries provide a foundation for collaboration, and SIFOOD aims to facilitate partnerships between Israeli firms and Singaporean partners to tap into regional markets. This collaboration could help Singapore improve its food security and reduce its reliance on imports.

site_title: Trump impeachment report could drop next week: Democrat
summary: US impeachment investigators are set to present their report on presidential wrongdoing as early as next week, according to House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff. The report, which includes evidence of Trump's alleged misconduct, will be sent to the Judiciary Committee for consideration of drafting articles of impeachment. Schiff has stated that the evidence is "clear and hardly in dispute" and that the committees may call new witnesses to testify, despite the White House's refusal to comply with subpoenas.

site_title: Expo 2020 unlikely to stop Dubai real estate market's downward trajectory
summary: Dubai's real estate market is unlikely to improve despite Expo 2020, with residential property prices falling by over a quarter since 2014. The event may boost tourism and retail, but its impact on the market will be temporary. Dubai's economy, driven by foreign trade and tourism, has maintained growth despite a regional slowdown. A new real estate planning commission has been set up to regulate projects, but a complete pause in new residential projects may be needed for a market recovery, according to DAMAC, one of Dubai's largest property companies.

site_title: Alstom UK fined £15m for Tunis metro contract bribe
summary: Alstom UK, the UK arm of French rail firm Alstom, has been fined £15 million for bribing its way to win a tram contract in Tunisia between 2003 and 2006. The company was convicted of conspiracy to corrupt and paying an intermediary 2.4 million euros to secure the 80-million-euro contract. The intermediary, Nevco, was run by the brother-in-law of Tunisia's late president Zine El Abidine Ben Ali. The fine brings to an end a case involving cooperation from over 30 countries, with Alstom also ordered to pay £1.4 million in costs.

site_title: Europe: Transatlantic dealmaking sends shares back to four-year peak
summary: European shares reached a four-year peak, closing 1% higher on Monday, driven by transatlantic deals and hopes of a US-China trade deal. Luxury brands such as LVMH and Pandora rose, while Novartis's takeover of The Medicines boosted the Stoxx 600 index. Optimism was fueled by reports of a "phase one" trade deal and China's willingness to improve intellectual property protections.

site_title: Australian politician slams Westpac for giving 'free pass to paedophiles'
summary: Australian Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton criticized Westpac Banking Corp for giving "a free pass to paedophiles" after the corporate watchdog Austrac accused the bank of allowing 23 million transactions that violated anti-money laundering protocols. The alleged breaches involve known child exploiters and have resulted in A$7.5 billion in losses for Westpac's market value. Westpac has resisted calls for senior executives to be removed and has taken steps to improve financial crime monitoring, but the bank's chairman has warned that removing CEO Brian Hartzer would be destabilizing.

site_title: New Certis Corporate University to create future-ready workforce
summary: Certis Corporate University (CCU) was launched in Singapore with a $10m facility to create a future-ready workforce. Leveraging innovative learning technologies and new teaching approaches, CCU aims to equip 20,000 employees with critical and industry-relevant skillsets by 2022. The university focuses on leadership development, Industry 4.0 training, and digitalisation. Minister for Education Ong Ye Kung emphasized the importance of upgrading workers' skills to stay competitive in the industry, citing the need for a "future-ready" workforce in Singapore.

site_title: The Internet is to blame for economic inequality
summary: A new study by economists Edward E Leamer and J Rodrigo Fuentes finds that the Internet has contributed to economic inequality by creating a digital imperative that favors higher-income workers. Since 1980, workers with advanced degrees have increased their working hours by 9%, while those with bachelor's degrees have seen a 7% increase, with no change for those with high school diplomas. This shift has led to higher wages for the upper class, while lower wages and job losses for the lower class, exacerbating economic inequality.

site_title: Disney's Frozen sequel opens with US$127m haul
summary: Disney's Frozen 2 opened at the US box office with a haul of $127 million, surpassing the original's $67.4 million opening weekend. Despite being a rare musical sequel success, the film received a generally favorable reception from critics, holding a 75% fresh rating on Rotten Tomatoes. This marks a significant achievement, especially considering the studio's aggressive marketing and the success of the original film, which grossed over $1 billion worldwide.

site_title: US: Stocks jump to records on trade deal hopes, mergers
summary: US stocks surged to records on Monday as hopes for US-China trade progress and major corporate merger announcements boosted investor confidence. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Index all reached new highs, with the Dow gaining 0.7% to 28,066.47, and the S&P 500 rising 0.8% to 3,133.64. Strong deal announcements, including a Tiffany merger and a TD Ameritrade acquisition, also contributed to the market's rally.

site_title: Greenhouse gases hit new peak in 2018: report
summary: Greenhouse gases reached a new record in 2018, exceeding the average yearly increase of the last decade, according to the World Meteorological Organization. Carbon dioxide levels surged from 405.5 to 407.8 parts per million, with methane and nitrous oxide also experiencing record increases. The report warns that future generations will face increasingly severe climate change impacts, including rising temperatures, extreme weather, and sea level rise. Despite optimism over the Madrid climate summit, WMO Secretary-General Petteri Taalas emphasizes the need for accelerated action to address the issue.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Saving our stray dogs
summary: A Money FM podcast, "Workday Afternoon", discusses the issue of stray dogs and how listeners can contribute to their welfare. The podcast encourages listeners to consider adopting stray dogs, providing them with food and shelter, and supporting local animal welfare organizations. The conversation aims to raise awareness about the importance of responsible pet ownership and the need for community involvement in caring for stray animals.

site_title: Govt invokes Pofma law, orders opposition party member to correct his Facebook post
summary: Singapore's Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) Office has issued a correction direction to Progress Singapore Party member Brad Bowyer, requiring him to correct a Facebook post deemed false. This is the first use of the law aimed at tackling fake news. Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat initiated the direction, which includes a correction notice at the top of the post. The move aims to curb misinformation online.

site_title: Trax investors selling US$100m of shares in partial exit
summary: Trax, a computer vision tech and in-store analytics startup backed by GIC, is selling US$100 million worth of secondary shares to realise returns for early investors. The sale, led by UBS, comes as the company gears up for a potential US IPO and follows recent failed attempts at listing by WeWork and Property Guru. Despite market volatility, Trax reports strong investor interest and expects to turn a profit soon, focusing on boosting gross margins and recurring revenue.

site_title: The US suburban office park, an aging relic, seeks a comeback
summary: The US suburban office park, Research Triangle Park in North Carolina, is seeking a comeback after being considered an aging relic. Opened in 1959, the development was initially praised for its bucolic setting and was home to companies like IBM and RTI International. However, the area has struggled to adapt to changing work environments and technological advancements. Efforts to revitalize the park are underway, but it remains to be seen whether the development can regain its former appeal and attract new businesses and talent.

site_title: Now showing on Capitol Hill - part entertainment, part political theatre
summary: US President Donald Trump's impeachment hearings have concluded, but the outcome remains uncertain. Despite dramatic testimony and evidence of a quid pro quo with Ukraine, Democrats are preparing articles of impeachment, which will likely be adopted by the House but face an uphill battle in the Senate. Republicans, who control the Senate, have shown no indication of joining the opposition party in impeaching Trump, and a conviction would require 20 Republican senators to support it. The outcome will ultimately be decided by voters in the 2020 presidential election.

site_title: Tim Berners-Lee, Web inventor, launches plan to stop internet abuse
summary: Tim Berners-Lee, inventor of the World Wide Web, has launched the "Contract for the Web," a plan to prevent internet abuse by governments, companies, and individuals. The contract, developed with dozens of experts and the public, aims to build a better Web by strengthening laws and regulations, ensuring human rights and democracy, and promoting healthy online conversations. Over 150 organizations, including Google and Facebook, have backed the plan, with governments and individuals also on board.

site_title: AA Reit inks fresh 12-year master lease with Singtel Optus unit in Australia
summary: AIMS Apac Reit (AA Reit) has secured a 12-year master lease extension with Singtel Optus unit Optus Administration at its Macquarie Park property in Australia. The agreement is with joint venture partner Stockland. This deal is a fresh agreement and not an extension of the existing lease.

site_title: Why age, education and skill sets no longer pose setbacks for SME bosses
summary: A Singaporean small business owner, MJ Heng, aged 60, has successfully adapted his business to focus on durians, a unique selling point to attract new customers. Similarly, 68-year-old Rod Lim, owner of Lim Chee Guan, has preserved traditional methods while embracing customer needs. Ernst and Young notes that most ASEAN SMEs intend to leverage digital technologies, but lack access to digital talent. Partnerships and training can help overcome these barriers, and a growing number of seniors are embracing technology.

site_title: Taylor Swift smashes American Music Awards record
summary: Taylor Swift broke American Music Awards records by winning six awards at 29 years old, surpassing Michael Jackson's 24 awards. She also received an honorary artist of the decade award, taking her total to 29 American Music Awards, a record that easily outstripped Jackson's total. Swift did not directly mention a dispute with her old record company during her acceptance speech.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, marking a significant success. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing the current CEO. MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Euro pinned near 10-day lows as economic outlook stays bleak
summary: The euro held near a 10-day low, weakening 0.1% to US$1.1010, due to a bleak economic outlook for the eurozone. Despite some positive news on the Sino-US trade front, investors remain cautious, with hedge funds increasing their negative bets against the euro. The European Central Bank's stimulus measures have not yet borne fruit, with the euro weakening 1.5% this month. Markets await a potential trade agreement between the US and China by year-end, which could impact the euro's value.

site_title: IMF cuts Japan's 2019 GDP forecast again to 0.8%
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) cut Japan's 2019 GDP forecast to 0.8% for the third time this year, citing a synchronized global slowdown affecting domestic demand. The IMF urged continued spending to support growth and prices, recommending the Bank of Japan to shift its policy measures to make them more sustainable. The fund also suggested extending measures to support growth, such as sales tax rebates, and increasing public spending on healthcare and childcare. The IMF warned that Japan's aging society and public debt would remain pressing concerns.

site_title: Businesses must hire fairly, groom local staff
summary: Singapore's economy relies on a diverse workforce to support its growth, but businesses must ensure fair hiring practices to avoid perpetuating negative perceptions. The government aims to promote growth driven by productivity and innovation, rather than workforce expansion alone. Employers must prioritize cultural diversity and avoid concentration risks by drawing from multiple sources, including local talent. The government will continue to monitor and support good employers through initiatives like the Human Capital Partnership programme, while taking action against those that engage in unfair hiring practices.

images.alt_text: Employers such as 3M, HP, Baxter and MasterCard have shown commitment and effort to develop a strong local workforce in Singapore. Many have put in place structured programmes to develop and train their employees to take up better jobs.

site_title: Problems overshadow music at Neon Lights
summary: The Neon Lights festival in Singapore was marred by technical issues, power cuts, and long queues, overshadowing the music performances. Headline acts like Honne, Mumford & Sons, and Mura Masa delivered solid shows despite the problems. However, Nick Murphy's set was cut short due to a power cut, and Aurora's performance was interrupted by a sound system failure. Festival-goers expressed frustration on social media, with some calling for ticket refunds. The festival organizer apologized for the technical glitches, but the issues detracted from the overall experience.

site_title: LVMH puts ring on Tiffany in US$16b marriage
summary: LVMH has agreed to buy Tiffany & Co for over $16 billion, the largest luxury-goods deal ever, in a move that values the US jeweler at 37% above its previous closing price. The deal, worth $135 per share, is expected to more than double LVMH's jewelry scale and boost its market share to over 18%. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move by LVMH chairman Bernard Arnault to challenge Cartier owner Richemont for dominance in the global jewelry business.

site_title: Singapore boosts training for 'smart estates' of the future
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture Singapore (SSG) and Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) have partnered with CapitaLand, CPG Corporation, and EM Services to redesign jobs and skills for the country's "smart estates" ecosystem. The Smart Estates Talent Development Programme (SETDP) aims to train 300 Singaporeans to design, build, and maintain smart estates by 2020. The programme will focus on emerging technologies like AI, AR/VR, and 5G, and will be supported by a training curriculum and industry standards. The goal is to equip the workforce with relevant skills and competencies to support the growth of smart estates in Singapore and the region.

site_title: Can Singapore become a second home for Chinese tech?
summary: Chinese tech firms are showing interest in Singapore, but the number of forays remains a trickle. Despite this, industry watchers believe Singapore's favorable location, business-friendly regulations, and available talent will continue to attract Chinese companies. The country has seen a notable increase in hiring for tech roles, with companies like Huawei and ByteDance expanding their presence in Singapore. Analysts also point to Singapore's proximity to the South-east Asian market and trade connectivity as a draw, providing a safe harbor for Chinese firms amid the US-China trade war.

site_title: Payments platform 2C2P raises US$52m in funding
summary: Payments platform 2C2P has secured US$52 million in funding from investors, bringing its total funding to US$70 million. The funding will be used to enhance its payments platform, hire talent, and consolidate market share in South-east Asia. The company aims to expand beyond the region in the next year. Founded in 2003, 2C2P helps regional businesses secure payments from customers in South-east Asia, with digital financial services expected to drive growth in the region's internet economy, predicted to exceed US$1 trillion by 2025.

site_title: Asian markets close mixed on latest trade news
summary: Asian markets closed mixed on Monday, with most regional markets ending higher due to upbeat trade news. China announced increased penalties on intellectual property theft, giving investors hope of a US-China deal. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index surged 1.5% following peaceful district elections. However, Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.16%, and Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index lost 0.3%. The mixed results were attributed to a lack of concrete steps towards a deal, with some experts expressing skepticism about the news.

site_title: MAS, ESG team up to matchmake startups with regional investors
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Enterprise Singapore (ESG) have partnered to matchmake startups with regional investors through "Deal Fridays", a deal-matching initiative that has facilitated over 200 investor-startup conversations. Since its launch in June, more than 200 leads have been generated, with startups such as fintech firm BondEvalue and educational tech firm Aarna Connect securing funding. The initiative aims to boost regional funding into Singapore's startup scene and follows MAS's US$2 billion investment programme to ramp up green financing capabilities.

site_title: Landslide win for HK democrats puts pressure on leader Carrie Lam
summary: Hong Kong's democrats won a landslide majority in district council elections, securing nearly 90% of the 452 seats. The record turnout, despite six months of anti-government protests, increased pressure on leader Carrie Lam to listen to calls for democracy. The pro-establishment opposition was strongly resourced but failed to gain significant ground. The elections marked a rare lull in the unrest, with the outcome seen as a significant blow to Carrie Lam's authority and a call for greater democracy in the Chinese-ruled city.

site_title: World Bank's US$225m in catastrophe-linked bonds listed on SGX
summary: The World Bank Group's International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) has issued two tranches of catastrophe-linked bonds totaling US$225 million, listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The bonds provide financial protection to the Philippines for losses from earthquakes and tropical cyclones, with a maximum payout of US$75 million for earthquakes and US$150 million for cyclones. The bonds are the first World Bank bonds listed in Singapore, the first catastrophe bonds listed on an Asian exchange, and the first sponsored by an Asian country's government.

images.alt_text: The World Bank Group's International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) has issued two tranches of catastrophe-linked bonds totalling US$225 million.

site_title: Huge barriers to Bloomberg's Democratic nomination bid
summary: Michael Bloomberg announced his candidacy for the 2020 US presidential election, entering the Democratic primary with his vast wealth and eclectic political biography. Despite his late entry, Bloomberg plans to spend $35 million on TV commercials and focus on delegate-rich states, bypassing early primary states. His candidacy faces obstacles due to his business entanglements, comments about women, and law enforcement policies. Bloomberg's wealth, estimated at over $50 billion, may intensify the debate about the power of the rich in politics, and he is expected to shake up the contest for the Democratic Party's moderate wing.

site_title: Bitcoin trades below key US$7,000 level for first time since May
summary: Bitcoin has dropped below the US$7,000 psychological level for the first time since May, falling over 10% and reaching a six-month low, due to concerns about China's crackdown on cryptocurrency operations. The world's largest cryptocurrency is on track for an eighth consecutive day of declines, tying a record losing streak from 2014. Experts attribute the drop to low volumes, attractive returns from traditional assets, and miner capitulation, with the cost of production estimated to be around US$6,000.

site_title: Amazon opens pop-up store on China's Pinduoduo until year-end
summary: Amazon is opening a pop-up store on Chinese e-commerce platform Pinduoduo until the end of December, carrying around 1,000 overseas products. This move follows Amazon's shift in strategy to focus on selling international goods to Chinese buyers and expanding its cloud services in the country. The store aims to provide customers with competitive prices, authenticity guarantees, and convenient shipping. This marks a departure from Amazon's previous focus on domestic-selling merchants, as the company seeks to compete with dominant players like Alibaba's Tmall and JD.com's marketplace.

site_title: Corporate leaders at greater risk of legal, regulatory liabilities
summary: Corporate leaders face increased scrutiny and liability due to a rapidly changing risk landscape and rising compliance requirements. A report by AGCS found that 59% of US securities fraud settlements are event-driven, with growing claims arising from product problems, environmental disasters, and cyber attacks. The risk of bankruptcy, climate change, and ESG failings also looms large, with litigation funding fueling the growth of securities class actions. As a result, boards are taking more interest in directors and officers (D&O) insurance to protect themselves from potential lawsuits.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as report sparks trade deal hopes
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday as a report strengthened hopes of a US-China trade truce, boosting market sentiment. The Dow Jones rose 0.15%, the S&P 500 gained 0.23%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.47%. The market rally was driven by anticipation of a trade deal and blockbuster deals, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: OCBC optimistic about growth stocks in 2020
summary: OCBC Investment Research predicts a shift in investor focus from dividend stocks to growth stocks in 2020, driven by global growth stimulus. Key picks include Alibaba, Trip.com, JD.com, and Tencent in the e-commerce and internet sectors. OCBC has left banks out of its 2020 stock picks due to concerns over slowing net interest margins. The report also highlights potential opportunities in Reit sector stocks, such as Ascendas and Singapore Airlines, citing stable oil prices and strong travel demand.

site_title: Beef industry battles to scrub polluter image as vegan burgers boom
summary: The US beef industry is attempting to rebrand itself as a more sustainable and environmentally-friendly option, despite a growing trend of vegan burgers and plant-based alternatives. Companies like Tyson Foods and Cargill have pledged ambitious reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, citing improvements in production efficiency and the adoption of regenerative farming practices. However, critics argue that the industry still faces significant challenges in reducing its carbon footprint, with methane emissions from cattle being a major contributor to global emissions.

site_title: Top 50 most-active stocks outperform STI year to date
summary: The top 50 most-active stocks on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) have outperformed the Straits Times Index (STI) year-to-date, with an average total return of 22% compared to the STI's 9.2%. The 10 most-traded stocks, including Singtel and DBS Group Holdings, garnered a combined S$2.2 billion in net institutional inflow, with a median return of 29%. This surpasses the STI's total return and median return of the 50 most-traded stocks.

site_title: Hard knocks path to the top
summary: Two Singaporean entrepreneurs, Wong Peck Lin and Mervin Wee, shared their experiences in growing their successful businesses, Udders and Jean Yip Group, respectively, in a fireside chat hosted by SGSME. Wong, co-founder of Udders, emphasized the importance of localizing flavors to cater to the Asian palate, while Wee, group managing director of Jean Yip Group, credited his success to setting precise goals, maintaining the right attitude, and energy. Both entrepreneurs also highlighted the importance of adapting to customer preferences and leveraging technology to overcome challenges, such as scaling up production and managing staff.

site_title: Uber's licence in London not extended
summary: Transport for London (TFL) announced it will not extend Uber's taxi operating licence in London, citing a pattern of failures that put passengers at risk, including unauthorised drivers uploading photos to other accounts. Uber has 21 days to appeal the decision and will continue to operate in the city during this time. The company had previously been given a 15-month licence, and its licence renewal was made contingent on reforms. Mayor Sadiq Khan defended the decision, citing concerns over passenger safety, while drivers of traditional cabs celebrated the move, saying it would make Londoners safer.

site_title: Jewellery, artifacts worth US$1.1b stolen from German museum
summary: Thieves stole US$1.1 billion worth of jewellery and artifacts from Dresden's Grunes Gewolbe museum in Germany early Monday morning. The burglary occurred through a window, and the robbers remain at large. The stolen items, including ensembles of diamonds, are considered unique and priceless in Europe, with estimated art-historic value. This is the second high-profile heist in Germany in recent years, following a 2017 theft of a solid gold coin worth US$4 million from Berlin's Bode Museum.

site_title: Aramco IPO retail subscription at US$5.8b, says lead manager
summary: Saudi Aramco's retail subscription for its initial public offering (IPO) reached US$5.8 billion, according to lead manager Samba Capital. The company plans to sell 1.5% of its stock in the IPO.

images.alt_text: Retail subscription for Saudi Aramco's initial public offering (IPO) reached US$5.8 billion on Monday, lead manager Samba Capital said.

site_title: First Sponsor to build mixed-use Sydney skyscraper with Australia's ICD
summary: A consortium led by First Sponsor has partnered with Australia's ICD Property to redevelop the City Tattersalls Club in Sydney, with an estimated total development cost of over A$400 million. The 124-year-old club will be revamped with retail outlets, restaurants, and a hotel, and a 49-storey skyscraper with 246 apartments and a 100-room hotel is planned above the site. First Sponsor will be the sole construction financier, providing up to A$370 million in funding, and holds an 80% stake in the project. Regulatory approvals are expected to be achieved in Q1 2020.

site_title: China plans record sale of $6b in sovereign USD bonds
summary: China plans to sell a record $6 billion in sovereign USD bonds, with a potential 3-20 year tenor. This marks the third consecutive year for China to issue dollar debt, aiming to build an offshore market for its companies and local authorities to access funding. The sale is expected to be announced on Tuesday and would be double the size of last year's issue, following China's first euro bond in 15 years. The move underscores China's efforts to develop an orderly offshore dollar bond market and follows a record-breaking year for Chinese dollar bond issuance.

site_title: Proposals made a year ago may point to a way out of WTO panel crisis
summary: The World Trade Organization's (WTO) seven-person appellate panel will cease to function on December 10 if the US does not relent, threatening trade disputes without finality. The US is unhappy with the appeal process taking over 3½ years and fees paid to panel members. The Trump administration wants the WTO to operate as an instrument to enforce contracts, while others see it as an international trade court. Proposals made a year ago by the EU and other countries to reform the appellate system may be the best way out of the impasse, but the US is blocking attempts to replace retiring panellists.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.49 points lower on Monday at 1,591.35, with a trading volume of 2.5 billion lots worth RM1.5 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 549 to 337.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Pine Capital Group's executive chairman Tomi-Jae Wanlun Tjio, 57, has left the company due to "personal matters", effective November 22. This follows a settlement with former chairman Tan Choon Wee last month. Moody's Investors Service has downgraded Frasers Hospitality Trust's outlook to negative, citing weakened operating performance. A Chinese district court has ruled a 2015 land transfer agreement was legal, affecting Wuxi Yilin Real Estate and Wuxi New District Phoenix Hospital.

site_title: Germany on track for Q4 growth as business morale edges up: Ifo
summary: Germany's business morale rose to 95.0 in November, surpassing expectations, and the economy is on track for a 0.2% growth in the fourth quarter. The manufacturing sector remains in recession, but domestic consumer-driven strength is driving the growth. The Ifo economic institute attributed the resilience to consumer spending, strong exports, and state spending. Despite this, the manufacturing sector's slowdown poses concerns for the economy, and Chancellor Angela Merkel's government has rejected calls for a stimulus package.

site_title: Indian doctors remove giant 7.4kg kidney from man
summary: Indian surgeons successfully removed a 7.4kg kidney from a man suffering from a life-threatening genetic condition. The removed kidney weighed as much as a bowling ball and occupied half of the patient's abdomen. This is one of the largest kidneys ever removed in an operation. The surgery was performed by a team of doctors led by Sachin Kathuria, who described the kidney as a "huge lump" that required careful removal. The patient's condition has improved, but further treatment is needed.

site_title: Luxury tycoon said to mull US$1.5b South African fibre sale
summary: Johann Rupert, billionaire owner of Richemont, is considering selling up to $1.5 billion worth of stakes in South African fibre networks Vumatel and Dark Fibre Africa. Rupert's company, Community Investment Ventures Holdings, is raising primary equity from local investors and refinancing senior debt. The sale could attract local telecommunications companies and infrastructure funds. Vumatel pioneered fibre-to-the-home industry, while Dark Fibre operates 10,000 kilometers of high-speed network infrastructure. Details of the potential valuation and sale timeline are still unclear.

site_title: As US malls struggle, thriving ones spend millions to reinvent themselves
summary: US malls are struggling, with nearly one in four expected to close by 2022. Thriving malls, however, are reinventing themselves as integrated lifestyle hubs with upscale shops, restaurants, and entertainment options. These investments come at the expense of lower-tier properties, exacerbating the divide between successful and struggling malls. Retailers are closing hundreds of stores nationwide, with many malls losing anchor tenants like Sears and J C Penney. Experts say the shopping mall as we know it is past its prime, and malls must adapt to changing consumer behavior by offering more than just stores.

site_title: Moody's downgrades Frasers Hospitality Trust's outlook to negative
summary: Moody's Investors Service downgraded the outlook on Frasers Hospitality Trust to negative from stable, citing the company's weakened operating performance. The credit rating agency affirmed the Baa2 issuer rating and backed senior unsecured ratings. Moody's expects FHT's credit metrics to remain weak relative to its rating over the next 12-18 months. This change reflects Moody's concern over FHT's financial stability.

site_title: Making America mediocre
summary: US President Donald Trump's economic policies have led to a level playing field being disrupted, favoring politically connected parties over more efficient competitors. The tariffs on steel and aluminum, justified as national security measures, have resulted in a complex and opaque waiver system, granting exemptions to some firms while denying them to others. This has led to complaints of uneven playing fields, with companies experiencing different outcomes for the same type of imported steel. Such discretionary decisions have also raised concerns about electoral politics and bias, with the Trump administration being accused of showing favoritism towards certain companies.

site_title: eBay to sell StubHub for US$4b to Swiss rival
summary: US online giant eBay agreed to sell its ticket marketplace StubHub to Swiss-based rival Viagogo for $4.05 billion in cash, allowing Viagogo to boost its global presence to over 70 countries. The deal comes after eBay's leadership change and asset sales amid slumping profits. Viagogo's founder and CEO Eric Baker, who co-founded StubHub, expressed excitement about the possibilities for the shared future, promising a win-win for fans with more choice and better pricing. The sale is expected to close by the end of 2020, pending regulatory approval.

site_title: Protecting this festive season from holiday hackers
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

As the holiday shopping season approaches, online stores and retailers are vulnerable to holiday hackers who use bots, phishing scams, and credential stuffing to steal sensitive information and make a quick buck. In the past eight months, there were over 10 billion attempts at credential stuffing, with retail industry losses estimated at billions of dollars. To protect themselves, retailers must develop smarter methods to monitor, identify, and block advanced threats from bad bots, and educate employees and consumers on spotting phishing scams. By prioritizing security, retailers can mitigate malicious activity and ensure a safe online shopping experience.

site_title: Regtech startup Tookitaki raises extra US$11.7m in Series A funding
summary: Tookitaki, a regulatory technology startup, has raised an additional US$11.7 million in Series A funding, bringing the total to US$19.2 million. The funding round was co-led by Viola Fintech and SIG, with existing investors also participating. The extra funding will support product enhancements, technological innovation, recruitment, and revenue growth, as well as expanding the company's research and development team in Singapore and Bangalore.

site_title: MindChamps to open new performing arts preschool in Singapore
summary: MindChamps PreSchool, in collaboration with Actors Centre Australia, is opening a performing arts preschool in Singapore's Orchard Road. The preschool aims to improve children's social, emotional, cognitive, and motor skills through theatrical strategies. This move comes amid growing concerns about the negative effects of children's screen time, with MindChamps' CEO stating that screen time can lead to disconnection from human connection. The new preschool will introduce theatre and arts elements and open in the new school year.

site_title: Europe: Shares lifted by US-China trade optimism
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Monday, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks, which are nearing an initial agreement. French luxury goods group LVMH gained 1.7% after signing a deal to buy Tiffany & Co. for $16.2 billion. The STOXX 600 index, led by trade-sensitive miners, saw a second straight day of gains.
