Economists expect a higher-than-expected German IFO business sentiment survey later in the day, further boosting market sentiment.

site_title: Chubb to buy added stake in China's Huatai Insurance for 10.8b yuan
summary: Chubb Ltd. will acquire an additional 22.4% stake in Huatai Insurance Group Co. Ltd. for 10.8 billion yuan (S$2.09 billion). This move is part of Chubb's strategy to tap into China's rapidly growing insurance sector. Chubb already holds a nearly 27% stake in Huatai and plans to buy an additional 7.1% stake after completing the first contingent. The acquisition is seen as an opportunity for Chubb to support Huatai as a long-term strategic shareholder and capitalize on the Chinese insurance market's potential.

site_title: Horse racing: Australia and Hong Kong end quarantine stand-off
summary: Australia has ended a two-year quarantine stand-off with Hong Kong, allowing the movement of horses between the two countries. The Hong Kong Jockey Club's training facility in mainland China was deemed biosecurity compliant by Australia's Department of Agriculture, meeting import standards. Horses can now be transported between Australia and Hong Kong under the same conditions as before the 2017 restrictions were imposed. This decision is seen as a strong endorsement of the biosecurity measures in place at the facility and the health status of Hong Kong's racehorses.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hemmed in by trade uncertainty
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars remain uncertain due to ongoing US-China trade tensions. The Aussie was trading at US$0.6797, within a tight range, while the kiwi dollar rose to US$0.6418, supported by recent gains. Investors await key local data releases this week, adding to the volatility.

site_title: Facial recognition at Indian cafe chain sparks calls for data protection law
summary: A popular Indian cafe chain, Chaayos, has sparked calls for data protection laws after customers complained about facial recognition technology that captured images without consent. Human rights advocates say the lack of legislative safeguards can lead to privacy breaches and profiling. The technology, marketed as a convenience, was tested in select cafes, but critics argue that a moratorium on such technology is needed until a comprehensive data protection law is introduced. A Personal Data Protection Bill is scheduled to be introduced in India's parliament by December 13.

site_title: Uber stripped of London operating licence, again
summary: Uber has had its London operating licence revoked for the second time, following a review by Transport for London (TfL) that found the taxi app had put passenger safety at risk. The decision was made after it was discovered that unauthorised drivers had uploaded their photos to other drivers' accounts, allowing them to pick up passengers as if they were the booked driver in at least 14,000 trips. Uber has 21 days to appeal the decision and can continue to operate during the process.

images.alt_text: Uber was stripped of its London operating licence on Monday for the second time in just over two years as the city's regulator said the taxi app was not "fit and proper", having put passenger safety at risk.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump on revived hopes for trade deal
summary: South Korean stocks surged 1% on Monday as hopes for a US-China trade deal revived, with upbeat remarks from both countries' leaders. China and the US are "very close" to a phase one trade deal, according to the Global Times. US President Donald Trump said a trade accord is "potentially very close" and China has invited top US trade negotiators for new talks. The Kospi index ended at 2,123.50, with foreigners selling shares for the 13th straight session, but foreign investors cheered the market on Trump's optimistic remark.

site_title: Greenhouse gases surge to record in 2018, exceeding 10-yr average rate: UN
summary: Greenhouse gases reached a record high in 2018, exceeding the 10-year average rate, according to the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO). The atmospheric concentration of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide and methane, rose faster than expected, cementing damaging weather patterns. The WMO Secretary-General stated that there is no sign of a slowdown in greenhouse gas concentrations, despite commitments under the Paris Agreement on Climate Change. This data is expected to guide discussions at the upcoming UN climate change summit in Madrid.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.2% on Monday amid trade deal caution
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.16% to 3,220.63 on Monday, despite upbeat trade news and a surge in Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index. China's markets saw mixed results after the country announced it would raise penalties on intellectual property theft, sparking hopes for a US-China trade deal. Analysts say the move suggests key concessions are being made, but a deal is still uncertain, and investors remain cautious.

site_title: World Bank makes first listing of US$225m catastrophe-linked bonds on SGX
summary: The World Bank Group's International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) has issued two tranches of catastrophe-linked bonds totaling US$225 million, listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The bonds provide financial protection to the Philippines for up to US$75 million for earthquakes and US$150 million for tropical cyclones over the next three years. This is the first time the World Bank has listed bonds in Singapore and the first catastrophe bonds sponsored by an Asian sovereign. The bonds mature on December 2, 2022, and pay monthly coupons.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's headline and core inflation rates eased in October, with headline inflation at 0.4% and core inflation at 0.6%, marking the slowest rates since March 2016. The World Bank issued SGX-listed catastrophe-linked bonds worth US$225m to protect the Philippines from natural disasters. AA Reit signed a 12-year master lease with Singtel Optus. A mixed-use development in Balestier is up for sale at S$14.7m. Meanwhile, global markets fell, with Singapore shares retreating 0.2% amid trade deal caution.

site_title: Singapore incubator BLOCK71 expands into Ho Chi Minh City
summary: Singapore's NUS Enterprise partners Vietnamese developer Becamex IDC Corporation to establish its eighth BLOCK71 incubation space in Ho Chi Minh City, promoting innovation and entrepreneurship development between the two countries. The joint initiative aims to support a two-way flow of talent, technologies, and start-ups, providing access to global networks, incubation support, and markets. This is part of Vietnam's growing start-up ecosystem, which has seen a six-fold increase in invested capital in technology deals in the last two years.

site_title: Bullying debate after death of K-pop star Goo Hara
summary: K-pop star Goo Hara, 28, was found dead in her home in Seoul, South Korea, on Sunday, sparking an online debate about bullying and the pressures of the entertainment industry. A fellow K-pop star, Sulli, took her own life in October after struggling with online bullying, and Goo had previously spoken out about abusive comments and depression. The case has raised questions about the need for stronger punishments for cybercrimes and the industry's treatment of its stars, with an online petition calling for action garnering over 20,000 signatures.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on fresh trade hope, elections lift Hong Kong
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday on fresh optimism over China-US trade talks, with Beijing offering concessions on intellectual property and Donald Trump hailing progress. Hong Kong stocks led the regional advance, surging 1.8% as pro-democracy candidates won community-level elections, which may pressure the local government and Beijing to act. Global markets have rallied in recent weeks on expectations of a trade deal, with Tokyo, Shanghai, and Seoul also gaining ground, while concerns remain about how tariffs will be wound back.

site_title: Japan panel warns against fiscal complacency amid low rates
summary: Japan's Fiscal System Council warned against fiscal complacency amid low interest rates, urging the government to stick to its aim of balancing a primary budget by March 2026. The council recommended examining flexible fiscal policy to stimulate growth, particularly in response to external risks. The government must prioritize fiscal reform, including controlling spending and boosting tax revenue, to sustain social security costs and ensure public finances. The council hailed the recent sales tax hike as a "milestone" in Japan's fiscal reform journey.

site_title: Asian airlines cautious about outlook for 2020; SIA's Subhas Menon to head AAPA from March
summary: Asian airlines are cautious about the 2020 outlook due to trade disputes and economic growth below forecasts. Passenger growth in Asia has moderated to 4.4% in the first nine months of 2020, down from 7.7% in 2018. The Association of Asia Pacific Airlines (AAPA) announced that Subhas Menon, a Singapore Airlines executive, will replace Andrew Herdman as director general in March. Herdman cited "unpredictability" in Hong Kong as a reason for AAPA's meeting relocation, with airlines cutting flights to the city due to declining demand.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on a cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.78% on Monday, driven by a cheaper yen and rallies in New York, amid US-China trade talks and Hong Kong tensions. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 23,292.81, while the Topix index gained 0.69%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally on trade hopes, election result
summary: Hong Kong shares rose sharply Monday on trade hopes and a landslide win for pro-democrats in local elections. The Hang Seng index jumped 1.50% to 26,993.04, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.72%. The election result gave the government a blow following months of protests that have hit the economy. The rally was driven by fresh trade hopes and a boost to investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: Exterior view of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The Hang Seng index jumped 1.50 per cent, or 397.96 points, to 26,993.04.

site_title: Wastewater treatment startup Hydroleap raises S$2.6m in latest funding round
summary: Hydroleap, a Singapore-based wastewater treatment startup, has raised S$2.6 million in funding led by Wavemaker Partners. The funds will be used to commercialize its electrical wastewater treatment technology for industrial parks, mining, and semiconductor industries. The company, founded by Dr. Mohammad Sherafatmand, offers a chemical-free, cost-effective, and environmentally-friendly solution using electricity to treat wastewater. This is Hydroleap's latest funding round, following previous investments from SGInnovate, Sparklabs Cultiv8, and Entrepreneur First.

site_title: South-east Asia payments platform 2C2P raises US$52m in funding
summary: 2C2P, a South-east Asia payments platform, has raised US$52 million in funding from investors including IFC, Cento Ventures, and Arbor Ventures. The funding will be used to enhance its platform, hire talent, and consolidate market share in the region. This brings 2C2P's total funding to US$70 million. The company aims to expand beyond South-east Asia over the next year, capitalizing on the region's growing digital financial services market, which is predicted to exceed US$1 trillion in gross transaction value by 2025.

site_title: Ramaphosa urges South Africa Inc to appoint more black managers
summary: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa urged businesses to increase the representation of black managers, citing a lack of progress in the private sector despite significant strides in the public sector. The call comes after criticism over the appointment of a white CEO at Eskom, a state-owned power utility. Ramaphosa noted that black people make up 79% of the economically active population but only 15% of top management, emphasizing the need for greater inclusion in the economy to achieve transformative goals.

site_title: LVMH to buy US jeweller Tiffany for US$16.2b
summary: LVMH has agreed to buy US jeweller Tiffany for $16.2 billion, its largest acquisition to date. The deal will boost LVMH's jewelry division and expand its presence in the US luxury market. Tiffany's board of directors has recommended shareholder approval, with the acquisition expected to close in mid-2020. The deal represents a 7.5% premium over Tiffany's closing share price and will help LVMH tap into the growing jewelry market, which saw comparable sales grow 7% in 2018.

site_title: Saudi central bank says Aramco IPO not causing liquidity issues for banks
summary: Saudi Arabia's central bank governor Ahmed al-Kholifey stated that the country's banking system is not experiencing liquidity issues due to Saudi Aramco's initial public offering (IPO). The bank is closely monitoring banking indicators daily and has not seen any significant impact on liquidity. Al-Kholifey expressed confidence that the large size of the IPO would not cause any liquidity squeeze.

site_title: Forging new paths for ASEAN's sustainable infrastructure needs
summary: Singapore's Infrastructure Asia and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) have announced plans to develop bankable green infrastructure projects across Southeast Asia, aiming to address the region's growing infrastructure needs and climate change challenges. The ADB forecasts that climate change could reduce Southeast Asia's GDP by 11% by the end of the century. To achieve this goal, the private sector must step up to provide 60% of green financing, a significant increase from the current 25%. The partnership aims to promote sustainable infrastructure financing, with recommendations including a 'Doing Sustainable Infrastructure Report', an ASEAN Urban Infrastructure Network, and a blended finance toolbox.

images.alt_text: Minister in the Prime Minister's Office Indranee Rajah during her keynote address at the Asia Infrastructure Forum held at Marina Bay Sands

site_title: Global natural gas glut has US exporters facing worst-case scenario
summary: US natural gas exporters face a potential worst-case scenario due to a massive global glut, which could lead to halting shipments to rebalance supply and demand. Citigroup predicts prices in Europe and Asia may collapse to levels forcing US liquefied natural gas suppliers to curb output, potentially curtailing exports of 2.7 billion cubic feet per day. The glut is driven by China's decreased demand and Europe's nearly full gas storage, making it challenging to find homes for American exports.

site_title: Oil kicks off week with gains on fresh hopes for US-China trade talks
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as US-China trade talks reignited optimism, with West Texas Intermediate crude gaining 10 cents to $57.87 a barrel and Brent crude futures rising 7 cents to $63.46 a barrel. US national security adviser Robert O'Brien stated an initial trade agreement is possible by the end of the year, while President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping expressed a desire to sign a deal. Despite concerns over Hong Kong unrest, the positive news boosted global markets, with strategist Michael McCarthy noting that a move by China to protect intellectual property is supporting trade talks.

site_title: Balestier freehold shophouse with apartment block up for sale at S$14.7m
summary: A mixed-use development called Victory Point in Singapore's Balestier Road is up for sale at S$14.7 million. The two-storey conservation shophouse houses a convenience store on the ground floor, while the second storey and attic are for office use. The indicative price translates to S$1,390 per square foot based on a 10,609 sq ft gross floor area.

site_title: Australia: Shares lifted by iron ore miners, but Westpac weighs
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 6,731.4, driven by gains from top iron ore miners BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue, which climbed between 1.8% and 2% following higher iron ore prices. Afterpay Touch Group surged 7.1% after an audit found no money laundering activity. In contrast, Westpac Banking Corp fell 1.3% for the fourth straight session, weighed down by concerns over anti-money laundering laws. US trade war news also influenced the market, with Robert O'Brien saying an initial trade deal with China was possible by the end of the year.

site_title: Electric cars racing at 273 kmh are test labs for SUVs
summary: BMW, Volkswagen, Audi, and Mahindra are racing electric-powered cars at speeds up to 273 km/h to develop and transfer technology to their SUVs and sedans. The Formula E series is incorporating breakthroughs in energy-management software, braking systems, and batteries into road cars. Manufacturers aim to improve and extend their electric lineups as countries phase out petrol vehicles. Key technologies include regenerative braking and energy-efficient software, which could give commercial electric vehicles a competitive edge, and help boost driving range and reduce costs.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam vows to 'listen humbly' after shock poll result
summary: Hong Kong's Carrie Lam vowed to "listen humbly" to the public after a pro-democracy camp won a crushing majority in community-level elections, dealing a significant blow to her Beijing-backed establishment. The election result, which saw candidates favoring greater democracy seize 452 out of 452 seats, has sparked widespread dissatisfaction among citizens. Lam acknowledged the result has sparked discussion of the territory's deep-seated problems, but did not commit to meeting the demands of the protest movement, including direct popular elections and a probe into alleged police brutality.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's unpopular leader Carrie Lam said on Monday her government would "listen humbly" to the public after voters dealt a humiliating election setback to the Beijing-backed establishment she heads.

site_title: Pine Capital executive chairman quits
summary: Pine Capital Group announced that its executive chairman, Tomi-Jae Wanlun Tjio, 57, has resigned for "personal matters" effective November 22. Tjio, who was appointed executive chairman in September, had previously been non-executive chairman. The company stated there are no unresolved differences in opinion between Tjio and the board of directors. This follows a settlement with former interim CEO and executive chairman Tan Choon Wee in October, after a legal dispute. Pine Capital's second-quarter net loss was S$1.8 million, with trading in its shares suspended since March.

site_title: First Sponsor to fund, redevelop Sydney site into 49-storey tower
summary: A consortium led by First Sponsor has partnered with ICD Property to redevelop the City Tattersalls Club site in Sydney into a 49-storey tower with apartments and a high-end hotel. The project, valued at up to A$370 million, follows City of Sydney approval for stage 1 concept development. The redevelopment includes retail outlets, restaurants, and health facilities, with plans to rejuvenate the historic clubhouse. Regulatory approvals are expected to be achieved in Q1 2020.

site_title: New shipping rules, China pummel Asian refinery profits
summary: Asian refineries are experiencing declining profits due to uncertainty over new shipping fuel standards and the rise of China as a product exporter. Refinery margins have reached their lowest since the 2008 financial crisis, with a US$1.19 loss per barrel of Dubai crude in early Asian trade. This compares to a US$4.11 average profit per barrel in October and a 365-day moving average of US$4.08 per barrel. The decline in refinery margins is attributed to the impact of new shipping fuel standards and China's growing influence in the market.

site_title: Amazon opens pop-up store on China's Pinduoduo until year-end
summary: Amazon has opened a pop-up store on Chinese e-commerce platform Pinduoduo, featuring about 1,000 overseas products until the end of December. This move marks a shift in Amazon's China strategy, focusing on selling goods from abroad and cloud services, after previously operating a marketplace for domestic-selling merchants. The store aims to provide customers with a curated selection of products, competitive prices, and convenience, amid increased competition in China's e-commerce market.

site_title: South-east Asia's first Korean startup centre to be set up in Singapore
summary: South Korea's Ministry of SMEs and Startups, in partnership with Enterprise Singapore, will establish the first South-east Asia Korea Startup Centre in Singapore in 2020. The centre will provide infrastructure and networking opportunities for South Korean small and medium-sized enterprises and startups to connect with Singapore's startup ecosystem. This move aims to promote business and technology partnerships between Singapore and South Korea, and comes after a memorandum of understanding on standards and conformance was signed between the two entities. The centre's establishment also marks a significant expansion of air services between Singapore and South Korea.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon up 0.21% on day
summary: Singapore's STI index resumed trading Monday afternoon, rising 0.21% to 3,232.41. The index saw 656.5 million shares traded, with 177 advancers and 132 decliners. Financials led the gain, with DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank increasing 0.16%, 0.04%, and 0.09% respectively. The rally follows Asian shares' cautious advance on optimism over the Sino-US trade dispute, with other markets also rising, including Japan's Topix, Hong Kong's Hang Seng, and South Korea's KOSPI.

site_title: Singapore's headline, core inflation both ease in October
summary: Singapore's headline and core inflation both eased in October, with headline inflation at 0.4% and core inflation at 0.6%, down from previous months. The easing was driven by a decline in electricity and gas costs, as well as lower services inflation. Economists expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore to hold steady at its next meeting in April, with forecasters predicting core inflation to average 0.5-1.5% and headline inflation to be around 0.5-1.5% in 2020.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Monday with strong gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the week with a strong gain, rising 1.05% at the opening of business on Monday. This follows China's recent concessions to the US in their mini trade deal negotiations. The Hang Seng index reached 26,873.35, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices also saw gains. The market optimism is attributed to the improved relations between China and the US, which has boosted investor confidence.

site_title: No 'phase two' US-China deal on the horizon, officials say
summary: US officials and Beijing representatives indicate a "phase two" trade deal between the US and China is unlikely in the near future, citing difficulties in striking a preliminary "phase one" agreement. The second phase would focus on intellectual property theft, but concerns over the lack of progress on this issue, combined with the US presidential election and White House reluctance to work with other countries, dim hopes for a comprehensive deal. A phase one deal may be delayed until next year, with many trade practices seen as unfair remaining unaddressed.

site_title: Australia's Afterpay shares leap after audit finds 'low risk' of money laundering
summary: Australia's Afterpay shares surged over 9% after an external audit found the company to be a "low-risk" business for money laundering and terrorism financing. The audit, ordered by the Australian financial crime watchdog AUSTRAC, confirmed Afterpay's compliance with anti-money laundering laws. The company reiterated that no suspicious activity was found on its systems, and AUSTRAC will review the report to determine if further action is required. The positive news comes after AUSTRAC previously flagged concerns over non-compliance with anti-money laundering rules by other companies, including PayPal and Westpac Banking Corp.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.79 points to 1,595.05. The market saw 98.51 million lots traded worth RM27.61 million, with 117 gains and 67 losses.

site_title: HP rejects Xerox takeover offer again
summary: HP has rejected Xerox's US$33 billion takeover bid, stating the sum "significantly undervalues" the company. The HP board of directors reiterated their rejection in a letter, citing uncertainty over Xerox's ability to raise the cash portion of the proposed consideration. Xerox chairman John Visentin had previously expressed surprise at HP's initial rejection, which sets a value of US$22 per share for the computing firm. The deal would unite two tech industry giants with storied histories, but the proposal remains on the table.

site_title: Stocks to watch: AA Reit, First Sponsor, Procurri, ThaiBev, Yoma, Hatten Land, ISEC Healthcare
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: AIMS Apac Reit secured a 12-year agreement with Optus Administration, First Sponsor partnered ICD Property for the redevelopment of City Tattersalls Club, Procurri Corp accepted a US$115 million cash offer for its hardware maintenance business, ThaiBev reported a 29.7% increase in full-year net profit, Yoma Strategic will retain a 25% stake despite Ayala Corp's investment plans, Hatten Land's share placement was extended to Nov 29, and ISEC Healthcare's mandatory offer was deemed "fair but reasonable" by CIMB Bank Berhad.

site_title: China Mengniu Dairy buys Kirin Australia unit for A$600m
summary: China Mengniu Dairy Co Ltd has agreed to buy Australia-based Lion-Dairy & Drinks Pty Ltd for A$600 million, expanding its presence in the Australian market and internationally. The acquisition, part-owned by the Chinese government, comes after the Australian government gave conditional approval for Mengniu's previous acquisition of infant formula maker Bellamy's Australia Ltd for A$1.43 billion. The deal highlights China's growing interest in Australia's dairy industry despite increased global scrutiny of Chinese acquisitions.

site_title: Surbana Jurong to design 15,000 homes in India with Singapore public housing features
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singapore-based urban and infrastructure consultancy, has secured an affordable housing project in Gujarat, India, with a scope of work including master planning, concept design, and project management services for 15,000 homes across 12 sites. The project incorporates Singapore's public housing features, such as void decks and community-centric spaces, to make Gujarat's public housing more vibrant and sustainable. The project aims to provide affordable housing to Gujarat's high population density cities, aligning with India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's target to provide housing for all by 2022.

site_title: Tolerance towards LGBT+ people seen rising globally
summary: Tolerance towards LGBT+ people has increased globally, with 111 of 167 countries showing improvement over the last decade, according to the Legatum Institute's 2019 Prosperity Index. Iceland was named the most tolerant country, while Tajikistan was the least. Social tolerance towards minority groups, including LGBT+ people, immigrants, and ethnic minorities, increased across every region except Eastern Europe & Sub-Saharan Africa. The acceptance of LGBT+ people rose from one in four to almost a third, with countries like Iceland, The Netherlands, and Norway ranking high.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.35%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 11.40 points or 0.35% to 3,237.05, with gains outnumbering losses 99 to 32. The most actively traded security, Rex International, gained 3.5% after 26.8 million shares changed hands. The index followed US and European markets, which ended higher on Friday after positive comments on a potential US-China trade deal and upbeat economic data.

site_title: Web inventor Berners-Lee launches plan to stop internet abuse
summary: World Wide Web inventor Tim Berners-Lee unveiled the "Contract for the Web," a plan to halt internet abuse by governments, companies, and individuals, at the UN Internet Governance Forum in Berlin. The contract, developed with dozens of experts and public members, calls for governments to strengthen laws and regulations, companies to prioritize human rights and democracy, and citizens to hold those in power accountable. Over 150 organizations, including Google and Microsoft, have backed the plan, with the governments of France, Germany, and Ghana also on board.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb on positive US-China trade comments
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Monday, driven by positive US-China trade comments. US President Donald Trump said a trade deal was "potentially very close", while Chinese President Xi Jinping expressed a desire for an initial pact. Global miners BHP Group and Rio Tinto advanced, along with energy and financials. However, Westpac Banking Corp fell as a result of breaching anti-money laundering laws. The ASX 200 index rose to 6,745.70, with Afterpay Touch Group surging 11.7% and Nufarm slumping 20%.

images.alt_text: Australian shares climbed on Monday as positive rhetoric from both the United States and China renewed hopes of an interim trade deal to end their 16-month long tariff dispute.

site_title: US Defence Secretary asks for navy chief's resignation: statement
summary: US Defence Secretary Mark Esper requested the resignation of Navy Secretary Richard Spencer amid a dispute over the handling of Navy Seal Eddie Gallagher's demotion. The demotion was reversed by President Donald Trump, prompting Esper's loss of trust and confidence in Spencer's candor with the White House. The Department of Defence stated Esper's request for Spencer's resignation. The move comes after Esper expressed frustration over the reversal, which he believed undermined the military's chain of command.

images.alt_text: US Defence Secretary Mark Esper on Sunday requested the navy chief's resignation amid a dispute over an elite Seal commando whose demotion for misconduct was reversed by President Donald Trump.

site_title: AA Reit inks 12-year master lease with unit of Singtel Optus
summary: AIMS APAC Reit (AA Reit) has signed a 12-year master lease with Optus Administration, a wholly-owned unit of Singtel Optus, for its Optus Centre property in Macquarie Park, Australia. The new lease commences on July 1, 2021, and includes an annual rental escalation of 3.25%. The agreement represents a 51.4% increase in AA Reit's implied value, with a pre-tax equity internal rate of return of 17% per annum. The property will provide an estimated net property income of A$28.3 million in the first year and A$36.5 million over the 12-year lease term.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by a cheaper yen and rallies in New York, as traders focused on US-China trade talks and the Hong Kong situation. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.80% and the Topix index increased 0.64%. The gains followed a similar trend in New York, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong democrats romp to local election landslide after months of protests
summary: Hong Kong's democrats secured a landslide victory in district council elections, winning over half of the 452 seats for the first time. The results came after six months of anti-government protests and record voter turnout. Democratic candidates defeated pro-establishment opponents, with some voting centers erupting in cheers and chants of "Liberate Hong Kong. Revolution Now." The outcome is seen as a symbolic victory for the pro-democracy movement, which has been pressing for greater autonomy and reform in the city.

site_title: China's Oct petrol exports hit record level on domestic fuel surplus
summary: China's October petrol exports reached a record 1.73 million tonnes, more than doubling from the same period last year, driven by a fuel surplus in the domestic market. The increase in petrol exports was largely offset by a decline in diesel exports, which fell to 1.19 million tonnes. Crude throughput rose to 13.62 million barrels per day in October, supporting exports. The surplus is seen as a sign of a slowing economy and fuel demand pressure in the domestic market.

site_title: Deadly rainstorms sweep northern Italy, southern France
summary: Deadly rainstorms swept northern Italy and southern France, killing three people and leaving two missing. In Italy, a motorway viaduct was washed away, and Venice was hit by knee-height floodwaters, causing damage to churches and prompting calls for improved flood protection. In France, two people died and at least one was missing as high floodwaters swamped cars and roads. The region has experienced a two-week wave of extreme weather, with over 4,500 households left without electricity.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report notes a week of value erosion in the Capesize market, but improved sentiment on Friday. The Baltic Dry Index has not been mentioned in this article, however, it is referenced in the "DRY BULK REPORT" section. The article does not provide a comprehensive summary of the dry bulk report or the Capesize market's value.

site_title: Grab eyes the unsung SMEs behind Fortune 500 heavyweights
summary: Grab, a fintech company, aims to provide financing to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Southeast Asia, particularly those in the food and beverage and retail segments. The company has rolled out loans to SMEs in Singapore and plans to expand to the Philippines and Thailand. Grab's approach uses data analysis to assess creditworthiness and provides flexible financing options, including cash-advance financing for Grab drivers. The company's goal is to fill the gap in supply chain financing for Fortune 500 companies and their distributors, which often have limited visibility into smaller distributors.

images.alt_text: Mr Lai (left) notes that banks are still looking to give SMEs a loan facility for a minimum of two years, when they just want working capital to tide over two weeks. Mr Mehrotra is betting that Grab's approach of monitoring the merchants' cashflow using data can give them a fighting chance.

site_title: EU plans 3.5b euro fund for startups in 'valley of death'
summary: The European Union plans a 3.5 billion euro fund to invest in early-stage deep tech startups, aiming to close the "valley of death" where science breakthroughs are needed but funding is scarce. The fund, set to launch in 2021, will provide equity and grant funding to firms in areas like manufacturing, biotechnology, and artificial intelligence. The EU hopes to make a significant impact with this fund, emulating traditional venture capital firms, and has received approval from investors like Index Ventures.

images.alt_text: The European Union (EU) is planning a 3.5 billion euro (S$5.26 billion) fund that will invest in early-stage technology in an effort to increase the pipeline of innovations that might someday take on giants in the US and China.

site_title: Singapore boosts training on developing 'smart estates' of the future
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture agency and Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) have partnered with CapitaLand, CPG Corporation, and EM Services to launch the Smart Estates Talent Development Programme (SETDP), aiming to train 300 Singaporeans to support the development of smart estates. The programme, which will start in 2020, will focus on skills such as design, development, and management of smart estates, and will be developed in collaboration with industry partners. The goal is to equip the workforce with relevant skills and competencies to seize opportunities in the built environment value-chain.

site_title: Bloomberg News to make editorial changes for owner's presidential run
summary: Bloomberg News will make editorial changes as it covers its owner, former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, in his presidential campaign. Editor-in-chief John Micklethwait cited the company's policy of not writing about itself or direct competitors, but will make case-by-case decisions. The agency will end unsigned editorials, suspend its editorial board, and explicitly state that Bloomberg News' owner is a candidate. The company will also not investigate the owner's family or foundations, but will publish investigative pieces on all Democratic candidates. Bloomberg is seen as a centrist challenger to President Donald Trump.

site_title: Airbnb queried by US Congress over listings that violate local laws
summary: US lawmakers are questioning Airbnb over listings that violate local laws and company policies. Six members of Congress, including Representatives from New Jersey, California, and Illinois, sent a letter to Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky, seeking information on how the company vets hosts and verifies rental listings. The lawmakers also expressed concern over deceptive listings that have led to customer scams. Airbnb has recently announced safety measures, including a 24/7 neighbor hotline and 100% verification of listings, amid regulatory issues with various cities across the US.

site_title: Nine firms get social enterprise grants worth S$1.3m from DBS
summary: DBS Bank's DBS Foundation awarded nine regional social enterprises grants totaling S$1.3 million. The grants, launched in 2015, support businesses that drive social impact and sustainability. Winners include NamZ, a food science startup promoting sustainable agriculture; reach52, an app-based health data platform; and Agape Connecting People, a job placement service for disadvantaged individuals. The grants will help the businesses scale up operations, expand market reach, and increase their impact on society.

site_title: The growing allure of Black Friday sales
summary: Black Friday sales are gaining popularity in Singapore, with major department stores like Robinsons experiencing a 25% increase in footfall along Orchard Road in 2018 compared to the previous year. Retailers may consider extending their operating hours to attract more customers, as shoppers stayed up later on Black Friday. The event brought higher footfall than the average footfall during the lead-up to Christmas, indicating a strong draw for consumers in Singapore.

site_title: Alibaba's Hong Kong share sale presents a US$43b dilemma
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has raised US$11.2 billion in its Hong Kong share sale, leaving it with a total of US$43 billion in cash. CEO Daniel Zhang and CFO Maggie Wu must decide how to utilize the funds, with three options: sitting on the cash, spending it on acquisitions and marketing, or returning it through dividends or buybacks. Historically, Alibaba has used the funds for marketing and acquisitions, which has depressed margins. The company's return on capital is 19.7%, and it has a precedent for using buybacks to prop up its stock, as seen in Apple's US$100 billion buyback in 2018.

site_title: Leaked documents show operations of prison camps in China's Xinjiang
summary: Leaked documents reveal the strict protocols governing life in China's Xinjiang detention camps, where over 1 million Uighurs and Muslim minorities are held. The guidelines, approved by the security chief in 2017, dictate daily activities such as haircuts, cell phone usage, and door locks, with full video surveillance and a points system to measure "ideological transformation." The documents show detainees are barred from contacting the outside world and must stay in detention for at least one year. China's embassy rejects the documents as "pure fabrication and fake news," but rights groups and experts say the evidence confirms widespread human rights abuses.

site_title: Conservative tipped to win presidential runoff in Uruguay
summary: Uruguay's long-dominant leftist ruling party, the Broad Front, faced defeat in a presidential election runoff as conservative candidate Luis Lacalle Pou is likely to win. Lacalle Pou, a senator and leader of the National Party, trailed the ruling candidate in the first round but secured a majority in Congress and a significant lead in the run-off. A win for the right would reflect a trend in the region of voters rejecting the incumbent party due to disappointing results, citing economic stagnation, high unemployment, and rising crime.

site_title: How to keep yourself in demand
summary: To remain relevant in the fast-paced digital age, finance professionals must acquire skills that make them "in-demand" and adaptable. Employers and recruiters seek exposure to change, reengineering, and disruptive organizations. Finance professionals must become digitally aware, possess industry trends knowledge, and have an informed opinion. Advanced qualifications, such as post-graduate degrees or micro-credentials, can help finance professionals upskill and enhance their strategic tools, concepts, and perspectives. Choosing a reputable provider and qualification is crucial, and a well-designed curriculum that allows for learning at one's own pace is essential.

site_title: Pope to comfort victims of Japan's 2011 'triple disaster'
summary: Pope Francis will visit survivors of Japan's 2011 "triple disaster" - earthquake, tsunami, and Fukushima nuclear meltdown - on the penultimate day of his trip to Japan. The disaster killed nearly 16,000 people and displaced 50,000, with many more dying from complications related to evacuations. Pope Francis will hold Mass in Tokyo's Tokyo Dome and meet with Japan's Emperor and Prime Minister, while also considering a meeting with people on death row to criticize Japan's death penalty. The trip comes after Francis' emotional visits to Nagasaki and Hiroshima, where he denounced nuclear deterrence and the use of nuclear power as a weapon.

site_title: Money Hacks podcast: Mortgage loans 101 (Ep 59)
summary: In the Money Hacks podcast (Ep 59), host The Business Times breaks down actionable financial tips on understanding mortgage loans. Guest Cris Ng, head of mortgage at Moneysmart.sg, discusses misconceptions about mortgage loans, floating vs fixed mortgage rates, and tips for first-timers, upgraders, and seasoned investors. Refinancing is often overlooked by Singaporeans, and upgraders can approach mortgage decisions by "decoupling". The episode aims to provide actionable financial tips for listeners, emphasizing the importance of consulting a financial adviser before making any investment decisions.

site_title: UK, Chinese visitors top list as 50,000 holiday in Saudi Arabia after restrictions ease
summary: Saudi Arabia has attracted 50,000 visitors since its September launch, with British and Chinese tourists being the top visitors, followed by those from other countries. The country has seen almost three times that number apply for tourist visas, with 140,000 requests made. Officials say the numbers are in line with expectations, but acknowledge that there is still a long way to go to compete with established destinations like Dubai. The government has loosened social restrictions to attract visitors, but plans to maintain conservative Islamic laws.

images.alt_text: King Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud (left) and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman attending the inauguration on Nov 21 of the Diriyah Gate, the revamp of the historic hometown of the Saudi royal family.

site_title: Greek peach farmers' desperation growing over extreme weather
summary: Greek peach farmers are struggling due to extreme weather conditions exacerbated by climate change. Unseasonably warm November weather and unusual rainfall patterns have led to crop damage, with nearly 1.5 million hectares of crops affected since 2011. The impact of US President Donald Trump's trade wars, including tariffs on Greek exports, is also taking a toll on farmers like Makis Antoniadis, who is considering alternative crops. Experts warn that urgent global action is needed to address climate change, as farmers are already suffering from disastrous production in recent years.

site_title: Bank of Thailand 'ready to act' if GDP growth disappoints
summary: The Bank of Thailand is prepared to use monetary policy if economic growth disappoints, its governor Veerathai Santiprabhob said. The central bank cut borrowing costs to 1.25% earlier this month and eased rules on capital outflows to slow the local currency's appreciation. The baht is Asia's best-performing currency, but the governor warned against taking the benchmark interest rate below zero, citing structural problems. The Bank of Thailand is monitoring the situation closely, particularly as the end of the year approaches, and is considering ways to boost policy transmission through new players or financial markets.

site_title: Duque opens Colombia talks following protests: official
summary: Colombian President Ivan Duque initiated a national dialogue with mayors and officials to address nationwide protests sparked by his government's policies, following three deaths and nearly 300 injuries during the unrest. Protesters demand a crackdown on drug trafficking, improved labor market conditions, and better retirement benefits. Duque has been criticized for his economic, social, and security policies, and the talks aim to assuage popular anger. The dialogue will involve various sectors, including business owners and workers, and is seen as a response to the protests that descended into violence.

images.alt_text: President Ivan Duque, the target of unprecedented anti-government protests in Colombia, on Sunday opened a national dialogue aimed at assuaging popular anger.

site_title: Hong Kong democrats score landslide victory in local elections amid political crisis
summary: In Hong Kong's local elections, pro-democracy candidates secured a landslide victory, winning over half of the 452 district council seats for the first time. With a record turnout of over 71% of 2.94 million voters, the pro-democracy camp secured at least 283 seats, compared to about 32 for the pro-establishment camp. The results are seen as a symbolic majority and a vote of support for the protest movement, potentially increasing pressure on Hong Kong's pro-Beijing chief executive Carrie Lam amid the city's worst political crisis in decades.

site_title: Money FM podcast: AI ethics - avoiding bias in algorithms
summary: A recent Money FM podcast discussed AI ethics, specifically avoiding bias in algorithms. The topic gained attention after Goldman Sachs' Apple-branded credit card was found to show bias against female applicants. Asheesh Mehra, co-founder of AntWorks, joined the discussion. The conversation highlighted the importance of addressing bias in AI systems to ensure fair decision-making. This issue has been raised by various organizations, including Singapore's Nanyang Technological University, which launched an AI and Digital Innovation office to foster design AI skills in students.

site_title: Johnson unveils manifesto for Brexit Britain
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson unveiled the Conservative Party's general election manifesto, promising to take the country out of the EU by January 31 and reinvigorating public services. The manifesto includes a Brexit deal negotiated with Brussels, tax cuts, and increased spending on public services such as healthcare, education, and the police. Johnson aims to secure a majority in the December 12 election to break the Brexit logjam, with polls suggesting the Conservatives are ahead of Labour. However, critics argue that the manifesto raises questions about the party's commitment to fiscal responsibility.

site_title: Record turnout of over 71% in Hong Kong local elections amid calls for full democracy
summary: Hong Kong residents voted in record numbers, with over 71% turnout in district council elections, amid calls for full democracy. The elections, seen as a test of support for Chief Executive Carrie Lam, were marked by attacks on candidates and pro-democracy protests. Pro-democracy candidates won several seats, with Jimmy Sham winning his contest, and pledged to continue fighting for democracy. The government, led by Lam, promised to listen to the views of district councils, but critics say Beijing's interference in Hong Kong's freedoms is a major concern.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong residents turned out in huge numbers on Sunday to vote in district council elections seen as a test of support for chief executive Carrie Lam following six months of pro-democracy protests, and polling took place with no major disruptions.

site_title: Lowest-rated junk bonds slump as others win
summary: The junk bond market, specifically CCC-rated debt, has seen a significant slump as investors demand higher yields to lend to companies such as McDermott International Inc and Frontier Communications Corp. The spreads in this tier of debt have breached 1,000 basis points for the first time in over three years. However, this event is largely isolated and not indicative of a broader market downturn, with the overall junk bond market tilting towards higher-quality debt. Defaults in leveraged debt markets have spiked, but the breach of 1,000 basis points is not seen as a sign of an impending reckoning.

site_title: Procurri accepts non-binding US$115m offer for business unit
summary: Procurri Corp has accepted a non-binding US$115m offer from Park Place to buy its third-party hardware maintenance business. The deal is subject to approval from Park Place's board of managers and equity fund majority owners, as well as regulatory requirements. Procurri's board notes that the letter of intent is not legally binding and there is no certainty the transaction will materialize. Trading in Procurri's shares has resumed after being halted in early November.

site_title: Grab heads into 2020 with wealth ambitions
summary: Grab is expanding its financial services, aiming to tap the trillion-dollar wealth market in South-east Asia by offering low-cost investment products. The company will partner or invest in existing wealth platforms, starting with simple cash products like money-market funds, and will consider global options. Grab has hired a former BlackRock executive to run its investment and new businesses unit, with a focus on transparent and low-fee models. The company's GrabPay wallet has seen significant growth, and it plans to launch a Mastercard virtual debit card in Singapore and the Philippines, allowing users to top up funds and spend online.

site_title: Aramco markets IPO in Dubai after talks with Kuwait fund
summary: Saudi Aramco marketed its initial public offering (IPO) in Dubai after talks with Kuwait's sovereign wealth fund, aiming for a deal worth up to $25.6 billion. The company's top executives met with investors in Dubai and Kuwait, seeking demand from sovereign investors including the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority and Singapore's GIC. Aramco has struggled to attract a major cornerstone investor, with some investors questioning the sustainability of its dividend policy. The Saudi government's fiscal policy and ability to sustain dividends are seen as key factors in investor comfort.

site_title: Asean tourism getting a lift from geopolitical tensions in North-east Asia: ANZ
summary: Asean tourism is experiencing a boost due to geopolitical tensions in North-east Asia, with travelers preferring destinations in Asean over those in North-east Asia. Hong Kong, China, Taiwan, and Japan-South Korea relations are dampening tourism in North-east Asia, while Vietnam, the Philippines, and Thailand are benefiting from increased tourism from mainland Chinese tourists. Thailand and Vietnam are expected to receive the highest growth boost, while Hong Kong will suffer the largest adverse impact on growth. The trend is expected to persist into 2020.

site_title: Upbeat data lifts US$; trade doubts linger
summary: The US dollar rose against a basket of currencies, driven by data showing US factory and services activity quickened in November. The dollar index was up 0.24% at 98.23, while the euro fell 0.28% against the dollar. Despite this, the dollar's strength was mixed due to ongoing trade doubts between the US and China, with Chinese President Xi Jinping expressing a willingness to work out a deal. The dollar's resilience also contrasts with a weaker pound, which fell 0.6% against the dollar.

site_title: 146,000 orders for Tesla Cybertruck two days after shattering reveal
summary: Tesla has received 146,000 pre-orders for its Cybertruck two days after its unveiling, with 42% opting for the dual-motor option and 41% for the triple-motor option. The single-motor version is less popular, with only 17% of orders. The company's website allows customers to place a fully refundable $100 deposit, which is cheaper than the $1,000 required to reserve a Model 3 sedan. The high demand for the Cybertruck comes despite a sharp decline in Tesla's shares after the truck's polarizing reveal.

site_title: SGX green-lights Yoma Strategic's Ayala share placement
summary: Yoma Strategic, a Myanmar-focused investment holding company, has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange to list a tranche of new shares to Philippine conglomerate Ayala Corp. The deal, worth US$237.5 million, sees Ayala taking a 20% stake in Yoma Strategic and its affiliate First Myanmar Investment Public Co. Yoma Strategic's chairman Serge Pun will retain a minimum 25% stake. The placement will be used to fund real estate investments, debt refinancing, and consumer businesses.

site_title: US meat producers want a slice of vegan market
summary: Traditional US meat producers, including JBS, Tyson Foods, and Hormel Foods, are entering the growing vegan market with plant-based products. The companies aim to capitalize on the success of alternative meat companies like Beyond Meat and Impossible Burger, targeting the 95% of consumers who eat meat rather than vegetarians. They focus on health benefits, such as incorporating more plants and vegetables into diets, rather than environmental or animal rights arguments. This shift is seen as a response to changing consumer preferences and a growing demand for plant-based alternatives.

site_title: Stocks may see tepid week ahead of Thanksgiving
summary: Singapore's stock market may experience a tepid week ahead of Thanksgiving, with investors focusing on US-China trade uncertainty and economic reports. The US financial markets will be closed on Thursday and Friday, and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell will speak on Monday night. Economic reports, including October trade and consumer spending data, are expected to be released.

site_title: Tiny German oil firm strikes black gold on the Rhine
summary: A small German oil firm, Rhein Petroleum, has struck black gold on the Rhine River, producing unusually pure crude oil. The company, founded in 2007, is now exploiting inland fields in southern Germany, where oil extraction was previously unprofitable. With prices above $60 per barrel, margins are more promising, and the company is using advanced technology to explore and extract hydrocarbon reserves. Despite environmental concerns, Rhein Petroleum has avoided hydraulic fracking and is exploring alternative uses for its oil, including manufacturing industries and wind turbine blades.

site_title: London property sales still healthy as buyers seek bargains
summary: London's residential property market remains active, with buyers seeking bargains ahead of the Dec 12 general election. Despite concerns over the election's impact, foreign buyers are taking advantage of discounts due to sterling's 25% decline since 2014, and first-time British buyers are benefiting from low interest rates, with some borrowing up to five times their salaries. The market is expected to be resilient, with recent rises in activity, and prices in cheaper northern cities rising slightly, while prime London areas continue to decline.

site_title: Herd of pound bulls sees currency's potential unleashed in 2020
summary: Analysts predict the pound will rise to US$1.35 by year-end if the Tories win the UK election, and potentially US$1.39 by the end of 2020. Funds are betting on the currency to strengthen as Boris Johnson's party gains a lead in polls. A Brexit deal is seen as crucial to the pound's rally, with Bank of America Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs expecting gains of over 4% versus the euro by the end of the first quarter. However, some investors remain cautious, citing longer-term economic threats.

site_title: Frozen II: How to make the new creatures appealing and enchanting marvels of design
summary: The filmmakers behind Frozen II aimed to create fresh and enchanting characters to propel Elsa's next adventure. To symbolize fire, wind, and water, the designers leaned into high-end cuteness, using blue-and-fuchsia colors, galloping strength, and invisible effects. For the fire spirit, Bruni, they chose a surreal, magenta-colored salamander, while the water spirit, Nokk, was designed to appear as a horse made of water, with a separation between its ocean-like hindquarters and its horse-like forequarters and face. The team aimed to create characters that would evoke a sense of magic and empowerment, particularly for Elsa.

site_title: China to raise penalties on IP theft in trade war compromise
summary: China plans to increase penalties for intellectual property rights violations as part of a trade war compromise with the US. The country aims to reduce frequent IP theft by 2022 and make it easier for victims to receive compensation. China will also lower thresholds for criminal punishments for IP theft and require local governments to implement stronger IP rights. The move is part of a partial trade deal between the two countries, with more contentious issues to be discussed later. China's goal is to strengthen IPR protection, boosting its economic competitiveness.

site_title: China selling surveillance tech by touting its long experience
summary: China is showcasing its surveillance technology at a Paris homeland security trade show, capitalizing on its vast experience in developing such systems. With 89 out of 1,100 companies participating, China is the best-represented nation at the event, despite concerns over the technology's use to violate human rights. Beijing aims to conquer the global market with its surveillance tech, which has raised concerns about its potential misuse.

site_title: Analysts less negative about Singapore's July-Sept earnings
summary: Analysts are less negative about Singapore's July-Sept earnings, with nearly one-third of public companies posting losses, while 314 were profitable. Net profits were 12% lower than the previous year, and total revenue fell 1%. Singtel posted a record quarterly loss, but other blue-chip companies, such as DBS and UOB, outperformed expectations. The retail and industrial sectors saw strong distribution and net property income growth, respectively. Analysts expect the October-December quarter to be less negative, with potential improvements in US-China trade sentiment and sustained growth in the technology and S-Reits sectors.

site_title: Canada's use of Huawei 5G 'puts US intel sharing at risk'
summary: US National Security Adviser Robert O'Brien warned Canada against using Huawei 5G technology, citing the risk of compromising intelligence sharing with the US and exposing Canadians to Chinese government profiling. O'Brien stated that Huawei's 5G equipment could contain back doors allowing access to sensitive data, including health records and social media posts. Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau postponed a decision on Huawei's 5G use until after the federal election. The US, Australia, and New Zealand have banned Huawei's 5G equipment, while Britain has taken a less firm stance.

site_title: Commitment and conviction
summary: Business leaders emphasize the importance of incorporating giving into their operations and strategies to build trust, attract top talent, and drive sustainable growth. Many companies see opportunities to make a positive impact through initiatives such as responsible procurement, volunteering, and charitable donations. Despite challenges, leaders can leverage their core competencies to create practical, market-based solutions that benefit society. A survey by the National Volunteer & Philanthropy Centre found that 64% of givers have integrated giving into their core business functions, resulting in benefits such as higher employee morale and leadership, and improved retention rates.

site_title: French gourmands find sake hits the spot when Burgundy or Bordeaux don't
summary: French gourmands are discovering the appeal of sake, with imports increasing by 160% between 2012 and 2017. Entrepreneurs, such as Takuma Inagawa, are capitalizing on this trend by producing French sake in wine-growing regions like Burgundy and Bordeaux. Experts predict the market will grow five-fold over the next decade, driven by a "sushi boom" and a desire for sustainable, locally-sourced drinks. French sommeliers have adopted sake as a high-end product, praising its versatility and ability to pair well with French cuisine.

site_title: Fullerton Hotel's charity dinner raises money for BT BAF
summary: A Christmas-themed charity buffet dinner was held at The Fullerton Hotel Singapore, with proceeds benefiting The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund. Ambassadors from six countries participated, whipping up specialty dishes, and a candle-lit march-in and light-up ceremony took place. Over 100 hotel staff and local celebrities attended, with the event also featuring performances by handbell ringers and youths from BT BAF. The final amount raised was not disclosed, but a portion of hotel sales and Santa bear sales were donated to the charities.

site_title: Singapore signs MOU with South Korea on cybersecurity cooperation
summary: Singapore has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with South Korea to enhance cybersecurity cooperation and information-sharing. The agreement was signed by Singapore's chief cybersecurity officer and South Korea's internet security president, witnessed by Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and South Korea's President Moon Jae-in. This marks Singapore's 9th international cybersecurity agreement, as the city-state aims to restructure its economy and position itself as a global innovation hub.

site_title: Temasek backs plan for Osram takeover by Austria's AMS
summary: Singapore's Temasek backs Austria's AMS' planned $5 billion takeover of German lighting group Osram, citing the "coming together" of the two companies in opto-electronics. Despite AMS' previous bid falling short, the company has offered to protect jobs and lowered the acceptance threshold to secure the deal. Osram shareholders have until Dec 5 to accept the offer, and Temasek's managing director Uwe Krueger has stated he will not get involved in business decisions. The move is seen as a strategic investment in the field of opto-electronics.

site_title: Ezion to offload 2 loss-making firms to cut costs, streamline assets
summary: Ezion Holdings, an offshore and marine service provider, plans to offload two loss-making firms by November 30 to cut costs and streamline assets. The company will sell its stake in Strategic Offshore Ltd for a nominal sum of US$1 and jettison its 30% stake in Rotating Offshore Solutions Pte Ltd through a share buyback deal. The disposals aim to reduce operational costs and improve the efficient use of capital and cash flow. Ezion expects to receive S$3 million and deferred cash payments from ROS.

site_title: Hotel pricing in Tokyo heats up ahead of 2020 Olympics and Paralympics
summary: Tokyo hotel prices are skyrocketing ahead of the 2020 Olympics and Paralympics, with some rooms increasing in price by as much as four times the usual levels. The Games' organising committee has cancelled some reserved rooms, causing fluctuating accommodation fees and creating a headache for spectators from afar. Hotel prices in central Tokyo are now over 100,000 yen (S$1,300) per night, making it difficult for many to afford. The number of hotels opening in Tokyo is expected to increase, with over 150 hotels anticipated to open by next year, adding to the accommodation shortage.

site_title: Aircraft industry's grand masters fight to a draw in Dubai
summary: Emirates, a major airline, has been forced to adjust its fleet due to the cancellation of the A380 program, resulting in a stalemate between Airbus and Boeing. Emirates placed an order for 50 Airbus A350s and 30 Boeing 787-9 Dreamliners, while canceling orders for the A330neo and 777X jets. The shift to smaller planes may lead to overcapacity in the industry, with analysts estimating a reduction of 18,000 seats on order. The changes reflect the changing travel demand landscape, with smaller planes offering more choice and frequencies for passengers.

images.alt_text: Models of the Airbus 350 and 330 displayed at the Dubai Airshow in Dubai last week. Emirates Airline says that it will buy 50 A350 aircraft while cutting its remaining orders for A380s.

site_title: Entrepreneurs urged to be progressive, stay nimble, competitive
summary: Entrepreneurs in Singapore have been urged to remain progressive and competitive in the face of a challenging economy. The Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME) and the Rotary Club presented the 31st Entrepreneur of the Year Award, recognizing Rachel Wong and Collin Ang for their innovative approaches to their respective industries. Despite a slowdown, Manpower Minister Josephine Teo noted that some sectors are showing growth, and the government is working to support businesses. The event highlighted the need for entrepreneurs to adapt and implement strategies to stay ahead in the future economy.

site_title: Bulls rushing into Canada's 'Big Six' banks with C$52b surge
summary: Canada's "Big Six" banks have experienced a C$52 billion surge in value, with shares climbing 12% over the last three months, almost doubling the rally in the country's benchmark equity index. The strong economic data and absence of interest rate cuts have contributed to the market gains, with analysts predicting an average 4% increase in adjusted earnings-per-share in the upcoming fiscal fourth-quarter results. This growth has been driven by housing and services, with inflation on target, according to Bank of Canada governor Stephen Poloz.

site_title: Challenges are part and parcel of the path to success: Nam Cheong chief
summary: Singapore Exchange-listed offshore support vessel (OSV) builder Nam Cheong's CEO Leong Seng Keat believes challenges are essential to success, citing his own career as an example. He joined Nam Cheong in 2005 after a stint in the IT sector and expanded the company's international presence. The company's build-to-stock strategy has delivered over 140 vessels, but it also carries a high-risk stigma. Despite the industry slump, Nam Cheong has successfully concluded its debt restructuring exercise and is now focused on diversifying income streams and growing chartering revenues.

images.alt_text: The industry is in the throes of the post-peak oil era, following the emergence of newer technologies such as renewable energy and electric vehicles, says Nam Cheong CEO Leong Seng Keat.

site_title: EU plans 3.5b-euro fund for 'valley of death' startups
summary: The European Union plans a 3.5 billion-euro fund to invest in early-stage technology startups in the "valley of death," a phase where breakthroughs need costly and risky research and development before a product can become viable. The fund, set to launch in 2021, will provide equity and grant funding to firms in deep tech areas such as manufacturing, biotechnology, and artificial intelligence. This move aims to close the investment gap and support innovation, following a surge in venture capital investments in European tech.

images.alt_text: The European Union is planning a 3.5 billion-euro (S$5.3 billion) fund that will invest in early stage technology in an effort to increase the pipeline of innovations that might someday take on giants in the US and China.

site_title: ISEC Healthcare offer deemed 'not fair but reasonable': CIMB Bank
summary: CIMB Bank has deemed ISEC Healthcare's mandatory offer as "not fair but reasonable". The S$0.36-a-share cash offer, triggered by Aier Eye International's 35% stake purchase, is a 5.88% premium over the last trading day's closing price. Despite considering the company's increasing dividend payout ratio and financial performance, CIMB deemed the offer price not fair due to the high premium paid by the selling shareholders, who hold 23.8% of the company. The offer closes on Dec 6.

site_title: Lagarde's ECB presidency marks period of transition
summary: Christine Lagarde's presidency at the European Central Bank (ECB) marks a period of transition, with no immediate drastic changes in ECB policies. The EURUSD is influenced by ECB's quantitative easing and the US-China trade deal, which may impact the USD. The EURUSD is in a downward equidistant channel, but has potential for intraday upward movements. A break above the current resistance level could lead to a test of the top of the band, while a hold could result in a test of the sub 1.09 levels.

site_title: Alibaba's Hong Kong listing attracts 200,000 retail buyers
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd's Hong Kong share sale has attracted around 200,000 retail investors, making it the most popular listing of the year by subscriber count. The retail portion was more than 40 times oversubscribed. This surpasses the number of retail buyers for Ping An Healthcare and Technology Company Ltd and China Literature Ltd during their initial public offerings.

site_title: Hatten Land's S$5.1m share placement deadline extended to Nov 29
summary: Hatten Land, a Catalist-listed developer, has extended the deadline for its S$5.1 million share placement to November 29, after the placee, Kingpin Investment Pte Ltd, requested more time to complete the placement. The placement, which priced shares at S$0.09 apiece, aims to finance development projects and general expenses. A referral fee of S$254,250 will be paid to businessman Tan Chin Tuan in cash instead of shares, as previously agreed. The company's shares closed at S$0.09 on Friday.

site_title: Director filings rise as earnings season ends
summary: Singapore's earnings season has ended with a decline in the Straits Times Index (STI) of 1.2% over the past five trading sessions. Director and substantial shareholder transactions increased, with 50 primary-listed stocks reporting over 120 changes in director interests and substantial shareholdings. Notable transactions include ESR Cayman Ltd's acquisition of AIMS APAC Reit units, CSE Global deputy chairman Mohd Abdul Karim bin Abdullah's disposal of shares, and Roxy-Pacific Holdings' executive chairman Teo Hong Lim's increased stake. Other notable transactions include United Global's executive director Jacky Tan Thuan Hor's acquisition of shares, GL substantial shareholder Quek Leng Chan's increased stake, and Bonvests Holdings chairman Henry Ngo's increased deemed interest.

site_title: Trump, Republicans give voice to Ukraine conspiracy theories
summary: US President Donald Trump and his Republican supporters are giving renewed attention to debunked conspiracy theories surrounding Ukraine, claiming it interfered in the 2016 presidential election and not Russia. Analysts warn this could have damaging long-term consequences for American democracy, as conspiracy theories can spread among both parties. Experts say the popularity of these theories has increased since Trump's election, with many Americans believing in unfounded claims, and that fact-checking has limited impact on those with strong convictions.

site_title: Japan, South Korea foreign ministers to meet after pact rescue
summary: South Korean Foreign Minister Kang Kyung-wha is set to meet her Japanese counterpart, Toshimitsu Motegi, in Nagoya after Seoul reversed its decision to sever a military information pact with Japan. The pact's expiration was postponed, leaving unresolved disputes over Japan's 1910-1945 occupation of the Korean Peninsula and export controls. Public opinion polls show neither South Korean President Moon Jae-in nor Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has a political incentive to reduce tensions, with Moon facing a parliamentary election and Abe struggling with a scandal.

site_title: China's October pork imports double from a year ago
summary: China's pork imports in October doubled to 177,426 tonnes, up 10.9% from the previous month, amid a 41% decline in the world's top pig herd due to African swine fever. This surge in imports has pushed retail pork prices up 148% to almost 59 yuan (S$11.43) per kg, contributing to food inflation. China has been increasing pork imports from countries like Brazil, Argentina, and Italy to alleviate its protein shortage, with beef and chicken imports also rising significantly.

site_title: Stocks likely to shadow US-China diplomatic moves
summary: US stocks are expected to continue shadowing diplomatic moves between the US and China, despite hopes for a trade deal. The "phase one" deal, signed in a possible phase one of the phase one deal, is unlikely to be finalized by the end of 2019, with further delays to tariffs possibly occurring. The economic picture remains mixed, with a survey showing American business activity picked up in November, but regional and international factory reports remaining in negative territory. Market nerves are evident, with the price of Bitcoin falling sharply and junk bonds seeing their "spreads" blow out to one of the widest levels of the current cycle.

images.alt_text: Retailers such as JCPenney, Kohl's and Macy's paint a picture that is familiar to anyone who has wandered around a US suburban mall in recent months - consumer desertion.

site_title: China envoy warns of 'very bad damage' if Canada follows US lead on Hong Kong
summary: China's new ambassador to Canada, Cong Peiwu, warned Ottawa against backing Hong Kong protesters, saying it would cause "very bad damage" to relations. Canada has expressed concern over the safety of its citizens in Hong Kong, while the US House of Representatives passed bills backing protesters. Cong demanded Canada's immediate release of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou, who is out on bail. Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau urged de-escalation and dialogue, but Cong criticized Canada for not taking action to stop Hong Kong rioters.

images.alt_text: China's new ambassador to Canada on Friday warned Ottawa not to follow the US lead and formally back protesters in Hong Kong, saying such a move would cause "very bad damage" to already poor ties with Beijing.

site_title: Putin to address Russia's crisis-hit ruling party
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin will address the United Russia convention, amid a crisis for the ruling party due to low popularity and mounting economic troubles. The party, established in 2001, has a constitutional majority in parliament but its rating hovers just above a record low of 32%. Analysts say the Kremlin needs to implement a rescue plan, but rule out major reforms. Putin's appearance at the convention aims to boost the party's ratings and signal his involvement, while analysts believe the Kremlin underestimates the party's crisis and its potential for change.

site_title: Pope departs Thailand for Japan, bringing anti-nuclear message
summary: Pope Francis departed Thailand on Saturday, heading to Japan for a three-day visit, where he will focus on his anti-nuclear campaign. He will visit the ground zeros of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, meeting blast survivors and praying at the bomb epicentre. Pope Francis wants a total ban on nuclear weapons, going further than his predecessors, and will meet Japan's "hidden christians" and survivors of the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster. The visit aims to raise awareness about the devastating effects of nuclear weapons and promote disarmament in a country that relies on the US nuclear umbrella for deterrence.

site_title: Agility, talent retention key to JK Tech's success
summary: JK Tech, a Singapore-based IT solutions provider, has achieved 25% compounded growth in its bottom line for the last three years, driven by a diverse customer base. The company's success is attributed to its Device as a Service (DaaS) contracts, which offer a single yearly fee for equipment leasing and maintenance services. JK Tech's DaaS segment is expected to grow to 15% of its business over the next two years. The company's biggest challenge is retaining staff, with a focus on building a strong team and offering creative incentives to motivate employees.

images.alt_text: Mr Ang's passion for serving customers and providing for his employees has kept him going through the ups and downs in the past 29 years of JK Tech's operations.

site_title: Netflix internal data signals users aren't fleeing to Disney
summary: Netflix's internal data suggests the streaming giant hasn't seen a significant increase in subscriber cancellations despite the launch of rival services from Disney and Apple. External data from Google searches and market tracker Sensor Tower Inc also support this, indicating Netflix is holding its ground in attracting new customers. Netflix shares rose 1.3% following the news, and the company expects to add over 25 million customers for the second year in a row. Despite new competition, Netflix remains confident in its growth prospects.

site_title: Jokowi orders shakeup of state energy giant to cut oil imports
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo ordered a shakeup of state-owned oil giant PT Pertamina to cut oil imports, aiming to reduce the current account deficit. Former Jakarta governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama will become president commissioner, while Emma Sri Martini will be chief financial officer. The changes aim to boost domestic oil production and processing, with plans to build new refineries and increase palm biodiesel production. The move is part of efforts to address a four-year high current account deficit and a declining oil production rate due to aging fields.

images.alt_text: In recent years, Pertamina has focused on taking over oil and gas fields from foreign firms whose licences have expired.

site_title: Amazon sues US over loss of pentagon cloud deal to Microsoft
summary: Amazon has filed a lawsuit against the US government, challenging the Defense Department's choice of Microsoft for a $10 billion Pentagon cloud-computing contract. The lawsuit, filed under seal, alleges that the government's decision would cause severe competitive harm to Amazon's business. Amazon claims that the government's decision contained sensitive information, trade secrets, and confidential financial data. This marks Amazon's most aggressive push to defend its competitive edge in federal government contracts.

site_title: Ex-Trump ally Bolton says Twitter account 'liberated' from White House control
summary: US President Donald Trump's former national security adviser John Bolton's Twitter account has been 'liberated' from White House control, Bolton announced on Friday.
