The account was previously taken over by the White House after Bolton's resignation in September. Twitter had returned control to Bolton after the White House refused to relinquish access. Bolton's return to the platform comes amid concerns over Trump's use of his personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani on Ukraine policy, which is under impeachment scrutiny.

site_title: Indonesia overhauls state energy giant to reduce oil imports
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has ordered an overhaul of state-owned oil giant PT Pertamina to reduce crude oil imports. Former Jakarta governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama will become president commissioner, while Emma Sri Martini will be chief financial officer. The move aims to cut oil and gas imports, which currently account for about 50% of Pertamina's total consumption, to address a 3% current-account deficit. The changes are part of a broader plan to boost domestic resource processing and increase export revenue, with the goal of reducing imports by half within three years.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo ordered an overhaul of the management of state-owned oil giant PT Pertamina, as the former Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) member seeks to reduce crude oil imports to rein in the current-account deficit.

site_title: All King Bibi's men: Netanyahu's inner circle key to criminal cases
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been charged with bribery, fraud, and breach of trust in three corruption cases. Investigations revealed secret recordings, illicit gifts, and a scheme to control his public image by trading regulatory favors for positive coverage. Netanyahu denies wrongdoing, calling the cases an "attempted coup" based on "fabrications." The cases involve his inner circle, including former chief of staff Ari Harow and media mogul Arnon Mozes, who provided testimony and have not been charged. Netanyahu faces a total of 10 counts, with evidence pointing to his involvement in regulatory moves benefiting his allies.

site_title: US: Wall St rises with US-China trade mood, upbeat economic data
summary: US stocks rose on Friday as President Trump and President Xi Jinping made positive comments on a potential trade deal, easing investor worries. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average posted their biggest daily gains in a lackluster week, with strong US manufacturing data and upbeat economic data contributing to the gains. Despite this, strategists remain cautious, citing uncertainty surrounding the trade deal and Trump's vague comments on signing or vetoing bills supporting protesters in Hong Kong.

site_title: Thousands gather for renewed Colombia protests, curfew called in Bogota
summary: Thousands of Colombians gathered in Bogota's Bolivar Plaza for renewed protests, marking the third day of demonstrations against President Ivan Duque's government. The protests, sparked by economic reforms and corruption, resulted in three deaths and widespread looting, including supermarkets and public buses. Authorities responded with tear gas, and a 9pm curfew was imposed on the city. The government has promised a national conversation to address social policies and fight corruption, but critics say the government's response has been inadequate.

site_title: Elon Musk says 'funding secured' has no universal meaning
summary: Elon Musk has argued that his "funding secured" tweet about taking Tesla private was not misleading, as it only meant that funding would be available if he decided to proceed with the transaction. Musk claims that investors misinterpreted the phrase, implying a formal agreement with specific terms. Tesla and Musk are seeking to dismiss a lawsuit filed by investors who claim the tweet was an act of fraud that cost them hundreds of millions of dollars. The company's filing states that Musk's words were neither false nor misleading at the time of the tweet.

site_title: Johnson promises 'sensible' tax cuts and spending plans
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has promised £23.5 billion worth of "sensible" tax cuts and increased spending, focusing on the health service, ahead of the December 12 election. The Conservative Party claims its plans will have minimal impact on the government's day-to-day budget until 2024. In contrast, the opposition Labour Party's plans for £83 billion in increased spending over the same period are seen as more radical. Johnson's finance minister, Sajid Javid, stated that Labour's plans are "reckless" and would harm investment in Britain.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, facing a Dec 12 election, promised £23.5 billion (S$41 billion) worth of "sensible" tax cuts and higher spending which he contrasted with the more radical plans of the opposition Labour Party.

site_title: WeWork is working on plan to reprice stock options
summary: WeWork is planning to reprice stock options held by employees, including those who have left or departed as part of a 2,400-layoff round, to a new strike price of US$4.12. This move aims to allow workers to still make potential future gains on their equity holdings. The company will offer an exchange offer to current and former employees to participate in the repricing of options at the new fair market value. The move may help SoftBank Group Corp reduce the size of its US$3 billion offer for WeWork stock, but it's unclear how it will affect the company's rescue package.

site_title: Campaigns pressure Facebook to stay put on political ads
summary: Facebook faces pressure from campaigns and organizations to limit how political ads target specific audiences, citing concerns it would harm smaller groups' fundraising and reach unregistered voters. The company is discussing potential changes, such as restricting ad targeting to 1,000 people, but has yet to make a final ruling. Google has already restricted ad targeting based on voter records, and Twitter has banned such ads. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has stated the company will run all political ads, despite concerns about free speech and disinformation.

site_title: Japan's Nov factory activity shrinks for 7th month, increasing economic strains
summary: Japan's factory activity shrank for a seventh consecutive month in November, with the Jibun Bank Flash Japan Manufacturing PMI reaching 48.6, below the 50.0 threshold. This marks the longest contraction since June 2012 to February 2013. The service sector saw a slight expansion, but it's insufficient to offset the industrial woes, with policymakers facing a challenge to prop up the economy growing at its slowest pace in a year.

site_title: High-profile deals mask slower year for GCBs
summary: High-profile deals in Singapore's Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market mask a slower year for the industry, with 34 deals totaling S$645.7 million in 2019, compared to 38 transactions worth S$933.3 million in the same period last year. The uncertain business backdrop and ongoing trade war are attributed to slower sales. Despite this, prices have stabilized, with some areas experiencing a 5% increase, while others, such as Bukit Timah, have softened. Experts expect transaction volume to remain steady in 2020, with demand driven by high-net-worth locals and newly minted citizens.

site_title: Nadal powers Spain into Davis Cup semis, Djokovic's Serbia ousted
summary: Rafael Nadal led Spain to a 2-1 victory over Argentina, securing a spot in the Davis Cup semi-finals. Nadal won his singles match 6-1, 6-2, then teamed with Marcel Granollers to beat Argentina in a must-win doubles match. Meanwhile, Britain eased into the semi-finals with a 2-0 win over Germany, while Russia defeated Serbia 6-4, 4-6, 7-6 (10/8) to reach the semi-finals, setting up a match against Canada.

site_title: Singapore, Asean can boost tourism with South Korea and collaborate in many areas: PM Lee
summary: Singapore and South Korea can boost tourism and collaborate in various areas, including the environment and fintech, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. During his visit, Lee emphasized the need to strengthen connectivity and people-to-people links between Asean and South Korea, particularly in the digital technology sector. The Asean-Republic of Korea (ROK) Commemorative Summit in Busan will mark the 30th anniversary of Asean-ROK dialogue relations, with Lee attending the summit from November 25 to 26.

site_title: WeWork names new executives, path to profitability by 2023: report
summary: WeWork has named four new executives, including Marcelo Claure as executive chairman, Maurice Levy as interim chief marketing and communications officer, and three others. The company outlined a six-point path to profitability, aiming to reach cash flow positivity by 2023. Claure emphasized WeWork's focus on member and employee experience, a "core differentiator" of the company. WeWork plans to concentrate on top 12 markets, explore revenue-sharing agreements with landlords, and expand in Asia and emerging markets through franchising and joint ventures.

site_title: Deliveroo rallies customers, riders, eateries to provide meals for elders in need
summary: Deliveroo partnered with charity organisation TOUCH Community Services to provide meals for elderly clients in need. From October 16 to November 15, customers could contribute a S$5 meal to elderly clients through the delivery app by selecting a meal option from three participating restaurants. This initiative aimed to give back to the community and provide essential meals to those in need.

site_title: Trump heads passionate debate on vaping, leaves issue unsettled
summary: US President Donald Trump held a White House debate on vaping, where he expressed interest in finding a solution to the issue affecting American youth. Trump initially considered banning flavored vaping products but has since eased off, instead focusing on a national vaping minimum age of 21. Industry representatives and medical professionals discussed the issue, with some arguing that flavors are targeting minors and others warning of job losses if a ban is implemented. The debate comes amid a growing public health crisis linked to vaping, with 2,290 illnesses and 47 deaths reported in the US since the summer.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump said Friday he was "here to listen" at a lively White House debate on the "very complex subject" of vaping and the impact of kid-friendly e-cigarette flavours on American youth.

site_title: Canadian official's critique of 737 MAX software reflects "working-level" view: regulator
summary: A Canadian Transport Canada official emailed Boeing officials, urging the removal of the MCAS anti-stall system involved in two 737 MAX crashes that killed 346 people. The email, described as a "working-level" discussion, was not reviewed by the Canadian regulator. Boeing is working to win regulatory approvals for proposed fixes to MCAS and associated pilot training, allowing the 737 MAX to fly again. The FAA and other regulators have engaged in discussions on the matter, but removing MCAS is seen as a "minor" risk, but not tolerated under aviation industry rules.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: UOL Group has accepted a bid of S$79.3 million to acquire the nine-storey commercial building in North Bridge Road, with plans to explore amalgamation with neighboring Odeon Towers and potential asset enhancement works. The property is on a 999-year lease and has a net lettable area of 22,075 sq ft. The legal completion of the purchase is expected on Dec 23.

site_title: Oil pulls back from 2-month highs on China trade worries
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday, retreating from two-month highs due to concerns over US-China trade talks. Brent crude futures eased to $63.44 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $57.89 a barrel. The uncertainty over a partial trade deal between the US and China kept prices in check, with Chinese President Xi Jinping saying his country wants to work out an initial trade pact. The OPEC+ production cuts are expected to continue, but the market is cautious about the demand outlook due to the ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Trump vague about whether he will veto bills that back Hong Kong protesters
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed uncertainty about whether he will sign or veto legislation supporting Hong Kong protesters, citing the ongoing trade deal with China. Trump claimed he prevented Beijing from crushing the protests with a million soldiers, stating it would have a "tremendous negative impact" on the trade deal. The legislation, which requires annual certification of Hong Kong's autonomy, would automatically become law if Trump does not sign or veto it by December 3. Despite this, lawmakers and some Republicans believe the bill would be overridden with a two-thirds majority vote in both the Senate and House.

site_title: Exploring the next frontier in healthcare
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) and digitalisation are revolutionizing the healthcare sector, enabling patient care to be reimagined and improved. The Singapore government is driving digitalisation efforts, with a focus on healthcare innovation and management. AI can analyse millions of medical data, enabling telehealth services and creating AI algorithms that can learn and improve healthcare data analysis. The digital twin technology has also been applied to human organs, such as the heart, allowing for virtual planning and simulation of physiological processes. Additionally, AI is being used in medical imaging to enable automated image labelling and more accurate diagnoses.

site_title: Throwing money out of helicopters
summary: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke's "helicopter money" concept, where money is directly distributed to citizens to boost aggregate demand, may be effective in stimulating the economy. Unlike quantitative easing, helicopter money bypasses banks and directly increases consumer spending. This approach could help inflate debt and alleviate deflation. However, the article does not provide specific details on the feasibility or implementation of helicopter money in practice.

site_title: Chinese defector provides intelligence trove to Australia: report
summary: A Chinese defector, Wang "William" Liqiang, has provided a significant intelligence trove to Australian officials, revealing China's involvement in spying operations in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Australia. Liqiang, who was involved in infiltration and disruption operations, shared details of China's covert control of listed companies to fund intelligence operations, including surveillance and profiling of dissidents. He also claimed to have infiltrated Taiwan and Hong Kong universities and media to counter pro-democracy movements. Liqiang, who faces execution if returned to China, has requested asylum in Australia and provided a sworn statement to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

site_title: Sibling pair that's lighting up the mixed martial arts scene
summary: Angela and Christian Lee, siblings and One Championship fighters, have achieved significant success in the mixed martial arts scene. Angela, the undisputed atomweight world champion, recently defeated Xiong Jingnan in Tokyo, while Christian, the lightweight world champion, won the lightweight world grand prix championship. The siblings, who have three world titles between them, are gearing up for another busy year in 2020, with plans to stay involved in One Championship events and compete for more titles.

images.alt_text: Angela Lee with her brother Christian, after both had won their bouts at the One: Century event in Tokyo on Oct 13. The siblings have had an incredible 2019 so far, and both are gearing up for another busy year.

site_title: Londoners are taking to canal boats to beat high property costs
summary: In London, where high property costs are a major issue, thousands of residents are opting for canal boats as an affordable alternative. Narrowboats, which can be moored for around £1,000 a year, offer a fraction of the cost of traditional housing. With over 4,200 boats currently in London, authorities are scrambling to create more moorings to meet demand. Boaters can choose from "continuous cruising" licenses, which allow them to move freely along the 100-mile canal network, or opt for more expensive permanent moorings. The trend is attracting a younger demographic, with many boaters citing the affordability and unique lifestyle as reasons for choosing canal living.

site_title: US existing home sales rise in October
summary: US existing home sales rose 1.9% in October to an annual rate of 5.5 million, matching analysts' expectations. Despite rising prices and tighter supplies, the sales recovery is attributed to low unemployment, rising wages, and low mortgage rates. Median home prices jumped 6.2% to $270,900, marking the 92nd straight month of price increases. Inventories fell 2.7% to 1.8 million units, representing a 3.9-month supply at the current sales rate.

site_title: Tesla's mocked cybertruck may be brilliant, car designer says
summary: Tesla's Cybertruck design, mocked for its unusual triangular roof and blocky lines, may be a brilliant marketing move, according to car designer Raphael Zammit. Despite initial shock and horror, Zammit sees the truck as a "no-compromise" design that could be the cheapest to manufacture, with minimal aesthetic investment. The vehicle's price tag of $39,000 and its extreme features, such as "bulletproof" glass, could appeal to customers in China and others seeking unique experiences. The Cybertruck's polarizing design may serve Tesla well in marketing and manufacturing, potentially allowing the company to pull a profit on the lowest model.

site_title: Tories plan extra land tax for foreign buyers of UK homes
summary: The UK's Conservative government plans to introduce a 3% land tax surcharge on foreign buyers of UK homes to curb demand and keep house prices in check. The tax, on top of existing stamp duty, is expected to raise £120 million annually and be used to fund homelessness programs. The move aims to address the issue of non-resident buyers inflating house prices and making it harder for first-time buyers to enter the market. The policy is part of the party's efforts to address the housing shortage ahead of the general election.

site_title: San Teh offer crosses 90% shareholding threshold; compulsory acquisition next
summary: The Kao family, led by San Teh directors and executives, has completed a cash offer to acquire 100% of the company's shares at S$0.28 apiece. With 95.38% of shares acquired, the offeror has crossed the 90% shareholding threshold, triggering a compulsory acquisition. San Teh's shares were suspended on Friday morning after the offeror acquired the necessary threshold. The Kao family aims to gain greater control and management flexibility, allowing for strategic initiatives and operational changes.

site_title: Eurozone output almost stalled in November: survey
summary: The eurozone's economy is seen to have "near-stalled" in November, according to a survey by IHS Markit, following months of manufacturing decline. Heightened geopolitical uncertainty, including Brexit, trade wars, and auto tariffs, contributed to the slowdown. Expectations for future output remain low, reflecting general concerns about slowing demand. This marks the latest in a series of disappointing economic indicators for the region.

site_title: Shares recover on Friday, end 0.4% down on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,225.65, up 33.44 points or 1.1% on Friday, as Asian markets recovered from trade worries. The STI dipped 0.4% on the week. Other Asian markets, such as Australia, Hong Kong, Japan, and Taiwan, also posted gains, while China closed lower. The market's recovery was attributed to conciliatory news reports on a US-China trade agreement.

site_title: ICE to launch Bitcoin futures contract in Singapore on Dec 9
summary: ICE plans to launch a Bitcoin futures contract in Singapore on Dec 9, the Bakkt Bitcoin cash settled monthly futures contract, which will be listed on ICE Futures Singapore and cleared by ICE Clear Singapore. The contract will be settled in US dollars and offers investors a convenient way to gain or hedge exposure in bitcoin markets. The launch comes as the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) consults on allowing the trading of derivatives, including payment tokens like Bitcoin, on approved exchanges.

site_title: 'Tis the season to be money savvy
summary: As the year-end approaches, Singaporeans are encouraged to review their financial decisions and plan for the future. The Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) offers tax relief for contributions made before Dec 31, while the Retirement Sum Topping-up Scheme allows individuals to build their retirement savings. Reviewing healthcare costs and housing loans is also crucial, with options to manage these commitments and consider refinancing or downgrading plans. Experts advise investing wisely and taking advantage of tax savings, while also considering the impact of rising healthcare costs and potential changes in the economy.

site_title: Banks breathe life into scrapped bond sales in red hot market
summary: Banks are experiencing a resurgence in bond sales, with European high-yield bond sales reaching a record €9 billion in November and US high-yield sales on pace for their busiest November since 2005. Companies are taking advantage of low debt costs before the year-end slowdown, with some issuers returning to the market after being delayed. Investors are seeking higher yields, particularly in the riskier high-yield spectrum, with some bonds selling at yields as high as 13.76%. Central banks' expansion of the money supply has driven yields low, creating opportunities for corporate treasurers to issue bonds.

site_title: ThaiBev full-year net profit up 29.7% at 23.3b baht
summary: ThaiBev's full-year net profit rose 29.7% to 23.3 billion baht, driven by a stronger spirits business, F&N, and Frasers Property. The company proposed a final dividend of 0.33 baht per share, with a total distribution of 0.48 baht per share for fiscal 2019. Revenue grew 16.4% to 267.4 billion baht, with domestic beverage sales showing signs of recovery due to government stimulus measures.

site_title: Europe: Positive trade cues help stocks wrap up dour week on an upbeat note
summary: European stocks ended a dour week on a positive note, with the pan-European STOXX 600 index rising 0.4% as upbeat data from major eurozone economies and positive rhetoric on a US-China trade deal boosted investor sentiment. Despite a mixed week, European sub-sectors mostly ended higher, with trade-sensitive miners jumping nearly 2%. A survey showed business activity picked up in France, while German business conditions continued to deteriorate. The US-China trade deal is "potentially very close," according to US President Donald Trump.

site_title: World is building walls but Singapore must build bridges: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of Singapore building bridges in a world where many countries are building walls. He stated that the country must stay united, renew its social compact, and work with like-minded partners to keep the world open. Heng highlighted the need for trade and multilateralism to maintain Singapore's economy and position as a small country in the world. He also emphasized the government's commitment to investing in Singaporeans and strengthening social safety nets, ensuring no one is left behind in the face of change.

images.alt_text: "If countries wall up, or if there is a new Iron Curtain, the cost to Singapore will be significant," Mr Heng says. "Trade is our lifeblood, and multilateralism is how small countries like us have a place in the world."

site_title: SPH Reit's private placement raises S$164.5m
summary: SPH Reit raised S$164.5 million from a private placement of 156.6 million new units, priced at S$1.05 per unit, a 5.5% discount to its VWAP. The funds will partially fund the proposed acquisition of a 50% stake in Westfield Marion Shopping Centre in Australia for S$627.9 million. The placement drew strong participation from new and existing institutional investors, with around S$162.4 million going towards the acquisition and the remaining for general corporate or working capital purposes.

site_title: Moody's downgrades outlook on MNACT over damaged HK mall
summary: Moody's downgrades the outlook on Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) to negative due to uncertainty over the earnings and operating performance of its largest asset, the Festival Walk mall in Hong Kong, following damage from violent clashes. The mall's closure highlights the vulnerability of MNACT's credit quality, but insurance coverage and stable assets in China and Japan are expected to mitigate the impact. Moody's affirmed the Baa1 issuer rating, but notes that a prolonged closure could result in a downgrade if losses are not substantially covered by insurance.

site_title: Going all-out in bursts improves your distance running
summary: Sprinting can improve distance running performance by activating fast-twitch muscle fibers and increasing speed. A study found that six sprint training sessions can improve running performance, even for experienced runners. To sprint effectively, focus on proper technique, including pumping arms, attacking the ground, and driving knees high. Drills such as high-knees and dorsiflexing can help improve these skills. Incorporating sprint workouts into your training can also boost calorie burn and overall endurance. By honing sprinting technique, runners can set new personal records in 5Ks and 10Ks.

images.alt_text: Pump the arms, pound the ground, drive the knees high, engage the core and form a straight line from head to the toe of your straight leg.

site_title: China revises 2018 GDP up 2.1%, says will not significantly impact 2019 growth calculation
summary: China revised its 2018 GDP up 2.1% to 91.93 trillion yuan, exceeding its goal of doubling the economy by 2020 from 2010. The revision, made after the fourth National Economic Census, shows the services sector contributed more to GDP than initially reported. The change will not significantly impact 2019 growth calculations. Chinese President Xi Jinping emphasized the need for equality in a "phase one" trade deal with the US, while the US has expressed doubts about the deal's progress.

site_title: Startups steer clear of big tech by innovating for business
summary: Startups are shifting their focus from the consumer internet to the business market, driven by the dominance of big tech companies like Google and Facebook. This trend is seen in venture funding, with business-focused startups receiving over $2.8 billion in investments, compared to $400 million for social media startups. Many entrepreneurs and engineers are leaving the consumer internet to develop software for businesses, including cloud computing and machine-learning tools. This migration is driven by the need for businesses to make sense of their digital data and the opportunity for startups to provide solutions to these challenges.

site_title: Joyas issues payment demand to supplier over US$5.4m debt
summary: Joyas International Holdings is demanding payment of approximately US$5.4 million from Hong Kong Silver Basic Group (HK Silver) for a nickel ore supply deal. The debt was secured by personal guarantees from HK Silver CEO Wang De Zhou and his family members. Despite a proposed repayment plan, no payment has been received, prompting Joyas to issue a letter of demand and a warning letter to HK Silver. Failure to pay will result in the enforcement of a share pledge against Wang De Zhou.

site_title: Reits (November 23-24, 2019)
summary: Realtors reported higher prices for Good Class Bungalows in Singapore. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates rose for the first time in five weeks, while Manhattan rents hit a record. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. WeWork secured new tenants for a post-bankruptcy space in Singapore and New World sold China property assets after a loan deal. The Q3 condo launch wave is expected to test demand for Singapore's prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark.

site_title: Gold mixed as markets mull uncertainties of Sino-US trade talks
summary: Gold prices experienced choppy conditions as investors weighed US-China trade uncertainties, despite a strong rally in global equities. Markets are navigating range-bound trades, with gold prices influenced by contradictory trade messages. Geopolitical risks and dollar asset diversification in Asia are expected to impact gold prices. The US-China trade spat continues to dominate market sentiment, with gold prices likely to remain volatile amidst strong cross-currents.

site_title: No end yet in sight for Dubai home price rut, survey finds
summary: Dubai's property market is expected to remain in a rut, with a turnaround more than a year away, according to a survey of experts. The chronic oversupply of homes and economic slowdown are cited as major factors. Since mid-2014, Dubai house prices have declined by at least a quarter, and there is no indication that the decline will end soon. Economists predict that it will take more than a year for the market to recover, highlighting the challenges facing the city-state's property sector.

site_title: Do you need to fire your customer?
summary: A business should not fire a customer unless absolutely necessary due to the investment and effort involved in acquiring and managing them. The most desirable customers are those with clear authority, timely needs, and a willingness to collaborate and pay on time. However, some customers may be difficult to manage, contributing to overhead costs rather than profits. Businesses should prioritize building long-term relationships with customers, educating them, and securing their loyalty. Termination should be considered only in cases where a customer's behavior is unethical or poses a risk to people or the planet.

site_title: Marie Kondo wants to sell you nice things. What's wrong with that?
summary: Marie Kondo, the tidying guru, has opened an online store offering curated, well-designed objects that amplify her brand. The move has sparked surprise and skepticism on social media, with some questioning whether she's being forced to promote products by her team at Goop. Kondo's online shop features items like Chakra tuning forks and computer brushes, which some users have joked about buying to fill their newly decluttered homes. The unexpected pivot has left fans and critics alike wondering about Kondo's intentions.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas says will not participate in Aramco IPO
summary: Malaysia's state energy company Petronas announced it will not participate in Saudi Aramco's initial public offering, contrary to earlier statements that it had been approached to join the listing. The decision was made without specifying a reason.

site_title: It's 'ka-ching' time for payments firms
summary: Singapore's payment services industry is experiencing robust growth driven by the digitalisation of payments, shopping, and consumer demand. The sector is expected to reach $7.5 billion in turnover by 2025, with a 3.6% annual growth rate. Despite a decline in global debit and credit card revenue per transaction, Singapore's growth is driven by its high online spending and the proliferation of e-wallets and payment portals. Experts predict a moderate and healthy growth rate, particularly in Asia, with the potential for e-wallets to cannibalise card payments in the long term.

site_title: Abuse and acrimony as crisis-hit Hong Kong holds district polls
summary: Hong Kong is holding district polls, with pro-democracy candidates hoping for a dramatic swing in their favor amidst the city's ongoing crisis. Despite a high turnout of 4.1 million voters, the election has been marred by protests, police cordons, and intimidation. Candidates have faced abuse and threats, with some being arrested over protest-related activities. The poll is seen as a gauge of the popularity of the city's chief executive Carrie Lam and the pro-Beijing government, with a big win for pro-democracy candidates potentially helping mobilize the movement for next year's parliamentary elections.

site_title: DBS upgrades Singtel to 'buy' after associate Bharti Airtel announces imminent tariff hikes
summary: DBS Equity Research has upgraded Singtel to a "buy" with a target price of S$3.60, citing a positive impact from Bharti Airtel's imminent tariff hikes, which could contribute 3% to Singtel's earnings. The tariff increase, starting Dec 1, is expected to boost regional associates' profit contribution for FY21. DBS analyst Sachin Mittal also raised Singtel's FY21 forecast underlying profit by 2% due to a healthier Bharti.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Friday, following gains in Asia, as investors remained optimistic about a potential mini trade deal between China and the US. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.4% to 7,269.49 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also gained 0.2%. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Currency doldrums spur complacency risk that could 'destroy profits'
summary: The US dollar's tightest yearly trading range in over four decades has led to complacency among corporate treasurers, risking potential losses if volatility erupts again. The US Dollar Index is on track for its narrowest annual trading band since 1976, with corporations becoming less willing to pay for hedging protection due to the subdued currency market. Experts warn that this complacency could "destroy profits" if currency moves suddenly change, with some advising clients to maintain hedges despite the calm market.

images.alt_text: The subdued moves in the currency market have created an environment where corporations are becoming less willing to pay up for hedging protection they haven't needed, according to Cambridge Global Payments.

site_title: China central bank cracks down on cryptocurrency trading in Shanghai
summary: China's central bank launched a crackdown on cryptocurrency trading in Shanghai, following similar campaigns in Shenzhen and amid preparations for a digital currency launch. The move aims to curb virtual currency trading and promote blockchain technology. This comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) is preparing to launch its own digital currency, which could further influence the cryptocurrency market. The crackdown is part of a broader effort to regulate and control the virtual currency industry in China.

site_title: Singapore shares recover on Friday, but lose 0.4% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,225.65, up 33.44 points or 1.1% on Friday, despite a 0.4% weekly loss. The gains were attributed to conciliatory news reports on a US-China trade agreement, with the Wall Street Journal reporting China invited US trade negotiators for talks in Beijing. Asian markets, including Australia, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, South Korea, and Taiwan, also posted gains, while China bucked the trend.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end week on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.48% to 26,595.08, despite concerns over the impact of a US lawmakers' bill supporting the city's rights. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.63% and 1.45%, respectively. Investors remain cautious due to trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, with the company planning to use the funds for its £10 billion upgrade. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target and operating losses similar to H1. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. MAS and PBOC also announced plans to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: India's property market set for modest lift from government measures
summary: India's housing market is expected to experience a modest rebound in the coming year due to government measures to clear unfinished projects. A 100 billion Indian rupee fund and additional 150 billion rupees from state-run financial institutions aim to revive over 1,600 moribund housing projects. Analysts forecast average national prices to rise 3% next year and 4.3% in 2021, with house prices in Bengaluru and Chennai expected to rise around 2% over the next two years. However, liquidity issues and high property prices remain concerns.

site_title: ESG analysis: Is judgment more important than data?
summary: CFA Institute and PRI's ESG integration efforts have highlighted the issue of quality ESG data, with investors and analysts citing gaps in data availability, particularly for small- and mid-cap companies and emerging markets. Despite growing data availability, financial professionals will need to rely more on judgment than data in ESG analysis and decision-making until data catches up. This is especially true for emerging markets and smaller companies, where reliable ESG data may not exist or be readily available. Judgment will be crucial in filling data gaps.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.65 points to 1,596.84. Volume reached 2.6 billion lots worth RM2 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 418 to 403.

site_title: Tycoon loses US$3b from India's mobile price war
summary: Tycoon Kumar Mangalam Birla's wealth has dropped by a third since 2017 due to mounting losses and debt at Vodafone Idea, a struggling Indian wireless carrier. His fortune, largely tied to the venture, has declined amid a demand slump for chemicals, metals, and cement products. The losses have also affected shares of his flagship firms. Birla's wealth loss is attributed to the Indian mobile price war, which has significantly impacted Vodafone Idea's financial health.

site_title: Maybank KE remains positive on S-Reits
summary: Maybank Kim Eng maintains a positive outlook for Singapore Reits (S-Reits), favoring industrial and hospitality Reits. The brokerage cites strong third-quarter DPU growth skewed towards retail and industrial Reits. It recommends buying top picks such as Ascendas Reit, Mapletree Industrial Trust, and CDL Hospitality Trusts, with target prices ranging from S$1.80 to S$3.35. The analysts attribute the sector's growth to stabilization of rents, recovery in hotel RevPAR, and overseas diversification. S-Reits offer a 280 basis points yield-spread and 4.6% dividend yield, making them an attractive option for investors seeking returns from yields and growth.

site_title: Why flying can also be a force for good for the planet
summary: A growing "flight shame" movement, popularized by climate activists, may inadvertently harm conservation efforts by discouraging long-haul trips, which generate significant revenue for nature-based tourism. The tourism industry supports over 10% of the global economy and employs 1 in 10 people. If tourism were to decline, entire countries like Africa could suffer economically, leading to increased poverty and undermining conservation efforts. In fact, tourism can be a key driver for conservation, as seen in countries like Tanzania and Colombia, where tourism helps fund conservation work and protects endangered species.

images.alt_text: An African wildebeest silhouetted against the evening sun. Last year, some 1.5 million tourists visited Tanzania, providing much-needed income for the biodiversity hot spot.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A public preview of Urban Treasures, a freehold condominium by Fragrance Group, will take place on Nov 23, with prices starting from S$845,000. A report found that fintechs lag banks in providing financial services to Singapore businesses, while ISOTeam secured S$35.4 million in new contracts. SPH Reit raised S$164.5 million from a private placement, and Tritech is proposing a share placement to raise S$4.2 million. Nordic Group purchased Envipure for S$14.8 million, and Singapore shares recovered on Friday, ending 0.4% lower on the week.

images.alt_text: The 237-unit freehold residential project in eastern Singapore will be completed by the end of 2021.

site_title: Australia housing market revival to continue into 2020: poll
summary: A Reuters poll of 13 property analysts predicts Australia's housing market will continue to revive in 2020, driven by further interest rate cuts to the record-low 0.75% benchmark cash rate. Average home prices are forecast to rise 5% nationally next year, nearly double the previous prediction, before slowing to 4.5% in 2021. Analysts expect housing prices to rise in Sydney and Melbourne, with forecasts of 7.7% and 7.4% growth, respectively, in 2020. However, some analysts remain skeptical about the market's sustainability, citing subdued income growth and consumer sentiment.

site_title: Pixel not-so perfect
summary: The Google Pixel 4 has improved photography capabilities and machine-learning features, but its battery life is a major concern, lasting around 8 hours compared to the Pixel 3's 9 hours. This is due to a smaller 2,800mAh battery. Despite its technical advancements, the Pixel 4 falls behind other phone manufacturers in terms of battery life, making it less suitable for heavy users.

site_title: Cash offer for San Teh closes; shares suspended pending delisting
summary: The Kao family has successfully acquired 95.38% of San Teh's shares with a cash offer of S$0.28 apiece, exceeding the 90% threshold for a compulsory acquisition. The offeror has requested the suspension of San Teh's shares, which had previously applied to delist from the Singapore Exchange on November 1. The shares will remain suspended pending delisting.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on Sino-US trade deal optimism; HK uncertainty caps gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi index ended the day 0.26% higher, snapping a four-day losing streak, as China's remarks on a potential trade deal with the US boosted optimism. However, US human rights bills on Hong Kong capped gains, and the won weakened. The benchmark bond yield rose, and foreigners were net sellers for a 12th consecutive day. Despite this, the Kospi has risen 2.98% so far this year, driven by the hopes of a trade deal.

site_title: Fintechs lag banks in providing financial services to Singapore businesses: report
summary: Fintechs in Singapore lag behind banks in providing financial services to businesses, with limited product offerings and regulatory constraints. A survey of 272 micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) found that 60% preferred accessing financial services through banks, while 84% of mid-sized businesses preferred secured loans from banks. Fintechs should partner with banks to offer a broader range of services, addressing concerns over data protection and customer satisfaction. The report suggests that fintechs can strengthen their brand image and attract non-adopters by communicating their data protection standards.

site_title: Private banker focused on billionaires on London hiring spree, eyes Singapore
summary: Azura, a wealth-management firm catering to billionaires, is expanding its London team, hiring 14 more bankers by the end of 2020, despite Brexit uncertainty. Founder Ali Jamal believes London remains a top destination for the wealthy, citing its financial system, lifestyle, and security. The firm's growth underscores the booming business of catering to the world's richest people, with billionaire wealth reaching $8.5 trillion in 2018. Azura also plans to grow its footprint in Monaco and Singapore.

site_title: Tesla unveils first-ever electric pickup truck
summary: Tesla unveiled its first-ever electric pickup truck, delivering on Elon Musk's promise to build an electric version of America's favorite vehicle. The truck has a starting price of US$39,900 and a maximum range of 805km. Musk emphasized the need for sustainable energy and the importance of a pickup truck in solving it, citing the top three selling vehicles in America are pickup trucks. The launch event took place in Los Angeles, marking Tesla's entry into the pickup truck market.

site_title: Our poets need Pythagoras!
summary: A group of doctors, scientists, and engineers protested a proposed change in the US national curriculum that would reduce science education to an elective course. They argued that science is essential for critical thinking and problem-solving, and that a bot cannot replace human thinking. The protesters, who waved posters with mathematical equations and images of amoebas, emphasized the importance of strengthening science education, not weakening it. The issue highlights the need for a strong foundation in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education.

site_title: Australia: Shares lifted by energy and miners; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Friday, driven by gains in energy and mining stocks, but fell 0.7% on Thursday. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,709.80, marking its biggest weekly loss in almost two months. Goldman Sachs cut its target price on Westpac, which faces an explosive lawsuit, weighing on financial sector concerns. The market strategist attributed the bounce back to a recapture of lost ground from the past two sessions.

site_title: Asia: Most markets on the rise as trade optimism returns
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday as optimism returned to trade talks between the US and China, with Vice Premier Liu He offering to host a meeting to push through a mini pact. Despite US lawmakers passing a bill supporting Hong Kong rights, which has angered Beijing, investors expect a deal to be signed soon. The Wall Street Journal reported that Washington may delay imposing fresh tariffs, a key demand of China. Asian markets, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Tokyo, rose, while Wellington and Manila fell.

site_title: Singapore Accountancy Commission accidentally leaks personal data of 6,541 people
summary: The Singapore Accountancy Commission (SAC) accidentally leaked the personal data of 6,541 people, including names, NRIC numbers, and contact details, to 41 recipients over four months. The leak occurred when a folder containing the data was unintentionally attached to e-mails and sent to organizations. The affected individuals were informed on November 7, and all 22 organizations have confirmed deleting the data. SAC has set up a panel to review the incident and make recommendations, and individuals can contact the commission for queries. The incident is considered serious and regrettable by SAC.

site_title: SocGen's heads of Asia trade finance depart after Singapore bunker fuel losses
summary: Societe Generale, a French bank, has seen its regional heads of trade and commodities finance for the Asia-Pacific leave the bank, amid concerns it may scale back financing services to the Singapore shipping fuel sector. The bank has been hit by losses from trade financing in the Singapore bunker fuel market, including a loss for Inter-Pacific Petroleum Pte, which had over $96 million in outstanding liabilities to SocGen. The bank remains committed to trade commodities finance, but is becoming more selective about counterparties in commodities trade finance.

site_title: Nordic Group buys environmental engineering firm Envipure for S$14.8m
summary: Nordic Group has acquired environmental engineering firm Envipure for S$14.8 million in cash, after a non-binding term sheet in September. The acquisition was completed on November 21 and Envipure has become a wholly-owned subsidiary. The deal is expected to allow Nordic Group to expand its product range and services, as well as tap new markets and customers in the semiconductor and environmental engineering sectors. The acquisition was financed through a combination of internally generated funds and bank borrowings.

site_title: US says concerned about China's attempts to influence Taiwan's presidential vote
summary: The US is concerned about China's attempts to influence Taiwan's upcoming presidential election, with China stepping up pressure on the self-ruled island ahead of the vote in January. The US top official in Taiwan, Brent Christensen, stated that Chinese attempts are of concern to the United States. Taiwan has denounced China for trying to interfere in its democratic process, including China's recent sailing of an aircraft carrier group through the Taiwan Strait. The US and Taiwan are closely watching the situation as the election approaches.

images.alt_text: The United States is concerned about China's attempts to influence Taiwan's upcoming presidential election, the top US official in Taiwan said on Friday, as China stepped up pressure on the self-ruled island ahead of the vote in January.

site_title: 2 car dealerships suddenly close, customers lose S$331,600: Case
summary: Two car dealerships, Universe Motoring and Karz Automobile, in Singapore suddenly closed, leaving customers with losses of approximately S$331,600. The closures, part of a larger trend, resulted in a 12% drop in consumer losses from December 2018 to September 2019, totaling about S$821,504. Consumers reported that dealers promised to transfer vehicle ownership but failed to do so, leading to repossession by finance companies. The Consumers Association of Singapore (Case) has reminded consumers to use two-factor authentication for vehicle ownership transfers online.

site_title: World is building walls but Singapore must build bridges: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for Singapore to build bridges amidst a world building walls. He stressed the importance of maintaining a free, open, and rules-based international order and highlighted the country's reliance on trade. Heng reiterated the government's commitment to supporting Singaporeans, particularly those who may be left behind by change, and emphasized the need for regional cooperation, citing examples of Singapore's partnerships with other Asean countries.

site_title: From 10 cents to US$1.3m, first Marvel comic sets auction record
summary: The first Marvel comic book, published in 1939 by Timely Comics, set an auction record at $1.26 million, according to Heritage Auctions. The comic, which features Spider-Man's first appearance, was sold in good condition and surpassed its initial price of 10 cents. This sale eclipses the previous record held by "Action Comics" #1, which sold for $3.2 million in 2014, and solidifies Marvel's place in comic book history.

site_title: Fragrance Group to preview Urban Treasures on Nov 23; prices start from S$845,000
summary: Fragrance Group will preview its new residential project, Urban Treasures, on November 23. The freehold condominium in District 14 features two 12-storey buildings with 237 apartments. Prices start from S$845,000 for a 452 sq ft one-bedroom unit, with a four-bedroom unit priced from around S$2.3 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Friday, snapping a three-day losing streak, as investors sought bargains amid US-China trade talks. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.32% to close at 23,112.88, while the Topix index rose 0.12%. Investors closely watched US-China developments, despite US President Trump's recent threats. This rally comes ahead of Singapore's GDP data and other regional market news.

site_title: Tycoon Richard Li's FWD ramps up US dollar bond sales amid expansion
summary: Billionaire Richard Li's FWD Group Ltd has ramped up US dollar bond sales, issuing $1.66 billion in five offerings this year, its largest annual sales. The company's expansion in South-east Asia, including a $3 billion acquisition in Thailand, is funded by debt offerings. Analysts attribute the surge in debt sales to FWD's acquisitions, with the company also considering Aviva's Singapore business. This marks a significant bet by Li on the region, following a series of asset purchases.

site_title: Singapore business body calls on firms to take up sustainable employment practices
summary: The Singapore Business Federation is calling on firms to adopt sustainable employment practices to tackle inequality. The federation's report, launched at a conference, recommends firms take ownership of upskilling professionals, avoid age discrimination, and redesign jobs for mature employees. The SBF is encouraging firms to sign a Sustainable Employment Pledge to improve their practices and has already seen 61 firms commit. The federation hopes that by committing to the pledge, firms can improve their processes and act as role models, ultimately leading to better businesses and long-term growth.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon up 0.62% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.62% on Friday afternoon, closing at 3,211.95 points. The index saw 518 million securities worth S$441.7 million trade, with 186 gainers and 101 losers. Tritech Group declined 16.3% after proposing a share placement to raise S$4.2 million. The rally follows a 5-day increase ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Addvalue unveils mobile satellite terminal for US fisheries market in tie up
summary: Addvalue Technologies, in partnership with Inmarsat and Network Innovations, has launched a mobile satellite terminal for the US fisheries market. The Addvalue iFleetONE system provides secure broadband communications and vessel monitoring services, meeting US National Maritime Fisheries Service requirements. Type-approved in four of the five US fisheries management regions, the system is expected to be fully compliant soon. The partnership aims to generate significant terminal sales and recurring revenue through bundled VMS subscription services.

site_title: Crypto bourse Binance says no China office amid raid rumours
summary: Binance, the largest cryptocurrency exchange, has denied rumors of a police raid at its Shanghai office, stating it doesn't have a fixed office in China. The speculation led to a 8.4% drop in Bitcoin's value on Thursday. Binance CEO Zhao Changpeng confirmed on Twitter that there was "no police, no raid, no office". The company operates remotely from over 40 countries, and its team works from home or cafes. The rumors sparked a sell signal, with Bitcoin breaking below $8,000 for the first time in nearly a month.

site_title: Thai bank targets US$1b spinoff among its fintech units
summary: Siam Commercial Bank Pcl, Thailand's third-largest lender, plans to spin off its fintech divisions, including Digital Ventures Co and National ITMX Co, to raise funds and increase independence. The move aims to monetize the bank's technology investments and boost earnings amid sluggish traditional lending. The bank expects one of the fintech units to become a "unicorn" with a valuation of US$1 billion or more. This strategy is part of the bank's effort to stay competitive in the market and transform into a technology company.

site_title: Brokers' take: CDLHT property deals seen as positive with 'buy' and 'hold'
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) has received positive feedback from brokers on two proposed deals, including the sale of Novotel Singapore Clarke Quay for S$375.9 million and the purchase of W Singapore for S$324 million. Analysts expect the deals to boost CDLHT's long-term growth, with potential capital distributions and occupancy rates rising. However, some analysts warn of lower distributions and a slight drop in distribution per unit (DPU) in the short term.

site_title: High spirits at Singapore's school for gin
summary: Students at a Singapore distillery create custom gin with an Asian twist by crushing juniper berries and blending them with various ingredients, such as local herbs and spices. The students are encouraged to experiment with different flavor profiles, from citrus and floral to herbal and spicy. This hands-on approach allows them to develop their own unique gin recipes. The distillery's focus on creativity and innovation sets it apart from traditional gin-making methods.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 0.03 points to 1,592.16. Volume reached 86.35 million lots worth RM33.93 million. Gainers outpaced losers 110 to 78. The lower opening was not directly related to any specific news, but rather a general market trend.

site_title: Moody's downgrades MNACT outlook on uncertainty over damaged Hong Kong mall
summary: Moody's downgraded the outlook on Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) to negative due to uncertainty over the earnings and operating performance of its largest asset, the Festival Walk mall in Hong Kong, which sustained extensive damage during violent clashes. The mall has been closed since then.

images.alt_text: The Singapore-based Reit's mall in Hong Kong has been closed after sustaining extensive damage during violent clashes across the city.

site_title: Manila-bound Philippine Airlines flight makes emergency landing in Los Angeles
summary: A Philippine Airlines Boeing 777 widebody made an emergency landing in Los Angeles after an apparent engine failure shortly after takeoff. The incident occurred on November 22, 2019, and all 347 passengers and 18 crew members are safe. The plane, Flight 113, landed safely at Los Angeles International Airport, with witnesses describing "bursts of flames" coming out of the right engine. The cause of the failure is unclear, but it comes amid scrutiny over Boeing's 737 Max jets following twin deadly crashes.

site_title: Trump signs stopgap funding, avoiding government shutdown
summary: US President Donald Trump signed a temporary spending bill, averting a government shutdown, after the Senate approved a one-month measure. The short-term bill funds federal operations until December 20, forcing Congress to debate and pass fiscal year 2020 funding. A long-term deal remains elusive due to disagreements over border security funding. The measure includes a 3.1% pay raise for the military, funds the 2020 census, and keeps critical public health programs going for another month. Two government shutdowns have occurred during Trump's administration, including the 35-day shutdown in 2018-2019.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades Singtel to 'buy' on India associate's mobile tariff hike
summary: DBS Equity Research upgraded Singtel to a "buy" from "hold" with a target price of S$3.60, citing Bharti Airtel's earlier-than-expected mobile tariff hike in India as a key factor. The tariff increase is expected to contribute to a sharp rise in regional associates' profit contribution in fiscal 2021. DBS analyst Sachin Mittal raised Singtel's FY21 forecast underlying profit by 2% due to a healthier Bharti, and expects a 10% mobile tariff hike at Bharti to contribute an additional 3% earnings to Singtel.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at Friday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.45% at the opening of Friday's trading, with the Hang Seng index reaching 26,584.88. This follows US lawmakers passing a bill supporting Hong Kong's rights, sparking anger in China and fuelling concerns about ongoing trade talks.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares opened with slight gains on Friday morning but investors remained on edge after US lawmakers passed a bill supporting the city's rights, causing anger in China and fuelling concern about ongoing trade talks.

site_title: China to speed up launch of rare earth futures contracts: exchange
summary: China plans to accelerate the launch of rare earth futures contracts, with the Shanghai Futures Exchange aiming to speed up the launch of alumina futures as well. The move comes amid speculation that China would use its dominant position as a rare earth exporter to influence global markets following trade talks with the US broke down in May. The exact launch date for the rare earth contracts was not mentioned.

site_title: Silicon Valley startup incubator Y Combinator closing China unit
summary: Y Combinator, a Silicon Valley startup incubator, announced it will close its China unit, YC China, due to a change in strategy to focus on supporting local and international startups from its US headquarters. The decision, made in 2019, was unrelated to US-China tensions over trade and intellectual property. YC China, launched in 2018, was led by Qi Lu, who will now fund companies under his own program, MiraclePlus. Y Combinator will continue to support Chinese startups applying to its US program.

site_title: Bargain hunters relish chance to buy cheap Hong Kong stocks
summary: Bargain hunters are taking advantage of the 1.6% decline in the Hang Seng Index, with some investors seeing cheap stocks as a good deal despite the uncertain outlook in Hong Kong. Despite protests and a surge in correlation, some analysts, such as Louis Tse and Joanne Lim, are recommending buying opportunities in companies like MTR Corp, Wharf Real Estate, and Macau casinos. Others, like Wang Yugang, are cautious due to the uncertain market conditions, while Justin Tang sees opportunities in diversified investments.

site_title: Charles Schwab in talks to buy smaller rival TD Ameritrade: report
summary: Charles Schwab Corp is in talks to acquire rival TD Ameritrade, a move seen as a response to industry disruption and pressure on profitability. The deal, valued at $26 billion, would give Schwab control of a majority of the market and scale, potentially leading to substantial cost synergies. The combined entity would have total assets of $5 trillion. The move could also force E*Trade to look for acquisitions, and antitrust regulators may scrutinize the deal.

images.alt_text: Charles Schwab Corp, the largest discount broker in the US financial world, is in talks to buy rival TD Ameritrade, CNBC reported, as profits in the industry come under pressure from a shift to zero commission.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.25%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.25% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,200.18. Despite global market declines overnight, the benchmark index gained as investors focused on domestic economic data ahead. Gainers outnumbered losers 61 to 30, with about 29.6 million shares changing hands. The rally marks the fifth consecutive day of gains for the STI.

site_title: China revises 2018 GDP up 2.1%, says will not significantly impact 2019 growth calculation
summary: China's 2018 GDP has been revised up by 2.1% to 91.93 trillion yuan, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. The revision does not significantly impact the 2019 GDP growth rate calculation. This is the latest in a series of annual GDP data revisions by China, which is routine practice. The updated figures do not alter the country's overall economic outlook, but may raise pressure on policymakers to address slowing growth.

site_title: Google shifts rules for political ads, pressuring Facebook
summary: Google has announced restrictions on targeting specific groups of voters with political ads, limiting advertisers to general categories such as age, gender, or postal code location. The move aims to reduce the spread of misinformation and follows a ban by Twitter on most kinds of political ads. Facebook is under pressure to modify its hands-off policy on political ads, with some analysts warning that the changes could favor well-financed and incumbent candidates, potentially hindering smaller campaigns.

site_title: US charges Chinese national with stealing trade secrets: Justice Dept
summary: A Chinese national, Haitao Xiang, has been charged with stealing trade secrets for China while working for Monsanto and its Climate Corp subsidiary in the US from 2008 to 2017. Xiang was stopped at a US airport with proprietary farming software and faces charges under the US Justice Department. Assistant Attorney General John Demers stated that this case is an example of the Chinese government's use of "Talent Plans" to encourage employees to steal intellectual property from US employers. Xiang, 42, is set to face trial in St. Louis, Missouri.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat with eyes on US-China trade
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Friday amid uncertainty over a possible US-China trade deal. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.01% to 23,041.03, while the broader Topix index gained 0.01% to 1,689.62. Investors remained cautious despite a strong session on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records. The lack of progress on US-China trade talks kept markets on edge, with traders brushing off new threats from President Trump.

site_title: Bloomberg takes next step towards White House run
summary: Michael Bloomberg, a billionaire businessman, has taken a step towards running for the White House by registering with the US Federal Election Commission. He filed paperwork to register a committee called "Mike Bloomberg 2020" and has prepared groundwork for a possible bid for the Democratic nomination. Bloomberg has a personal fortune of $50 billion, which could shake up the crowded field of candidates. He plans to focus on the March primaries, including "Super Tuesday," rather than campaigning in states holding primaries in February.

site_title: ICE to launch Bitcoin futures contract in Singapore on Dec 9
summary: INTERCONTINENTAL Exchange (ICE) plans to launch a Bitcoin futures contract in Singapore on December 9, with the Bakkt Bitcoin cash-settled monthly futures contract being listed on ICE Futures Singapore and cleared by ICE Clear Singapore. The new contract will be settled against data from the physically delivered Bakkt Bitcoin monthly futures contract, and will be available for trading in US dollars. This move comes after the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) released a consultation paper on derivatives trading, including payment tokens like Bitcoin. The launch will offer investors a convenient way to gain or hedge exposure in Bitcoin markets.

site_title: ChildAid raises S$2.12m for low-income kids
summary: ChildAid 2019 raised S$2.12 million for low-income kids through its two charities, The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund. The event brings the total amount raised over 15 years to over S$22.71 million, since the annual charity concert series started in 2005. The funds support arts training and financial assistance for disadvantaged children.

site_title: Xerox threatens hostile bid unless HP opens its books
summary: Xerox Corp has threatened to take its $33.5 billion buyout bid for HP Inc hostile unless the company agrees to a "friendly" discussion and open its books by November 25. HP rejected the offer, citing undervaluation, and left the door open for a deal where HP becomes the acquirer of Xerox. Analysts say the combination could create superior value for shareholders, but challenges to integration remain due to different offerings and pricing models.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on the back of material, energy stocks; New Zealand slips
summary: The Australian benchmark index rose 0.5% to 5,708.50, driven by gains in energy and material stocks. After two sessions of heavy selling, the market recaptured losses, with energy and materials stocks leading the rebound. The rebound comes after a 0.7% drop on Thursday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index bouncing back from a 3% decline over the previous two sessions.

site_title: Oil rises to 2-month high on hopes of longer Opec cuts, US-China trade deal
summary: Oil prices rose to a 2-month high due to hopes of longer OPEC output cuts and signs of US-China trade deal progress. Brent crude rose 2.5% to $63.97 a barrel and WTI crude rose 2.8% to $58.58 a barrel. OPEC and its allies are likely to extend output cuts until mid-2020, and China has invited US trade negotiators for new talks. The market is also supported by reduced refinery throughputs and increased uncertainty in Hong Kong.

site_title: 'Smart cities' urged to look beyond rich, white men
summary: Advocates warn that smart cities' focus on high-tech solutions risks excluding vulnerable groups, including the poor, disabled, and elderly. They urge greater representation of women and people with disabilities in urban planning and data collection. Experts suggest using technology to address accessibility barriers, such as traffic lights that detect and assist disabled pedestrians. Cities like Tumakuru in India are incorporating digital solutions to improve services, but advocates emphasize the need for inclusive and democratic decision-making processes.

site_title: ISOTeam to upgrade Istana, Botanic Gardens as part of S$35m in new contracts
summary: ISOTeam secured S$35.4 million in new contracts, with two addition and alteration projects totaling S$17.8 million for the Istana and Singapore Botanic Gardens. The projects, expected to be completed by December 2022 and April 2020, were among several new contracts won by the facilities maintenance specialist. This brings the group's total new project value to S$86.7 million for FY2020, with shares falling 0.5 cents to close at 24 cents.

site_title: Petronas sees commercial production this year at southern Malaysia refinery
summary: Petronas, a Malaysian state oil company, confirmed that its southern Malaysia refinery will begin commercial production by the end of 2019, despite a report of a delay. The refinery, a $27-billion joint venture with Saudi Aramco, suffered a fire in April that damaged the atmospheric residue desulphurisation unit. The unit is expected to begin operation by mid-2020. The project, which includes a 300,000 barrels-per-day oil refinery and a petrochemical complex, has been shut since April.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SPH Reit, MLT, ISOTeam, Jumbo, Nordic, Tritech, Addvalue
summary: SPH Reit raised S$164.5 million in a private placement to fund the acquisition of an Australian mall, with the issue price set at S$1.05 per new unit. Mapletree Logistics Trust secured its first sustainability-linked loan, a S$200 million six-year revolving credit facility from OCBC Bank, referencing its rooftop solar installation programme. Other stocks to watch include MLT, ISOTeam, Jumbo, Nordic, Tritech, and Addvalue, with market developments influencing trading of their securities.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
Its private placement has raised S$164.5 million to partially fund the proposed acquisition of a half stake in an Australian mall, SPH Reit said on Friday morning.

site_title: G-20 has put up "historically high levels" of trade barriers: WTO
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) reported that the G-20 economies have imposed "historically high levels" of trade barriers, with 28 new restrictions worth an estimated $460.4 billion in mid-2019. This represents a 37% increase from the previous period. The restrictions, mainly through tariff increases and import bans, have a clear impact on global growth, job creation, and purchasing power, according to WTO Director General Robert Azevedo. Strong leadership from G-20 economies is needed to avoid increased uncertainty and lower investment.

site_title: Bombshell GM lawsuit has bribes, backdoor schemes
summary: General Motors has filed a bombshell lawsuit against Fiat Chrysler, alleging bribes and backdoor schemes. The lawsuit claims Fiat Chrysler's deceased CEO Sergio Marchionne orchestrated a plot to manipulate the United Auto Workers union to force GM into a merger. GM seeks to recover billions of dollars lost due to FCA's influence on the union. The lawsuit comes as Fiat Chrysler is embroiled in labour talks with the UAW and faces pressure from the US Justice Department over a bribery scheme. FCA has dismissed the allegations, calling the lawsuit a diversionary tactic.

site_title: WeWork to lay off 2,400 workers worldwide
summary: WeWork, an office-sharing firm, will lay off 2,400 employees worldwide, about a fifth of its workforce, due to mounting losses and efforts to reorganize. The layoffs, which began weeks ago, aim to create a more efficient organization. The company recently lost nearly $1.3 billion in the third quarter and scrapped plans for an initial public offering. CEO Adam Neumann was forced out and the company received a bailout from Japan's SoftBank Group. The dismissed workers will receive severance and benefits.

site_title: US grants final approval for expanded Delta, Air France, Virgin, KLM joint venture
summary: US Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao granted final approval for an expanded joint venture among Delta Air Lines, Air France KLM, and Virgin Atlantic. The agreement replaces previous arrangements, allowing for more options on European flights and replacing the previously approved US-United Kingdom and US-Continental Europe joint ventures. This move aims to enhance travel options and benefits for passengers.

images.alt_text: US Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao on Thursday granted final approval for an expanded trans-Atlantic joint venture for Delta Air Lines Inc, Air France KLM SA and Virgin Atlantic.

site_title: Europe: Trade woes knock shares for the fourth day; Thyssenkrupp slumps
summary: European stocks declined for a fourth consecutive day, weighed down by mixed US-China trade talks and Thyssenkrupp's worst day in 19 years due to dividend scrapping. The Stoxx 600 fell 2% below its four-year peak, while European miners and technology sectors lost 1% and 0.4%, respectively. Fears of delayed US-China trade deal and Hong Kong tensions impacted investor sentiment, but markets closed near session lows.

images.alt_text: European stocks dropped for a fourth straight day on Thursday as mixed headlines about US-China trade talks muted risk appetite, while German conglomerate Thyssenkrupp suffered its worst day in nineteen years after scrapping its dividend.

site_title: India to defer spectrum fees to help ailing telcos
summary: India's Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced a two-year moratorium on spectrum payments for telcos, worth up to $8.54 billion, to help the ailing industry. The move comes after the Supreme Court ordered carriers to pay $13 billion in overdue fees. The relief aims to preserve the remaining wireless carriers in a market that has shrunk from 12 to three private firms. The two-year moratorium will begin in April 2020, with interest payments continuing.

site_title: 2019 growth forecasts for NODX, trade pared back
summary: Singapore's 2019 growth forecast for non-oil domestic exports (NODX) has been trimmed to -10.0 to -9.5% from a year ago, following a 9.6% decline in Q3 NODX and total trade. The government also downgraded its forecast for total merchandise trade to -4.5 to -4.0%. This comes after a fourth consecutive quarter of NODX decline.

site_title: The fight to halt the theft of ideas is hopeless
summary: Intellectual property rights may be an imperfect compromise, and current protection is excessive, allowing monopoly. China's desire to access advanced technology is inevitable and beneficial in the long run. China is already a source of new ideas, and a two-way idea flow is expected. The value of existing knowledge erodes, and further advances are essential, with intellectual property rights being only a partial solution. High-income countries must combine to reach a new settlement with China, balancing protection of intellectual property with mutual advantage within the WTO.

site_title: US: Third day of declines for Dow, S&P as Wall Street sags
summary: US stocks declined for the third consecutive day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 falling 0.2% each. The decline comes despite a reported offer from Beijing for another face-to-face meeting with US trade negotiators, and ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday week. The tech-heavy Nasdaq also lost 0.2%. US officials are hesitant to meet without clear commitments from Beijing addressing key US complaints. The decline is attributed to ongoing trade tensions rather than economic data, with some analysts noting a "technical" rather than "fundamental" sell-off.

site_title: SPH Reit's private placement raises S$164.5m
summary: SPH Reit has raised S$164.5 million from a private placement of 156.6 million new units, with an issue price of S$1.05 per unit. The funds will partially fund the proposed acquisition of Westfield Marion Shopping Centre in South Australia for S$627.9 million. The placement drew strong participation from new and existing institutional investors, with 98.7% of gross proceeds going towards the acquisition. The new units are expected to be listed on December 2, 9am, upon in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Trump conduct 'beyond anything Nixon did': House impeachment chair
summary: US President Donald Trump's withholding of military aid from Ukraine to demand dirt on a potential 2020 election rival, Joe Biden, is considered "beyond anything done by disgraced predecessor Richard Nixon", according to House Intelligence Committee chairman Adam Schiff. Trump's actions, including a July 25 phone call, led to the impeachment inquiry. Schiff stated that Trump's behavior is a "terrible tragedy for us but a greater tragedy for the rest of the world" as it undermines global trust. The impeachment inquiry is ongoing, with several witnesses testifying that military aid was contingent on Trump's demand.

site_title: Heavy Metal
summary: H Moser & Cie, a 191-year-old independent watchmaker, breaks tradition by introducing its first metal watch bracelet. The move aims to expand the brand's market presence and appeal to a broader audience, particularly younger customers. CEO Edouard Meylan aims to reach 3,000 watches a year in three to five years, establishing Moser as a leading independent brand. The brand's high-quality, competitively priced in-house movements and sleek metal bracelets are expected to attract new customers and grow the brand's reputation.

site_title: Porsche Taycan takes its Singapore bow
summary: Porsche unveiled its Taycan electric sports car in Singapore, marking its Asia-Pacific debut. The event, held at The Float @ Marina Bay, also celebrated the collaboration with Lucasfilm Ltd for the Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker movie. Three Taycan variants were showcased, with prices starting at around S$500,000. Porsche expects to see how customers in the region will receive the innovative new product, citing the youthful and progressive nature of the Asian market. The Taycan is set to arrive in Singapore in August 2020.

site_title: Tritech to raise S$4.2m from proposed placement at S$0.0388 per share
summary: TRITECH Group is proposing a share placement of up to 110.8 million new shares at S$0.0388 apiece to raise around S$4.2 million in gross proceeds for working capital. The issue price represents a 5.8% discount to the volume-weighted average price of S$0.0412 per share. The placement shares will represent 11.7% of the existing share capital and 10.4% of the enlarged share capital.

site_title: US unveils US$600m aid for DRC transition
