The court heard Mura followed Soubry to parliament and called her a traitor. Mura, standing for the far-right English Democrats, was convicted of harassment.

site_title: Ex-JPMorgan trader found guilty in US currency-rigging trial
summary: A former JPMorgan Chase trader, Akshay Aiyer, was found guilty of conspiring to rig foreign exchange trades for personal gain. Aiyer was convicted of one count of conspiracy by a jury in federal court in Manhattan and is scheduled to be sentenced on April 3. The conviction is seen as a reminder of the US Department of Justice's commitment to holding individuals responsible for financial schemes that violate global financial markets.

site_title: Firms should leverage EU-Singapore FTA perks: Chan Chun Sing
summary: The European Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) has entered into force, offering benefits such as tariff elimination, reduced technical barriers, and improved access to the EU services sector and public procurement. The agreement is expected to benefit Singaporean businesses, particularly small and medium enterprises, with simplified customs procedures and reduced technical rules. EU Commissioner for Trade Cecilia Malmström sees the agreement as a sign of strong support for the rules-based international order, while HSBC Asia-Pacific head of global trade and receivables finance Ajay Sharma expects it to enhance Asean's competitiveness.

site_title: BRC Asia's full-year earnings swell on Lee Metal acquisition
summary: BRC Asia's full-year net profit more than doubled to S$31.6 million due to the acquisition of Lee Metal, with revenue surging 61% to S$913.3 million. Gross profit climbed 70% and operating profit margin increased to 4.2%. Despite higher expenses, the group's balance sheet remains healthy, with a net asset value of S$262.9 million. BRC Asia expects a brighter outlook for the next 12 months, citing a recovering domestic construction sector in Singapore.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Karin Technology sold its Shanghai property to an individual for 3.2 million yuan, realizing 320,000 yuan in fair value gain. The sale will improve its cash flow position. GDS Global reported a widened full-year net loss to S$1.76 million due to declining revenue in the construction industry. The company's revenue declined 19.6% to S$14.26 million.

site_title: Canada's Trudeau unveils domestically-focused cabinet
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau unveiled a 36-member cabinet, expanding his government after the Liberals lost 20 seats in the October election. Chrystia Freeland was promoted to deputy leader to address internal divisions and woo western provinces, while Jonathan Wilkinson was appointed Environment Minister. The cabinet aims to address issues such as a slowing economy, geographic divisions, and climate change, following Trudeau's promise to "heal the country's internal divisions." Trudeau's minority government faces an emboldened opposition and a resurgence in separatism in Alberta and Quebec.

images.alt_text: Canada's Justin Trudeau unveiled an inward-looking cabinet on Wednesday, with rising star Chrystia Freeland swapping foreign affairs for a new role healing the country's internal divisions.

site_title: Saudi king urges Iran to quit 'harmful' expansionism
summary: Saudi King Salman urged Iran to abandon its expansionist ideology, which he said has harmed its own people, following violent street protests in Iran. The protests erupted after a 200% increase in petrol prices. The king reiterated that Saudi Arabia does not seek war but is ready to defend its people. Tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran have soared after a series of attacks on oil tankers and installations in the Gulf, with Washington and Riyadh blaming Iran. King Salman hopes for a political settlement in Yemen, where Iran-aligned Huthi rebels have been fighting the Saudi-backed government.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's King Salman urged arch-rival Iran on Wednesday to abandon an expansionist ideology that has "harmed" its own people, following violent street protests in the Islamic republic

site_title: General Motors sues Fiat Chrysler over bribes to auto union
summary: General Motors filed a federal lawsuit against Fiat Chrysler, alleging the company bribed auto union officials to secure an unfair advantage in labor talks and force GM into a merger. The lawsuit points to former FCA CEO Sergio Marchionne and guilty pleas by former FCA executives, who bribed former UAW officials, as central to the alleged conspiracy. The case references a long-running program that has tarnished the union's image, and GM is seeking damages and other relief.

images.alt_text: General Motors filed a federal lawsuit against Fiat Chrysler on Wednesday, alleging its rival bribed auto union officials to secure an unfair advantage in labor talks and to force it to agree to a merger.

site_title: Beyond Brexit, foreign policy missing from UK election
summary: The UK general election campaign has largely overlooked foreign policy, with Brexit dominating the discussion. Despite the UK's significant defence budget, aid budget, and diplomatic network, its global influence has waned over the past decade. The government's approach to international relations has been criticized for being flawed and diminishing the country's international standing. The UK is seeking to rediscover its heritage as a great global trading nation, but the process is not straightforward, with potential disagreements on trade deals, particularly with the US. A new foreign policy review is necessary to address the challenges posed by Russia, terrorism, and other global issues.

site_title: Duterte vows to ban e-cigarettes, orders arrest of those vaping in public
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte vows to ban the importation and use of e-cigarettes, citing concerns over nicotine and other chemicals. He orders law enforcement agencies to arrest those vaping in public, following a teenager's contraction of a lung illness tied to vaping. The ban aims to address the health risks associated with e-cigarettes, which contain unknown chemicals.

site_title: CapitaLand to sell The Star Vista for S$296m
summary: CapitaLand is selling its stake in The Star Vista mall to Rock Productions, the business arm of New Creation Church, for S$296 million. The sale is expected to generate S$145 million in net proceeds and a net gain of S$32 million for CapitaLand. The divestment is part of CapitaLand's asset recycling strategy, which has seen the company divest S$5.7 billion worth of assets this year. The sale is also seen as beneficial for Rock Productions, which expects healthy returns from the mall.

site_title: Google opens startups campus in Tokyo's trendy Shibuya district
summary: Google has inaugurated its new campus in Tokyo's Shibuya district, featuring a dedicated Google for Startups Campus with an accelerator program for 12 AI and machine learning startups. The campus, which doubles Google's employee headcount in Japan, aims to support women founders and promote inclusiveness. The move is part of Google's efforts to combine education and training with evangelism for its cloud and business services.

site_title: Temasek to stay the course in allocating more funds to the US
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state investor, plans to continue allocating more funds to the US despite escalating trade tensions between the US and China. According to John Vaske, head of Americas, Temasek's available funds are substantial and have been allocated to US deals, representing about 15% of its portfolio. This stance holds true regardless of whether the US and China de-link or work together, Vaske stated.

site_title: 51% of FIDReC disputes filed against banks and finance companies
summary: FIDReC, Singapore's Financial Industry Disputes Resolution Centre, received 1,037 complaints in the financial year ended June 30, with 51% against banks and finance companies. The median claim amount was S$5,000, while the average was S$24,000. Disputes involved inappropriate advice, misrepresentation, and unauthorised credit card transactions, with 78% of general insurer complaints related to liability. FIDReC resolved 1,218 complaints, with 94% concluded within six months, and plans to improve services and capabilities.

site_title: Damaged Festival Walk mall in Hong Kong remains closed
summary: The Festival Walk shopping mall in Hong Kong, owned by Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT), remains closed due to extensive damage from recent unrest. Recovery works, including debris cleanup and repair assessments, are ongoing. Insurers have been notified, and claims assessments are underway. Metal hoardings have been erected for safety and security. The mall's closure has affected MNACT's second-quarter performance, with 62% of net property income coming from Festival Walk.

site_title: Home loans more accessible with sliding interest rates
summary: Interest rates on home loans in Singapore have dropped, making it more accessible for buyers to secure affordable loans. Major banks, including DBS, Maybank, and Standard Chartered, are offering longer fixed-rate loans and lower floating-rate packages. The average 5-year fixed rate loan is now around 2% per annum, while floating rates start at 1.82%. Experts advise against taking on longer fixed-rate packages due to the risk of falling interest rates, recommending shorter fixed-rate loans or floating rates instead.

site_title: Hello - is anyone there?
summary: A Singapore Airlines article from 2019 reflects on the evolution of business communications, from telex and fax to email and the internet. The author reminisces about the early days of email as a relief from client queries, but notes its ubiquity and loss of control. The article does not contain any recent news or events, but rather a personal reflection on the author's experience in the industry.

site_title: 'Bromance' with Cook could see a thaw in Trump's big-tech ties
summary: US President Donald Trump's visit to Apple's Texas manufacturing plant marks a truce in his war on Silicon Valley, with an unlikely "bromance" with CEO Tim Cook. Cook has sidestepped Trump's anger by being diplomatic, avoiding public criticism and instead focusing on American manufacturing. The visit comes after Apple announced it would keep making Mac Pro computers in the US, and Trump has praised Cook's efforts, calling him "very diplomatic." The relationship may ease tensions between the White House and the tech industry.

site_title: Canada's largest railroad hit by strike, putting Trudeau in hot seat
summary: Canada's largest railroad, Canadian National (CN) Railway, experienced a strike by 3,000 unionized workers, disrupting the shipping of commodities and affecting the country's export of farm products. The strike, which began on November 19, 2019, has sparked calls for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government to intervene. The strike comes at a critical time for Trudeau's government, which relies on smaller parties to pass legislation and faces criticism from western provinces about its failure to get new oil pipelines built. Industry groups have urged the government to step in to limit damage to the economy.

site_title: STI sees red on US-China trade deal woes
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) fell 9.09 points or 0.3% to close at 3,229.78, as US-China trade deal woes weighed on Asian markets. The US Senate passed a Hong Kong bill, drawing ire from Beijing, triggering losses in Malaysia, South Korea, and Taiwan. Investors are now cautious about future US-China trade discussions, with some advising to buy risk-off insurance or hedge into gold. Despite this, Singapore's telco Singtel rose 2.5% after its Indian associate Bharti Airtel announced plans to raise phone rates.

site_title: Sony cooks up new AI and robotics unit for food revolution
summary: Sony launches Sony AI, a new research arm focused on artificial intelligence and robotics, particularly in the food industry. The unit aims to create new tools for chefs to expand their creativity with AI and robotics, resulting in innovative dishes. Sony foresees the development of robotic kitchens for elderly people and restaurants where robots cook in front of guests. The company is not the only tech giant entering the food market, with IBM already partnering with McCormick on AI in flavor and food product development.

site_title: Pope Francis lands in Thailand on start of Asian tour
summary: Pope Francis arrived in Thailand on November 20, 2019, as part of his Asian tour, marking his first visit to the country in nearly four decades. The pontiff was greeted by cheering faithful and met with Thailand's deputy prime minister, Somkid Jatusripitak, before attending a welcome party. Pope Francis' visit aims to promote interreligious dialogue and nuclear disarmament, and he will also meet with the Thai prime minister, King Maha Vajiralongkorn, and the 20th Supreme Patriarch of Thailand.

site_title: aiTrust's private placement raises S$150m
summary: ASCENDAS India Trust has raised S$150 million from a private placement, 4.1 times subscribed, at S$1.508 per unit. The funds will be used to partially finance a business park project in Bangalore, with 96% going towards upfront costs and the remaining 4% for fees, expenses, and existing pipeline projects. The new units are expected to be listed on the Singapore Exchange on Nov 28, with a-iTrust's gearing expected to fall to 31.3% from 33.3%.

site_title: US dollar rises as US-China relations worsen
summary: The US dollar rose as US President Donald Trump threatened to escalate a trade war with China, prompting China to condemn a US senate measure backing pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong. China's yuan slipped to a two-week low after Trump's tariff threat, while trade-exposed currencies fell. The move follows ongoing trade negotiations between the two countries, with Trump's fresh salvo on Canada also contributing to market volatility.

site_title: Airlines' fuel practices raise doubts over environmental commitments
summary: Airlines' fuel practices are raising doubts over their environmental commitments, as fuel tankering, a money-saving strategy, results in increased emissions of greenhouse gases. Airlines fill tanks at departure airports to avoid extra fuel costs at destination airports, leading to an estimated 286,000 tonnes of additional CO2 emissions annually. Despite adopting mechanisms to offset emissions, the industry is torn between economic and environmental imperatives, with some airlines practicing fuel tankering for operational reasons. The practice is expected to generate net savings of 265 million euros per year for airlines, but experts argue the industry is not doing enough to reduce emissions.

site_title: Trade war a negative-sum outcome for Asia
summary: A Morgan Stanley economist suggests that the US-China trade war has resulted in a negative-sum outcome for Asia, with China losing more than the other Asian economies gain. Despite some Asian producers benefiting from increased imports, the impact on aggregate demand will overwhelm any positive trade substitution effect, according to economist Deyi Tan. The outlook for Asia in 2020 hinges on the outcome of US-China trade negotiations, with a potential phase one deal potentially leading to a slowdown before a recovery. Economies in Asia-ex-Japan, such as South Korea, Singapore, and India, are relatively better placed to benefit from the trade war.

site_title: SIA-MAB partnership is about dollars and sense
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Malaysia Airlines Berhad (MAB) have formed a commercial pact to tap into each other's traffic flow and markets, driven by strong competition and muted economic outlook. The collaboration, which includes codeshare routes and joint products, aims to widen SIA's reach to more Malaysian cities and progressively codeshare on flights to Europe and other destinations. The deal is seen as a win-win for both airlines, with SIA's deep pockets and reputation expected to support the partnership, despite MAB's struggles with steep losses.

site_title: US Senate upholds human rights, democracy in HK Bill; China reacts angrily
summary: The US Senate has unanimously adopted the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act, supporting human rights and democracy in Hong Kong and threatening to revoke its special economic status. China has reacted angrily, summoning a US diplomat and threatening countermeasures. The bill bans the sale of tear gas and other equipment used to suppress pro-democracy protests and mandates sanctions against those committing human rights abuses. The US Senate's move is seen as a strong statement in support of Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement, which has been met with violent crackdowns since June.

site_title: New A*Star food innovation institute provides single access point for firms
summary: The Singapore Institute of Food and Biotechnology Innovation (SIFBI) will be launched by the second quarter of 2020, providing a single access point for firms interested in food innovation research. The institute, part of the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star), aims to establish Singapore as a leader in developing and commercializing agri-food innovation and tech solutions. Under common leadership, existing A*Star divisions will operate with a clearer strategy, promoting collaboration and innovation in the food and biotechnology sectors.

site_title: Singapore govt bonds to see steeper yield curve: analysts
summary: Singapore government bonds are expected to see a steeper yield curve in the coming weeks, with the 2- to 30-year spread and 5- to 30-year spread widening. This is due to easing short-term funding conditions and a selloff in longer-term SGS bonds. Analysts attribute the widening spreads to rising developed-market bond yields and the duration-heavy SGS 2020 issuance calendar. The 10-year SGS bond yield may continue to play catch-up to its US Treasury counterpart, with the 10-year yield expected to rise further if the China-US trade agreement is not signed by December 15.

site_title: 'The future is electric': Porsche sets out plans to battle Tesla in the US
summary: Porsche plans to produce over 50% electric vehicles by 2025, surpassing market leader Tesla in the US. The German manufacturer aims to offer a fully electric version of its Macan SUV from 2021, competing directly with Tesla's Y model. Porsche's Taycan, unveiled in September, is a luxury model capable of 0-60 mph in under three seconds, rivaling Tesla's offerings. The company's North American chief, Klaus Zellmer, stated that the future is electric, with Porsche committed to battery-powered vehicles. This move is seen as an attempt to overtake Tesla in the US market.

site_title: Shophouses in Bali Lane, Duxton Road up for sale by tender
summary: A pair of shophouses in Bali Lane, Bugis, Singapore, are up for sale by tender at a "fire sale" price of S$9.8 million and another at S$4.9 million in Duxton Road, both zoned "commercial" and near train stations. The shophouses at Bali Lane have a 999-year leasehold tenure and offer a high rental yield of 3.3%. The sale is seen as a result of the owner's desire to redeploy capital quickly, with the area becoming increasingly attractive to multinational companies and millennials.

site_title: ChildAid celebrates 15 years of giving back
summary: ChildAid 2019, a 15th-anniversary charity concert in Singapore, showcased 132 child performers on the Esplanade Theatre stage. The event raised funds for The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, supporting arts training and education for disadvantaged children. The concert featured notable performances, including a nod to its history, and was attended by notable alumni and musicians. The event is expected to raise over S$2 million for the two charities, with donations from various partners.

site_title: S African govt rules out any further funding to resolve airline wage strike
summary: South Africa's government has ruled out providing further funding to resolve the ongoing airline wage strike at South African Airways. Public Enterprises Minister Pravin Gordhan stated that the country is facing severe fiscal constraints and no more aid can be made available. The government has already provided over 20.5 billion rand (S$1.9 billion) to the airline over the past three years. The airline's management team is handling negotiations, and unions are urged to work towards a speedy resolution to the labour action, which has grounded flights and worsened the carrier's financial position.

site_title: COEs end mixed, price gap between categories slims
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums ended mixed, with some categories rising and others falling. COE prices for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp increased to S$32,000, while those for larger vehicles decreased to S$39,700. The price gap between small and big cars narrowed to S$7,700. Commercial vehicle COE prices fell to S$24,502, and motorcycle premiums dropped to S$3,921. The mixed results were influenced by year-end promotions and economic uncertainty.

site_title: MAS mulls regulating trading of payment token derivatives
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is considering regulating derivatives of payment tokens, such as Bitcoin and Ether, allowing trade on four approved exchanges. However, MAS warns that these derivatives are not suitable for retail investors due to their high price volatility and lack of intrinsic value. Retail investors will face stricter margin requirements, with a minimum of 1.5 times the standard amount required for institutional investors. The move aims to balance developing the decentralized finance industry with protecting retail investors' interests.

site_title: Asia needs to put more money where its mouth is
summary: Asia is expected to spend over US$8 trillion on food by 2030, doubling its current spend, with annual investments rising to US$290 billion. This surge will drive market growth of 7% annually, fueled by technological innovation and sustainable food production. Key investments will focus on healthier and more sustainable food, as well as increasing food quantity to meet the region's growing population. Asian cities are poised to become global agrifood powerhouses, with private and government sectors playing crucial roles in driving growth and collaboration.

site_title: UK home prices to lag inflation on Brexit uncertainty: poll
summary: UK home prices are expected to lag inflation until 2021 due to Brexit uncertainty, according to a Reuters poll. London prices are forecast to fall 1.5% this year and remain steady in 2020, while nationwide prices will rise 1% this year, 1.5% in 2020, and 2.3% in 2021. Economists predict a free-trade deal with the EU is the most likely outcome, but a no-deal Brexit would have the most deflationary impact on home prices. The uncertainty continues to deter buyers, with London's affordability problem persisting.

site_title: Thai opposition chief disqualified from Parliament in ruling
summary: Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit, leader of the Thai opposition party Future Forward, was disqualified from parliament by the Constitutional Court for breaking rules on media ownership. The ruling came despite his party's control of almost half the lower house of parliament and his criticism of the royalist establishment's grip on power. The court's decision was seen as a potential step towards the dissolution of the party, and analysts worry about the impact on Thailand's fragile democracy, where officials are struggling to revive the economy with a slim government majority.

site_title: Australia's Westpac slapped with 23m money laundering breaches
summary: Australia's Westpac Banking Corp has been accused of 23 million breaches of anti-money laundering laws, with regulators claiming the bank ignored red flags and enabled payments from convicted child sex offenders and high-risk countries. Austrac, the financial crime watchdog, is pursuing fines of up to A$483 trillion, with Westpac CEO Brian Hartzer admitting the bank "should have done better" and accepting most of the regulator's assertions. The case is the country's biggest-ever money laundering scandal, and its outcome will have significant financial and reputational implications for the bank.

site_title: Mission: Cutting food and fashion waste
summary: Three teams of youth in Singapore have received funding to scale up their ideas to reduce waste and carbon emissions. The funding comes from OCBC's #OCBCCares Environment Fund, totaling S$70,000. The teams aim to find new life for Singapore's usable discards, with a focus on food and textile waste. Statistics show that 17% of 7.7 million tonnes of waste in Singapore last year came from food and 6% from textiles, with the goal of minimizing waste to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and tackle the country's waste culture.

site_title: Building the business case to fight climate change
summary: Singapore's recent $2 billion commitment to drive sustainability and green finance comes at a critical time, following a warning from 11,258 scientists about the climate emergency. Companies must reassess the emerging threats and map out responses demanded by stakeholders. To fight climate change, businesses need to build a new case that goes beyond responsibility and risks, focusing on self-interest. This requires assessing the implications of climate change actions on financial bottom lines and demonstrating tangible benefits. A third angle, "rationale," is necessary to complete the triangle, enabling companies to see that taking on climate change is in their own self-interest.

site_title: Former AMKTC general manager, company director jailed over corrupt business dealings
summary: A former general manager of Ang Mo Kio Town Council, Wong Chee Meng, was sentenced to 27 months' jail for corruption offences involving bribes of over S$50,000 from a director of two construction firms. The director, Chia Sin Lan, was also sentenced to 21 months' jail. The bribes were used to influence tenders and contracts worth S$9,874,650. Wong admitted to three counts of corruption, including accepting bribes for a Toyota Corolla, payments to his mistress, and entertainment expenses.

site_title: The US$15b reason Asia bond defaults could rise in 2020
summary: Asia's financial stress is expected to rise in 2020, with nearly $15.1 billion of dollar bonds due, prompting fears of defaults. Companies in the region, including Chinese conglomerates and coal miners, are facing financial strain due to weaker regional borrowers, rising failures in China, and a liquidity crunch in India. Goldman Sachs forecasts a 3% default rate for Asia high-yield corporate bonds, while experts warn of a "lot more hectic" situation, with discussions on restructuring and debt problems increasing. Defaults could be triggered by China policymakers' tolerance for credit stress.

site_title: Aston Martin joins the ranks of luxury SUVs with the US$189,000 DBX
summary: Aston Martin unveiled its first SUV, the DBX, priced at $189,000, in Los Angeles and Beijing. The DBX features a 542-horsepower twin-turbocharged V-8 engine, 516 pound-feet of torque, and a 0-60 mph time of 4.3 seconds. The luxury SUV competes with Bentley's Bentayga, Rolls-Royce's Cullinan, Lamborghini's Urus, and Porsche's Cayenne Turbo. The DBX aims to balance Aston Martin's sales, which have been impacted by Brexit woes, and is expected to boost the brand's annual production to 14,000 vehicles by 2023.

site_title: When overwork is good and encouraged
summary: A game-theoretic model suggests that overwork is encouraged in certain high-potential employees to prove their worth to organizations, as it benefits both the individual and the company. This approach attracts workers who value showcasing their abilities and are willing to accept lower salaries in exchange for the opportunity. However, this strategy can lead to burnout and mistakes. Organizations that promote overwork typically attract high-potentials, while those that discourage overwork tend to hire proven talents and hidden gems who may not benefit from overworking. Ultimately, there is no one-size-fits-all solution, and organizations must balance the incentives for overwork to find the best approach for their workers.

images.alt_text: If a worker's talents are (at least partially) uncertain, then every project, every presentation, every meeting is an opportunity to learn and showcase talents. This explains why workers may sometimes want to overwork.

site_title: Aston Martin unveils first SUV, eyes luxury buyers in China
summary: Aston Martin unveiled its first SUV, the DBX, in Beijing and Los Angeles, aiming to tap into China's growing luxury car market. The company seeks to more than double its sales in China, currently around 500 units per year. The DBX features a four-litre V8 engine, capable of 181mph, and is priced at $189,900 in the US, with similar prices expected in China. The move is seen as a response to the growing demand for SUVs, which account for nearly half of new car purchases in China, but also raises environmental concerns.

site_title: Alibaba to price HK shares at HK$176 in landmark listing
summary: Alibaba Group will list its Hong Kong shares at HK$176 each, raising up to US$12.9 billion and marking the largest share sale in the city in nearly a decade. The deal is seen as a much-needed boost to Hong Kong, which has been affected by anti-government protests and its first recession in a decade. The listing is also a world record cross-border secondary share sale, providing a significant influx of capital for the Chinese e-commerce giant.

site_title: Wall Street mired in US$2t Saudi Aramco quandary
summary: Saudi Aramco's scaled-back IPO raises questions about the effectiveness of mammoth syndicates of advisers and IPO book-runners. Despite nearly every major investment bank being involved, the sale of shares to big institutional funds in the West was largely redundant due to Saudi Arabia's focus on a local sale. The abundance of advisers and book-runners may have contributed to the failure to deliver a realistic valuation, with the risk of diluting accountability among peers. A more focused group of banks might have avoided this issue, but ultimately, the irreconcilable difference between investor willingness to pay and the Crown Prince's acceptance remained.

site_title: Aviva shares drop as corporate shakeup leaves investors unimpressed
summary: Aviva shares dropped 2.9% to 406 pence after the British insurer announced a corporate shakeup, reorganizing into five divisions and selling its Hong Kong business stake. The move fell short of investor expectations for a broader change in strategy. Aviva's CEO Maurice Tulloch outlined a simpler strategy with attractive growth engines, but analysts expressed disappointment, saying investors would be "a little underwhelmed." The insurer set three-year targets, including a 12% return on equity and a £300 million net cost saving by 2022.

site_title: Continental to cut 5,040 jobs as combustion engine demand falls
summary: Continental, a German auto supplier, plans to cut 5,040 jobs by 2028 due to declining demand for combustion engine components. The company will close sites in Germany and the US, affecting around 3,340 jobs, and reduce production in Italy. Continental's engine manufacturing activities are threatened by stricter emissions rules and the shift to battery-powered vehicles. The job losses are part of the company's efforts to adapt to the changing market and focus on more sustainable technologies.

site_title: Open innovation can be Singapore's competitive advantage
summary: Singapore is shifting towards open innovation to maintain its status as a major innovation hub in Asia. This approach involves collaborative research and development outside of traditional company or institutional boundaries. Open innovation allows for the sharing of knowledge and expertise, helping small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and startups access larger companies and resources. The recent launch of the Open Innovation Network (OIN) is a key step forward, providing innovation platforms for various sectors and challenges. This move is expected to strengthen Singapore's competitive advantage and drive demand for sustainable technologies and solutions.

site_title: China tortured me over Hong Kong, says former British consulate employee
summary: A former employee of Britain's consulate in Hong Kong, Simon Cheng, claims Chinese secret police tortured him while he was detained for 15 days after returning from a trip to mainland China in August. Cheng was beaten, deprived of sleep, and shackled, and was forced to give a written confession and sing the Chinese national anthem. Britain condemned the treatment, with Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab calling it "torture" and "disgraceful". Cheng, who supports the pro-democracy movement, has resigned from the consulate and fled to an unnamed third country, seeking asylum.

site_title: US envoy followed Trump orders in Ukraine 'quid pro quo'
summary: US Ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland testified that he followed President Donald Trump's orders in seeking a "quid pro quo" from Ukraine, pressuring the country to investigate Joe Biden and his son Hunter. Sondland said Trump held off on a White House summit with Ukraine's president, Volodymyr Zelensky, unless Kiev publicly announced investigations into a gas company and a conspiracy theory. The ambassador believed this was a quid pro quo for arranging a White House visit for Zelensky, and he opposed the suspension of security aid to Ukraine.

site_title: Czech developers tangled in kafkaesque maze of red tape
summary: In Prague, Czech developers face significant bureaucratic hurdles, slowing the construction of new apartments despite high demand and soaring housing prices. The city's booming tourism industry and rapidly growing population have exacerbated the supply squeeze, with prices increasing 22% last year. Developers, like Central Group's Michaela Tomaskova, are calling for faster permit processes to stabilize the market. However, the approval process is often lengthy, taking up to 10 years, and involves multiple authorities, making it a "kafkaesque" experience. As a result, new apartments are scarce, and prices show no signs of slowing down.

site_title: Saudi Aramco to meet investors in Dubai and Abu Dhabi
summary: Saudi Aramco plans to meet investors in Dubai and Abu Dhabi to raise up to $25.6 billion in its world's biggest share sale. The state oil giant has set an indicative price of $1.7 trillion, below the $2 trillion sought by Saudi's crown prince. The company will not directly sell shares to investors in developed markets, instead opting for a largely domestic-focused offering. The IPO is seen as a key milestone in Saudi Arabia's efforts to diversify its economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is consulting on regulating trade of payment token derivatives, such as Bitcoin and Ether, on approved exchanges. Meanwhile, the Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) expressed concerns over Utico's offer for Hyflux, and longer-term Singapore government bonds face headwinds due to rising bond yields. The Straits Times Index fell 0.3% as Singapore shares dropped.

site_title: SIAS concerned over lack of finality on Utico's offer
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) is concerned about the lack of finality on Utico's offer to acquire Hyflux, with the deal still in negotiations. Despite Hyflux's commitment to finalize the deal, changes have been introduced at the last minute by Utico, causing delays. SIAS urges all parties to continue negotiations to achieve a commercially acceptable outcome for all stakeholders. The deal, which involves Utico taking an 88% stake in Hyflux, has been ongoing since October, with Hyflux's shares suspended since May last year due to financial difficulties.

site_title: Rich people say politics spurring them to donate more money
summary: Wealthy individuals in the US are increasing their charitable donations due to the country's political climate. A Wells Fargo study of 525 people with incomes over $240,000 found that 40% are giving more, while 7% are giving less. 54% of Democrats, 39% of independents, and 18% of Republicans have increased their contributions. Economic factors, such as tax changes, have also influenced donations, with a quarter of recent giving attributed to this factor. The average donation to non-faith-based organizations was $5,400, with a median donation of $2,000.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips at open on escalating US-China tensions
summary: US stocks slipped at the open on November 20, 2019, due to escalating tensions between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.19% to 27,879.55, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.18% and 0.32%, respectively. Investors are concerned that strained US-China relations could derail trade negotiations.

site_title: Alibaba raises US$11b in biggest Hong Kong listing since 2010
summary: Alibaba Group Holding raised approximately US$11 billion in a Hong Kong stock sale, priced at HK$176 per share. The offering, despite Hong Kong's worsening political unrest, was oversubscribed and allocated more shares to individual investors. The deal could swell Alibaba's cash pile to about US$44 billion, surpassing other internet companies. It also pleased local and Chinese officials, showcasing Hong Kong's potential as a financial hub.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks snap three days of gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended down on Wednesday, snapping a three-day gain, due to worries over China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng index dropped 0.75%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.78% and 0.71%, respectively. This follows a three-per-cent advance earlier in the week.

site_title: Thai court strips opposition frontman of MP status
summary: A Thai court has stripped opposition leader Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit of his MP status due to a media shareholding case, potentially leading to a 10-year prison sentence and a ban from politics. Thanathorn, the frontman of the Future Forward party, denied the charges, claiming they were politically motivated. The ruling could deal a significant blow to the party, which won significant support among millennials with its anti-military stance.

site_title: Sri Lanka's new president names brother Mahinda as PM
summary: Sri Lanka's new President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has sworn in his elder brother Mahinda as prime minister, following the resignation of Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe. Mahinda, a former president, will assume duties as premier soon after Wickremesinghe steps down on Thursday. The move comes after Wickremesinghe's party suffered a humiliating defeat at the presidential polls. The Rajapaksa brothers are credited with crushing the Tamil Tigers, but their security services have been accused of war crimes and human rights abuses.

site_title: Suu Kyi to contest Rohingya genocide case at world court
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi will contest a Rohingya genocide case at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), with Myanmar denying accusations of genocide against its Rohingya Muslim minority. Over 730,000 Rohingya have fled to Bangladesh since a 2017 military crackdown, with Gambia filing a lawsuit. Suu Kyi's government has retained international lawyers to defend Myanmar, with the first public hearings set for Dec 10-12. Suu Kyi will lead a team to the Hague to defend Myanmar's national interest, despite facing criticism for not speaking out against human rights violations.

images.alt_text: Aung San Suu Kyi will appear before the International Court of Justice (ICJ) to contest a case filed by Gambia accusing Myanmar of genocide against its Rohingya Muslim minority, her government said on Wednesday.

site_title: GDS Global widens full-year net loss to S$1.76m
summary: GDS Global reported a widened full-year net loss of S$1.76 million, down from S$630,000 a year ago, due to declining revenue of 19.6% to S$14.26 million. The decline was primarily attributed to a 41.4% drop in door and shutter system sales, offset by increases in service and maintenance revenue and trading and designing of production components.

site_title: Aviva restructures into 5 divisions, sells Hong Kong stake to Hillhouse Capital
summary: British insurer Aviva is restructuring into 5 operating divisions, simplifying its business following a review. It is selling its Hong Kong stake to co-investor Hillhouse Capital and aims to achieve a 12% return on equity by 2022, with a £300 million net cost saving. Aviva is also reviewing its businesses in Vietnam and Indonesia, and has decided to keep its Singapore operation and joint venture in China. The insurer's new divisions include investments, savings and retirement; UK life; Europe life; Asia life; and general insurance.

site_title: US-China trade war a negative-sum outcome for Asia: Morgan Stanley economist
summary: Morgan Stanley economist Deyi Tan suggests the US-China trade war has resulted in a negative-sum outcome for Asia, with gains made by other Asian economies at China's expense being less than the losses incurred. Despite initial optimism, research data indicates nine out of 10 Asian economies have lost global export share, and the impact of trade tensions will overwhelm any positive effects. The outcome hinges on the outcome of US-China trade negotiations, with a potential "phase one" deal potentially allowing for a recovery in 2020, but with a slow-motion slowdown expected before a recovery.

site_title: US Senate passes Hong Kong rights bill, angering China
summary: The US Senate has unanimously passed a bill supporting "human rights and democracy" in Hong Kong, threatening to revoke its special economic status and banning the sale of tear gas and rubber bullets used to suppress pro-democracy protests. China has responded angrily, summoning a US diplomat and threatening countermeasures, including revoking the US-China trade agreement. The bill requires the US president to review Hong Kong's favorable trade status annually and mandates sanctions against officials committing human rights abuses.

site_title: MAS mulls regulating trade of payment token derivatives
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is considering regulating the trade of payment token derivatives, such as Bitcoin and Ether derivatives, on approved exchanges like Singapore Exchange Derivatives and Asia-Pacific Exchange. The regulation aims to introduce a controlled product for institutional investors, but retail investors are not suitable for this type of trading due to high price volatility and potential losses. Retail investors will face higher margin requirements, starting from June 30 next year, with a minimum 50% floor. MAS invites comments on the proposed regulation until December 20.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 0.3% after HK bill draws ire of Beijing
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.3% to close at 3,229.78, as markets in Asia-Pacific posted losses due to concerns over a US-China trade deal. The US Senate passed the Hong Kong bill, drawing ire from Beijing, which triggered a sell-off in Asian markets. Despite this, Singapore's STI fared better than its peers, partly due to a surge in Singtel's shares. The US-China trade deal's prospects remain uncertain, with investors seeking to hedge against potential losses.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on fresh trade worries
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday due to fresh concerns over US-China trade talks, following Beijing's criticism of the US over Hong Kong protests. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.62% and the Topix index dropped 0.33%. The decline was attributed to heightened market uncertainty, with traders weighing the implications of US-China trade tensions on global markets.

site_title: South Korea: Shares slide as US, China spar over Hong Kong protests
summary: South Korean shares fell over 1% on Wednesday as tensions between the US and China over Hong Kong protests dimmed hopes for a trade deal. China made stern representations to the US embassy in Beijing after the Senate unanimously passed legislation aimed at protecting human rights in Hong Kong. Foreigners dumped domestic shares for the 10th consecutive session, net selling US$285.59 million worth of shares. This drop marks the lowest close in a week for the Seoul stock market's main KOSPI.

site_title: CapitaLand to sell The Star Vista to Rock Productions for S$296m
summary: CapitaLand to sell The Star Vista to Rock Productions for S$296 million. The divestment is expected to generate net proceeds of approximately S$145 million and a net gain of approximately S$32 million. The sale is part of CapitaLand's asset recycling strategy, with the company having divested close to S$5.7 billion worth of assets year to date. The transaction is expected to be completed by the end of the year, with Rock Productions also exploring the possibility of having CapitaLand continue operating and managing the retail mall on its behalf.

site_title: Hong Kong's world-beating stock gain falters after just two days
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index experienced a 2.9% surge in two days, but lost 0.6% in pre-market trading on the third day, wiping out its gains. Volatility decreased by 11% and short-selling volume reached 16% of total equity turnover. The US Senate passed a bill supporting Hong Kong protesters, prompting China's threat to retaliate. Analysts attribute the initial gains to beaten-down valuations, improved US-China trade sentiment, and uncertainty surrounding local district elections. The Hang Seng Index now trades at 10 times earnings, a 35% discount to global peers, but remains a high-risk investment due to ongoing protests.

site_title: Beijing tariff demands may expand US-China 'phase one' trade deal significantly
summary: US President Donald Trump may expand the 'phase one' trade deal with China significantly if he agrees to roll back existing tariffs on Chinese goods, according to people familiar with the talks. China's demands include removing existing tariffs, higher Chinese purchases of US farm goods, and improved access to China's financial services industry. Trump wants to keep existing tariffs for future leverage, but Beijing is balking at committing to specific agricultural purchases. The deal's scope and timeline are uncertain, potentially pushing it into next year.

site_title: Thai Oct domestic car sales drop 11.3% y-o-y: industries federation
summary: Thai domestic car sales dropped 11.3% in October, reaching 77,121 units, due to stricter lending by banks and flooding in the country. This marks the fifth consecutive month of decline. Sales are forecast to fall 3.8% in 2019 to 1 million units, down from a 19.5% rise to 1.05 million units in 2018. The decline affects Thailand's position as a regional vehicle production and export base for top automobile manufacturers.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets fall at open
summary: Europe's stock markets fell at the start of trading on Wednesday, with the FTSE 100 losing 0.6% to 7,282.10 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also declined 0.6% and 0.7% respectively. This decline follows a global rally in the previous session.

images.alt_text: Europe's leading stock markets retreated at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index losing 0.6 per cent to 7,282.10 points.

site_title: StanChart eyes millennials with savings product offering 2% interest rate
summary: Standard Chartered launched its JumpStart savings account, targeting millennials aged 18-26 with a 2% interest rate on the first S$20,000. The account offers no minimum deposit, no fees, and no lock-in period. Since its soft launch, nearly 7,000 accounts were opened, with plans to expand to other areas, such as financial seminars and community outreach. The bank aims to help millennials build healthy financial habits as they transition into working professionals, with a focus on saving for home ownership and marriage.

site_title: Singapore, a potential agri-food powerhouse in Asia: report
summary: Singapore and other Asian cities have the potential to become global agri-food innovation powerhouses, according to a recent report by PwC, Rabobank, and Temasek Holdings. These cities offer a positive regulatory environment, technical expertise, talent, and a strong pool of investors, which will drive investment and innovation in the region's agri-food sector. The report highlights the need for investments across the agri-food chain to solve Asia's food challenge, particularly with the growing population and urbanization expected by 2030. Private equity, venture capital, and accelerators are expected to play a major role in driving such investments.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.17 points to 1,601.14. Volume reached 2.9 billion lots worth RM2 billion, with 434 gainers and 403 losers.

site_title: Apple starts construction of new US$1b campus in Texas
summary: Apple has begun construction on a $1 billion campus in Austin, Texas, near its existing facility where it manufactures MacBook Pro laptops. The project was announced in 2019 and is seen as a move to diversify its manufacturing base. Apple CEO Tim Cook will tour the Texas factory, which has been a point of contention with President Donald Trump due to its reliance on Chinese production. The development is a significant step in Apple's efforts to increase its presence in the US market.

images.alt_text: Apple Chief Executive Officer Tim Cook is set to give a tour of the Texas factory to US President Donald Trump

site_title: Australia: Shares tumble on Westpac breach, Sino-US trade rhetoric
summary: Australian shares fell 1.4% to 6,722.40, weighed down by losses in financials, particularly Westpac Banking Corp, which dropped 2.2% after regulators accused it of anti-money laundering breaches. US President Donald Trump's reluctance to roll back tariffs on Chinese imports dampened hopes of a trade deal between the two major economies, affecting investor sentiment.

site_title: Louis Dreyfus Co, Temasek Lifesciences Accelerator tie up on agri-food innovation
summary: Louis Dreyfus Co and Temasek Lifesciences Accelerator have partnered to boost agri-food innovation in the region. Through the partnership, Louis Dreyfus will access new technology from the accelerator's portfolio of startups, while the accelerator will benefit from Louis Dreyfus' supply chain and asset network for market penetration and partnerships. This collaboration aims to drive innovation and growth in the agri-food sector, leveraging the strengths of both companies.

site_title: CBRE snags new Singapore head of valuation & advisory services from Knight Frank
summary: CBRE has appointed Png Poh Soon as its head of valuation and advisory services for Singapore, effective January 2, 2020. Png brings over 17 years of experience in real estate services, specializing in land acquisitions and property tax. He will focus on driving the growth of CBRE's valuation services and report to Moray Armstrong and Vamshi KK Nakirekanti. Png's expertise and network will benefit CBRE's corporate and institutional clients, particularly in mortgage valuation.

site_title: Alibaba won't join Hong Kong's stock benchmark any time soon
summary: Alibaba Group Holding won't be included in Hong Kong's most widely followed stock benchmark unless the index provider significantly revises its rules to accommodate companies with unequal voting rights. This special arrangement was a reason Hong Kong lost out to New York for Alibaba's initial public offering in 2014. The index compiler will hold a consultation early next year to review the eligibility of companies with such structures.

site_title: Singapore and Mexico affirm growing ties, sign raft of new agreements
summary: Singapore and Mexico signed several cooperation agreements, including water resource management, science and technology, and international development. The agreements aim to strengthen trade and investment ties between the two countries. The leaders pledged to conclude a free trade agreement by this year, with the Pacific Alliance being a key focus. Bilateral trade between Singapore and Mexico has grown to $4.7 billion in 2018, making Mexico Singapore's second-largest trading partner in Latin America. The two countries also celebrate 45 years of diplomatic relations next year, with commemorative activities planned, including an exhibition on Mexican history and culture.

site_title: Japan economy minister says he hopes Britain joins TPP trade pact after Brexit
summary: Japanese Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura expressed hope that Britain would join the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade pact after Brexit. Nishimura stated that negotiations on Britain's entry into the free trade bloc cannot proceed as long as it remains an EU member. He also emphasized the importance of maintaining strong economic relations between Japan and Britain after Brexit.

site_title: Wirecard defends accounting after report of unit's delayed audit in Singapore
summary: Wirecard AG has defended its accounting practices after a report suggested delays in an audit of its Singapore operations from 2017. The company stated that Ernst & Young couldn't form a "final audit opinion" due to restrictions from an ongoing investigation in Singapore, not irregularities. Wirecard claimed its local financial statements were duly audited within the scope of the audit. The shares fell about 10% in pre-market trading.

site_title: Shophouses along Bali Lane, Duxton Road up for sale by tender
summary: A pair of shophouses along Bali Lane in Bugis, Singapore, are up for sale by tender at discounted prices of S$9.8 million and S$4.9 million, respectively. The shophouses have a 999-year leasehold tenure, commercial zoning, and are within walking distance to Bugis MRT interchange. PropNex Realty attributes the discounts to the owner's desire to cash out quickly for personal use. The sale is seen as part of Singapore's growing commercial district, which is attracting multinational companies and millennials.

site_title: Emerging markets have monetary firepower to drive world economy
summary: Emerging markets, including India, Brazil, and Indonesia, have sufficient monetary firepower to support the global economy, which is experiencing its weakest expansion in a decade. Central banks in these countries can cut interest rates further to cushion an economic downturn. Morgan Stanley economists predict emerging markets will grow 4.4% next year, more than three times the growth rate of developed countries. This outlook is driven by the potential for growth stabilization in the US-China trade war and the International Monetary Fund's expectation that emerging markets will drive global economic growth.

site_title: SIAS says Utico made last-minute changes to Hyflux rescue package
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) has expressed concerns over Utico's last-minute changes to the Hyflux rescue package, which could potentially scuttle a deal that could benefit many stakeholders. Despite a two-month extension granted by the Singapore High Court, negotiations between Hyflux and Utico have been hindered by repeated changes. SIAS urges all parties to continue negotiations for a commercially acceptable outcome.

site_title: Cancer screening startup Lucence raises US$20m in funding led by IHH
summary: Lucence Diagnostics, a Singapore-based genomic medicine firm, has raised US$20 million in Series A funding led by IHH Healthcare, one of the world's largest private healthcare groups. The funding will be used to provide liquid biopsy technology to more patients across Asia and North America for personalized treatment selection. Lucence's technology focuses on early detection of multiple cancers, including lung, breast, and colorectal cancer. The startup plans to start new clinical studies to evaluate its technology for early cancer detection.

images.alt_text: Lucence founder Tan Min-Han said that the fresh capital will enable the startup to provide its liquid biopsy technology to more patients across Asia and North America.

site_title: Hyflux to hold FY2018 AGM by Dec 31
summary: Hyflux has been granted a two-month extension by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) to hold its FY2018 annual general meeting (AGM) by December 31, 2019. The company had initially requested a three-month extension. Additionally, Hyflux obtained four-month extensions from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to release its FY2018 and FY2019 financial results. The company's FY2018 annual return must be filed by January 31, 2020.

site_title: The Greater Mekong region will urbanise faster than UN's estimates: ANZ
summary: The Greater Mekong region, comprising Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam, is expected to urbanise at a rate of 3.7% per annum, faster than the UN's projected 2.3%, according to ANZ. This growth is driven by the relocation of manufacturing facilities from China and reorganisation of regional supply chains. The accelerated urbanisation is seen as a positive factor for regional economies and provides governments with a policy tool to stimulate growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on strong yen, falls on Wall Street
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on November 20, 2019, due to a strong yen and falls on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.40% and the Topix index fell 0.42%. The declines were attributed to lingering uncertainty over US-China trade talks.

site_title: Asian users aged 31-34 most accurate in finance assessments: Robocash
summary: Asian users aged 31-34 are the most accurate in matching their finance needs to actual capabilities, according to Robocash Group. This age range outperformed 18-24 and 51-60-year-olds by 7.9% and 12.3% respectively. Millennials in Indonesia (25-30) and the Philippines (31-34) showed the best accuracy, while Vietnamese clients were less accurate, registering a difference of 19.5% and 16.8% respectively. Robocash analysts expect the difference to shrink in the future as other generations gain experience and knowledge in using online financing services.

site_title: Longer-term Singapore government bonds facing headwinds: DBS
summary: Singapore government bonds with tenors above 10 years are facing headwinds due to profit-taking pressure, according to DBS Group Research. Rising developed-market bond yields and a duration-heavy 2020 issuance calendar are driving the selloff. Despite this, shorter-term bonds remain stable, and the spread between SGS and US Treasuries remains in line with the US curve. DBS expects steepening pressures to persist on the SGS yield curve, especially in the 2- to 30-year spread, and sees potential for outperformance in 5-year and 10-year SGS bonds contingent on the China-US trade agreement.

site_title: US Senate in unanimous support for Hong Kong protesters
summary: The US Senate unanimously passed legislation supporting human rights and democracy in Hong Kong, threatening to revoke the territory's special status with China. The bill also bans the sale of equipment used to suppress protests. The move comes after China expressed strong indignation over a similar measure passed by the US House of Representatives last month. The Senate aims to reconcile the bills and pass them to President Trump's desk for signature. The legislation sends a clear message to Hong Kongers fighting for their freedoms, with senators standing firmly in support of the territory's autonomy.

site_title: COEs end mixed, price difference between big and small car premiums narrows
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums ended mixed at the latest tender, with prices for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp increasing to S$32,000, while those for larger vehicles decreased to S$39,700. This narrowed the price difference between small and big car COEs to S$7,700. Commercial vehicle COE prices fell to S$24,502, and motorcycle premiums dropped to S$3,921. The price movements were influenced by year-end promotions and economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums ended mixed at the latest tender on Wednesday (Nov 20) as year-end promotions countered prevailing market weakness on the back of economic uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.23%
summary: Singapore shares started Wednesday lower, down 0.23% to 3,231.47, following a decline in US indices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.4% and the S&P 500 retreated 0.1%. Asian markets also fell, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index down 0.4%. The Straits Times Index was led by losses in local lenders DBS, OCBC, and UOB.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon down 0.19% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading on Wednesday, down 0.19% at 1:05pm, with 542.5 million securities worth S$489.3 million changing hands. Decliners outnumbered advancers 202 to 112, with notable losers including YZJ Shipbuilding (-2.8%), Rex International (-1.6%), and DBS (-1.1%). Banking stocks also fell, while Singtel gained 2.8%.

site_title: SP Group commits S$35m for digital workplace, formalises training committee
summary: SP Group has committed S$35 million over three years to develop digital workplace competencies, targeting areas such as customer service, cybersecurity, and data analytics. The company is formalizing a training committee with the Union of Power and Gas Employees (UPAGE) to address talent resourcing needs and ensure employees have the right skills for business growth. This initiative aims to alleviate fears about job displacement due to technology and promote upskilling for better wages and work prospects.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink as Hong Kong bill adds to trade jitters
summary: Asian markets declined on Wednesday due to renewed trade jitters, following the US Senate's passage of a bill supporting Hong Kong civil rights. The bill, which must be signed off by President Trump, threatens to revoke Hong Kong's special economic status and impose sanctions on Chinese officials. This move is expected to anger Beijing, adding to concerns about the China-US trade talks. Markets fell across Asia, with Hong Kong down 0.8%, Shanghai down 0.2%, and Tokyo down 0.7%. Oil prices remained flat, with traders drawing a line between a trade deal and oil demand growth.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte says to ban 'toxic' vaping
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has ordered a ban on e-cigarettes, citing concerns over their toxicity. The ban includes the use and importation of electronic cigarettes, and those caught vaping publicly may face arrest. The move comes after the country reported its first vaping-related lung injury, a 16-year-old girl hospitalized. The ban is the latest in a series of e-cigarette restrictions, following India's ban in September 2019 and existing bans in several countries including the US state of Massachusetts and Brazil.

site_title: US housing outlook improves but not breaking new ground: poll
summary: US home prices are expected to continue rising, albeit at a slower pace, until at least 2022, with a predicted 3.0% rise in 2019, followed by 2.9% and 2.8% over the next two years. The outlook remains steady, with a tight supply of homes and a strong demand for housing. However, nearly 60% of analysts predict a rebound in housing market activity over the next year, driven by a potential truce in the US-China trade dispute and falling mortgage rates.

site_title: Temasek looks to expand US deals regardless of trade war
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state investor, plans to continue allocating funds to the US despite escalating trade tensions. About 15% of its portfolio is invested in North America, and around 7% in life sciences and agribusiness. Despite a 3 billion euro stake in Bayer losing value due to lawsuits, Temasek remains optimistic about the investment, taking a long-term view. The firm will focus on early-stage investments, increasing stakes in existing portfolio companies, and private equity, until Bayer's situation is resolved.

site_title: Australia billionaires plan to export solar power to Singapore
summary: Australian billionaires Mike Cannon-Brookes and Andrew Forrest have invested tens of millions of dollars in a project to supply solar power from northern Australia to Singapore via a subsea high voltage cable. The A$22 billion project, called Sun Cable, aims to build a 10-gigawatt solar farm, a 22-gigawatt hour battery storage facility, and a 4,500 km transmission network. The project, which would supply a fifth of Singapore's power needs, hopes to secure financing by late 2023 and is seen as a world-changing potential project with the potential to create jobs and set Australia's economy up for the future.

site_title: Canada's largest railroad hit by strike, putting Trudeau in hot seat
summary: Thousands of Canadian National Railway workers went on strike, disrupting the shipping of commodities and putting Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government in a hot seat. The strike, involving 3,000 unionized workers, centers on contract issues, including fatigue and safety concerns. Canada, a major exporter of farm products, relies heavily on CN and Canadian Pacific Railway to transport commodities. Industry groups and companies, including the mining and forestry sectors, are calling on the government to intervene to limit the economic damage, with the strike potentially triggering mine closures and layoffs.

site_title: HDB to sell new S$700m 1.75% senior bond at par
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) will issue a S$700 million, 5-year senior bond at par value, with a fixed coupon of 1.75% paid semi-annually, starting from 2020. The bond matures on Nov 25, 2024, and will be used to finance development programmes and refinance existing borrowings. The bond is expected to be rated "Aaa" by Moody's and will be listed on the Singapore Exchange in denominations of S$250,000.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.00 points to 1,601.31. Volume reached 53.8 million lots worth RM22.26 million. Gainers beat losers 90 to 63.

site_title: Even Hong Kong's homegrown bankers are considering moving away
summary: Hong Kong's financial hub is experiencing growing unease among bankers and executives due to the city's social unrest, with some considering moving to the US, China, or other countries. Applications for certificates of no criminal conviction, a step toward moving abroad, have surged, and local polls indicate an increasing desire to leave. Despite no exodus, private talks among colleagues and employers suggest nerves are fraying, with some weighing the possibility of relocating to mitigate the impact of the ongoing protests and China's increasing control.

site_title: Exxon's credit rating outlook lowered by Moody's on cash burn
summary: ExxonMobil's credit rating outlook was lowered to negative by Moody's due to a "substantial" cash burn to fund growth. The oil major's debt metrics are expected to weaken over the next few years, with debt likely rising despite asset sales. ExxonMobil's negative free cash flow and high dividend payout are key factors contributing to the downgrade. This move follows a similar downgrade in 2016 during the oil price crash, and investors are wary of the company's ability to fund its growth capital spending program.

images.alt_text: Exxon Mobil Corp had the outlook on its top-notch debt rating lowered by Moody's Investors Service Inc to negative due to a "substantial" cash burn to fund growth.

site_title: 5 more countries sign Singapore convention on mediation
summary: Five more countries, including Armenia, Chad, Ecuador, Gabon, and Guinea-Bissau, have signed the Singapore Convention on Mediation, bringing the total number of signatory countries to 51. This demonstrates commitment to multilateralism and a rules-based international order. The convention aims to promote mediation in cross-border commercial disputes and is relevant to the work of the Permanent Court of Arbitration (PCA) in Singapore. The PCA has administered 28 proceedings and concluded nine hearings since setting up its office in 2018.

site_title: Eastern Pacific, Techstars launch maritime startup accelerator
summary: Eastern Pacific Shipping and Techstars have launched a global maritime startup accelerator programme to bring digital and technology-led solutions to the shipping industry. The first cohort of nine startups, from Singapore, Denmark, the UK, and the US, will undergo three months of research and development, mentorship, and collaboration. The startups will access operational data and deploy their technology on Eastern Pacific's fleet of over 150 vessels, aiming to solve problems such as fuel consumption, operational efficiency, and improving life-at-sea for seafarers.

site_title: Morgan Stanley pushes advisers to boost revenue in 2020 pay plan: sources
summary: Morgan Stanley has introduced a new 2020 compensation plan that incentivizes advisers to boost revenue and target wealthier customers. The plan features a 16-tier "pay-out grid" that determines payouts based on annual revenue, with those generating less than $5 million required to deliver an additional 10% to reach the 2019 payout level. The plan also penalizes advisers for working with low-income households and those not enrolled in comprehensive financial plans. The changes could affect around half of Morgan Stanley's 15,553 advisers, according to compensation consultant Andy Tasnady.

site_title: Australia's Westpac accused of 23 million money laundering breaches
summary: Australia's Westpac Banking Corp was accused of 23 million breaches of anti-money laundering rules, with AUSTRAC regulator saying the bank enabled payments from "high risk" countries and convicted child sex offenders. The oversight failure led to "serious and systemic non-compliance" with anti-money laundering laws, with fines of up to A$21 million possible. The breach occurred from 2013 to late 2018, despite the bank knowing about "heightened child exploitation risks" and failing to set up an automated detection system until 2018.

site_title: New A*Star food innovation institute gives single touchpoint for industry
summary: Singapore's new A*Star food innovation institute, set to open in the second quarter of 2020, will provide a single touchpoint for industry players interested in food innovation research. The institute brings together existing A*Star divisions focused on food, nutrition, and biotechnology to support the development of healthier and more sustainable foods for the Asian market. It aims to foster agri-food innovation and technology solutions, providing a clearer strategy and synergies across units, and offering end-to-end support to the industry.

site_title: Migrants found alive in refrigerated truck on Dutch-UK ferry
summary: A cargo ferry from the Netherlands to Britain discovered 25 migrants alive in a refrigerated container on Tuesday. The ship returned to the Dutch port of Vlaardingen after the stowaways were found, with two taken to hospital for possible hypothermia. The discovery comes a month after 39 Vietnamese people were found dead in a refrigerated truck in Britain, highlighting the risks of illegal migrant routes to Europe. The driver of the truck that brought the migrants to the ferry has been arrested.

site_title: China sets up 147.2b yuan fund to upgrade manufacturing: Shanghai Sec News
summary: China has established a 147.2 billion yuan national investment fund to upgrade its manufacturing industry, investing in growth-stage and mature companies in areas like new materials, IT, and power equipment. The fund, backed by 20 stockholders, including the Ministry of Finance, will support the entire manufacturing industry value chain. This is China's latest effort to promote advanced manufacturing and integrated circuit sectors, following previous national funds set up in these areas. The fund's investment will help China's manufacturing industry transformation and upgrading.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks retreat at Wednesday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks retreated on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng index falling 0.58% to 26,936.79, following two days of gains. Investors remained cautious due to the lack of progress in China-US trade talks. The Shanghai Composite Index also declined 0.20%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.74%. The retreat came after a five-day rally in Singapore stocks and amid ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust raises S$150m in upsized private placement
summary: Ascendas India Trust raised S$150 million in a private placement, 4.1 times subscribed, with an issue price of S$1.508 per unit. The funds will be used to partially finance a business park project in Bangalore and repay existing indebtedness. The company's gearing is expected to fall to 31.3% from 33.3%. The new units are expected to be listed on the Singapore Exchange on November 28.

site_title: Climate impacts 'to cost world US$7.9t' by 2050
summary: Climate change is projected to cost the world economy $7.9 trillion by 2050, shaving off 3% of global GDP. Africa is the most at-risk, with 4.7% of its GDP in the balance. Developing nations are more vulnerable to climate impacts, with countries like Angola, Nigeria, Egypt, Bangladesh, and Venezuela facing significant losses. The US is forecast to be one of the least impacted, but its climate policies pose a temporary setback. A coordinated global effort is needed to address the impacts of climate change, with experts emphasizing the need for immediate action.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree NAC Trust, Ascendas India Trust, Aspial, Willas-Array, GS
summary: Several Singapore companies reported developments affecting their shares on November 20, 2019. Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) announced its Festival Walk shopping mall in Hong Kong remains closed due to unrest. Ascendas India Trust raised S$150 million in a private placement. Aspial Corporation's Australia 108 project is expected to realize A$400 million over the next 12 months. Willas-Array Electronics reported a widened second-quarter net loss. GS Holdings sold its loss-making subsidiary for S$2 million. Karin Technology Holdings sold its Shanghai property for S$620,000. Malaysia Smelting Corporation's Rahman Hydraulic Tin received approval for new mining leases.

site_title: Trump says media 'sick' over health rumours
summary: US President Donald Trump accused the media of scaring his wife Melania with reports of his poor health following a surprise hospital visit on Saturday. Trump, 73, underwent part of his annual medical exam at a government hospital outside Washington, but the White House explanation failed to quell speculation about his health. Trump called the media "sick" for fueling concerns, which have persisted despite the explanation.

site_title: Bigger BTO flats in 2 estates see keen interest
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) recently concluded a sales exercise for 4,571 new Build-to-Order (BTO) flats, with the mature estates of Ang Mo Kio and Tampines seeing high demand for bigger units. Ang Mo Kio's four-room flats were 13 times oversubscribed, while Tampines' five-room flats were 11 times oversubscribed. The increased demand is attributed to the revised policy changes, including a higher income ceiling and enhanced CPF housing grants, allowing more people to buy bigger units.

site_title: Digital battleground looms large for 2020 US elections
summary: US President Donald Trump is facing a massive digital counterattack ahead of his 2020 re-election campaign, with opponents spending multimillion-dollar efforts to prevent him from dominating the web. Trump has spent over $30 million on Facebook and Google ads since 2018, prompting calls for better policing of political misinformation. His opponents are rushing in with countermeasures, while platforms like Twitter have banned campaign ads. The digital battleground is set to intensify as the 2020 elections approach.

site_title: Enhancing consumer and investor protection in Initial Coin Offerings
summary: The emergence of Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs) has created a new way for financing economic activity, but it also requires regulations to protect consumers and investors. In a typical ICO, companies issue cryptocurrencies in exchange for other cryptocurrencies, with funds received used to finance businesses. The lack of regulations in the ICO market poses significant risks for investors, making it essential to enhance consumer and investor protection.

site_title: In testy leadership debate, UK PM Johnson promises quick Brexit
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has doubled down on his Brexit promises, saying only he can take Britain out of the European Union quickly. In a testy leadership debate with Labour's Jeremy Corbyn, Johnson pledged to implement the exit deal he negotiated with Brussels and lead Britain out of the EU by January 31. Corbyn vowed to hold a new referendum in six months if Labour wins the December election. Polls show the public is split over who won the debate, with 51% backing Johnson and 49% Corbyn.

site_title: Japan exports post worst fall in 3 years as shipments to US, China slide
summary: Japan's exports plummeted 9.2% year-on-year in October, the largest decline in three years, driven by weakening demand from the US and China. Shipments of cars, aircraft engines, and plastic materials declined, marking the longest run of declines in exports since 2015-2016. The economy's growth slowed to its worst in a year in the third quarter, and lawmakers have called for a stimulus package to support the economy. Japan's imports sank 14.8% year-on-year, resulting in a surplus of 17.3 billion yen.

site_title: US banks BB&T and SunTrust get final approval of merger
summary: BB&T and SunTrust have received final approval from the Federal Reserve and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to merge, creating Truist Financial Corporation, the sixth-largest US commercial bank. The combined entity will have assets of over $450 billion and deposits of over $330 billion. The merger, completed on December 6, aims to save $1.6 billion in administrative costs and compete against major banks like Bank of America and Wells Fargo. As a condition, BB&T must divest 30 bank branches with over $2.4 billion in deposits to mitigate competitive effects.

site_title: UK PM Johnson's Conservatives criticised for 'factcheck' Twitter handle switch
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Conservative Party faced criticism for changing the name of one of its Twitter accounts to "factcheckUK" during a televised debate, making it appear as an independent fact-checking service.
