The move was deemed misleading by fact-checking charity Full Fact, who accused the Conservatives of trying to discredit Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn. The account reverted to its regular branding after the debate. The Labour Party labeled it a "scam" and accused the Conservatives of lacking trustworthiness in government.

site_title: Karin Technology sells Shanghai property for 3.2m yuan
summary: Karin Technology Holdings sold its Shanghai property to an individual for 3.2 million yuan, generating a fair value gain of 320,000 yuan. The sale will improve the company's cash flow position and is intended to be used for working capital. The property, valued at 2.9 million yuan, was previously valued by BMI Appraisals on June 30, 2019. The sale is expected to be completed by January 16, 2020.

site_title: Europe: Shares take a breather, ease off four-year peak
summary: European stocks closed lower after a morning surge, reversing a four-year peak. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.5% before paring gains, tracking Wall Street's retreat. Trade talks between Washington and Beijing remained unclear, despite a new 90-day extension for US companies to do business with Huawei. Defensive sectors like utilities and telecoms declined, while travel & leisure and automakers rebounded. Analysts caution against overextending gains, citing past corrections when the index reached record highs.

site_title: Pentagon says Iran's missiles unrivaled in Middle East
summary: The Pentagon has stated that Iran has developed a larger and more sophisticated missile arsenal than any other Middle Eastern country, including Israel. Despite decades of sanctions, Iran continues to grow its missile force, which it considers a strategic necessity due to its limited air force. The country has developed missiles capable of striking at a distance of 2,000km, including the 1,250km-range Khoramshahr missile. The US intelligence community warns that if an arms embargo is lifted on Iran next year, it will acquire advanced capabilities beyond its reach for decades.

site_title: Two GoBear co-founders resign; Indonesia comparison business to close
summary: Two co-founders of fintech startup GoBear, Ivonne Bojoh and Marnix Zwart, have resigned and will leave by the end of the year. The company is closing its Indonesia financial comparison business, with about 10 employees set to be laid off. GoBear's sole remaining co-founder, Frank Stevenaar, will remain in charge. The company cited a shift to a content model to drive critical financial education in the Indonesian and Malaysian markets. GoBear reported a net loss of S$22.1 million in 2018, despite S$6.2 million in revenue.

site_title: US officials tell impeachment probe of concerns over Trump Ukraine call
summary: US lawmakers heard from two witnesses to the Ukraine call, Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman and Jennifer Williams, who expressed concerns over President Trump's demands for investigations into Joe Biden. Vindman reported the call to lawyers, saying it was "inappropriate," while Williams described the reference to Biden as "unusual" and delving into domestic US politics. The witnesses' testimony amplifies the investigation into whether Trump abused his power, with nearly $400 million in military aid and a White House meeting at stake.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare's COO Louis Tan Tiong Chin, 37, resigned to pursue other opportunities, effective Feb 4, 2020. ST Engineering divested its Australian pilot training business for S$9.3 million. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription.

site_title: Lagarde perfectly capable of facing down her ECB sceptics
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde has taken the helm at a time of rising skepticism over monetary policy's effectiveness in achieving inflation targets. Critics argue that the ECB has limited tools to stimulate growth, but experts believe Lagarde can still implement further rate cuts and asset purchases to address economic concerns. The ECB has already cut interest rates and restarted quantitative easing, and Lagarde's efforts to address tensions within the governing council may provide a clean slate for future decisions.

site_title: Trump can no longer impose Section 232 auto tariffs after missing deadline: experts
summary: US President Donald Trump's Section 232 tariffs on foreign-made cars and auto parts, imposed to make America's trade relationships more fair, have expired due to his failure to announce a decision by a self-imposed deadline. Experts say the administration must now find alternative means to tax European or Japanese car imports, as the Trade Expansion Act of 1962 allows for tariffs only if the Department of Commerce deems them a national security threat. Trump's pledge to impose tariffs remains unfulfilled, leaving the US with no clear path to tax European or Japanese car imports.

site_title: Mapletree NAC Trust says damaged Hong Kong mall still closed
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) said its Festival Walk shopping mall in Hong Kong remains closed due to extensive damage from recent unrest, with recovery works ongoing. Insurers have been notified, and claims assessment is underway. The mall, which generates 62% of MNACT's net property income, has been closed since November 12. Metal hoardings have been erected for safety and security precautions. The closure has led to a 0.86% drop in MNACT units.

images.alt_text: Protesters had smashed glass panels at Festival Walk and set fire to the mall's Christmas tree last week amid violent clashes in the city.

site_title: Uber safety culture lacking in autonomous car incident: regulator
summary: A US regulatory official stated that an investigation into a 2018 fatal Uber self-driving car crash in Arizona revealed an ineffective safety culture at the company. The National Transportation Safety Board found that the vehicle's automated driving system and human operator were both at fault, with the system misclassifying a pedestrian as a bicycle or 'other'. Uber temporarily suspended its autonomous program and resumed operations in Pittsburgh with a driver at the wheel. The incident highlighted a deeper problem with Uber's safety culture, according to chairman Robert Sumwalt.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Do we need in-car cameras?
summary: The Money FM podcast "Chasing Cars: Do we need in-car cameras?" discussed the need for in-car cameras and their potential benefits in various situations. Julian Kho from sgcarmart and Claressa Monteiro explored the pros and cons of in-car cameras, including their ability to deter accidents and provide evidence in the event of an incident. The podcast concluded that while in-car cameras can be a useful safety feature, they are not a foolproof solution and should be used in conjunction with other safety measures.

site_title: MSC's tin mining arm granted new leases in Perak until 2034
summary: Malaysia Smelting Corporation's (MSC) tin mining arm, Rahman Hydraulic Tin (RHT), has received approval for new mining leases in Perak, Malaysia, until 2034. The leases cover over 700 hectares of land for the RHT tin mine, the largest hard-rock open pit tin mine in Malaysia.

site_title: Dividends are in favour, but there are still bets in Singapore growth stocks
summary: Analysts in Singapore are focusing on dividend stocks due to market volatility and weak business conditions, but some growth stocks are still considered attractive. Analysts recommend companies like AEM, Penguin, mm2, and Fu Yu, which offer both growth potential and steady dividends. Despite the challenges, growth stocks are expected to outperform the average market, driven by robust earnings growth or topline expansion, particularly in sectors like consumer goods and real estate.

site_title: Education is a journey, not a destination - and definitely not about passing an exam
summary: China's education system is under scrutiny, with experts calling for a shift from a results-based model to one that focuses on individual growth and development. The gaokao exam, which determines a student's college prospects, is seen as overly harsh and narrow. Tara Westover's memoir Educated, which tells the story of a woman who rose from a fundamentalist Mormon upbringing to earn a PhD from Cambridge, highlights the importance of education as a journey, not a destination. Reform efforts are needed to address issues of mental health, student debt, and the emphasis on traditional subjects over vocational training, with some suggesting a more holistic approach to education that prioritizes personal growth and practical skills.

site_title: Sustainability's challenge: Fix the hole in the reporting layer
summary: Businesses must adopt a comparable and robust sustainability reporting framework to effectively address environmental and social impact. However, the current lack of uniformity and quality of disclosure creates an issue, making it difficult for investors and consumers to assess the full cost of a product or service. The absence of a gold standard reporting framework has led to "greenwashing" and skepticism about the usefulness of sustainability reports, hindering the ability to make informed decisions. A stronger system of checks and balances is needed to ensure the integrity of sustainability reporting.

site_title: US: Dow retreats from record as Home Depot shares slump
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average retreated 0.4% to end at 27,933.98, snapping a two-day record streak, after Home Depot shares plummeted 5% due to a disappointing sales forecast. Despite this, comparable sales increased 3.6% and US home construction data beat expectations. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.2% to notch a third straight record. Other retailers, such as Kohl's and TJX, had mixed results, while Boeing shed 0.6% following safety recommendations.

images.alt_text: The Dow's two-day streak of records ended on Tuesday following a big drop in Home Depot shares over a disappointing sales forecast.

site_title: Oil slumps on oversupply fears, trade talk concerns
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures dropping 2.5% to $60.91 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling 3.2% to $55.21 a barrel. Concerns about excess global supply and limited progress in resolving the US-China trade dispute weighed on prices, despite a pact by Opec+ to cut oil output by 1.2 million barrels per day. Russia is unlikely to deepen cuts, and investors worry about potential oversupply, while a Chinese government source expressed gloom over prospects for a trade deal.

site_title: Elizabeth Warren calls out Blackstone for 'shameless' profits from housing
summary: US presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren criticized Blackstone Group Inc for profiting from the 2008 housing crisis, accusing the company of "shamelessly" buying foreclosed apartments and single-family homes. Warren's proposal to strengthen tenants' rights targets companies like Blackstone, Colony Capital, and Cerberus Capital Management, which she claims profited from the destruction of home ownership for millions of American families.

site_title: Singapore calls for more global partners, including Chinese firms, in push for AI
summary: Singapore calls for global partners, including Chinese firms, to collaborate on artificial intelligence (AI) despite the US's trade restrictions on Chinese AI companies. Minister-in-charge Vivian Balakrishnan emphasized the importance of openness and ethical standards in AI development. Singapore aims to become a hub for AI testing and implementation, with a focus on social and political acceptability. The country has allocated S$900 million for AI research and development and has already established partnerships with Chinese tech giants such as Alibaba and Huawei.

site_title: Private equity muscling into Britain's booming retirement market
summary: Private equity firms are expanding into Britain's growing pension-transfer market, taking over costly pension funds from struggling companies. Insurers, which dominate the market, are expected to handle over £30 billion in transfer deals this year. Private equity firms, backed by US giant TPG and family office Truell, are backing superfunds that claim to offer lower costs and better returns. The UK government supports the emergence of superfunds, but warns of risks to retirees and proposes measures to prevent companies from undermining insurers.

site_title: Del Monte warns of Q2 loss, may refinance US$1.4b in loans
summary: Del Monte Pacific, a loss-making food and beverage company, is evaluating options to refinance its US$1.4 billion loan facilities for its US subsidiary, Del Monte Foods Inc. The company expects to report another loss for Q2 FY2020 due to one-off expenses, but its core earnings are expected to be positive and higher than last year. Del Monte is finalizing one-off expenses and is making divestments at four production facilities in the US as part of its "asset-light strategy." The company expects cost savings to improve its Ebitda margin by 225-275 basis points over the next 24 months.

site_title: A small crash with big consequences for Ferrari, says boss Binotto
summary: Ferrari boss Mattia Binotto described a collision between Sebastian Vettel and Charles Leclerc at the Brazilian Grand Prix as a "small crash with big consequences." The incident, which put both drivers out of the race, has led to a summons for the drivers to discuss their mistakes and prevent recurrence. Ferrari is concerned about the team's stability going into 2020, when they could be competing for titles. The team may revise terms of engagement to address the issue, similar to how Mercedes handled the rivalry between Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg.

site_title: Tata Steel to axe 3,000 jobs in Europe as crisis spreads
summary: Tata Steel plans to cut 3,000 jobs in Europe due to stagnant EU steel demand and global overcapacity, compounded by trade conflicts. The majority of the job cuts, approximately two-thirds, will be office-based staff. This move comes amid a heated UK general election campaign. The reduction in workforce is aimed at cutting costs and addressing the challenges faced by the European steel industry.

site_title: Shipping groups exchange broadsides at global maritime meeting
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) held a global maritime meeting, where representatives from nearly 70 countries discussed reducing greenhouse gas emissions from ships. The meeting aimed to achieve a 40% reduction in carbon intensity from shipping by 2030. However, environmental groups criticized the lack of progress and low ambition shown by the IMO. The European Commission plans to include shipping in its emissions trading system, which the shipping industry strongly opposes, as it would impose a market-based measure that could be complicated to implement. The IMO is expected to adopt a goal-based approach to achieve short-term emissions reductions.

site_title: US aircraft carrier transits Strait of Hormuz
summary: The US aircraft carrier strike group Abraham Lincoln successfully transited the Strait of Hormuz on November 19, 2019, demonstrating the US commitment to freedom of navigation in the region. The move came amid heightened tensions with Iran, following a series of attacks on foreign tankers in the area. The transit occurred without incident, with safe and professional exchanges between US forces and Iran's coast guard. This marked the first time a US aircraft carrier group had navigated the strait since June, when a US drone was downed by Iran.

site_title: Julius Baer announces first buyback in 8 years
summary: Julius Baer announced its first share buyback in 8 years, totaling 400 million Swiss francs, despite a writedown on its Italian subsidiary Kairos. The move comes as inflows slowed due to client withdrawals from Kairos. The bank reported a mixed performance for the first 10 months of the year.

site_title: Hong Kong university protesters defy surrender warnings
summary: Pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong defied police warnings to surrender on the third day of a stand-off at Hong Kong Polytechnic University, where dozens remained huddled inside despite exhaustion and fears of arrest or police violence. The siege has sparked a new phase of mass disruption, with China sending fresh signals that its patience with the nearly six-month-long unrest is running out. Over 1,000 people have been arrested since the unrest began in June, and the protesters remain determined to fight on, with some fearing jail if they surrender.

images.alt_text: Dozens of exhausted pro-democracy protesters occupying a Hong Kong university defied warnings to surrender on Tuesday on the third day of a stand-off with police, as China sent fresh signals that its patience with nearly six months of unrest was running out.

site_title: Showtime for Stadia cloud gaming service
summary: Google's Stadia cloud gaming service has announced 10 more games to bring its lineup to 22, with subscriptions available in 14 countries. The service, which allows users to access console-quality games on various devices, including TVs, computers, and smartphones, has seen a surge in demand, with Founder's Edition kits selling out. Stadia Pro subscriptions, priced at $10 a month, will offer access to games hosted at Google's data centers, with some free games available. The service aims to revolutionize the video game industry, which is expected to reach $150 billion this year.

site_title: Airbnb incurs Paris wrath over Olympics partnership
summary: Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo has criticized Airbnb's nine-year partnership with the International Olympic Committee, warning that it will worsen the shortage of apartments on the rental market and drive up rents. The deal, announced in London, aims to provide Olympic accommodations and promote "Olympian Experiences" for Airbnb guests. Despite Airbnb's claims that the partnership will benefit both visitors and hosts, Hidalgo vows to tighten rules on tourist rentals in the French capital, one of Airbnb's biggest markets.

site_title: Ex-label says Taylor Swift can sing her old hits at awards show
summary: Taylor Swift's former label, The Big Machine Label Group, has agreed to allow her to perform some of her early hits at the American Music Awards on November 24, despite a public feud over the rights to her first six albums. The licensing agreement was announced jointly with Dick Clark Productions, but the production company later distanced itself from the statement. Swift had previously claimed that her ex-label was preventing her from performing her old songs and using her music for a Netflix project. The agreement does not resolve all issues, but it allows Swift to sing her old hits at the awards show.

site_title: Aspial to realise A$400m cash from Australia 108 project in next 12 months
summary: Aspial Corporation expects to realize A$400 million in cash proceeds from its Australia 108 project over the next 12 months, primarily from the settlement and handover of units to buyers. The company will also disclose "unbilled contracts" signed with buyers. Despite a 69% plunge in Q3 net profit, Aspial remains positive on the project's progress, citing a recovering market and rising dwelling values in Melbourne. The company expects to finance its outstanding bonds through a combination of proceeds from unit sales, external financing, and cash flow.

site_title: Australia's Woodside expects to triple its reserve base with new projects
summary: Australia's Woodside Petroleum plans to triple its reserve base to 3.7 billion barrels over the next seven years with new projects worth over $36 billion in Australia, Senegal, and Myanmar. The company aims to expand production by 6% annually for the next decade. Woodside is nearing a final investment decision on major projects, including the Sangomar oil project and the Scarborough gas project, with the Scarborough project expected to be finalized in early 2020. The company's CEO, Peter Coleman, believes the company has a compelling growth story despite market risks and fluctuating LNG prices.

site_title: Magnus Energy's new board's priority will be to boost sales: activist shareholder
summary: A former managing director of Magnus Energy is seeking to regain control of the board to boost sales and revive the company, which has plummeted in value due to the issuance of convertible notes and subsequent conversion to shares. The activist shareholder, Charles Madhavan, believes the company is worth more if not for years of "abuse" and plans to leverage his network of experts and business partners in the oil and gas sector to turn things around. He aims to focus on Mid-Continent Equipment Inc, the company's 55% stake in an oil and gas equipment distribution business, and explore new projects, including a potential oilfield project and a mini-refinery in Indonesia.

site_title: With storms wrecking grids, Japan seeks home battery networks
summary: Japan's government is encouraging homeowners to invest in home battery networks as recent typhoons have disrupted power to almost 1.4 million customers. With rooftop solar installations set to expire, policy makers see an opportunity to create backup electricity networks. The government plans to spend 7.5 billion yen to promote purchases of devices that can help form virtual power plants. As the country aims to boost clean-energy output to 22-24% by 2030, the focus is on making the power system more resilient to natural disasters and absorbing new renewable sources.

site_title: New floating Eco-Ark produces up to 20 times more fish than coastal farms
summary: A floating Eco-Ark, measuring 48m by 28m, has been anchored off Singapore's coast, producing up to 20 times more fish than traditional coastal farms. The vessel houses 30 tonnes of fish bred for food. This innovative system has shown promising results in sustainable seafood production.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant Financial may join race for Singapore digital bank licences
summary: Jack Ma's Ant Financial Services Group may apply for a virtual banking licence in Singapore, joining traditional incumbents DBS and OCBC in the growing market for digital banking in South-east Asia. The move follows Singapore's efforts to open up the industry to new competitors, similar to Hong Kong where Ant and Chinese competitors obtained licences earlier this year. A successful entry by Ant would pit it against traditional banks in the region, with a potential retail or wholesale licence.

images.alt_text: Mr Ma's Ant Financial is China's largest online financial company. Ant didn't say if it will seek a retail or wholesale licence.

site_title: Pessimism, poor performance persist: BT-SUSS poll of business climate
summary: The Singapore economy remains in a state of pessimism, with businesses showing glum conditions for the sixth consecutive quarter. Despite manufacturing emerging as the best-performing sector, firms' sales, profits, and orders weakened in the third quarter. The Business Times-Singapore University of Social Sciences (BT-SUSS) Business Climate Survey found a net balance of -36% for sales, -40% for profits, and -40% for orders. Experts predict a narrow range of 0.3-1.7% growth for the fourth quarter and 0.3-0.8% for the full year, citing uncertainty from the US-China trade conflict.

site_title: Japan's lower house passes limited US trade deal
summary: Japan's lower house of parliament approved a limited trade deal with the US, clearing the way for tariff cuts on US farm goods and Japanese machine tools. The deal is expected to boost Japan's economy by 0.8% over 10-20 years, with 212.8 billion yen of overall tariffs reduced. However, the elimination of US tariffs on Japanese cars and car parts is unclear, casting doubt on Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's assurances that the deal is "win-win". The US has not confirmed that cars were excluded from the agreement, and President Trump has threatened to impose tariffs under Section 232, sparking uncertainty over the deal's future.

site_title: China slams HK high court ruling; says it has sole authority over city's constitution
summary: China has strongly condemned a Hong Kong high court ruling that overturned a ban on face masks worn by pro-democracy protesters, saying it has sole authority over the city's constitution. Beijing claims only the legislature can rule on the constitution, and the judicial branch has overstepped its bounds. The move is seen as a challenge to Hong Kong's autonomy and has sparked concerns that Beijing may deploy troops to quell the unrest.

site_title: China interfering in election 'every day', says Taiwan president
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen stated that China is interfering in Taiwan's elections "every day" as it seeks to damage the island's democracy. China recently sailed an aircraft carrier group near Taiwan, prompting Taiwan to denounce it as an attempt to intimidate voters. Tsai emphasized Taiwan's sovereignty and independence, saying the island already has a government, democratic system, and diplomatic relations. China claims Taiwan as sacred Chinese territory and has enacted an "anti-secession law" allowing force to be used if needed, but Tsai rejected this assertion, calling Taiwan a sovereign country.

site_title: Fed chief reasserts independence in talks with Trump
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell reaffirmed the central bank's independence during a meeting with President Donald Trump on Monday. The meeting came amid a public attack on the Fed by Trump, who has criticized Powell's monetary policy decisions. Powell stated that the Fed's policy decisions will be based on objective analysis, disregarding politics. The Fed has cut interest rates three times this year, citing concerns over the economy's slowdown, but Powell said the central bank will hold its fire for now, waiting for new economic information.

site_title: All at sea: Qatar signs up floating hotels for World Cup
summary: Qatar has signed an agreement with MSC Cruises to use two of its ships, the MSC Europa and MSC Poesia, as floating hotels for the 2022 World Cup. The ships will accommodate 4,000 fans and offer a "spectacular view" of Doha's West Bay skyline. The agreement aims to provide sustainable solutions for the month-long tournament, which is expected to attract 1.5 million visitors. The ships will be powered by liquefied natural gas and feature amenities such as swimming pools and bars.

site_title: A mini-cycle recovery is coming
summary: A global economic recovery is expected to begin in the first quarter of 2020, driven by simultaneous easing in trade tensions and policy easing. Renewed US-China talks have staved off additional tariff increases, while 20 of 32 central banks have eased monetary policy in 2019. The global weighted average policy rate is expected to reach a seven-year low, and moderate fiscal easing is also underway. This recovery is expected to be led by emerging markets, such as China, and will be the third mini-cycle recovery of the past decade.

site_title: HK protests: Why they have gone global
summary: The Hong Kong protests have gone global, sparking international concerns about China's rising economic might. The protests, which have lasted over 22 weeks, have spread to cities and college campuses worldwide, attracting support from foreign governments, politicians, and international businesses. The US Congress has passed the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act, which would impose sanctions and travel restrictions on those responsible for arbitrary detention and torture. The protests have also led to economic sacrifices for Hong Kong, with tourism and retail sales declining, and the territory entering a recession.

site_title: A potential quantum leap for blockchain applications
summary: Google computer scientists claim a quantum computer has achieved "quantum supremacy," outperforming traditional computers in a calculation. However, IBM scientists refute this claim, saying a classical computer can perform the same calculation in just two days. Quantum computers use qubits, which can be 1 and 0 simultaneously, potentially overcoming a problem holding back blockchain applications. This breakthrough could lead to significant advancements in blockchain technology, but further research is needed to confirm its potential.

images.alt_text: Associate Professor Paul Griffin

site_title: Oil and gas play heats up in October: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported that the top three oil and gas-related stocks with market cap above S$100 million in the current quarter averaged a total return of 105.3% as of November 19, 2019. The stocks were Rex International (+144.9%), PACC Offshore Services (+115%), and Mermaid Maritime (+56.1%). This brings their year-to-date total return to 95.7%.

site_title: Morgan Stanley upgrades Singapore banks to overweight
summary: Morgan Stanley has upgraded Singapore banks to "overweight" due to stronger return on equity, earnings visibility, and relative dividend yield. Analysts expect growth in book value and dividend yields of around 4.5% despite earnings downgrades in 2019. UOB is preferred, while OCBC is least preferred due to potential mergers and acquisitions. The upgrade contrasts with analysts' "underweight" stance on Hong Kong financials, which face a rapidly slowing economy and declining net interest margins.

site_title: US Nov homebuilder sentiment eases for first time in five months
summary: US homebuilder sentiment eased in November for the first time in five months, edging down one point to 70, according to the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index. Sales and traffic of prospective buyers cooled, marking a slight decline from the previous month's level. This is the first decrease in sentiment since May 2019.

site_title: Watch bees surf to safety on waves they create
summary: A team of researchers at the California Institute of Technology discovered that when honeybees fall into bodies of water, they use their wings to generate ripples and glide towards land, allowing them to surf to safety. This behavior is a world-class survival skill, as wet wings would normally prevent flying. By creating and riding their own waves, bees can escape ponds and return to their hives, showcasing their remarkable adaptability and resourcefulness.

site_title: Challenging the old order
summary: Brothers Alex and Arthur Chua of the Goldbell Group successfully digitized their family business, challenging the old order. They implemented data-driven decisions and scoreboards to improve forecasting, despite initial resistance from staff and the "old guard." The company has expanded its services, including floor stocking, equipment financing, and commercial lending, and has invested in technology, such as an on-demand ride-sharing startup, Ministry of Movement. The brothers prioritize industry-agnostic financing and focus on core competencies, avoiding straying too far from their business. They have also strengthened their foundation with the opening of a large integrated multi-storey heavy vehicle aftersales centre and a mobility accelerator programme, Move.SG.

images.alt_text: (L-R) Alex Chua, CEO, Goldbell Financial Services, and Arthur Chua, CEO, Goldbell Group. Initially, the group's staff, a lot of them older than the brothers and who had been with the company for longer, could not understand why things had to change.

In 2019, the company opened its Goldbell Tuas Service Centre with support from Enterprise Singapore. The facility is the largest integrated multi-storey heavy vehicle aftersales centre in Singapore and uses the latest automated technologies. It houses all of Goldbell's capabilities, except for financial services, under one roof.

site_title: Europe's drift towards recession a concern for all
summary: Europe is drifting towards a recession, with the eurozone's gross domestic product growing only 0.2% in the third quarter, and Germany's growth at 0.1%. The European Central Bank (ECB) is struggling to stimulate growth, and its options are limited, with self-imposed limits on bond purchases approaching. The ECB's president, Christine Lagarde, is facing a dilemma, and policymakers are turning to fiscal policies, such as government spending and taxes, to stimulate growth, but these are hindered by countries' debt burdens and reluctance to increase spending.

site_title: Ford introduces the all-electric Mustang
summary: Ford has introduced the all-electric Mustang Mach-E, an SUV with a range of at least 370 km, surpassing the Chevy Bolt and Tesla Model 3. The vehicle features over-the-air software updates and a touch screen, blurring the lines with Tesla. The Mach-E aims to deliver a thrilling driving experience, stunning style, and adaptability to customers' lifestyles. With a $500 reservation deposit, the vehicle's deliveries won't begin until spring 2021, marking a bold shift in Ford's focus towards electric energy amidst the growing demand for SUVs.

site_title: Willas-Array's Q2 loss widens to HK$31.25m
summary: Willas-Array Electronics, a Hong Kong-based electronics distributor, reported a widening second-quarter net loss of HK$31.25 million, down from HK$230,000 a year earlier. Revenue fell 17% to HK$880.2 million, and gross profit more than halved to HK$44.6 million. The company attributed the decline to intense price competition and weak demand amidst US-China trade tensions, with a net loss for the half-year of HK$55.8 million.

site_title: Pence aide listened to Trump-Zelenskiy call
summary: Vice President Mike Pence's aide, Jennifer Williams, testified that she listened to President Donald Trump's July 25 call with Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelenskiy, revealing the call's "more political in nature" than other calls with foreign leaders. Williams stated that Trump pressured Zelenskiy to open investigations into Joe Biden and his son Hunter Biden. Her testimony is part of the Democratic-led inquiry into Trump's potential impeachment. Trump later attacked Williams, calling her an "independent bystander" and criticizing Pence for failing to defend her.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust to raise at least S$100m through private placement
summary: Ascendas India Trust plans to raise at least S$100 million through a private placement of 66.3 million units at an issue price of between S$1.465 and S$1.508 per unit. The funds will be used to invest in a business park in Bangalore, expanding its presence and increasing trading liquidity. The project, valued at 7.5 billion rupees (around S$144 million), is expected to be completed in several phases over 10 years.

site_title: Aramco sees nearly enough early orders to pull off IPO
summary: Saudi Aramco's bankers are confident that investor interest in the company's reduced initial public offering (IPO) is sufficient to proceed, with nearly enough orders to cover the institutional portion of the deal after the first three days of marketing. However, the exact amount of demand remains to be confirmed as underwriters compare the received orders.

site_title: Airlines zoom in on grounded Boeing 737 MAX at Dubai Airshow
summary: Airlines have announced plans to order up to 50 Boeing 737 MAX jets worth $6 billion, despite a global grounding since March. Kazakhstan's Air Astana signed a letter of intent to order 30 MAX 8 jets for its Fly Arystana subsidiary. The airline expressed confidence in Boeing's ability to resolve problems with the MAX. This move comes as airlines look to capitalize on the 737 MAX's return to service, with other carriers also considering orders. The deals are seen as a significant boost for Boeing's sales efforts.

site_title: Deloitte calls for more tax breaks for jobs and R&D
summary: Deloitte has proposed tax breaks for investments in jobs and research and development (R&D) to make Singapore a more attractive place for businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The firm suggests tax credits for SMEs that invest in employee training, increased tax deductions for R&D activities, and relaxed rules for acquiring intellectual property (IP) rights. Deloitte also recommends expanding tax breaks for SMEs, easing foreign talent requirements, and increasing the lifespan of incentives set to expire.

site_title: Queues throng Lebanese banks after one-week closure
summary: Banks in Lebanon reopened after a week-long closure, with queues forming at branches. Police were deployed to maintain order, and banks imposed restrictions on hard currency withdrawals and transfers abroad. Cash withdrawals are limited to $1,000 per week, and transfers are restricted to urgent personal spending only. The central bank assured depositors that their funds are safe and that it can maintain the value of the Lebanese pound, which is pegged to the US dollar.

images.alt_text: At the Fransabank in Beirut (above), queues were building up as banks across the city reopened on Tuesday after a week-long closure.
At the Fransabank in Beirut, queues were building up as banks across the city reopened on Tuesday after a week-long closure (above).

site_title: Oslo fells London's annual Christmas tree in decades-old tradition
summary: Norway's annual Christmas tree tradition, which began in 1947, has been continued in London's Trafalgar Square. A 24-metre, 85-year-old spruce tree was felled and will travel across the North Sea to be lit on December 5. The tree is a symbol of gratitude for Britain's support during World War Two and represents the lasting bond between the two countries. The tradition, attended by British and Norwegian officials, highlights the importance of friendship, dialogue, and commitment between nations, according to the Lord Mayor of Westminster.

site_title: Nintendo unveils Tokyo gamers' wonderland
summary: Nintendo has unveiled its first Japanese store in Tokyo's Shibuya district, marking the company's move towards greater commercialization of its popular characters. The store, located in the Parco department store, offers a range of goods featuring characters like Mario and allows customers to try out the Nintendo game controller. The store's opening follows the success of the Pokémon Center retail chain, also managed by Nintendo. This new location aims to attract more casual fans and build on Nintendo's gamer culture.

site_title: Magnus Energy asks requisitioning shareholders to amend EGM resolutions
summary: Magnus Energy Group has asked shareholders requisitioning an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to amend resolutions to ensure that if a new director is voted in, they must be a Singaporean. The company has invited shareholders to remove the only remaining director, Seet Chor Hoon, and appoint new directors, but with the condition that at least one director must be a Singaporean resident. This change aims to prevent the removal of the current director without a replacement.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens at record high as trade optimism persists
summary: Wall Street opened at a record high on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 43.54 points to 28,079.76, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also reaching new highs. The gains were driven by optimism over the US-China trade war, despite a decline in retail stocks. The US stock market has continued its rally despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed's future actions.

site_title: GS Holdings disposes stake in wholly-owned subsidiary for S$2m
summary: CATALIST-LISTED GS Holdings has sold its 6.5 million shares in wholly-owned subsidiary GreatSolutions to GSG Capital for S$2 million. GreatSolutions, a dishwashing and cleaning services firm, was loss-making for three consecutive years, with a net loss of S$3.5 million in 2018. GS Holdings believes continued investment in the unit is unlikely to yield benefits without significant capital investment.

site_title: Wealth fund at 10t kroner has Norwegians trying to cash out
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, valued at 10 trillion kroner ($1.5 trillion), has seen an increase in inquiries from Norwegians wondering if they can withdraw their share. Despite the fund belonging to the people, it's not designed for individual withdrawals. The fund, which holds 1.5% of the world's listed equities, aims to benefit future generations and invests outside Norway to avoid overheating the domestic economy. The government also uses some of the fund's wealth to support present-day Norwegians, but individual withdrawals are not possible.

site_title: Negative US-China trade deal headlines hit STI
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 19.79 points or 0.6% to close at 3,238.87 on Tuesday, weighed down by concerns over the US-China trade deal. The Japanese and South Korean benchmarks also declined. In contrast, markets in Australia, China, Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Taiwan gained. The US-China trade deal's lack of progress continues to impact market sentiment, with investors becoming increasingly impatient.

site_title: Sweden drops Assange rape investigation after nearly 10 years
summary: Sweden has dropped its nearly 10-year investigation into WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange for rape allegations after a review of evidence. Deputy Chief Prosecutor Eva-Marie Persson deemed the complainant's evidence credible but deemed it unreliable due to fading witness memories. The decision not to proceed with an indictment was made after a comprehensive assessment of the case.

images.alt_text: A Swedish prosecutor said on Tuesday she would not proceed with an investigation into an allegation of rape against WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange after a review of the evidence.

site_title: Saudi Arabia doubles the amount banks can lend for Aramco IPO
summary: Saudi Arabia's central bank has doubled the leverage limits for retail investors buying shares in oil giant Saudi Aramco, allowing banks to provide a 2:1 ratio of loans to deposits. This move aims to boost local demand for the potential world's largest initial public offering.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge higher in cautious trading
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Tuesday, driven by positive corporate updates and a 90-day extension for US companies to do business with Huawei. However, uncertainty over a US-China trade deal held back investors. London-listed shares led gains, while automakers rebounded after robust passenger car registrations in Europe in October.

site_title: US hails US$110m rice export agreement with South Korea
summary: The US has agreed to export over $110 million worth of rice to South Korea annually, with 132,304 tons of American-produced rice set to be provided. This is the highest volume of US access ever, with Seoul allocating about a third to American growers. The agreement, set to take effect in January, comes after South Korea adopted tariff-rate import quotas for around 400,000 tons of rice from the US, Australia, China, and Thailand. The deal is seen as crucial for the US rice industry, with half of its crop being exported each year.

site_title: US dollar snaps three-day losing streak
summary: The US dollar snapped a three-day losing streak against rivals, rising 0.1% to 97.87 against its peers, driven by gains against the Swiss franc and Japanese yen. The dollar's recovery was attributed to a decrease in bearish bets by hedge funds and a decrease in trade war tensions, despite China's pessimism about a "phase one" trade deal. Despite the gains, the US dollar remained within well-worn trading ranges, and currency market volatility remained low.

site_title: White House official criticises Trump call, decries 'cowardly' attacks
summary: A White House official, Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman, testified in the impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump, calling the president's phone call to Ukraine's leader "improper" and criticizing "cowardly" attacks on witnesses. Vindman, the top Ukraine expert at the National Security Council, stated that it's improper for the president to demand a foreign government investigate a US citizen and political opponent. The inquiry focuses on a July 25 phone call in which Trump asked Ukraine to carry out investigations that would benefit him politically.

site_title: India faces 2022 deadline for attaining economic goals
summary: India's government faces a 2022 deadline to achieve its ambitious economic goals, outlined in the "Strategy for New India @ 75." The strategy aims to double the manufacturing sector's growth rate to 9-10% by 2022-23 and create 8% economic growth during 2018-23. However, the country's current economic growth is slowing down, with a six-year low of 5% in the June quarter and a contraction in industrial growth in September. The government has taken initiatives to promote manufacturing and entrepreneurship, but results have been disappointing. The strategy also aims to convert farmers into "agripreneurs" and double their income by 2022-23, but corporate investment in agricultural infrastructure remains insufficient.

site_title: Sri Lankan shares hit over 1-year high, rupee up as Rajapaksa assumes office
summary: Sri Lankan shares reached a one-year high, closing at 6,142.76, while the rupee rose to a three-month peak at 179.25/50 per dollar, as former defense chief Gotabaya Rajapaksa took office as president. The benchmark index rose 0.22% and is up 1.49% for the year. Foreign investors bought government securities, and the election outcome reduced political uncertainty, which is expected to boost economic growth.

site_title: Donors pledge US$2.6b for 'last mile' of polio eradication
summary: Donors pledged $2.6 billion to support the global polio eradication plan, aiming to immunize 450 million children annually. This funding, including a $1.08 billion donation from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, will help achieve a polio-free world. The World Health Organisation (WHO) has made significant progress, cutting global polio cases by 99% since 1988, but type 1 polio virus remains endemic in Pakistan and Afghanistan. The funding will support the 2019-2023 "endgame strategy" to fully eradicate polio, with $3.27 billion needed to implement the plan.

site_title: Magnus Energy asks requisitioning shareholders to amend EGM resolutions
summary: Magnus Energy Group's board of directors has agreed to requisitioning shareholders' requests for an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove and appoint directors. The shareholders, who previously sought to remove director Seet Chor Hoon, have been asked to amend their resolutions to ensure the appointment of a Singapore resident director as a replacement. The company has also requested that the shareholders drop a resolution to remove directors appointed after the requisition notice. The EGM is expected to be held soon, following a recent annual general meeting where all resolutions were rejected and the chairman and two directors ousted.

site_title: Air Astana says plans to buy 30 Boeing 737 MAX
summary: Kazakh flag carrier Air Astana plans to buy 30 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft, with the order to be finalized in coming months. The planes will serve as the backbone of Air Astana's new low-cost carrier FlyArystan. This is the first firm order for the 737 MAX since it was grounded in March following two crashes that killed 346 people. The deal is seen as a boost to Boeing, which has been struggling with the crisis, and follows a previous letter of intent from British Airways parent IAG to buy 200 of the planes.

site_title: Desperate Hong Kong protesters explore sewers in campus escape bid
summary: Protesters in Hong Kong, besieged by police at Hong Kong Polytechnic University, are exploring desperate escape plans, including crawling through sewers. The protesters have removed metal manholes and made forays into the tunnels, following rumors of successful exfiltrations. Some have been arrested, while others have escaped, with police warning of lethal force if they come under attack. The protesters, who have been occupying the campus for days, are facing dwindling supplies and dwindling hope, with one protester saying "the people outside can't help us."

site_title: US housing starts increase along with permits in October
summary: US new-home construction rose 3.8% in October to a 1.31 million annualized rate, the strongest pace since the start of the year. Permits, a proxy for future construction, also increased 5% to a 1.46 million pace, the highest since May 2007. Single-family home starts rose 2% to 936,000, while multifamily starts increased 8.6%. This data indicates the housing market is improving, driven by lower mortgage rates and optimism among developers. Existing home sales are forecast to increase in October, and new-home sales remain near a 12-year high.

site_title: Top 3 oil and gas related stocks returned 105% so far this quarter: SGX
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported that the top 3 oil and gas-related stocks with a market cap above S$100 million returned 105.3% in the current quarter, with Rex International (+144.9%), PACC Offshore Services (+115%), and Mermaid Maritime (+56.1%) leading the gain. This brings their year-to-date total return to 95.7%. The energy/oil & gas sector generated a 7.6% return in October, following a 0.3% gain in September and a -8.9% loss in August, as WTI crude prices rose over 10% since early October amid US-China trade negotiations.

site_title: Strike-hit South African Airways says state will not come to the rescue
summary: South African Airways (SAA) has resumed some regional flights but warned that only a deal with striking unions can keep it in the air. The airline, which has cancelled hundreds of flights since the strike began, said a government bailout is unlikely. Acting chairwoman Thandeka Mgoduso stated that the public enterprises minister, Pravin Gordhan, reiterated that there is no money in the public coffers for the airline. SAA's cash-strapped situation has cost 50 million rand (S$4.6 million) per day, with the figure decreasing as some flights resume.

site_title: Asia Pacific clocks record-breaking year-to-date real estate transaction volume of US$128 billion
summary: Asia Pacific's commercial real estate transaction volumes reached a record high of US$128 billion year-to-date, driven by a 18% year-on-year increase in Q3 volumes to US$42 billion. Singapore's office market saw a 175% surge in investment due to strong rental growth and net absorption. This marks the best Q3 performance on record, with a 10% increase in volume compared to 2018. The region's economic growth is expected to continue, despite recent tariff threats and rate cuts aimed at shielding the economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 0.95 points to 1,605.31. Volume was 2.7 billion lots worth RM1.6 billion, with losers slightly outnumbering gainers 411 to 408.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant Financial may join race for Singapore digital bank licences
summary: Billionaire Jack Ma's Ant Financial Services may apply for a virtual banking licence in Singapore, adding a heavyweight contender to the digital banking market in South-east Asia. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is offering up to five digital banking permits, and Ant Financial is "actively looking into" this opportunity. A successful entry would pit Ant Financial against traditional incumbents DBS Group Holdings and Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp. Singapore's move follows a similar one in Hong Kong, where Ant and Chinese competitors obtained licences earlier this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with another strong rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks experienced a strong rally, with the Hang Seng index climbing 1.55% to 27,093.80. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.85% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 1.83%. Investors remain optimistic about a China-US trade deal, contributing to the market's confidence. The protests in Hong Kong, which had a significant impact on the city last week, appear to be subsiding.

site_title: Student protesters hold out as Hong Kong leader urges peaceful resolution
summary: Hong Kong's leader, Carrie Lam, urged a peaceful resolution to the ongoing standoff between police and protesters at Hong Kong Polytechnic University, where about 100 defiant protesters remained after over two days of clashes. The university has been surrounded by police since the clashes began, resulting in over 200 injuries. China's legislature questioned the legality of a Hong Kong court ruling that banned face masks worn by protesters, further escalating tensions. Lam said her government was on the "reactive side" in dealing with the protests, but did not rule out more violence.

site_title: EasyJet cuts growth plan as European economies weigh on fares
summary: EasyJet has revised its growth plan for fiscal 2020, trimming expansion to the lower end of its 3-8% capacity increase range due to uncertain European economic growth and lower fares. The airline cited "reassuring" forward bookings for the first half of the year, which are slightly ahead of last year. This adjustment aims to bolster fares and cope with potential demand fluctuations.

site_title: Airbnb lobbies local Japan governments to ease curbs for Olympics
summary: Airbnb is lobbying Japanese local governments to ease curbs on short-term home rentals during the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. The company seeks exemptions from rules that require hosts to register with local governments and impose restrictions on rentals. Following Japan's introduction of these rules last year, the short-term home rental market plummeted. Airbnb Japan's country manager, Yasuyuki Tanabe, plans to collaborate with local governments to create exemptions for the Olympics, aiming to revive the market.

site_title: Mario shopping kart: Nintendo unveils Tokyo store to lure casual gamers
summary: Nintendo Co Ltd unveiled its first Japanese store in Tokyo's Shibuya shopping district, marking a step towards commercialization of its popular characters. The Nintendo Tokyo store offers a range of goods featuring Mario, Link, and Kirby, and will be evaluated before potential further openings. The company aims to attract casual fans and build on the success of the Pokémon Center retail chain. This move follows the success of the Pokémon Center in New York and the upcoming Super Nintendo World attraction at Universal Studios Japan.

images.alt_text: Nintendo Co Ltd unveiled its first Japanese store on Tuesday in Tokyo's trendy Shibuya shopping district, in a step towards greater commercialisation of its cast of popular characters.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower with eyes on US-China trade row
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Tuesday due to concerns over the US-China trade row. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.53% and the Topix index declined 0.23%. Investors remain cautious, with a pessimistic mood in Beijing regarding trade talks. However, news of the US granting 90 days to cease business with Huawei improved market sentiment. Major exporters, including Toyota and Honda, were lower, while chip-making equipment manufacturer Tokyo Electron dropped 1.25%.

site_title: Google CEO opens new Japan campus in Tokyo's trendy Shibuya district
summary: Google CEO Sundar Pichai inaugurated the company's new Japanese head office in Tokyo's Shibuya district, relocating from its current location. The new campus, in the 35-floor Shibuya Stream skyscraper, also houses Google's seventh Google for Startups Campus in the world, focusing on AI and machine learning. The campus aims to support established startups in Japan, with an accelerator program expected to double Google's employee headcount in the country to over 2,000.

images.alt_text: Google Chief Executive Officer Sundar Pichai was in Tokyo Tuesday to inaugurate the relocation of the company's Japanese head office to an expansive new complex in the trendy district of Shibuya.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks down on report of China pessimism over trade deal
summary: South Korea's stock market dropped 0.34% on Tuesday due to concerns over US-China trade tensions. A report cited Chinese officials as being troubled by US President Donald Trump's reluctance to roll back tariffs. This, combined with Hong Kong protests, led to foreign investors selling $10.80 million worth of shares. The KOSPI has risen 5.50% this year, but the current decline may be a sign of investor anxiety over ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.6% after negative US-China trade deal headlines
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% to close at 3,238.87, reversing Monday's gains, amid concerns over a US-China trade deal. The negative impact was more pronounced in Singapore compared to other Asia-Pacific markets, which saw gains. The decline was attributed to worries over the prospects of a US-China trade deal and markets' patience wearing thin. The STI's blue-chip index saw 217 decliners beat advancers 183, with Golden Agri-Resources and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding experiencing significant declines.

site_title: Aroundtown agrees to buy TLG Immobilien in 3.1b euro deal
summary: Aroundtown SA agreed to buy TLG Immobilien AG for 3.1 billion euros, creating Germany's biggest commercial landlord. The deal values TLG shares at 27.66 euros each, surpassing Monday's closing price. The combined company will have over 25 billion euros of assets and be based in Berlin. The merger is expected to improve share liquidity and potentially include the company in the DAX index, preventing rivals from scaling up through similar mergers. The deal was accepted by TLG's largest shareholder, Ouram Holding SA.

images.alt_text: The deal values TLG shares at 27.66 euros each, 3.2 per cent more than Monday's closing price, Luxembourg-based Aroundtown said in a statement.

site_title: Showtime for Stadia cloud gaming service
summary: Google launches Stadia cloud gaming service, allowing users to access console-quality games without the need for consoles. The service, launched on November 19, 2019, boasts 22 games and promises more by the end of the year. Stadia uses Google's cloud computing technology to offer rich features, aiming to capture a piece of the global video game industry valued at over $150 billion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Jack Ma's Ant Financial may apply for a virtual banking licence in Singapore, adding a heavyweight contender to the race. The energy/oil and gas sector on SGX generated a 7.6% return in October, reversing August's -8.9% return. Aspial expects to realise A$400m from Australia 108 settlement in the next 12 months. Singapore rose three notches to 10th spot in the IMD World Talent Ranking, while the STI fell 0.6% after negative US-China trade deal headlines.

images.alt_text: Jack Ma's Ant Financial Services said it may apply for a virtual banking licence in Singapore, a move that would add a heavyweight contender to the race.

site_title: Ham, Thanksgiving's second fiddle, will cost you this year
summary: African swine fever has caused a surge in ham prices, reaching levels not seen since 2014. The disease, which has affected hog herds in Asia, has created a supply gap in China, where pork is a staple. As a result, Americans may have to pay more for Thanksgiving hams, and global demand for hams is increasing due to upcoming celebrations like Las Posadas and Lunar New Year. This has led to a shortage, boosting American exports and potentially increasing prices for consumers.

site_title: HSBC says British pound may soar. Or crash
summary: HSBC predicts a binary choice for the British pound's future, with a UK-EU deal on Brexit potentially sending it to $1.45 by end of 2020, and a no-deal Brexit possibly dropping it to $1.10. Any resolution, including another referendum or a Brexit deal, could lead to economic growth and interest rate increases. A hung parliament would be the worst scenario, with recession fears and uncertainty. Polls suggest a Conservative majority, but the voting scenarios remain complex and unpredictable.

site_title: One dead, 11 missing in South Korean fishing boat blaze
summary: A South Korean fishing boat caught fire off the southern coast, resulting in one death and 11 missing. The vessel, carrying 12 crew members, including six South Koreans and six Vietnamese nationals, was west of Jeju island. Only one body, a badly burned South Korean, has been recovered. Authorities are investigating the cause of the fire and searching for the missing using helicopters, a patrol plane, and coast guard vessels.

site_title: Australia: Shares end modestly higher on RBA's dovish tone; NZ up
summary: Australian shares ended modestly higher, with the S&P/ASX 200 index advancing 0.7% to 6,814.20, driven by a dovish tone from the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA). The RBA kept rates steady but hinted at a potential rate cut in February or December. Mining stocks led gains, with Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals Group rising 1% and 2.7% respectively. Tech stocks fell 1.2%, with WiseTech Global plummeting 8% after a short seller issued a critical report.

site_title: Here to help: how friendships can help your health
summary: Researchers have found that friendships have a significant impact on health, surpassing the effects of romantic partners. A 10-year Australian study showed that older people with a large circle of friends were 22% less likely to die, while a 2006 study of nearly 3,000 nurses found that women without close friends were four times more likely to die from breast cancer. Friendships also make ageing easier, with a study of Swedish men finding that having friendships, not a life partner, reduced the risk of heart attack and fatal coronary heart disease.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says campus protesters must surrender
summary: Hong Kong's chief executive, Carrie Lam, says protesters occupying a city centre university must surrender to achieve a peaceful resolution. She demands protesters stop violence, give up weapons, and follow police instructions. This comes after a three-day standoff.

site_title: 'The Crown': Who is Princess Anne?
summary: Princess Anne, the second child and only daughter of Queen Elizabeth II, is portrayed in the latest season of "The Crown" as a relatable and down-to-earth royal. Born in 1950, she has a passion for horses and competed in the 1976 Olympics. As the president of the British Olympic Association, she continues the royal family's affinity for equestrian sports. At 69, she is 14th in line to the throne, with a lifelong title as Princess Royal, which she was given in 1987.

site_title: Steel giant to axe 3,000 jobs as crisis rips through Europe
summary: Tata Steel Ltd plans to cut 3,000 jobs in Europe, mostly office-based staff, to cut costs amid stagnant demand and global overcapacity. The move comes as the European steel industry faces declining demand, slowing growth, and competition from overseas supplies. The company aims to boost sales of higher-value steels, improve efficiency, and cut procurement costs. The job cuts are part of efforts to target positive cash flow by the end of 2021, with Tata Steel focusing on growing in India.

site_title: TikTok has escape route that Huawei lacks
summary: TikTok may have a more favorable escape route than Huawei due to its potential for a public market listing, valued at around $13.5 billion. Unlike Huawei, which relies heavily on Chinese suppliers and has a larger annual revenue of $105 billion, TikTok's US$9 million per user acquisition price in 2017 makes it more likely to be sold or spun off. This contrasts with Huawei, which faces a long-term "no-win situation" due to US concerns over national security and 5G competition.

site_title: Federal Reserve chief reasserts independence in talks with Trump
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell reasserted the central bank's independence during a meeting with President Donald Trump on Monday, amid Trump's public attacks on monetary policy. Powell stated that the Fed will set interest rates based on economic information, not politics. Trump had tweeted that the Fed's interest rate was too high relative to other countries, but Powell's comments were consistent with previous testimony. The Fed will continue to support maximum employment and stable prices, without regard to politics.

site_title: New Zealand to ramp up monitoring of NAB unit over capital calculation errors
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand, is increasing its monitoring of Bank of New Zealand (BNZ) due to errors in its risk capital calculation process. BNZ has made three capital calculation errors, resulting in misreported risk-weighted assets over several years. As a result, BNZ will increase its operational risk capital model from $350 million to $600 million. The regulator views this as a precautionary measure to address potential compliance issues, which will be removed once remediation is complete.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as investors seek trade-deal clarity; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares were flat on Tuesday as investors waited for clarity on US-China trade deal negotiations. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.4% lower, with no significant market-moving catalysts to drive the market. Market strategist Mathan Somasundaram attributed the flatness to stretched market multiples and a need for certainty to drive further growth.

site_title: Anxious families wait outside besieged Hong Kong campus
summary: Families of Hong Kong protesters wait anxiously outside Polytechnic University as police vow to arrest everyone inside, who have been besieged for three days. Around 100 protesters remain barricaded, demanding the right to elect leaders and an inquiry into alleged police brutality. The government refuses to compromise, with Chief Executive Carrie Lam saying those inside must surrender. The occupation is the most serious and sustained episode yet, with protesters using the "Blossom Everywhere" strategy to disrupt the transport network.

site_title: Bharti Airtel, Vodafone Idea rally on plan to increase mobile tariffs
summary: Shares of Bharti Airtel and Vodafone Idea surged as the wireless carriers announced plans to raise mobile tariffs starting December 1, the first increase since the entry of billionaire Mukesh Ambani into India's telecommunications market. Vodafone Idea rose 21% and Bharti Airtel jumped 5.8% following the announcement. The move comes after the carriers reported losses and debt, with Vodafone Idea facing a net loss of 509 billion rupees and high debt of $14 billion. The regulator is likely to initiate discussions on rationalizing pricing.

site_title: Love Mud Do: McCartney to headline 50th Glastonbury Festival
summary: Paul McCartney will headline Glastonbury Festival's 50th anniversary in 2024, playing the Pyramid Stage on June 27. The 77-year-old last performed at the festival in 2004. This marks a dream come true for co-organiser Emily Eavis, who had previously expressed regret over missing out on booking another Beatle, George Harrison, in the past. Tickets for the 2024 event were sold out in half an hour when they went on sale in October. This marks McCartney's first performance at the festival since 2004.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon down 0.68% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 0.68% to 3,236.61 at 1:05pm on Tuesday, with 827.5 million securities worth S$541 million changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 175 to 150, as local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC fell. Asian markets fluctuated amid China-US trade talks concerns, with Hong Kong extending Monday's rally.

site_title: KKR taps CK Infrastructure, buyout groups as it seeks bids for Goodpack: sources
summary: KKR & Co has tapped buyout groups including CK Infrastructure, Blackstone, and EQT AB to gauge interest in buying Singapore-based Goodpack, an intermediate bulk container maker. The private equity group is seeking bids with a potential valuation of at least $2 billion, making it one of the largest PE-backed sales in Asia. Indicative bids are due in early December, with a high-profile auction attracting multiple parties, according to a banker familiar with the sale process.

site_title: Aspial to realise A$400m from Australia 108 in next 12 months
summary: Aspial Corporation expects to realize A$400 million from its Australia 108 project over the next 12 months, reflecting unbilled contracts. The project, which includes the tallest residential building in the southern hemisphere, has seen a 10% cancellation rate of its 1,103 apartments. Despite a 69% plunge in Q3 net profit, the company remains positive on the pace of settlement and handover for pre-sold units and continued sales of completed units. The project's completion is seen as a boost to the Melbourne housing market, which is expected to stage a full recovery in January.

site_title: Australia's Woodside sees reserve base tripling as new projects progress
summary: Australia's Woodside Petroleum plans to triple its gas and oil reserve base over the next seven years with projects worth over $36 billion in Australia, Senegal, and Myanmar. The company aims to expand production by 6% annually, reaching 3.7 billion barrels, and is seeking to sell stakes in its Scarborough and Pluto projects to fund its spending plans. Spot LNG prices are expected to turn from a glut to undersupply as early as 2024, with Woodside planning to retain a significant stake in its Scarborough project.

images.alt_text: Australia's Woodside Petroleum on Tuesday laid out plans to triple its gas and oil reserve base as it pursues projects worth over US$36 billion in Australia, Senegal and Myanmar.

site_title: Malaysian palm oil to meet new EU food safety levels by 2021 -minister
summary: Malaysia's palm oil industry is set to meet new EU food safety standards by 2021, with the government enforcing regulations to ensure palm oil meets the EU's 2.5 ppm limit for 3-MCPDE contaminants. The EU is considering setting new limits on food contaminants in refined fats and oils, including 3-MCPD esters found in palm oil. Malaysia aims to have 70% of its oil palm areas certified by the Malaysian Sustainable Palm Oil (MSPO) standard by February, with 60% already certified.

images.alt_text: Malaysia, the second-biggest producer and exporter of palm oil after Indonesia, will enforce regulations to ensure that by 2021 its palm oil meets new food safety standards under consideration by the European Union, a minister said on Tuesday.

site_title: Deloitte calls for tax breaks on 'unsuccessful' staff investments for Budget 2020
summary: Deloitte recommends tax breaks for 'unsuccessful' staff investments in Singapore's Budget 2020. The firm suggests tweaking tax policies for intellectual property, research and development, and human capital investments to make the country more attractive to businesses. This, according to Deloitte, is necessary due to globalization and the growth of a digital economy. The proposed changes aim to boost Singapore's competitiveness and encourage investment in key areas.

site_title: Stop! Don't charge your phone this way
summary: A US-based scam targets travelers during the holiday season by using USB chargers at airport charging stations or hotel USB ports to drain their bank accounts. The Los Angeles County District Attorney's Office warns that hackers could be waiting, and a free charge could result in financial loss. Authorities advise travelers to be cautious and not use unfamiliar chargers.

site_title: Cadbury candy maker sees 'no stopping of growth' in demand
summary: Mondelez International, owner of Cadbury and Toblerone brands, expects strong chocolate consumption growth in Indonesia, driven by the country's large population and increasing snacking occasions. Sales of Cadbury chocolate have grown 36% annually in the past three years, and are expected to expand by over 40% this year. Despite Indonesia's reduced cocoa production, Mondelez sees a growing market, with Japan being a key driver. To address price concerns, Mondelez plans to sell more affordable chocolate products.

site_title: New Zealand tightens foreign investment rules
summary: New Zealand has introduced stricter foreign investment rules, giving the government the power to reject overseas investments in sensitive areas if deemed detrimental to the country. The new rules apply to infrastructure, military technology, and media firms, and are not targeted at China, New Zealand's largest trading partner. The reforms aim to protect national security and public order, with officials stating that the powers will be used rarely and only where necessary. This change marks a shift from previous screening based on buyer character and financial capability.

site_title: A tiny Brontë book comes home
summary: The Brontë Society has acquired the second volume of Charlotte Brontë's miniature magazine, "The Young Men's Magazine", for $777,000 after a lengthy saga. The 19-page, 4,000-word manuscript, created by Brontë at 14, will return to the brick parsonage on the moors where it was written. The Brontë Parsonage Museum had raised $111,000 through crowdfunding and secured funding from the National Heritage Memorial Fund to purchase the manuscript, which features hand-lettered ads and stories. The museum already owns four of the six volumes of the series.

site_title: Australian dollar unsettled as RBA Board sounds dovish note
summary: The Australian dollar dropped 0.3% to US$0.6787 after the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) minutes showed a case could be made for cutting rates this month, but the Board decided to wait. This dovish surprise led to a narrowing of odds on future rate cuts, with the odds of a December cut decreasing to around 30% and February increasing to 72%. The RBA is expected to keep the cash rate at 0.75% for now, but may consider other measures such as asset purchases to achieve full employment.

site_title: Australia signs critical minerals research pact with US
summary: Australia's minerals agency, GeoScience Australia, has signed a research pact with the US Geological Survey (USGS) to jointly develop a better understanding of both countries' critical minerals reserves. The agreement, signed without specific funding, aims to map potential critical mineral resources and prioritize developing Big Data to understand supply and demand scenarios. The deal builds on an initial agreement signed a year ago and comes as Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison visits the US. The pact is seen as a move to secure Australia's role as a reliable and secure international supplier of critical minerals, particularly rare earths.

site_title: New York State Attorney General investigating WeWork: sources
summary: The New York State Attorney General's office is investigating WeWork, examining potential self-dealing by founder Adam Neumann, including leasing properties back to the company and borrowing against his own stake. WeWork is facing significant financial struggles, including ballooning losses and a planned layoff of thousands of employees. The company has already agreed to a rescue by SoftBank Group, which will provide $6.5 billion in debt and equity. WeWork's restructuring plans, including job cuts, will be announced later this week.

site_title: Bank of Japan conducting research on digital currency: central bank chief
summary: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank is conducting research on digital currencies but has no plans to issue them. Kuroda emphasized the need for a sufficient framework to ensure governance and risk management if stable coins are issued globally. He also warned that such coins backed by large companies could impact monetary policy and financial system stability.

site_title: Inchcape Singapore's first woman MD to also head Greater China business
summary: Jasminne Wong, 43, has been appointed as the CEO of Inchcape Greater China and Singapore, making her the first woman MD of the company. The appointment is effective January 1, 2020, combining the two Inchcape territories under one leadership. Wong previously ran Inchcape Singapore and joined the company in 2017, despite having no automotive experience, and has led several successful initiatives, including Toyota's Triple Crown award and partnerships with transport providers. The move aims to strengthen Inchcape's presence in the region.

site_title: Snapchat checks for deception in political ads
summary: Snapchat has confirmed it checks political ads for deception and misrepresentation, enforcing its ban on such material. The platform's review process aims to balance allowing engagement with young voters while preventing misinformation. This approach differs from Twitter's decision to ban all paid political ads and Facebook's tolerance of proven lies. Snapchat's policies prohibit deceptive ads, with an in-house team reviewing paid messages to ensure compliance. The platform plans to bar all paid political messages starting November 22.

site_title: Singapore enters top 10 list for global talent competitiveness
summary: Singapore has entered the top 10 list of the world's most competitive places for talent, ranking 10th according to the IMD World Talent Ranking. Switzerland topped the list, followed by Denmark, Sweden, Austria, and Luxembourg. Singapore rose three notches, with high scores for talent readiness and a large percentage of science graduates. However, its appeal dipped due to high cost of living and particle pollution. The US ranks 12th, while Japan is 35th and China is 42nd.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing with trade in focus, Hong Kong extends gains
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Tuesday, with Hong Kong extending its gains after a report said China was concerned about the US-China trade talks. Despite optimism over a potential mini trade deal, regional traders were given a mixed lead from Wall Street, where all three main indexes ended at new records. China's pessimism over a pact due to Donald Trump's reluctance to roll back tariffs remains a concern, with investors keeping pace with the rapid shifts in the negotiations.

site_title: Spotify-backer Northzone raises US$500m for new investments
summary: Northzone, a venture capital firm backed by Spotify, has raised US$500 million for its ninth fund, the largest investment vehicle to date. The fund will focus on early-stage startups across Europe and the US, with an initial check of up to €15 million. Northzone has a history of successful investments, including companies like Spotify, iZettle, and Trustpilot. The firm's strategy remains unchanged, with a focus on tech-driven businesses and generalist investments. This is one of the biggest VC funds raised in Europe this year, following other notable investments from firms like Accel and Atomico.

site_title: China says only it can rule on Hong Kong constitution
summary: China asserts sole authority to rule on Hong Kong's constitution, contradicting a high court decision that found a ban on face masks worn by pro-democracy protesters unconstitutional. The ban was imposed by Beijing's unelected leader, citing colonial-era legislation. Beijing claims the judicial branch overstepped and only the legislature has the right to rule on laws. The move is seen as a further erosion of Hong Kong's autonomy, fueling violent protests. China vows to maintain control and has warned of deploying security forces if the situation becomes uncontrollable.
