summary: India's coal-fired power plants, responsible for 80% of the country's industrial emissions, are at risk of missing the December 2017 deadline to retrofit equipment to curb air pollution. According to industry estimates, 51% of these plants are set to fail to comply, with some having until the end of 2022 to meet the regulations. The Association of Power Producers estimates the cost of compliance to be around $38 billion, citing debt-laden power producers' inability to afford the investment.

images.alt_text: More than half of India's coal-fired power plants ordered to retrofit equipment to curb air pollution are set to miss the deadline, private industry estimates and a Reuters analysis show, as millions in the country wake up to toxic air each day.

site_title: China cuts key liquidity rate for first time since 2015
summary: China's central bank unexpectedly cut a key interbank lending rate to 2.50% from 2.55%, the first easing in over four years, in a move to prop up slowing growth. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) also lowered the borrowing cost on its medium-term lending facility (MLF) loans by the same margin. Analysts see the cut as a signal that policymakers are ready to act to address concerns over inflation, which rose past the government's target in October, and a potential slowdown in growth.

site_title: Thai GDP grows 0.1% q-o-q in Q3; y-o-y below forecast at 2.4%
summary: Thailand's economy grew 0.1% in the third quarter, the slowest rate in a year, according to official data. This met the forecast and marked the weakest quarterly expansion since a contraction in 2018. On an annual basis, GDP rose 2.4%, below the forecast of 2.6%. The government has lowered its 2019 GDP estimate to 2.6%, down from its previous forecast range of 2.7-3.2%.

site_title: RedDoorz eyes growth with 2 new leadership appointments
summary: RedDoorz, a Singapore-based hotel booking and management platform, has announced two new leadership appointments to drive "significant growth" in 2020. Jupe Tsui has been appointed as chief financial officer (CFO), while Liviu Nedef has joined as group senior vice-president of marketing. With over 30 years of experience, Tsui will refine the company's financial growth strategy, while Nedef aims to make RedDoorz the leading affordable hotel brand in South-east Asia. The company has grown five times in size over the past year and plans to continue expanding, with a new regional tech hub in Vietnam and a potential public listing.

site_title: Oil prices flat with markets on hold for progress in US-China trade talks
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Monday, with Brent crude futures down 5 cents to $63.25 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate crude unchanged at $57.72 a barrel. Investors are awaiting updates on US-China trade talks, despite concerns over rising oil supplies. Analysts see a trade deal as more feasible, which is bullish for oil, but a monthly IEA report suggests a supply glut could develop in 2020. China and the US had "constructive talks" on trade, but details are scarce.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as dealers eye trade talks, Hong Kong rallies
summary: Asian markets are mixed on Monday as investors await a potential US-China trade deal. China and the US are close to a mini trade deal, with top officials stating progress has been made. Markets rose, with Shanghai and Tokyo increasing, but Hong Kong climbed despite violent protests. The situation in Hong Kong remains volatile, with demonstrators holed up in a university campus and authorities warning of live rounds. A bill aimed at defending civil rights in Hong Kong may be passed in Washington, further escalating tensions.

images.alt_text: Asian markets were mixed on Monday on broad optimism that China and the United States are close to a mini trade deal, while Hong Kong rallied after last week's hefty losses but investors remain on edge over violent protests that have wracked the city.

site_title: Hong Kong home sales plunge over weekend
summary: Hong Kong home sales plummeted 78% over the weekend due to escalating violent protests, which have disrupted the city and made potential buyers cautious. The protests, including clashes at Hong Kong Polytechnic University, have paralyzed the city and disrupted public transport. The relaxation of mortgage rules last month appears to have had a short-lived impact on property sales. The unpredictable social events have intensified, affecting apartment visits and buyer sentiment, according to Midland Realty International Ltd.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Monday's open; STI down 0.19%
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.19% at the start of the week, with the Straits Times Index at 3,232.78. Non-oil domestic exports fell 12.3% year-on-year in October, marking an eighth straight month of decline. Banking stocks, such as DBS and OCBC Bank, also dropped. Gainers included Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and SIIC Environment, while Raffles Education rose after appointing a new director and approving a property sale.

site_title: Malaysian KFC operator's owner considers selling it
summary: Malaysian fast-food operator QSR Brands (M) Holdings is considering selling its controlling stake to potential buyers, valuing the company at approximately RM6 billion (S$1.96 billion). The decision comes after shelving an initial public offering due to weak markets, with investors seeking non-binding offers by the end of November. The company operates over 1,300 KFC and Pizza Hut restaurants in Southeast Asia, and its major shareholders include private equity firm CVC Capital Partners and state-owned Johor Corp.

site_title: Hot stock: Yangzijiang soars 10% on news of chairman's impending return
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding shares surged 10% on Monday after executive chairman Ren Yuanlin's expected return, amid a confidential probe in Beijing. The chairman, on leave for over three months, is considered "safe and healthy" and won't affect daily operations. The company's third-quarter profit declined 10% to S$136.3 million. Ren Letian, chairman's son and CEO, stated the case is "complicated" but not affecting daily operations.

site_title: Asian airlines slash flights to Hong Kong as unrest escalates
summary: Asian airlines, including PT Garuda Indonesia, SpiceJet, AirAsia Group, PAL Holdings, and Cebu Air, have cut flights to Hong Kong due to escalating anti-government protests and an economic downturn. The cuts come as Hong Kong police fired tear gas at protesters and the city faces its first recession in a decade. The reductions in flights are expected to continue through mid-December, with AirAsia citing lower passenger numbers and PAL Holdings using smaller planes due to safety concerns.

images.alt_text: Several Asian airlines have cut flights to Hong Kong over the coming weeks, according to industry scheduling publication Routes Online, as anti-government protests in the city grow increasingly violent and disrupt daily life.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Monday with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the week higher, following another record-setting close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng index rose 0.47% to 26,451.64, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices fell 0.06% and 0.15%, respectively. Traders remained cautious amid ongoing violent protests in Hong Kong, but the market was boosted by the US stock market's record-breaking close.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB initiates coverage on BRC Asia with 'add', street-high price target of S$1.90
summary: Brokerage CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on BRC Asia with an "add" call, setting a street-high price target of S$1.90. The analysts are bullish on the supplier of prefabricated steel products due to its market leadership, improving balance sheet strength, and the recovery of Singapore's construction sector. They expect stronger procurement power and cost synergies to boost its net margins, and anticipate a re-rating catalyst for the stock. The company has a capacity to generate cash and pay higher dividends in the coming years.

site_title: Thailand GDP growth recovers but outlook is weak on baht, trade
summary: Thailand's GDP growth rebounded 2.4% in the third quarter, below the median estimate of 2.7%. The country's trade-reliant economy remains weak due to slumping exports, a strong currency, and a mixed tourism sector. The central bank cut interest rates to a record low and announced measures to slow the baht's gains, which have risen over 9% in the past year. The US-China trade war and economic uncertainty continue to impact Thailand's economy, with a weak outlook for the full year.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports sink 12.3% in October; worse than expected
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 12.3% in October, the eighth consecutive month of decline, according to Enterprise Singapore. This drop was larger than expected, reversing three consecutive months of easing. Non-oil re-exports also declined 2.3% year-on-year. The decline was driven by a 36% drop in pharmaceutical shipments, 19.2% in petrochemicals, and 47.3% in primary chemicals. Total trade decreased 9.7% and imports dropped 10.3% while exports slipped 9.2%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.45 points to 1,593.30. Volume was 66.63 million lots worth RM19.34 million, with 116 gainers beating 43 losers.

site_title: Double-whammy of Brexit, election hits UK housing market: survey
summary: A survey by Rightmove shows a 14.9% decline in properties put up for sale in the UK, the largest annual fall in over 10 years, due to the combination of Brexit and an election. The average property price rose 0.3% and sales agreed fell 2.9%. Some potential sellers may be waiting for a change in stamp duty tax, which could reduce home acquisition costs. This marks the first time the market has seen a double whammy of Brexit and an election affecting housing.

site_title: SoftBank's Yahoo Japan to merge with Line app operator
summary: SoftBank Corp plans to merge Yahoo Japan with Line Corp, creating a US$30 billion tech giant. The deal will be completed in October 2020 and sees SoftBank Corp and Naver form a 50:50 venture controlling Z Holdings, which will operate Yahoo Japan and Line. Line's shares rose 2.6% after the news, as SoftBank seeks to bulk up against rivals. The merger is the latest example of consolidation in Japan's technology industry, with SoftBank also acquiring online fashion retailer Zozo Inc.

site_title: Ford bets on an electric Mustang to charge its turnaround
summary: Ford unveiled the Mustang Mach E electric sport utility vehicle, a high-profile test for the automaker's restructuring efforts. The Mach E, designed by a new team, represents a visible sign of Ford's overhaul of its product creation process, aiming to slash $20 billion from its five-year product plan. The vehicle's development was accelerated to meet a fall 2020 launch, with a new architecture and futuristic interior. The Mach E combines the Mustang's image with a clean car goal, with Ford Chairman Bill Ford Jr stating it's a "Mustang experience."

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Yanlord, UE, Manulife US Reit, Frasers Prop, SIIC, Tiong Seng
summary: DBS Group became the first bank in Singapore and South-east Asia to adopt the Equator Principles, a globally recognized framework for environmental and social risk management. Yanlord Land's takeover offer for UE ordinary shares has turned unconditional, with Yanlord announcing a mandatory cash offer for WBL Corp shares. Manulife US Reit appointed Robert Wong Teck Ling as its chief financial officer. Frasers Property reported a 25.3% drop in net profit due to lumpiness in development earnings. SIIC Environment signed three upgrading supplementary agreements for wastewater treatment plant projects in China.

site_title: SGX bags excellence award for 2nd consecutive year
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has won the "Exchange of the Year" award for excellence for the second consecutive year, according to Regulation Asia. The award recognized SGX's targeted approach to market regulation and its commitment to moving towards a 'community' approach. The exchange was also praised for its collaboration with industry partners to raise standards and deter market misconduct. SGX's initiatives, including its Surveillance Handbooks and Dashboard, were cited as key factors in the award. The exchange's CEO, Tan Boon Gin, expressed a commitment to continuing to address regulatory issues and counter wrongdoers.

site_title: Nam Cheong to build shipyard, training centre in Labuan
summary: Nam Cheong, a Malaysian offshore support vessel builder, plans to redevelop a 7.3-hectare site in Labuan, Malaysia, into a shipyard and training centre. The company will invest RM60 million and move its fabrication and shipbuilding-related activities from Indonesia and China to Labuan starting January 2020. The new complex will include a warehouse, fabrication workshops, and a training centre, expected to contribute positively to Nam Cheong's financial performance from 2021 onwards. The project aims to support the growth of oil and gas industries in Labuan, Sabah, Sarawak, and Brunei.

site_title: US urging a no vote on Russia-led UN resolution calling for global cybercrime treaty
summary: The US and its Western allies are urging a no vote on a Russian-led UN resolution that would pave the way for a global treaty on cybercrime, warning it's a thinly veiled effort to create global norms supporting state control of the Internet. The resolution, sponsored by Russia, China, and other nations, would permit blocking of websites deemed critical of authorities and monitoring of dissidents. Critics see it as a threat to democracy and free speech, with the US and Western Europe battling Russian efforts to undermine democratic institutions and Chinese cybertheft of intellectual property.

images.alt_text: The United States and its Western allies are urging opposition to a Russian-led resolution at the United Nations that they warn is a thinly veiled effort to create global norms that endorse state control of the Internet.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower with eyes on US-China talks, forex
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on November 18, 2019, due to investor concerns over US-China trade talks and the forex market. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.04% to 23,294.62, while the Topix index lost 0.10% to 1,695.04. Investors were watching the US-China talks, which had previously caused volatility in the forex market.

site_title: Bolivia government says unrest is 'down by half'
summary: Bolivia's interim government reported a decline in violent demonstrations, with the number of trouble spots "down by half," according to Interior Minister Arturo Murillo. At least 23 lives have been lost and scores injured since late October, amid protests against former President Evo Morales and interim leader Jeanine Anez. The government's decree exempting armed forces from criminal responsibility has been criticized by human rights groups, who fear it may lead to violent repression. Protests continue, with coca growers demanding Anez's resignation and fresh elections.

site_title: SIIC Environment to upgrade 3 wastewater treatment plants in China
summary: SIIC Environment has signed three upgrading supplementary agreements for wastewater treatment plant projects in China, expected to contribute positively to the company's performance. The projects, signed by subsidiaries SCNF and Ranhill Fuzhou, will upgrade discharge standards and add reclaimed water treatment processes, with designed capacities ranging from 15,000 to 100,000 tonnes per day. The upgrades are expected to improve environmental standards and enhance the group's performance.

site_title: HP rejects Xerox's US$33.5b offer to buy the company
summary: HP has rejected Xerox's $33.5 billion cash-and-stock offer to buy the company, citing that the proposal undervalues HP and is not in the best interests of shareholders. The board unanimously concluded that the offer significantly undervalues HP and is highly conditional. HP remains open to a potential merger with Xerox and hopes for further engagement. The decision comes after activist investor Carl Icahn pushed for a merger between the two companies.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop weighed by gold stocks; New Zealand down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Monday, weighed down by gold stocks, as investors await details on a US-China trade deal. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 36.3 points to 6,757.80. Financial stocks, including National Australia Bank and Commonwealth Bank, fell 0.7% each. Tech stocks also declined, with Afterpay Touch Group and Link Administration Holdings shedding 3% and 2.5% respectively. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.4%.

site_title: Hong Kong police warn they may use 'live rounds' if they face deadly weapons
summary: Hong Kong police warned they may use live rounds against protesters wielding deadly weapons, a first in a six-month crisis. The warning was made after three protesters were shot, prompting police to reconsider their approach. Police spokesman Louis Lau stated that if protesters continue to use "deadly weapons," police would use "minimum force, including live rounds." This move marks a significant escalation in the conflict.

site_title: DBS to adopt the Equator Principles in sustainability push
summary: DBS has become the first bank in Singapore and South-east Asia to adopt the Equator Principles, a globally recognized framework for assessing and managing environmental and social risk in development projects. The bank aims to disclose information on large-scale developments it is involved in and step up financing of renewable energy projects. This move follows DBS's existing adherence to due diligence processes and its commitment to stop financing new coal-fired power plants by 2021. The bank believes its adoption of the Equator Principles will contribute to a more sustainable future and align with its sustainability agenda.

site_title: Thousands could be impacted by PG&E's upcoming potential power cuts
summary: Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) warns that an upcoming strong offshore wind event could prompt power cuts for approximately 180,000 customers in California's Sierra Foothills, North Valley, and North Bay. The potential cuts are intended to prevent equipment sparking wildfires in hot weather. This is the latest in a string of recent events for PG&E, which has been criticized for widespread and poorly communicated outages. The utility filed for bankruptcy in January, citing potential civil liabilities of over $30 billion from wildfires linked to its equipment.

site_title: Tiong Seng secures S$125m in green facilities from OCBC, DBS
summary: Tiong Seng Holdings secured S$125 million in green facilities from OCBC Bank and DBS Bank. The green loan, worth S$70 million, will be used for environmentally beneficial projects, while the environmental performance-linked facilities, S$55 million, will refinance existing loans and cover general corporate purposes. The facilities will offer interest rate and performance bond commission discounts if agreed performance targets are met or exceeded. Tiong Seng aims to focus on environmental and green objectives with the new funding, following its top win at the Building Construction Authority awards ceremony.

site_title: Spark New Zealand keeps Huawei on list of preferred suppliers
summary: Spark New Zealand has maintained Huawei as one of its preferred suppliers for equipment, despite concerns over national security risks. The telecom provider had initially faced opposition from New Zealand's intelligence agency over its proposal to use Huawei's 5G equipment. However, Spark has announced plans to roll out 5G services, indicating that it will proceed with its original plans despite the controversy.

site_title: Facial recognition makes subtle advance in Britain
summary: Britain's use of facial recognition technology has sparked controversy after a discreet experiment in London's Kings Cross area between 2016 and 2018. The technology, which compares captured faces to databases, has been used to prevent and detect crimes but has raised concerns over privacy and fundamental rights. Data watchdogs have called for a legal framework, while a survey found public support for its use by the police, with over 80% backing its use. Critics argue the technology risks undermining individual rights and urge authorities to slow down its development.

images.alt_text: The experiment was conducted discreetly. Between 2016 and 2018, two surveillance cameras were installed in the Kings Cross area of London to analyse and track passers-by using facial recognition technology.

site_title: Air New Zealand to cancel some summer flights due to Rolls-Royce engine checks
summary: Air New Zealand will cancel around 14,000 summer flights due to ongoing Rolls-Royce engine checks on its Boeing 787-9 aircraft. The issue is with the high-pressure turbine blades, prompting Rolls-Royce to request more frequent maintenance. The national carrier has 10 Trent 1000 engines on its fleet, and schedule changes are now unavoidable. Further changes may also be necessary. The cancellations will affect around 14,000 customers this summer.

site_title: Money FM podcast: MAS CFO shares takeaways from the Singapore Fintech Festival
summary: MAS CFO Sopnendu Mohanty discussed takeaways from the 2019 Singapore Fintech Festival. Emerging trends include the use of AI, blockchain, and cybersecurity. Ethical concerns around AI were also highlighted. For the 2020 edition, Mohanty expects increased focus on digital identity, data governance, and international cooperation. The festival aims to promote innovation and growth in the fintech industry, with the goal of making Singapore a hub for financial technology.

site_title: Hong Kong police seal off university amid fears of crackdown
summary: Hong Kong police sealed off Hong Kong Polytechnic University, trapping hundreds of protesters inside, amid a standoff that raised fears of a bloody showdown. The protesters, many students, clashed with police using petrol bombs, bricks, and homemade catapults, resulting in scores of injuries, including scalding burns from water cannon chemicals. Police warned that they would use live bullets if protesters continued to use lethal weapons. The standoff is the latest in five months of anti-government protests in Hong Kong, which have posed a challenge to Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Reform of West Africa's CFA franc likely to raise host of problems
summary: West African countries considering reforming the CFA franc, a currency pegged to the euro, may raise several problems. Eight countries use the euro-pegged currency, which is tied to French colonial rule, and its reform is politically sensitive. The Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) has agreed to adopt a single currency, the "eco", but some countries plan to withdraw their reserves from the Bank of France, which guarantees payments into euros. Critics argue that the peg limits the economies' ability to implement monetary policies suited to their needs.

site_title: National Australia Bank seeks to raise about A$1.4b through notes offer
summary: National Australia Bank is seeking to raise A$1.4 billion through the issuance of medium-term notes to bolster its capital ahead of a regulatory deadline. The notes, carrying a floating or fixed rate, will mature in November 2031. The bank aims to strengthen its capital position in preparation for the deadline, which is expected to be met in the near future.

site_title: Carving out bigger roles for malls
summary: Landlords are finding innovative ways to revitalize malls and make them more appealing to consumers, who are increasingly turning to e-commerce. Five strategies identified include localizing the experience, featuring unique attractions and innovative concepts, changing the tenant mix, repositioning malls with greater social and community bonding appeal, and adopting new technology. These efforts aim to enhance the real-life shopping experience and social interaction element in malls, boosting foot traffic and mall performance.

site_title: Hong Kong's job market starts weakening as recession deepens
summary: Hong Kong's job market is weakening due to the ongoing recession and months of political protests. Retailers, restaurants, and hotels are cutting wages, hours, or letting staff go, leading to an expected end of the city's record-low unemployment level. Unemployment rates in the consumption and tourism-related sector are expected to rise, with forecasts of 3% and 10% by mid-2020. The labor market is expected to feel growing pain in the coming months, with some experts predicting unemployment will reach 4% and 3.5% in the near term.

site_title: Iran's Khamenei backs fuel price hike, blames 'sabotage' for unrest
summary: Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei backed the recent fuel price hike, blaming "sabotage" and "counter-revolution" for nationwide protests. The price increase, which raised gasoline to 15,000 rials per liter, has led to clashes between security forces and demonstrators in Tehran and dozens of other cities, resulting in at least one death and over 1,000 arrests. Khamenei also called for officials to prevent price hikes in other goods, as the government claims the fuel price increase will raise $2.55 billion annually for subsidies.

site_title: Can Nestle be virtuous and yet profitable?
summary: Nestle, the world's largest food company, is responding to growing pressure to combat climate change by investing in plant-based alternatives and reducing plastic waste. CEO Mark Schneider, who has made environmental commitments, defends the company's efforts, including adding iron to Maggi bouillon cubes to address nutritional deficiencies in Africa. However, critics argue that Nestle promotes obesity in developing markets and depletes aquifers through bottled water production. As the demand for sustainable food solutions grows, Nestle's shift towards plant-based products may be a step towards reducing its environmental impact while maintaining profitability.

site_title: The Peak launches award to recognise the best in tech
summary: The Peak, a high-end lifestyle magazine, is launching the inaugural Peak Tech Laureates awards to recognize the best in tech. The awards, launched in conjunction with The Peak's 35th anniversary, will be judged by a panel of 35 individuals from various organizations and will focus on innovative solutions and impact. Winners will be notified in March 2020 and will receive congratulatory packages starting at S$8,000, with the ceremony taking place in May 2020.

site_title: Yanlord's UE takeover offer turns unconditional
summary: Chinese property developer Yanlord Land Group has turned its takeover offer for United Engineers (UE) unconditional after acquiring an additional 9.4% stake, lifting its share to 51.47% and crossing the 50% threshold. Yanlord's stake now represents the majority of UE's shares, with the offeror's unit becoming an indirect subsidiary of the company. The offer price remains unchanged at S$2.70 per share.

site_title: Hong Kong activist urges Germany to halt Chinese army training
summary: Hong Kong democracy activist Joshua Wong urged Germany to halt Chinese army training, citing the recent troop deployment in the protest-hit city. Wong criticized the German defense ministry for continuing the program despite the violent protests. Amnesty International also backed Wong's plea, calling for an immediate end to military cooperation. The German military plans to provide logistics and senior officer training to 11 Chinese soldiers in 2020. Wong's comments come after a meeting with German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas, prompting Beijing's anger.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong democracy activist Joshua Wong urged Germany on Sunday to stop military training assistance to China after its troops appeared in the protest-hit Asian financial hub, a German daily reported.

site_title: Bloomberg sorry for 'stop and frisk' as he mulls presidential bid
summary: Billionaire Michael Bloomberg has apologized for his past support of the "stop and frisk" policing policy, which disproportionately targeted black and Latino New Yorkers. The former mayor of New York City, who is considering a presidential bid, acknowledged the "erosion of trust" his stance had created among ethnic minorities. Bloomberg's apology comes amid his potential candidacy, with critics labeling it as vote-pandering. Former Massachusetts governor Deval Patrick also entered the presidential race, citing his experience as a bridge builder and commitment to fairness.

images.alt_text: Billionaire Michael Bloomberg on Sunday walked back his longtime support for the controversial "stop and frisk" policing policy that disproportionately targeted black and Latino New Yorkers as he mulled jumping in the race for president.

site_title: Manulife US Reit manager names new chief financial officer
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (Manulife US Reit) has appointed Robert Wong Teck Ling as its new chief financial officer (CFO). Wong, a seasoned finance professional with 23 years of experience, will work with the CEO and management team to formulate strategic plans and apply capital management strategies. He previously held director and senior vice-president positions at various real estate investment management companies, including ARA Trust Management and CBRE Global Investors. The nominating and remuneration committee and board are satisfied with Wong's qualifications and experience for the role.

site_title: Asean M&A appetite stable despite uncertainty
summary: Asean's merger and acquisition (M&A) appetite remains stable despite global uncertainty, with 41% of respondents planning acquisitions in the next 12 months, close to the 10-year historical average. Despite decreased confidence in growth, 61% of South-east Asian respondents do not expect an economic downturn. Top motivations for M&A include access to new markets, acquiring technology, and acquiring talent. However, firms must seize opportunities to restructure and reduce costs due to macroeconomic headwinds, and address talent and skills shortages.

images.alt_text: The merger and acquisition (M&A) appetite in South-east Asia remains stable despite global uncertainty, according to the latest EY Global Capital Confidence Barometer released on Nov 12.

site_title: Nissan alliance in flux a year after Ghosn shock
summary: The Renault-Nissan alliance is rebooting after a year of upheaval following Carlos Ghosn's shock departure as chairman. New board chairman Jean-Dominique Senard is tasked with meeting huge challenges, including profitability and technological innovations. The alliance, which sold 10.76 million vehicles last year, has seen volumes slide back below rivals Toyota and Volkswagen. Renault and Nissan are exploring new initiatives, including governance reform and pooling expertise on electric power, but analysts warn that the process will take time. Senard remains optimistic about the alliance's future, citing a positive meeting of partner boards.

site_title: WeWork is spending US$438m to renovate Lord & Taylor building in NY
summary: WeWork is investing US$438 million to renovate the Lord & Taylor building in New York, with plans for two floors of retail, a basement food hall, and nine floors of office space. The project, expected to be completed by late 2020, will increase the building's outstanding debt to US$900 million. The renovation comes as WeWork seeks to cut costs and become profitable after an abandoned IPO, the ouster of its co-founder, and a bailout from SoftBank. WeWork had previously considered making the space its headquarters, but also explored leasing options with Amazon.

site_title: China-Austria deal threatens to kill off Tito's Adriatic dream
summary: China is threatening to undermine Slovenia's maritime legacy with its planned high-speed line to Trieste, which could siphon away traffic from Luka Koper, the country's busiest container terminal on the Adriatic. The project, part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, aims to increase China's political clout and revive ancient trading routes. Luka Koper's aging rail line is its Achilles heel, and the company is fighting back with plans to build a new terminal and modernize equipment. The project's completion could take years, leaving locals worried about the port's future.

site_title: Economic, political and social progression
summary: Oman celebrates its 49th National Day, marking the birthdate of its beloved leader, His Majesty Sultan Qaboos bin Said. The country has made significant progress in economic, social, and political sectors, contributing to peace, safety, and stability in the region. Oman has been recognized for its achievements in various competitiveness indicators, including freedom from terrorism and independence of the judiciary. The country is also promoting its favorable investment climate and has established a Special Economic Zone at Duqm. Oman and Singapore have a long history of friendly relations, with trade and tourism between the two nations increasing in recent years.

site_title: Food Empire's CEO increases interest following Q3 results
summary: Food Empire's CEO, Tan Sri Lim Wee Yeen, has increased the company's interest following the release of its Q3 results. The Straits Times Index declined 1.6% from Nov 8-14, bringing its 2019 total return to 9.3%. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2.

site_title: WhiteCoat to provide telehealth service to AIA Shield clients
summary: Digital health provider WhiteCoat is expanding its partnership with AIA to offer on-demand telemedicine services to AIA HealthShield Gold Max plan policyholders via mobile devices. WhiteCoat's services, which include consultation, diagnosis, and medical referrals, are available 24/7 and can be accessed within 12 minutes. Policyholders will enjoy a preferential fee for consultations, with medicines separately charged. The partnership aims to provide immediate medical care to those with mobility issues, such as the elderly, and is seen as a step towards making WhiteCoat the everyday go-to digital healthcare provider.

site_title: Made in China: Samsung farms out more phones to fend off rivals
summary: Samsung plans to outsource a fifth of its smartphone production to China, with around 60 million phones made by original design manufacturers (ODMs) next year. This move aims to reduce costs and compete with low-cost rivals like Huawei and Xiaomi. However, critics worry it may compromise quality control and manufacturing expertise. Samsung has partnered with Wingtech, which also produces phones for other brands, to develop and produce budget phones quickly. The strategy is seen as a necessary move to remain competitive in the budget phone market, where profits are scarce.

images.alt_text: Samsung's plan to outsource a fifth of its smartphone production to China next year may help it compete with low-cost rivals such as Huawei and Xiaomi but it's a strategy fraught with risks, people with familiar with the move said.

site_title: Raffles Education names new director; shareholders approve property sale
summary: Raffles Education appoints Liu Ying Chun as non-executive, non-independent director, citing his strong background in China's education sector. The company also approved the sale of a land plot in New South Wales, Australia, with 99.88% of shareholders voting in favor. The property was initially bought in 2014 for A$29 million and will be sold for A$80 million.

site_title: SoftBank's second Vision Fund starting life smaller than the first
summary: SoftBank has completed an initial fundraising push for its second Vision Fund, raising approximately $2 billion, significantly less than its targeted $108 billion. This comes after SoftBank committed $38 billion of its own capital and replaced Saudi Arabia as the largest investor. The fund's first close is part of ongoing talks with potential investors, including Apple and Microsoft. SoftBank's second fund has already made one investment, in Chinese online property listing service Beike Zhaofang. The company is reflecting on its performance, with founder Masayoshi Son acknowledging a problem with his own judgment.

site_title: PizzaExpress owner keeps lenders waiting for crucial debt talks
summary: PizzaExpress Ltd's owner, Hony Capital, has failed to respond to debt talks with lenders, leaving the chain with a £1.1 billion debt pile and its first debt maturity looming in August next year. Lenders, holding 70% of PizzaExpress' most senior bonds, have offered to provide new funds, but Hony Capital has remained silent. Creditors are concerned that the expansion into China is draining cash from the business, and a restructuring is likely, with options including refinancing and exchanging debt for shares. A "sensible way" to restructure would be for secured bondholders to take over the UK operations.

site_title: Zara's founder builds global real estate empire
summary: Spanish billionaire Amancio Ortega, founder of Zara, has built a global real estate empire worth around 10 billion euros, including properties used by Facebook and Amazon in Seattle and a significant portion of London's Oxford Street. Ortega diversifies his fashion fortune by reinvesting dividends in real estate, and his investment holding Pontegadea Inversiones targets stable markets and top-category tenants, such as major multinationals. The 83-year-old is the world's sixth richest person and maintains a conservative approach to investing, avoiding housing and focusing on offices, shops, and hotels.

site_title: Regulators to beef up policing of corporate and governance breaches
summary: Singapore regulators plan to enhance collaboration among authorities to patrol corporate and governance breaches in the capital markets. A joint forum will review accounting and disclosure issues, and improve coordination among bodies such as the Monetary Authority of Singapore, Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority, and the Singapore Exchange Regulatory Co. This move aims to speed up prosecutions and enhance regulatory efficiency.

site_title: US-China trade deal to guide market in data-light week
summary: US and China are working towards a "phase one" trade deal, with investors awaiting news on the deal's timing and location. Market sentiment remains sensitive to trade developments, and traders are also monitoring tensions in Hong Kong. Economic data releases in the region include October's non-oil domestic exports and Q3 GDP figures from Singapore, Thailand, and Japan. Despite some positive market movements, risk appetite remains cautious, and investors are waiting for key details on the US-China trade deal.

site_title: Dick Lee will sing two songs at ChildAid 2019
summary: Dick Lee, a renowned Singaporean musician, will perform two songs at ChildAid 2019 on November 20 and 21 at the Esplanade. This marks the charity concert's 15th anniversary, with Lee serving as creative director for three years. Lee has chosen to sing "Bunga Sayang" and "Fried Rice Paradise" to celebrate the event, aiming to do something "special" to commemorate the occasion.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the week's tanker and dry bulk market. Key highlights include: Capesize rates nudged up in the Pacific, but softened at the end of the week; Panamax rates declined, with activity limited in South America to the Far East; Ultramax/Supramax rates saw negative movement, with limited period activity; Handysize rates continued to be bearish, with limited activity; VLCC rates slipped slightly, but the market is reported to have bottomed and is now rebounding; Suezmax rates recovered, with Aframax rates gaining ground; and Clean rates were volatile, with rates fluctuating in various trades.

site_title: Sri Lanka president-elect Rajapaksa a polarising figure
summary: Sri Lanka's president-elect Gotabaya Rajapaksa, a polarizing figure, won the election with 52.25% of the votes. His victory has raised concerns about a potential return to a security state, similar to the one he created during the civil war against Tamil separatists, which could lead to hostility towards Muslims. Experts warn that Sri Lanka's Muslims are among those most fearful of a Gotabaya presidency. Rajapaksa has vowed to rebuild the country's security arms and tackle religious extremism, but his past as defense secretary has raised allegations of human rights abuses.

images.alt_text: Mr Rajapaksa has the image of a decisive leader who gets things done.

site_title: Danske Bank gold revelations prompt Danish lawmakers to call for broader probe
summary: Danske Bank is under scrutiny for allegedly using gold to help wealthy clients in Estonia hide their fortunes. The bank's Estonian branch offered gold bars to customers, mostly from Russia, to convert their money into. Danish lawmakers are calling for a broader probe into the matter, with Business Minister Simon Kollerup describing the setup as "utterly despicable." The bank is already being investigated by US authorities and faces criminal probes in Denmark, Estonia, and France. The sale of gold bars is not listed in Danske's 2018 report, but a lawyer confirmed that gold was sold via the now-defunct Estonian branch, totaling $5 million.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Raffles Education Corp appointed Liu Ying Chun, CEO of Oriental University City Holdings HK, as a non-executive, non-independent director, citing his strong background in China's education sector. He will also serve on the risk management committee.

site_title: Airbus-backed tournament unveils first electric racing aircraft
summary: Airbus-backed tournament Air Race E unveiled the world's first electric-powered sports aircraft, White Lightning, at the Dubai Air Show. The aircraft, manufactured by UK-based Condor Aviation, can reach speeds of 482 km/h on a 5 km circuit. Air Race E plans to launch its inaugural series of international races in 2020, aiming to be the world's first all-electric airplane competition. The racing series will test innovation and accelerate the journey towards electric commercial travel.

site_title: Sembcorp app makes it 'ezi' to recycle correctly
summary: Sembcorp Industries launched the ezi mobile app in Singapore to promote recycling. The app, developed in partnership with DBS and Republic Polytechnic, provides interactive education and doorstep collection services. Users receive rewards for recycling, including 10-50 cents per kilogram for different materials. The pilot program aims to boost recycling rates and raise public awareness. By end-2020, Sembcorp plans to roll out its services to other zones and form partnerships with environmentally conscious organizations.

site_title: China's central bank warns on growth pressure, inflation views
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has warned of downward pressure on the economy and inflation risks, citing slowing investment growth and sluggish industrial production. The PBOC will increase counter-cyclical adjustments to mitigate these pressures, while remaining vigilant on inflation expectations. The consumer price index rose to a 7-year high in October, but the bank expects inflation pressure to decline in the second half of 2024. The central bank also dismissed concerns of deepening deflation, stating that factory-gate prices should return to year-on-year growth in a few months.

site_title: Stocks set to trend higher as trade war, Brexit worries fade amid renewed hopes
summary: US stocks are trending higher amid renewed hopes for a US-China trade deal, despite concerns that the agreement may not be as extensive as previously thought. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed above 28,000 for the first time, driven by hints from administration officials and positive earnings reports from retailers such as Target and Walmart. Other factors contributing to the market's positivity include the UK's likely election victory for Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the US Federal Reserve's support for the value of houses and the stock market.

images.alt_text: Last week saw better-than-expected reports from Walmart - the world's largest retailer by sales - and JCPenney, which until the dawn of the Internet age, was one of the world's largest retailers.

site_title: Progress in elections and judicial system
summary: Oman's ninth term of Majlis Ash'shura elections, held on October 27, marked a significant milestone with the election of two women to the Shura Council, boosting women's participation in politics. The country also successfully implemented technology in the voting process, including online registration and a touch-screen device, dubbed "Swatak." This move reflects Oman's efforts to support and facilitate its development through the judicial system, as established by the Supreme Judicial Council. The country's commitment to women's rights and technological advancements is a positive indication of its progress in various sectors.

images.alt_text: The elections mark one of Oman's highlights for its 49th National Day.

site_title: Who's afraid of a 100-year life? Here's a roadmap
summary: Professors Lynda Gratton and Andrew Scott argue that longevity shouldn't be perceived as a burden, but rather a gift. They believe that only 25% of ageing is genetic, and the rest is influenced by lifestyle choices and the environment. The authors propose a holistic definition of asset management, encompassing personal attributes, skills, and networks. This approach emphasizes the importance of intangible assets, such as education, social capital, and psychological well-being, in sustaining individuals into older ages. By adopting a multi-stage life, individuals can redistribute time, invest in intangible assets, and build resilience.

site_title: Yangzijiang's key man 'safe' and sound, expected to return soon
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's executive chairman Ren Yuanlin is "safe and healthy" and expected to return soon after being on leave for over three months to assist in a confidential probe in Beijing. The company, China's largest non-state-owned shipbuilder, has secured 70% of its contracts worth US$696 million despite falling short of its annual target of US$1.5 billion to US$2 billion. Analysts expect a vessel replacement cycle to ramp up as more clarity emerges on IMO 2020 emission rules. The company's stock has recovered from a 28% drop in early August, and lenders have been supportive, with friendly customers placing orders as a show of support.

site_title: Gold poised to move higher under cloud of geopolitical uncertainty
summary: Gold prices are poised to move higher due to geopolitical uncertainty, with a bullish flag formation on the daily chart indicating a potential uptick. The flag pattern, characterized by a price spike and pullback, is seen as a continuation pattern, suggesting prices will continue to rise. A hammer candlestick pattern at the support level and oversold signals from the daily stochastics oscillator also support a bullish move, with resistance levels at the upper band of the flag pattern, 1,515.55, and 1,534.48.

site_title: Saudi Aramco valuation set at up to US$1.7t
summary: Saudi Aramco has set a price range for its IPO, valuing the oil giant between $1.6 trillion and $1.7 trillion. This is below the crown prince's target of $2 trillion but still makes it potentially the world's biggest IPO. The company plans to sell 1.5% of its shares, or about 3 billion shares, at an indicative price range of 30-32 riyals per share.

site_title: It's time to light up your annual reports
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

The tradition of decorating a Christmas tree originated in 16th-century Germany as a symbol of hope during winter. Today, it's a global phenomenon celebrated by people of different cultures and faiths. As companies prepare their annual reports, they should prioritize storytelling that resonates with various stakeholders, including customers, employees, suppliers, and shareholders. The Business Roundtable's reimagined purpose of companies emphasizes the importance of delivering value to stakeholders. To light up their annual reports, companies should focus on initiatives that bring meaning to employees, celebrate supplier success, and highlight sustainable practices that benefit the community and shareholders.

site_title: Dollar slips against euro, sterling on trade talk optimism
summary: The US dollar fell 0.28% against the euro and 0.18% against the British pound on Friday, driven by optimism over ongoing trade talks with China. US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross expressed confidence in a "phase one" trade deal with China, despite a weak retail sales report. The dollar rose 0.41% against the yen, as investors shifted out of safe-haven assets. Analysts believe China's slowing economy may give the US leverage in negotiations, with some expecting a deal before US tariffs on Chinese goods take effect on December 15.

site_title: Uncertain outlook seen for Google's cloud gaming service Stadia
summary: Google's cloud gaming service Stadia has an uncertain outlook, despite its launch on November 19, 2019. The service allows users to play console-quality video games on a web browser or smartphone, aiming to break into the US$135 billion global video game industry with cloud technology. Rich new features are expected to broaden audiences, but the service's long-term success remains uncertain.

site_title: Asia Partners banks on 'Golden Age' from rising affluence of the middle class
summary: Asia Partners, a new investment firm, aims to capitalize on South-east Asia's "Golden Age" of startup formation, where the rising affluence of the middle class boosts spending power and creates a zone for tech unicorns to emerge and thrive. The firm is addressing the Series C and D gap, where venture funding for companies is scarce. Asia Partners will invest $20-100 million in companies with strong local network effects, focusing on pan-regional and uniquely South-east Asian businesses. The firm has already led a deal with hospitality startup RedDoorz, which focuses on affordable hotel accommodation in the online travel sector.

site_title: The resilience of Hong Kong's property market
summary: Hong Kong's property market has shown resilience despite the escalating violence and social unrest in the city. The total amount of mortgage in the banking system is only 10% of the entire cash deposits, and the loans-to-deposit ratio is 76%, indicating a strong balance sheet. The low gearing levels of listed property companies and the presence of cash in the system suggest that property owners are not highly leveraged, and there is enough cash to absorb a potential property price correction. The market remains fundamentally strong, with no panic selling despite the crisis, and the people of Hong Kong continue to demonstrate resilience.

site_title: US and South Korea to postpone joint air drills
summary: The US and South Korea will postpone joint air drills with North Korea, described as an "act of goodwill" to contribute to diplomacy and peace. The decision comes after months of deadlocked diplomacy with Pyongyang, which has protested the drills as preparations for invasion. The joint air drills, originally set to take place in November, will now be delayed without a set timeline for resumption. The move is seen as an effort to create space for diplomats to strike an agreement, but North Korea has criticized the US for its "hostile policy" and rejected the idea of resuming talks.

site_title: US and China trade negotiators discuss concerns of phase one
summary: US and Chinese trade negotiators held a phone call to discuss core concerns of phase one of the trade deal, following President Trump's administration signaling that talks are entering the final stages. Vice-Premier Liu He spoke with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, agreeing to remain in close communication. The US has expressed concerns over China's commitments, while China has maintained a positive stance. The two sides have held working-level video conferences on issues such as agricultural purchases and intellectual property theft. A deal is still close, but not yet finalized.

site_title: Kitchen Culture sees 11.6% rise in net loss between audited, unaudited FY19 results
summary: Kitchen Culture reported a 11.6% increase in net loss between its audited and unaudited FY19 results, with the audited net loss reaching S$4.12 million compared to S$3.7 million in the unaudited results. The increase was attributed to write-offs in inventories and bad debt, as well as higher operating expenses. The company's revenue was slightly higher in the audited results, driven by additional distribution and retail revenue.

site_title: Tritech inks MOUs with Chinese firms on possible fintech foray
summary: Tritech, a Singaporean water and environmental group, has signed two Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) with Chinese firms Ooway Technology and China Business Credit Guarantee (CBC), potentially leading to an entry into fintech and a new controlling shareholder. The MOUs involve Tritech assisting CBC in cross-border financing and a credit product, and investing in Ooway through a share swap arrangement. The deal aims to tap into the Chinese bond market, which is the third-largest in the world, and provide a holistic solution for SOEs and private companies to raise capital offshore.

site_title: Hong Kong activists vow to 'squeeze economy' as the city smoulders
summary: Hong Kong activists clashed with police on Sunday, vowing to "squeeze the economy" as the city faces its worst week of violence in months. Protesters fired arrows and petrol bombs from a barricaded university campus, while police responded with tear gas and blue liquid from water cannons. The protests, which started over a bill allowing extradition to China, have escalated into a broader fight for freedoms and universal suffrage. The city has been pushed into a recession, and two people have died in the violence. The situation remains volatile, with protesters and residents at odds over the occupation of a major university campus.

site_title: StashAway offers portfolio to manage cash
summary: StashAway, a Singapore-based robo-advisor, has launched a cash management portfolio called StashAway Simple. The portfolio offers a 1.9% return on deposits with no deposit requirements, minimum balance, or lock-up periods. Investors will pay an average 0.2% expense ratio fee. The goal is to help individuals better manage their savings, and the firm aims to become a principal wealth management partner for its clients. This move comes after the firm's successful income portfolio launch and a recent US$12 million funding round.

site_title: 4-day work week: boon or bane?
summary: A four-day work week is being considered by employers, with opinions divided on its benefits and drawbacks. Some argue it can improve work-life balance and productivity, while others believe it may hinder competitiveness and require significant adjustments to HR policies. Key proponents, such as Vijay Kumar and Leonard Cheong, suggest that flexible working arrangements can be beneficial, especially in developed countries like Singapore. However, others, like Helen Ng and Damien Dhellemmes, express concerns about the impact on customer-facing roles and the need for on-site presence. Ultimately, a four-day work week may be feasible for some businesses, but its adoption will depend on individual company cultures and priorities.

site_title: When corporate giving makes business sense
summary: Businesses that prioritize corporate social responsibility (CSR) are not only doing good, but also benefiting financially. Studies show that customers with a favorable impression of a company's CSR efforts are three times more likely to be loyal, and employees are five times more likely to remain with their employer. Companies like Salesforce and Databricks demonstrate the potency of social impact by integrating their core competencies and corporate giving, leading to improved employee morale, leadership, and retention rates. As a result, CSR is no longer seen as a charitable act, but a sound business strategy.

site_title: Prince Andrew bombs in BBC interview, raising more questions
summary: Prince Andrew's BBC interview to discuss his friendship with convicted pedophile financier Jeffrey Epstein has been widely criticized as a public relations disaster. The prince's attempts to explain away his association with Epstein, including a visit to Epstein's New York mansion in 2010, were seen as insincere and confusing. His answers, such as recalling a specific date to go to a Pizza Express restaurant, were deemed implausible. The interview has damaged the royal family's reputation, with many questioning why Prince Andrew agreed to the interview despite advice from his PR consultant to stay away.

site_title: Saudi Aramco in race for IPO record with US$1.7t top value
summary: Saudi Aramco is set to become the world's biggest IPO with a potential value of up to $1.7 trillion, after setting a price range of 30-32 riyals per share. The oil giant plans to sell 3 billion shares, valuing the IPO at 96 billion riyals ($34.8 billion). The IPO is restricted to Saudi and foreign institutions, and analysts have given a valuation range of $1.2 trillion to $2.3 trillion. This could beat Alibaba's 2014 record IPO of $25 billion.

site_title: US to force hospitals to reveal rates
summary: The US Department of Health and Human Services announced a plan to force hospitals to publish their prices of care and discounted deals with insurers starting in 2021. The goal is to increase transparency in healthcare costs, allowing patients to make informed decisions. The proposed rule also requires private insurance companies to provide cost estimates before treatment. The move aims to reduce healthcare costs by promoting competition among hospitals and insurers.

site_title: China's central bank warns of growth pressure, rising inflation
summary: China's central bank has warned of downward pressure on the economy, citing slowing investment growth and sluggish industrial production. The People's Bank of China will increase counter-cyclical adjustments to ease credit and address rising inflation, which reached a seven-year high of 3.8% in October. The bank remains vigilant on the risk of inflation and trade conflicts, emphasizing the need to maintain room in conventional monetary policy. Despite these challenges, the PBOC expects inflation pressure to gradually decline in the second half of next year.

site_title: Amazon antitrust complaint lodged in US gets attention in EU
summary: The European Union has requested a US Congressional committee to share a complaint alleging Amazon rewards merchants who use its logistics services with better visibility on its e-commerce website. The complaint, made by a long-time Amazon merchant, accuses Amazon of "tying" its marketplace and logistics service together, giving it an unfair advantage. The EU is already investigating Amazon's double role as store and host to other retailers, and this complaint may add to the antitrust probe. Amazon has disputed the allegations, saying its logistics prices are competitive and its sellers aren't penalized for using other delivery options.

site_title: Sri Lanka strongman Rajapaksa wins presidency by big margin
summary: Sri Lanka's former civil wartime defence chief Gotabaya Rajapaksa won the presidential election with a 52.25% majority, defeating housing minister Sajith Premadasa. Rajapaksa promised to secure the country against militant threats following Easter bombings and vowed to be leader of all Sri Lankans, regardless of their ethnic and religious identities. His victory is seen as a nationalist sweep, tapping into the anger and fears of majority communities, and is expected to strengthen ties with China, which has invested billions in the country.

site_title: Alibaba calls off event for Hong Kong share sale amid unrest
summary: Alibaba has cancelled its investor luncheon in Hong Kong due to intensifying protests, instead conducting meetings by phone. The move comes amid logistics and safety concerns, following disruptions to the city's airport and transit system. The planned share sale, valued at at least $12 billion, remains unchanged, with Alibaba aiming to price the institutional tranche on November 20.

site_title: US to extend licence for its companies to continue business with Huawei: sources
summary: The US Commerce Department is set to extend a two-week licence allowing US companies to continue doing business with Huawei, amid discussions with China to resolve a trade war. The extension, which was initially 90 days, aims to minimize disruption to rural carriers reliant on Huawei for 3G and 4G networks. The move follows a May blacklist of Huawei citing national security concerns, with the company repeatedly denying the accusations. The extension is part of ongoing talks between the US and China to resolve a trade war that has lasted over a year.

site_title: Hong Kong campus protesters shoot arrows, set fires
summary: Protesters at Hong Kong Polytechnic University shot arrows and hurled petrol bombs, with police responding with tear gas and water cannons. A media liaison officer was hit by an arrow, and a police officer was injured by a metal ball. The clashes, which began overnight, continued into Sunday evening, with protesters setting fire to debris and forcing evacuations. The university, one of five occupied campuses, is a stronghold of the protest movement, which has been seeking greater autonomy from China. The violence has raised concerns about Beijing's grip on Hong Kong, with clashes escalating to the highest level since President Xi Jinping came to power in 2012.

site_title: Bloomberg will spend US$100m on anti-Trump online ad blitz
summary: Billionaire Michael Bloomberg is launching a $100 million digital ad campaign in four key battleground states to attack and define President Donald Trump ahead of a potential 2020 presidential run. The ads, which will run through the end of the primary season, will not feature Bloomberg himself but aim to create an anti-Trump narrative. The move is seen as a pre-emptive strike to counter Democratic concerns about Bloomberg's wealth and a potential financial advantage in the general election.

site_title: US and China have significant differences ahead of trade talks
summary: US and Chinese negotiators held a phone call to narrow differences on an initial trade agreement, but remain split on key issues, including tariffs and China's commitment to purchase US farm products. US President Donald Trump has not agreed to remove tariffs, and China wants to make purchases based on market needs. The two sides are expected to continue negotiations before a potential deadline in December, with US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross expressing optimism about reaching a final agreement.

site_title: Viking Offshore enters term sheet to raise S$5m from proposed placement
summary: Viking Offshore and Marine (VOM) has entered a term sheet with Ruddin Advisory and Blue Ocean Capital Partners to raise S$5 million by placing out 66.5% of its enlarged share base. The company, under court protection from creditors, plans to use the funds to repay debts, pay professional fees, and fund working capital. The term sheet provides an exclusivity period of 30 days for negotiations and finalization of a definitive agreement. The proposed placement is subject to shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting. Shares have been suspended from trading since June.

site_title: Oil close to two-month high as trade war positivity hits markets
summary: Oil prices rose to nearly two-month highs due to optimism about a potential US-China trade deal. Oil futures jumped 1.7% on Friday, driven by comments from White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow. Despite record-high oil production and rising inventories, oil prices rose due to concerns about global demand growth and economic growth. West Texas Intermediate settled at $57.72 a barrel, while Brent rose to $63.30 a barrel. The deal's impact on oil prices is expected to be a key indicator of global economic growth.

site_title: Cannabis flameout looks almost as bad as the dotcom bust
summary: Wall Street's enthusiasm for the cannabis industry has quickly turned to despair, with many companies losing two-thirds or more of their value in a matter of months. Despite widespread legalization, bank financing has dried up and institutional investors remain on the sidelines. Companies such as Canopy Growth Corp and MedMen Enterprises Inc have seen their shares plummet, with Canopy's market value shrinking from C$24 billion to C$7.1 billion. Analysts predict a long recovery, with one analyst boosting US sales forecasts to $85 billion by 2030, but the industry remains federally illegal in the US, limiting access to institutional investors.

site_title: Wealthy buyers go house-hunting in new cities
summary: Wealthy homebuyers are shifting away from global cities, seeking alternative locations due to rising costs and decreased appeal. Luxury property prices in 45 cities rose 1.1% in Q3, the weakest annual gain since 2009. Notable declines include 4.4% in New York, 3.9% in London, and 10% in Vancouver. This trend reflects a growing preference for cities with more affordable housing options, such as Boston, as wealthy buyers seek safe havens.

site_title: Yanlord stake in UE crosses 50% mark, offer turns unconditional
summary: Yanlord Land Group's takeover offer for United Engineers (UE) has turned unconditional, with its stake crossing the 50% mark. Yanlord acquired 59.9 million shares of UE at the S$2.70 offer price, bringing its total stake to 51.46%. The offeror, Yanlord Investment Singapore (YIS), has also announced a mandatory unconditional cash offer for WBL at S$2.5947 per share. This move provides an opportunity for remaining shareholders to exit the unlisted firm.

site_title: Twin engines helping to boost Oman's economy
summary: Oman is boosting its economy through tourism and logistics strategies. The country's tourism sector has seen a significant increase in visitors, with 3.3 million tourists in 2017 and 55 new hotel projects planned for 2018-2019. The Sultanate aims to develop 14 tourist resort complexes by 2020. Additionally, Oman is working to become a global logistics hub, with the government holding company ASYAD overseeing the logistics sector and developing its ports to attract investment. The logistics strategy, SOLS 2040, aims to contribute 14 billion Omani rial to the country's GDP by 2040.

images.alt_text: "Ports are a mainstay of the logistics sector, and the Sultanate's port network consists of four main facilities - the Sultan Qaboos Port (above), Sohar Port, Salalah Port, and Duqm Port," says the The Ministry of Information.
Oman's golden sand dunes make the oldest independent state in Arab world a unique winter destination.
Oman is in a strategic position with good traffic.

site_title: Taylor Swift wins some support in feud with old label, and lots of silence
summary: Taylor Swift and her former record label, Big Machine Label Group, exchanged accusations over her rights to perform old songs. Swift claimed her label refused permission for her to sing a medley of her old hits at the American Music Awards, while Big Machine called her claims "false information." Singer-songwriters like Sara Bareilles and Selena Gomez expressed support for Swift, but many other prominent female artists remained silent, including Katy Perry, Adele, and Beyonce. The dispute centers on Swift's contract, which restricts her from re-recording her old material until November 2020.

site_title: US dollar slips against euro, pound on trade talk optimism
summary: The US dollar fell 0.28% against the euro and 0.18% against the British pound due to optimism over ongoing US-China trade talks. US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross stated progress on a "phase one" trade pact, boosting trade-exposed currencies like the euro and pound. The dollar rose 0.41% against the yen, as safe-haven assets declined. Analysts attribute the dollar's decline to weak US retail sales data and China's slowing economy, which may give the US economic leverage.

site_title: US Supreme Court to hear Google bid to end Oracle copyright suit
summary: The US Supreme Court agreed to hear Google's appeal to escape a multi-billion dollar lawsuit accusing Google of infringing Oracle's software copyrights for building the Android operating system. A lower court ruling revived the suit, with Oracle seeking at least $8 billion in damages. The justices will hear arguments in the case during their current term, with a ruling due by the end of June. Google argues that its inclusion of Oracle's code in Android constitutes fair use, while Oracle claims that Google copied thousands of lines of code without a license, harming its business.

site_title: China blocks visit by outspoken Australian lawmakers for study trip
summary: Two Australian lawmakers, Andrew Hastie and James Paterson, were barred from visiting China for a study trip due to their "frankness about the Chinese Communist Party". The lawmakers, known for their outspoken criticism of the Chinese regime, were set to participate in a study tour organized by China Matters, an Australia-based think-tank. The Chinese government cited the lawmakers' criticism as the reason for the ban, stating that "honest discussion and the free exchange of ideas" pose a threat. The lawmakers expressed disappointment, stating they looked forward to a time when the Chinese government would "realize it has nothing to fear from honest discussion".

site_title: A 9-year-old boy is about to get a degree in electrical engineering
summary: A 9-year-old Belgian boy, Laurent Simons, is set to graduate from the Eindhoven University of Technology with a degree in electrical engineering, becoming one of the youngest people to do so. Born with an IQ of 145, Laurent studied at the university since he was 8 and is on track to complete his program in 10 months. He plans to study medicine, do a PhD, and create artificial organs, motivated by his grandparents' heart conditions. Laurent's parents have managed his social media presence, which has gained over 13,000 followers, and he aims to study in the US in the future.

site_title: Trump asked Tokyo for US$8b to keep US troops in Japan: sources
summary: US President Donald Trump asked Japan to quadruple its payments for US troops stationed there to around $8 billion, citing unnamed current and former US officials. The current agreement expires in March 2021, and the demand was made during a trip to the region by John Bolton and Matt Pottinger in July. The request is part of Washington's efforts to increase defense spending from allies.

site_title: Sponsor says it has strict rules in managing conflicts of interest at Sabana Reit, ESR Reit
summary: ESR Cayman, the sponsor of Sabana Reit, has implemented strict internal controls to regulate conflicts of interest between the two Reits following an activist fund's call for a merger. The sponsor has set up separate structures to prevent the sharing of information between the managers of both Reits, addressing potential conflicts of interest.

site_title: Pro-China protesters to rally amid Hong Kong chaos
summary: Pro-China protesters plan to rally in Hong Kong on Saturday, denouncing violent anti-government unrest and supporting police. The rallies come as protests, sparked by perceived Communist Party meddling, have turned violent, with protesters barricading campuses and attacking police. A 70-year-old street cleaner died after being hit by a brick, and a protester was shot in the abdomen. Protesters demand full democracy and an independent investigation into police brutality, while China denies interfering and blames Western countries for stirring up trouble. The Hong Kong government has yet to respond effectively to the crisis.

site_title: Google makes a bid for banking, where other tech firms have flopped
summary: Google is teaming up with Citigroup and the Stanford Federal Credit Union to launch "smart checking" accounts, code-named Cache, in 2020. The project aims to provide users with budgeting tools and insights, but details on specific features are unclear. This marks Google's entry into the banking industry, despite previous attempts by technology companies to create digitally focused alternatives to traditional banking having limited success. The move is seen as an extension of Google Pay, and the company is relying on its partners to manage customers' accounts, rather than seeking a banking charter.

site_title: Europe: Shares clock sixth weekly gain on trade cheer
summary: European shares rose 0.4% for a sixth-straight week, driven by bullish comments from a White House official on US-China trade talks, which lifted optimism about a potential trade deal. The Stoxx 600 index closed near four-year highs, with trade-sensitive and technology stocks leading gains. Defensive sectors like utilities and telecom lagged. Despite some regional disappointments, European indices ended the week marginally higher, driven by positive forecasts from industry bellwethers.

site_title: Election may be least of UK investors' woes as growth caves in
summary: UK investors may be overlooking the country's economic woes despite optimism over a potential Brexit deal. The economy has shrunk for the second month, and trade talks with the EU are fraught. Sterling has surged 5% this quarter, but some investors, like Allianz Global Investors, warn against complacency. Algebris Investments expects the pound to stay under pressure in the long term. The UK's economic growth is caveing in, making the election outcome less of a priority for investors.

images.alt_text: With all the focus on getting the positioning right for next month's UK election, investors may be overlooking bigger threats beyond.

site_title: Gold totters as trade optimism propels stocks to record highs
summary: Gold prices retreated from a near one-week peak on Friday, falling 0.2% to $1,467.48 per ounce, as US stock markets hit record highs following comments on progress in the US-China trade agreement. Optimism over the trade deal has reduced safe-haven demand for gold, which has gained 14% this year. US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled no further interest rate cuts unless there's a material change in the economic outlook, and analysts expect gold to rise 0.6% this week.

site_title: Tennis: Zverev seals semi-final spot, bumps out Nadal
summary: Defending champion Alexander Zverev reached the semi-finals of the ATP Finals, defeating Russian debutant Daniil Medvedev 6-4, 7-6(4) to secure second spot in the group. Zverev's win eliminated Rafael Nadal, who had earlier lost to Stefanos Tsitsipas, and set up a semi-final match against Dominic Thiem. The loss ends Nadal's hopes of a semi-final against Roger Federer, who will face Tsitsipas instead. Zverev credited the young players for improving their game, and expressed concern about his upcoming semi-final against Thiem.

site_title: New top-tier condos see better sales this year
summary: Singapore saw a record-breaking 104 non-landed new homes sold in the first 10 months of the year, with a price tag of S$5 million and above, surpassing the previous high in 2011. Despite economic uncertainties, the data indicates healthy demand for top-tier condos.

site_title: On 16th birthday, California student opens fire at his high school, killing two
summary: A 16-year-old California high school student opened fire on his classmates on his 16th birthday, killing two and wounding three. The suspect, who acted alone, pulled a .45 caliber handgun from his backpack and fired on students in 16 seconds before taking a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head. The motive behind the shooting is unknown, and police have found no evidence of a connection to the 2018 Parkland, Florida school shooting. The incident has reignited a debate over gun control in the US, with 85 school shootings reported in the country this year.

images.alt_text: A Southern California high school student killed two classmates and wounded three on Thursday, pulling a .45 caliber semiautomatic handgun from his backpack and emptying it in a matter of seconds as the school day began.

site_title: Reynolds wrap maker backed by Rank Group files for US IPO
summary: Reynolds Consumer Products Inc, maker of Reynolds Wrap aluminum foil and Hefty trash bags, has filed for a US initial public offering (IPO) with a planned valuation of $7 billion. The company, backed by New Zealand billionaire Graeme Hart's Rank Group, listed the IPO size as $100 million, with the number of shares and price range yet to be decided. This follows a period of increased IPO activity in the US, with $2.93 billion raised in 31 IPOs so far this quarter. The company plans to list its shares on Nasdaq under the symbol REYN.

site_title: US: Wall Street forges new records on trade optimism, Dow crosses 28,000 mark
summary: US stocks reached new highs on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average crossing the 28,000 mark for the first time. The Dow rose 0.8% to 28,004.89, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also posted gains. The positive sentiment was driven by comments from top White House economic advisor Larry Kudlow on a possible US-China trade deal, which is expected to be finalized in the coming days. Despite ongoing trade tensions, the rebound in consumer spending and a decline in the manufacturing sector were also contributing factors to the market's optimism.

site_title: A very big TV and a very small computer
summary: LG unveils the world's first 8K OLED TV, the OLED88Z9, with a 88-inch screen and 33 million pixels, featuring AI-enhanced picture and sound quality. The TV supports 8K resolution, HDR, and WiSA connectivity. Meanwhile, Lenovo launches ultra-portable desktops, the ThinkCentre M90n-1 Nano and M90n-1 Nano IoT, designed for small businesses with space-saving and energy-efficient designs, supporting up to 8th Gen Intel Core processors and SSD storage.

site_title: New home prices in China maintain steady growth in October
summary: China's new home prices maintained a steady 0.5% growth in October, marking the 54th straight month of gains, but momentum slowed in mega-cities like Beijing, Shanghai, and Shenzhen. Annual growth slowed to 7.8%, the weakest pace since August last year. Analysts expect property market conditions to worsen, particularly in low-tier cities, and some predict Beijing may need to reverse its tightening measures by spring 2020 to stabilize growth.

site_title: Hibernation works for bears. Could it work for us, too?
summary: Researchers studying hibernating grizzly bears have made significant discoveries about the physiological changes that occur during hibernation. The study found that the bears' fatty tissues undergo significant changes, while muscle tissue remains relatively unchanged.
