The accident occurred when one bus driver lost control, crossing a median and crashing into another bus traveling in the opposite direction. The cause of the accident was not immediately known. This incident highlights the common issue of traffic accidents in Indonesia, where vehicles are often old and poorly maintained.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.72 points to 1,594.50. Volume was 37.71 million lots worth RM16.2 million. Gainers beat losers 85 to 56.

site_title: Asia: Equities swing as trade cues awaited, Hong Kong in focus
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Thursday, with investors cautious due to the lack of concrete details from the US-China trade talks. Despite Donald Trump's comments that the trade agreement with China is moving along rapidly, markets remained volatile. Hong Kong's violent protests continued to draw attention, and the Singapore stock market notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records in the US, while the STI rose 0.4% in Singapore. Investors remained divided on the Fed's views, with some expecting a rate cut.

site_title: Google checking account service on its way: report
summary: Google is planning to launch a checking account service, dubbed "Cache", in collaboration with Citigroup and a Silicon Valley credit union, reportedly set to launch next year. The service will partner with financial institutions to handle security and regulatory compliance issues. This move follows internet titans like Apple and Amazon exploring online financial transactions, and comes amid growing competition in the digital banking space, with Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency plans facing regulatory resistance.

site_title: Portal Asset Management launches Asia-Pacific cryptocurrency, blockchain fund
summary: Portal Asset Management, a Singapore-based firm, has launched its first Asia-Pacific cryptocurrency and blockchain fund, targeting sophisticated investors in the region. The Portal Digital Fund aims to manage over $100 million in funds and offers a simple, risk-managed solution to access the growing digital assets economy. The fund will focus on two investment streams: quantitative-driven trading and long-only venture capital and private equity funds. Portal's two-year return on its strategy has been 110.8%, outperforming the CCi30 Index and top cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Hong Kong banks worry about risk of easier mortgage rules as recession takes hold
summary: Hong Kong banks are increasing mortgage application standards amid concerns about a potential recession, which could lead to borrowers defaulting on loans. The banks are raising interest rates and reducing cash rebates to borrowers, and some are phasing out rebates entirely. The move follows the recent easing of down-payment requirements, which allowed first-time homebuyers to borrow up to 90% of a HK$8 million home's cost. Historically, mortgage delinquency is rare in Hong Kong, but bankers are taking precautions to protect their profitability and asset quality.

site_title: Australian dollar stumbles to 1-month low on poor jobs, China data
summary: The Australian dollar dropped to a one-month low on Thursday, 0.5% to US$0.6802, amid weak employment data and disappointing Chinese economic numbers. The country lost 19,000 jobs in October, contrary to forecasts, and the jobless rate rose to 5.3%. Investors now see a 24% chance of a Reserve Bank of Australia rate cut in December, up from 0% previously. The Australian dollar's decline also saw it test support near US$0.6800, while bonds rallied on the data, with yields on three-year paper falling 7 basis points.

site_title: Hot stock: Yoma shares jump 20% on Ayala investment despite Q2 loss
summary: Yoma Strategic shares jumped 20% on Thursday after Philippines conglomerate Ayala invested US$155 million, taking a 20% stake in the company, despite a Q2 loss of US$44.2 million. The investment will fund business growth and expansion, with the remainder used to refinance debt. This is part of Ayala's US$237.5 million investment in Yoma Group, which includes Yoma Strategic and affiliated company First Myanmar Investment Public Co.

site_title: Chile central bank says injecting US$4b to halt peso slide
summary: Chile's central bank announced a US$4 billion injection to halt the peso's slide to historic lows, with the currency reaching 795 to the dollar on Wednesday. This measure aims to mitigate potential market tensions. The peso had previously reached a record low of 783 on Tuesday.

site_title: Trump says he's a 'big fan' of Turkey's Erdogan
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed his admiration for Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, calling him a "big fan" during a joint press conference. Trump highlighted Turkey's role as a NATO ally and strategic partner, despite opposition from Congress. The comments were seen as a departure from previous US stances on Erdogan, who has faced criticism for human rights abuses and authoritarian tendencies.

site_title: Regtech startup Silent Eight raises US$6.2m in oversubscribed Series A round
summary: Silent Eight, a Singapore-headquartered regulatory technology startup, has raised an oversubscribed US$6.2 million in its Series A round. The capital will be used to hire new employees to support its banking and insurance customers. With almost 50 employees globally, the company plans to double its global headcount by the end of Q1 2020. This funding will aid its research and development efforts, particularly in Singapore, where it will hire for positions such as data scientist and product manager.

site_title: Saudi Aramco names first woman to head overseas office, days before IPO
summary: Saudi Aramco has appointed Marwa al-Khuzaim as the first woman to head its overseas office, Aramco Asia Singapore, effective December 1. She will oversee corporate strategies in southeast Asia and Australia, responsible for marketing crude oil and driving performance of services such as supply chain and procurement. Her appointment comes before the company's IPO on November 17, which may raise between $20 billion and $40 billion. Al-Khuzaim previously held a supply chain director role at Aramco Chemicals Company.

site_title: Banyan Tree Q3 loss deepens to S$9.4m; CFO steps down to head new Phuket unit
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings reported a net loss of S$9.4 million for its third quarter, down from S$7 million a year ago, due to lower operating profit from hotel and property sales segments. Revenue declined 20% to S$55.4 million, primarily due to delayed revenue recognition from property sales and non-consolidation of revenue from Banyan Tree Seychelles. CFO Kuan Chiet has left the position to head a new Phuket unit, with Eddy See continuing to oversee human resource and risk management functions.

site_title: Singapore shares dip at Thursday's open; STI down 0.01%
summary: Singapore shares dipped 0.01% at Thursday's open, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,238.99. Gainers outnumbered losers 71 to 50, with Rex International and Yoma Strategic Holdings posting significant gains. Rex reported a third-quarter profit of US$582,000, while Yoma announced a US$155 million investment from Ayala Corporation. Banking stocks were down, with DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank experiencing losses.

site_title: Australian mining giant BHP appoints new CEO
summary: Australian mining giant BHP has appointed Mike Henry as its new CEO, replacing outgoing Andrew Mackenzie at the end of 2019. Henry, a long-time employee, has extensive global experience and will focus on delivering high performance and returns. BHP's annual net profit more than doubled to US$8.3 billion in the year to June 30, driven by higher iron ore prices and a rebound from setbacks. Mackenzie, retiring after seven years, expressed confidence in Henry's ability to unlock value from BHP's resources.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after weak growth data
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on November 14, 2019, after weaker-than-expected growth data in Japan and ongoing US-China trade deal doubts. The Nikkei 225 index edged down 0.08% to 23,301.34, while the Topix index fell 0.19%. The decline follows a global trend, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P finish at records despite trade deal doubts
summary: US stocks finished at records on Wednesday despite doubts over a potential trade deal between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3% to 27,783.59, while the S&P 500 finished essentially flat at 3,091.96. Disney shares surged 7% after reporting 10 million subscribers for its streaming service on its first day. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony largely met investor expectations, and the Nasdaq fell less than 0.1% to 8,482.10. Markets pared gains after a report suggested Chinese officials were hesitant to agree to a trade deal.

site_title: Brexit Party's Farage turns down electoral pact offer from PM Johnson's Conservatives: report
summary: Britain's ruling Conservative Party offered an electoral pact to Brexit Party leader Nigel Farage, targeting 40 Labour-held seats, but he rejected the deal as it didn't meet his demands. Farage wanted the Conservatives to withdraw their candidates from those seats. The Brexit Party's decision to turn down the offer may impact the UK's Brexit negotiations and the Conservative Party's chances in the next general election.

site_title: Yoma in the red for Q2; Ayala buys 20% stake for US$155m
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Myanmar-focused company, reported a net loss of US$44.2 million for its fiscal 2020 second quarter, primarily due to a US$31.6 million fair value loss from disposing of a China investment. Revenue for its real estate development segment declined, while its consumer segment saw revenue more than double. The company also announced that Ayala Corporation bought a 20% stake for US$155 million.

site_title: Temasek prices oversubscribed 12-year, 30-year euro bonds at 0.5% and 1.25%
summary: Temasek Holdings has priced its 12-year, 30-year euro bonds at 0.5% and 1.25% respectively, with the 12-year bond being oversubscribed by 7 times. The bonds, worth $750.1 million, will be issued below par, giving a yield to maturity of 0.609% and 1.317% respectively. The deal attracted "strong demand from high-quality investors globally," with fund managers subscribing to 60% of the bonds.

site_title: Golden Agri back in the black with Q3 profit on lower expenses, other income
summary: Golden Agri-Resources (GAR) posted a Q3 net profit of US$801,000, reversing a loss of US$53.9 million in the same period last year, due to lower expenses and other income. Earnings per share rose to 0.01 US cent from a loss of 0.42 US cents last year. No dividend was declared. This improvement is attributed to cost-cutting measures.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SPH, Yoma, Eagle Hospitality Trust, Rex, Golden Agri, YZJ, Tuan Sing
summary: Singapore stocks experienced varied developments on Thursday, with some companies reporting positive earnings and others facing challenges. SPH diversified its student accommodation portfolio with a €15.6 million acquisition in Germany. Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a net loss of US$44.2 million, while Eagle Hospitality Trust's distributable income fell 1.2% due to lower revenue. In contrast, Rex International returned to profitability with a US$582,000 net profit, and Golden Agri-Resources posted a third-quarter net profit of US$801,000. Meanwhile, Tuan Sing Holdings' Q3 net profit plummeted 95% due to lower revenue and increased finance costs.

site_title: Brexit will make Britain 'second-rate player': EU's Tusk
summary: Outgoing EU Council president Donald Tusk warned that Brexit will make Britain a "second-rate player" unable to compete with major powers like the US, China, and EU. Tusk stated that the departure marked the end of the British Empire and that the UK will become an outsider, a "second-rate player," after leaving the EU. He urged those seeking to keep Britain in the bloc not to lose hope, saying that the UK can only play a global role as part of a united Europe.

site_title: Egypt oil pipeline fire kills six
summary: A fire broke out on an oil pipeline in Egypt's Bahira province, killing six people and injuring 15. The leak was attributed to thieves, and the blaze was quickly extinguished. The incident occurred near Itay al-Baroud, halfway between Cairo and Alexandria. The wounded were taken to a nearby hospital, and the leak was fixed. The cause of the fire remains a result of the "thieves" syphoning off oil from the pipeline.

site_title: Oil edges up ahead of US storage data as Opec, Federal Reserve see robust economy
summary: Oil prices rose 0.5-0.6% on Wednesday, with Brent futures settling at $62.37 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $57.12 per barrel. The increase was attributed to positive economic comments from US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and Opec, which suggested a robust economy. This rebound in risk appetite was seen as a response to Powell's testimony emphasizing growth and low rates. Oil prices are expected to be influenced by the upcoming US storage data report.

site_title: SPH buys 284-bed student accommodation in Germany for 15.6m euros
summary: SPH has acquired a 284-bed student accommodation in Bremen, Germany for 15.6 million euros (S$23.4 million). This is the company's fifth investment since last year and expands its purpose-built student accommodation portfolio to 5,343 beds across 11 cities in the UK and Germany. The asset, Galileo Residenz, has had near-full occupancy over the past nine years and is located on the University of Bremen campus. The acquisition is expected to have no material impact on SPH's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the fiscal year ending August 31, 2020.

site_title: Facebook nixes billions of fake accounts
summary: Facebook has removed approximately 5.4 billion fake accounts this year, a significant step in the company's ongoing battle against manipulation and misinformation. The social network has also seen a 16% increase in government requests for user data, with the US leading the way. Despite efforts to curb disturbing content, Facebook acknowledges that mistakes can still occur and is investing in systems to improve accuracy. CEO Mark Zuckerberg emphasized the importance of regulation to openly disclose details about efforts to stop the spread of harmful content, stating it's crucial for understanding the prevalence of such content.

site_title: Japan's economy grew 0.1% in third quarter of 2019: government
summary: Japan's economy grew 0.1% in the third quarter of 2019, a slowdown from 0.4% in the previous period. The growth was largely driven by domestic demand, with household spending surging 9.5% year-on-year. However, exports were impacted by global trade tensions, outweighing the growth. Economists had expected a stronger pace of growth due to consumers rushing to complete purchases before a planned consumption tax hike. The slowdown raises concerns for the health of Japan's economy, with some analysts expecting a backlash in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Eric Watson, Cultural Medallion recipient 2019
summary: Eric Watson, a renowned Singaporean composer, was interviewed on the Money FM podcast about his work. Born in the UK, Watson learned to play piano and violin before moving to Singapore in 1991. He has successfully fused diverse musical and cultural sources in his compositions. Watson was awarded the Cultural Medallion in 2019 for his contributions to Singapore's rich musical traditions and cultures. He discussed his musical journey, influences, and the importance of preserving Singapore's musical heritage.

site_title: France's Saint-Gobain to buy Continental Building for US$1.4b
summary: France's Saint-Gobain has agreed to buy US drywall maker Continental Building Products in a deal worth $1.4 billion, including debt. The acquisition represents a 34.4% premium to Continental Building's average share price. The deal, expected to close in 2020, aims to create a new subsidiary and generate $50 million in cost savings and performance improvements.

site_title: Rex International swings into the black for Q3
summary: Rex International reported a net profit of US$582,000 in Q3, compared to a net loss of US$1.6 million in the same period last year. Revenue increased 45% to US$135,000, driven by service revenue and other income, which rose to US$2.5 million. The company has turned profitable and has US$41.4 million in cash and cash equivalents. No dividend was declared, but the group plans to drill an appraisal well in Oman and achieve oil production in Q1 2020.

site_title: Singapore maps out route to becoming AI powerhouse
summary: Singapore has unveiled its National AI Strategy, aiming to leverage artificial intelligence to transform the economy and become a global AI powerhouse by 2030. The strategy, launched at the Singapore FinTech Festival, outlines five key national projects in areas such as transport, healthcare, and education. A National AI Office will be created to consolidate efforts, with S$500 million set aside for research and development. The government also announced a Model AI Governance framework and an initiative called Veritas to ensure responsible AI adoption in the financial sector. Analysts praise the strategy as a timely and major step forward, citing Singapore's education system, knowledge-based economy, and sound governance as key success factors.

images.alt_text: The launch of Singapore's National AI Strategy is the next step of its "Smart Nation" journey, said Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat at the Singapore FinTech Festival and Singapore Week of Innovation and TeCHnology (SFF x SWITCH) conference.

site_title: US household debt nears US$14t in Q3: New York Federal Reserve
summary: US household debt reached nearly $14 trillion in Q3, a 0.7% increase from the prior quarter, driven by mortgage borrowing and student loans. This marks the 21st consecutive quarter of rising debt. Student loan debt rose $20 billion to $1.5 trillion, with higher default rates among borrowers from majority-black neighborhoods, likely due to large income disparities. Bankruptcies fell 13.4% to 186,000, and new delinquencies among mortgage borrowers reached a record low.

site_title: Google denies misusing data from provider of healthcare
summary: Google denies collecting and misusing identifiable patient data from Ascension Hospital network, a major US healthcare provider. According to Google executives, employees access patient information only to build an internal search tool, and no data is used for artificial intelligence research. The company claims to store and encrypt data in a virtual private space, and that it never sells or combines data with other information. Google's actions have sparked criticism from politicians, including Senator Richard Blumenthal, who calls it a "blatant disregard for privacy."

site_title: Alternative meat startups can't slay sacred cows of the food business
summary: Alternative meat startups, such as Beyond Meat, struggle to achieve mass market appeal and reasonable pricing, despite their rise due to consumer concerns over climate change and animal welfare. Experts say these fundamentals are crucial to the food business, and alternative meat startups must focus on these aspects to succeed. Venture firm Big Idea Ventures managing partner Andrew Ive noted the importance of these factors in the growth of the industry.

site_title: Mumbai Trump Tower builder's rating slashed
summary: Moody's Investors Service has cut the rating of Macrotech Developers, a Mumbai-based Trump Tower developer, to Caa1, indicating high credit risk due to significant refinancing risks. The company's US$325 million bonds mature in March 2024, and while it has made refinancing efforts, Moody's analyst Sweta Patodia stated that these measures do not completely alleviate the risks. This downgrade reflects deepening problems for India's real estate sector.

site_title: HK chaos raises fears about what's next; schools are shut, work disrupted
summary: The Hong Kong government ordered schools to shut on November 13, 2019, due to safety concerns amid the ongoing unrest. Firms across the city also urged workers to stay home to ensure family safety. Protests have escalated, with violent clashes between police and protesters at the Chinese University of Hong Kong. The government has taken measures to maintain order, but concerns about Chinese intervention have risen, potentially threatening Hong Kong's autonomy and US trade privileges.

site_title: London added to network to link local startups to UK market
summary: Singapore's Enterprise Singapore (ESG) has added London to its Global Innovation Alliance (GIA) network, connecting local startups to the UK market. ESG has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with UK accelerator IoT Tribe, launching two GIA programmes starting in 2020. The programmes will support startups expanding into the UK and Europe, and vice versa. The move aims to facilitate growth and innovation between Singapore and the UK, with up to 10 participants in each inaugural cohort.

site_title: Disney+ streaming service gets 10m subscribers at launch
summary: Disney+ reached 10 million subscribers within a day of its launch, exceeding expectations despite technical issues that prevented customers from accessing certain titles. The service, which offers thousands of movies and TV episodes from Disney, Pixar, Marvel, and National Geographic, marks a significant milestone for the media giant. Analysts say the strong demand for the unique catalogue positions Disney+ for long-term success, even in a fluid market with new players entering the scene.

images.alt_text: Disney+ marks a huge bet by the media-entertainment giant, pitching it into direct conflict with on-demand services such as Netflix and Amazon Prime which have disrupted the Hollywood media landscape.

site_title: HK unrest has slashed local sales, says Ferragamo
summary: Ferragamo reports a 45% decline in sales in Hong Kong during the third quarter, exceeding estimates from rival luxury companies. The decline is attributed to months of anti-Beijing protests deterring tourists and locals from spending. This marks a significant drop, with LVMH and Kering reporting 25% and 35% declines, respectively. The Hong Kong unrest has had a substantial impact on the local luxury market.

site_title: Europe: Trade woes, Hong Kong unrest knock shares off 4-year peak; Spain lags
summary: European shares fell 0.2% from four-year highs, hurt by ambiguity over a US-China trade deal and unrest in Hong Kong. Despite improved earnings expectations, the region remains in a corporate recession. Banks were the biggest drag, weighed down by exposure to Hong Kong. Spanish stocks led losses, as a new coalition formed by the Socialists and far-left Unidas Podemos extended a slide. The focus shifts to German GDP numbers, expected to show a technical recession.

site_title: Trump says will make decision on auto tariffs 'very soon'
summary: US President Donald Trump announced he will make a decision on tariffs on imported autos "very soon." Industry sources expect tariffs to be deferred for another six months. Trump has been considering 25% tariffs to defend US automakers, but Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said duties might not be necessary after "good conversations" with automakers. German automakers, particularly BMW, may be hesitant to make concessions due to existing investments in the US. The US has been in talks with EU, Japanese, and other automakers to avoid tariffs.

site_title: Global oil demand growth to slow from 2025: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts global oil demand growth will slow from 2025 due to improved fuel efficiency and increased use of electric vehicles. Oil use in passenger cars is expected to peak in the late 2020s, while demand is projected to increase by 0.1 million barrels per day in the 2030s, reaching 106 million bpd by 2040. The agency forecasts 330 million electric cars on the road by 2040, displacing 4 million bpd of oil use.

site_title: MAS reviving its electronic know-your-customer project
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviving its electronic know-your-customer (e-KYC) project, dubbed "KYC 2.0". The initiative, first proposed in 2017, aims to improve the efficiency of checking against sanctions and blacklists. This time, MAS will focus on a less costly technology architecture. The move coincides with the launch of the Bank for International Settlements' (BIS) innovation hub in Singapore, which will work on public digital infrastructures and supervisory tech solutions. The goal is to create a more modern and technologically savvy financial system that supports the digital economy.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Powell urges US Congress to focus on debt, deficit
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell urged US Congress to address the rising national debt and deficit, warning that the debt could limit lawmakers' willingness to act during an economic downturn. The US budget deficit soared to $1 trillion in the 2019 fiscal year, and government borrowing is over $23 trillion. Powell also cautioned that the Fed's tools to respond to a recession are limited, and fiscal policy may be restrained by the growing debt. Despite these warnings, Powell stated that the US economy is likely to continue growing, albeit with continued risks from the global slowdown and trade disputes.

site_title: Sunrise counts cost of its failure to buy Liberty Global business
summary: Sunrise Communications faces a potential 125 million Swiss franc (S$172 million) loss due to its failed bid to buy Liberty Global's Swiss unit. The US cable company had agreed to a 6.3 billion franc deal, but it was halted after opposition from the Swiss telecommunication company's largest shareholder. Sunrise's costs include a 50 million franc break-up fee, 19 million francs in underwriting fees, and 24 million francs in integration costs. The company had hoped to revive the deal, but Liberty Global has held out hope for a revised agreement.

images.alt_text: Last month, Sunrise scrapped its takeover of Liberty's UPC Switzerland business when German firm Freenet, which holds 25% of the Swiss group, baulked on concerns the move was too expensive.

site_title: US won't rush into deal that does not rebalance ties with China: diplomat
summary: A US diplomat, Rafik Mansour, emphasizes the importance of a fair and reciprocal relationship with China, stating that the US won't rush into a deal that doesn't address structural issues. Mansour reaffirms the US commitment to the Indo-Pacific region, citing $2 trillion in bilateral trade, despite President Trump's absence from recent Asean meetings. The US is focused on a "quality agreement" with China, with a focus on public-private partnerships and high standards for infrastructure projects, seen as a response to China's Belt and Road Initiative.

site_title: Switch from PMDs to PABs may not root out problems if bad habits persist
summary: Singapore's ban on personal mobility devices (PMDs) from footpaths has been welcomed by most, but its effectiveness in addressing safety concerns remains uncertain. The ban, implemented on November 5, has inconvenienced many users, rendering their PMDs worthless. Authorities had initially tested PMDs as a mode of transport, introducing regulations and safety measures. However, critics argue that a more strict regulation on imports and usage could have been implemented. The ban has also disrupted the food-delivery industry, with gig workers and retailers expressing concerns.

site_title: Olam posts 1.5% dip in Q3 net profit to S$20.4m
summary: Olam International, an agri and food giant, reported a 1.5% dip in Q3 net profit to S$20.4m, primarily due to higher net finance costs and depreciation from adopting a new accounting standard. Revenue increased 0.2% to S$8.31 billion, while earnings per share remained unchanged. The company has exited several businesses and is working on its 2019-2024 strategic plan, which includes acquisitions and divestments.

site_title: Why US inequality is higher than Europe's
summary: The US has higher levels of income inequality compared to Europe, despite experiencing faster average income growth over the past four decades. In Europe, policies such as national minimum wages, worker protections, and free public education and healthcare have contributed to a more even income distribution. In contrast, the US has seen a widening gap between the rich and the poor, with the top 50% of earners experiencing a significant increase in income, while the bottom half has grown only 3% since 1980. To tackle inequality, policymakers can adopt either predistributive or redistributive policies, with progressive taxation and social transfers being key to reducing current and future inequalities.

site_title: Goliaths of India real estate rise as sales soar
summary: India's top nine listed real estate companies saw sales jump 159% in the year ended March, outperforming the broader real estate industry. These developers reduced their debt by 8% while competitors struggled. The S&P BSE Realty Index surged 21% this year, its biggest annual gain since 2017. Home buyers are flocking to listed companies to mitigate risk of stalled projects, while the government's 250 billion-rupee fund aims to salvage 6% of constructions running behind schedule.

site_title: Japan's biggest US bundled corporate loans investor pares holdings
summary: Norinchukin Bank, Japan's largest US bundled corporate loans investor, has pared its holdings for the first time in over a year, becoming more selective about purchasing collateralized loan obligations (CLOs) to obtain better returns. The bank's holdings fell slightly at the end of September from 8 trillion yen (S$88 billion) in June, due to a lack of attractive new deals and a volume of maturing products exceeding purchases. Norinchukin plans to continue investing in CLOs, but with caution and a focus on maintaining diversity in its asset portfolio.

site_title: The Arcade up for collective sale again with S$780m asking price
summary: The owners of The Arcade in Collyer Quay are making a second attempt at a collective sale with an asking price of S$780 million, 10% less than 2014's S$868 million. The 20-storey building, with a 999-year lease, is zoned commercial and could be redeveloped into an integrated development with a hotel, residential units, office, and retail space. Owners stand to receive between S$700,000 and S$29.9 million per unit, depending on size. The site's estimated land rate is S$2,833 per square foot per plot ratio.

site_title: Licensed to thrill: Bond author's steamy letters go on sale
summary: Licensed to thrill: A collection of letters between James Bond creator Ian Fleming and his wife Ann, including sexually-charged correspondence, went on sale. The couple met in 1934 but didn't marry until 1952, the year Fleming wrote Casino Royale. The letters, part of a broader collection of correspondence, also document the success of Fleming's 007 books. The auction highlights the personal side of Fleming's life and career, offering a glimpse into the private lives of the iconic author and his wife. The letters are expected to fetch a significant price.

site_title: China retail giant Alibaba gets nod for huge HK listing
summary: China's retail giant Alibaba has received approval to list shares in Hong Kong, potentially the city's largest IPO in nearly a decade. The approval is seen as a boost to Hong Kong's financial authorities, which have been affected by months of pro-democracy protests. The listing is also a significant move for Alibaba, which could help the city regain its financial stability and attract more foreign investment.

images.alt_text: Approval for the sale will give the city's financial authorities a huge boost as Hong Kong is battered by months of pro-democracy protests.

site_title: Chinese takeover marks new chapter in history of British Steel
summary: A Chinese company, Jingye, has acquired British Steel for £1.2 billion, marking a new chapter in the UK's tumultuous steelmaking history. The takeover is expected to bring a breath of fresh air to the 4,000 British Steel employees, with Jingye promising to invest in the industry. However, concerns remain about the long-term sustainability of the business and the potential impact on the UK's steel production, which is a significant contributor to the country's economy.

site_title: Apple assembler's quarterly profit beats estimates
summary: Apple assembler HON Hai Precision Industry Co reported quarterly profit of NT$30.7 billion (US$1 billion) for the September quarter, beating analysts' estimates of NT$27.7 billion. The solid demand for Apple's iPhone 11 range indicates strong sales.

site_title: MNACT tumbles on news overnight that protesters had damaged its HK mall
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) plummeted 4.9% on news that its Festival Walk mall in Hong Kong suffered extensive damage due to anti-government protests. The mall, which generates 62% of MNACT's net property income, has been closed since Tuesday and may need to rethink tenant incentives. The damage includes smashed glass panels, set fires, and no reported injuries. MNACT's manager is assessing the damage and will provide an update.

site_title: The dearth of IPOs weakens capitalism
summary: The US is witnessing a decline in initial public offerings (IPOs), with companies delaying their public debuts, potentially exacerbating the wealth divide and weakening governance and valuations. This trend threatens the fabric of capitalism, as public investors are left with limited opportunities for growth. Companies that stay private for longer may develop bad habits, such as questionable governance structures, and private market valuations may not accurately represent a company's worth. To address this issue, the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) should review disclosure requirements, shareholders should reward good behavior, and public exchanges should advocate for policy and regulatory changes.

site_title: Taxman nabs 10 people over suspected illegal GST refund claims
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) arrested 10 people suspected of involvement in a criminal syndicate linked to illegal GST refund claims. The arrests were made under the amended GST Act, which granted Iras' officers the power to arrest without a warrant. The operation, conducted from October 23 to 24, and Tuesday to Wednesday, resulted in the seizure of 200 electronic devices and business records from 36 business entities in 73 locations. The syndicate is believed to be involved in GST carousel fraud, a type of tax refund claim where multiple companies sell and export goods without paying GST.

site_title: Tesla picks Germany for European gigafactory
summary: Tesla has chosen Germany for its European gigafactory, with the plant to be located near Berlin and create around 10,000 jobs. The decision, announced by CEO Elon Musk at a Frankfurt event, bolsters the company's presence in the region and cements its reputation as a major player in the automotive industry. The plant, expected to be operational by 2021, marks a significant expansion of Tesla's global manufacturing network and underscores the company's growing influence in the electric vehicle market.

site_title: Three AI myths that are hurting businesses
summary: Business leaders in a region recognize AI's importance for competitiveness, with 80% agreeing its value. However, only 41% of organizations have started their AI journey due to a lack of thought leadership and investment commitment. Many decision-makers have unrealistic expectations about AI, leading to misconceptions about its capabilities. This misconception can hinder businesses from effectively implementing AI solutions.

site_title: Next step in Vancouver real estate crackdown - a single regulator
summary: British Columbia plans to introduce a single regulator for real estate and financial services, aiming to combat money laundering in the Canadian market. The joint regulator will be established by the spring of 2021, bringing real estate regulation under the BC Financial Services Authority. This move is part of the province's efforts to restrict foreign investment and speculation in housing, following a scandal in 2016 and a recent report estimating over $7 billion in dirty money was laundered through the province in a year.

site_title: Asia slides on HK chaos, trade deal doubts
summary: Asian markets slid on Wednesday, with Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.9% to 3,239.22, amid uncertainty over a US-China trade deal and escalating chaos in Hong Kong. The Hang Seng Index dropped 1.8% to 26,571.46, with Australia, China, Japan, Malaysia, South Korea, and Taiwan also posting losses. Investors were disappointed by US President Donald Trump's speech, which failed to provide clear details on trade talks. Despite some bright spots in tech manufacturing, the region's markets remained volatile, with trading volume reaching 1.51 billion securities in Singapore.

site_title: China moving away from hard lending targets
summary: China's regulators have shifted away from setting lending targets for small businesses, citing a more comprehensive approach to evaluating banks and easing concerns over the country's banking industry. Big five state-owned banks have increased lending to small businesses by 48% in the first nine months, beating an earlier target of 30%. This move aims to alleviate pressure on banks as bad debt levels surge, with regulators considering a plan to urge local banks to merge and local authorities taking a greater role in dealing with troubled lenders.

site_title: Why coffee drinking is up but prices slump
summary: Coffee consumption has increased globally, but trade prices have dropped by 40% over the past three years, negatively impacting producers. Meanwhile, the cost of coffee remains unchanged, with espresso and latte prices remaining full-fat. This disparity suggests a disconnect between the global market and the actual production costs, likely due to market fluctuations and tariffs. The falling prices are attributed to a surplus of coffee beans and increased competition among producers.

site_title: UOB and HSBC use technology to address opaqueness of bonds
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) and HSBC have launched initiatives to address the transparency and efficiency issues in the bond market using technology. UOB uses artificial intelligence (AI), while HSBC employs blockchain. This move aims to increase transparency and efficiency in the fixed-income realm. The efforts follow long-standing issues in the industry, and the use of technology is expected to improve the overall experience for bond investors.

site_title: Singapore firms both winners and losers in yuan's downtrend
summary: Singapore firms are experiencing varying effects from the decline of the Chinese yuan, with some benefiting from the US dollar's appreciation and others facing losses. Companies with a production base in China and sales in USD, such as Hi-P International and Valuetronics, are seeing significant gains due to the yuan's decline. In contrast, companies like Sasseur Reit and CapitaLand Retail China Trust are facing losses due to the decline of the yuan's value against the Singapore dollar. Analysts predict a mixed outlook, with some expecting the yuan to weaken further and others predicting a possible stabilization.

site_title: Swiss franc hits 1-month high vs euro as hedge funds cut bets
summary: The Swiss franc reached a one-month high against the euro, gaining 0.3% to 1.0904 francs per euro, driven by hedge funds unwinding their negative bets and a weakening appetite for risky assets amid Hong Kong unrest. The franc's gains were also boosted by the Swiss central bank's loosened grip on the currency. Meanwhile, the New Zealand dollar surged 1.3% to US$0.6407 after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand kept interest rates on hold. The US dollar remained firm against rivals, and the British pound remained steady around the US$1.2840 line.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust posts lower than forecast DPU of 1.649 US cents for Q3
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) reported lower-than-forecast distributable income (DPU) of 1.649 US cents for Q3, down 1.2% from projected S$14.5 million. Revenue declined 10.6% due to macroeconomic headwinds and a Category 5 hurricane affecting its largest asset in Florida. Despite this, the Reit manager remains "encouraged" by outperformance and market share gains. EHT units closed up 0.5 US cent, and the Reit manager reaffirmed its commitment to the quality and location of its premium branded hotels.

site_title: ComfortDelGro Q3 net profit falls 10.8%
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp reported a 10.8% decline in third-quarter net profit to S$70 million due to unfavorable exchange rates and decreases from existing businesses. Revenue edged up 1.1% to S$979 million, driven by contributions from new acquisitions. Earnings per share fell to 3.23 cents, down from 3.63 cents a year ago. The company attributed the decline to the weakening global economic and political environment, but noted stronger contributions from overseas businesses, particularly in Australia.

site_title: At museums around the world, a focus on food
summary: The Cité Internationale de la Gastronomie de Lyon, a 43,055-square-foot cultural gastronomy centre, has opened in France, aiming to showcase the city's rich gastronomic landscape. The centre, costing 20 million euros, features interactive and sensorial experiences, including traditional Lyonnaise cuisine and a virtual farmers market. It joins a growing trend of museums worldwide focusing on food, exploring its cultural, educational, and sustainability aspects, as seen in exhibitions such as the Museum of Food and Drink and the Disgusting Food Museum.

site_title: Japan's MUFG posts 6.3% fall in H1 net profit as one-time factor peels off
summary: Japan's MUFG reported a 6.3% drop in H1 net profit to 609.9 billion yen, due to a one-time factor peeling off, compared to 650.7 billion yen last year. The bank maintained its full-year profit forecast at 900 billion yen, below analyst estimates. Despite weak domestic lending, MUFG's net operating profit rose 11.1% due to increased trading profit. The bank is focusing on overseas markets, particularly in Asia, and has plans to boost its headcount.

site_title: Billionaires have never had it so good in the present day
summary: The world's billionaires have never had it so good, with many having built their fortunes from scratch and being less feted for exceptional achievement. Billionaires like Bill Gates are under pressure to pay more tax, with Elizabeth Warren proposing a wealth tax. However, UBS argues that billionaires' wealth is driven by their "smart risk-taking, business focus, and determination," and that they have an "obsessive business focus" and "high resilience." The article highlights the "billionaire effect," which includes the superstar effect, security effect, insider effect, and tax effect, which enable billionaires to sustain their riches.

site_title: Euronav picks Linggi Port as supply base for marine fuels
summary: Euronav, a Belgian tanker operator, has signed a service agreement with Malaysia's Linggi Port, making it its supply base for marine fuels, including low-sulphur fuel oil. The deal marks a milestone for Malaysia's bunkering industry, aiming to rival Singapore's largest hub. The agreement covers bunker fuel, crew supply, and provisions for ships on East-of-Suez routes. This move comes ahead of the UN's International Maritime Organization's rule change, requiring a 0.5% sulphur content in fuel, set to take effect in January.

site_title: Condo rents slip in October, HDB rents inch up: SRX
summary: Singapore condo rents declined 0.2% in October from September, but rose 4.2% year-over-year, while HDB rents edged up 0.3% and 1.4% year-over-year. The core central region saw the largest decline, while HDB rentals increased in all regions. The decline in rental volume for condos has been ongoing for three consecutive months, attributed to seasonal factors and weakening employment outlook. However, some multinational corporations may redeploy employees to Singapore, potentially supporting the private rental market.

site_title: India's headline inflation breaches central bank's threshold
summary: India's retail inflation rose 4.62% in October, exceeding the Reserve Bank of India's 4% target and potentially slowing monetary policy easing. Food and beverage prices surged 6.93%, driven by a 26% increase in vegetable prices. Despite interest rate cuts, the above inflation print may limit the RBI's ability to make further cuts, with Governor Shaktikanta Das indicating the accommodative stance will continue as long as necessary to revive growth.

site_title: Fund managers bullish, and 'melt up' possibility cited if US and China forge deal
summary: Global fund managers are increasingly bullish on markets, with a majority expecting Wall Street to rise if the US and China forge a trade deal. However, they also warn of volatility due to unpredictable elections and geopolitical events. Market strategists predict a possible "melt up" in the final stage of a bull market, while others foresee a recession. The US dollar is expected to depreciate, fueling a rise in US exports and commodities, with equities and commodities seen as top performers in 2020.

site_title: High fashion goes sustainable
summary: The fashion industry has made significant strides in sustainability, with over 150 luxury brands, including Hermès, signing the Fashion Pact. Hermès has been using reclaimed materials to create eco-friendly accessories since 2010. The brand's Petit h exhibition features whimsical gifts made from unused fabric, leather, and ceramics. Meanwhile, a pop-up retail event in Singapore, Boutique Fairs, supports local artisans and sustainable shopping. The article also highlights the growing importance of sustainable dining, with chefs and restaurateurs sourcing top-quality ingredients from China.

site_title: CapitaLand's Bridge+ to set up fintech hub in Singapore's CBD
summary: CapitaLand's Bridge+ will establish a fintech hub in Singapore's CBD, supporting the growth of fintech players and "enlivening the community" with its 56,000 sq ft development in the 29-storey office building at 79 Robinson Road. The hub is set to open in the third quarter of next year, enhancing the central business district's financial ecosystem.

site_title: Primary dealers remain key for European govt bond sales, debt officials say
summary: European government bond auctions remain reliant on primary dealers, despite tougher regulation since the financial crisis, according to debt agency chiefs. The role of banks as primary dealers has stabilized, with measures introduced in the UK increasing commercial viability. The number of primary dealers has decreased in recent years, mainly due to falling bond market turnover. Debt officials emphasize the importance of primary dealers, citing them as fundamental to government bond sales. Measures to support primary dealers, such as adjusting auction structures, have been successful in maintaining stability.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Malaysian property developer Hatten Land reported a 54.6% surge in revenue to RM83 million in Q1, with a net profit of RM2.6 million. Boustead Projects saw a 39% drop in net profit to S$4.9 million due to intense competition and margin pressures. Accordia Golf Trust's distribution per unit (DPU) soared 54.5% to 2.07 yen, with a 29% rise in H1 net profit to 3.5 billion yen. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's Q3 net profit slid 10% to 702.3 million yuan amid weak market conditions.

site_title: A clamour for equality - and democracy
summary: A wave of protests and demands for equality and democracy have swept across Latin America, sparking a shift away from neoliberalism and towards a more responsive welfare state. The "pink tide" of leftist leaders that dominated the region in the early 2000s is receding, with many countries experiencing economic crises and corruption scandals. Protests over voter fraud and electoral tampering have forced leaders out of office, and a new swing to the left is underway. However, the leeway for economic change is narrow, and everyday Latin Americans expect more from their governments, with a focus on reducing inequality and improving public services.

site_title: BT readers younger, more affluent and engaged
summary: The Business Times (BT) has a stable, high-quality readership with professionals and managers accounting for 78% of its readership, an increase from 72% in 2018. Eight in 10 readers have a monthly household income of more than S$7,000, and 67% of affluent readers attend events advertised in the paper. The paper's digital readership among affluent readers has risen for five consecutive years, with a median age of 36 years old and a majority of readers in their 30s and 40s.

site_title: SGX watch list: Is it fair to penalise firms that fall short only on market cap?
summary: A-Sonic Aerospace, listed on the Singapore Exchange, is under scrutiny for being on the watch list despite being profitable and meeting minimum trading price criteria. The company's low trading liquidity hinders its ability to boost its stock price to meet the minimum stipulated market capitalisation of S$40 million, despite having a net attributable profit of US$1.51 million and net tangible assets of US$28.57 million. The SGX watch list aims to promote investor confidence, but the question arises whether companies meeting profitability and valuation criteria should be penalized for something beyond their control.

site_title: Brexit Party's Farage will stand down no more candidates
summary: Nigel Farage, leader of the Brexit Party, announced he will no longer withdraw Conservative candidates from 317 seats, instead opting to contest seats held by Labour and other remainer parties. Farage stated his goal is to challenge those who support the Remain side in the upcoming election.

images.alt_text: Brexit Party leader Nigel Farage said he would stand down no more candidates beyond the 317 Conservative seats his party has already withdrawn from.

site_title: SembMarine's Q3 loss deepens, stock skids 4%
summary: SembCorp Marine reported a wider-than-expected loss of S$53 million in the third quarter, down from a S$30 million loss in the same period last year. The company's revenue fell 39% to S$717 million, and its stock price dropped 4% to S$1.29. Analysts attribute the poor performance to additional costs for rigs and floater projects, as well as persistently low business activity. SembMarine expects the trend of losses to continue into the final quarter and full-year losses to be higher than last year.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust posts Q3 DPU of 1.649 US cents
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) reported a Q3 distributable income (DI) of US$14.4 million, down 1.2% from projections. The distribution per unit (DPU) was 1.649 US cents, 1.3% lower than forecast. Lower revenue, primarily due to a Category 5 hurricane in Florida, contributed to the decrease. Despite this, the Reit manager remains optimistic about the portfolio's outperformance and market share gains.

site_title: Paris e-scooters under pressure to prove their green credentials
summary: Paris is re-evaluating its e-scooter program due to concerns over their environmental impact. Despite claims that they reduce carbon emissions, studies show that the production and maintenance of e-scooters emit significant amounts of pollution. The devices' short lifespans and daily charging requirements also contribute to their overall environmental harm. In response, the city will limit the number of e-scooter operators allowed on the streets, with Lime, a popular e-scooter company, hoping to be one of the few allowed to continue operating.

site_title: Fed's Powell expects 'sustained expansion' of US economy
summary: Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell stated that the US economy is likely to continue growing, with a strong labor market and inflation near 2%. However, the economy faces risks from the global slowdown and trade disputes. Despite cutting interest rates three times this year, Powell believes the central bank will maintain its stance. Powell's comments come amid concerns about China's slowing GDP growth and its impact on global markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 12.51 points to 1,597.22. Volume reached 2.1 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 585 to 291, indicating a bearish market trend.

site_title: PropNex Q3 profit down 15.2% at S$6.1m
summary: PropNex, a Singapore-based real estate agency, reported a 15.2% decline in net profit to S$6.1 million in Q3 2019, due to lower commission income and higher staff costs. Revenue slipped 1.3% to S$122.5 million, with a significant increase in project marketing services. The company expects sales activities to continue, with an estimated 18,000 transactions for the year, a 18.7% decline from 2018.

site_title: Alibaba launches US$13.4b Hong Kong listing to fund expansion
summary: Alibaba Group launched a share sale worth up to $13.4 billion in Hong Kong to fund expansion plans, despite ongoing unrest in the global financial hub. The sale aims to raise funds for investments in online delivery and travel platforms, as well as video streaming service Youku. The company's Hong Kong shares are expected to be priced at a discount of up to 5% of the US equivalent, with trading set to begin around November 25.

images.alt_text: Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group launched the share sale for its Hong Kong listing on Wednesday, braving unrest in the global financial hub to try to raise up to US$13.4 billion to fund its expansion plans.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on trade worries, Hong Kong unrest
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday due to President Trump's threat to raise tariffs on China unless a trade deal is struck. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 69.45 points, the S&P 500 dropped 7.66 points, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 31.07 points. The Hong Kong unrest also contributed to the market's decline, with investors uncertain about the impact of the US-China trade tensions and the ongoing protests in Hong Kong.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance posts 35.7% fall in Q3 net profit to S$23.6m
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 35.7% decline in its third-quarter net profit to S$23.6 million, down from S$36.7 million in the same period last year. Interest income rose 14.3% to S$102.4 million, while interest expense increased 46% to S$51 million. The net interest margin declined by 21 basis points. Earnings per share fell to 21.12 cents, down from 32.9 cents in the previous year.

site_title: Singapore's EDBI gives financial solutions firm Pico's regional push a leg up
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board Investment (EDBI) has invested in financial solutions provider Pico, providing financial solutions for the company's regional push. Pico will leverage EDBI's expertise and knowledge of Asian and Singaporean operating environments to expand its Asia-Pacific presence. The firm plans to add 20 more data centers and double its APAC headcount to 80 employees over the next 18 months. EDBI's investment and partnership with Pico aim to strengthen Singapore's position as a leading global financial center, particularly in promoting investment in new technology innovations such as blockchain.

site_title: China lowers capital ratio requirement for some infrastructure projects
summary: China has lowered the minimum capital ratio requirement for some infrastructure projects, including ports and highways, to 20% and 5% respectively. This move aims to "reasonably expand effective investment" and boost economic growth. The change, announced at a Cabinet meeting chaired by Premier Li Keqiang, also allows for up to 50% of the minimum capital investment to be raised through equity financing. The move comes as China's fixed asset investment grew 5.4% from January-September, slowing from the previous month.

site_title: US consumer prices increase more than expected in October
summary: US consumer prices increased 0.4% in October, the largest gain since March, driven by higher energy, healthcare, and food costs. The core CPI, excluding volatile components, rose 0.2%. This stronger-than-expected reading and jump in healthcare costs suggest a potential pick-up in the core PCE price index. The Federal Reserve's decision to pause interest rate cuts is supported by stable inflation, better-than-expected job growth, and a de-escalation of trade tensions.

images.alt_text: US consumer prices rebounded more than expected in October and underlying inflation picked up, which together with abating trade tensions and fears of a recession, support the Federal Reserve's signal for no further interest rate cuts in the near term.

site_title: Tuan Sing Q3 earnings slump 95% on revenue drop, higher finance costs
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings' Q3 net profit plummeted 95% to S$206,000 due to a 29% drop in revenue to S$67 million, primarily from industrial services and property segments. Finance costs rose 22% to S$13.1 million, mainly due to higher interest expense. For the nine months, net profit fell 88% to S$1.8 million, and revenue decreased 14% to S$218.4 million. No dividend was declared for the period.

site_title: House begins Trump impeachment inquiry hearings
summary: The US House of Representatives has begun televised public hearings for the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump, marking a new phase in the investigation. Three diplomats, William Taylor and George Kent, will testify about Trump's dealings with Ukraine, including a July 25 phone call that Trump asked Ukraine's president to investigate Joe Biden and his son. The hearings may pave the way for the House to approve articles of impeachment, leading to a trial in the Senate on whether to convict Trump and remove him from office. The impeachment process has raised concerns about the future of Trump's presidency and the country's electoral landscape.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust H1 DPU soars 54.5% to record high of 2.07 yen
summary: Accordia Golf Trust reported a 54.5% increase in its half-year distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.07 yen, the highest since its listing in 2014. The trust's net profit rose 29% to 3.5 billion yen, driven by improved performance at its golf courses. Revenue increased 3.6% to 27.2 billion yen, and the number of players increased by 8.5%. The trust's DPU of 2.61 Singapore cents will be paid out on December 18.

site_title: Salt Bae backers seeking partner and US$1b valuation: sources
summary: Turkish billionaire Ferit Sahenk and co-founders Nusret Gokce and Mithat Erdem are considering selling a stake in Nusr-Et steakhouse, valued at up to $1 billion. The owners, who hold a combined 49% stake, may sell to international investors. Dogus Holding, Sahenk's company, has been restructuring debt and selling stakes in hotels and restaurants, with potential disposals worth up to $1.2 billion. A financial adviser is assessing potential bids, and a potential initial public offering in London is also being considered.

site_title: Yangzijiang Q3 net profit falls 10% amid fewer orders
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's third-quarter net profit fell 10% to 702.3 million yuan due to a weak market and lower orders. Global new shipbuilding orders declined 44% in the first nine months of 2019, amid trade and economic uncertainty and the IMO 2020 emission rules. The company secured 15 new vessel contracts this year, versus 36 in 2018, and delivered 13 vessels in Q3. Gross profit margin worsened to 14% due to higher raw material and labor costs.

site_title: European steel leaders seek scrutiny of Chinese British Steel bid
summary: European steel lobby Eurofer plans to scrutinize Chinese group Jingye's proposed £1.2 billion purchase of British Steel, citing concerns over fair competition and potential state aid. The deal, if finalized, would be the latest instance of China exporting excess steel capacity to the EU. Eurofer director general Axel Eggert stated that China's surplus steel accounts for two-thirds of global excess, weighing on the sector and complicating the sale. The deal's regulatory approval is pending, with the European Commission and British government yet to comment.

site_title: Temasek launches 12-year and 30-year euro bond offering
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state investment firm, is launching a dual-tranche euro bond offering consisting of a 12-year and 30-year bond. This is Temasek's first euro-bond sale in almost four years, as low borrowing costs draw more Asian issuers to Europe. The bonds will be unconditionally guaranteed by Temasek and will be offered outside the US to non-US persons. The net proceeds will fund Temasek's ordinary course of business. The offering is backed by a US$20 billion guaranteed global medium-term note programme, which has been assigned an "Aaa" rating by Moody's and "AAA" by S&P.

images.alt_text: Singapore state investment firm Temasek Holdings said its wholly-owned subsidiary would launch a dual tranche offering of euro bonds on Wednesday.

site_title: Signs mount that Qatar embargo may end as mediation gears up
summary: Qatar and a Saudi-led bloc may end the 2017 embargo as mediation efforts gain momentum, with a soccer tournament in Doha set to pave the way for a breakthrough. Saudi Arabia, the UAE, and Bahrain have agreed to participate in the tournament, and Qatar has started repairing relations with its neighbors. The developments signal an easing of tensions, with the UAE pulling out troops from Yemen and Saudi Arabia preparing for a major oil sale. A possible resolution could be a result of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's efforts to resolve conflicts and stabilize the kingdom's political situation.

site_title: ComfortDelGro posts 10.8% fall in Q3 net profit to S$70m
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp's Q3 net profit fell 10.8% to S$70 million due to unfavorable exchange rates and decreases from existing businesses. Revenue edged up 1.1% to S$979 million, driven by contributions from new acquisitions. Earnings per share dropped to 3.23 cents from 3.63 cents a year ago. The company attributed the decline to a weakening global economic and political environment, but noted stronger growth from its overseas businesses, particularly in Australia.

site_title: Asean M&A appetite stable despite uncertainty: EY survey
summary: The EY Global Capital Confidence Barometer found Southeast Asia's merger and acquisition (M&A) appetite stable despite global uncertainty. 41% of respondents had acquisition plans in the next 12 months, below the global average but near the 10-year historical average. Experts warn Southeast Asian firms to take the slowdown and trade tensions seriously, seizing opportunities to restructure and reduce costs while maintaining strong balance sheets.

site_title: Europe: Stocks move lower at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened lower on Wednesday, following Asian exchanges affected by Hong Kong violence and US-China trade talks. London's FTSE 100, Frankfurt's DAX 30, and Paris' CAC 40 all declined, with the FTSE 100 down 0.5% to 7,331.75 points. The decline follows Asian markets, which were also impacted by the ongoing US-China trade tensions and the Hong Kong protests.

site_title: Singapore shares skid 0.9% on HK violence, Trump disappointment
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.9% to 3,239.22 on Wednesday, following the US President's disappointing speech on trade policy and the escalating violence in Hong Kong. The Hang Seng Index dropped 1.8% to 26,571.46, with other Asia-Pacific markets also posting significant losses. Local stocks with exposure to Hong Kong, such as Jardine quartet and Reit MNACT, saw substantial sell-offs. Trading volume and turnover were higher than the daily average, with 1.51 billion securities traded and S$1.14 billion in total turnover.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as investors await Fed remarks
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on November 13, 2019, as investors awaited remarks from the US Federal Reserve chief and key Chinese data. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.85% to 23,319.87, while the Topix index dropped 0.55% to 1,700.33. Cautious investors were watching for potential market movements after the US Federal Reserve's comments.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) co-created a framework with the financial sector to promote responsible AI and data analytics adoption. MAS will restart its e-KYC project and Temasek will issue 12-year and 30-year euro bonds. Razer is exploring a Singapore digital banking licence. The STI fell 0.9% due to Hong Kong violence and Trump's disappointment. Internationally, Vietnam reacted to Trump's tariff announcement, the Asian garment industry braces for higher US tariffs, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will be working with financial industry partners on an initiative known as Veritas - a framework for financial institutions to promote the responsible adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) and data analytics.

site_title: AEI Corp's share price jumps 21%, prompting SGX query
summary: AEI Corp's share price surged 21% in the last half-hour of trading on November 13, 2019, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The stock closed at S$0.88, with over one million shares changing hands. AEI Corporation attributed the trading to the sale of its business, stating it was unaware of any unannounced information. The unusual price movement raised questions about the company's sale process.

site_title: ESG expands GIA network, launches new innovation platform with IMDA
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) has expanded its Global Innovation Alliance (GIA) network to London, partnering with IoT Tribe to enable two-way exchange of companies between Singapore and the UK. ESG also launched the Open Innovation Network (OIN) with the Info-Communications Media Development Authority (IMDA), featuring open innovation challenges from corporates and government agencies. The move aims to promote open innovation and provide startups and SMEs with access to new markets, partnerships, and talent.

site_title: Japan's Fast Retailing enlists robotics startups to automate warehouses
summary: Japanese fashion group Fast Retailing, owner of Uniqlo, has partnered robotics startups Mujin Electronics and Exotec Solutions to automate its warehouses. The move is part of a 100 billion yen investment to increase automation globally. The partnerships aim to improve efficiency in picking and shipping processes. This follows Fast Retailing's previous commitment to increase automation at its facilities, highlighting the company's efforts to enhance operational efficiency through technology.

site_title: Olam posts 1.5% dip in Q3 net profit to S$20.4m
summary: Olam International, a major agri and food giant, reported a 1.5% dip in Q3 net profit to S$20.4 million, primarily due to higher finance costs and depreciation. Excluding exceptional losses, net profit would have grown 30.4% to S$27 million. Revenue increased 0.2% to S$8.3 billion, with the edible nut and spices segment experiencing growth, while the confectionery and beverage ingredients segment declined due to lower coffee prices. The company maintained a robust balance sheet and is well-positioned for the rest of 2019.

site_title: Crypto data tracker eyes fighting fake trading volume
summary: CoinMarketCap, a leading cryptocurrency data tracker, has launched a new "Liquidity" metric to combat fake trading volume. The metric averages order sizes and distance from the mid price over 24 hours, providing a more accurate representation of real trading activity. The new metric aims to reduce the impact of artificially inflated volume figures, which are common in the industry. By using this methodology, CoinMarketCap hopes to better identify the most liquid markets for its 3,000+ listed crypto assets. This move is seen as a step to increase transparency and credibility in the cryptocurrency market.

site_title: The Arcade up again for collective sale with S$780m asking price
summary: The owners of The Arcade in Collyer Quay are offering a collective sale with a price tag of S$780 million, 10% lower than the 2014 attempt. The 20-storey building, comprising 127 units, is estimated to generate between S$700,000 and S$29.9 million per owner. The site, with a 999-year land tenure, could be redeveloped into an integrated development, including a hotel, residential units, office, and retail space, under the Draft Master Plan 2019. The sale will close on January 8, 2020.

site_title: Japan's largest lender MUFG posts 6.3% fall in H1 net profit
summary: MUFG, Japan's largest lender, reported a 6.3% drop in H1 net profit to ¥609.9 billion, compared to ¥650.7 billion in the same period last year. The decline was attributed to the release of bad loan provisions. Despite the drop, MUFG maintained its profit forecast for FY 2023-2024 at ¥900 billion, below analyst estimates. The company's net operating profit rose 11.1% due to increased trading profit.

images.alt_text: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) reported on Wednesday a 6.3 per cent drop in net profit for the six months through September, as its profit in the same period of last year was buoyed by the release of bad loan provisions.

site_title: PBOC wants 'controllable anonymity' in China's digital currency
summary: China's People's Bank of China (PBOC) aims to introduce a digital version of the yuan, balancing functionality with concerns about anonymity. Director-general Mu Changchun stated that the goal is "controllable anonymity" for transactions, allowing for anti-money-laundering actions and combating terrorism financing while maintaining user anonymity. The digital currency would be accessed through a mobile wallet, similar to an ATM, and is not currently targeted at capital markets or trade-financing centers.

site_title: Hong Kong to shut all schools on Thursday for safety reasons
summary: Hong Kong will suspend classes on Thursday due to transportation and safety concerns amid escalating violence from anti-government protests. The protests, which have paralyzed parts of the city for a third day, have seen protesters block roads, clash with police, and engage in vandalism. The Hong Kong Education Bureau made the announcement, urging protestors to stop violent acts. The situation remains tense, with protesters planning demonstrations across the harbour and police investigating incidents of violence.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB downgrades Singapore Medical Group to 'neutral'
summary: RHB Research Institute downgraded Catalist-listed Singapore Medical Group (SMG) to "neutral" with a target price of S$0.36 due to a lack of near-term catalysts and tepid earnings growth. SMG's shares fell 3.1% to 31.5 cents after the downgrade. Despite organic revenue growth and plans to add specialists, near-term profitability growth is expected to be limited by higher costs. RHB lowered its revenue forecasts for FY2020 and FY2021 by 11% and earnings forecasts by 4% and 5%, respectively.

site_title: Property tech startup Smarten Spaces raises US$12m from Hong Kong's Symphony
summary: Smarten Spaces, a Singapore-based property tech startup, has raised US$12 million in Series A funding from Hong Kong's Symphony International Holdings. The funding will accelerate expansion across Asia-Pacific and North America. Smarten Spaces offers a digital platform for space management, utilizing artificial intelligence to improve productivity and operational efficiency. With a projected global smart space industry value of US$19.9 billion by 2024, the startup aims to eliminate inefficiencies in the industry. This investment will provide "synergistic opportunities" as Smarten Spaces expands geographically, driven by Symphony's portfolio of investments in real estate and consumer brands.

site_title: Temasek to sell 12-year, 30-year euro bonds
summary: Temasek Holdings' subsidiary, Temasek Financial (I) Limited, will launch a dual-tranche offering of euro bonds, including a 12-year and 30-year bond, under its US$20 billion guaranteed global medium-term note programme. This is Temasek's first euro-bond sale in nearly four years, driven by low borrowing costs. The bonds will be offered outside the US to non-US persons and will be listed on the Singapore Exchange. Net proceeds will fund Temasek and its investment holding companies' ordinary business activities.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop on US-China trade talk uncertainty; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.8% on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 6,698.30, amid uncertainty over US-China trade talks. US President Donald Trump offered no new details on a phase one trade deal, sparking concerns of a potential tariff increase. This led to losses in the metals and mining sub-index, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto falling 0.8% and 1.7%, respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.8%.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks slide on trade deal concerns, Hong Kong unrest
summary: South Korea's stocks slid 0.86% on Wednesday as investors lost hope for a Sino-US trade deal, despite President Donald Trump's promise to complete an initial trade deal with China "soon." The KOSPI index fell to its lowest since November 4, with foreigners selling $24.03 million worth of shares. Meanwhile, unrest in Hong Kong also affected the market. The KOSPI has risen 3.99% this year, but the drop was attributed to Trump's speech failing to meet market expectations.

site_title: OUE C-Reit posts 44% rise in Q3 DPU to 0.79 S cent
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) reported a 44% increase in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.79 Singapore cents, driven by gains from its merger with OUE Hospitality Trust in September. Total income available for distribution rose 85.9% to S$29.5 million, and net property income increased 54.8% to S$50.1 million, mainly due to the inclusion of OUE Downtown Office and Mandarin Gallery.

site_title: MAS to reboot e-KYC project
summary: MAS will reboot its failed electronic know-your-customer (e-KYC) project, aiming for a more efficient way to check against sanctions and blacklists. The project was initially proposed in 2017 but was deemed too expensive to implement in 2018. This time, MAS will use a "less costly" technology architecture. The reboot comes as the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) establishes an innovation hub in Singapore, focusing on public digital infrastructures and supervisory tech solutions to support the digital economy.

site_title: CapitaLand's Bridge+ to set up fintech hub in Singapore's CBD
summary: CapitaLand's Bridge+ will establish a fintech hub in Singapore's central business district (CBD) at 79 Robinson Road, set to open in the third quarter of 2024. The hub will facilitate collaborations and knowledge sharing among fintech players, with agreements in place with key players such as the Asean Financial Innovation Network and the Singapore FinTech Association. The development will offer a range of workspace solutions and provide a platform for the international fintech community to connect with local partners through seminars and events.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks sink as violent unrest hits city
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.82% due to violent unrest, with the Hang Seng index sinking to 26,571.46. The demonstrations, entering a more violent phase, have raised concerns about the city's safety and ease of doing business. The China-US trade war and economic disruption have also impacted the local economy, which fell into recession for the first time in 10 years. Regulators' approval of Alibaba's $15 billion share sale may be affected, and investors are wary of a resolution to the protests.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon down 0.64% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.64% on Wednesday, closing at 3,246.92 points, as Asian markets remained in negative territory due to US-China trade war uncertainty. Decliners outnumbered advancers 206 to 131, with banking stocks, such as DBS and UOB, losing 0.7-0.8% each. The slump was also attributed to news of extensive damage at Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust's Festival Walk property in Hong Kong.

site_title: New Zealand keeps interest rates unchanged, dashing easing expectations
summary: New Zealand's central bank kept interest rates unchanged, defying market expectations for a cut. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) cited subdued economic growth and a low interest rate as reasons to maintain current policy settings, but left room for further monetary stimulus. The decision boosted the New Zealand dollar, and economists expressed differing views on the bank's assessment of the economy, with some predicting a rate cut in early 2026.

site_title: China Sinopec plans 100-barge fleet to ship cleaner marine fuel: source
summary: China's Sinopec Corp plans to build a 100-barge fleet to supply very low sulphur fuel oil (VLSFO) to meet the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) 2020 emission standards. The fleet will include 50 new vessels and 50 smaller barges, with a total cost of around $776.5 million. Sinopec aims to become a top regional supplier of VLSFO and has designated 10 subsidiary refineries to produce the fuel. The company hopes the fleet will help it meet its goal of supplying 10 million tonnes of IMO-compliant fuel next year and 15 million tonnes in 2023.

site_title: Asia: Markets hit by trade uncertainty, Hong Kong tanks again
summary: Asian markets declined on Wednesday due to uncertainty over China trade talks, with US President Donald Trump's speech failing to provide reassurance. Trump warned that tariffs would increase if a deal is not reached, despite saying a phase one trade deal could happen soon. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index plummeted over 2% as protests turned violent, and the yuan dropped below 7.00 per dollar. The US dollar rallied against the yen after the New Zealand central bank held off cutting interest rates, offering a glimmer of hope for investors.

site_title: US Democrats announce eight more witnesses for public impeachment hearings
summary: US Democrats have announced eight more witnesses for public impeachment hearings into President Donald Trump, following previous closed-door hearings. The witnesses will testify in open hearings regarding allegations that Trump pressured Ukraine to supply damaging information on rival Democrats and possible 2020 presidential election challenger Joe Biden.

site_title: Razer still 'exploring' Singapore digibank route: CEO
