summary: Razer CEO Tan Min-Liang confirmed that the company is still exploring a digital banking license in Singapore. Razer processes billions of dollars in gaming credits yearly, serving 80 million global gamers. The company aims to provide more regulated financial services, including digital banking, to cater to its young and underserved market. With digital banking applicants having six weeks left to submit to the Singapore regulator, Razer is evaluating its options for expanding into the sector.

images.alt_text: Gaming accessories firm Razer Inc is still "exploring" ways to provide more regulated financial services via its fintech arm, including a digital banking licence in Singapore, said its CEO Tan Min-Liang.

site_title: Hatten Land Q1 profit jumps to RM2.6m; to hold AGM on Nov 23
summary: Malaysian property developer Hatten Land reported a 1Q net profit of RM2.6 million, more than six times its previous year's net profit of RM424,000. Revenue surged 54.6% to RM83 million, driven by higher earnings from projects Harbour City and Satori. The company will hold its AGM on November 23.

site_title: One dead after suspected suicide bombing in Indonesia
summary: A suspected suicide bombing outside a police station in Medan, Indonesia, killed at least one attacker and injured at least one police officer. The bombing occurred at 8:45am local time and was reportedly perpetrated by at least two individuals. Indonesia has struggled with Islamist militancy, with police stations being frequent targets. The attack comes after a similar incident in August when authorities shot and arrested a suspected militant in Surabaya.

images.alt_text: The explosion happened around 8.45am local time (0145 GMT) at a police compound in Medan on Sumatra island.

site_title: Mainland students fleeing Hong Kong campus standoff with China's help
summary: Mainland Chinese students studying in Hong Kong are fleeing the Chinese University of Hong Kong due to the ongoing protests, which have turned the campus into a battleground. Students, including 19-year-old Leo Lin, are being helped by Chinese nationals and China's Communist Youth League, and are offered free accommodation in Shenzhen. The protests, sparked by opposition to a government bill allowing extraditions to mainland China, have expanded to include calls for greater democracy and an independent inquiry into police tactics.

site_title: HSBC to explore using distributed ledger technology in Asia's bond markets
summary: HSBC is set to trial the use of distributed ledger technology (DLT) in Asia's bond markets, in collaboration with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Temasek. The initiative aims to streamline bond issuance and servicing processes, reducing costs for issuers, investors, and custodians. The trial will utilize tokenized securities and smart contracts on a permissioned ledger to enhance information exchange and tracking of bonds throughout their life cycle. The move is the first end-to-end digitalization initiative focusing on Asia's bond markets, addressing inefficiencies in the fixed income market.

site_title: China holding third Taiwanese man on security grounds: state media
summary: China is investigating the disappearance of a third Taiwanese man, Shih Cheng-ping, on suspicion of national security activities. He, along with two other Taiwanese residents, Tsai Chin-shu and Lee Meng-chu, are being held by Chinese authorities. The cases come amid tense relations between China and Taiwan, with Beijing viewing the island as part of its territory awaiting reunification. Chinese officials claim they are handling the cases strictly according to the law.

images.alt_text: Beijing is investigating a Taiwanese man on suspicion of engaging in activities that endanger national security, Chinese state media reported ON Wednesday - the third such case to come to light in three months.

site_title: Hong Kong banks tell staff: cancel meetings, watch family, be safe
summary: Hong Kong banks have issued safety memos to employees, urging them to cancel meetings and consider working from home due to escalating violence and protests. Banks such as HSBC, BNP Paribas, and JPMorgan Chase have reminded staff to prioritize their safety and flexibility, with some offices located near protest sites. The memos also advise staff to check travel plans and remain vigilant while commuting. The situation has led to school closures and traffic disruptions, making it challenging for bankers and traders to get to work.

images.alt_text: Safety memos have become a part of daily life at big banks in Hong Kong but the latest edition are expressing an even higher level of caution as violence escalates, sometimes on streets directly outside office doors.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tumble at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.12% at the open on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index falling to 26,761.16, amidst ongoing violent protests that have crippled the city. Fears of further unrest and its impact on the economy have led to the market's downturn.

site_title: The coffee conundrum: consumption is up but trade prices are low
summary: Global coffee consumption has increased by 2.1% a year for the past decade, but trade prices have fallen 40% since 2017 due to bumper harvests in Brazil, the world's main coffee producer. This has created "real structural problems" for producers, who are struggling to support themselves, invest in production, and prepare for climate change. High-quality demand protects prices for certain varieties and regions, but the majority of producers are vulnerable to prices fixed by traders. The supply chain's long length means that trade prices are only about 10% of the cost of an espresso or latte.

site_title: MAS co-creates framework with financial sector for responsible use of AI
summary: MAS co-creates framework with financial sector for responsible AI adoption. The Veritas framework, announced by Deputy PM Heng Swee Keat, promotes fairness, ethics, accountability, and transparency in AI and data analytics. The framework will evaluate financial institutions' AI solutions against these principles, strengthening internal governance and use of data. The initiative aims to build a progressive and trusted environment for AI adoption in the financial sector, with a focus on customer marketing, risk scoring, and fraud detection. A report on the findings and conclusions will be produced in the second half of 2020.

site_title: Condo rents slip in October as demand shrinks; HDB rents inch up: SRX
summary: Singapore condo rents declined 0.2% in October, while HDB rents rose 0.3% from September. Condo rents are still 16.9% below their peak in January 2013, and 4.2% higher year-on-year. HDB rents rose 1.4% year-on-year, with all room types posting increases except for executive rents. Rental volumes for condos declined 0.8% from September, while HDB flats decreased 4.3% from the previous month. Experts attribute the decline in rental demand to seasonal factors and weakening employment outlook.

site_title: Singapore unveils new strategy aimed at developing AI ecosystem
summary: Singapore has unveiled its National AI Strategy (NAIS), committing over S$500 million to develop and use AI in key sectors such as transport, healthcare, and education. The strategy aims to create social and economic value through increased productivity and quality of public goods. Five key sectors will be focused on, with a focus on building a holistic AI ecosystem through partnerships, education, and data sharing. A National AI Office was set up to work on AI priorities, and investments will be made in AI-related R&D and digital infrastructure.

site_title: KrisEnergy inks letter of award for Cambodia oil platform fabrication
summary: KrisEnergy, a Houston-based oil firm, has signed a conditional letter of award with PT Profab, an Indonesian subsidiary of National Oilwell Varco, for the fabrication of a minimum facilities wellhead platform (mini-platform) for its Apsara oil field in Cambodia. The mini-platform, worth an undisclosed amount, will be built at PT Profab's facility on Batam Island, Indonesia, and is expected to be completed by the first half of 2020, with a peak production rate of 7,500 barrels of oil per day. This development phase is part of KrisEnergy's efforts to mitigate risk and collect critical data for future phases.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge lower on trade uncertainties; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.2% on Wednesday due to uncertainty over the Sino-US trade deal, with mining stocks dragging the index lower. Index heavyweights BHP Group and Rio Tinto fell 0.7% and 1.5%, respectively. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4% as the country's central bank left interest rates unchanged.

site_title: Alibaba-backed EV startup XPeng says raises US$400m for growth
summary: Chinese electric vehicle manufacturer XPeng, backed by Alibaba Group, has raised $400 million from investors including Xiaomi Corp to fund its growth. The fundraising values the five-year-old firm at nearly $4 billion, higher than its previous valuation. The funds will be used for research and development, mass production, branding, and expanding its retail network. XPeng is one of several Chinese startups competing with global leaders like Tesla in the rapidly changing EV market, which faces challenges due to government subsidy cuts and increased competition.

site_title: Bloomberg calls for Trump defeat, takes new step toward 2020 run
summary: Billionaire Michael Bloomberg has officially filed to join the Democratic presidential race, calling for President Donald Trump's defeat in 2020. Bloomberg, a 77-year-old former New York mayor, has filed in Arkansas and Alabama, both with early deadlines. He stated, "We must defeat Trump. He has failed us at every turn." Bloomberg's move comes as the 2020 presidential election approaches.

site_title: Chinese takeover marks new chapter in history of British Steel
summary: A Chinese company, Jingye, has acquired British Steel in a £1.2 billion deal, marking a new chapter in the UK's steelmaking history. The takeover is expected to bring a sustainable future for the industry, with Jingye promising to invest in the company. The move is seen as a breath of fresh air for British Steel's 4,000 employees, but concerns remain about the long-term viability of the business. The takeover follows a series of crises in the UK steel industry, including nationalisation, privatisation, and recurring losses.

site_title: Making ride-hailing safer is going to cost you
summary: A ride-hailing company, Didi Chuxing, plans to relaunch its carpooling service, Hitch, in China after a "comprehensive safety review and product revamp." The service will be limited to shorter trips and restricted to women's rides during specific hours, but critics argue that these measures are insufficient. The industry needs to rethink the tradeoff between safety and cost, and companies should consider raising the barriers to entry to hire fewer, better drivers. Governments should also step in to regulate the industry and ensure safer rides.

site_title: Australia's wage drought suggest more stimulus needed to flare economic growth
summary: Australia's wage growth slowed to 0.5% in the September quarter, down from 0.6% in the June quarter, and 2.2% from a year ago, disappointing expectations and suggesting more policy stimulus is needed to boost the economy. This slow growth has weighed on household consumption and has become a key uncertainty for the domestic outlook. The Reserve Bank of Australia has already slashed its benchmark rate to a record low of 0.75% and may consider further measures, including quantitative easing, to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.34% to 23,438.94. Investors awaited the US Federal Reserve chief's speech and key Chinese data later in the week. The broader Topix index also declined 0.16%.

site_title: Hot stock: SembMarine down 3% after reporting deeper Q3 loss; OCBC downgrade
summary: SEMBCORP Marine (SembMarine) shares dropped 3% after reporting a deeper Q3 loss of S$52.6 million, missing street estimates. Revenue fell 38.6% to S$717.2 million due to lower project recognition. OCBC Investment Research downgraded its recommendation to "sell" and lowered the fair value estimate to S$1.24. The company expects losses to continue into Q4 and a higher full-year loss than last year. Challenges in the offshore and marine sector persist, with intense competition.

site_title: Google healthcare data move makes some quesy
summary: Google has defended its "Nightingale" project, which aims to modernize healthcare by accessing medical data of millions of people. The project, revealed in a blog post, involves moving data and analytics to a private, secure cloud hosted by Google. The US Office for Civil Rights has launched an inquiry to ensure compliance with laws regarding patient data privacy. Google assures that all data will be kept private and secure, and will not be combined with consumer data. The project is part of Google's efforts to compete in the healthcare market, with analysts calling it a "shame" that the project is being met with distrust.

images.alt_text: Google on Tuesday defended a project aimed at modernising healthcare while giving it access to medical data of millions of people.

site_title: Seoul-Tokyo row risks sending 'wrong message': USFK chief
summary: Seoul and Tokyo's deteriorating relationship risks sending a "wrong message" to adversaries, USFK Chief General Robert Abrams said ahead of the expiration of their military intelligence sharing pact, GSOMIA. The deal's termination, set to occur on November 22, has raised concerns about stability and security in the region. Abrams warned that without the pact, the US might appear weaker, complicating diplomacy in the region, particularly with North Korea. The US has a treaty ally obligation to defend South Korea from its nuclear-armed neighbor.

site_title: Oil tanker anchored on Asia's busiest shipping route to become refuelling hub
summary: A Euronav NV-owned supertanker, the Oceania, anchored off Malaysia's west coast, will become a refuelling hub for marine fuel ahead of new IMO 2020 industry rules. The tanker, carrying 3 million barrels of low-sulphur fuel, will serve as a floating storage and distribution center for TAG Marine Sdn Bhd. This move aims to secure cheaper fuel for Euronav's fleet and provides a ready supply of shipping fuel in Asia before the new standards take effect on January 1. The port operator sees this as a shot in the arm for Kuala Linggi port.

site_title: Hot stock: MNACT down 4.9% after 'extensive damage' to Hong Kong mall from protests
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) saw its stock price drop 4.92% to S$1.16 following 'extensive damage' to its Festival Walk property in Hong Kong due to protests. The damage occurred after groups of protestors smashed glass panels and set fires to the mall, including a Christmas tree and office lobby. The property remains closed on Wednesday. MNACT generates 62% of its net property income from Festival Walk and will assess the damage and provide an update in due course.

site_title: PropNex Q3 profit slips 15.2% to S$6.1m
summary: PropNex, a Singapore-based real estate agency, reported a 15.2% drop in Q3 net profit to S$6.1 million, due to lower commission income and higher staff costs. Revenue fell 1.3% to S$122.5 million, with commission income from agency services decreasing and project marketing services increasing. Staff costs rose 30.9% to S$3.5 million, mainly due to salary increments and staff bonuses. No dividend was declared for the quarter.

site_title: Valuetronics Q2 profit up 26.3% on absence of one-off provision for China plant
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 26.3% rise in net profit for its fiscal 2020 second quarter to HK$56 million, driven by the absence of a one-off provision for a China plant affected by flash flooding. Revenue edged down 0.5% to HK$712.8 million, with the consumer electronics segment experiencing a 10.4% increase and the industrial and commercial electronics segment declining 8.2%. The company attributed the decline to the US-China trade war, leading to customer diversification outside China.

site_title: Hong Kong faces third day of chaos after night of rage
summary: Hong Kong faces a third day of chaos as protests against Beijing's tightening control continue. Pro-democracy protesters clashed with riot police on a university campus, resulting in violent scenes and widespread disruptions. The clashes, which began on Tuesday, have left closed metro stations, suspended rail lines, and cancelled bus services. The protests, which have been largely confined to weekends, have now spread to the working week, targeting local neighborhoods to keep police distracted. The city's education authorities have advised parents to decide whether to send children to school due to the disruptions.

site_title: Some of the world's richest brace for a major stock selloff
summary: Wealthy individuals worldwide are bracing for a potential major stock selloff in 2020, with a majority expecting significant market drops and nearly four-fifths anticipating increased volatility. A survey of over 3,400 respondents found 25% of their average assets are currently in cash, primarily due to concerns over the US-China trade conflict and upcoming presidential election. Despite this, 70% remain optimistic about investment returns over the next decade, with many shifting to safer assets like cash due to short-term uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.15 points to 1,610.88. The market saw 32.15 million lots traded worth RM11.65 million, with 103 gainers outpacing 56 losers.

site_title: Venice underwater as exceptional tide sweeps through canal city
summary: Venice experienced its highest tide in over 50 years, with waters peaking at 1.87m, flooding streets and historic sites, including St Mark's Square. The exceptionally intense "acqua alta" was attributed to a fierce wind and powerful rainstorms that hit Italy. Authorities reported damage to homes and hotels, with some areas experiencing waters above 1.94m, a record since 1966. The city's infrastructure project to protect against high tides was highlighted as a long-term solution, but its effectiveness remains uncertain due to cost overruns and delays.

site_title: UK PM Johnson has 14-point lead over Labour before election: YouGov poll
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Conservative Party has a 14-point lead over the opposition Labour Party, according to a YouGov opinion poll published ahead of the UK's December 12 election. The poll found 42% of voters support the Conservatives, while Labour has 28%. The Liberal Democrats are on 15%, and the Brexit Party is on 4%. This is a significant change from previous polls using the same methodology, where the Conservative and Labour parties were tied.

site_title: Facebook messaging apps getting unified payment system
summary: Facebook is consolidating its payment system across its messaging apps, including Messenger, Instagram, and WhatsApp, into a unified system called Facebook Pay. The move aims to simplify transactions and safeguard user data. Facebook Pay will begin rolling out in the US this week, initially for fundraisers, in-game purchases, and person-to-person payments. The system will eventually be expanded to other platforms, including Instagram and WhatsApp, and will provide a single, secure system for handling financial transactions.

site_title: IEA says world needs 'laser-like focus' to bring down emissions
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warns that the world must adopt a "laser-like focus" to reduce emissions and achieve a sustainable energy future, as current policies are insufficient to meet the Paris Agreement's goal of limiting global warming to 1.5°C. Under the IEA's Sustainable Development Scenario, global CO2 emissions would fall two-thirds by 2050 and reach net zero by 2070, with a 50% chance of hitting the 1.5°C target if CO2 can be removed from the atmosphere.

site_title: Hong Kong clashes rage on university campus and business district
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy protesters clashed with riot police on a university campus and in the city's business district, extending violent unrest for over five months. Police fired tear gas and rubber bullets, while protesters threw bricks and petrol bombs, with hundreds injured. The clashes followed a brutal day on Monday, when a protester and a man were shot, prompting calls for compromise from Western powers. China has refused to give concessions, warning of tougher security measures, including the potential deployment of the People's Liberation Army. The European Union and Britain called for restraint and a political solution, as the situation's far-reaching impact on lives and livelihoods makes a credible and swift solution imperative.

site_title: SembMarine Q3 loss widens to S$52.6m
summary: Sembcorp Marine reported a widened net loss of S$52.6 million in its third quarter, from S$29.8 million a year ago. Revenue fell 38.6% to S$717.2 million, mainly due to lower revenue recognition from rigs and floaters projects. The company expects losses to continue into the fourth quarter and full year loss to be higher than last year's. Challenges in the offshore and marine sector persist, with intense competition and low activity levels in most segments.

site_title: Chilean peso drops to historic low amid weeks-long crisis
summary: Chile's currency, the peso, reached a historic low of 784 pesos to the dollar, dropping over 3% due to weeks-long mass street protests against the economic policies of President Sebastian Pinera. The protests, which began on October 18, have left the country in crisis, with demonstrators demanding greater social reform. Finance Minister Ignacio Briones warned that the currency's fall would impact prices and inflation, while analysts predict sustained unrest will weaken growth.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.38%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.38% on Wednesday, closing at 3,255.39, after a mixed US trading session overnight. The Straits Times Index pared its Tuesday gains, with 80 losers outnumbering 66 gainers. The most actively traded security, Jiutian Chemical, rose 11.8% after a strong day, while Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust slid 4.1% after reporting damage to its Hong Kong mall due to protests. US stocks ended mixed, with the Nasdaq posting a new record, while European shares climbed to a four-year high.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, UOL, SATS, SembMarine, Oxley, BreadTalk, Dasin Retail Trust
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) reported a 33.7% year-on-year decline in third-quarter net profit to S$114.96 million, impacted by impairment losses and transaction costs. UOL Group posted a 7% drop in net profit to S$80 million due to lower profit from property development. Meanwhile, other companies such as Oxley, Dasin Retail Trust, and BreadTalk were also mentioned in the article as being watched by investors.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly higher as Nasdaq hits new record
summary: US stocks ended the day mixed, with the Nasdaq posting a new record despite uncertainty over the US-China trade war. The Dow Jones remained unchanged, while the S&P 500 gained 0.2%. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose nearly 0.3% to close at a new high of 8,486.09. President Trump's speech failed to offer clarity on trade disputes, instead threatening to raise tariffs on Chinese goods. The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates on hold, with Chairman Jerome Powell set to testify on Wednesday and Thursday.

site_title: Oil steadies after Trump dashes hopes on trade deal details
summary: Oil prices ended Tuesday little changed after US President Donald Trump offered few details about Washington's trade talks with Beijing, weighing on crude futures. Brent crude futures fell 12 cents to $62.06 a barrel and WTI crude futures settled down 6 cents to $56.80 a barrel. Concerns about slower economic growth and oil demand due to the trade dispute between the US and China have weighed on prices. Earlier, data showed crude inventories at Cushing fell by 1.2 million barrels, but crude stockpiles nationwide are forecast to rise for a third week in a row.

site_title: Musk announces new Tesla factory will be in Germany
summary: Elon Musk announced a new Tesla factory in Germany, to be located in the Berlin area near the new airport. The "Gigafactory" will be part of Tesla's European expansion, with plans to begin production by 2021. The company aims to tap into the European market, where it is estimated to have around 30% of the battery-powered car market. Musk praised German engineering and the city of Berlin, stating it has some of the best art in the world. The design center will also be set up in the area.

site_title: Federal Reserve's election year challenge: Is slowing US job growth a 'material' change?
summary: Federal Reserve officials face a challenging election year if US job growth slows as expected. Chair Jerome Powell has set a high bar for further rate reductions, requiring a "material" shift in the country's economic outlook. A slowdown in job growth on its own would not qualify, and Fed officials may struggle to explain why a slowdown is not a bad sign. President Donald Trump is centering his reelection campaign around the economy, and Fed officials may be reluctant to cut rates, despite expectations of a slowdown in economic growth.

site_title: US dollar edges up ahead of Trump's trade speech
summary: The US dollar edged up 0.2% against a basket of currencies ahead of US President Donald Trump's speech on US trade policy, with traders optimistic that he may delay a tariff decision on European carmakers by six months, potentially boosting the market. The global US dollar index rose, while the euro hit four-week lows against the US dollar, and the offshore Chinese yuan remained flat.

site_title: Apple set to launch new MacBook Pro with bigger screen, new keyboard
summary: Apple is set to launch a new 16-inch MacBook Pro with a larger screen and revamped keyboard, marking the first major update to the line in three years. The new laptop features a brighter display, more reliable keyboard, and main processors from Intel, replacing Apple-made chips. The 16-inch model will replace the current 15-inch option, starting at $2,399, and is expected to go on sale this week. The new laptop is part of a year of Apple product releases, including the iPhone 11 line and Mac Pro desktop computer, which will be released in December.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust Q3 DPU falls 5.5%; to buy 2 Chinese malls from sponsor, chairman
summary: DASIN Retail Trust reported a 5.5% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.71 Singapore cents for its third quarter, due to a "distribution waiver" by major unitholders. Revenue increased 3.4% to S$18.7 million, driven by the September acquisition of Doumen Metro Mall. The trust also announced plans to buy two Chinese malls, Shunde Metro Mall and Tanbei Metro Mall, from its sponsor and chairman, Zhang Zhencheng, for an estimated S$333 million.

site_title: Boeing gives pilot new job after firestorm over leaked messages: sources
summary: Boeing has transferred a technical pilot, Patrik Gustavsson, to a new job after criticism over leaked 2016 messages about a flawed flight control system. The messages, between Gustavsson and colleague Mark Forkner, eroded $14 billion of Boeing's market value and highlighted the company's knowledge of problems with the MCAS system before two crashes killed 346 people. Gustavsson was moved to Boeing's Test & Evaluation group, where pilots test the 737 Max aircraft, within the last two weeks.

images.alt_text: One of two Boeing technical pilots who described flaws in a crucial flight control system in leaked 2016 instant messages has been transferred to a new job at the US planemaker, two people familiar with the matter said on Tuesday.

site_title: British security officials play down cyber attack on Labour Party
summary: British security officials downplayed a cyber attack on the Labour Party during the general election campaign, stating it was "confident the party took the necessary steps to deal with the attack" and was ultimately unsuccessful. The National Cyber Security centre (NCSC) confirmed the attack was "large-scale" but did not provide further details. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn described the incident as "very serious", while campaign activities were slowed but restored to normal. There is no evidence to suggest a state-sponsored attack, with sources suggesting low-level hacking was involved.

site_title: BT's charity efforts make significant inroads
summary: A study by research firm Kantar found that The Business Times Budding Artists Fund has significantly impacted the lives of underprivileged children, boosting their confidence, focus, and happiness by up to 48%. The fund, established in 2004, has helped over 18,000 children undergo arts training, leading to improved socio-emotional development and academic performance. Beneficiaries reported a more positive self-image, emotional control, and a sense of direction, with 77% describing the fund as "very good" or "excellent" in helping students.

site_title: BreadTalk Q3 gain dives 81% to S$513,000 on higher expenses
summary: BreadTalk Group, a Singapore-based food and beverage company, reported a 81% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$513,000 in Q3, with a net profit margin of 0.3%. The company's earnings per share and net asset value per share also decreased. Despite a 10.1% increase in revenue to S$173.6 million, higher distribution and selling expenses led to the decline. The company expects additional revenue from its Food Junction acquisition and will work to drive synergy between its brands.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The future of the automobile industry
summary: The future of the automobile industry is being shaped by technological advancements and shifting consumer demands. Tesla has marked its formal entry into India with a Mumbai launch event, while also planning to expand its robotaxi services in California and Arizona. Meanwhile, FedEx is partnering with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas. Japan's carmakers are also adapting to the US market by slashing export prices to offset tariff hits. As the industry continues to evolve, electric vehicle manufacturers like BYD are facing pressure to cut emissions.

site_title: Europe: German data, earnings nudge stocks near 4-year highs; Madrid lags
summary: European shares rose 0.6% to near a four-year high on Tuesday, driven by positive German investor sentiment data and upbeat earnings. The ZEW survey showed improved mood among German investors, suggesting a more favorable outlook despite expected technical recession in Germany's largest economy. Meanwhile, Spanish stocks lagged due to a socialist-far-left coalition forming in Madrid.

site_title: SATS Q2 net profit falls 7.6%
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based airport and food services provider, reported a 7.6% decline in net profit for the second quarter, to S$60.7 million, due to lower cargo volumes. Revenue improved 9.8% to S$497.4 million, while group expenditure rose 11.7% to S$432.4 million. The company has declared an interim cash dividend of six cents per share. SATS continues to invest in growth opportunities and infrastructure, despite a slowdown in trade and economic growth.

site_title: It's still about the economy - and it's far from hunky-dory
summary: The US economy remains a concern, despite recent stock market highs, as job growth and consumer spending are key indicators of economic health. A strong October jobs report led to a surge in the stock market, but experts caution that the economy is still fragile due to the US-China trade conflict and a slowdown in business investment. Central banks are cutting interest rates to mitigate the effects, but a significant breakthrough in trade talks and a smooth UK exit from the EU are needed for sustainable growth. Recession fears have eased, but investors should be cautious of a sudden turn in trade talks.

site_title: Burger King's plant-based burgers launched in Europe
summary: Burger King has launched its plant-based Whopper burger in 25 European countries, featuring patties made by Unilever's The Vegetarian Butcher brand. The move aims to tap into the growing demand for plant-based food, driven by concerns over health and environmental impact. The Rebel Whopper, priced similarly to its beef counterpart, will be available at over 2,500 stores in countries such as Germany, Spain, and Italy. This is Burger King's largest product launch in Europe, with plans to expand the rollout to other regions.

site_title: Revolut drops out of Singapore digibank race over high capital requirement
summary: Revolut, a UK-based fintech, has ruled out joining Singapore's digital bank landscape due to high capital requirements. According to CEO Nikolay Storonsky, the high capital requirements of S$1.5 billion within three to five years make it "not make sense" for Revolut to obtain a banking license. Despite being in talks with potential partners, Revolut will not submit an application, citing the high costs as a "no" for now. This decision follows similar rejections by other fintech companies, including Instarem and TransferWise.

site_title: Google signs healthcare data, cloud computing deal with Ascension
summary: Google has signed a cloud computing deal with Ascension, a healthcare provider operating 150 hospitals and 50 senior living facilities in the US. The deal grants Google access to Ascension's datasets, which could aid in developing artificial intelligence tools. The partnership includes lab results, doctor diagnoses, and hospitalization records, totaling a complete health history. Google maintains that patient data will not be combined with consumer data, and the partnership is in compliance with the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA). The deal aims to improve clinical effectiveness and patient safety using AI.

site_title: Fed likely to defy history with steady rates
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is likely to signal that monetary policy remains on hold, defying historical precedent of action in presidential election years. This stance is in contrast to the Fed's past actions in previous election years, where policy changes were made to address economic conditions. Powell's decision aims to preserve the Fed's independence and credibility, despite President Trump's criticism of the institution. The economy shows signs of stability, with recent data including a solid employment report, which has led investors to expect no further rate cuts, contradicting some forecasts.

site_title: GIC, BlackRock buy UK gas pipeline firm Kellas Midstream
summary: GIC and BlackRock have agreed to buy UK gas pipeline firm Kellas Midstream from private equity firm Antin Infrastructure Partners. The joint venture, Global Energy and Power Infrastructure Funds (GEPIF) III, will purchase the firm for an undisclosed amount. Kellas Midstream owns key gas infrastructure in the UK Central and Southern North Sea, including the Central Area Transmission System, Esmond Transportation System, and Humber Gathering System. The deal is expected to close in early 2020 and reflects growing interest from institutional investors in energy and power investments.

site_title: China should cut rates, fiscal policies should take priority: PBOC adviser
summary: China's economic growth is cooling, with growth near 30-year lows and factory price deflation deepening, prompting adviser Sheng Songcheng to suggest policymakers prioritize fiscal policy over cutting interest rates. A proactive fiscal policy, including front-loading local government bond issuance and tax cuts, should be pursued to support infrastructure projects and boost economic growth. Monetary policy should play a supporting role in lowering real financing costs.

site_title: Trump hails economic boom, says China trade deal is 'close'
summary: President Donald Trump credited the US economic boom to his policies, despite warnings from industries and a report stating that the trade wars threaten 1.5 million jobs and burden consumers with higher costs. Trump said a partial trade deal with China is "close" but warned he will raise tariffs further if the pact fails. The report contradicts the White House message that the US is easily weathering the trade conflict, citing cargo volume declines and lost markets. Economists warn the trade war is hitting the global economy and eroding US exports and business investment.

site_title: A record US$173 billion is flowing from Korea into riskier assets
summary: South Korean investors poured a record $173 billion into riskier assets, such as real estate, infrastructure, and hedge funds, in 2019, a significant increase from previous years. This trend is driven by the search for yield in a low-interest-rate environment. However, the investments expose buyers to higher risks due to less liquidity and information availability. Some institutions are facing issues, including a dispute over an Australian real estate fund and delayed maturities on derivative-linked securities. Experts warn of the need for investors to mitigate risks and select asset classes carefully.

site_title: KrisEnergy Q3 loss widens amid drop in oil prices
summary: KrisEnergy, a Singapore-based upstream oil and gas firm, reported a widened net loss of US$16.7 million in its third quarter, from a loss of US$11 million a year ago, due to lower oil prices and sale volumes. Revenue nearly halved to US$22.9 million, and the group's capital deficiency position deepened to US$63.3 million. KrisEnergy is undergoing financial restructuring and has applied for court-supervised debt restructuring.

site_title: Eyes on Oxley as Yanlord raises UE cash offer
summary: Yanlord Land Group has raised its cash offer for United Engineers (UE) to S$2.70 per share, surpassing the 50% threshold required for control. The offer, which includes 39.2 million shares, brings Yanlord's total interest in UE to 41.42%. Oxley Holdings, the second-largest shareholder, has not commented on its intentions but may be tempted to exit UE, with some analysts suggesting it could be a "value trap" for the company.

site_title: China's pork rally set to ease as govt acts to rein in costs
summary: China's pork prices, which have surged due to high demand and supply chain issues, may begin to ease by the end of the year as the government takes measures to control costs. The government plans to release state reserves, increase imports, and force commercial storage firms to release inventories before Lunar New Year holidays. These efforts aim to stabilize prices, which have pushed China's inflation to a seven-year high. The measures are expected to take effect in the middle of December, potentially easing price pressures.

site_title: Oxley reverses year-ago loss with Q1 net profit of S$12.2m
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a net profit of S$12.2 million for Q1 2019, reversing a year-ago loss of S$655,000. The gain was driven by higher gross profit from hotels and development projects, as well as gains on revaluation of a property and mark-to-market of derivative instruments. Revenue was up 66% to S$282.8 million, and about 66% of 10 development projects have been sold since April 2018, with sales expected to reach 70% by end-2019.

site_title: First Resources Q3 profit slips 28.5%
summary: First Resources, a palm oil producer, reported a 28.5% drop in net profit to US$27.9 million for its third quarter, mainly due to weaker palm oil prices. Sales fell 19.7% to US$137.6 million, while cost of sales decreased 15.8%. The group expects production to peak in the third quarter, with prices potentially influenced by Indonesia's B30 biodiesel mandate. Despite the decline, the company believes the long-term fundamentals of the palm oil industry remain positive.

site_title: Amaravati project terminated: Sembcorp
summary: Sembcorp Industries has terminated the Amaravati project, a 684-hectare startup area development in Andhra Pradesh, India, following a change in scenario for the capital city's development. The project, expected to take over 20 years, had incurred costs of "a few million dollars" for design services. The closure is not expected to impact Sembcorp's investment plans in India or its earnings per share and net asset value for the 2019 financial year.

site_title: The changing colour of money - new directions for payment systems, currencies
summary: Central banks are being forced to step up their role in improving payment security and efficiency due to rapid technological advancements. The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) has launched the BIS Innovation Hub, with locations in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Switzerland, to drive efforts in critical financial technology trends and engineer public goods to enhance the global financial system. The hub aims to develop foundational public digital infrastructures, improve cross-border payments, and promote financial inclusion. Central banks believe the public sector should play a leading role in improving the functioning of the monetary system, rather than reinventing money itself.

site_title: Nissan reports 70% drop in quarterly profit
summary: Nissan Motor Co Ltd reported a 70% drop in quarterly profit, cutting its full-year outlook to an 11-year low due to falling sales. The Japanese automaker's weak financial performance, lasting nearly two years, highlights the challenges for its new executive team. The company's ongoing turmoil follows the ouster of former head Carlos Ghosn. The drop in profit and outlook has significant implications for Nissan's future, underscoring the scale of work ahead for its new leadership team, set to take over on December 1.

site_title: Facebook's Libra a 'good idea', but still too many unknowns: panellists
summary: Facebook's Libra digital currency is seen as a good idea, but with significant unknowns regarding money laundering, terrorist financing, and monetary sovereignty. Central bankers and private players cautiously welcome its attempt to solve cross-border payments issues.

site_title: Boeing says 737 MAX expected to resume flying in January
summary: Boeing expects the 737 MAX to resume flying in January, delaying its return by one month from December, following two fatal crashes that killed 346 people. The company still hopes to receive certification from the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) next month and is working on updated training requirements and modified software. The grounding has dragged on beyond initial expectations, and airlines like Southwest and American have pushed back their timeframe for resuming flights on the 737 MAX until early March.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices extend climb in October: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices rose 0.8% in October, the fastest increase in three months, while sales volume increased 3.6% with 807 units resold. Year-on-year, prices were up 2% and volumes were 14.8% higher. Strong demand and market optimism for new homes may have driven the increase, but prices are still slower than new home sales. The resale market is expected to continue rising, albeit at a slower pace, driven by newly-launched projects and buoyancy in the primary market.

site_title: China's Huazhu to buy German luxury hotel group Steigenberger
summary: Huazhu Group, China's fifth-largest hotel group, is acquiring Steigenberger hotels for 700 million euros (S$1.05 billion) in cash. The deal values Deutsche Hospitality, Steigenberger's parent, at 17-18 times its 2019 expected earnings. Huazhu aims to expand its global reach and will add 118 existing hotels and 36 under development to its portfolio. Four Steigenberger brands will be rolled out in China, with no job cuts planned. The acquisition is expected to increase Huazhu's hotel count to over 5,000.

site_title: HK 'pushed to brink of total breakdown': police
summary: Hong Kong police fired tear gas in multiple locations, including the Central financial district, Mong Kok, and universities, to break up pro-democracy protests that police described as leading the city to the "brink of total breakdown." The clashes came a day after police shot a protester and a man was set on fire in some of the worst violence in decades. Over 3,000 people have been arrested since the protests escalated in June, with protesters demanding an end to police brutality and interference from Beijing.

site_title: Singapore property portals face double-edged sword in regional expansion
summary: Singapore's property portals, such as PropertyGuru and 99.co, are struggling financially due to high employee costs and lack of scale. Despite posting significant losses, the companies aim to expand into the region, citing the need for scale to sustain their business. However, analysts warn that the market is becoming increasingly competitive, with the potential introduction of a government-backed HDB portal, which could further reduce their market share. To survive, the companies must balance short-term losses with long-term growth, similar to Amazon's strategy of financing loss-making business units.

site_title: Landsec posts H1 loss on store closures
summary: British property developer Land Securities Group reported a pre-tax loss of £147 million for the first half due to store closures by retailers amid slack consumer sentiment and the shift to online selling. The company is offloading assets to focus on its profit-generating London portfolio. Land Securities cited high numbers of company voluntary agreements by retailers and expects the trend to continue, particularly ahead of the UK's general election. Despite a 3.2% decrease in EPRA net asset value, the company remains confident.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges higher at open with focus on Trump speech
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones rising 0.04% to 27,701.59, the S&P 500 gaining 0.07% to 3,089.28, and the Nasdaq Composite increasing 0.08% to 8,471.07. Investors await President Donald Trump's speech later in the day for clarity on US-China trade relations, which has been a focus of market attention.

site_title: HDB launches 4,571 BTO flats for sale, mostly in Tengah
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 4,571 new Build-To-Order (BTO) flats for sale, mostly in Tengah, as part of the year's last and biggest BTO exercise. The flats are available under the BTO and Sale of Balance Flats schemes, with prices starting from $110,000 for a two-room flexi flat and $442,000 for a three-generation flat. Applications for the flats close on November 18, with more BTO flats to be released in May 2020. This is the second sales exercise following the announcement of higher grants and income ceilings for first-time flat buyers.

site_title: UOL Q3 net profit slips 7% to S$80m on lower earnings from development
summary: UOL Group's third-quarter net profit slipped 7% to S$80m due to lower earnings from property development, with revenue from the segment falling 34%. However, revenue from management services and technologies climbed 22% and dividend income grew 10%. The group reported strong underlying demand in the Singapore residential market, with Avenue South Residence being the top-selling project for September. UOL's shares closed three cents higher at S$7.91, despite a cautious outlook on the economic outlook and Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Higher operating costs slash Cosco Q3 earnings by 46%
summary: Cosco Shipping International (Singapore) reported a 46% decline in third-quarter net profit to S$1.2 million due to higher operating costs. The company's board chairman, Gu Jing Song, resigned after becoming chairman in August, as part of its holding company's policy to rotate "key management talents." Year-to-date net profit dropped 22% to S$5.9 million, with earnings per share down 25% to 0.25 Singapore cent. The company aims to expand its logistics network through acquisitions and investments, with expansion plans in Malaysia progressing.

site_title: Apple plans AR, VR devices with new 3D sensor system
summary: Apple is developing a range of augmented-reality (AR) and virtual-reality (VR) devices, including a new iPad Pro, high-end iPhones, a combined VR/AR headset, and AR glasses, powered by a new 3D sensor system. The technology is expected to be released as early as 2020 and 2023, with a focus on gaming, video, and virtual meetings. The new sensor system will be more advanced than the Face ID sensor and will be the core of Apple's next big hardware push beyond the iPhone, iPad, and Apple Watch.

images.alt_text: When the new gadgets launch, they will likely become part of Apple's growing wearable devices segment.

site_title: Bursting the billionaire bubble
summary: Billionaires' immense wealth may not be beneficial for their reality sense, and some are more likely to exhibit bad judgment due to ego and politics. Most billionaires made their money in finance, real estate, and fashion, with technology coming in fourth. Historically, the US economy functioned without as many billionaires, and the current era of soaring inequality contradicts the idea of "trickle-down" economics. The billionaire class's views on politics, including lower taxes and reduced social programs, are not popular among the general public, with most people wanting higher taxes and increased spending on social programs.

site_title: Hyatt to bid for Xenia's US$500m Kimpton portfolio
summary: Hyatt Hotels Corp has emerged as a potential bidder for Xenia Hotels & Resorts' US$500m Kimpton portfolio, according to people with knowledge of the matter. Xenia has received multiple offers for the portfolio, which includes Kimpton Hotel Monaco properties in Chicago, Denver, and Salt Lake City. Hyatt's policy is not to comment on potential transactions, but the company has expressed a commitment to reducing its portfolio of owned real estate. A sale of the portfolio could fetch around US$500 million, and management contracts for the properties can be terminated in the event of a sale.

site_title: Strategies for a bear market
summary: A bear market has made correlations less effective for building effective portfolios, as asset classes remain at an all-time high. Diversification has not been rewarding over the last 10 years, with concentration in developed markets being the winning strategy. To improve this, a dynamic downside protection strategy utilizing market health signals, such as implied volatility, can be effective. This strategy can deliver protection when needed, with an annualized return of 4.2% compared to 1.45% with a traditional put strategy.

site_title: Relay Majulah raises S$1.6m for President's Challenge
summary: Relay Majulah, Singapore's first 2,000-kilometer relay, concluded on Sunday with a final 10-kilometer leg, exceeding its S$1 million target and raising over S$1.6 million for 67 charities under the President's Challenge. The event, which challenged 200 runners to complete the nation-wide relay in 200 hours, featured participants from diverse backgrounds, including cancer survivors, persons with disabilities, and ordinary people. The relay's co-chairmen, Ong Tze Boon and Bennett Neo, emphasized the importance of community and giving, stating that together, they can make a change and be stronger and better.

site_title: Will TikTok become the next Huawei?
summary: TikTok, a short-form video app, is facing scrutiny from US authorities over security concerns, including intelligence gathering and ties with the Chinese government. Similar to Huawei, which was blacklisted by the US in 2019, TikTok's parent company ByteDance is under review by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US. Observers warn that TikTok may face similar accusations, potentially leading to its loss of the American market. However, TikTok has taken steps to reassure users that their data is stored in the US, and the company's resilience and counter-attacking moves may mitigate the crisis, much like Huawei's efforts to demonstrate its healthy operations.

site_title: France's central bank to open Asian office in Singapore next year
summary: The Banque de France (BDF), France's central bank, plans to open its second office abroad in Singapore next year, aiming to boost monitoring of Asian economies and financial systems. The office will also strengthen relations with central banks and financial authorities in the Asia-Oceania region. This move follows a growing trend of central banks and sovereign wealth funds anchoring their overseas offices in Singapore to gain insights on Asian economic and financial developments. The move is seen as a key step in strengthening France's link with the Asian continent in today's globalised world.

site_title: AI is too important to leave to Google and Facebook alone
summary: The US government should provide infrastructure for a technological future by offering a public option for artificial intelligence, rather than relying on big tech companies like Google and Facebook. A public option would allow startups and governments to develop and use AI without relying on these companies, promoting competition and innovation. The proposal includes three components: a public data pool, increased research and development spending, and expanded AI procurement across various sectors. This would address the current imbalance of power in the tech industry and preserve democratic values.

site_title: Investors wary after Monday's sell-off
summary: Asian equities recovered from Monday's sell-off, with Singapore's Straits Times Index rising 0.8% to 3,267.80. Investors were cautious ahead of US President Donald Trump's speech on US trade policy and a potential tariff delay on European autos. Crude palm oil prices increased, driving gains in agribusiness players such as Golden Agri-Resources, Wilmar International, and Bumitama Agri. Trading volumes were high, with 1.63 billion securities traded in Singapore.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SBS Transit reported a 1.5% net profit increase to S$20 million in the third quarter, driven by improved public transport revenue. Metro Holdings saw a 21.7% decline in net profit to S$10.3 million due to worsened associate results and finance costs. Cromwell European Reit's distribution per unit rose 1% to 1.01 euro cents, despite being 1.9% lower than forecast, thanks to strong office and logistics contributions.

site_title: Disney+ faces glitches on launch day
summary: Disney+ faced technical issues on its launch day, with users experiencing glitches and an error screen featuring Mickey Mouse. The issue affected some users but not all, with many able to access the service and give positive reviews. The streaming service, which offers new and classic content from Disney, Marvel, Star Wars, and Pixar, is a direct competitor to Netflix and Apple TV+. Disney did not immediately respond to the issue.

site_title: Singapore needs longevity agenda to harness the benefits of longer lives
summary: Singapore needs a "longevity agenda" to capitalize on its high life expectancy and address the country's low birth rate. A proposed council of experts will consider policies to support longer, healthier lives. The concept of a "100-year life" challenges traditional retirement planning, with experts urging a shift towards flexible working and multi-stage life paths. The government's efforts to raise the retirement age to 65 and extend re-employment age to 70 are seen as a start, but more measures to support flexible working at all ages are needed to address ageism in the workplace.

site_title: Thomson Medical posts S$0.75m Q3 net loss, reverses year-ago profit
summary: Thomson Medical Group posted a net loss of S$751,000 for the third quarter, reversing its year-ago profit, due to higher operating expenses and financing costs. Revenue grew 10% to S$59.6 million, driven by increased patient load and revenue intensity. For the nine months, net profit was down 85% to S$1.7 million, while loss per share was 0.002 cent. No dividend was declared.

site_title: CDL Q3 net slides 33.7% on impairment losses
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) reported a 33.7% year-on-year decline in its third-quarter net profit to S$114.96 million due to impairment losses on two hotels and transaction costs from the delisting of Millennium & Copthorne Hotels. Revenue fell 12.9% to S$885.3 million, primarily due to the lumpy nature of its property development segment. Excluding impairment losses, profit after tax and minority interests would have declined by 11.4%.

site_title: Singapore's Temasek considers first euro-bond sale since 2016
summary: Singapore's Temasek Holdings is considering its first euro-bond sale in nearly four years, with plans to issue 12-year and 30-year benchmark notes. The move follows low borrowing costs in Europe, drawing more Asian issuers to the market. This comes as negative interest rates and investor demand hold down borrowing costs compared to the dollar. Temasek, a AAA-rated issuer, joins a wave of Asian and global issuers, including China's recent euro bond sale.

site_title: Brexit's £61t derivatives spat needs fix now, banks say
summary: The world's biggest banks are urging the European Commission to pass an urgent Brexit fix to ensure access to London derivatives clearinghouses and avoid £61 trillion in contracts. The industry's top lobbying associations, including the FIA, sent a letter to the Commission, requesting clarity well in advance of the end of December 2019. The lack of clarity poses financial stability risks and could prompt firms to move business out of London as early as next month. The EU's stopgap solution is set to expire in March.

site_title: MAS, Deloitte, S&P create prototype research platform for fintech investments
summary: MAS, Deloitte, and S&P Global Market Intelligence have developed a digital research platform for fintech investments, aiming to increase transparency and enhance confidence in fintech companies. The platform provides comprehensive views of fintech companies, including business models, funding, and technology stacks. It enables investors to compare and prioritize companies, potentially improving deployment of capital in startups. The prototype is designed to provide reliable and up-to-date company information, addressing current limitations in sourcing investment opportunities through informal networks. The platform will be further developed to leverage synergies with the API Exchange developed by MAS.

site_title: It's time for Tencent to hive off its fintech business and let it shine
summary: Tencent Holdings is considering spinning off its growing fintech business into a separate company to unlock its estimated $230 billion value. The move would make the entity China's fourth-largest listed company and the world's sixth-biggest financial-services firm. Fintech accounts for 26% of Tencent's revenue and has grown over 70% last year, primarily through payments. Analysts estimate the business could be worth $137-230 billion, and a spinoff could allow the company to regain market attention, potentially surpassing Alibaba's fintech unit, Ant Financial.

site_title: A century and half on, Suez Canal is a 'lifeline' for Egypt
summary: The Suez Canal, opened in 1869, remains a crucial waterway for Egypt's economy, 150 years after its initial opening. Nationalized in 1956, the canal has undergone expansions, including a 2015 upgrade to accommodate larger ships. Today, it serves as a vital lifeline for Egypt's economy, supporting international trade and commerce.

site_title: UK Labour suffers 'major cyber attack' ahead of election
summary: The UK Labour party has suffered a "large-scale cyber attack" ahead of the general election, which slowed some campaign activities but ultimately failed to breach data due to robust security systems. The party reported the incident to the National Cyber Security Centre and described it as "very serious". Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn expressed concern about potential outside interference in the election, stating that a cyber attack against a political party is "suspicious" and warrants worry. The party's digital platforms were restored to normal operation after the incident.

site_title: Tories in pole position with commanding lead
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Conservative Party holds a commanding lead in opinion surveys ahead of the general election, with a 70% chance of winning a majority government. Nigel Farage's decision not to field Brexit Party candidates in Conservative-held seats could help the Tories retain those seats, but may also split the vote and potentially harm Johnson's party. The election's outcome remains uncertain, with Labour still a possibility, and the framing of the ballot could shift to focus on issues like the economy, the National Health Service, and law and order, which could benefit Labour.

site_title: Setback for India PM's party as financial capital placed under direct rule
summary: India's financial capital, Maharashtra, has been placed under direct rule by the president after weeks of deadlock over who would form the government following the state's elections. The move is a setback for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party, which was expected to remain in control. The state was ruled by the BJP and its right-wing regional ally Shiv Sena, but they failed to agree on a power-sharing deal. The president's direct rule can last up to six months, and experts predict fresh elections will be called within a few weeks.

site_title: Tyson Foods misses quarterly sales estimates
summary: Tyson Foods Inc missed quarterly sales estimates, with sales rising nearly 9% to $10.88 billion, but falling short of analysts' average estimate of $11 billion. The company's net income decreased to $369 million, or $1.01 per share, from $537 million, or $1.47 per share, a year earlier, due to weakness in its beef business. The drop in cattle processing capacity contributed to the decline.

site_title: Wealthy amass record US$121b in tax-sheltered accounts
summary: Wealthy individuals have amassed a record $121.4 billion in tax-sheltered donor-advised funds (DAFs) in 2018, a 20.1% increase from 2017. DAFs, which allow individuals to donate to charities and receive tax deductions, saw a 55% rise in account formation to 728,563 in 2018. However, critics argue that the growth in DAFs may be contributing to a decline in charitable giving by individual households, with 20 million fewer households giving money in 2016 than in 2000.

site_title: Singapore is top draw in Asean for fintech funding
summary: Singapore remains the top destination for fintech funding in ASEAN, attracting 51% of total funding in 2019, with the city-state home to 45% of fintech firms. The sector has grown 30 times since 2014 to reach US$1.14 billion, with insurance technology, payments, and personal finance leading the way. Firms are optimistic about funding, with 79% targeting businesses, and 21% expressing interest in digital bank licenses. Talent remains a challenge, with 58% of firms citing it as an inhibitor to regional expansion.

images.alt_text: Financial technology (fintech) firms in Singapore continued to attract the lion's share of global funding among Asean countries, and the Republic remains the preferred base for fintech firms in the region, a new report by United Overseas Bank (UOB), PwC and the Singapore FinTech Association (SFA) has found.

site_title: Raffles Education narrows Q1 net loss to S$8m on higher revenue
summary: Raffles Education Corporation narrowed its Q1 net loss to S$8 million from S$19.8 million in the same period last year, driven by 11% higher revenue of S$25.9 million. Despite this, the company faced higher finance, depreciation, and personnel expenses, as well as a currency exchange loss of S$9.1 million. Raffles Education attributed the results to the challenging global education environment and increased competition, and plans to streamline operations for better cost management and efficiency.

site_title: Keeping seafarers' mental health shipshape
summary: A study by Cardiff University's Seafarers International Research Centre found that psychological disorders are increasing among serving seafarers, with over half of employers having not addressed mental health for a decade. Key causes of concern include lack of internet access, long working hours, and poor accommodation and food. The study recommends providing free internet access, better terms and conditions of work, and confidential counseling services to improve mental health and well-being. Employers are urged to address these issues to prevent conditions such as anxiety and depression among seafarers.

site_title: Ezion Q3 net loss swells to US$75.4m amid 12% fall in revenue
summary: Ezion Holdings reported a significant net loss of US$75.4 million in the third quarter, a 12% decline in revenue, and a 1,910% increase in loss per share. The company attributed the decline to reduced utilisation and charter rates for its jack-up rigs, tugs, and barges. Ezion also recognised additional impairment losses and loss allowances, contributing to its substantial net loss. The company's shares have been suspended from trading since March 2019.

site_title: CDL posts 33.7% drop in Q3 net profit to S$115m
summary: CDL's Q3 net profit dropped 33.7% to S$115m due to impairment losses and transaction costs from Millennium & Copthorne Hotels' delisting. Revenue declined 12.9% to S$885.3m. Earnings per share fell 33.5%. CDL plans to accelerate integration of M&C, controlling costs, and repositioning underperforming assets to create sustainable hotel performance. The company aims to maximize shareholder value through initiatives that leverage its global network and resources.

site_title: Singapore real estate offers best Asia-Pac bets: report
summary: Singapore's real estate market now offers the best investment prospects in the Asia-Pacific, according to the Emerging Trends in Real Estate Asia-Pacific 2020 report by the Urban Land Institute (ULI) and PwC. The city-state saw a surge in transactions in the first half of 2019, driven by cross-border capital, and volumes in the second half are expected to be strong. Singapore's office sector has largely absorbed the oversupply, and confidence in medium-term prospects has returned, making it a defensive asset in an uncertain economic climate.

site_title: Telecom industry consolidation doesn't mean a TPG crash out
summary: Telecom industry consolidation does not necessarily mean a TPG crash out, according to StarHub's third-quarter earnings call. The company earned S$9 million from TPG Telecom for access to shared network facilities, which was a significant portion of its operating profits. This booking was seen as a positive sign, as it indicates a strong partnership between the two companies. Analysts were more interested in this booking than the company's top line, highlighting the importance of partnerships in the telecom industry.

site_title: Indonesia investment growth sped up in Q3: UOB
summary: Indonesia's investment growth accelerated in Q3, with total investment realisation growing 18.4% year-over-year, driven by a 18.9% increase in domestic direct investment and a 17.8% surge in foreign direct investment. Singapore was the top country of origin, accounting for 27.1% of FDI realisation. The government's efforts to achieve balanced growth are reflected in the investment growth, and analysts are cautiously optimistic about Indonesia's ability to attract longer-term investment.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit posts 1% rise in Q3 DPU to 1.01 euro cents
summary: Cromwell European Reit reported a 1% rise in Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.01 euro cents, beating forecasts by 1.9%. Revenue increased 39.2% to 43.8 million euros, driven by contributions from office properties and a strong performance in Germany and the Netherlands. Net property income rose 32.3% to 28.4 million euros, and income available for distribution increased 50.8% to 25.8 million euros. The Reit's nine-month DPU was up 2.3% to 3.05 euro cents, in line with IPO forecasts.

site_title: Centurion posts 21% rise in Q3 net profit, makes new appointments
summary: Centurion Corporation reported a 21% rise in Q3 net profit to S$8.8 million, driven by new properties and higher occupancy rates. Revenue rose 17% to S$33.1 million. Earnings per share increased to 1.05 Singapore cents. For the nine months, net profit edged up 3% to S$26.9 million, while revenue rose 10% to S$97.3 million. CEO Kong Chee Min attributed the growth to the company's strategy in the specialised accommodation business. The company made new appointments, including Wong Kok Hoe as deputy chairman and Lee Wei Loon as an independent non-executive director.

site_title: Pine Capital expects wider half-year net loss on one-off costs
summary: Pine Capital, a Catalist-listed investment firm, expects a wider net loss for the half-year ended Sept 30 due to one-off costs, including increased compliance costs. The company has been hit by lower revenue due to the suspension of trading in its subsidiary, Advance Capital Partners Asset Management, on fundraising activities. Trading in Pine Capital shares has been suspended since March. The company is taking steps to prepare for resumption of trading.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.58 points to 1,609.73 on Tuesday, with 416 gainers outweighing 397 losers. The index was boosted by a volume of 2.5 billion lots worth RM1.8 billion.

site_title: Facebook's Libra can coexist with central banks' digital currencies, says its co-creator
summary: Facebook's Libra can coexist with central banks' digital currencies, according to Christian Catalini, co-creator of Libra. He stated that Libra would complement central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) and help streamline payment operations. Despite concerns about monetary policy interference and financial stability, Catalini argued that Libra's reserve is based on assets managed by central banks, making it a complementary system. Other panelists, including JPMorgan executives, expressed concerns about the potential impact of CBDCs on the commercial banking system.

images.alt_text: Facebook's Libra can coexist with central banks' digital currencies, says its co-creator

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended Tuesday with gains, recovering some losses from the previous day, despite ongoing protests. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.52% to 27,065.28, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also gained 0.17% each. The gains came despite fresh protests blocking roads and shutting businesses, leaving traders on edge.

site_title: EU court says Israel settlement goods must be labelled
summary: The European Court of Justice has ruled that food products from Israeli-occupied territories, including settlements in the West Bank and Golan Heights, must be labelled as such to avoid misleading consumers. The court's decision comes after France's top tribunal asked for clarification on EU rules, citing international law and ethical considerations. The EU's executive arm has stated that the ruling does not change its support for Israel's security, but the Palestine Liberation Organisation has called for the EU to go further and ban products from international markets.

site_title: UOL Q3 net profit slips 7% to S$80m on lower property development earnings
summary: UOL Group's net profit dropped 7% to S$80 million in Q3, mainly due to lower property development earnings. Group revenue fell 10% to S$476.6 million, with a 34% decline in property development revenue. The decline was offset by higher revenue recognition from other segments. The company attributed the drop to delayed recognition of revenue from several development projects.

site_title: SATS posts 7.6% lower Q2 net profit of S$60.7m
summary: SATS posted a 7.6% lower Q2 net profit of S$60.7m due to lower cargo volumes and investments in growth initiatives. Revenue improved 9.8% to S$497.4m. The company's Q2 earnings per share fell to 5.4 Singapore cents, down from 5.9 cents in the previous year. SATS has declared an interim cash dividend of six cents per share, payable on Dec 11. Despite the slowdown in trade and economic growth, SATS continues to invest in growth opportunities.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip as Trump fans trade talk uncertainty; NZ up
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.3% on Tuesday, led by losses in the financial sector, following US President Donald Trump's comments on trade negotiations with China. Trump stated that talks had moved at a slower pace than expected, dampening sentiment. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,753.00, despite positive growth figures from a business conditions measure. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index edged higher to 10,926.31 ahead of a central bank policy meeting on interest rates.

site_title: Cosco posts 46% fall in Q3 net profit to S$1.2m on higher operating costs
summary: Cosco Shipping International (Singapore) reported a 46% decline in Q3 net profit to S$1.2 million due to higher operating costs. The company's turnover remained largely unchanged, while cost of sales increased 1%. Earnings per share fell to 0.05 Singapore cent. The group aims to expand its logistics network in South and Southeast Asia through acquisitions and investments. Non-independent executive director Gu Jing Song resigned as board chairman, and Zhu Jiandong will take his place.

site_title: Nissan reports 70 per cent Q2 profit slump, slashes full-year outlook
summary: Nissan Motor Co Ltd reported a 70% profit slump in Q2, citing falling sales and weak financial performance. The automaker cut its full-year outlook to an 11-year low, citing uncertainty over its future leadership and tensions with top shareholder Renault SA. Operating profit fell to 30 billion yen, marking its worst second-quarter performance in a decade and a half. Nissan's new executive team is set to take over on December 1, amid efforts to revamp the company's top ranks and implement a global recovery plan to rein in costs.

site_title: BreadTalk posts 81% slump in Q3 net profit to S$513,000 on higher expenses
summary: BreadTalk Group reported a 81% slump in its Q3 net profit to S$513,000, down from S$2.7 million in the same period last year. Higher distribution and selling expenses, up 34%, outweighed the 10.1% increase in revenue. This decline was attributed to increased costs, despite a higher topline of S$173.6 million.

site_title: Sri Lanka prisoners demand freedom after Swede's killer pardoned
summary: Hundreds of Sri Lankan prisoners protested at the Welikada prison, demanding freedom after President Maithripala Sirisena pardoned Jude Jayamaha, convicted of murdering a Swedish teenager. Over 1,000 prisoners refused to return to their cells, and four climbed onto the prison's roof. The pardons came after Jayamaha's term in prison was nearing its end. The move has sparked widespread outrage, with the prisoners calling for their own freedom.

site_title: Arctic blast to send Eastern US into deep freeze
summary: A deep freeze is sweeping across the Eastern US, bringing snow and ice that has left at least four dead, including an 8-year-old girl in Kansas. Temperatures are expected to break daily records across the eastern half of the country, reaching as low as -1°F in Sioux City, Iowa, and 25°F in Greenwood, Mississippi. The cold front is expected to affect areas from the Southern Plains to the Ohio River Valley, with snowfall reaching up to 1 foot in the Northeast.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 0.8% ahead of Trump's US trade policy speech
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.8% to 3,267.80 on Tuesday, driven by gains from major counters such as United Engineers, Food Empire, and Golden Agri-Resources. Investors are positioning themselves ahead of US President Donald Trump's speech on US trade policy, which could impact the market. Trading volume was high, with 1.63 billion securities traded, and investors remain cautious despite a 5-day rally.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.3% to 7,352.20 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also gaining 0.3% and 0.4% respectively. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were also a focus. In other markets, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Temasek injects more money into UK-based startup pureLiFi
summary: Temasek Holdings has invested in pureLiFi, a UK-based startup that uses light to deliver high-speed and secure internet. The US$18 million Series B round will be used to supply LiFi technology to mass-market mobile device and lighting manufacturers. pureLiFi aims to lead the advancement of LiFi chipsets for consumer devices, with a projected market size of US$75.5 billion by 2023. The company will focus on developing gigabit LiFi components and partnering with manufacturers such as Getac and O2 Telefonica.

site_title: L'Oreal, Nestle score big at Alibaba's Singles' Day shopping fest
summary: Alibaba's Singles' Day shopping festival generated a record 268.4 billion yuan (S$52.19 billion) in sales, surpassing 100 million yuan gross merchandise value for 299 brands, including L'Oreal and Nestle. Food supplements, makeup, and baby milk powder were top-selling import products. Sales growth eased to 26% from 30% in previous years, beating analyst expectations of 20-25% expansion. Analysts attribute the growth to aggressive promotions, targeting rural cities, and a slowing economy, with consumers seeking discounted prices.

images.alt_text: Chinese shoppers snapped up food supplements, facial masks and baby milk powder at the world's largest shopping festival, with brands such as L'Oreal and Nestle among the biggest winners, Alibaba data showed.

site_title: KrisEnergy Q3 loss widens to US$16.7m on lower oil prices, sale volumes
summary: KrisEnergy, an upstream oil and gas firm undergoing financial restructuring, reported a widened net loss of US$16.7 million in its third quarter, down from US$11 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 41.6% to US$22.9 million due to lower oil prices and sale volumes. The company's average realised oil and liquids sale price fell 19.3% to US$57.15 per barrel, and shares have been suspended since August 14.

site_title: DBS Bank showcases sustainability efforts at SFF
summary: DBS Bank showcased its sustainability efforts at the Singapore Fintech Festival, featuring a carbon-neutral booth made from 95% compressed recycled straws and a "hanging garden" with plants to be rehomed after the festival.
