The bank also partnered with social enterprises to collect and compost used coffee grounds, producing enough fertilizer for one year. DBS aims to minimize its carbon footprint by returning materials to suppliers and recycling materials. The initiative is part of the bank's commitment to creating a sustainable future.

images.alt_text: From left: Pamela Chng, founder of Bettr Barista;Karen Ngui, head of group strategic marketing and communications at DBS Bank;Samuell Ang, general manager of Edible Garden City

site_title: TransferWise CEO preps for Malaysia launch, no IPO plans for now
summary: TransferWise, a fintech startup, is launching an international payments service in Malaysia as part of its Asian expansion. CEO Kristo Kaarmann stated that the company has no immediate plans for an initial public offering (IPO) at a $3.5 billion valuation, which has been profitable for three years. The company has been expanding beyond existing markets in Singapore, Hong Kong, and other countries, and has recently opened an office in Brussels, preparing for potential Brexit outcomes.

site_title: Oxley posts Q1 net profit of S$12.2m, reverses year-ago loss
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a net profit of S$12.2 million for the first quarter ended Sept 30, reversing a year-ago loss of S$655,000. Revenue increased 66% to S$282.8 million, driven by higher gross profit from hotels and development projects in Singapore, and gains from property revaluation and derivatives. However, gains were partially offset by higher foreign exchange losses, finance costs, and consultancy fees. Earnings per share rose to 0.29 Singapore cent from a loss of 0.02 cent a year ago.

site_title: Ho Ching urges others to join Temasek to report on electricity, transport usage to fight global warming
summary: Temasek Holdings CEO Ho Ching urges businesses to report on electricity and transport usage to combat global warming. Starting from the next financial year, Temasek will track and report on its own electricity, water, and air miles, with a goal of halving greenhouse gas emissions by 2030. Ho Ching also suggests that businesses report on their direct emissions from burning fossil fuels or green forests, and water consumption, to start reducing emissions and waste. Temasek aims to become carbon neutral by 2020 and is investing in sustainable solutions, including plant-based proteins and better fertilizers.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump on chipmakers; investors eye Trump speech
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.79% on Tuesday, driven by gains in chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, which closed up 2% and 2.3% respectively. The Kospi index ended at 2,140.92, boosted by expectations of higher demand for chips. US President Donald Trump's speech later in the day may offer clues on trade talks with China, which has investors anxiously awaiting any positive news.

site_title: Central bank of France to set up first Asian office in Singapore
summary: The central bank of France, Banque de France, plans to establish its first Asian office in Singapore in early 2020. The move aims to boost monitoring of Asian economies and financial systems, as well as strengthen relations with central banks and financial authorities in the region. The office will also set up a dealing room to better serve international official sector entities. The partnership is seen as a key step in strengthening France's link with the Asian continent in a globalized world.

site_title: Singapore beats out Hong Kong for property investment prospects
summary: Singapore has taken the top spot for real estate investment prospects in Asia, with apartment prices rebounding and the office sector absorbing oversupply, according to a report by Urban Land Institute and PricewaterhouseCoopers. Hong Kong, hit by anti-government protests, has dropped to the bottom of the list, while other cities such as Ho Chi Minh City, Bangkok, and Sydney round out the top five. The report attributes Singapore's success to its relative stability and avoidance of geopolitical risks.

site_title: The Zagat guide is back in print
summary: The Zagat guide is back in print after a three-year hiatus, with the release of the 2020 New York City restaurant guide. The 352-page book retains its classic design and features the same top-rated restaurants as the 2017 guide, including Le Bernardin, Gramercy Tavern, and Peter Luger Steak House. The Infatuation, which acquired the brand last year, consulted with the original creators, Tim and Nina Zagat, to restore the rating system and consulted over 12,000 people in the voting process.

site_title: Podcast: SFF x Switch 2019 Ep 4: Deciphering crypto
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) head Ravi Menon discusses whether central banks need to issue digital currencies, amid Facebook's Libra stablecoin sparking debate on cryptocurrencies as a new form of money. Menon explains that central banks don't need to issue digital currencies, citing the existing role of commercial banks and the potential risks of digital currencies. The MAS will participate in the Singapore Fintech Festival and Singapore Week of Innovation and Technology, running from November 11-15.

site_title: Singapore fintechs dominate funding within Asean: report
summary: Singaporean fintech firms continue to dominate funding in the Asean region, attracting over 51% of total funding in 2019. The city-state remains the preferred base for fintech firms, with 45% of such firms in Asean, and Singapore-based firms receiving the most evenly distributed funding across insurance technology, payments, and personal finance. The report highlights Singapore's favourable regulatory environment and strong investor interest as key factors in its attractiveness to fintech firms.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Revolut CEO Nikolay Storonsky stated that having a banking license in Singapore doesn't make sense due to capital requirements. A new report by UOB, PwC, and the SFA found that Singapore remains the preferred base for fintech firms in Asean. Retail sales in Singapore dropped 2.2% in September for the 8th straight monthly decline. Condo resale prices rose 0.8% in October, while Singapore shares gained 0.8% ahead of a US trade policy speech by Trump.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Tuesday, driven by gains in the construction sector. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.81% to close at 23,520.01, while the Topix index rose 0.33%. Investors remained cautious over the US-China trade deal and unrest in Hong Kong.

site_title: Amazon confirms plans for store under new grocery brand
summary: Amazon plans to launch a new grocery store brand in 2020, separate from its Whole Foods Market chain. The store will have a conventional checkout line and will offer a wider range of products, including non-organic options. This move comes as Amazon seeks to expand its presence in the US$900 billion grocery industry, where it has yet to make significant headway. The new brand is expected to open in the Los Angeles neighborhood of Woodland Hills.

site_title: Qantas to drop Sydney-Beijing route due to competition from China carriers
summary: Qantas will discontinue its Sydney-Beijing route in March due to increased competition from Chinese airlines and weak business class demand. The airline had previously relaunched the route in 2017 but had lowered the number of weekly flights. Qantas will redeploy the Airbus A330 capacity to other Asian routes. Despite this, the airline maintains daily flights from Sydney to Shanghai, where it partners with China Eastern Airlines. The decision reflects the growing competition in the market and Qantas' focus on more profitable routes.

site_title: Wall Street bonuses poised to drop as banks focus on cost cuts
summary: Wall Street bonuses are expected to drop in 2019, with equity traders facing a 15% decline and debt and equity underwriters seeing a 10% drop. Fixed-income traders may see a 5% decrease. Banks are focusing on cost cuts due to muted capital markets results and uncertain interest rates. Hedge fund and private equity bonuses are expected to rise 5%. Johnson Associates' managing director Alan Johnson attributes the decline to increased competition, saying the industry is in the "new normal."

images.alt_text: Traders and bankers hoping a better-than-expected third quarter would boost their year-end pay are likely to be disappointed.

site_title: AEM names ST Engineering's Chandran Nair group president
summary: AEM Holdings appointed Chandran Nair as its group president, effective January 1, 2020, to support global growth and new business units. Nair, previously president of ST Engineering's robotics and autonomous systems business, brings experience in semiconductor test and automation. AEM shares rose 2.9% after the announcement, with Nair's ability to direct change and drive performance seen as an asset to the executive management team.

site_title: Revolut bows out of Singapore digibank race: CEO
summary: Revolut's CEO, Nikolay Storonsky, announced the fintech company is bowing out of Singapore's digital banking licence race due to high capital requirements. The minimum paid-up capital for a digital full bank in Singapore is S$1.5 billion within three to five years, which Revolut deemed unfeasible. Despite being in talks with several companies in Singapore, Revolut chose not to pursue the licence, citing its focus on other markets. The company had launched its multicurrency e-wallet services in Singapore earlier this month and has amassed over 30,000 active users.

images.alt_text: "Based on our initial analysis, it does not make sense to have a banking licence here because of the capital requirements," said Revolut chief executive Nikolay Storonsky at the sidelines of the Singapore FinTech Festival and Singapore Week of Innovation and TeCHnology (SFF x SWITCH) conference.

site_title: Want to lose money? Run Saudi and Russian crude in an oil refinery
summary: Refineries in key processing regions, including Singapore and South Korea, would lose money if running solely on Saudi Arabia's Arab Light crude and Russia's Urals, according to data from Oil Analytics Ltd. The decline is partly due to high prices for the two crudes and a slump in the market for high-sulphur fuel oil, which will be phased out by the IMO 2020 regulations. The new rules favor low-sulphur crudes, which are expected to benefit refineries that can efficiently process these crudes, while others may struggle to sell at favorable prices.

site_title: Asian investors make the move into Europe
summary: Asian investors are increasingly focusing on Europe, particularly Central and Eastern Europe, due to attractive yields and investment opportunities. Key drivers include currency trends, market maturation, and valuations in Asia. Asian investors, mainly from Singapore, South Korea, and Hong Kong, are targeting logistics, office space, and student housing. The trend is expected to continue, with opportunities in smaller European countries and developing Asian markets. However, Brexit uncertainty may impact UK investments, and yield compression is a concern as Asian investors enter the market.

site_title: Shifting the focus of breast cancer to prevention
summary: A growing percentage of women survive breast cancer, but the disease remains a leading cancer killer. Efforts to reduce breast cancer mortality have shifted from post-surgical treatment to prevention, with long-term studies highlighting protective measures that could significantly reduce the risk of developing breast cancer. These include risk-reducing medications, such as tamoxifen, raloxifene, and aromatase inhibitors, and lifestyle changes, such as regular physical activity, a healthy diet, and avoiding excess weight. Experts emphasize the importance of adopting these measures, even if they may not eliminate the risk entirely, as the disease can still develop despite preventive efforts.

images.alt_text: Efforts to reduce deaths from breast cancer in women have long focused on early detection and post-surgical treatment with drugs, radiation or both to help keep the disease at bay. And both of these approaches, used alone or together, have resulted in a dramatic reduction in breast cancer mortality in recent decades.

site_title: Chicken 'billionaire' Poland is Europe's poultry king
summary: Poland has become Europe's top chicken producer and exporter, raising over a billion chickens for meat last year. The country's poultry industry has grown significantly over the last decade, with many farms like the one in Kondrajec Panski housing up to 54,000 chickens. Animal rights activists criticize the living conditions of chickens on industrial farms, citing practices such as force-feeding and inhumane slaughter methods. Despite this, Poland's poultry exports are thriving, with EU countries like Germany and the Netherlands being major markets.

site_title: Protesters hit Hong Kong commute as western powers urge restraint
summary: Protesters in Hong Kong disrupted the city's commute for a second day, blocking roads and subway trains, amid spiraling violence following police shootings and clashes with protesters. Western powers, including the US and Britain, urged restraint and called for dialogue. Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam criticized protesters for using violence to achieve democratic freedoms, while protesters claim Beijing is tightening control over the city. The situation remains volatile, with protesters and police engaging in cat-and-mouse clashes, and the city's transport network severely affected.

site_title: Singapore retail sales down 2.2% in September for 8th straight monthly fall
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 2.2% in September for the 8th consecutive month, but this was slightly better than predicted economists' 3% fall. The decline was mainly driven by motor vehicles, furniture, and household equipment. However, some categories, such as computer equipment, wearing apparel, and medical goods, saw strong growth. Retail sales are expected to recover in the coming months due to healthy employment figures, rising salaries, and strong consumption demand. The full-year retail sales contraction is predicted to be 2%, milder than the 2.5% year-to-date fall for the first nine months.

images.alt_text: Singapore's retail sales fell 2.2 per cent in September, in the eighth straight month of year-on-year decline, according to latest Department of Statistics figures on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia downgrade deals another blow to flying safety in Asia
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) downgraded Malaysia to a Category 2 nation, restricting Malaysian carriers from setting up new flights to US airspace. This move, effective immediately, affects airlines such as AirAsia X, and is based on deficiencies in the Civil Aviation Authority of Malaysia in areas like technical expertise and record keeping. The downgrade may negatively impact public perception, maintenance business, and employment opportunities for local pilots and engineers, potentially driving up insurance premiums and leasing rates.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's aviation-safety downgrade makes Asia the region with the most markets where airlines are restricted from US airspace.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as dealers await trade news, Hong Kong rises
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday as investors awaited developments in the China-US trade talks. Hong Kong rebounded after Monday's steep losses, while the pound rose against the dollar and euro due to news that the Brexit party would not run against Boris Johnson's Conservatives in the UK general election. Despite expectations of a mini trade pact, the talks remain fragile, and markets are operating on limited information. Hong Kong's unrest continues, with sporadic protests, and the US expressed concern over the situation. Tokyo and Singapore rose, while Shanghai and Sydney fell.

site_title: Jimmy Carter hospitalised for procedure to relieve brain pressure
summary: Former US President Jimmy Carter, 95, was hospitalized on Monday for a procedure to relieve brain pressure due to recent falls. The procedure, to be performed on Tuesday morning, aims to alleviate pressure caused by bleeding. Carter, who suffered a fractured pelvis in October, also injured his head in a fall earlier in the month but continued to volunteer. His wife, Rosalynn, is by his side, and he is resting comfortably.

site_title: Amaravati capital city startup area project terminated: Sembcorp
summary: Sembcorp Industries has terminated its 684-hectare startup area project in Amaravati, the new capital city of Andhra Pradesh, following a change in scenario for the development of the city. The project, expected to take over 20 years, had been in the early stages and incurred costs of "a few million dollars" for design services. The closure will not impact Sembcorp's and CapitaLand's investment plans in India. The decision comes after the Andhra Pradesh government decided not to proceed with the startup area, citing other priorities for the state.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon up 0.37% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.37% on Tuesday, driven by gains from ST Engineering, which posted a 3.4% rise in net profit, and Mapletree Commercial Trust, which saw a 2.73% increase. Other active stocks, such as Golden Agri-Resources and United Overseas Bank, also saw gains. The index closed at 3,252.59 points, with 804.9 million shares worth S$572.9 million traded.

site_title: Record 201t won is flowing from South Korea into riskier assets
summary: South Korean investors are pouring tens of billions of dollars into unconventional assets abroad, seeking higher yields amid sagging equity and bond returns. Record holdings of overseas alternative assets have reached 201 trillion won (S$234.84 billion), with investors joining global peers in taking on higher risks. However, some signs of trouble are emerging, including disputes over investments and problems with underlying assets. Experts warn that investors should exercise caution and set up adequate processes to mitigate risks, recommending more selective investment strategies and lower-risk assets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks bounce at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index adding 0.51% to 27,064.26, following sharp declines the previous day. Investors remained cautious amid fresh protests in the city. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.10% and the Shenzhen Composite Index was flat. The gains were driven by bargain-buying, but the market's trajectory remains uncertain.

site_title: Travis Kalanick sells 20% of his stake in Uber after lockup
summary: Travis Kalanick, Uber's 43-year-old director, sold approximately 20% of his stake in the company, worth around $547 million, after a 180-day lockup period. The sale comes as Uber's shares have tumbled 40% since its initial public offering, reducing the company's value from $76 billion to $46 billion. Despite the sale, Kalanick still owns 78 million shares, a 4.6% stake, and has a net worth of around $3.7 billion.

site_title: Capsule living: a 'cheap' option for young people flocking to LA
summary: Capsule living, inspired by Japanese hotels, has become a "cheap" option for young people in Los Angeles, particularly those with artistic aspirations. UP(st)ART, a community offering affordable housing with amenities like a gym and recording studio, charges $750/month, roughly half the rent of a studio in LA. While some view this as a short-term solution, others see it as a viable option, with residents like Kimma Moonshine finding it ideal for working on their art.

site_title: Fitch Solutions sees Singapore sugar rules having little impact on consumer spending on beverages
summary: Fitch Solutions predicts Singapore's sugar regulations for sugar-sweetened beverages will have little impact on consumer spending. Industry companies have already adjusted products, and the regulation focuses on informing consumers rather than taxation. Consumer spending on carbonated beverages is expected to grow 1.5% per capita from 2019 to 2023, averaging S$37 per annum. The regulation's focus on labelling and advertising rather than taxation limits its potential impact on consumer behavior.

site_title: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam says protesters 'paralysing' the city are selfish
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam criticized protesters as "selfish" for trying to "paralyze" the city, calling them the "people's enemy" as violence escalated. Police shot a protester and set a man on fire in dramatic scenes. Lam praised residents who volunteered to clear roadblocks and respected those who went to work despite difficult conditions. The city braced for further disruptions after many workers were sent home early and shops shut due to the violence.

site_title: WeWork in talks with John Legere of T-Mobile for CEO job: sources
summary: WeWork is in talks with John Legere, the CEO of T-Mobile, for the CEO job, according to sources. Legere is considered a candidate due to his track record of reviving T-Mobile since becoming its CEO in 2012. WeWork is seeking a new CEO to lead the company's overhaul after receiving a bailout from SoftBank and facing questions about its business model and governance. The company is expected to lay off thousands of employees and sell non-core operations, and Legere would face significant conflicts of interest due to SoftBank's control over both companies.

site_title: LTA to deploy 60 electric buses by ST Engineering, Chinese firms next year
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) plans to deploy 60 electric buses by ST Engineering and Chinese firms Yutong and BYD by the first half of next year. The e-buses, which can carry 80-120 passengers, will undergo a trial to test their performance under local traffic and weather conditions. The trial aims to reduce carbon emissions by 7,840 tonnes annually, equivalent to 1,700 passenger cars. The new buses will feature increased accessibility and user-friendliness, including colour passenger information display systems and easier boarding with open strollers.

site_title: Top K-pop awards show pulls out from Hong Kong due to protests
summary: The Mnet Asian Music Awards (MAMA) has cancelled its Hong Kong event due to months-long political unrest in the city. The decision follows a number of other events, including tennis and football matches, being postponed or cancelled. The show's organiser, CJ ENM, cited "various circumstances" as the reason for the venue change, and instead plans to hold the event in Nagoya, Japan on December 4. This marks the first time the festival will not take place in Hong Kong, which had hosted the event since 2012.

site_title: Moody's cuts global sovereign rating outlook to 'negative' for 2020
summary: Moody's cut its global sovereign rating outlook to 'negative' for 2020 due to unpredictable world politics and trade wars, which will slow growth and increase economic risk. This move affects countries such as Britain, South Africa, India, Mexico, Turkey, and Hong Kong. Moody's cited three main drivers for the downgrade: unpredictable politics, trade wars, and their impact on open and commodity-exporting economies.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip on trade talk uncertainties; New Zealand edges higher
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Tuesday, tracking US market losses, amid uncertainty over Sino-US trade talks. US President Donald Trump's comments over the weekend, which included incorrect reporting about US willingness to lift tariffs, dampened sentiment. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index edged higher, with utility firm Meridian Energy Ltd gaining 1% and Spark New Zealand rising 0.9%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 3.86 points to 1,612.01. The market saw a gain of 114 to 63 in favor of gainers over losers, with 45.32 million lots traded worth RM15.46 million.

site_title: US Supreme Court to examine 'Dreamers' programme that Trump wants axed
summary: The US Supreme Court will examine the fate of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) programme, which provides protection from deportation for approximately 700,000 undocumented immigrants who entered the US as children. The programme was established by the Obama administration in 2012 and was ended by President Donald Trump in 2017, citing that it was established illegally. The court will hear arguments on whether the programme's phase-out was lawful and if the Trump administration acted arbitrarily in ending it. A decision is expected next year, potentially affecting the lives of hundreds of thousands of "Dreamers."

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday's open despite HK, trade woes; STI up 0.38%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.38% to 3,252.98 points on Tuesday, recovering from the previous day's losses despite Hong Kong's escalating violence and US-China trade uncertainty. Banking stocks led gains, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC increasing 0.38%, 0.34%, and 0.18% respectively. Other gainers included ST Engineering, which rose 2.25% after announcing a 3.4% net profit increase.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices extend climb in October: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices rose 0.8% in October, faster than the 0.4% increase in September, with volumes rising 3.6% to 807 units. Year-on-year, prices increased 2.0% and volumes were 14.8% higher than the five-year average. The highest transacted price was S$29.5 million for a unit at The Marq On Paterson Hill. Strong demand and market optimism for new homes may have driven the increase, but prices still lag behind those of new home sales.

images.alt_text: The highest transacted price for a resale unit for October went to a unit at The Marq On Paterson Hill for S$29.5 million, which translated to about S$4,677 per square foot.

site_title: Australia readies for 'catastrophic' bushfires
summary: Thousands of firefighters in eastern Australia prepared for "catastrophic" bushfires on November 12, 2019, as gale-force winds and scorching temperatures fueled massive blazes. Dozens of fires were burning out of control, threatening a vast region surrounding Sydney, with temperatures expected to reach 40°C and winds topping 60 km/h. The New South Wales Rural Fire Service warned of an "off the scale" threat, with up to 600 schools closed and residents advised to evacuate. The fire season was already on track to be one of Australia's worst on record, with over 1 million hectares burned in New South Wales alone.

site_title: Hyatt to bid for Xenia's US$500m Kimpton portfolio
summary: Hyatt Hotels Corp is emerging as a bidder for Xenia Hotels & Resorts Inc's US$500m Kimpton portfolio, which includes luxury hotels in Chicago, Denver, and Salt Lake City. The management contracts for the portfolio can be terminated in the event of a sale. Xenia has received multiple offers for the portfolio, and its shares have gained 22% this year, compared to a 5% gain for the Bloomberg REIT Hotels Index. The sale could potentially fetch US$500 million.

site_title: London pupils shine through Steve McQueen's new artwork
summary: British artist Steve McQueen has photographed over 76,000 London schoolchildren in their class groups for a new exhibition at the Tate Britain. The project, featuring 3,128 class photographs, offers a "hopeful portrait of a generation to come" and is also displayed on billboards across the city. The work aims to capture the hopes, mischief, and personalities of the children, providing a unique insight into their lives at the age of seven and eight. The exhibition showcases McQueen's large-scale photography project.

site_title: MAS, Deloitte, S&P create prototype research platform for fintech investments
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), Deloitte, and S&P Global Market Intelligence have developed a prototype digital research platform to enhance transparency and confidence in fintech investments. The platform aims to provide comprehensive views of fintech companies, including business models, funding, and technology stack. It will enable investors and financial institutions to connect with fintech startups, facilitating faster decision-making and increased confidence in early-stage companies. The MAS, Deloitte, and S&P will continue to explore opportunities to develop the platform further, with the goal of improving the deployment of capital in startups.

site_title: Yanlord raises cash offer for United Engineers to S$2.70 apiece from S$2.60
summary: Yanlord Land Group, a China-based property developer, has increased its cash offer for United Engineers to S$2.70 per share from S$2.60. The offer now values UE at S$1.66 billion. Yanlord has acquired 6.15% of UE shares, bringing its total ownership to 41.42%. The offer document and acceptance forms will be sent to shareholders on November 13, and Yanlord will not revise the price further unless a competitive situation arises.

site_title: Tencent should be split up
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd, China's largest company, is hiding a valuable fintech business. The division, which includes payments and wealth management, could be worth up to $230 billion, making it China's fourth-largest listed company and the world's sixth-biggest financial services firm. Analysts estimate the business could unlock significant value by spinning it off into a separate company, potentially rivaling Alibaba's Ant Financial Services Group. This move could help Tencent regain its limelight and unlock the full potential of its fintech business, which has grown by over 70% in the past year.

site_title: Tencent Music's quarterly revenue beats on subscriber growth
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group reported a quarterly revenue beat, driven by subscriber growth, with a 31% increase to 6.51 billion yuan. The company added more paying users to its social entertainment services unit, with a 23.2% rise to 12.2 million users, but the growth metric slowed down. Tencent Music's music streaming unit saw a 42% jump in paid users, while the company's net income rose to 1.02 billion yuan. Despite a larger user base, the company's paying users are fewer than those of Spotify, with about 35 million compared to Spotify's 100 million.

site_title: HDB launches 8,170 flats for sale, including 4,500 BTO flats in Tengah, Ang Mo Kio and Tampines
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has launched 8,170 new flats for sale, including 4,571 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in Tengah, Ang Mo Kio, and Tampines. Prices start from S$110,000 for a two-room flexi flat and S$442,000 for a three-generation flat. The flats are available in three Tengah projects and mature estates Ang Mo Kio and Tampines. Eligible buyers can tap into the Enhanced CPF Housing Grant of up to S$80,000. Application for the flats closes on November 18.

site_title: Burger King eyes big bite of Europe market with 'veggie Whopper'
summary: Burger King has launched its 'veggie Whopper' in 25 European countries and 2,500 restaurants, aiming to capture a significant share of the growing plant-based food market. The vegetarian version of its prime 'Whopper' hamburger was tested in the US and Sweden before its European launch. Company president David Shear believes this is the biggest production launch in Europe and sees significant potential for the category's growth.

site_title: Datapulse appoints ICP unit to manage Seoul hotel
summary: Datapulse Technology has appointed ICP unit Travelodge Hotels Asia to manage Hotel Aropa in Seoul, South Korea, after an audit committee deemed the hotel management agreements as normal commercial terms and not prejudicial to the company's interests. The appointment followed a rigorous hotel operator selection process, which included two other candidates and a global commercial real estate services firm as a consultant. Datapulse chairman Aw Cheok Huat, who owns 20.8% in ICP, excused himself from the process due to his indirect stake in Datapulse.

site_title: GIC, BlackRock buy UK gas pipeline firm Kellas Midstream
summary: Sovereign wealth fund GIC and asset manager BlackRock have agreed to buy UK gas pipeline firm Kellas Midstream from private equity firm Antin Infrastructure Partners. The joint venture will acquire the firm's key gas infrastructure in the UK Central and Southern North Sea, including the Central Area Transmission System, Esmond Transportation System, and Humber Gathering System. The deal is expected to close in early 2020 and is part of a growing trend of institutional investors seeking exposure to energy and power investments.

site_title: Ignoring women costs the financial industry US$700b a year
summary: The financial industry is losing approximately $700 billion annually by failing to cater to women's needs, according to a report by Oliver Wyman. This under-served group is missing out on revenue due to products defaulting to men's needs and lack of women in senior management. The report highlights that insurers could generate $500 million in new premiums if they sold life policies to women at the same rate as men, and wealth and asset managers could lose $25 billion in fees. The industry's gender gap remains a challenge, with only 20% of finance executives globally being women.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank's quarterly profit slides amid record-low interest rates
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia reported a near 10% drop in first-quarter cash profit due to margin pressure from record-low interest rates. The bank's net interest margin fell from the June quarter, and headwinds from low interest rates will continue to impact margins. The bank's cash profit fell to A$2.26 billion for the three months ending in September, compared to A$2.50 billion a year earlier. Despite this, CBA's shares rose 1% to A$80.85 in early morning trade.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MCT, First Resources, Raffles Medical, UE, Bumitama, Vicom, KSH
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) raised S$460.5 million from a preferential offering, issuing 205.6 million new units at S$2.24 apiece. First Resources posted a 28.5% drop in net profit to US$27.9 million in its third quarter, mainly due to weaker palm oil prices.

site_title: France, UK, Germany, EU 'extremely concerned' by Iran's nuclear deal breach
summary: France, Germany, the UK, and the EU expressed "extreme concern" over Iran's re-starting nuclear activities at the Fordow facility, breaching the 2015 Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action. The International Atomic Energy Agency confirmed the move. The EU urges Iran to reverse measures inconsistent with the agreement, calling for compliance.

site_title: SunMoon narrows Q2 net loss to S$304,000
summary: SunMoon Food Company reported a Q2 net loss of S$304,000, narrowing from S$2.1 million in the previous year. Revenue declined 86% to S$2 million due to a shift in focus from uncertain margin growth to sustainable growth with more certain margin. The company has reorganized its operations and reduced costs. Despite this, it expects a negative impact on short-term revenue and will not achieve year-on-year revenue growth. SunMoon will continue to focus on value-added fresh fruit products and expand its agri-food offerings.

site_title: Wall Street's very own unicorn emerges in private credit frenzy
summary: Owl Rock Capital, a four-year-old private credit firm, has secured a $500 million investment from Neuberger Berman's Dyal Capital Partners, valuing the company at $2.5 billion. Founded by three veteran Wall Street dealmakers, Owl Rock has amassed over $14 billion in capital through business development companies. The investment will support the launch of a new publicly traded BDC and a new opportunities fund. The deal highlights the growth of the private credit market, which is on pace to reach $1 trillion by next year.

site_title: US frack sand suppliers latest casualties in shale industry slump
summary: US frack sand suppliers face the latest casualties of the shale industry slump due to low oil prices and demands for higher investor returns. Two years ago, over 20 West Texas mines opened, leading to an oversupply and subsequent price drop of 80% from its peak. Companies like Carbo Ceramics, ProPetro Holding Corp, and Halliburton Co are closing mines, idling equipment, and cutting jobs. Industry experts estimate the market is oversupplied by 15 million tons a year, with US Silica predicting some competitors will shut down, helping next year's margins.

site_title: Bumitama Q3 profit slips 29.7% on lower palm oil prices
summary: Indonesian palm oil producer Bumitama Agri reported a 29.7% decline in third-quarter net profit to 189.61 billion rupiah due to weaker palm oil prices. Revenue rose 1.4% to 1.94 trillion rupiah, but cost of sales increased 7.7% and finance costs rose 33.1%. The company has not declared a dividend and plans to redeploy its cash reserves for development and operations. Palm oil prices are expected to continue improving due to lower production and higher demand.

site_title: Asia's 'mini Chinas' struggle to capitalise on US trade war
summary: Asia's 'mini Chinas' are struggling to capitalize on the US-China trade war, with no single economy able to replicate China's success. A report by Bloomberg Economics identified India and Indonesia as potential winners, but found they face structural problems such as inadequate infrastructure and political instability. India and Indonesia have made progress in manufacturing, but their working age populations and infrastructure are still lagging behind China. Vietnam, often cited as a potential winner, is also hindered by infrastructure issues and rising port congestion. New technologies are changing the nature of global production, making it harder for countries to reproduce China's success.

site_title: First Resources Q3 profit falls 28.5% on weaker palm oil prices
summary: First Resources, a palm oil producer, reported a 28.5% drop in net profit to US$27.9 million for its third quarter, mainly due to weaker palm oil prices. Sales fell 19.7% to US$137.6 million, and earnings per share decreased to 1.76 US cents. The company attributed the decline to lower average selling prices, but expects production to pick up seasonally. Despite concerns over slower supply growth and Indonesia's biodiesel mandate, First Resources believes the palm oil industry's long-term fundamentals remain positive.

site_title: South African Airways restructuring to affect nearly 1,000 workers
summary: South African Airways (SAA) is restructuring, potentially leading to job losses for 944 employees. The airline, struggling with debt and revenue issues, has been aided by government bailouts. Finance Minister Tito Mboweni announced a plan to reimburse the company's 9.2-billion rand debt over three years. The restructuring process aims to address challenges including insufficient revenue, volatile fuel prices, and mounting debt, following a period of corruption and mismanagement in the country's state-owned companies.

site_title: CNMC Goldmine Q3 profit surges to US$2m on gold prices
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings reported a US$2 million profit in its third quarter, more than eight times the US$235,611 profit in the same period last year. The surge was driven by record gold prices, lack of listing expenses, and a one-off Malaysia tax reversal. The company sold gold bars at an average price of US$1,494.95 per ounce, up from US$1,205.02 in 2018. Earnings per share rose to 0.49 US cents from 0.06 US cents in the same period.

site_title: Oil slips as trade worries offset Cushing drawdown
summary: Oil prices slipped as US-China trade negotiations showed little progress, keeping prices pressured despite bullish inventory data in the US. Brent crude fell 33 cents to settle at $62.18 a barrel, while US WTI crude fell 38 cents to settle at $56.86 a barrel. Analysts worry about a potential supply glut in 2020 due to the ongoing trade war, which has slowed economic growth worldwide. Inventory data at Cushing, the delivery point for WTI, showed a 1.2 million barrel drop, providing some support.

site_title: US solar-panel maker SunPower spins off production into Singapore-based firm
summary: US solar-panel maker SunPower is spinning off its panel production operations into Singapore-based firm Maxeon Solar, focusing on installing rooftop systems. The move, valued at $1.03 billion, comes as the industry matures and companies specialize in one area. SunPower will continue to run its installation business, while Maxeon will be led by CEO Jeff Waters. The spin-off marks a shift in strategy for SunPower, which will now focus on high-efficiency panels for space-constrained installations.

images.alt_text: SunPower Corp, one of America's largest solar-panel makers, is giving up its manufacturing business to focus on installing rooftop systems.

site_title: Australian business activity improves modestly in Oct: survey
summary: Australia's business conditions improved modestly in October, according to a survey, with the National Australia Bank's index of business conditions rising one point to +3. Sales and employment also showed a slight increase. However, forward-looking indicators have improved, suggesting a possible stabilisation in conditions. The economy has been experiencing a soft patch, with sluggish consumer spending and lacklustre wage growth. Despite interest rate cuts and tax rebates, the business sector remains under pressure, with inflation rising amid higher import costs.

images.alt_text: A closely watched measure of Australian business conditions edged higher in October as firms reported a much-needed pick up in sales, offering a hint of stabilisation after months of weakness.

site_title: At UN, North Korea accuses US of holding back progress
summary: North Korea's ambassador to the UN, Kim Song, accused the US and South Korea of hostility hindering peace on the peninsula during a UN speech. North Korea has not conducted nuclear or long-range missile tests in over 20 months, a moratorium often praised by President Trump. The ambassador blamed US provocations and South Korea's "double-dealing" behavior for the lack of progress, despite Trump's hopes for a landmark deal. The US insists on tangible denuclearization steps before easing sanctions.

site_title: Mexico grants asylum to Bolivian leader Morales: foreign minister
summary: Mexico has granted asylum to Bolivian President Evo Morales, who stepped down amid protests and growing unrest over his re-election. Morales, 60, requested asylum after departing Bolivia, citing humanitarian reasons. The decision was made by Interior Minister Olga Sanchez Cordero, and Morales will receive asylum with immediate effect for his protection. Morales had been in power since 2006 and was facing massive protests over his re-election. Mexico had announced its willingness to grant asylum on Sunday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat amid concerns over trade, Hong Kong
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Tuesday amid concerns over a US-China trade deal and unrest in Hong Kong. The Nikkei 225 index edged up 0.06%, while the Topix index fell 0.10%. The flat opening follows global markets' resilience to new US threats, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened almost flat on Tuesday amid worries over a US-China trade deal and fresh unrest in Hong Kong.

site_title: US$2b investment boost for Singapore's green finance push
summary: Singapore has launched a US$2 billion Green Investments Programme (GIP) to support the growth of climate-friendly projects and deepen green finance activities in the country. The initiative will channel funds to asset managers committed to investing in public market firms with a strong green focus. The programme aims to spur investments in renewable energy, green buildings, and carbon sequestration, and will also develop grant schemes to support green lending. The move is part of Singapore's efforts to become a global green finance hub and mitigate the risks of climate change.

site_title: Uber chief walks back comment about murder of Saudi journalist Khashoggi
summary: Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi apologized for calling the assassination of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi a "mistake," walking back his previous remarks. In a tweet, Khosrowshahi stated he was wrong to downplay the incident and expressed regret for not being clear about his views. Khashoggi was strangled and dismembered in 2018, prompting harsh criticism of Saudi Arabia. Khosrowshahi's comments sparked an uproar in the US, and he downplayed the kingdom's role in Uber, stating they are just another shareholder.

site_title: Red alert for GOP or code blue for Democrats?
summary: The US Republican Party is losing support among white voters, while Democrats risk alienating them. This shift is similar to the decline of the Whig Party in the 19th century, which failed to adapt to changing social and economic conditions. In recent elections, Virginia and Kentucky have turned blue, with white suburban voters switching to the Democratic Party. The GOP is becoming a minority party, with mostly white middle-aged men representing rural areas. The electoral map is shifting, with suburbs turning purple and blue, while exurbs and rural areas remain GOP strongholds.

site_title: Leadership myths and mistakes
summary: A former HR and business management executive shares that leaders often fall prey to myths and mistakes, hindering company progress and employee productivity. The author, who built a team and business in Singapore and Asia, emphasizes the importance of empowering employees through trust-based, transparent, and high-performing work environments.

site_title: Chinese spend big in Singles' Day shopping spree
summary: Chinese consumers set a new record for spending on Singles' Day, with nearly 192 billion yuan (S$37.3 billion) spent within the first 12 hours, surpassing last year's full 24-hour record of US$30.7 billion. The e-commerce leader Alibaba reported strong sales, with US$1 billion spent in just 68 seconds, and total gross merchandise volume hitting 100 billion yuan within 64 minutes. The shopping event, now in its 11th year, reflects consumer sentiment in China's economy, which is experiencing an extended slowdown.

site_title: US: Stocks lose ground but Boeing news provides boost
summary: US stocks ended the day slightly higher, rebounding from early losses, as Boeing's announcement to return its 737 Max to service after two deadly crashes boosted the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Boeing shares jumped 4.6%, helping the Dow recover and end the day at 27,691.49. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also closed down, but the Dow's gain offset early losses. Investors await news on the US-China trade conflict, with government inflation data and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony scheduled for later in the week.

site_title: Boeing says 737 Max expected to resume flying in January
summary: Boeing expects the 737 Max to resume flying in January, a month later than initially planned, after completing the first of five milestones required to return the aircraft to service. The company still hopes to receive certification from the FAA in December, allowing it to resume deliveries before the end of the year. Boeing has made changes to the plane's Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System and has completed a simulator evaluation with the FAA, but still needs to run additional tests with airline pilots and a multi-regulatory body to validate training requirements.

site_title: MAS-led payments network promises applicability beyond finance
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has developed a blockchain-based prototype for a multi-currency payments network, enabling payments in different currencies on the same network. The network aims to improve cost efficiencies for businesses and is undergoing industry testing. The prototype, part of Project Ubin, will provide interfaces for other blockchain networks to connect and integrate seamlessly, offering features such as delivery-versus-payment settlement and conditional payments. MAS hopes the development will encourage other central banks to conduct similar trials, making cross-border transactions faster, cheaper, and safer.

site_title: Europe: Defensive stocks help shares to end flat, London lags
summary: European shares ended flat on Monday, despite a turnaround in bank stocks and gains in sectors considered safer bets during times of economic uncertainty. London's FTSE 100 fell 0.4%, while stocks in Frankfurt dropped 0.2% and Paris rose 0.1%. Defensive stocks such as food and beverage and real estate helped recover losses, but European miners were the biggest losers. The Stoxx 600 index closed at its highest level in over four years last week, but investors remain cautious due to ongoing issues in Hong Kong, Spain, and the UK.

site_title: Trump expected to delay EU auto tariff decision for 6 more months: Politico
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to delay a decision on tariffs on imported European Union autos for six more months, according to Politico. The US must decide by November 14 whether to impose tariffs of up to 25% under the Section 232 law, which has already been delayed once. This decision affects the European Union's automotive industry, and Trump's delay may have implications for the global economy. The exact timing of the announcement is unclear, but it is expected to be made this week.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump is expected to announce this week that he is delaying a decision on whether to slap tariffs on imported European Union autos for another six months, Politico reported on Monday, citing an unnamed person familiar with the decision.

site_title: HK violence escalates; more clashes between police and protesters
summary: Violence escalated in Hong Kong on Monday, with clashes between police and protesters leaving downtown paralyzed and two men clinging to life. A police officer shot a protester at point-blank range, and a man was doused with petrol and set on fire. The violence sparked fears of further chaos, with Hong Kong stocks suffering their biggest loss in three months. The government urged protesters to remain calm, but Chief Executive Carrie Lam said violence would not prompt concessions, including an independent inquiry into police violence.

site_title: China gets backlash from HK and mainlanders over new rules
summary: China's new plan to ease property rules for Hong Kongers has sparked backlash on both sides of the border. The plan, part of the Greater Bay Area integration programme, aims to make it easier for Hong Kong residents to buy apartments in Guangdong province by exempting them from additional levies. However, mainland Chinese residents have taken to social media to express anger over perceived unfair treatment and high property prices. The move comes as Hong Kong grapples with its worst political crisis, with protests fueled by frustration with the government and sky-high property prices.

site_title: SpaceX sends up 60 mini-satellites with plans for thousands more
summary: SpaceX launched a Falcon-9 rocket from Cape Canaveral, Florida, placing 60 mini-satellites in orbit as part of its Starlink network, aiming to expand internet access globally. The company plans to launch 42,000 satellites, raising concerns among scientists about crowded skies and potential collisions. SpaceX CEO Elon Musk hopes to control 3-5% of the global internet market, valued at $30 billion annually, to finance his space ventures and eventually colonize Mars. The company has received authorization for 12,000 satellites and plans to launch 24 more to extend coverage worldwide.

site_title: Public healthcare agencies to adopt SGQR payments by end-2020
summary: DBS Bank is working with Singapore's public healthcare system to adopt the unified payment code, Singapore Quick Response Code (SGQR), by the end of 2020. The initiative aims to encourage a gradual shift to digital payments, with 27 public hospitals, specialty centers, and polyclinics launching SGQR in November. The move is part of Singapore's push towards a cashless and chequeless society, with around one in five consumers currently paying healthcare bills via cash or cheque. SGQR allows consumers to make payments by scanning a QR code with their mobile phones and typing in the bill reference number.

site_title: Dennis Tan quits as OCBC's head of consumer financial services; Sunny Quek to replace him
summary: Dennis Tan, 50, is leaving OCBC Bank's consumer financial services Singapore after 10 years, with Sunny Quek taking over as head, effective Nov 13, 2019. Tan, a member of the bank's group management committee, is pursuing other interests. Quek, previously head of branch and premier banking at Citibank Singapore, will report to Ching Wei Hong, OCBC's chief operating officer. Quek has led the premier banking business to be a leader in the affluent segment space, according to OCBC.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Zeemart cares for migrant workers
summary: Zeemart, a Singaporean company, has launched an initiative to care for migrant workers. On the Money FM podcast "Soul of Business," co-founder Keith Tan and head of talent Beena Natarajan discussed the new initiative as part of corporate social responsibility. The company aims to improve the lives of migrant workers through this effort, highlighting the importance of corporate purpose and social responsibility in the business world.

images.alt_text: From left: Claressa Monteiro, MONEY FM 89.3 presenter; Beena Natarajan, head of talent; Keith Tan, co-founder of Zeemart

site_title: ST Engineering Q3 profit rises 3.4% to S$139.1m
summary: ST Engineering reported a 3.4% rise in net profit to S$139.1 million for its third quarter, driven by higher revenue across all sectors. The aerospace segment saw a 53% increase in revenue and 17% in net profit, while electronics sector revenue rose 10% but net profit fell 7%. The company's order book stood at S$15.9 billion as of September 30, providing revenue visibility for the next few years.

site_title: Growth-stage funding gap holds back aspiring unicorns, say panellists
summary: A funding gap at the growth stage, also known as Series C and D, is hindering aspiring unicorns in Singapore. Early-stage investors focus on high return multiples, while late-stage backers prioritize proven business models. This gap is limiting startups' potential, according to Nick Nash, co-founder of Asia Partners. Research suggests that startups seeking over $100 million in funding have an easier time securing funding than those seeking between $90 million and $100 million.

site_title: DBS has solid Q3, but faces margin squeeze
summary: DBS, Southeast Asia's largest lender, reported a solid third-quarter with net profit rising 15% to $1.63 billion, despite a margin squeeze due to three US Federal Reserve interest rate cuts. The bank now expects full-year net interest margin growth of about three basis points, below its earlier forecast. Loan growth is expected to be moderate, with mortgage loans declining for the third straight quarter, and overall loans growing at a 4% rate.

site_title: Aviation industry is committed to making flying sustainable
summary: The aviation industry is committed to making flying sustainable, with a goal to cap net emissions from 2020 and cut them in half by 2050. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has reaffirmed its commitment to the Carbon Offset and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA), which aims to mitigate around 2.5 billion tonnes of CO2 and generate over $40 billion in climate finance between 2021 and 2035. The industry is also investing in sustainable alternative fuels and new technologies, such as electric airplanes, to reduce its carbon footprint by 80%.

site_title: Oei Tiong Ham Park GCB put up for auction with S$23m guide price
summary: A Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in Singapore's Oei Tiong Ham Park is up for auction with a S$23 million guide price. The 15,216 sq ft property features six ensuite bedrooms, a private swimming pool, and a garage. Located near Holland Village and Orchard Road, it is marketed by Knight Frank and will be auctioned off on November 13. This is the second GCB auction scheduled for the same day, with another property in District 28 also up for sale.

images.alt_text: The District 10 freehold property has a land size of 15,216 square feet and floor size of 6,000 sq ft, which works out to a price of S$1,511.57 per sq ft. PHOTO: KNIGHT FRANK

site_title: AirAsia transfers two KL-Singapore slots to long-haul sister airline
summary: AirAsia Group Bhd is transferring two daily return flights on its Kuala Lumpur-Singapore route to long-haul sister airline AirAsia X Bhd. The transfer aims to boost revenue and increase capacity by doubling the slots with Airbus A330s, which can carry more passengers. The airlines will share operating profits on a 50-50 basis, with an expected RM2.42 million in the first year. The move follows AirAsia X's struggles financially and comes after rival airlines signed an expanded codeshare agreement.

site_title: 28 KAP Mall shop owners suing Oxley unit for misrepresentation
summary: A group of 28 KAP Mall shop owners are suing Oxley Sanctuary, the developer of the freehold strata, for alleged misrepresentation. The plaintiffs claim they were told by Huttons Asia, the exclusive marketing and sales agent, that McDonald's and Cold Storage would be anchor stores at the mall, but neither tenant has moved in. The owners allege they bought units at inflated prices and suffered losses due to low rental rates and lack of customer traffic. Oxley Sanctuary denies the allegations and has named Huttons as a third-party defendant in the lawsuit.

site_title: NY deliveries go high-tech
summary: New York City residential buildings are adopting high-tech solutions to manage the increasing package delivery volume. Companies like Package Concierge offer locker systems with real-time notifications and lobby screens, allowing residents to track and pick up packages remotely. The average 200-unit building receives 70 packages a day, and locker systems help manage the package flow, reducing security issues and increasing resident satisfaction. So far, Package Concierge has implemented its system in 137 buildings in the New York metropolitan area, with 25 in NYC.

site_title: IRAS recovers S$75m in corporate taxes, penalties in first nine months
summary: IRAS recovered S$75 million in corporate taxes and penalties for the first nine months of 2019, exceeding the same period in 2018 by nearly S$8 million. The amount came from 2,368 companies across various industries. IRAS attributes the increase to heightened vigilance in audit and investigation work, citing data analytics as a key tool. Companies that fail to comply with tax obligations may face penalties of up to two times the under-charged amount. Poor record-keeping practices, particularly among smaller food and beverage businesses, and family-owned companies, are identified as contributing factors.

site_title: DBS and OCBC tie up with tech giant Google
summary: Singapore banks DBS and OCBC are partnering with Google to launch Google Pay services, with OCBC's PayNow and DBS's PayLah! expected to be available in early 2020. The services will enable users to make peer-to-peer transfers, pay merchants, and earn rewards directly into their bank accounts. This collaboration aims to expand payment journeys for consumers and bring significant scale to existing services, following Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's call to increase e-payments in Singapore.

site_title: Barings quitting business of managing real estate stock funds in strategy overhaul
summary: Barings is exiting its business of managing real estate stock funds, including the US$1 billion Invesco Oppenheimer Real Estate Fund and the US$53 million Dunham Real Estate Stock Fund, as part of a strategy overhaul. The firm cited growing investor demand for private assets, which are yielding higher returns and fees. Barings will stop sub-advising the Dunham fund on January 1, 2020, and will focus on its core real estate strategies, including private real estate equity and debt. The move comes as the firm manages over US$43.6 billion in real estate assets.

site_title: US-China trade doubts, HK unrest spook investors
summary: Singapore stocks began the week on a negative note, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 23.65 points to 3,240.65, a 0.7% decline. US-China trade doubts and Hong Kong unrest spooked investors, with regional markets such as China, Japan, and Malaysia also posting significant losses. Only Australia bucked the trend. The losses came despite better-than-expected earnings from DBS Group Holdings and ST Engineering.

site_title: PAL Holdings president Lucio Tan Jr dies at 53
summary: PAL Holdings president Lucio "Bong" Tan Jr, 53, died from brain herniation after collapsing during a basketball game on Saturday. He took over as president and COO of PAL Holdings on October 28 and was considered a potential successor to his father, Lucio Tan. His death casts uncertainty over the leadership of the airline group, with shares of LT Group and PAL Holdings reacting to the news. Tan's sister described him as "an elder brother whom we all relied on for advice, counsel and leadership."

site_title: Qantas joins pledge to slash emissions to net zero by 2050
summary: Qantas joins other airlines in pledging to slash carbon emissions to net zero by 2050, with a goal of capping net emissions at 2020 levels. The airline will invest A$50m over 10 years to develop sustainable fuel, aiming to lower emissions by 80% compared to traditional jet fuel. Qantas operates the largest carbon offset programme in the aviation industry and will match every dollar spent on offsets, doubling the number of flights offset.

site_title: The siren song of strategic autonomy
summary: US President Donald Trump's protectionist policies, including tariffs, have fueled anxiety about the future of world trade. However, developing countries are less likely to follow suit due to their globalized supply chains. The US has found no followers in its aggressive use of tariffs. The global trading system is at risk if the world doesn't navigate carefully, with potential hidden hazards. Trump's policies mark a new chapter in US foreign policy, which may have implications for global trade and economic relations.

site_title: World War II movie Midway surprise winner at US box office
summary: World War II movie "Midway" unexpectedly took the top spot at the US box office, earning an estimated $17.5 million in domestic ticket sales from Friday to Sunday. The film, which re-creates the pivotal 1942 air and sea battle, had a lukewarm response from critics, holding a 41% fresh rating on Rotten Tomatoes. In contrast, horror movie "Doctor Sleep" trailed behind, selling an estimated $14.1 million in tickets, despite its 73% fresh rating.

site_title: Euro stays near 4-week low against dollar
summary: The euro held steady near a four-week low against the US dollar on Monday, despite initial optimism over a potential US-China trade deal. The euro traded at US$1.1026, flat from earlier, while the dollar rose amid escalating tensions in Hong Kong. Analysts believe the euro may not benefit significantly from a trade deal, as China is unlikely to increase imports from the euro zone. The dollar also rose after US President Donald Trump hinted at a potential deal with China.

site_title: MAS, IMDA to pilot real trades on cross-border SME digital platform
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) will pilot real trades on the cross-border SME digital platform, Business sans Borders (BSB), in the first half of 2020. The platform connects SMEs with a global ecosystem of buyers, sellers, logistics service providers, financing, and digital solution providers. The second phase will trial real SME transactions, starting with Singapore, the Philippines, and India, and includes pilot procurements by the Singapore government and the central bank of the Philippines.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sembcorp Industries' subsidiary Sembcorp Utilities acquired a 30% stake in Sembcorp Gas for S$12.1 million. Pan Asian Holdings is divesting its China pipe and valve manufacturing unit for S$2.8 million. Vicom posted a 6.5% increase in net profit to S$7.2 million in Q3, while Singapore Medical Group's net profit decreased 0.1% to S$3.14 million. The Singapore stock market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Ditching corporate life to start you tiao business
summary: Audrey Chew, a 35-year-old Singaporean entrepreneur, transformed her family's traditional you tiao business into a successful mass-produced venture, You Tiao Man, after returning from a 10-year stint in China. She took risks, faced challenges, and innovated products such as charcoal and wholegrain you tiao, earning the Healthier Choice Symbol. Chew attributes her success to resilience, adaptability, and continuous learning, and her business now supplies to top restaurants and hotels in Singapore.

site_title: Foreign workers, GST hike keeping SMEs up at night
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are concerned about coping with reduced foreign manpower and an impending Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike. Senior Minister Chee Hong Tat suggested that businesses hire local workers from vulnerable groups, such as the young, older, and disabled, and raise productivity to mitigate the impact. The GST hike, expected between 2021 and 2025, will affect SMEs' costs, but Chee said businesses will need to consider the impact on customers and pass costs through. The government has existing schemes to help companies cope with productivity improvements, but no specific measures were announced.

site_title: China and the US: Deep-seated differences remain
summary: China and the US have reached a "first phase" trade agreement, but intractable issues remain to be addressed in future phases. US Vice-President Mike Pence has criticized China's trade surplus, human rights record in Xinjiang, intellectual property theft, and militarization of the South China Sea. This criticism is part of a broader increase in rhetoric from the Trump administration, with President Trump opening a new chapter in US foreign policy. Despite the agreement, deep-seated differences between the two nations persist, indicating a long-term stalemate in their relationship.

site_title: CapitaLand wins Asean award for fight against poverty
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based property developer, won the Asean Rural Development and Poverty Eradication (RDPE) leadership award for its efforts in rural and community development. Since 2005, the company has donated over S$39 million to support underprivileged children and elderly in communities where it operates. CapitaLand's philanthropic arm, CapitaLand Hope Foundation, allocates 0.5% of its net operating profit annually to promote social growth and development. The company's initiatives, such as its Ready-for-School program, aim to provide equal opportunities for children from low-income families.

site_title: An edgy NY mixed-use site puts the heart back in the Lower East Side
summary: Essex Crossing, a $1.9 billion mixed-use development in New York's Lower East Side, is considered one of the city's most promising new projects. Completed in phases, it replaces a vacant lot with subsidized apartments, community perks, parkland, and local businesses. The project balances equity with gentrification, with nearly 30 former residents returning to their original homes. Essex Crossing creates 1,079 new apartments, including 195 subsidized units, and features a new Essex Market, a 14-screen movie theater, and community services. The development's focus on affordability and community benefits sets a precedent for balancing private enterprise and social responsibility.

site_title: APTT Q3 DPU falls to 0.3 S cent; it's in talks with potential investors
summary: Asian Pay TV Trust (APTT) reported a Q3 DPU of 0.3 Singapore cent, down from 1.625 cents a year ago. The company's net profit more than doubled to S$5.1 million and Ebitda declined 12.1% to S$43 million due to challenging market conditions in Taiwan. APTT has reaffirmed its distribution guidance for 2019 and 2020 and is in talks with potential investors as part of a strategic review. The company's CEO expressed confidence in its ability to manage pressure on ARPU through cost management and broadband growth initiatives.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada by President Trump. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC's incoming CEO Tan Teck Long has a DBS background. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and PBOC are to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Jardine C&C to privatise Malaysian arm for RM90.6m
summary: Regional auto dealer Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C) plans to privatize its Malaysian arm Cycle & Carriage Bintang Berhad (CCB) for RM90.6 million, or RM2.20 per share. Jardine C&C holds 59.1% of Bursa Malaysia-listed CCB, whose shares were down 3% on Friday. The privatization is part of Jardine C&C's efforts to focus on its core business.

site_title: Magnus Energy minorities show that collectively they are a force to be reckoned with
summary: Shareholders of Magnus Energy, a Singaporean investment holding company, voted out the chairman and two directors at its annual general meeting, citing concerns over poor corporate governance and strategy. The company has incurred cumulative losses of over $56.5 million in the past four years and has been burning cash in unviable projects. Provenance Capital, an external reviewer, has highlighted shortfalls in the company's policies and board practices. The outcome of the AGM is seen as a positive step for corporate governance in Singapore, demonstrating the collective power of minority shareholders to hold management accountable.

site_title: KSH Q2 net profit more than triples to S$6m
summary: KSH Holdings reported a significant surge in Q2 net profit, more than tripling to S$6 million, driven by a 66.9% increase in revenue from its construction business to S$58.8 million. This represents a 51.6% increase in net profit and 66.4% in revenue for the half-year ended Sept 30. Earnings per share rose to 1.96 cents, up from 1.29 cents in the previous year. The company has proposed an unchanged interim cash dividend of one Singapore cent per share.

site_title: Dutch court orders Facebook to pull financial fraud adverts
summary: A Dutch court has ordered Facebook to remove advertisements that misuse the likeness of local celebrities to promote fraudulent Bitcoin-related investments. The court ruled that Facebook must pull the ads or face fines of up to 1.1 million euros. The decision came after Dutch tycoon John de Mol sued Facebook for failing to respond to repeated requests to remove the ads, which led to investors losing $1.7 million. The court found that Facebook's arguments that it is a neutral platform are not acceptable, as the company plays an active role in setting ad policies and pricing.

site_title: Growth of contraceptive use highest in African countries
summary: The number of women and girls using modern contraception has increased by tens of millions, with Africa recording the largest gains. 314 million women and girls out of 926 million of child-bearing age now use contraceptive methods, a 2% global gain since 2012. In East and Southern Africa, gains reached 7%. The Family Planning 2020 organization has seen significant growth, aiming for 120 million new users by 2020, citing family planning as a basic right to empower women and improve their lives.

site_title: Could home be a 3D printout?
summary: A 3D-printed house called Tera, measuring 7 meters high and 500 square feet, is set to be constructed in Garrison, New York, using basalt and biopolymers. The project, developed by AI SpaceFactory, aims to demonstrate the future of home building, reducing construction costs, environmental impact, and hazards. The Tera house will feature amenities such as a sleeping pod, bathroom, and study area, and is expected to be completed in a few weeks. The project's use of local materials and automation is expected to drive down construction costs and provide efficient use of materials, with potential benefits for emergency housing and sheltering the homeless.

site_title: Boris Johnson on track for win, with majority on knife edge, odds say
summary: Boris Johnson is favored to win the UK general election on December 12, with a 75% chance of remaining as prime minister, according to bookmakers. He is also likely to win an overall majority in Parliament, with odds suggesting a 60% chance. Recent opinion polls show the Conservatives with a 12 percentage point lead over Labour. Johnson's Brexit Party rival Nigel Farage has ruled out contesting 317 Conservative seats, further increasing the Conservatives' chances.

site_title: Europe gives go ahead to market Ebola vaccine
summary: The European Union has authorized the marketing of the Ebola vaccine "Ervebo" by US pharmaceutical giant Merck, allowing its wider commercial use in the bloc. The vaccine, developed by Merck, has helped stem an outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where over 2,150 lives have been lost. The EU's decision comes after a trial by the European Medicines Agency and follows the successful administration of the vaccine to over 236,000 people, including 60,000 health workers. This marks a significant step forward in saving lives in Africa and beyond.

site_title: China's Jingye forges rescue deal for British Steel
summary: China's Jingye Group has agreed to buy British Steel for an undisclosed amount, saving thousands of jobs. The deal includes the purchase of British Steel's UK mills and stakes in Dutch steelmaker FN Steel and specialist UK manufacturer TSP Engineering. Jingye will invest £1.2 billion over the next decade to upgrade the plants and machinery, preserving thousands of jobs in the UK steel industry. The deal will see the two businesses combine to form a global steelmaking group, creating a world-class steelmaking entity with global scale and ambition.

site_title: United Engineers Q3 profit lifted by S$65.2 million net revaluation gain
summary: United Engineers' (UE) Q3 net profit rose to S$84.8 million, driven by a S$65.2 million net revaluation gain from four investment properties. Excluding the gain, net profit would have been S$19.6 million, a 156% increase from the same period last year. This was after controlling shareholder Yanlord Investment triggered a mandatory general offer for UE's shares.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust's preferential offering 1.45 times subscribed
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) raised S$460.5 million from a preferential offering, 1.45 times subscribed, and S$458 million from a private placement, totaling S$918.5 million. The issue price for new units is S$2.24 apiece, with 205.6 million units to be issued. The new units will begin trading on the Singapore Exchange on November 15.

site_title: Trump to meet with vaping industry on vaping, e-cigarettes
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to meet with vaping industry officials, medical professionals, and state representatives to discuss the vaping and e-cigarette crisis. The meeting aims to focus on children's health and safety, as well as jobs, amid a nationwide outbreak of injuries and deaths linked to the products. Trump's administration will issue its final report on the products next week.

site_title: Saxo Bank claims against Innopac resume; unrelated Innopac MOU terminated
summary: Saxo Bank has resumed its claims of nearly S$14.7 million against Innopac Holdings, alleging negative account balances at two subsidiaries. Innopac counters, stating its claims are without merit, and will defend its rights while pursuing damages. The company also terminated its memorandum of understanding with Masmeyer Holdings for a joint venture in Malaysia, citing unfulfilled conditions. Innopac shares remain suspended.

site_title: Queen Mary repair costs: EHT says 'premature' for independent review of estimates
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has stated that it's premature to appoint its own expert to evaluate the costs of Queen Mary's maintenance, awaiting the outcome of Long Beach's review of Urban Commons' (UC) proposal. The City of Long Beach has engaged a third-party marine engineering firm to review UC's proposal, which estimates $5-7 million in repair costs. A peer review of the ship's inspection reports is also underway, expected to be completed in November. EHT's board will consider options, including appointing a professional valuer, depending on the review's outcome.

site_title: Dennis Tan quits as OCBC's head of consumer financial services, Sunny Quek taking over
summary: OCBC Bank announced the departure of Dennis Tan, 50, as head of consumer financial services, effective November 12, 2019. Tan, a 10-year OCBC veteran, is leaving to pursue other interests. Sunny Quek, previously head of branch and premier banking at Citibank Singapore, takes over the role, succeeding Tan. Quek has made significant contributions to OCBC's retail banking business and will lead the consumer banking team, which was recognized as the world's best consumer bank by Global Finance.

site_title: Politics, not economics, becoming more important for BRICS
summary: The BRICS (Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa) annual summit is underway in Brasilia, with a growing focus on politics rather than economics. The bloc has created alternative institutions, such as the New Development Bank, to promote its interests abroad and counter Western influence. However, the relevance of BRICS as an economic club is questioned due to diverging economic trajectories among its members. Despite this, BRICS has contributed to declining global income inequality, driven by the growth of emerging markets like India and China, which have lifted millions out of poverty.

site_title: BBR wins contracts to build floating, rooftop solar panels
summary: BBR Holdings' subsidiary BBR Greentech has won two contracts to construct floating solar PV systems, one for PUB and another for private sector clients. The systems will power waterworks and industrial buildings, producing enough green energy to supply 30% of the installations' total energy requirement. Construction works are in progress, with systems expected to be operational by Q2 2020. The contracts are not expected to have a material financial impact on BBR's earnings for the current financial year.

site_title: Rich Capital JV being sued by main contractor in Batam
summary: A joint venture vehicle linked to Rich Capital is being sued by its main contractor, Rich-Link Konstruksi, over the Oxley Convention City project in Batam, Indonesia.
