summary: Top Global, a property developer, is shifting its focus to hospitality tech to reduce asset heaviness. The company, which owns 5footway hostels, has introduced smart solutions such as self-service check-in and dynamic pricing. Revenue from property development accounts for 75% of its total revenue, with the rest coming from tech solutions. Top Global plans to expand its tech business abroad, starting with Bali, where it launched its smart solutions brand Ultron in October. The company aims to capture a few percent of the market share and eventually offer tech solutions in other industries.

site_title: First combined fintech festival, SWITCH kicks off today
summary: The Singapore FinTech Festival (SFF) x SWITCH kicked off on November 11, 2019, featuring over 400 speakers, 900 exhibitors, 41 international pavilions, and 60,000 participants from 130 countries. The event was announced by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, Enterprise Singapore, and the National Research Foundation.

site_title: China's hottest investment: overpriced sneakers
summary: China's sneaker market has become a hotspot for investment, with limited-edition collaborations and resale profits reaching up to 5,000% due to speculation. Online platforms like Poizon and Nice have seen explosive growth, with volumes exceeding $1 billion, and attracting hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign investment. Authorities have warned about the dangers of speculation, while enthusiasts like Hu Huaiyuan and Liu Xingfeng are making quick profits by buying and reselling sneakers. The market's appeal lies in its perceived quick profits and the influence of NBA stars and streetwear culture in China.

images.alt_text: With the Chinese authorities limiting individual stock-market price movements to contain volatility, sneakers are embraced by younger investors seeking quick profits in a commodity they can relate to.

site_title: UOB is banking on data
summary: UOB is leveraging data analytics to transform its business, with significant benefits for the bank and its customers. The bank has implemented AI-powered anti-money laundering (AML) monitoring, reducing false positives by 60% and correctly identifying 5% more AML risks. UOB's data lake approach has made data more accessible, and over 500 staff have been trained on data visualization tools. The bank is also partnering institutions to grant data analytics scholarships. UOB's investments in data capabilities have enabled the launch of its digital bank TMRW in Thailand in just 14 months and have improved customer experience through data-driven insights. The bank remains committed to ethics, particularly in the use of AI, and will continue to prioritize responsible innovation.

site_title: A new approach to digital banks
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will round up digital banking licence applications by year-end, awarding up to two full bank and three wholesale bank licences by mid-2021. Several companies, including AMTD Group, Ping An Insurance, and Standard Chartered Bank, are eyeing digital banking opportunities in Singapore. Analysts say tapping unmet needs, such as SME funding and gig worker financial security, and leveraging data to assess credit needs will level the banking field. Digital banks are expected to start operations by 2021, with UOB's TMRW digital bank targeting millennials and using data analytics to align consumers to savings goals.

site_title: Denmark and Iceland clash over priceless mediaeval manuscripts
summary: Denmark and Iceland are at odds over a priceless collection of medieval manuscripts, known as the Arnamagnaean Collection, which includes an almost complete 15th-century copy of the Old Norse king saga "Heimskringla". The collection was bequeathed to the University of Copenhagen in the 18th century by an Icelandic scholar and is considered one of the most important collections of early Scandinavian manuscripts. Iceland's Culture and Education Minister wants more of the collection returned, citing the need to make cultural heritage visible, while Denmark's professor in charge argues that the remaining manuscripts are part of Denmark's cultural heritage.

site_title: IMF approves US$450m loan tranche for Pakistan
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has approved a US$450 million loan tranche for Pakistan as part of a US$6 billion, three-year loan package. The move comes after the country met all performance criteria for the end of September, with signs of improving economic stability and slowing inflation. The loan is aimed at helping Pakistan right its economy, with conditions including slashing civil expenditure, freezing military spending, and raising revenues to stem a fiscal deficit. The IMF also praised Pakistan's efforts to combat money laundering and terror finance controls.

site_title: ESG calls for more open innovation on sustainability
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) is launching initiatives to encourage innovation in sustainability, aiming to improve resource management and reduce operating costs. The Sustainability Open Innovation Challenge will engage industry leaders, government agencies, and small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to develop innovative solutions. This approach, known as open innovation, taps into a bigger talent pool and helps companies develop solutions more quickly. The goal is to strengthen Singapore's competitive advantage and support the development of new products and solutions, while also addressing the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals.

site_title: Greater support for medtech firms in Singapore to thrive
summary: Singapore's medtech sector is poised for growth, with the Asia market expected to reach $133 billion in 2020, surpassing the European Union. The sector has seen significant growth, with over 250 homegrown medtech companies in 2018, more than double that of 2014. However, the industry faces unique challenges, including higher barriers of entry and longer gestation periods. To address these, Singapore has established initiatives, such as the Diagnostics Development Hub, to support innovation and commercialization. The government also encourages partnerships between public healthcare clusters and medtech startups, providing resources and infrastructure for growth.

site_title: Mastercard takes on digitalisation trend with new experience centre
summary: Mastercard has launched its Experience Centre (MEC) at the Singapore FinTech Festival, a space for collaborations and idea generation with fintech startups and banks. The centre complements Mastercard's Accelerate programme, providing customized platforms for fintechs to accelerate growth and scale up. The goal is to tap into fintechs' innovative technologies and problem-solving skills, bringing new value to the industry.

site_title: Singapore's fintech ecosystem and its role in Asean
summary: Singapore's fintech ecosystem has grown significantly since the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) initiated the fintech journey four years ago. The combination of capital, talent, market access, and progressive regulations has propelled Singapore to become a world-leading fintech hub. The industry's growth is crucial for Singapore to maintain its status as a major international financial center and to promote the financial services sector, which contributes 13% to Singapore's GDP and employs 200,000 workers.

site_title: Top tech trends that help bring about a more sustainable future
summary: Top tech trends, including application programming interfaces (APIs), artificial intelligence (AI) and the Internet of Things (IoT), and blockchain, are helping businesses create a more sustainable future. APIs enable financial inclusion and drive sustainability through digital trade financing services, while AI and IoT facilitate circular procurement and reduce waste. Blockchain technology offers trust and efficiency in supply chains, providing added transparency and traceability in industries such as agriculture. By leveraging these trends, companies can make real and impactful changes towards a sustainable future.

site_title: US wants UN to take up Dalai Lama succession: envoy
summary: The US is urging the UN to take up the issue of the Dalai Lama's succession, amid concerns China may try to handpick his successor. US Ambassador-at-large for international religious freedom Sam Brownback met with the 84-year-old Dalai Lama in India and expressed the US desire to build global support for the principle that the choice of the next spiritual chief belongs to Tibetan Buddhists, not the Chinese government. China has indicated it could name the next Dalai Lama, potentially to support Chinese rule, and the US hopes to raise awareness at the UN to prevent this.

site_title: Money: an existential question
summary: Innovations in the global monetary system raise concerns about its safety. For centuries, philosophers and economists have debated the value and meaning of money, with bloodshed often accompanying disputes over its worth. Money is primarily represented by tangible forms like dollars and coins, storing and symbolizing purchasing power in market economies. Recent events highlight the importance of safeguarding the system, including the transition to green and transition finance, Chinese banks' struggles with consumer lending, and the impact of US tariffs on the global economy. Safeguarding the monetary system is paramount as innovations continue to rise.

site_title: Incumbent banks are battle-ready for competitors
summary: Singapore's incumbent banks are well-prepared to defend their market share as the financial sector becomes increasingly digital. The Association of Banks in Singapore notes that banks have not been complacent and have seen success with quick payments via mobile numbers, with PayNow transactions crossing 5 million in July. The service has been extended to corporate customers and banks have prioritized cybersecurity and customer experience. Despite the rise of fintechs, the incumbent banks remain confident in their ability to adapt and compete.

images.alt_text: By July this year, the number of PayNow transactions crossed five million, up significantly from just 150,000 when it was launched two years ago.

site_title: Payments in South-east Asia: A new frontier
summary: South-east Asia's high mobile penetration rates and underbanked population create a ripe environment for new entrants in the payments space. Non-bank players and technology firms are well-positioned to grow, but a price-war scenario could pose new challenges. Deloitte warns that fragmentation across the payments landscape and interoperability issues may hinder growth. The region's fragmented regulatory landscape, infrastructure, and talent shortages are key barriers to digital payments adoption. A price-war scenario could lead to low pricing, reduced service quality, and innovation, but regulators and industry players can collaborate to address these issues and create a more secure and efficient ecosystem.

site_title: Avarga posts 2 per cent dip in Q3 net profit
summary: AVARGA, the former UPP Holdings, reported a 2% dip in Q3 net profit to S$7.7 million, down from S$7.8 million in the same quarter last year. Revenue slipped 11% to S$389.6 million, primarily due to decreased selling prices for commodity products. Gross margin increased by 30% to S$38.1 million, with a 10.2% gross profit margin percentage. The company's earnings per share fell to 0.81 Singapore cent, also down from the previous year.

site_title: Moody's downgrades Britain debt outlook to negative
summary: Moody's downgraded Britain's debt outlook to negative due to the country's difficulty in dealing with policy challenges during the Brexit debate. The agency cited "paralysis" in policymaking and weaker economic and fiscal strength, making the country more susceptible to shocks. The debt grade remains at Aa2, but the negative outlook reflects Moody's concerns about Britain's ability to address its economic challenges.

images.alt_text: Credit ratings agency Moody's on Friday downgraded the outlook for Britain's debt, citing increasing difficulty dealing with policy challenges the country faces amid the Brexit debate.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Far East Orchard Limited has acquired two freehold student accommodation properties in Leeds and Sheffield, UK, for £66.5 million, adding 974 beds to its portfolio. This brings the total number of purpose-built student accommodation beds to 3,260 across 11 properties in the UK, surpassing its target of 3,000 beds by 2023. The acquisition follows the group's earlier purchase of 622 beds in Bristol and Liverpool in March this year.

site_title: China factory gate prices falter, while inflation soars to near 8-year high
summary: China's producer prices fell 1.6% in October, the steepest decline in over three years, due to weak demand and the Sino-US tariff war. In contrast, consumer prices rose at their fastest pace in almost eight years, driven by a surge in pork prices due to African swine fever. This reinforces the need for Beijing to maintain stimulus measures.

site_title: US wants to repatriate WWII soldiers' remains from China
summary: The US is seeking to strengthen military cooperation with China, including repatriating the remains of American soldiers killed in China during World War II. Defence Secretary Mark Esper plans to meet with Chinese counterpart General Wei Fenghe during his upcoming Asia tour, where he will ask for increased cooperation on missing persons and raise concerns about China's violations of international sanctions, including illicit oil shipments to North Korea.

site_title: HK protests continue for 24th straight weekend
summary: Hong Kong police clashed with protesters for the 24th consecutive weekend, with demonstrators blocking roads and vandalizing shopping malls. The protests, which began in June, have been marked by violence and anti-government sentiment. An international expert panel has criticized Hong Kong's police watchdog for lacking the ability to properly investigate police actions during the unrest. The protests are set to continue ahead of district council elections in the city, which are scheduled for two weeks later.

site_title: Ernst & Young issues disclaimer of opinion on Hatten Land's financial statements for FY2019
summary: Malaysian property developer Hatten Land's independent auditor Ernst & Young has issued a disclaimer of opinion on the company's financial statements for FY2019 due to material uncertainties regarding its ability to continue as a going concern. The auditor highlighted high loan balances, cash flow strain, and delayed project completions. Despite the auditor's concerns, Hatten's board disputes the findings, citing a new financing agreement and support from major shareholders. The company's financial statements are now considered unreliable due to the uncertainty.

site_title: E-commerce offers Thai small retailers big jump in reach and income
summary: A new report by Sea Group found that Thai small retailers who expand into online sales can boost takings by 51% a year. The shift to e-commerce has also grown retailers' customer bases beyond their home markets, especially for lower-income regional sellers. Traditional brick-and-mortar vendors saw increased income from both online and offline sales after launching products on the Shopee e-commerce portal. E-commerce adoption has eased labor shortages for Thailand's small and medium-sized enterprises, with the share of retailers with non-local customers increasing from 45% to 81%.

site_title: Government to inject S$100m to help train rail workers, easing operators' cost burden
summary: The Singapore government has announced a S$100 million Rail Manpower Development Package to train rail workers, easing the cost burden on operators. The package, which will last five years, includes investments in hardware equipment and scholarships for future leaders. The move aims to improve service levels for commuters and address the industry's challenges, including high maintenance costs and aging assets. Rail operators SBS Transit and SMRT have welcomed the initiative, which will provide training for 1,500 workers and support the development of a world-class workforce.

site_title: Deloitte gives disclaimer of opinion on Tee International's FY2019 financial statements
summary: Deloitte, Tee International's independent external auditor, has issued a disclaimer of opinion on the engineering group's FY2019 financial statements due to insufficient audit evidence. The auditor noted transactions totaling S$3.75 million paid to Tee International's former CEO, Phua Chian Kin, which raised inconsistencies with previously disclosed information. Deloitte expressed uncertainty about potential issues and their impact on financial statements, as well as concerns over management override of controls and internal control over financial reporting. An external investigator's work is ongoing, which may shed new light on the matter.

site_title: Charlize Theron honoured by Hollywood
summary: Charlize Theron was honored by Hollywood for her "fearless" career tackling themes including sexual harassment before the #MeToo movement. The 44-year-old actress, known for her transformative roles, received the American Cinematheque Award for her "visceral performances" in films like "Monster" and "North Country." Theron's career has seen her play complex and darker characters, earning her respect from peers like Jason Reitman and recognition from the film industry.

site_title: Pompeo slams Iran 'intimidation' of IAEA inspector as 'outrageous'
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has criticized Iran's treatment of an IAEA inspector, labeling it an "outrageous and unwarranted act of intimidation." The inspector was briefly prevented from leaving Iran after triggering an alarm at a uranium enrichment plant, prompting Iran to cancel her accreditation. Pompeo called for Iran to allow IAEA inspectors to conduct their work unimpeded, citing concerns about the agency's monitoring and verification activities. The incident comes amid Iran's progressive scaling back of nuclear commitments under the 2015 deal.

site_title: Far East Orchard buys two student accommodation properties in Leeds and Sheffield for £66.5m
summary: Far East Orchard Limited has acquired two student accommodation properties in Leeds and Sheffield, UK, for £66.5m, bringing its total PBSA beds to 3,260 across 11 properties. The newly acquired properties, The Foundry and The Elements, have been operating at full occupancy since 2017 and 2018, respectively. This acquisition surpasses the group's target to grow its PBSA portfolio to 3,000 beds by 2023. The properties will be managed by the existing facility manager in Brighton and other UK cities.

site_title: New York auctions push lesser-known artists
summary: New York's fall auctions will highlight lesser-known artists, seeking diversity in a market that has been dominated by high-priced works. Christie's and Sotheby's will feature rare paintings by artists such as Ed Ruscha, David Hockney, and Willem de Kooning, with estimates ranging from $20 to $50 million. The sales are expected to set individual records for artists with lower profiles, with a focus on fresh, previously unexhibited works. Despite the absence of a superstar work, auction houses are confident, citing strong demand for female and African-American artists, including Lee Krasner, Jean-Michel Basquiat, Charles White, and Norman Lewis.

site_title: ESR Cayman increases AA Reit interest by 4%
summary: ESR Cayman increased its AA Reit interest by 4% after acquiring 26,827,400 units in AIMS APAC Reit (AA Reit) for a consideration of S$37,290,086. This increased ESR Cayman's deemed interest in AA Reit from 5.24% to 9.09%. The acquisition also increased ESR Cayman's direct interest in AA Reit to 1.285%.

site_title: Bloomberg files papers paving way for US presidential bid
summary: Michael Bloomberg has filed papers to register as a candidate in the Alabama Democratic primary, paving the way for a potential US presidential bid. The 77-year-old billionaire has not publicly announced his run but his inclusion in the crowded field keeps his options open. Analysts say a Bloomberg candidacy could harm frontrunner Joe Biden, but Biden remains confident and unfazed. Trump also weighed in, saying Bloomberg would fail but potentially hurt Biden. Bloomberg's entry into the race could shake up the contest, with his huge personal wealth and Wall Street ties potentially drawing support away from Biden.

site_title: China-US trade war to ease but conflicts will persist: China's ex-finance minister Lou Jiwei
summary: China's ex-finance minister Lou Jiwei stated that a Sino-US trade war could ease, but conflicts between the two nations will persist. He noted signs of compromise in the trade war, citing the recent agreement to roll back tariffs if a "phase one" deal is concluded. However, this idea has faced opposition from some US administration quarters. Lou's comments suggest that while tensions may ease, broader conflicts between China and the US will continue.

site_title: Instagram test of hiding 'likes' spreading to US
summary: Instagram is testing hiding "likes" in the US, following successful trials in other countries. The test will be rolled out to a small portion of US users next week. Instagram chief Adam Mosseri announced the expansion in a tweet, inviting users to provide feedback on the feature.

site_title: Chinese inflation hits highest rate since 2012
summary: China's consumer prices rose 3.8% in October, the highest annual rate since 2012, driven by a surge in pork prices due to African swine fever. This is the fastest rate in almost eight years, exceeding forecasted 3.4%. Pork prices have more than doubled in the past year, leading to increased prices of other meats and eggs. The government is intervening to stabilize prices and guarantee supplies, amid concerns over inflation.

images.alt_text: China's consumer prices grew at their fastest rate in almost eight years in October driven by a spike in pork prices caused by an outbreak of African swine fever, according to official figures released Saturday.

site_title: Failure to launch: The biggest IPO pull-outs of 2019
summary: Several high-profile companies abandoned their initial public offerings (IPOs) in 2019 due to weak investor demand, reflecting a weakening global economy and casting doubt on the solidity of some disruptive businesses. Notable cancellations include WeWork, Endeavor Group Holdings, GFL Environmental, Ferretti, KKR & Co's Latitude Financial, and Bitmain Technologies. The cancellations also highlight concerns over price volatility and infrastructure failures in the tech sector.

site_title: Two dead, at least 150 homes lost in Australia bushfires
summary: At least two people have died and over 150 homes have been destroyed in catastrophic bushfires in eastern Australia, forcing thousands to flee their homes. Firefighters are struggling to reach hard-to-reach communities as the death toll is expected to rise. The blazes, which are being fueled by hot and windy weather, have burned schools, detention centers, and old people's homes, with 30 more people injured. Prime Minister Scott Morrison has warned that the situation may worsen with next week's weather forecast, and has called on the military to assist with the firefighting efforts.

site_title: SFF X SWITCH to kick off on Monday with a focus on sustainability
summary: The Singapore FinTech Festival (SFF) X SWITCH will kick off on Monday, featuring over 400 speakers, 900 exhibitors, and 60,000 participants from 130 countries. The event focuses on sustainability and climate change, with a lineup of speakers including Queen Maxima and Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat. The festival will showcase innovative technologies across five sectors and include competitions, deal-making opportunities, and innovation labs. The event aims to catalyze cross-industry exchange and learning in technology adoption and commercialization of new solutions.

site_title: Twitter spy case highlights risks for big tech platforms
summary: A federal indictment alleges two former Twitter employees, one US citizen, and two Saudis worked together to spy on dissident Twitter accounts for the Saudi government and royal family. The incident highlights the risks for big tech platforms holding sensitive data, which can be targeted by intelligence agencies. Analysts say massive databases held by Silicon Valley giants can be attractive targets for espionage, and the incident underscores the need for greater security measures. The case raises concerns about the potential for companies to be pressured by intelligence agencies to compromise their data.

site_title: South Korea to end intel-sharing pact with Japan as planned
summary: South Korea reaffirmed its plan to terminate the General Security of Military Information Agreement (GSOMIA) with Japan on November 23, 2019, as previously stated. The decision does not weaken the alliance with the US, according to a presidential official. The pact, signed three years ago, allows for the sharing of military intelligence between the two countries. The termination marks a symbolic end to the agreement, with no immediate impact on military operations.

site_title: US: Wall Street hits new records despite mixed signals on trade
summary: US stocks closed at new records on Friday, despite mixed signals on the US-China trade war. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose a fraction above Thursday's record close, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also gained. President Trump said he hadn't agreed to roll back tariffs as part of a partial trade deal, contradicting earlier claims by the Chinese government. Despite tariff uncertainty, global investors remain optimistic, and the Nasdaq rose for the sixth week in a row.

site_title: Officials raised alarm over White House-Ukraine talks in early July: testimony
summary: Two White House national security officials, Fiona Hill and Alexander Vindman, testified that they reported concerns to White House attorney John Eisenberg about improper pressure on Ukraine in early July, two weeks before President Donald Trump's phone call with Ukraine leader Volodymyr Zelensky. The pressure was allegedly from top Trump allies seeking political help for the US leader. This contradicts Trump's claim that he was unaware of the pressure. The testimony is part of the impeachment inquiry into Trump's actions.

images.alt_text: Two White House national security officials sounded alarms about improper pressure on Ukraine in early July, well before President Donald Trump's bombshell phone call with Ukraine leader Volodymyr Zelensky, according to impeachment testimony released Friday.

site_title: Hong Kong faces 24th weekend of protest after student's death
summary: Hong Kong protesters plan a 24th consecutive weekend of pro-democracy rallies, including inside shopping malls, to demand universal suffrage. The rallies come after the death of 22-year-old student Chow Tsz-lok, who fell from a parking lot during a police dispersal. The incident is likely to fuel anger with the police, who are under pressure over accusations of excessive force. Protests have escalated since June, with clashes between protesters and police, and calls for a general strike and public transport blockades have been made. The protesters' demands for greater democracy and an end to perceived Chinese meddling remain unchanged.

site_title: Southwest Airlines pushes back Boeing 737 Max return until March
summary: Southwest Airlines has pushed back its planned return to Boeing 737 Max flights until March 6, 2020, citing a proactive decision to remove the aircraft from service as a measure to reduce last-minute cancellations and disruptions. The move comes as the aircraft has been grounded globally since mid-March following two fatal crashes that killed 346 people. Boeing expects to receive regulatory approval to resume flights in the fourth quarter of 2019, and Southwest remains confident in the safety of the aircraft once certified by the FAA.

site_title: WeWork, ex-CEO Neumann, Softbank sued over botched IPO, plummeting value
summary: WeWork and ex-CEO Adam Neumann are being sued by minority shareholder Natalie Sojka for breaching fiduciary duties. Sojka accuses the board of directors, including Softbank's Masayoshi Son, of self-dealing and a "fire-sale" rescue, which granted Neumann a $1.7 billion exit package. The lawsuit seeks to block future transactions with Softbank and restrict stock repurchases from minority shareholders, and also demands punitive damages. WeWork's valuation has plummeted to $5.9 billion after its IPO was canceled in September.

site_title: Building personal relationships in business
summary: A successful business relies heavily on personal relationships, particularly trust. A former mentor's positive influence on the author's career highlights the importance of building trust, as it determines the effectiveness of mentors in their roles. In business, relationships in customer relations, ethics, and personal connections are crucial. Trust is the foundation of these relationships, yet it's becoming increasingly unreliable. By prioritizing honesty, care, and allowing for mistakes, businesses can build trust and ultimately succeed.

site_title: Singapore to steer maritime's green push beyond global standards
summary: Singapore's Maritime Singapore Green Initiative will be enhanced and extended until 2024, focusing on decarbonization beyond global standards. New incentives will encourage the adoption of low-carbon fuels like liquefied natural gas (LNG) and LNG bunkering during port stays. The initiative aims to prepare Singapore's shipping industry for a lower-carbon future, with plans to go green and digital, including digitalizing services and upskilling the maritime workforce. The Singapore Registry of Ships has also reached 95 million gross tonnage, maintaining the country's position among the top five in the world.

site_title: Oil rises after falling on Trump comments on US-China trade
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday after falling due to US President Donald Trump's comments on the US-China trade deal. Brent crude futures rose 22 cents to $62.51 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose 9 cents to $57.24 a barrel. The comments followed a report that officials from both countries had agreed to roll back tariffs, but the plan faces internal opposition in the US administration. Despite a deal, oil prices remain under pressure due to concerns of a supply glut in 2020.

site_title: Grape expectations
summary: Cold Storage's 12th International Wine Fair features over 300 wines from around the world, with a focus on lesser-known wines and 'green' vineyards. Regional merchandise manager Fiona Stephens recommends crowd-pleasers such as prosecco, sauvignon blanc, and Argentinian malbec. The fair showcases a range of wines, including organic and sustainably produced options, with prices starting from below S$25 and going up to S$300. Stephens hopes to build a "green section" of wines at supermarkets, offering environmentally conscious wines with minimal packaging.

site_title: Europe: Shares break 5-day winning run as Trump dampens trade talk hopes
summary: European shares broke a five-day winning streak on Friday, closing 0.3% lower, after US President Donald Trump said he has not agreed to roll back tariffs on China, dampening hopes of a partial trade deal. Defensive sectors like healthcare and utilities rose, while miners and bank stocks declined. Trump's comments worsened sentiment, with the Stoxx 600 index ending its fourth straight week of gains. The uncertainty surrounding US-China trade talks has investors adopting a defensive position, with shares in Telecom Italia and Beazley rising.

site_title: China export drop in Oct beats forecasts but more pain ahead
summary: China's exports dropped 0.9% in October, beating forecasts, but economists warn of more pain ahead due to the ongoing US trade war. Shipments were slower than September's 3.2% drop, but still worse than expected. Imports fell 6.4% for the sixth straight month, and China's trade surplus with the US increased to $26.42 billion. Despite easing tensions, the US-China trade deal may not alleviate the main headwinds facing exporters, with outbound shipments expected to remain weak in the coming months.

site_title: France scraps plans for Franco- Chinese shopping mall near Paris
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has scrapped a 3-billion euro shopping mall project near Paris, EuropaCity, which was set to open in 2027. The project, involving French retail group Auchan and Chinese conglomerate Dalian Wanda, featured an indoor ski slope and circus. The decision comes after the Elysee Palace announced the project's cancellation on Thursday.

site_title: HRnetGroup Q3 profit down 4.9% after revaluation of securities
summary: HRnetGroup reported a 4.9% decline in Q3 net profit to S$12 million, primarily due to a revaluation of securities. Excluding this effect, net profit rose 3.1% to S$12.7 million.

site_title: US tech giants pledge billions for housing, but will it matter?
summary: US tech giants Apple, Google, and Facebook have pledged $4.5 billion to address California's affordable housing shortage. However, experts question the impact of the funds, citing high construction costs and local government resistance to new development. Building a single unit of subsidized affordable housing in California costs around $450,000, making the tech companies' investments seem inconsequential. The state needs to build 3.5 million housing units by 2025 to address the shortage, but the theoretical cost is $1.6 trillion, and experts argue that money alone cannot solve the issue, which is rooted in intransigent local politics and high housing costs.

site_title: MoneyMax Q3 profit more than triples to S$3m
summary: MoneyMax Financial Services reported a 3-fold increase in Q3 profit to S$3m, driven by stronger performance from certain business segments. Revenue surged 48.8% to S$52.9m, while material costs and employee benefits expenses also rose. The company expects the next 12 months to be challenging due to global uncertainties, but remains profitable for fiscal 2019. No dividend was declared, and shares closed at S$0.15, down 5.1%.

site_title: Moody's cuts India's outlook to 'negative' on growth risks
summary: Moody's Investors Service cut India's outlook to "negative" from "stable", citing growing risks of a slower economy growth due to government ineffectiveness and increasing debt burden. The ratings agency cut outlook for 21 Indian companies, including State Bank of India and Infosys, to "negative" from "stable". Despite a 5% year-on-year economic growth between April and June, Moody's expects a government deficit of 3.7% of GDP and a prolonged financial stress among rural households. India's economy fundamentals remain robust, but weak demand and a credit crunch among non-bank financial institutions weigh on corporate growth.

site_title: Venture Corp net profit rises 5.5% to to S$85.2m in Q3
summary: Venture Corp, a Singapore-based electronics manufacturing services firm, reported a 5.5% rise in net profit to S$85.2 million in Q3, driven by productivity and operational efficiency gains. Revenue rose 12.8% to S$869.1 million, while R&D expenses declined 54.6% due to lower customer demand. The company expects uncertainties in the business and geopolitical environment to persist, but plans to invest in new technology domains and ecosystems through multilateral partnerships.

site_title: UOB withdraws statutory demands, JM application against Hoe Leong Corp
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has withdrawn its application to place Hoe Leong Corp under judicial management after the Singapore High Court granted leave. UOB had filed a notice to withdraw its statutory demands, which were issued for S$5.7 million. Hoe Leong Corp is restructuring under financial pressure, having sold two vessels for US$1.7 million. The company is discussing a plan with UOB, which acquired a 28.66% stake in Hoe Leong Corp last year. The sale is expected to generate S$2.3 million in net proceeds.

site_title: DBS aims for moderate M&A diet to avoid indigestion
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, plans to focus on moderate acquisitions that complement its digital transformation efforts, rather than large deals that might distract from this goal. CEO Piyush Gupta stated that the bank will prioritize "bolt-on" acquisitions, valued at around 5% of its market cap, to conserve energy and bandwidth for this critical endeavor.

site_title: Four areas of misunderstanding around ESG integration
summary: Investors and practitioners have low understanding of Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) integration, including its definition, criteria, and performance. Despite research proving ESG integration can be beneficial, many perceive it as sacrificing performance due to misconceptions about negative screening. Key areas of misunderstanding include evidence of investment benefits, ESG issues, materiality, and ESG integration practices. To improve understanding, knowledge sharing, training, and case studies are essential, and investors should focus on developing their own materiality frameworks and considering ESG factors in fundamental analysis.

site_title: Former Xiaomi director paying S$31.5m for GCB in Tanglin Hill
summary: Former Xiaomi director Koh Tuck Lye is paying S$31.5 million for a 16,446 sq ft freehold land area in Tanglin Hill, Singapore, translating to S$1,915 per square foot. The buyer plans to tear down the 30-year-old bungalow and build a new house.

site_title: Finding balance in a tiny, wobbly boat
summary: A writer reflects on the toll of intense work and anxiety, feeling overwhelmed by the demands of late-stage capitalism. They realized their physical limitations and sought a new approach, trying rowing as a way to balance work and mindfulness. The experience taught them that physical activity and self-care were essential for managing stress and finding balance in life.

images.alt_text: Rowing is about perpetually starting over, as every stroke is an invitation to correct mistakes made during the one before.

site_title: EU Council approves EUSFTA, agreement to enter into force on Nov 21
summary: The European Union has approved the European Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA), which will enter into force on November 21, 2019. The agreement eliminates tariffs for 84% of EU products entering Singapore and 100% of Singapore exports to the EU, with remaining tariffs to be removed in 3-5 years. Singapore firms will gain improved market access to EU services sectors, including professional services and tourism, and enhanced access to EU public procurement opportunities. The agreement also aims to reduce unnecessary technical barriers to trade and promote green public tenders.

site_title: EU's new chief says Brexit 'shock' has 'strengthened bloc's unity'
summary: EU's new chief, Ursula von der Leyen, says Brexit has strengthened the bloc's unity, contrary to predictions of discord. She notes the EU's ability to grow stronger in times of crisis, particularly with the UK's departure. Von der Leyen believes the EU's unity is demonstrated by the bloc's collective stance on Brexit negotiations, despite differences among member states. This unity has helped to maintain the Good Friday Agreement in Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.

images.alt_text: The "shock" of Brexit has brought the rest of the bloc closer together, incoming European Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen said Friday.

site_title: KKR's new Asia-focused fund targets record US$15b in 2020
summary: Global private equity firm KKR is targeting a record $15 billion for its new Asia-focused buyout fund, which aims to invest in consumer, technology, and manufacturing firms across major markets including Australia, China, Japan, and India. The fund's fundraising will start in Q1 2020, with a first close by June, and has already received interest from prospective investors. This would be KKR's largest US dollar-denominated private equity capital raising in the region, surpassing its previous record of $9.3 billion in 2017.

site_title: Ronny Chieng remains a true blue Singaporean at heart
summary: Ronny Chieng, a Malaysian-born comedian of Singaporean descent, is set to perform two shows in Singapore as part of his Tone Issues Tour. The comedian, who has appeared on The Daily Show with Trevor Noah and has a Netflix special premiering in December, talks about his "tone issues" and his love for Singaporean food, particularly "char kway teow." Demand for tickets has been high, prompting a second performance to be added. Chieng's rise to fame began after he traded in his law degree for comedy, and he has since created his own television series and appeared on various US late-night shows.

site_title: S$7m grant set up to help food delivery riders affected by footpath ban
summary: A S$7 million grant has been established to help food delivery riders in Singapore replace their electric scooters, banned from footpaths, with bicycles or power-assisted bicycles. The grant, set up by the government and three major food delivery companies, provides up to S$1,000 for bicycles or S$600 for power-assisted bicycles. Riders can trade in their e-scooters from next Friday and must surrender them at designated points. The move aims to support affected riders who will switch to alternative modes of transport.

site_title: Temasek announces organisational changes
summary: Temasek International has announced organisational changes, effective January 1, 2020. CEO Dilhan Pillay Sandrasegara appointed Chia Song Hwee as deputy chief executive officer, aiming to adapt to complexity and deliver strategic initiatives. The changes focus on sustainability, with Temasek embedding its Environmental, Social, and Governance framework into investment processes and aiming to halve its portfolio's carbon footprint by 2030.

site_title: Strong fintech opportunities still open in emerging, developed Asia markets: Fitch Solutions
summary: Fitch Solutions Macro Research reports that emerging and developed Asia markets offer strong fintech opportunities, driven by venture capital funding, mobile broadband expansion, and supportive regulators. The region's massive population of 54% of the global population and $30 trillion annual GDP presents a wide range of opportunities. In developed markets, fintech focuses on peer-to-peer lending, wealth management, and microfinancing, while in emerging markets, mobile money and e-payments dominate. The report also notes increased fintech regulation and a high interest in cryptocurrencies, with Asian central banks regulating digital currencies to prevent money laundering.

site_title: Is Singapore's semicon sector on the skids?
summary: Singapore's semiconductor sector is experiencing a down cycle amid slow consumer demand and ongoing US-China tensions. Despite this, the industry's global competitiveness is being questioned. Industry observers believe Singapore's high costs, lack of subsidies, and distance from key manufacturing sites make it challenging for companies to compete. However, the government is investing heavily to boost the industry, with a focus on emerging trends in artificial intelligence, autonomous vehicles, and smart manufacturing. Despite this, some experts argue that preserving the industry may not be worth the cost, and a pragmatic approach is needed to ensure the nation's overall manufacturing sector remains vibrant.

site_title: Japan's Abe tells Cabinet to compile stimulus package to support economy
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe asked his Cabinet to compile a stimulus package to support the economy, focusing on investment for growth and infrastructure development to cope with natural disasters. The package will include measures to promote investment and address overseas risks affecting Japan's economy, which has been hurt by the US-China trade war and soft global demand. The size and scope of the package will depend on proposals from various ministries, with a supplementary budget and annual budget to be compiled by the year-end and April 2020, respectively.

site_title: Global bond sell-off persuades some investors to buy the dip
summary: A global bond sell-off has sparked buying interest among investors, particularly those with a grim view of the economy. Yields on 10-year US Treasuries dropped to 1.91% in Asia, after reaching a three-month high of 1.97% on Thursday. Some investors see the sell-off as a buying opportunity, citing improved US-China trade talks and a potential recession. Experts expect the sell-off to be contained, with yields likely to stay low, and some traders have profited from lucrative bets on the recent yield climb.

site_title: Launched: All-in-one Singapore platform integrating PayNow, Nets and other e-payment methods
summary: Rapyd, a London-based fintech startup, has launched an all-in-one payment platform in Singapore, integrating key payment methods such as PayNow, Nets, and GrabPay. The platform, called the Singapore Platform, allows users to make cross-border payments and enables merchants to make or accept payments using various methods. The platform uses Rapyd's infrastructure to facilitate real-time fund movement, simplifying the payment process and reducing costs. The move aims to make it easier for users to go cashless and enable merchants to offer multiple payment options, with the platform set to expand globally.

site_title: Best World's net profit down 16.9% at S$24.8m in Q3
summary: Best World International, a Singapore-based skincare company, reported a 16.9% decline in Q3 net profit to S$24.8 million, despite a 41.2% revenue growth to S$114.3 million. The company attributed the earnings slide to the lack of one-time "other operating income" in the previous year. Revenue was driven by gains in direct selling and franchise sales segments, but profit was eroded by rising cost of sales and increased custom duties on US-made skincare products. The company's shares remain suspended due to an ongoing probe by the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: UIC posts 13.1% fall in Q3 net profit
summary: United Industrial Corp (UIC) posted a 13.1% year-on-year decline in Q3 net profit to S$52.9 million, despite a 28% increase in revenue to S$194.4 million. The company attributed the decline to increased selling and distribution costs, administrative expenses, and finance costs related to its consolidation of the Marina Mandarin hotel complex. UIC expects to take a year to increase income from the complex and plans to leverage its recently acquired stake in Marina Centre to expand its income base.

site_title: Aspial's profit slips after buyers walk away from Australia 108 as property cycle turns
summary: Aspial Corp's third-quarter profit fell 69% to S$5.7 million due to fewer settlements at the Australia 108 mega project in Melbourne. The decline in revenue was attributed to the property cycle turning, with buyers walking away from the project. Despite this, the company expects to receive fresh cash from handovers, which should improve its debt profile. Aspial's revenue is expected to continue to be impacted by the property market, but the company remains optimistic about its prospects.

site_title: Climate change: companies must adapt or perish
summary: Companies face increasing pressures from climate change, including regulatory, environmental, and consumer pressures, which could upend business models. The past five years (2015-2019) are the hottest on record, and climate change's physical effects are felt globally. Policymakers' strengthened response to climate change creates both risks and opportunities for businesses. Adapting to climate change is crucial for companies to survive, as longer-term climate risks could lead to significant disruptions.

site_title: Mastercard, Tappy to embed payment chips in fashion items
summary: Mastercard and Tappy Technologies have partnered to embed payment chips into fashion accessories such as watches, sunglasses, and bracelets. The first product to debut will be Timex Group's payment-enabled analogue watches, set to launch in Singapore and other South-east Asian markets in 2020. The technology, patented by Tappy, features a waterproof chip with a fingerprint sensor for two-factor verification and will be integrated with Mastercard's Digital Enablement Service. This allows consumers to use fashion accessories as a payment method at Mastercard merchants that accept contactless payments.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The High Court granted a debt moratorium to Koon Holdings and a subsidiary until February 28, 2020, as part of their restructuring exercise. Meanwhile, Hiap Hoe reported an 82% year-on-year decline in net profit and a 16.3% revenue drop in the third quarter. Metro Holdings took a 20% stake in an Australian property portfolio for S$89.5 million, while CapitaLand sold a serviced residence property for S$101 million. Other companies, including ISDN Holdings, SK Jewellery Group, and Yeo Hiap Seng, also reported significant declines in net profit and revenue.

site_title: China bedevilled by a banking mess
summary: China's banking system is undergoing a painful cleanup, with multiple banks experiencing trouble in quick succession since May. A bank failed, while two others were bailed out, prompting depositors to rush out their savings. The government is trying to suppress panic while addressing the issues, which could have led to a financial meltdown in the US. The country's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Chinese banks have also struggled with Beijing's consumer lending push, and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) is considering a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus to counter US tariffs.

site_title: SK Jewellery posts 57.9% fall in Q3 net profit
summary: SK Jewellery Group reported a 57.9% drop in Q3 net profit to S$459,000 due to lower revenue and increased depreciation expenses. Revenue fell 46.2% to S$32.6 million, primarily due to the cessation of SK Bullion operations in May. Net asset value per share was 10.83 Singapore cents as of Sept 30, with no dividend declared.

site_title: Hedge fund plans distressed Asia credit fund as stress looms
summary: A Hong Kong-based hedge fund, Double Haven Capital, plans to raise $250-500 million for its first distressed Asia credit fund, targeting stressed bonds yielding at least 1,000 basis points over US Treasuries. The fund aims to profit from refinancing risks and fears surrounding potential defaults. The market for such notes has grown to $60 billion, with many stressed borrowers being first-time issuers with limited investor relations capabilities. The fund will also include a small part of Double Haven's private lending business.

site_title: Temasek Lifesciences Accelerator launches incubator to invest in startups
summary: Temasek Lifesciences Accelerator (TLA) has launched The Hatchery, a life sciences startup incubator in Singapore. The incubator provides access to mentorship, 17,000 sq ft of co-working space, and research facilities. TLA aims to fund and support over 30 startups in the next five years, with a target of S$100 million in funds raised. The Hatchery is part of Enterprise Singapore's Startup SG Accelerator initiative and has already supported startups like Allegro Aqua and Pathnova. TLA's goal is to provide a nurturing environment for startups to deliver real-world impact.

images.alt_text: Temasek Lifesciences Accelerator (TLA) has launched a life sciences startup programme to incubate over 30 startups in the next five years.

site_title: US mortgage rates retreat for first time in 3 weeks
summary: US mortgage rates fell for the first time in three weeks, dropping to 3.69% for a 30-year fixed-rate average. This decline follows a five-week decline trend. The 15-year fixed-rate average fell to 3.13% and the five-year adjustable rate average dropped to 3.39%. The temporary decline is attributed to market volatility, with rates expected to rise again in the near future.

site_title: Singapore fintech startup DEXTF raises US$460,000 in seed funding
summary: Singapore-based fintech startup DEXTF has secured US$460,000 in seed funding led by LuneX Ventures and SGInnovate. The platform aims to bridge investors with asset managers, eliminating intermediaries and enabling non-custodial fund management. With the new capital, DEXTF plans to launch its product and further develop its technology, addressing the need for a more efficient and secure digital asset management system.

site_title: Singapore's wealthy grew their riches by 10.5% from last year
summary: Singapore's 22 billionaires, primarily in real estate and consumer retail, saw a 10.5% increase in wealth from last year, defying the global trend of declining billionaire wealth. This growth is attributed to the robust demand for goods and services from Asia's growing middle class.

site_title: And the band played on
summary: YouTube Music is now available in Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Philippines, Hong Kong, and Taiwan, offering personalized music streaming and playlists. YouTube Premium, the paid version, allows background playback, offline downloads, and ad-free experiences. A report shows that in-app purchases are declining, with gamers preferring to spend on fewer games rather than multiple franchises. The decline is attributed to the community's wariness of IAP-style marketing gimmicks and the failure of additional game content to attract players.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.7% as traders ease into weekend
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.65% on Friday, retreating from a four-day advance, as traders took profits ahead of the weekend and released weaker earnings. The Straits Times Index closed at 3,264.30, down 21.42 points. This marks the largest decline among regional markets.

site_title: The secret and frustrating life of a Google contract worker
summary: Google's workforce is divided into two tiers: permanent employees and temporary, vendor, or contract staff. More than half of its workers are in the latter category, missing out on benefits and perks. Kevin Kiprovski, a contract worker, revealed his $40,000 annual salary while demoing Google gear to students, sparking a confrontation with a teacher. Kiprovski resigned and sent an email criticizing the disparities, highlighting the stark contrast between his low pay and the company's reputation. This raises questions about Google's labor practices and the treatment of its contract workers.

site_title: Centuries old warships linked to 'Vasa' found in Sweden
summary: Swedish maritime archeologists discovered two 17th-century warships in the Swedish archipelago, believed to be the sister ship of the iconic "Vasa", which sank in 1628. The wrecks, found in a strait leading into Stockholm, are in good condition due to the brackish waters of the Baltic Sea. The ships are thought to have been sunk on purpose after decommissioning, serving as underwater spike strips for enemy ships. Wood samples will be sent to a laboratory for dating, aiming to identify the ships and confirm their connection to the "Vasa".

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open lower as trade-fueled rally pauses
summary: The US stock market opened lower on Friday, pausing its record run fueled by trade hopes and strong corporate earnings. The S&P 500 fell 0.13% to 3,081.25, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.14% to 8,422.67. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.04% to 27,686.20. The decline comes despite optimism about a potential US-China trade truce and an upbeat earnings season.

site_title: Reits (November 9-10, 2019)
summary: Realtors reported mixed results for the week of November 9-10, 2019. US mortgage rates declined for the fifth consecutive week, while UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches is expected to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents hit a record, and Goldman Sachs acquired 262 billion won hotel and retail assets in Seoul. New World is selling its China property assets after securing a loan deal, and WeWork secured new tenants at its post-bankruptcy space in Singapore.

site_title: POSH appoints Provenance Capital as independent financial adviser in Kuok cash offer
summary: POSH appoints Provenance Capital as its independent financial adviser for the buy-out offer from Robert Kuok's Kuok group of companies. The offer, announced on November 4, values POSH at S$0.215 in cash per share. The board advises shareholders to exercise caution and consider the independent directors' recommendations when a circular is sent out. POSH's shares closed up 2.38% at the offer price, but the company's struggles and the need for caution have raised concerns among investors.

site_title: LVMH does not rule out raising Tiffany bid: sources
summary: LVMH, the French luxury giant, has not ruled out raising its initial $14.5 billion offer to acquire US jeweler Tiffany, sources close to the deal say. The offer, which values Tiffany at $14.5 billion, was initially met with skepticism by Tiffany's board, who believe it is too low. Following a request from Tiffany's board to reconsider, LVMH resumed talks and is considering a price increase, with some sources estimating it could reach $135-$140 per share. If successful, the deal would be one of the largest ever for LVMH.

site_title: Christmas currency shopping: pound or euro?
summary: A strong rally in the pound (GBP) has led to a potential breakout from a long-term downtrend, with a possible target of 1.33. In contrast, the euro (EUR) is experiencing a temporary rally within a strong downtrend, with little evidence of a trend change. Investors remain short the EUR/USD, and a retreat is expected to reach 1.08. The GBP/USD rally has the potential to develop into a sustained trend change, making it a better choice for holiday spending.

site_title: Synagie Corp launches S$0.10-a-share rights issue to fund 2020 growth plans
summary: Synagie Corp, a Catalist-listed e-commerce solutions provider, plans to raise up to S$3.84 million through a renounceable non-underwritten rights issue at S$0.10 per share. The issue, which will yield net proceeds of S$2.12 to S$3.84 million, aims to fund expansion plans in 2020, including the launch in Indonesia and partnerships in Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, and Vietnam. The company will use one-third of the proceeds for working capital and has secured commitments from several shareholders.

site_title: US may postpone China tariffs due in December: Trump advisor
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade adviser, Peter Navarro, said tariffs on Chinese goods scheduled to take effect in December may be postponed, but existing tariffs would not be rolled back. This comes as negotiations between the US and China appear to be progressing, with White House officials expressing optimism about reaching a phase one trade deal. If a deal is reached, it could include tariff agreements and concessions, although no details have been revealed. The proposed postponement of December's tariffs would be seen as a positive development for investors worldwide.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump could postpone tariffs on Chinese goods scheduled to take effect in December, White House trade adviser Peter Navarro said Friday.

site_title: Trader linked to S$39.9m SkillsFuture scam jailed for 6 years and 8 months
summary: A Singaporean trader, Vincent Peter, 51, was jailed for 6 years and 8 months for money laundering offences related to a S$39.9 million SkillsFuture scam. He handled over S$4 million of the scammers' ill-gotten gains from 2017. This is the sixth person linked to the scam to be convicted, with others sentenced to jail earlier. The scam targeted SkillsFuture Singapore, a public institution, and involved 9 dormant companies with 8,386 fraudulent course fee grant applications.

site_title: Australian bushfires wipe out half of koala colony, threaten more
summary: Australian bushfires have destroyed about half of the koalas living on a coastal reserve in New South Wales, with around 350 koalas estimated to have died. The Lake Innes Nature Reserve, home to 500-600 koalas, has seen two-thirds of its habitat destroyed, leaving the rest under threat from 15 major blazes. Experts warn that warmer weather due to climate change and deforestation will worsen conditions for koalas, potentially leading to extinction by mid-century if decline rates continue.

site_title: Yoma Strategic flags expected Q2 loss
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a Q2 loss due to a fair value loss of approximately US$32 million from its disposal of a Chinese investment. The company plans to use the proceeds to expand its core businesses and repay debt. Yoma Strategic also announced plans to divest its telecommunication tower investment for US$57.5 million and acquire an additional 10% interest in Digital Money Myanmar Ltd for US$6 million, with the latter being considered an interested person transaction.

site_title: Tennis' hottest young stars on show at ATP Finals
summary: The ATP Finals, a season-ending tennis tournament, is set to take place in London, with the world's top eight singles players and doubles teams competing for the $9 million prize pool. Three young stars, Daniil Medvedev, Stefanos Tsitsipas, and Matteo Berrettini, make their debut in the tournament. Rafael Nadal, the world No. 1, will begin the tournament on Monday night, but is not fully fit due to an abdominal strain. Novak Djokovic is the bookies' favourite to win, while Roger Federer aims to equal his record of six titles. The tournament will feature a round-robin stage, with the top players vying for the trophy.

site_title: AsiaPhos Chinese subsidiary's ex-staff withdraw severance pay claims: board
summary: AsiaPhos, a Chinese phosphate miner, has reported that 11 out of 12 former employees' claims for severance pay have been voluntarily withdrawn. The claims, totaling around 1.84 million yuan, were initially filed after a court dismissed a similar claim in September. The company's board stated that further announcements will be made regarding the legal proceedings. The news did not impact AsiaPhos' share price, which closed at 0.8 Singapore cent.

site_title: Best World reports 16.9% drop in Q3 profits to S$24.8m
summary: Best World International, a Singapore-listed skincare company, reported a 16.9% decline in Q3 profits to S$24.8m, despite a 41.2% revenue growth. The decline was attributed to increased cost of sales and higher distribution costs. The company is under scrutiny by the Singapore Exchange over its sales model in China, and its CEO, Dora Hoan, is facing concerns over her relationship with a key customer. Best World has switched to a "franchise" model and is facing ongoing investigations and legal issues.

site_title: Triyards receives summons to be placed under judicial management
summary: Tyrays Holdings, a Singapore-based marine operator, has received a summons to be placed under judicial management by OCBC. The bank is seeking the appointment of interim judicial managers and a pre-trial conference is set for November 28. Tyrays shares have been suspended since 2017 and the company is assessing the impact of the applications and seeking legal advice. A hearing date has not been fixed yet for the judicial management application. The company's financial situation has been troubled, with shares suspended since 2017.

site_title: Billionaires' wealth falls for first time since 2015
summary: The world's richest people saw their wealth decline for the first time since 2015, according to a report by UBS and PwC. Billionaires' wealth fell 4.3% globally to US$8.5 trillion last year, primarily due to geopolitical turmoil and volatile equity markets. The decline was particularly sharp in Greater China and the Asia-Pacific region. Private wealth in Hong Kong fell 4% in 2018, amidst anti-government protests and an economic recession.

site_title: Total securities market turnover up 9% m-o-m to S$21.6b in October: SGX
summary: Singapore's total securities market turnover rose 9% month-on-month to S$21.6 billion in October, driven by a return of risk appetite amid US-China trade negotiations and easing Brexit uncertainties. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 4% in October, while benchmark futures volumes declined 14% month-on-month. Lendlease Global Commercial Reit raised S$740.3 million in its IPO, and SGX saw increased secondary equity fundraising activity and sustainability bond listings.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng Q3 net profit jumps to S$2.76m on absence of fair-value loss
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng, a mainboard-listed drinks maker, reported a significant surge in third-quarter net profit to S$2.76 million, up from S$95,000 in the same period last year. The company's revenue rose 9.6% to S$93.8 million, driven by higher sales in Singapore, Cambodia, China, and Europe. The absence of fair-value losses on equity investments contributed to the earnings boost.

site_title: EUSFTA approved, targeted to come into force on Nov 21
summary: The European Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) has received final approval from the Council of the European Union, with the aim of entering into force on November 21, 2019. The agreement eliminates tariffs for 84% of EU products entering Singapore and 100% of Singapore exports to the EU, with the remaining 16% tariffs to be removed over three to five years. The EUSFTA also improves market access for Singapore firms in various services sectors and removes technical barriers to trade in areas such as electronics and pharmaceuticals.

site_title: ISDN Q3 net profit falls 25.5%
summary: ISDN Holdings reported a 25.5% decline in net profit to S$1.8 million in Q3, mainly due to a general economic slowdown and depreciation of the Chinese yuan. Revenue fell 5.8% to S$64.7 million. For the 9 months ended Sept 30, net profit declined 41.2% and revenue decreased 8.3%. This marks a continuation of the company's declining financial performance.

site_title: Metro Holdings buys 20% of Australian property portfolio for A$95.8m
summary: Metro Holdings, a department store operator, has acquired a 20% stake in a US$95.8 million Australian property portfolio through a joint venture agreement with regional property group Sim Lian. The portfolio consists of 14 freehold properties across Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne, and Perth. Metro will manage the portfolio through an asset management company, citing high occupancy and defensive leases. The investment is expected to generate a stable income stream, but is not expected to significantly affect Metro's consolidated net tangible assets and earnings per share.

site_title: DLF buyout offer closes with 64% shares acquired
summary: DLF Holdings' buyout offer closed with QRC Pte Ltd acquiring approximately 64.13% shares, exceeding the 64% target. The offeror, QRC, aims to carry on DLF's existing business and maintain its listing status. The acquisition was triggered after QRC acquired a 57.16% stake in the company at S$0.0809 per share, followed by an offer of S$0.081 per share for the remaining shares. DLF shares closed unchanged at S$0.185 on the day of the offer's closure.

site_title: Indian WhatsApp users ask govt to explain ties with Israeli firm in privacy breach case
summary: A group of 19 Indian users, including journalists and lawyers, have asked the government to explain ties with Israeli firm NSO Group over a privacy breach involving WhatsApp. The group, affected by NSO's Pegasus spyware, claimed their safety and security were compromised. WhatsApp accused NSO of helping clients break into phones of 1,400 users worldwide. The Indian government has neither confirmed nor denied using the spyware and has asked WhatsApp to explain the breach and safeguard user privacy.

site_title: Ryobi Kiso judicial managers ask to push creditors' meeting deadline into 2020
summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings' judicial managers have asked to extend the deadline for sending creditors a statement of proposals and summoning a creditors' meeting from November 13, 2019, to May 13, 2020, and the judicial management period from November 13, 2019, to June 13, 2020. They also seek permission to make interim distributions to unsecured creditors on the court's terms. The request will be heard on November 15, 2019.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.7% as traders ease into weekend
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.65% on Friday, retreating from a four-day advance, as traders took profit ahead of the weekend and released weaker earnings. The index closed at 3,264.30, down 21.42 points, with tech manufacturing plays like Hi-P International, AEM Holdings, and UMS Holdings seeing declines. The decline cut the benchmark index's four-day winning streak but still finished 1.08% higher than the previous week.

site_title: S$7m grant to help food delivery riders affected by footpath ban replace e-scooters
summary: The Singapore government has introduced a S$7 million grant to help food delivery riders replace their electric scooters banned from footpaths. Riders can trade in their e-scooters for up to S$1,000 for a power-assisted bicycle or S$600 for a bicycle. The grant aims to support affected delivery riders in switching to alternative modes of transportation, such as bicycles or personal mobility aids.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.40 points to 1,609.73. Volume reached 3.105 billion lots worth RM2.153 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 422 to 411, indicating a positive market sentiment.

site_title: Temasek announces organisational changes
summary: Temasek International has announced organisational changes, effective January 1, 2020. CEO Dilhan Pillay Sandrasegara appointed Chia Song Hwee as deputy CEO, and made other appointments to drive strategic and institutional initiatives. Pillay emphasized the need for clarity and robustness in the face of increasing complexity, while maintaining a commitment to sustainability. The changes aim to support Temasek's strategic and institutional initiatives, and to halve its portfolio's carbon footprint by 2030.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: NTUC plans to raise retirement and re-employment ages to 2021, ahead of national schedule. Temasek Lifesciences Accelerator launches an incubator, The Hatchery, to invest in startups. UOB withdraws its application to place Hoe Leong under judicial management. A new all-in-one Singapore payment platform, Rapyd, has been launched, allowing for instant collections and payouts overseas. Vividthree will be the exclusive tech provider for Malaysia's HeurêkaLand Project. Corporate earnings reports show mixed results, with HRnetGroup and MoneyMax experiencing increases in profits, while SUTL Enterprise saw a decline.

site_title: Lion Air finds cracks in two Boeing 737 NGs with fewer flights than FAA safety directive
summary: Lion Air, an Indonesian airline, has found structural cracks in two Boeing 737 NG planes with fewer flights than the US Federal Aviation Administration's (FAA) safety directive. The cracks, located on the "pickle fork" part, are now grounded for repairs. The discovery could prompt the FAA to require inspections for 737 NGs with fewer than 22,600 cycles, which had not been mandated previously. The incident highlights ongoing scrutiny on airline maintenance operations following the 2018 Lion Air crash that killed 189 people.

images.alt_text: Lion Air has found structural cracks in two Boeing 737 NG planes with fewer flights than a US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) threshold for checks, Indonesia's aviation safety regulator said on Friday.

site_title: United Industrial Corp Q3 earnings drop by 13.1% amid Marina Mandarin consolidation
summary: United Industrial Corp (UIC) reported a 13.1% year-on-year drop in Q3 net profit to S$52.9 million, despite a 28% revenue growth to S$194.4 million. The decline was attributed to higher costs and lower share of associates' and joint ventures' profits, primarily due to the consolidation of Marina Mandarin hotel complex expenses. Earnings per share fell to 3.7 Singapore cents, and UIC expects to take a year to expand its income base from the Marina Mandarin deal.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall to snap six-day winning streak
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended a six-day winning streak with significant losses, falling 0.7% to 27,651.14. Investors took cash off the table amid planned protests over the weekend, contributing to the losses. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with losses of 0.49% and 0.19% respectively. The losses marked a reversal of the previous week's gains, as investors sought to lock in profits and prepare for potential market volatility.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index fell 0.7 per cent, or 196.09 points, to 27,651.14.

site_title: Americans have more debt, need family help to buy homes: report
summary: Americans are waiting longer to buy their first homes, with the median age hitting 33 for the first time, amid a supply crunch that's pushed up prices. The median sales price rose to $272,100 in September, with African Americans and Hispanics making up a small share of homebuyers, despite comprising a larger share of the US population. Low interest rates and unemployment have made mortgages more accessible, but the shortage of workers has hindered homebuilders. Homeownership for blacks is at historic lows, with significant implications for building wealth and creating a nest egg.

site_title: China export drop beats forecasts in October but more pain tipped
summary: China's exports declined for the third consecutive month in October, with a 0.9% drop compared to forecasts of a 3.9% plunge. Imports also fell for the sixth straight month, dropping 6.4%. Despite a slower decline, economists warn of more pain to come due to the ongoing US trade war, which has dragged on the global economy. A mini trade deal between China and the US may ease tensions, but it's unlikely to alleviate the main headwinds facing exporters. China's trade surplus with the US increased to $26.42 billion.

site_title: Y Ventures queried by SGX after shares jump 18%
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) queried Catalist-listed Y Ventures after its shares surged 18.1% to 12.4 cents, with 56 million shares changing hands. Y Ventures attributed the price jump to discussions with a potential joint venture (JV) partner, but stated no definitive terms or binding agreement had been reached. The company claims not to know of any information not previously announced that might explain the price surge. This is the third SGX query to Y Ventures in six months.

site_title: Venture Corp Q3 net profit rises 5.5%
summary: Venture Corp reported a 5.5% increase in Q3 net profit to S$85.2 million, driven by productivity gains and operational efficiency. Revenue rose 12.8% to S$869.1 million, and earnings per share improved to 29.5 Singapore cents. The company expects to see traction in new technology domains and ecosystems, with plans to invest in growing capabilities through multilateral partnerships. Net profit for the nine months ended Sept 30 edged up 1.7% to S$266.9 million.

site_title: UOB withdraws JM application, statutory demands against Hoe Leong
summary: UOB withdraws its application to place Hoe Leong Corporation under judicial management after the Singapore High Court granted leave for withdrawal. The bank also withdraws statutory demands against the company, which had received a demand for S$5.7 million. Hoe Leong Corp is under financial pressure due to its restructuring plan and proposed sale of two vessels for US$1.7 million, expected to generate S$2.3 million in net proceeds. The sale is part of a plan to restructure debt owed to bank creditors and its controlling shareholder.

site_title: Hiap Hoe Q3 net profit falls 82%
summary: Hiap Hoe, a property developer, reported an 82% decline in net profit to S$114,000 in the third quarter due to lower sales of development properties and higher expenses. Revenue fell 16.3% to S$35.3 million. The company attributed the decline to the acquisition of Aloft Perth hotel in March. Despite this, earnings per share improved to 0.02 Singapore cent. For the nine months, net profit rose 74.5% to S$5.9 million, while revenue fell 37.9% to S$96.6 million.

site_title: Australia: Shares steady as energy gains offset gold plunge; NZ up
summary: Australian shares closed little changed, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 0.04% due to a sell-off in gold miners. Gains in energy stocks, particularly Woodside Petroleum, offset the losses. The index posted a weekly gain of 0.8%. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.8%, driven by a weekly gain of 1.1%. The decline in gold prices, which slumped 2% overnight, was attributed to signals of progress in trade talks.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as trade-fueled rally loses steam
summary: European shares fell 0.4% on Friday, halting a week-long rally, due to mixed signals on US-China trade. A planned tariff rollback was met with internal opposition in the White House, dampening hopes. Tariff-hit miners, such as copper miners, fell 1.3%, while defensive plays like telecoms and utilities gained. The week's gains were the fifth straight for the pan-European STOXX 600 index.

site_title: Mastercard, Tappy tie up to embed payment chips in fashion accessories
summary: Mastercard and Tappy Technologies have partnered to embed payment chips in fashion accessories, allowing consumers in Singapore to make contactless payments using watches, sunglasses, bracelets, and rings. The first product, Timex Group's analogue watches, will be launched in the first half of 2020 in Singapore and other Southeast Asian markets. Tappy's patented chip features a fingerprint sensor for two-factor verification and can be integrated with Mastercard's Digital Enablement Service. The partnership aims to expand payment functionality beyond smart watches and cater to fashion-conscious consumers seeking payment capabilities in accessories.

site_title: Japan's Abe tells cabinet to compile stimulus package to support economy
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe asked his cabinet to compile a stimulus package to support the economy and build infrastructure to cope with natural disasters. The package will include measures to promote investment for growth through fiscal investment and loan programs.
