The government aims to release the package as soon as possible, with the size of spending dependent on proposals from various ministries. The move comes as Japan's economy faces pressure from the US-China trade war and soft global demand.

site_title: SUTL Enterprise Q3 profit falls 35% to S$0.6m on higher costs for new marina club
summary: SUTL Enterprise Limited reported a 35% decline in its third-quarter net profit to S$612,000, mainly due to higher costs for its ONE°15 Marina Puteri Harbour club in Malaysia. Revenue dropped 4% to S$7.7 million, but sales of goods and services increased by 7% to S$5.1 million. The company maintains a healthy financial position with S$45.5 million in cash and cash equivalents. Despite the decline, SUTL remains optimistic about its business, citing the global leisure boat market's forecasted growth to US$56.26 billion by 2026.

site_title: CapitaLand sells HK serviced residence for HK$581.8m
summary: CapitaLand sold its Hong Kong serviced residence, Citadines Mercer Hong Kong, for HK$581.8 million (S$101 million) to an unnamed third party. The sale is part of the company's strategy to divest from underperforming assets. The property's net asset value and agreed value were considered in the sale price, which is below the property's original value of HK$740.8 million.

site_title: S Korea: Stocks snap winning streak on trade deal uncertainty
summary: South Korean shares snapped a six-session winning streak on Friday due to uncertainty over a Sino-US trade deal. The deal aims to roll back existing tariffs, but White House officials and outside advisers oppose it. Despite initial optimism, Reuters reported that the agreement faces fierce opposition, causing stocks to decline. The uncertainty has cast a shadow over the market, affecting investor confidence.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon down 0.88% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading on Friday afternoon down 0.88% or 28.79 points to 3,256.93, with 869.8 million securities worth S$612.2 million traded. Banking stocks, such as DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also fell. The decline was part of a broader negative trend in Asian markets, with MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan down 0.2%.

site_title: Strong opportunities for fintech in emerging, developed Asia markets: Fitch Solutions
summary: Fintech companies and investors see strong opportunities in emerging and developed Asia markets, driven by substantial venture capital funding and expanding mobile broadband. In developed markets like Singapore, fintech focuses on peer-to-peer lending, wealth management, and cryptocurrencies due to a saturated payments market. In contrast, emerging markets like Bangladesh and Pakistan favor mobile money and e-payments. Asian fintech companies raised $22.7 billion in funding in 2018, and increased regulation has led to a focus on data protection and cybersecurity.

site_title: Working individuals to have shot at entrepreneurship through Antler-NUS tie-up
summary: Antler, a talent incubator, has teamed up with the National University of Singapore (NUS) to launch a part-time startup program, allowing working individuals to pursue entrepreneurship while keeping their current jobs. The program, which will support up to 60 participants annually, provides funding of up to S$240,000 and access to global advisory networks. Founders with software or deep tech skills will be matched with those with business backgrounds, and the program will run in two phases, with a US$100,000 investment and further funding of S$100,000 available.

site_title: Tech firms react to netizens' digital privacy concerns
summary: Tech firms are responding to growing digital privacy concerns by showcasing their skills and launching initiatives to address the issue. Whistleblowers and digital pioneers have long sounded the alarm about online privacy abuses, and now, entrepreneurs are bidding to turn this concern into a profitable industry. At the Web Summit in Lisbon, tech entrepreneurs showcased their skills, with organizer Paddy Cosgrave stating that there is a growing movement to regain digital privacy rights.

images.alt_text: "Providing personalised encryption at the level of the device, so that any key stroke on your device is unreadable by a third party ... is booming. There are many companies trying to make progress in this space," Mr Cosgrave said.

site_title: Royal Mail seeks to block potential Christmas strike
summary: Royal Mail is seeking an interim order to block a potential Christmas strike by its union, the Communication Workers Union, citing concerns about the General Election on December 12. The CWU voted 97% in favour of a nationwide strike, claiming the company failed to adhere to a pension deal agreed last year. Royal Mail claims it has honoured the deal. The move comes amid worries about industrial action around Christmas, a traditionally busy period for the postal service.

site_title: WEnergy Global, partners pump US$20m into four Philippines energy projects
summary: Singapore-based WEnergy Global and its partners are investing US$20 million in four new energy projects in the Philippines, aiming to bring sustainable renewable energy to off-grid communities. The projects, set to be completed in two years, are designed to replicate the success of the Sabang Renewable Energy Microgrid project, which was commissioned in 2019. The Philippine Department of Energy encourages decentralised energy systems through the private sector to end energy poverty by 2022, with WEnergy Global's investment in line with this goal.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on trade optimism
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher for a fourth consecutive session, driven by optimism over a potential China-US trade deal. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.26% to 23,391.87, while the Topix index gained 0.27% to 1,702.77. Banks and automakers, such as Mitsubishi UFJ Financial and Toyota, saw significant gains, with Honda's net profit still declining due to currency exchange rates and sales. The move follows Wall Street's recent rally, with the US Dow and S&P 500 finishing at fresh records.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks closed higher for a fourth straight session on Friday, extending rallies on Wall Street on hopes of a China-US trade deal.

site_title: All-in-one Singapore payment platform launched by fintech startup Rapyd
summary: Rapyd, a London-based fintech startup, has launched an all-in-one payment platform in Singapore, integrating major payment methods and enabling businesses and consumers to make cross-border payments instantly. The platform uses Rapyd's infrastructure to facilitate real-time fund movement and offers over 900 payment types across 100 countries. The launch simplifies the payment process, reduces costs, and improves operational efficiencies for merchants. This follows Rapyd's recent remittance licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore and a $100 million Series C funding round led by Oak HC/FT.

site_title: Hong Kong student who fell during protest clashes dies
summary: A Hong Kong student, Alex Chow, who fell from a multi-storey car park during police and protester clashes last weekend has died, hospital officials confirmed. Chow, a computer science undergraduate, was taken to the hospital in an unconscious state on Monday morning after being found in a pool of blood inside a car park where police fired tear gas. The circumstances of his injury are unclear, but he has been embraced by the five-month-old protest movement. His death is likely to raise tensions in the city after months of violent rallies.

site_title: Japan seizes record 400kg of cocaine at port
summary: Japanese authorities have seized a record 400kg of cocaine worth approximately $73 million at Kobe port. This exceeds the previous record set in August at 177kg. The origin of the cocaine is unclear, with speculation that it may have been sent by mistake. Japan has strict drug laws, and users face severe public opprobrium. The seizure is a significant blow to organized crime, which relies heavily on drug sales for financial gain.

site_title: Five killed, 120 injured in Iran earthquake
summary: A 5.9-magnitude earthquake struck northwestern Iran on Friday, killing five people and injuring 120. The quake, described as "moderate", was 8km deep and followed by five aftershocks. It occurred about 120km southeast of Tabriz, East Azerbaijan Province.

site_title: Japanese companies likely to spurn Saudi Aramco IPO - JXTG president
summary: Japanese companies are unlikely to invest in Saudi Aramco's IPO due to difficulties in evaluating the company's value, according to JXTG president. Despite Aramco's plans to raise $20-40 billion, typically conservative Japanese companies may be hesitant, citing concerns over the company's valuation. This could impact the IPO, which has been announced but released few details.

site_title: Singapore fintech startup DEXTF raises US$460,000 in seed funding
summary: Singapore-based fintech startup DEXTF has secured US$460,000 in seed funding from LuneX Ventures and SGInnovate, with the goal of launching a decentralized traded funds platform that eliminates intermediaries and empowers investors. The funding will be used to complete the proof of concept and develop the product, with the aim of democratizing digital asset management and providing a secure and scalable solution. The platform will bridge investors with asset managers, enabling delegation of investment decisions without transferring ownership of assets.

site_title: Moody's cuts India's outlook to 'negative' on mounting growth risks
summary: Moody's Investors Service cut India's ratings outlook to "negative" from "stable" due to mounting growth risks. The agency cited government and policy ineffectiveness in addressing economic weakness, leading to increased debt burden. Despite retaining a 'Baa2' rating, Moody's warned of prolonged financial stress, weak job creation, and a credit crunch among non-bank financial institutions, which may lead to a more entrenched slowdown. India's economy grew 5.0% year-on-year in Q2, its weakest pace since 2013, amid global trade frictions and domestic slowdowns.

site_title: Temasek Lifesciences Accelerator launches incubator, to invest in startups
summary: Temasek Lifesciences Accelerator has launched The Hatchery, a life sciences startup incubator providing mentorship, co-working space, and research facilities to over 30 startups in the next five years. The incubator will be funded by The Lifesciences Innovation Fund, aiming to support startups with up to S$100 million in funds raised. The Hatchery, run by TLA, offers access to research infrastructure, equipment, and a network of scientists, entrepreneurs, and investors. The program is part of Enterprise Singapore's Startup SG Accelerator initiative and has already seen successful startups like Allegro Aqua and Pathnova commercialize their technologies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.24 points to 1,607.09. The market saw 69.03 million lots traded worth RM18.72 million. Gainers outpaced losers 127 to 41.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at Friday's open, extending a seven-day winning streak, driven by fresh hopes for China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.17% to 27,894.56, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.51% to 2,993.98. The rally followed a record close on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh highs despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down as traders ease into weekend
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday as investors took a break after a strong week, with the China-US trade talks remaining uncertain. A plan to roll back tariffs was announced, but the White House failed to comment, causing uncertainty. The Dow and S&P 500 reached records, but profit-taking and a lack of progress in trade talks led to losses in Hong Kong, Sydney, and Singapore. Shanghai and Tokyo were exceptions, with slight gains.

site_title: Julius Baer names new South-east Asia private banking head
summary: Julius Baer has appointed Jason Moo, former Goldman Sachs Singapore CEO, as its new head of private banking for South-east Asia. Moo will start work on February 17, 2020, and oversee the bank's operations in Singapore. He replaces Torsten Linke, who will lead a new sub-region called "global India and developed markets" effective January 1, 2020. Moo's experience in wealth management and product knowledge will help drive the bank's expansion in the region, according to Jimmy Lee, the bank's Asia-Pacific head.

images.alt_text: Jason Moo will start work on Feb 17, 2020, subject to regulatory approval, and be responsible for the bank's operations and development in Singapore.

site_title: NTUC to raise retirement and re-employment ages in 2021, ahead of national schedule
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore will raise its retirement and re-employment ages to 63 and 68, respectively, ahead of the national schedule. This change, effective January 1, 2021, will benefit about 430 workers who would have retired at 62 and 280 workers who can re-employ until 68. The move aims to support older workers and align with the national plan to increase the retirement age to 65 and 70 by 2030.

site_title: Maritime Singapore green scheme extended till 2024 with eye on decarbonisation
summary: Singapore's Maritime Singapore Green Initiative will be extended until 2024 to focus on decarbonization, with new incentives for low-carbon fuels and digital platforms. The initiative aims to encourage the adoption of greener fuels and digital technologies, while enhancing digital connectivity and workforce skills. The extension will also include new measures to support mid-career professionals and promote maritime talent.

site_title: Digital life insurance calculator launched for consumers to gauge protection needs
summary: The Life Insurance Association (LIA) has launched a digital life insurance calculator to help consumers assess their financial protection needs. The calculator, which has been used 500 times since its soft launch, asks 7 simple questions and provides a report on insurance coverage gaps, protection needs, and financial resources. The initiative aims to bridge Singapore's 20% mortality and 80% critical illness protection gaps, which total S$893 billion. The calculator aims to encourage consumers to be proactive in ensuring they and their loved ones are well-protected.

site_title: China calls Hong Kong protesters 'mobsters' after stabbing
summary: China has condemned radical Hong Kong protesters as "mobsters" after a pro-Beijing lawmaker was stabbed during five months of violent protests demanding democratic freedoms and police accountability. Beijing and Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam have refused to offer a political solution, leading to escalating violence. The international finance hub is shaken, with protests and counter-protests ongoing. China's criticism of the protesters is seen as an attempt to suppress dissent and maintain control over the territory.

site_title: China, US agree tariff rollback if phase one trade deal is completed
summary: China and the US have agreed to roll back tariffs on each other's goods in a "phase one" trade deal if it is completed. The Chinese commerce ministry confirmed the agreement, which would cancel tariffs in phases, while a US official said the rollback would be part of the first phase of a trade agreement. The deal is still being negotiated, and experts warn it could still fall apart. The US has agreed to scrap tariffs scheduled for December 15 on about $156 billion worth of Chinese imports, including cell phones and toys.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on trade optimism
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, extending Wall Street rallies on hopes of a China-US trade deal. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.86% or 201.14 points to 23,531.46, while the Topix index gained 0.59% or 10.08 points to 1,708.21. Investors are optimistic about a potential December trade accord between the two economic superpowers.

site_title: Africa must quadruple power investment to supply electricity for all, IEA says
summary: Africa needs to quadruple its power investment to provide electricity for all its 2 billion people by 2040, requiring $120 billion annually. The International Energy Agency (IEA) recommends harnessing renewable energy sources like solar, wind, and hydropower, and optimizing natural resources to meet the growing demand. The agency predicts that 530 million Africans will still lack electricity in 2030 if current investment rates continue. With the right policies, Africa can pursue a less carbon-intensive development path and grow its economy four-fold by 2040.

site_title: KKR's new Asia-focused fund targets record US$15b in 2020: sources
summary: Global private equity firm KKR & Co is targeting a record US$15 billion for a new Asia-focused buyout fund, set to start fundraising in the first quarter of 2020. The fund, which aims to invest in consumer, technology, and manufacturing firms across Australia, China, Japan, and India, would be the largest US dollar-denominated private equity fund raised in the region. This would surpass KKR's previous record of US$9.3 billion in 2017, and would also be the biggest US dollar-denominated private equity capital raising in Asia.

site_title: North Korean defector says Kim 'doesn't deserve' Trump's compliments
summary: A North Korean defector, Grace Jo, has expressed disagreement with US President Donald Trump's praise for Kim Jong Un, saying Kim "doesn't deserve" it. Jo, who escaped the North after losing family to repression, met with Trump at the White House and believes Trump's compliments are likely a "politics" move to be "very nice" and "polite." Jo's experience includes losing family to starvation and being sent back to North Korea multiple times before escaping to the US in 2008.

images.alt_text: Kim "doesn't deserve all those compliments," Grace Jo told reporters.

site_title: Stocks to watch: EHT, SPH Reit, LMIRT, Genting, MoneyMax, MindChamps
summary:
Key stocks to watch: 

EHT awaits clarity on Queen Mary hotel repair, SPH Reit expands in Australia, LMIRT's DPU rises, Genting's profit plummets, MoneyMax's profit triples, MindChamps' earnings plummet, and Koh Brothers' sales decline. Other stocks saw gains due to private takeovers, CEO deaths, and board retirements.

site_title: Vividthree named exclusive tech provider for Malaysia tourism mixed project
summary: Vividthree Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, has signed a memorandum of understanding with the Malaysian Institute of Economic Research and Science Discoveries Sdn Bhd to be the exclusive provider of immersive technology and gamification for the HeurêkaLand Project in Malaysia. The 45-acre project, valued at RM1.3 billion, will feature six museums, indoor and outdoor theme parks, and an aquarium. Vividthree will provide technological expertise and content development for the project, with an estimated budget of RM130 million for immersive experience and entertainment content.

site_title: HRnetGroup Q3 profit down 4.9% to S$12m after revaluation of securities
summary: HRnetGroup reported a 4.9% decline in Q3 net profit to S$12 million, despite a 3.1% increase in net profit excluding security revaluation. Revenue rose 1.6% to S$106.7 million, driven by stronger North Asia contributions. Singapore revenue dropped 3.7% due to a lacklustre economy, while North Asia's gross profit grew 5% and accounted for a record 47.4% of total gross profits. The company attributed low growth in Singapore to business sentiments and plans to offset pressure through expansion of its flexible staffing brand.

site_title: Former NYC mayor Bloomberg preparing presidential run: US media
summary: Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg is preparing to enter the 2020 presidential election as a Democrat. Despite initially saying he wouldn't run, Bloomberg has been gathering signatures in Alabama and is expected to file paperwork soon. He views Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders as too left-wing and sees Joe Biden as weak, according to a source. Bloomberg's entry would add to the crowded field of Democratic candidates vying for the nomination to face President Donald Trump.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Friday's open; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.4% at the open on Friday, amid a global risk-on mood, despite news that the US and China were prepared to exchange tariff rollbacks. The Straits Times Index fell to 3,273.31 points, with gains edging out losses slightly. Key stocks such as Rex International and Genting Singapore moved in opposite directions, while banking stocks like DBS and OCBC Bank traded mixed. The market is set to be influenced by a slew of corporate earnings in the week ahead.

site_title: Digital securities services provider Propine enters MAS fintech sandbox
summary: PROPINE, a Singapore-based digital securities services provider, has entered the Monetary Authority of Singapore's FinTech Regulatory Sandbox and received a conditional licence. Propine offers services for institutions, including custody, asset servicing, and regulatory reporting. This admission follows its US$1.17 million seed funding round in November 2019, with investors including Decacorn Capital and SGInnovate. The startup's admission aims to support the development of digital securities services in Singapore.

site_title: New York judge orders Trump to pay US$2m in damages to charities
summary: A New York judge ordered Donald Trump to pay $2 million in damages to charities for using his former charity to further his political and business interests. The order comes after a civil lawsuit filed by New York Attorney General Letitia James, who accused the Trump Foundation of "persistently illegal conduct." The lawsuit alleged improper coordination between the charity and Trump's campaign team during his 2016 White House bid. This is another legal setback for President Trump.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as gold miners slump, New Zealand rises
summary: Australian shares remained flat in early trading on Friday, despite a 1.7% gain in the energy sector, driven by an overnight rally in oil prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.8 points to 6,725.1, as declines in resources stocks outweighed gains in energy stocks. This was despite a 1% gain on Thursday, putting the benchmark on track for a 0.8% weekly gain.

site_title: Elizabeth Warren challenges Bill Gates on 'wealth tax'
summary: Democratic presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren challenged Bill Gates on his skepticism about her proposed "wealth tax" on the richest Americans, offering to meet him after he expressed concerns about the impact on innovation. Gates said he would pay $6.37 billion under Warren's tax, less than the $6.697 billion that Amazon co-founder Jeff Bezos would owe. Gates expressed support for progressive taxation but declined to donate to Warren's campaign, instead saying he'd vote for the "more professional" candidate, likely Warren, if she faces off against Donald Trump.

site_title: Singapore wants to become an Asian hub for digital banks: MAS
summary: Singapore aims to become an Asian hub for digital banks, according to Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) Managing Director Ravi Menon. This move would improve banking services in Singapore and other parts of South-east Asia. By anchoring technology firms at the early stage of their development, Singapore seeks to provide access to the domestic banking market. This strategy would benefit both the local and regional banking markets.

site_title: Facebook unveils steps to combat 2020 US elections disinformation
summary: Facebook has unveiled steps to combat online disinformation and foreign interference in the 2020 US elections, including securing elected officials' accounts, clearly labeling fact-checked content, and indicating page ownership. The measures, announced by CEO Mark Zuckerberg, follow a similar effort after the 2016 US election. Facebook Vice President of Integrity Guy Rosen stated that the company has a responsibility to stop abuse and election interference on its platform.

site_title: Italy raises doubts over banking 'breakthrough' by Germany
summary: Italy has expressed skepticism over Germany's proposal to deepen financial ties in the eurozone, citing concerns that Berlin is trying to impose unwanted reforms on fragile Italian banks. German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz has backed a common European deposit insurance, but with conditions that Italy's Finance Minister Roberto Gualtieri considers too tough, including writing off bad debt and harmonizing bankruptcy rules. The proposal has sparked a sensitive discussion, with Eurogroup chief Mario Centeno warning that it will take time to reach an agreement.

site_title: MoneyMax Q3 profit more than triples to S$3m
summary: MoneyMax Financial Services reported a Q3 profit of S$3m, more than tripling from S$990,000 a year ago, driven by a 48.8% surge in revenue to S$52.9m. Material costs and employee benefits expenses also increased, offsetting the profit growth. The company expects to remain profitable for fiscal 2019 but faces challenges from global uncertainties, including volatile gold prices and lower consumer demand.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end at records on US-China trade deal optimism
summary: US stocks reached new records on Thursday as optimism over a potential US-China trade deal lifted investor sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gained 0.7% and 0.3%, respectively, following Chinese comments on removing tariffs in stages. However, gains were tempered by a Reuters report on White House opposition to rolling back tariffs, and the US-China trade agreement remains uncertain. Despite this, a jump in US Treasury yields and positive earnings reports from companies like Ralph Lauren lifted investor confidence in global growth.

site_title: Japan September household spending surged 9.5% before tax hike
summary: Japan's household spending surged 9.5% in September, driven by consumers rushing to complete purchases before a 10% sales tax hike in October. The increase, after a 1.0% rise in the previous month, is closely watched to gauge if Japan is emerging from decades-old deflation. Consumers spent on durable goods, automobile-related items, and commuter train passes, contributing to the surge. Despite historical concerns that tax hikes can lead to recessions, fears have receded, and the government insists the increase is necessary to fund key policy priorities.

site_title: Euronext CEO Boujnah says no tie-up talks with any European bourse
summary: Euronext CEO Stephane Boujnah has denied rumors of merger talks with Spanish exchange BME or any other European bourse. In a media conference call, Boujnah stated there is no dialogue with any exchange in Europe and no offer has been made. He clarified that Euronext's third-quarter results were unaffected by these baseless rumors.

site_title: Saudi king hosts CIA chief after Twitter charges
summary: Saudi Arabia's King Salman hosted CIA Director Gina Haspel after three people were charged in the US with spying on Twitter users critical of the royal family. The charges, filed on Wednesday, involve two Saudis and a former Twitter employee allegedly working to unmask ownership details behind dissident accounts. The meeting with Haspel comes amid strained ties between Saudi Arabia and the US, which have been affected by the brutal murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The Saudi official stated that the kingdom expects its citizens to abide by foreign laws, but did not comment on the charges.

site_title: Music by the numbers: scientists reveal a secret to great song writing
summary: Scientists analyzed 745 classic US Billboard pop songs and found that the combination of uncertainty and surprise in chord progressions leads to greater musical pleasure. The study, led by Vincent Cheung, used machine learning to quantify uncertainty and surprise, and found that when test subjects were uncertain, they preferred music that was not surprising. The brain's amygdala, hippocampus, and auditory cortex were activated, reflecting emotional processing, learning, and sound processing. The findings could help songwriters craft more enjoyable songs, but caution that there is no magic formula and other factors also contribute to musical pleasure.

site_title: Beyond Meat eyes production in Asia before the end of 2020
summary: Beyond Meat plans to start production in Asia before the end of 2020, with a focus on China, a major untapped market for its plant-based products. The company aims to expand sales in Taiwan, Singapore, and Hong Kong, where it already sells its products. As consumers increasingly prioritize health and sustainability, the global plant-based market is expected to reach $140 billion by 2030, according to Barclays. This move comes as the global market for plant-based products is expected to explode in the coming decade.

site_title: US official criticises countries 'opening their arms' to Chinese 5G
summary: US Chief Technology Officer Michael Kratsios criticized countries that adopt Chinese 5G networks and artificial intelligence technologies, citing concerns over laws compelling Chinese firms to cooperate with their country's intelligence services. Kratsios urged Europe to take a stand with the US, despite European companies continuing to use Huawei products for 5G networks. Huawei condemned Kratsios' comments as "hypocritical and manifestly false," while the African Union rejected claims of a cyber security breach involving the company. Kratsios' comments come amid ongoing tensions between the US and China over technology policy.

site_title: Cyprus signs US$9b gas deal with energy majors
summary: Cyprus has signed a US$9.3 billion deal with Shell, Noble Energy, and Delek to exploit the Aphrodite gas field, estimated to contain over 113 billion cubic meters of gas. The 25-year license, set to begin extracting gas by 2025, will generate an average yearly income of US$520 million for Cyprus over an 18-year period. This comes after revisions to a production sharing agreement were made due to a significant fall in hydrocarbon prices since 2014, and follows the discovery of a larger natural gas reserve off Cyprus' coast in February.

images.alt_text: Cyprus announced on Thursday it had signed its first natural gas exploitation deal worth US$9.3 billion with a consortium comprised of industry giant Shell, US-based Noble and Israel's Delek.

site_title: Big oil stuns Brazil in back-to-back auction flops
summary: Major global oil firms, including Exxon and Chevron, snubbed Brazil's second consecutive oil auction, passing on offshore blocks. Only Petrobras and a Chinese state firm received bids, with four blocks receiving no interest. This marks a significant setback for Brazil's oil industry, which was expected to emerge as a top player in Latin America. The lack of foreign interest may prompt officials to reconsider the bidding system, which gives a privileged position to state-run Petrobras.

site_title: Shake It Up
summary: Shake Shack is introducing its Christmas Cookie Shake in Singapore, a holiday tradition in the US, for S$7.80. The limited-edition drink features sugar cookie frozen custard, whipped cream, and red and green sprinkles. The company is also releasing a customisable leatherette cover notebook (S$35) in collaboration with Bynd Artisan, starting from Nov 15.

site_title: Europe: Trade optimism, upbeat earnings send shares to 4-year peak
summary: European shares rose for a fifth consecutive session to reach a four-year high, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks and positive earnings reports. Siemens, UniCredit, and Lufthansa shares jumped as the German industrial company, Italy's biggest bank, and German airline announced cost-cutting plans to revive profits. China's commerce ministry announced a deal to roll back trade tariffs, sparking a broad-based rally across Europe. The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.4% higher, nearing its record high.

site_title: More HDB resale flats sold in Oct after policy changes kick in
summary: In October, more HDB resale flats were sold, with 2,213 units changing hands, a 18% increase from September. Higher grants for first-time buyers took effect in September, with the Enhanced CPF Housing Grant offering up to S$80,000. Resale flat prices dipped 0.2% over September's figures, but remained 0.1% higher than a year ago. Analysts attribute the surge in resale sales to the new policy changes, expecting high resale volume in the next month and stable prices in the coming months due to increasing supply.

site_title: China, US agree to roll back tariffs in phases to reach deal
summary: China and the US have agreed to roll back tariffs on each other's goods in phases as they work towards a deal. The agreement was announced by a Chinese Ministry of Commerce spokesman, who stated that top negotiators had serious discussions and agreed to remove additional tariffs in phases as progress is made. If confirmed, the understanding could provide a roadmap to a deal, potentially de-escalating the trade war. The two sides continue to negotiate on the location and timing of a phase one deal, with possible locations in Asia and Europe being considered.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Challenges business leaders are facing in achieving growth
summary: Business leaders face significant challenges in achieving growth and greater impact due to a lack of leadership capability, which can cost corporations billions annually. John Kim, a serial entrepreneur and venture firm Managing Partner, highlighted this issue in a recent podcast. He emphasized that leadership capability is crucial for driving business success and that it can be a major obstacle for companies to overcome.

site_title: Disney tops earnings estimates ahead of streaming launch
summary: Disney reported quarterly earnings of $1.05 billion, beating estimates, driven by blockbuster film releases like Aladdin and The Lion King. Revenue grew 34% to $19.1 billion, with studio operations contributing a 52% rise. The company prepares for the launch of its streaming service, Disney+, on November 12, aiming to compete globally against Netflix. Disney absorbed 21st Century Fox operations and secured distribution agreements, including on Amazon's Fire TV platform. The company's cable and theme park divisions saw smaller revenue gains.

site_title: Oil rises above US$62 a barrel on hopes for US-China trade deal
summary: Oil prices rose above $62 a barrel on Thursday after China hinted at progress in a US-China trade deal, lifting hopes for an end to the long-standing dispute. China and the US agreed to cancel tariffs in phases, prompting analysts to revise forecasts for oil demand. Brent crude rose 55 cents to $62.29 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude climbed 80 cents to $57.15. However, doubts about a trade deal could resurface, and rising inventories limit potential price gains.

site_title: GE to invest up to US$60m in gas turbine repair in Singapore
summary: GE to invest up to US$60 million in a gas turbine repair facility in Singapore, aiming to cut repair cycle time for Asian customers by up to two months. The new repair centre, set to open in 2021, will create 160 advanced manufacturing jobs and increase man-hours by 50%. The facility will reduce the need for shipping components from the US, boosting productivity and supporting Singapore's industrial output.

site_title: Singapore and Shanghai now threaten Hong Kong's status as financial hub
summary: Hong Kong's status as Asia's top international financial centre is under threat due to its declining stock trades and struggling wealth management industry. The city's high rents and low taxes are also deterring financial players. Pro-democracy protests are disrupting daily life, battering the local economy into a recession and angering decision makers in Beijing. Singapore is gaining ground, with its wealth management industry growing and its taxes being more competitive. As a result, Hong Kong's financial hub status is at risk, with Shanghai emerging as a potential rival.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong has long defied predictions it'll lose its stature as Asia's top international financial centre - but for how much longer?

site_title: Two ground-floor shop units at Alexis in Alexandra up for sale by tender
summary: Two ground-floor units at Singapore's mixed-use development Alexis in Alexandra Road are up for sale with an indicative price of S$10 million (approximately S$3,259 per square foot). The units, totaling 3,068 square feet, have F&B potential and are located near Queenstown MRT station. The sale is open to locals, foreigners, and companies, with no stamp duties imposed. The units are part of a six-storey development with 21 commercial units, 293 apartments, and a public basement car park, and are expected to benefit from nearby condominium developments and public housing projects.

site_title: When should companies issue profit warnings?
summary: Companies in Singapore should issue profit warnings before publicly announcing their earnings results, particularly if they have material information that may impact the price or value of their securities. This can occur if they have provided guidance on their business and operations, but the results are likely to be materially different, or if there are significant external conditions that will result in a deterioration in near-term earnings prospects. The Singapore Exchange requires companies to disclose information concerning events that would likely have a material effect on their price or value.

site_title: Boeing CEO will forgo 'tens of millions of dollars' in compensation
summary: Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg has agreed to forgo "tens of millions of dollars" in compensation, including bonuses and equity grants, following criticism over his compensation package following the 737 MAX crashes. Muilenburg plans to donate the value of his equity grants to a fund supporting the families of the 346 victims. He expressed a desire to remain CEO for three years and has also expressed support for reforms of the Federal Aviation Administration's certification process. Muilenburg stated his actions are a "message of responsibility."

site_title: Just Jazz
summary: The Jazz Association Singapore Orchestra (JASSO) commemorates Singapore-UK friendship with a special show, "Pinnacle Concert 2019", on Nov 15 at Victoria Theatre. Led by Jeremy Monteiro, the concert features English vocalist Tina May and guest musicians Alan Barnes, Henry Lowther, and Tom Walsh, alongside local singers Louis Soliano and Alemay Fernandez. The event marks the Bicentennial of Singapore-UK friendship with a repertoire of jazz standards and newly-commissioned compositions. Tickets range from S$35 to S$75.

site_title: Commerzbank cuts full-year profit outlook
summary: Commerzbank downgraded its full-year profit outlook, citing lower interest rates, higher taxes, and increased competition. The bank now expects consolidated net income to be lower than in 2018, reversing its previous target of a slight increase. CEO Martin Zielke has announced a new round of cost cuts and longer-term financial targets, including reducing the workforce by over 2,000. The bank's Polish subsidiary mBank is also being sold, and profitability is expected to remain below the competition for at least the next four years.

site_title: Wirecard expects to be cleared in Singapore police probe, says CEO
summary: Wirecard, a German payments company, has expanded a KPMG audit to address allegations of manipulating accounts, following a Singapore police investigation. CEO Markus Braun denies the allegations, stating they are "unfounded." The company reported a 43% gain in quarterly profit. Wirecard aims to "draw a line under" the allegations through the additional review.

site_title: Airbus extends lead over Boeing with 415 jet sales in October
summary: Airbus secured 415 new jet orders in October, surpassing Boeing's 170 orders, further widening the gap between the two manufacturers. Airbus' January-October total reached 718 aircraft, while Boeing's net total was 54 after cancellations. The European planemaker also secured a record order for 300 aircraft from India's IndiGo, bringing its total to 718 aircraft. Airbus' annual delivery target was cut by 2-3% to 860 aircraft, while Boeing's net total sank to a negative 84 airplanes after accounting adjustments.

site_title: Weinstein The Monster
summary: A new documentary, "Untouchable," features heartbreaking interviews with victims of alleged sex offender Harvey Weinstein, shedding light on his decades-long history of misconduct. The documentary, directed by Ursula Macfarlane, features testimony from women who claim Weinstein assaulted or harassed them, including model Ambra Gutierrez, who recorded his boastful remark about touching women without consent. The film ultimately focuses on the courageous women who spoke out against Weinstein, with actress Paz de la Huerta stating, "It's not over. It continues." The documentary is available on iwonder.com.

site_title: Scant bond returns will divert investors to equity: JP Morgan
summary: JP Morgan Asset Management reports that investors may shift to stocks due to low bond returns, but high stock prices may limit future gains. The firm's 2020 Long-Term Capital Market Assumptions report suggests equity over bonds, despite the sharp reversal in global monetary policy.

site_title: Cool Moves
summary: Singapore dance company Frontier Danceland presents Milieu, its annual year-end production, featuring works by Italian choreographer Marioenrico D'Angelo and German choreographer Sita Ostheimer. D'Angelo's "Skinny Dipping" explores the fear of letting go, while Ostheimer's "Nowhere But 2.5 Meters" examines the power and limitations of rhythm in communication. Milieu runs at the SOTA Studio Theatre on Nov 15 and 16, with tickets starting at S$30.

site_title: 30 years after fall of Berlin Wall, Germany is still unequal
summary: Thirty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, Germany remains unequal, with women still fighting for top positions in politics, economics, and science. Despite reunification, women make up only 34% of parliament, 16% of cabinet ministers, and 21% of CEOs in the top 100 companies. Women's representation in leadership positions is still a pressing issue, with significant disparities in various sectors. The country's progress towards gender equality has been slow, and there is still much work to be done to address the persistent imbalance.

site_title: SPH Reit takes A$670m stake in South Australia mall
summary: SPH Reit has acquired a 50% stake in Westfield Marion Shopping Centre in South Australia for A$670 million (S$627.9 million). The deal, funded by a recent perp issue, debt, and/or equity fund-raising, increases the Reit's weighted average lease expiry to 5.1 years and raises its portfolio's exposure to Australian assets to 19.7%. The acquisition strengthens SPH Reit's presence in the Australian market and enhances its sustainability and resilience through increased geographic diversity and longer underlying leases.

site_title: Peer review of reports on EHT's Queen Mary in the works
summary: The City of Long Beach has hired a local engineering firm to review reports on the condition of the Queen Mary floating hotel, leased to Eagle Hospitality Trust. The review aims to provide clarity on critical issues flagged in previous inspection reports, expected to be completed this month. This move follows previous inspection reports filed by consultant Edward Pribonic, which raised concerns about the hotel's maintenance and condition. The review is aimed at providing a second opinion and addressing the concerns raised by previous reports.

site_title: RX is now a prescription for fun
summary: Lexus has unveiled the revamped RX 300, a mid-life facelift of its popular SUV, with a focus on enhancing its driving experience. The new model features a stiffer shell, laser screw welding, and improved infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. The RX 300 is available in three versions, with the base model priced at S$253,800 in Singapore, and boasts sharper handling and a more refined ride compared to its competitors. The revised model aims to leave drivers satisfied, with a human touch added by skilled craftsmen known as takumi.

site_title: Facial recognition system for India triggers fears of mass surveillance
summary: India is set to install a nationwide facial recognition system, sparking fears of mass surveillance and privacy concerns. The system, which will be among the world's largest, aims to catch criminals and find missing children but lacks transparency on data storage and regulation. Human rights and technology experts warn of the risks of social policing and control, citing past biases in the technology. The system's deployment and use raise questions about individual privacy and the potential for institutionalized systemic discrimination.

site_title: Singapore must stay open and inclusive to thrive in digital age: Iswaran
summary: Singapore must remain open and inclusive to thrive in the digital age, said Communications and Information Minister S Iswaran. The digital economy in South-east Asia is expected to treble to US$300 billion by 2025. To seize opportunities and grow the pie, Singapore must stay open and be inclusive, ensuring equitable distribution of benefits. This approach will help mitigate the negative impacts of globalization and technological change on workers and businesses.

images.alt_text: Trade pacts conceived in a pre-digital era are not designed for the new economic realities and trade patterns, says Mr Iswaran. Hence the need to update agreements or strike new arrangements.

site_title: Grand Shanghai gets a facelift
summary: Grand Shanghai, a Singaporean restaurant, has undergone a facelift, but still needs to refine its menu and address weak spots. The restaurant, located at King's Centre, offers lunch and dinner services from Tuesday to Sunday. Despite its age, Grand Shanghai remains a contender in the competitive food scene, catering to the "foodies" crowd.

images.alt_text: Claypot chicken soup with pork wontons.
Grand Shanghai's shiny new digs and old-school chandelier-decorated glitz.
Above, left: Steamed Shanghainese pork dumplings. Above, right: Sautéed egg white with crabmeat and a drizzle of truffle oil.

site_title: Toyota announces US$1.8b share buyback after strong Q2
summary: Toyota Motor Corp announced a US$1.8 billion share buyback after beating quarterly forecasts with 2.75 million vehicle sales globally, a 5.6% increase in North America, and a 14% operating profit rise to 662.3 billion yen. Operating profit in North America more than doubled, thanks to reduced discounting. Toyota maintains its forecast for operating profit in the year to March, but lowers its global car sales forecast by 2.7% to 10.7 million units.

site_title: World food prices up for first time in 5 months: FAO
summary: World food prices rose for the first time in 5 months in October, driven by increases in sugar and cereal prices. The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) reported a 1.7% monthly increase and a 6% year-over-year increase in its food price index. Sugar prices jumped 5.8% due to expected supply reductions in India and Thailand, while cereal prices rose 4.2% due to reduced crop prospects and robust trade activity. FAO lowered its forecast for global cereal production in 2019 to 2.704 billion tonnes.

site_title: Crazy Asian Comic
summary: Ronny Chieng's new stand-up special "Asian Comedian Destroys America" premieres on Netflix on Dec 17, featuring his first headlining performance in four years. The Malaysian-born comedian, known for his roles in "Crazy Rich Asians" and "The Daily Show with Trevor Noah," will also perform his "Tone Issues" tour in Singapore, including a show at Esplanade Theatre on Nov 29. Tickets are available from S$68 to S$98.

site_title: Developers confident of beating 2020 ABSD deadline
summary: Developers in Singapore are confident of selling their unsold units before the 2020 and 2021 buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) deadlines, despite having 95 unsold units across seven projects. Many projects have already sold over 90% of their inventory, and some have even cleared their final units. Developers attribute the swift take-up to robust demand and low supply in 2017. However, projects with deadlines beyond 2021 may face uncertainty, and some developers may need to use creative sales pitches to clear their remaining stock.

site_title: Dyna-Mac surges 12.9% after death of CEO, biggest shareholder
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings' shares surged 12.9% after the death of its CEO and largest shareholder, Desmond Lim Tze Jong. The company's shares reached an 18-month high of 13.1 cents, with 42.7 million shares changing hands. Dyna-Mac's management stated that its businesses will continue as usual, and it will update shareholders on a new chairman and CEO. The company's largest shareholders include Keppel Corp and Temasek Holdings, which hold a combined 49.79% stake in the firm.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: EC World Reit cut distribution per unit to 1.489 Singapore cents in Q3, down 4.4% year-on-year, despite a 3.2% rise in net property income and 7.5% growth in gross revenue. Vibrant Group plans to buy out LTH Logistics for S$13.5 million, while Koh Brothers saw Q3 net profit fall 38.6% year-on-year to S$1.01 million. MindChamps PreSchool reported a 73.1% decline in Q3 net profit to S$300,000 despite a 70% revenue increase.

site_title: Adopting plastic alternatives starts with customers
summary: The Japanese government has implemented a policy requiring retailers to charge for plastic bags starting next summer in an effort to reduce plastic consumption. This move aims to address the country's high plastic packaging waste production per capita, with Asia being a significant contributor to global ocean plastic pollution. Consumers are crucial in driving change, and supporting brands adopting sustainable alternatives can pressure others to follow suit. Education and awareness about the environmental impact of plastics are also key to addressing the plastic crisis, and "greenwashing" claims must be called out to promote informed decision-making.

site_title: Financial sector must step up its role in sustainable financing
summary: The financial sector must significantly increase its role in sustainable financing to cut global carbon emissions and limit global warming. The UN IPCC has called for a decline in global carbon dioxide emissions by 2030 to avoid severe consequences. Current energy, transport, buildings, and water infrastructure contribute to 60% of greenhouse gas emissions, requiring $95 trillion in investments between 2016 and 2030. The private sector, including banks and capital markets, must step up to fund this investment gap, complemented by climate policies and regulations.

site_title: Lufthansa to cut more costs, as cabin crew start strike
summary: Lufthansa announced plans to cut costs at its Austrian Airlines, Brussels Airlines, and Lufthansa Cargo businesses in an effort to revive profits. The airline reported better-than-expected quarterly figures, with shares rising 6.7% despite facing a two-day cabin crew strike that will cancel 1,300 flights and affect 180,000 passengers. The strike, called by the trade union UFO, is over pay and pensions, and Lufthansa's CEO has offered to enter into arbitration talks with the union. The airline aims to achieve a margin of 7% in the longer term through cost-cutting measures, including staff reductions and fleet standardization.

site_title: Culture Critique
summary: Roxane Gay, a renowned cultural critic, will deliver a lecture titled "Understanding Identity Through Pop Culture" at the Singapore Writers Festival on Nov 10. Gay's book "Bad Feminist" is a global bestseller, and her insightful analysis of how pop culture shapes our identity has inspired many readers. The lecture promises to be an intellectual and entertaining experience, with Gay taking questions from the audience and providing sassy responses. Tickets are available for S$25.

site_title: Sunburst 2019 presents theatre of inclusiveness
summary: The School of the Arts (SOTA) in Singapore hosted "Sunburst 2019", a theatre production that addressed inclusiveness, raising $275,000 for people with muscular dystrophy and financially disadvantaged arts students. The show, titled "The Ramp", featured a ramp symbolizing inclusivity and highlighted challenges faced by young people staging an all-inclusive concert. The production included music performances, dance, and spoken word, with guest performances by beneficiaries of the Muscular Dystrophy Association Singapore. The event was well-received, with a strong response from the audience and corporate sponsors.

site_title: Citic Envirotech shares surge on news of privatisation bid
summary: Citic Envirotech shares surged 44.6% on Thursday after its majority owner planned to take the company private. The counter peaked at $0.54 before closing at $0.535. The move follows a resumption of trading after the news broke. The company's shares had previously closed at $0.46.

site_title: HK leaders accused of spending 'peanuts' to save deteriorating economy
summary: Hong Kong's leaders have announced a cheap fiscal stimulus of HK$21 billion (S$3.3 billion) to address the city's deteriorating economy, but economists say it amounts to less than 1% of the city's economy and won't meaningfully help now or in the long run. The stimulus is seen as inadequate, with the city's annual output standing at about US$363 billion and fiscal reserves of US$150 billion. Economists criticize the government for failing to address structural problems like income inequality and limited social support.

site_title: Q3 DPU for Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust up
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) raised its third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.56 Singapore cents, a 14.3% increase from the previous quarter. The trust's distributable income rose 29.5% to S$18 million, driven by a 11.8% increase in net property income to S$44.1 million. The change in DPU reflects the direct collection of service and utilities recovery charges from tenants. Despite a negative impact from expiring master leases, the manager is actively managing tenancy mix and taking mitigation measures for the car park business.

site_title: Sam Shank, Head of Hotels, Airbnb
summary: Sam Shank, Airbnb's Head of Hotels, advises budding internet entrepreneurs not to start-ups, citing his own experience with HotelTonight, a last-minute hotel booking app acquired by Airbnb for over $400 million. Shank, 46, co-founded HotelTonight in 2010 and reduced its burn rate from $2.5 million per month to zero by mid-2016. He partnered with Airbnb to provide good hotels for guests seeking a wider variety of options, and the app has been downloaded by over 15 million users. Shank attributes his success to the optimistic and flexible environment of San Francisco, where he was able to execute his idea despite initial challenges.

site_title: OCBC, Japan's SMFG vie to buy Bank Permata
summary: OCBC and Japan's SMFG are vying to buy Indonesia's Bank Permata, with SMFG's banking unit and OCBC carrying out due diligence. The bank's owners are seeking a valuation of over 1.6 times its current book value. Japanese banks are expanding overseas to tap Indonesia's emerging middle class. Standard Chartered and Astra International own a 45% stake in Permata, valued at US$2.7 billion, which has nearly doubled this year. A final round of bidding is expected in the next couple of weeks.

site_title: Liquidnet sees record year trading in Singapore
summary: Liquidnet, the largest "dark pool" operator in the Asia-Pacific region, has achieved a record year trading in Singapore, generating over US$1.5 billion in total value of equities bought and sold as of November 7, 2019. This surpasses the US$1.38 billion recorded in 2018, highlighting the platform's growth and importance in the region's financial markets.

site_title: Ex-Twitter employees charged with spying on users for Saudis
summary: Two former Twitter employees and a Saudi national have been charged with spying on dissidents who used Twitter. The employees allegedly used their company credentials to gain access to the accounts of "users of interest" to the Saudi royal family. The charges stem from a criminal complaint unsealed in the US. The Saudi national was recruited while the San Francisco-based Twitter employee was from Twitter's hometown.

site_title: Dollar gains vs yen as investors dump safe-havens
summary: The dollar rose against the yen on Thursday after Chinese commerce ministry comments suggested that a possible trade deal between the US and China could involve simultaneous tariff cancellations. Investors interpreted the comments as positive news, reducing demand for safe-haven currencies. The dollar jumped to near three-month highs versus the yen, while the euro also gained 0.1% against the dollar. China's offshore yuan strengthened to a three-month high, and the Australian and New Zealand dollars also gained.

site_title: Wearnes Automotive unveils S$1,200 monthly parking for special cars
summary: Wearnes Automotive has launched a climate-controlled storage facility for high-end cars, offering a tax-free storage option for a monthly fee of S$1,200. The facility, which can accommodate 80 cars, provides a safe and secure environment for collectors to store their prized vehicles, including rare and limited-edition supercars. The service aims to position Wearnes as the go-to place for car collectors, with the goal of preserving the cars as art pieces rather than focusing solely on cost savings.

site_title: Genting Q3 profit dips; ploughs on with RWS 2.0
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 24.5% year-on-year decline in third-quarter profits to S$158.9 million, attributed to higher sales costs and a 6.7% revenue decline in gaming takings. Despite a 1% increase in non-gaming revenue, the company cited "headwinds." Genting Singapore is investing in a five-year expansion at Resorts World Sentosa and plans to diversify into Japan, with construction set to begin in the second half of next year.

site_title: China to ban vaping in public places to quash habit among teens
summary: China plans to ban e-cigarettes in public places to combat the growing vaping habit among teenagers, following a week of banning online sales. The ban is part of an action plan to combat smoking and vaping, urging legislation, law revisions, and enforcement to restrict e-cigarettes. The move aligns with countries like India, Brazil, and Singapore, and comes after a mysterious lung disease linked to vaping has affected 1,888 people and killed 37. The ban aims to create a smoke-free environment in schools and seriously investigate the illegal sale of smoking products.

site_title: Indonesia defends economic statistics against doubters
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati defended the country's economic growth statistics against doubters, stating that the data is accurate and independent. The country's economy expanded 5.02% in the third quarter, steady around 5% for several years. Indrawati attributed the growth to household consumption and positive net exports, and expressed openness and transparency about the data. She also mentioned concerns over investment and government spending slowdowns, but expected growth to rebound in the fourth quarter.

site_title: All that glitters is not Golden Rice
summary: Farmers and consumer groups are protesting the introduction of genetically modified Golden Rice in Bangladesh and other countries due to concerns over its impact on consumer health and farmers' livelihoods. Despite being hailed as a solution to malnutrition, studies have shown that the beta-carotene content in Golden Rice is negligible and degrades quickly, rendering it ineffective. The SGRN believes that Golden Rice poses a threat to farmers' traditional seeds and sovereignty, and that it will create more problems for the poor rather than addressing the issue of Vitamin-A deficiency.

site_title: Recycled Luxury
summary: Swiss sustainable fashion label SOTTES makes its Singapore debut with a shop-in-shop concept in Surrender's flagship store, showcasing whimsical designs made from recycled materials in a zero-waste environment. The brand features a capsule project using scrap leather, manufacturing waste, and recast silver to create accessories and clothing, priced from S$890 to S$5800. This move demonstrates that upcycled fashion can be both eco-friendly and luxurious, challenging traditional notions of high-end fashion.

site_title: The life and times of BMW M
summary: BMW M, a high-performance sub-brand, has expanded its portfolio with the introduction of the X3 M Competition SUV, offering 510 horsepower. The brand's sales have grown 229% over the past six years, with a target of 140,000 units for 2019. BMW M is focusing on electrification, with plug-in hybrid cars in development, set to hit the market around 2025. The brand prioritizes customer demand, listening to fans who want more M in everything, and aims to release 10 new M models over the next two years.

site_title: GIC buys 50% stake in 42-storey Beijing office building
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has acquired a 50% stake in a 42-storey Beijing office building for an undisclosed sum, becoming the sole owner post-acquisition. The Grade A building is located in the Lize Financial Business District, with enhanced accessibility due to its connection to a public transport interchange station. This investment reflects GIC's confidence in China and commitment to acquiring quality assets with long-term earning potential.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz leads the luxury pack
summary: Mercedes-Benz reported a record third quarter, selling 590,514 cars globally, a 12.2% increase over 2018. The brand is on track to retain its position as the best-selling luxury automotive brand in 2019, ahead of BMW and Audi. Despite a global car market contraction, Mercedes-Benz's expansion of its compact model range contributed to its success, with double-digit growth rates abroad. In Singapore, Mercedes-Benz sold 5,948 cars in the first nine months of 2019, solidifying its position as the third best-selling brand in the country.

site_title: Protecting Singapore's Heritage
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched an exhibition to commemorate 30 years of conservation efforts in Singapore. The journey began in the 1960s with conservation being a key consideration, despite urban renewal being a priority. The Preservation of Monuments Board was established in 1971, and the first national monuments were granted in 1973. Since then, over 7,200 buildings and structures have been conserved, with URA continuing to roll out programmes to encourage owners to restore their buildings. The exhibition runs until December 14 at URA Centre Atrium.

site_title: Jaguar's most powerful car takes to the catwalk
summary: Jaguar unveiled its most powerful car, the F-Pace SVR, in Singapore, featuring a 550hp supercharged V8 engine, 0-100km/h in 4.3 seconds, and a top speed of 283km/h. The SUV boasts upgraded suspension, bigger brakes, 22-inch wheels, and an external aerodynamic package. Priced at S$388,999, it's the most expensive Jaguar model in Singapore, but competitively priced compared to German performance SUVs. The F-Pace SVR is part of Jaguar's Special Vehicle Operations and marks the brand's latest high-performance model.

site_title: The Question Of Home
summary: The M1 Fringe Festival in Singapore features immersive artworks that explore the theme of home and belonging. The festival, which runs from January 8-19, 2020, includes performances and installations that invite audiences to participate in the storytelling process. The works, inspired by Lee Tzu Pheng's 1967 poem "My Country And My People," tackle issues of identity, displacement, and social participation. The festival's artistic director Sean Tobin notes that the themes remain relevant today, with works such as "A Tiny Country" and "Café Sarajevo" encouraging audiences to question their immediate environments and engage with complex social issues.

site_title: Wellness Sabbaticals - The New Detox Retreat
summary: A growing trend in wellness retreats is the "Wellness Sabbatical," a longer-term program that combines work and wellness. This concept allows individuals to take time off from work while still being connected, promoting a healthier work-life balance. Key benefits include increased productivity, creativity, and lower risk of heart disease. Research suggests that sabbaticals can lead to lasting lifestyle changes, and many retreats are now offering structured programs that support guests during their transition. With the rise of digital nomadism, companies may consider sending top executives on wellness sabbaticals, potentially changing the way work is done and the mindset of high-net-worth individuals.

site_title: Allied Tech expects nine-month net loss in Q3 results
summary: Allied Technologies, a precision engineering firm, expects to post a net loss for the nine months to Sept 30 due to a decline in gross profit margin attributed to a challenging business environment and global economic uncertainties. The company's shares have been suspended since May amid concerns over financials and a missing S$33 million from an escrow account. Trading guidance is based on preliminary unaudited financial results, which will be disclosed on Nov 14.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Holiday Workout
summary: A 20-minute hotel workout routine, led by Dr. Bernice Liu, a senior physiotherapist, helps maintain exercise regime during holidays. The routine includes squats, lunges, bridging, long plank to downward dog, side plank and hip abduction, and burpees, targeting lower and upper body muscles. These exercises can be done barefoot and without equipment, and are safe to do on alternate days. The routine is designed to be completed in a hotel room and can be increased in intensity and repetitions as fitness levels improve.

site_title: New Outlook For Chinese Cuisine
summary: Young Asian chefs in Singapore's stalwart Chinese restaurants are redefining the country's cuisine by embracing modern techniques and international flavors. Executives like Aaron Tan and Edward Chong are incorporating Western elements, such as foie gras and rosemary, into traditional Chinese dishes. Their goal is to elevate the dining experience, attract a younger audience, and break away from the perception that Chinese food is limited to oyster sauce and sesame oil. Despite resistance from senior chefs, these innovators aim to prove that Chinese cuisine is a gourmet frontier, with techniques like sous vide and smoking adding depth to classic dishes.

site_title: Whisky Spotlight
summary: The annual Whisky Live Singapore, Southeast Asia's largest whisky and spirits showcase, will take place on Nov 9-10 at Andaz Singapore. Over 600 whisky and spirit expressions from 70 brands will be available for sampling, with masterclasses by renowned distilleries like Octomore and Teeling Whiskey. Local bars will also offer cocktails on the Cocktail Terrace. Ticket prices start from S$55 and can be purchased at whiskylive.sg.

site_title: US, China, Japan and Korea to dominate 5G
summary: The US, China, Japan, and Korea will dominate the global 5G market by 2025, accounting for over half of subscribers. Europe will lag in consumer adoption, but excel in business uses. Developing nations will primarily rely on 4G technology for connectivity, while the global IoT market is expected to reach $1 trillion in 2025, with 5% coming from connectivity services.

site_title: EHT listing should have been a no-no with SGX
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT), listed just five months ago, has destroyed nearly 40% of shareholder value. Two major red flags in its IPO prospectus include a lack of valuation numbers for six hotels and a high capitalisation rate of 4.9% for the remaining 12 hotels. The sponsor, Urban Commons, lacks transparency, with no information on its financials. The article concludes that SGX should avoid a "tick-the-box" mentality when approving IPOs to prevent low-quality Reits from damaging the sector's reputation.

site_title: Simon Keswick to retire from Jardines family business at 77
summary: Simon Keswick, 77, is retiring from Jardine Matheson Holdings after nearly six decades, stepping down on January 1, 2020. Keswick was chairman and managing director from 1983 to 1987 and played a key role in shaping the company's structure. His son, Benjamin, will take over as chairman and managing director. The company reported earnings in line with last year, but Hong Kong unrest affected consumer businesses. Jardine Matheson closed up 1.34% at $58.42.

site_title: MindChamps Q3 net profit plunges by 73.1% to S$300,000 on expansion-related costs
summary: MindChamps PreSchool, a mainboard-listed early childhood education player, reported a 73.1% year-on-year decline in third-quarter net profit to S$300,000 due to surge in expansion-related costs. Revenue increased 70% to S$15.6 million, but administrative expenses almost doubled to S$7.33 million. The company plans to re-invest profits, not recommending a dividend. This marks a 61.6% decline in nine-month net profit to S$1.04 million.

site_title: Global debt surges to record high of US$188t says IMF chief
summary: Global debt has surged to a record high of $188 trillion, exceeding double the world's economic output, according to IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva. This represents a 14% increase from the previous record in 2016. Private sector borrowing accounts for the majority, but high debt burdens leave governments, companies, and households vulnerable to economic downturns. Georgieva called for steps to ensure sustainable borrowing, including transparent lending practices and debt restructuring.

site_title: India sets up 250b-rupee fund to revive stuck housing projects
summary: India has established a 250 billion-rupee ($4.78 billion) fund to revive stalled housing projects, expected to cover about 6% of the 576,000 projects worth 4.6 trillion rupees behind schedule in seven major cities. The fund will also support written-off projects as bad loans. While the measure is a step forward, experts say it may not be enough to address the issue, and careful structuring and pricing are crucial for its success. The fund will be operational in six months, with an estimated 16% of stalled projects to be helped over time.

site_title: When the chips are down
summary: Singapore's semiconductor industry faces another down cycle, exacerbated by the US-China trade war, threatening its role as a key pillar of the local economy. The sector, which employs over 60,000 people, is losing its edge to other regions, including China. As the industry navigates uncertainties, businesses are focusing on upgrading essential goods and services, such as banking and financial services, to remain competitive. The sector's future remains uncertain, with experts warning of the need for innovation and investment to maintain its position in the global market.

site_title: Bovis, Galliford agree on housing deal in ailing British market
summary: Bovis Homes has agreed to a £1.08 billion cash-and-share deal with Galliford Try to acquire its residential businesses, more than doubling Bovis' housing development business. The deal, set to close in January, will make Bovis the fifth largest player in the struggling British market. Galliford shareholders will hold 29.3% of Bovis, and CEO Graham Prothero will join Bovis as COO. The acquisition is expected to boost Bovis' earnings per share by low double digits and bring cost synergies of at least £35 million per annum.

site_title: UK's Conservatives and Labour vow to spend big in battle for votes
summary: The UK's Conservative and Labour parties are vowing to spend billions on infrastructure, with the Conservatives pledging £100 billion and Labour aiming to spend double that amount. Finance Minister Sajid Javid and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn are engaging in a spending battle, with both parties promising to end years of austerity and invest in growth and struggling regions. The election, set for December 12, is seen as a contest between two parties willing to break with economic austerity, with both parties focusing on the economy and making promises to stimulate growth and repair social fabric.

site_title: Home Is Where The Art Is
summary: A retired art gallerist in Singapore has purchased a bungalow with a unique view - a jungle next to his home. He had been eyeing the plot for years and immediately snapped it up when it came on the market. The owner, who wishes to remain anonymous, has expressed his excitement about his new home, which he believes is a million-dollar view.

site_title: STI gains on positive corporate news
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 23.03 points or 0.71% to 3,285.72, driven by local corporate developments. Gainers outnumbered losers 235 to 165, with a record-breaking 1.85 billion securities traded. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, as Singapore's bourse remains unfazed by regional market developments.

site_title: Aussie mates show off their quarter-century Quarter Pounder 'mate'
summary: Two Australian men, Casey Dean and Eduards Nits, claim to have kept a McDonald's Quarter Pounder burger from 1995 intact for 25 years, with no signs of decomposition. The burger has shrunk slightly but remains recognizable, with sesame seeds still intact. The men refer to it as their "mate" and have created social media profiles and written a song about it. A McDonald's spokeswoman attributes the burger's preservation to its dry environment and lack of moisture, which inhibits bacterial growth. The burger is considered the oldest known McDonald's burger in the world.

site_title: Love and loss in Modern Love
summary: The New York Times' long-running column "Modern Love" has been adapted into an Amazon Prime TV series, featuring a star-studded cast including Anne Hathaway, Tina Fey, and Dev Patel. The 8-episode anthology is based on personal essays published in the NYT column, with episodes having the same titles as the essays. While the show offers a romantic vignette with varying doses of realism, it can feel annoyingly pat and self-satisfied, and the format may not translate well to the screen, resulting in overly long dialogue and pensive looks.

site_title: Investcorp eyes food sector with US$500m fund
summary: The Singapore office of Investcorp has launched a US$500 million fund to invest in food brands and manufacturing sites in Asia, with a focus on China's highly fragmented food sector. The fund, co-owned by Investcorp, China Resources, and Fung Strategic Holdings, aims to make 12 investments over five years, with each investment ranging from US$40-70 million. The partners expect to capitalize on China's growing middle class and trend of spending on premium and healthier food brands, despite concerns about slowing economic growth.

site_title: China says it has agreed with US to cancel tariffs in phases
summary: China and the US have agreed to cancel tariffs in phases as part of a trade deal. The US will scrap tariffs on $156 billion worth of Chinese imports, including cell phones and laptops, on December 15. Both countries must simultaneously cancel some tariffs to reach a "phase one" trade deal. The agreement is seen as a significant step towards ending the months-long trade war between the two nations.

site_title: Stop working and go home: why long work days may not work
summary: Microsoft's experiment in Japan, where employees worked 5 consecutive 3-day weekends, showed a 40% sales increase per employee. Similar results were found in a 2018 experiment at a New Zealand company and research by Stanford University economist John Pencavel on World War I munitions plant workers. Long work hours can lead to fatigue, decreased productivity, and reduced usefulness of extra hours. Social signalling may also contribute to the cycle of working long hours. Mandating shorter hours, such as four-day work weeks or more paid vacation, could improve productivity and work-life balance in countries like the US and Japan.

site_title: Procurri Corp suspends trading as it mulls potential third-party offer for its assets
summary: Procurri Corp, a Mainboard-listed enterprise hardware supplier, has suspended trading as it considers a potential third-party offer to buy some of its assets. The company received an unsolicited letter of intent and is reviewing the material terms of the deal. Trading will remain suspended until an announcement is made on the possible transaction. The shares last traded at S$0.37 before the halt.

site_title: Ralph Lauren jumps on brisk sales despite Hong Kong protests
summary: Ralph Lauren Corp reported same-store sales growth of 2% in the latest quarter, beating analysts' average projection of 1.1%. The company attributed this growth to increased spending by domestic customers in North America, despite a decline in foreign shoppers due to Hong Kong protests. Sales in Asia fell short of expectations, with a 1% growth in Hong Kong due to 27% drop in business amid unrest. The company expects overall revenue growth of 2-3% this year, which may be impacted by the Hong Kong protests.

site_title: SE Asian banks 'to lose out on US$5b in payments revenue by 2025'
summary: Southeast Asian banks are projected to miss out on up to $5 billion in payments revenue by 2025 due to the growth of digital payments and competition from non-banks. According to Accenture, banks that adopt latest technologies and focus on value-added services will capture incremental growth, while those that fail to adapt will lose 14.3% of their payments revenue. The region's payments revenue is expected to grow at 6.1% annually, with Singapore banks facing a 20% displacement of payments revenue by digital payments and non-banks.

site_title: Vibrant to consolidate stake in chemical logistics subsidiary for S$13.5 million
summary: Vibrant Group, a MAINBOARD-LISTED logistics player, plans to consolidate its stake in chemical logistics subsidiary LTH Logistics (Singapore) for S$13.5 million. The deal gives Vibrant complete control of LTH Logistics' cash stream, valued at S$114 million. LTH Logistics provides storage and logistics services for chemicals in Singapore and Malaysia. The acquisition is expected to streamline financial resources, but may negatively impact Vibrant's net tangible assets and earnings per share.

site_title: Lynas hunts for Malaysia waste storage site as deadline looms
summary: Lynas Corp, a rare earths miner, is racing against time to find a site in Malaysia's Pahang state for a low-level radioactive waste storage facility by March.
