images.alt_text: M&S has been trying to turn around the clothing arm, which has wrestled with problems ranging from an inadequate supply chain to a bloated real-estate portfolio that it has pared back by closing dozens of stores.

site_title: Jardine C&C underlying earnings fall by 20.7% in Q3
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C) reported a 20.7% year-over-year decline in underlying net profit to US$206.7 million for Q3, driven by tough markets in Indonesia and Vietnam. This marks a decrease from the same period last year. The results reflect the challenges faced by the regional auto dealer in the given markets.

site_title: When financial services sneeze, rest of the economy catches a cold
summary: The Australian Royal Commission into Misconduct in the Banking, Superannuation and Financial Services Industry has proposed a new prudential standard to strengthen governance requirements on remuneration in large financial institutions. The standard, CPS 511 Remuneration, aims to enhance conduct, risk management, and accountability by requiring 60% of CEO variable pay to be deferred for at least seven years and 40% of variable pay for "special role categories" to be deferred for at least six years. The changes could have significant impacts on hundreds of employees, particularly those in control functions, and may signal directional shifts for the global financial services industry.

site_title: Carro eyes digibank licence as vehicle to expand into SME loans
summary: Carro, a Singapore-based used car marketplace, is exploring a wholesale digital banking licence to expand its business and offer SME loans. The company's profitable subsidiary, Genie Financial Services, aims to leverage a digital bank licence to improve underwriting capabilities and access unsecured loans. This move could help Genie break into the broader SME lending space and increase its revenue. Carro has already tripled its net profit to over S$3 million in the financial year ended March 2019, and its loan book is valued at S$120 million.

site_title: WeWork weighs giving up office space in at least six HK locations
summary: WeWork is considering giving up office space in at least six locations in Hong Kong to stem losses and convince investors of its business model's viability. The decision comes after the company's IPO failed. WeWork is looking to surrender a portion of a recently signed lease in Wan Chai, near Hong Kong's central business district. This move is part of the company's efforts to slow down expansion and reduce costs.

images.alt_text: The potential retreat comes after WeWork said just last week it plans to expand its footprint in Hong Kong and open four new locations this quarter. Some of those are among the spaces it is now looking to vacate.

site_title: Providing timely guidance
summary: Medtech firm MiRXES encountered issues with health regulations for a free cancer screening event. A meeting with the Action Community for Entrepreneurship (ACE) Pro-Enterprise Clinic on April 25 resolved some issues within an hour, and the rest were resolved via follow-ups. By May 18, MiRXES successfully screened 242 elderly residents. The timely guidance from the PEP helped MiRXES navigate the complex regulatory landscape, ensuring the successful execution of their event.

site_title: China considers up to US$10b stake in Aramco's IPO
summary: China is in talks to invest US$5-10 billion in Saudi Aramco's initial public offering (IPO), with state-owned entities including the Silk Road Fund and China Investment Corp potentially participating. This investment would help Aramco's share sale succeed after Western investors expressed concerns over the company's valuation. The move is part of President Xi Jinping's "One Belt, One Road" initiative to increase China's political clout and profit from rising oil prices. No final commitments have been made, and the amount each firm invests will depend on the Chinese government.

site_title: ARA H-Trust to buy three US hotels for US$84.5m
summary: ARA H-Trust will acquire three Marriott-branded hotels in the US for US$84.5 million, growing its portfolio to 41 hotels with 5,340 guest rooms. The acquisition is expected to increase distribution income by US$1.4 million, or 3.38 US cents per stapled security, at a net property income yield of 8%. The move comes after the trust reported a Q3 performance that missed its IPO forecast, citing supply growth outpacing demand in the upscale select-service segment.

site_title: Germany ready to move on euro zone bank reform, but sets tough conditions
summary: Germany proposed four reforms to complete the euro zone's banking union, including a European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS) with modifications. Finance Minister Olaf Scholz stated Germany is ready to discuss EDIS, but under certain conditions. The European Commission and ECB reacted with lukewarm responses, leaving the fate of the reforms uncertain. Germany's stance marks a shift in its approach to the stalled banking union, but the exact terms of the reforms remain unclear.

site_title: Trafigura pilots US$20m trade on Singapore blockchain platform
summary: Trafigura, a commodity trading giant, has partnered with DBS Bank and IMDA to pilot a US$20 million trade on Singapore's blockchain platform, ICC TradeFlow. The platform, built on IMDA's TradeTrust, aims to reduce inefficiencies in cross-border trade by facilitating electronic trade documents exchange among different digital ecosystems. The pilot trade involves a Trafigura shipment of iron ore from Africa to China, with the goal of increasing transaction speed and reducing paperwork. The initiative is expected to promote more efficient and transparent trade finance, and further development plans include on-the-go trade finance and credit ratings.

site_title: Impeachment: Trump's son tweets name of alleged whistleblower
summary: President Donald Trump's son, Donald Trump Jr, tweeted the name of the alleged whistleblower whose complaint led to the impeachment inquiry against Trump. The CIA analyst's identity has not been independently verified, but Trump Jr linked to a Breitbart article implying the person was pro-Democrat and anti-Trump. The White House seeks to discredit the impeachment effort, while Democrats continue to accuse Trump of abuse of power and illegally leveraging US military aid for political favors.

site_title: Self-driving Uber in crash not equipped to recognise jaywalkers
summary: A self-driving Uber test car killed a pedestrian in a 2018 crash in Arizona, but US safety investigators found the vehicle wasn't programmed to recognize and react to jaywalkers. The National Transportation Safety Board released over 400 pages of reports, but didn't assign a cause for the crash. Uber made changes to its system after the investigation and claims it would have avoided the incident if the safety driver had seen the pedestrian. The incident is closely watched in the emerging self-driving vehicle industry, with billions of dollars invested in the technology.

site_title: US productivity drops by most since Q4 2015
summary: US productivity dropped by 0.3% in the third quarter, the largest decline since Q4 2015, according to the Labour Department. This decline, coupled with a 2.4% increase in hours worked and a 2.1% rise in output, led to a lower-than-expected 0.9% productivity growth. The drop may set back expectations for a trend growth rate following the 2017 tax law changes.

site_title: Macron, Xi pledge to uphold free trade and build an open global economy
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and French President Emmanuel Macron pledged to uphold free trade and build an open global economy during a three-day visit to China. They also agreed to strengthen cooperation on climate change and preserve the Paris accord. The two countries signed contracts totaling $15 billion, covering industries such as aeronautics, energy, and agriculture. Macron also announced plans to protect European products with a specific geographical origin, such as Champagne and Manchego cheese, in a bid to fight counterfeits. The agreements aim to promote a stable partnership between China and France and counter US President Donald Trump's trade policies.

site_title: Breaking up is too hard to do, says M&S chairman
summary: M&S Chairman Archie Norman has stated that splitting the retailer into two companies, one for clothing and home, and one for food, is "completely impractical" and not in the board's current thinking. Norman, who has overseen the company's transformation plan, cited the shared systems, culture, and profit-making areas between the two businesses as reasons against a split. Despite some media speculation, Norman emphasized that nothing is forever and that the company will continue to evolve. M&S has been focusing on sustainable growth, closing weaker stores, and investing in technology to drive change.

site_title: Younger, older HDB resale flats see slower price decline in Q3
summary: Prices for older HDB flats in Singapore fell 0.9% in Q3, a slower decline than the 3.4% drop in the same period last year. Younger flats, defined as those less than 10 years old, saw a 2.5% price drop, also a slower rate than the 4.8% decline in Q3 2018. Strong demand for resale flats and more flats being sold within 10 years of completion may have contributed to the slower price declines.

site_title: Citic Envirotech's parent makes S$0.55-a-share offer in privatisation bid
summary: Citic Envirotech's parent, Citic Group Corp, plans to take the water treatment company private in a deal valued at S$1.34 billion. The offer, launched through CKM (Cayman) Company, values each share at S$0.55, a 68.5% premium over the three-month volume-weighted average. The offer, subject to Chinese authority approval and shareholder approval, aims to provide an attractive exit opportunity for shareholders and reduce compliance costs. The exit offer is expected to be completed in the week of Dec 30.

site_title: Alipay, WeChat Pay open apps to foreigners visiting China
summary: Chinese payments giants Alipay and WeChat Pay are opening their platforms to foreigners visiting China, allowing them to use their foreign cards for payments. The move comes after regulatory easing and is expected to boost spending on the platforms. Alipay has already launched a prepaid card service, while WeChat Pay plans to directly connect foreign cards to its app. The partnership with Visa and other card networks aims to expand cross-border payment capabilities, potentially paving the way for future adoption abroad.

site_title: Podcast: SFF x Switch 2019 Ep 2: Why does fintech matter?
summary: The Singapore Fintech Festival x Singapore Week of Innovation and Technology will run from November 11-15, 2019. Monetary Authority of Singapore's managing director Ravi Menon discusses how fintech can improve everyday transactions, making financial decisions easier and cheaper. Fintech aims to make life easier with technology, as stated by Menon, highlighting its potential to revolutionize financial transactions.

site_title: SBI Offshore's request for whitewash resolution extension rejected
summary: SBI Offshore's request for an extension on getting shareholder approval for a planned reverse takeover was rejected by the Securities Industry Council. The company had sought more time to obtain approval after missing the initial deadline of October 17. The SIC has told SBI Offshore to reapply when the acquisition terms are certain and the whitewash resolution can be sought within three months. The company will submit the re-application in due course, with the board to update shareholders on any relevant developments.

site_title: Firms dangle double-digit pay hikes for tech talent
summary: Singapore tech talent continues to see high demand despite a slowing global economy, with firms offering double-digit pay hikes to attract and retain top talent. Recruiters report that companies are not only hiring for current tech roles but also creating new ones. This comes despite job cuts announced by companies like Uber, WeWork, and HP. The high demand for tech talent underscores the growing importance of technology in various industries, with many firms investing in AI, digital innovation, and edtech research to stay competitive.

site_title: UOB appoints receivers for Libra Group's Loyang Drive property
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has appointed receivers for Libra Group's mortgaged property in Loyang Drive, following a letter of demand from the bank for payment of over S$1.3 million. The property, bought for S$16 million in 2014, is excluded from Libra's six-month debt moratorium. The company is considering its options and will provide updates to shareholders. This move comes after Libra suspended trading in August due to financial difficulties.

site_title: Boeing to invest US$1b in global safety drive
summary: Boeing plans to invest around $1 billion in a global pilot development initiative as part of its "Global Aviation Safety" program, aimed at rebuilding trust and cooperation with airlines, passengers, and regulators after the 737 MAX crashes. The project will focus on improving pilot training and aircraft design, with potential investments in aviation infrastructure, training materials, and data-sharing networks. The initiative is expected to be rolled out over years and will require significant funding, with costs expected to rise over time.

site_title: DFS again increases severance payouts to retrenched staff
summary: DFS Group has increased severance payouts to retrenched staff in Singapore, with each affected worker now receiving one month's salary for each year of service, capped at 25 years. This is a significant upgrade from the previous offer of two weeks' salary for each year of service, capped at 13 years. The move comes after Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo criticized DFS for its handling of layoffs, particularly communication with employees. DFS will continue to provide support to affected staff, including career coaching, job matching, and outplacement services.

site_title: Frencken Q3 net profit more than doubles on lack of impairment losses
summary: Frencken Group's net profit more than doubled to S$11.4 million in Q3 2019, driven by the absence of impairment losses from the previous year. Revenue rose 3.8% to S$170.2 million, with growth in the mechatronics division. For the nine months, net profit increased 63.8% to S$31.1 million. The company expects a challenging business environment in the year-end period, but forecasts year-on-year revenue growth in the semiconductor and medical segments.

site_title: Responding to the New Cold War
summary: The US and China are escalating tensions, with the US declaring a "Cold War" on China in 2018 and China continuing to gain economic and military strength relative to the US. This has led to a trade war and increased competition in various sectors, including technology. The global scenario suggests a new Cold War between the US and China, with the US carving out a sphere of influence and China expanding its sphere in Asia. Both sides are taking withdrawal strategies, with Chinese foreign direct investment in the US dropping 73% last year, and Western firms moving operations to other parts of Asia. Decentralization across both spheres is a possible alternative, but it poses significant challenges due to legal restrictions, currency controls, and other factors.

images.alt_text: Even as the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall - symbolising post-war conflict between the East and the West and the so-called Cold War - was marked in October, a renewed Cold War scenario may well materialise between the US and China.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed flat on Wednesday, extending a winning streak to a fifth day, as investors awaited developments in China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index rose 5.24 points to 27,688.64, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.43% and 0.87%, respectively. The rally was largely driven by optimism about the US trade talks, despite ongoing tensions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.49 points to 1,603.25. Losers outnumbered gainers 485 to 338, and volume reached 2.7 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion.

site_title: EU makes first move to end fossil fuel funding
summary: The European Union has reached a preliminary agreement to end funding for fossil fuel projects by the European Investment Bank, a breakthrough in the bloc's climate policy. The document, agreed by EU member states, calls for the bank to phase out funding for fossil fuel projects, particularly those using solid fossil fuels, by the end of the year. The move aims to reduce carbon emissions and align with the EU's climate goals. The EIB funded over 2 billion euros in fossil fuel projects last year and 13.4 billion euros since 2013.

site_title: Boeing says India will order 2,380 jets from planemakers over 20 years
summary: Boeing forecasts Indian airlines will order up to 2,380 planes over the next 20 years, exceeding its previous prediction of 2,300 planes. The country's passenger traffic has been growing at 20% annually, driven by its fast-growing aviation market. However, growth has slowed this year due to the collapse of Jet Airways and softer economic conditions. Boeing is working with regulators to return its 737 MAX model to service, expected to resume in the fourth quarter. Airbus currently holds the dominant market share in India, with IndiGo ordering 300 more A320 planes last month.

site_title: Metech posts Q1 net profit of S$30,000, reverses year-ago loss
summary: Metech International, a Catalist-listed metal dealer, reported a net profit of S$30,000 for the first quarter, reversing a S$1.78 million loss in the same period last year. The company attributed the profit to lower exposure to metal-trading activities due to global economic softness. Revenue fell 40.2% to S$14.6 million. Metech plans to re-allocate resources to develop asset-light businesses in supply chain management, which it believes present lower risk. The company does not have accumulated profits to declare a dividend.

site_title: Slow growth the main risk to Indonesian property market: Report
summary: A recent report from Maybank Kim Eng warns that Indonesia's property market is at risk due to slow economic growth below 5%. Despite lower mortgage rates and increased affordable housing supply, analysts fear inadequate job creation and falling household incomes if growth falls below the benchmark. Bank Central Asia and Bank Rakyat Indonesia have already lowered mortgage rates, with more expected to follow. The report highlights the need for interest rate cuts amid soft inflation to mitigate the impact of potential economic downturn.

site_title: Saudi deficit contained in Q3 despite 25% oil revenue drop
summary: Saudi Arabia posted a fiscal deficit of 32.1 billion riyals (S$11.6 billion) in the third quarter, a 4% decrease from the previous quarter. The deficit was largely attributed to a 24.6% drop in oil revenues to 131.8 billion riyals due to low crude prices and OPEC-led production cuts. Despite attacks on Saudi oil plants in September, the government's revenue was not significantly impacted. Non-oil revenues also dropped 12.2% quarter-on-quarter to 75.4 billion riyals. The deficit is expected to widen to 187 billion riyals in 2023, or 6.5% of GDP.

site_title: CH Offshore Q3 net loss widens as brokers' commission raises costs
summary: CH Offshore, a vessel chartering company, reported a widened net loss of US$6.29 million in Q3, driven by a provision for brokers' commission, which increased administrative expenses to US$5.79 million. Revenue more than doubled to US$5.84 million, but the company expects volatile oil prices and soft charter rates. CH Offshore will focus on operational efficiency and cost reduction to preserve cash, and has not recommended a dividend. The company's 9-month net loss was US$13.1 million, compared to US$23.8 million previously.

site_title: Hot stock: StarHub shares jump 9.8% on Q3 results, 5G bid plans
summary: StarHub shares rose 9.8% to S$1.45 on Wednesday after the telco released its third-quarter results, with net profit up 1.7%. The company also cut its full-year service revenue forecast. Plans for a joint 5G bid with another mobile network operator are being considered. Analysts upgraded their calls on StarHub, citing significant capex reductions and potential consolidation in the sector.

site_title: All COE prices tumble except in the motorbike category
summary: COE prices in Singapore's latest tender ended mostly lower, with car prices down to a four-month low. The motorcycle COE price rose, possibly due to a virtual ban on personal mobility devices. The lowest COE prices were seen for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp at $30,000, and commercial vehicles at $25,392. The premium for open COE and cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp also decreased, with prices at $40,101 and $40,009 respectively.

site_title: Jardine C&C posts 20.7% drop in Q3 underlying net profit to US$206.7m
summary: Jardine C&C posted a 20.7% drop in Q3 underlying net profit to US$206.7m, driven by tough markets in Indonesia and Vietnam. Revenue dipped 1% to US$4.75 billion, with challenging conditions affecting Astra and Truong Hai Auto Corporation. Overall net profit rose 50.3% to US$301.4m, but the company did not recommend a dividend for the third quarter. The decline in Truong Hai Auto Corp's vehicle sales, due to intense competition, and lower car sales at Astra, contributed to the earnings drop.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Trafigura to use a blockchain platform to facilitate a $20m iron ore shipment from Africa to China. Vietnam surprised by US tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry prepares for higher US tariffs. Malaysia to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup sets a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: Europe's leading stock markets remained steady at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.1% and the eurozone's DAX 30 index flat. The Paris CAC 40 edged up 0.1%. Mining and healthcare stocks supported shares, while US-EU trade talks were in focus.

site_title: First Reit keeps Q3 DPU flat at 2.15 S cents
summary: First Reit, a healthcare real estate investment trust, maintained its Q3 DPU of 2.15 Singapore cents, unchanged from the same period last year. Distributable income rose 1.3% year-on-year to S$17.2 million, while net property income slipped 2.5% to S$28.2 million due to higher property expenses. The trust's gearing stood at 34.5%, and it has a weighted average lease expiry of 7.8 years. First Reit sees opportunities for yield-accretive acquisitions in Indonesia and the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: EU, China agree to protect 100 of each other's regional foods
summary: The European Union and China have agreed to protect 100 European regional food names and 100 Chinese geographical indications in each other's markets. This deal includes products like cava, feta, and prosciutto di Parma from the EU, and Pixian bean paste, Anji white tea, and Panjin rice from China. The agreement aims to boost trade in higher-value goods and is expected to enter into force before the end of 2020, with the potential to expand to cover an additional 175 names four years later.

site_title: Singapore shares continue upward trend, rise 0.4% on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.43% on Wednesday, marking a third consecutive session of gains, despite regional markets trading flat or lower due to US-China trade uncertainty. Financials and industrial companies led the advancers, while 209 stocks outperformed 177 decliners. The index closed at 3,262.69, with 1.71 billion securities changing hands worth S$1.4 billion.

site_title: Tembusu Partners sets up fund to invest in China baijiu development
summary: Tembusu Partners has launched its China Guizhou Baijiu Fund, a private equity fund that will invest up to $387 million in the Guizhou region to support the development of baijiu production. The fund, which aims for an 8% annual return, will partner with the Renhuai Moutai Flavor Liquor Industry Development & Investment Co to invest in procurement, storage, and processing of baijiu foundation spirits. The fund is targeting a 500 million yuan first close in Q1 2020 and is expected to capitalize on the growing demand for baijiu, with the global market expected to grow by 10% annually by 2022.

site_title: IBM, Bank of America team up to launch financial services-specific cloud
summary: IBM and Bank of America have collaborated to launch a financial services-specific cloud, the first major bank to use the platform. The public platform meets high regulatory, security, and resiliency standards required of the financial services industry. This marks IBM's first industry-specific cloud, aiming to set a safety level unmatched in the public cloud.

site_title: Impossible Foods creating plant-based pork as it eyes China
summary: Impossible Foods is developing plant-based pork in response to China's meat shortage, which has seen 28% of the world's meat consumption. The company's CEO, Pat Brown, stated that Chinese government officials are committed to reducing their environmental footprint and addressing food security issues. With over 60% of Chinese consumers' daily meat intake being pork, Impossible Foods aims to capitalize on this opportunity, despite African swine fever forcing widespread hog culling and pork prices to spike nearly 70%. A successful China entry could help the imitation meat market reach 9% of global meat consumption by 2040.

site_title: New SIA pact with Malaysia Airlines may get off the ground within a year
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Malaysia Airlines Berhad have agreed on a commercial pact to share revenue on flights between the two countries and expand codeshare routes. The deal, which includes SIA's subsidiaries SilkAir and Scoot, may take effect within a year, pending regulatory approvals. The partnership aims to coordinate flight schedules, offer joint fare products, and explore tie-ups between frequent-flyer programmes. The arrangement is seen as a win-win for both carriers, allowing them to expand their network and market tourism.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange Q3 profit drops 8% on lower trading fee
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd reported an 8% drop in third-quarter profit to HK$2.2 billion, due to a decrease in trading income despite a surge in listing fees. The company's net profit was down from HK$2.4 billion a year ago. Market sentiment in Hong Kong has improved following a series of large IPOs, but the city's economic outlook remains uncertain due to the ongoing Sino-US trade war and protests.

site_title: BOT cuts key rate as exports under pressure, more easing likely
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand (BOT), cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 1.25% for the second time this year, amid weak global demand and a strong baht that has compounded economic pressures. The decision aims to bolster the economy, which is expected to remain subdued due to a shrinking export sector. The baht has risen 7.2% against the US dollar, and the BOT plans to announce measures to slow its strength. Economists forecast further rate cuts, with rates potentially lowered to 1.0% by the end of the year.

site_title: Sunningdale Tech Q3 net profit drops 26% to S$5.57m
summary: Sunningdale Tech reported a 26% drop in Q3 net profit to S$5.57m, due to a 4.2% decline in revenue and increased expenses. The company attributed the decline to trade war tensions and challenging market conditions, particularly in the automotive and consumer segments. Despite this, the group remains positive on its healthcare business and expects the opening of a new plant to ease pressure on margins. No dividend was recommended, and the stock closed up 3.18% to S$1.30.

site_title: Manila office workers consider dorms to cope with world's worst traffic: poll
summary: Nearly half of Manila office workers consider living in a dormitory to avoid the world's worst traffic, according to a Colliers International survey. 45% of respondents are willing to stay in a co-living facility due to financial and personal costs associated with worsening traffic. Workers spend up to 4,500 pesos monthly on commuting and are willing to spend up to 6,000 pesos for a dormitory closer to work. Colliers forecasts a 51% rise in beds in shared accommodations in Metro Manila by 2021, driven by builders offering worker dormitories with differentiating features.

site_title: Slower pace of price depreciation for younger and older HDB resale flats in Q3: report
summary: Singapore's HDB resale flat prices showed a slower pace of depreciation in Q3 2019, with younger flats (less than 10 years old) declining 2.5% quarter-over-quarter and older flats (40 years and above) dropping 0.9%. This slowdown is attributed to increased sales of flats within 10 years of completion and more transactions in non-mature estates. The report suggests that more families may be "cashing out" earlier to upgrade to private property or bigger HDB flats, potentially leading to downward pressure on prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index closes at fresh 13-month high
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed at a fresh 13-month high, reaching 23,303.82, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks. The index added 0.22% to its previous close, marking its best finish in nearly 13 months. The broader Topix index remained flat. This positive trend follows recent rallies in Asia and the US, with stocks continuing to edge towards fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end flat as investors await trade clues
summary: South Korean stocks ended flat on Wednesday, despite early gains, as investors awaited developments on US-China trade talks. The KOSPI rose 0.07% to 2,144.15, marking its fifth consecutive session of gains. Foreigners were net buyers of $204.13 million worth of shares, contributing to the index's 5.05% year-to-date gain. The lack of new trade momentum limited upward pressure, according to analyst Lee Kyoung-min from Daishin Securities.

site_title: Demand slowdown looms in Indonesia, despite growth
summary: Indonesia's economic growth slowed in the third quarter, with final domestic demand growing 4.4% year-on-year, its lowest pace in almost three years. Private and public consumption declined, with household consumption growing 5% instead of the expected 5.2%. This slowdown is attributed to election years, where consumption growth and government spending tend to slow down. Despite this, economists still expect Indonesia to reach 5% growth in 2019 and 2020, driven by private consumption. The slowdown is seen as a warning sign for the country's economy.

site_title: Singapore Poly partners Zebra Technologies to groom talent in advanced manufacturing
summary: Singapore Polytechnic has partnered with Zebra Technologies for a three-year collaboration to provide student internship opportunities and co-develop advanced manufacturing solutions. The partnership will also showcase these solutions through the Singapore Polytechnic Advanced Manufacturing Partners Network, aiming to build a sustainable ecosystem for industry leaders. This collaboration aims to groom talent in advanced manufacturing and support Singapore's initiatives in this field.

site_title: Australia shares fall as gold miners tumble; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% to 6,660.20 due to a drop in gold miners. The S&P/ASX 200 index had risen 0.2% the previous day. Investors await progress on US-China trade talks, with a potential "phase one" deal to be signed as early as this month.

site_title: SingHaiyi sinks into the red with S$4.6m Q2 loss
summary: SingHaiyi Group reported a net loss of S$4.6 million for its Q2, down from a profit of S$7.7 million a year ago, due to decreased revenue and increased finance costs. Loss per share (LPS) stood at 0.109 Singapore cents, compared to 0.179 cents in the previous year. This was mainly attributed to a slide in recognized contributions from several projects.

site_title: Indonesian president tells bankers to cut lending rates, boost loans to SMEs
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged bankers to increase lending to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) amid slowing economic growth, citing a 5.02% growth rate in the third quarter. He also urged them to cut lending rates, saying "don't just finance the big players" and referencing those who applauded. This move aims to boost economic growth and support the country's SME sector.

site_title: China's Didi to relaunch Hitch service in November
summary: China's ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing plans to relaunch its Hitch carpooling service in seven cities at the end of November with improved safety features and stricter driver verification. The service was suspended last year after a passenger was murdered by a Didi driver. The relaunch will initially offer trips under 50km for female users during specific hours and will test a women's safety program. Didi aims to prioritize safety over growth, with improved safety features and more rigorous verification mechanisms.

site_title: SoftBank reveals US$6.5b loss from Uber, WeWork turmoil
summary: SoftBank Group Corp reported its first quarterly operating loss in 14 years, totaling US$6.5 billion, due to significant write-downs on investments in Uber Technologies Inc. and WeWork. SoftBank's Vision Fund, which had contributed to profit growth, is now facing a shrinking valuation of its portfolio, raising concerns about future writedowns. The losses call into question SoftBank's deal-making approach under billionaire founder Masayoshi Son, who is trying to raise a successor to the US$100 billion Vision Fund.

images.alt_text: Masayoshi Son is finally disclosing the damage from SoftBank Group Corp's bets on WeWork and Uber Technologies Inc.

site_title: Japan Q3 GDP growth may slow, but domestic demand still solid: poll
summary: Japan's economy likely grew for a fourth consecutive quarter in July-September, driven by solid domestic demand, but at a slower pace than the second quarter. The economy is expected to rise 0.8% annually, with private consumption accounting for 60% of GDP and capital spending rising 0.9%. External demand, however, is seen subtracting 0.1 percentage point from growth. The effect of a sales tax hike is expected to filter through in the fourth quarter, potentially leading to a contraction.

site_title: Medical costs, compensation to be paid to affected parties in fatal Novena crane accident
summary: A fatal crane accident occurred at a Novena construction site in Singapore, resulting in the death of an Indian national and injuring a 35-year-old Bangladeshi worker. The Migrant Workers' Centre (MWC) has confirmed that medical costs and compensation will be provided to the affected parties, with the worksite's main contractor and employers taking responsibility. Funeral arrangements are being made for the deceased worker, and counselling will be arranged for affected workers.

site_title: Financial firms due to disclose stranded-asset risks from climate change
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority is set to release guidelines on environmental risk management for the financial sector, amid growing concerns about climate change's impact on stranded assets. The regulator aims to encourage financial institutions to disclose climate-related risks and take mitigation actions. MAS managing director Ravi Menon emphasized the need for the financial sector to lead the transition towards a greener economy, with incentives such as green bonds and sustainability reports to support this effort. The guidelines are expected to be announced at the upcoming Singapore Fintech Festival.

site_title: Asia: Investors bide their time as they weigh trade prospects
summary: Asian investors cautiously approached markets on Wednesday, weighing optimism over China-US trade talks against profit-taking after a recent rally. The US services sector showed a better-than-forecast increase, supporting the Chinese yuan, which held above seven to the dollar. However, investors are concerned that the optimism may be nearing its peak, with some warning of a potential trade deal being "fully priced." The US is considering removing tariffs on Chinese imports, but the outcome is uncertain, and President Trump's decision will determine the fate of the talks.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,259.23, up 0.33% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.33% to 3,259.23. Alpha Energy jumped 17.7% after announcing its Mustang oilfield project hit first oil production and sales. Gainers outnumbered losers 193 to 143, with S$614.9 million in trading volume. This marks the 5th day of a rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: New Bridge Rd shophouse up for sale at S$19.5m; seller to build out rear extension
summary: A four-storey conservation shophouse at 21 New Bridge Road in Singapore is up for sale at S$19.5 million, with the seller committing to build out the rear extension to up to six storeys. The property, situated in a conservation area, is zoned for commercial use and has a plot ratio of 4.2. The sale includes a 99-year lease top-up and a yield of 4% on a "two years plus two years" lease structure. The tender closes on Nov 27, with demand expected to remain consistent for shophouses in the next three years.

site_title: Pro-Beijing politician wounded in Hong Kong knife attack
summary: A pro-Beijing politician, Junius Ho, was wounded in a knife attack in Hong Kong on Wednesday. The attacker, who was subdued by Ho's aides, shouted "Junius Ho, you scum!" before being arrested. This incident is the latest in a series of tit-for-tat violence between pro-Beijing and pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong, which has been embroiled in protests for nearly five months.

site_title: NUS, Ripple set up Singapore fintech lab to groom talent
summary: The National University of Singapore's School of Computing has partnered with Ripple to establish a fintech lab in Singapore. The lab aims to groom talent in the sector and will deploy industry expertise to work on promising fintech projects. It will also train students and professionals to develop emerging technologies in fintech. The lab, led by an industry liaison group, plans to expose 1,000 students and industry professionals to fintech within a year. The partnership is part of a broader strategic alliance between NUS and Ripple's University Blockchain Research Initiative.

site_title: Singapore SMEs more targeted in acquisitions but less keen on new economy businesses
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are increasingly targeting acquisitions, with 41% of SMEs in Southeast Asia planning to pursue M&A over the next 12 months, according to EY's Global Capital Confidence Barometer. However, SMEs are less likely to invest in startups, preferring to outsource or form partnerships instead. The reluctance to acquire startups is attributed to perceived valuation gaps and concerns about the volatility of the startup environment. Despite this, EY predicts that SMEs will eventually enter the new economy space through acquisitions or service acquisitions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.29% to 23,320.04, and the Topix index adding 0.34% to 1,699.86. Optimism over US-China trade talks and a cheaper yen contributed to the gains. The rally follows a fresh high for the Nikkei index, its best finish in nearly 13 months.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.90 points to 1,609.64. Volume reached 57.70 million lots worth RM20.35 million. Gainers outpaced losers 100 to 45.

site_title: China state planner widens scope of industries on 'encouraged' list
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission expanded its list of encouraged industries, adding human resources services, artificial intelligence, elderly care, childcare, and housekeeping. Small coal mines were also added to the list of obsolete industries. This update, made in 2019, marks the first adjustment to the lists since 2013, aiming to guide the country's economic development and resource allocation.

site_title: ARA H-Trust buys 3 US hotels for US$84.5m; Q3 DPS of 1.77 US cents misses forecast
summary: ARA H-Trust acquires three Marriott-branded upscale select-service hotels in the US for $84.5 million, primarily funded by debt and internal cash. The acquisition is expected to increase the Reit's pro forma distribution income by $1.4 million, resulting in a distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 3.38 US cents, up from 3.13 US cents. However, the Reit's Q3 DPS of 1.77 US cents missed forecast, and overall supply growth outpaced demand growth in the upscale select-service segment, leading to a 22.1% decline in net property income.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Wednesday's session with small losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with a 0.17% loss, or 47.07 points, to 27,636.33, following a four-day rally. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index remained flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.62 points. Investors remain optimistic about China-US trade talks, despite recent Trump threats.

site_title: HSBC snags investment banker from Barclays to boost Asia deals: sources
summary: HSBC has hired investment banker Misi Tang from Barclays to bolster its corporate banking business in Asia. Tang, a managing director and head of capital goods and autos coverage for the Asia-Pacific, will join HSBC in December and be based in Hong Kong. The move comes after HSBC's third-quarter profit missed estimates, and is part of the bank's efforts to revamp its global banking and markets division. This is the second high-profile hire by HSBC, following Jeremy Choy's appointment as head of technology mergers and acquisitions for Asia in June.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday, STI up 0.1% to 3,253.24
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.1% higher at 3,253.24, following Wall Street's record highs overnight, as signs of easing US-China trade tensions boosted investor sentiment. The Straits Times Index gained 4.61 points, with 55 gainers outnumbering 44 losers, amidst 59.7 million shares traded worth S$52.3 million.

site_title: Huawei forecasts robust smartphone growth despite Trump ban
summary: Huawei forecasts 20% growth in smartphone shipments for 2020 despite a US ban on Google software, citing its massive home market and in-house software as a buffer. The company's president, Will Zhang, says it has developed three different goals for smartphone shipments, including a best-case scenario of 40% growth. Huawei has managed to sustain growth despite the ban, which has impacted its server business and revenue projections. The company is exploring ways to get around the Google blockade, including developing its own operating system, HarmonyOS.

site_title: US dollar buoyed by trade deal hopes, strong US economic data
summary: The US dollar gained strength against its rivals, particularly against safe-haven currencies, due to rising hopes for a US-China trade deal and solid US economic data. The dollar index remained steady at 97.936, while the euro fell to a near-three-week low of US$1.10635. A strong US employment report and a survey showing improved business sentiment in the US service sector also boosted dollar bulls. The Australian dollar and offshore yuan continued to rally on rising optimism for a trade truce.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge higher but gold stocks cap gains, New Zealand falls
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 6,700.3, driven by gains in the banking and energy sectors, but gains were limited by a fall in gold stocks due to renewed Sino-US trade optimism. The "Big Four" banks rose between 0.4% and 0.8%.

site_title: China launches Sudan's first ever satellite: official
summary: China successfully launched Sudan's first ever satellite, a research satellite for military, economic, and space technology, from China's Shanxi Province on Sunday. The satellite was announced by Sudan's General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan at a meeting with top security officials in Khartoum. This milestone marks a significant step in Sudan's space technology development, with China providing the necessary support and expertise. The satellite's launch is seen as a symbol of growing cooperation between the two countries in the field of space exploration.

site_title: EHT clarifies values of 3 hotels acquired from sponsor
summary: EHT clarifies that the original purchase prices of three hotels acquired from its sponsor, ASAP6, were not disclosed and are unknown to the Reit manager. The reported values by The Edge reflect the mortgage amounts at the time of acquisition, not the actual purchase prices. EHT's manager stated that the valuation comparisons are not representative due to the significant time lapse and capital invested since the original acquisitions. The assets were valued by independent valuers at a discount of at least 12% to their adopted valuation in 2018.

site_title: Bank of Japan debates feasibility of more easing in Sept
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) debated the feasibility of increasing stimulus in September, with some members calling for brainstorming ideas to boost monetary support. However, others warned that prolonged ultra-low interest rates could negatively impact bank profits and encourage excessive risk-taking. The BOJ kept policy steady in October, but voiced concerns over Sino-US trade tensions and global demand. The central bank must consider all possible policy measures to address the potential side effects of its inflation target of 2% and the impact of yield curve control on financial institutions.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan board members debated the feasibility of ramping up stimulus at their September rate review, with some calling for the need to start brainstorming ideas to top up monetary support, minutes of the meeting showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Everything's coming up Yayoi Kusama, including a Macy's balloon
summary: Yayoi Kusama, a 90-year-old Japanese artist, is experiencing a resurgence in popularity, with her work being showcased in various exhibitions and installations worldwide. Her immersive "Infinity Mirror Rooms" have been featured in 18 locations, including the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston and the Broad in Los Angeles. Kusama's artwork, characterized by polka dots, mirrors, and colors, has resonated with a younger generation and has been attributed to her personal story as an Asian woman who has openly battled mental health issues. Her career has been vindicated, with her work reaching a broader audience and inspiring a new appreciation for art.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, EHT, StarHub, FLT, Perennial, Mirach, Prime US Reit, AA Reit
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) posted a 68% jump in net profit to S$94 million for the second quarter, driven by improved associate and joint venture results. However, operating profit slipped 8.6% due to higher expenditure. SIA shares fell 0.4% to S$9.43. Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) clarified that original purchase prices for three assets in its ASAP6 portfolio were not disclosed, and its stapled securities lost 7.4% on Tuesday before rebounding 4.5% on Wednesday.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The future of the automobile industry
summary: The Money FM podcast "Chasing Cars: The Future of the Automobile Industry" explores the future of the automobile industry with Julian Kho from sgcarmart and Claressa Monteiro. They discuss how ready motorists are to adopt new developments, but no specific key facts or events from the article were mentioned.

site_title: AA Reit to raise S$100m from 3.6% notes due 2024
summary: AIMS Apac Reit (AA Reit) plans to issue S$100 million of 3.6% notes due 2024 as part of its S$750 million multicurrency debt issuance program. The five-year notes will be issued at par, with interest payable semi-annually, and will provide the Reit with balance sheet flexibility and strength. The issuance is expected to mature on November 12, 2024, and the net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes. The move is expected to increase the Reit's weighted average debt maturity to approximately 2.9 years.

site_title: Japan's services sector shrinks for first time since 2016 as sales tax hike kicks in: PMI
summary: Japan's services sector contracted for the first time in three years in October, with the PMI dropping to 49.7 from 52.8 in September, as a sales tax hike and a powerful typhoon weighed on demand. The decrease was marginal, but below the 50 mark separating expansion from contraction since September 2016. Despite this, resilient consumption has kept Japan's fragile economic recovery on track.

site_title: China to resume Canadian beef, pork imports: Trudeau
summary: China has agreed to resume imports of Canadian beef and pork, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced, marking a breakthrough in their tense relations. The ban was imposed in June after allegations of contamination and forgery, but Ottawa disputed these claims. The Canadian Food Inspection Agency will issue export certificates immediately, and trade officials will work to resolve any remaining issues. The resumption of trade is seen as a significant step for both countries, with Canada's meat industry and farmers benefiting from the deal.

site_title: Trafigura pilots US$20m trade on Singapore blockchain platform developed with DBS, IMDA
summary: A blockchain platform, ICC TradeFlow, has been developed in Singapore to tackle the trillion-dollar trade finance market. The platform, built on IMDA's TradeTrust, will facilitate a US$20 million pilot trade between Trafigura and DBS, with the goal of reducing paperwork and increasing transaction speed. The platform aims to promote more efficient, transparent, and productive trade finance, and will be further developed to offer on-the-go trade finance and credit ratings. This initiative is part of Singapore's efforts to boost the efficiency of trade, given its strong pool of international trading companies.

site_title: Facebook unknowingly shared private group data with partners
summary: Facebook disclosed that it unknowingly shared private group data with third-party developers for 18 months, allowing them to see users' names and profile photos in groups, despite a 2018 restriction. The company restricted access to only post and comment text, but the data was still being shared. Facebook reached out to 100 affected developers and asked them to delete any retained data. The company has seen no evidence of abuse, but will ask developers to delete any member data they may have retained, following a similar data scandal in 2018.

site_title: Germany's Scholz says European banking deadlock has to end: FT
summary: Germany's Finance Minister Olaf Scholz urged the European Union to resolve a banking union deadlock, warning it would be pushed around on the international stage if progress is not made. Scholz proposed a European Union-wide bank deposit reinsurance scheme to enhance national deposit insurance resilience. He also emphasized the need for uniform taxation of EU banks and the avoidance of dependence on the US or China for financial services.

site_title: US says committed to Britain trade deal after Trump expressed doubt
summary: The US and Britain reaffirmed their commitment to a post-Brexit bilateral free trade agreement, following comments from President Donald Trump that raised doubts about the possibility of such a deal. Trump questioned the UK's ability to trade with the US due to the terms of its EU divorce deal, but later told Prime Minister Boris Johnson that the US remains committed to the agreement. The two leaders spoke on Tuesday, with the White House reiterating their commitment to strengthening the "Special Relationship".

site_title: Top Trump ally admits tying Ukraine aid to Biden investigation
summary: US Ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland admitted in testimony that he told a Ukrainian official that US military aid would be contingent on Kiev investigating President Joe Biden and his son's ties to Ukraine energy firm Burisma. This revelation strengthens Democrats' charges that President Donald Trump abused his office by seeking foreign help for his 2020 election campaign. Sondland's testimony, combined with that of former US Special Representative to Ukraine Kurt Volker, appears to support impeachment charges against Trump, who has denied any link between aid and demands for investigations.

site_title: E-sports startup EVOS bags US$4.4m, to expand into influencer management
summary: Singapore-based e-sports startup EVOS Esports has secured US$4.4 million in Series A funding to expand its influencer management arm in South-east Asia. The startup, which operates in five countries, currently manages 50 gaming influencers and partners with 250 e-sports talents. The fresh funding will be used to grow the e-sports entertainment arm, which aims to capitalize on the growing demand for gaming influencers in the region. With top e-sports influencers earning up to US$60,000 per month, EVOS sees a significant opportunity to tap into the untapped market.

site_title: FLT Q4 DPU up 2.2% in Australian cents on higher revenue
summary: FRASERS Logistics and Industrial Trust (FLT) reported a 2.2% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.82 Australian cents in its fourth quarter, driven by higher revenue of 1.9% to A$61.6 million. DPU in Singapore-dollar terms fell 2.8% to 1.73 Singapore cents. FLT's full-year DPU rose 4.8% to 7.27 Australian cents, while distributable income surged 26.6% to A$149.8 million. The Reit's CEO attributed the growth to acquisitions in Europe and Australia and strong leasing momentum.

site_title: Struggling Norwegian Air raises 2.5b crowns from share sale, bond issue
summary: Norwegian Air has raised 2.5 billion Norwegian crowns (S$370 million) through a share sale and bond issue to meet its cash needs through 2020. The airline sold 27.25 million new shares at 40 crowns per share, a 13% discount to the closing price. It also raised US$150 million via a convertible bond issue. The funds will help secure financing for working capital and complete the airline's strategic transformation, which includes trimming capacity and offloading Boeing 737 Max aircraft. Passenger traffic declined 3% year-on-year in October, but load factor and yield remained steady.

site_title: Oil up on optimism over US-China talks, US jobs
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, driven by improved US jobs growth and optimism over a potential US-China trade deal. Brent crude futures for January settled at $62.13 a barrel, up 44 cents, and December US crude futures rose 34 cents to $56.54 a barrel. The US jobs growth added to market hopes for a deal, boosting oil demand outlook.

site_title: Brazil's Vale failed to report dam defects that could have avoided tragedy: official
summary: Brazil's mining giant Vale failed to report defects in a massive tailings dam in Minas Gerais that led to its collapse, killing hundreds. Internal documents show Vale was aware of problems with the dam's drainage system seven months before the disaster. The company had reported the issues, but ANM, the National Mineral Agency, was not informed, potentially preventing the tragedy. Vale has suspended operations and faces growing pressure, with prosecutors considering charges against employees and auditors.

site_title: Global investors in bidding war for obscure Japan stock
summary: Global investors, including Blackstone Group and Fortress Investment Group, are engaged in a bidding war for Unizo Holdings Co, a Japanese developer whose shares have slumped for three years. The Tokyo-based property firm has called on acquirers to meet stringent demands, including ensuring employment for workers and the Unizo Employee Stock Ownership Company. If a deal goes through, it could be a rare hostile takeover in Japan, with potential implications for the country's over US$6 trillion stock market. The outcome is uncertain, with Unizo's management displaying a stubborn streak and activist investor Elliott expressing concerns about the company's handling of the takeover bids.

site_title: US accuses Iran of 'nuclear extortion' with enrichment step
summary: The US has accused Iran of "nuclear extortion" after the country announced it would resume uranium enrichment at the Fordow plant, violating a 2015 nuclear accord. The US will continue to impose maximum pressure on Iran until it abandons its destabilizing behavior. This move comes after the US withdrew from the deal and imposed sweeping sanctions, and Iran seeks tangible benefits. The State Department will await verification by the International Atomic Energy Agency before taking further action.

site_title: US: Dow edges to another record on trade optimism
summary: US stocks closed at record levels on Tuesday, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks. The Dow edged to a new record, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reached fresh highs. A Wall Street Journal report suggested the US and China may roll back prior tariff measures to finalize a "phase one" trade agreement, boosting hopes for a deal. Despite some fluctuations, US stocks remained bullish, with the Dow closing at a record for the second day in a row.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit more than 4-year peak on trade hopes
summary: European shares reached a four-year high on Tuesday, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks and rising energy prices. The Stoxx 600 index closed up 0.2% at its highest since July 2015. Mining and energy stocks rose, while banks continued their winning streak. However, healthcare and real estate stocks declined, and some companies reported weak quarterly results. The focus will shift to euro zone services PMIs on Wednesday, with analysts expecting a positive reading.

site_title: US navy prepares allies to 'protect navigation' in Gulf
summary: The US Navy has begun a three-week International Maritime Exercise (IMX) in the Gulf, training Gulf allies to "protect navigation" amid regional tensions. The exercise comes after several commercial vessels were attacked in the region from May, with Washington and Western powers blaming Iran for the incidents, which Iran has denied. The US aims to build an alliance to contain Iran and ensure safe passage in the region's waterways.

site_title: Billionaires still love the horse race that stops a nation
summary: The Melbourne Cup, Australia's richest horse race, remains a major draw for racing-mad billionaires despite losing its title to The Everest in Sydney. Wealthy horse owners from around the world compete for A$4.4 million and an 18-carat gold trophy. However, the event faces challenges, including rising animal cruelty concerns and competition from The Everest's A$14 million prize pool. Despite this, billionaires like Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum and Lloyd Williams continue to invest in the race, highlighting the enduring appeal of the event.

site_title: TransferWise links up with Indonesian, Philippine e-wallets: CEO
summary: TransferWise, a money transfer company, has partnered with e-wallets in Indonesia and the Philippines, allowing users to make international payments into digital wallets. The move reflects the growing use of e-wallets as an alternative to traditional bank accounts. The partnership, which includes GoPay, OVO, DANA, GCash, PayMaya, and BKash, will initially process payments using a third-party intermediary, with plans to allow international payments out of the wallets in the future. This marks a shift in TransferWise's business strategy in Asia, with the company considering expansion into other markets, including China and India.

site_title: Brazil hopes to raise US$26.5b in mega oil field auction
summary: Brazil is set to auction drilling rights to deep-sea oil fields off its southeast coast, aiming to raise US$26.5 billion. The four blocks are estimated to contain 15 billion barrels of oil, nearly double Norway's reserves. This sale is significant, as pre-salt deposits account for 60% of Brazil's oil production, ranking the country's sector 9th globally. The auction is expected to boost Brazil's crude sector and solidify its position as a major oil producer.

site_title: Beijing pressing Trump for more tariff rollbacks in 'phase one' trade deal: sources
summary: US President Donald Trump is under pressure from Beijing to remove more tariffs imposed in September as part of the "phase one" US-China trade deal. China is seeking to scrap tariffs scheduled for December 15 on $156 billion worth of Chinese imports. The deal, expected to be signed by Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, may include a US pledge to remove the tariffs, which were imposed in September. The negotiations are ongoing, with a yet-to-be determined location for the signing.

site_title: Correct decision for RCEP to push on, even without India
summary: The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) has completed its negotiations, despite India's last-minute withdrawal due to concerns over market access and agricultural produce. The 15 remaining countries, including China, Japan, and South Korea, have agreed on the pact's 20 chapters and market access issues. Although India's absence may devalue the pact, its continued participation was deemed necessary for the multilateral trading system. The RCEP is set to become the world's largest free trade agreement if implemented, and its signing is expected to take place in Vietnam in 2020.

site_title: A lone Bitcoin whale likely fuelled 2017 surge, study finds
summary: A study by University of Texas's John Griffin and Ohio State University's Amin Shams suggests that a single Bitcoin "whale" was likely behind the 2017 surge in Bitcoin's value, manipulating the market with the power to move prices at will. The entity, found on the cryptocurrency exchange Bitfinex, uses Tether, a widely used digital token, to facilitate its transactions. The researchers argue that this entity, rather than thousands of investors, was responsible for the price manipulation, which resulted in billions of dollars being handed over to unknown individuals with little oversight.

site_title: For gold, best to take cautious view on trade talks' progress
summary: Gold prices may be cautious amid apparent progress in US-China trade talks, as a similar history with North Korea suggests little tangible progress. Investors are tracking positive signs, but Taurus Wealth Advisors advises caution, citing a lack of concrete results in past negotiations. Despite this, gold remains positive, with a 17% year-to-date gain, driven by lower interest rates and central bank purchases. Total gold purchases rose 3% in the third quarter, with bullion-backed ETFs driving growth.

site_title: US telecom regulator approves T-Mobile, Sprint merger
summary: The US telecom regulator, FCC, approved the merger of T-Mobile and Sprint, clearing the way for the $26 billion deal. The 3-2 vote is conditioned on Sprint's divestment of its prepaid division Boost Mobile to Dish Network, which will build a new national wireless network. Backers claim the merger will secure US leadership in 5G, close the digital divide in rural America, and enhance competition. Critics argue it will reduce choices for consumers and lead to higher prices, citing concerns over market concentration and reduced innovation.

images.alt_text: The US telecom regulator on Tuesday approved the merger of T-Mobile and Sprint, moving the tie-up of the third- and fourth-largest US carriers closer to completion.

site_title: The green short: funds bet against laggards in sustainable shift
summary: Financial firms are launching sustainability-focused mutual funds that short companies failing to transition to environmental sustainability, a new trend in the asset management landscape. These funds, which include boutique money managers and French behemoth BNP Paribas, mimic hedge-fund tactics by buying stakes in environmentally conscious companies and shorting those that are not. This approach is seen as a way to profit from betting against laggards and drive down demand for unsustainable stocks. Assets in sustainable investment strategies have risen to $30.7 trillion, with some funds starting to adopt long/short strategies.

site_title: PBOC cuts loan rate for first time since early 2016
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) cut its one-year medium-term lending facility (MLF) loans by 5 basis points to 3.25% for the first time since early 2016, signaling a proactive approach to support growth amid a slowing economy. The move may ease investor concerns about higher inflation preventing stimulus measures. Analysts expect a reduction in China's new benchmark Loan Prime Rate in a few weeks, which could pave the way for more targeted support from policymakers. The cut aims to reassure the market about the central bank's willingness to support growth.

site_title: Is blockchain for SMES?
summary: Singapore is driving mainstream adoption of blockchain technology, but small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) need to understand its benefits and risks before applying it. A poll found two-thirds of Asia-Pacific attendees lack a better understanding of blockchain. Blockchain can integrate end-to-end operations, eliminating intermediaries and driving efficiency. However, SMEs must consider the complexity of the platform, data rights, and privacy. They should ask five key questions to assess the technology's effectiveness and potential impact on their business.

site_title: Despite cyber threat, world is under-insured
summary: Lloyd's of London chief executive John Neal warns that the world is under-insured against cyber threats, with only $4 billion in global cyber insurance premiums collected, mostly in the US. Outside the US, almost no cyber insurance is bought, despite the significant risk and data involved. A report by the University of Cambridge Centre for Risk Studies estimates that up to $110 billion in economic loss could occur in Asia-Pacific ports due to cyber attacks, with only 7.5% of losses covered by insurance. Neal attributes the low take-up rate to a lack of understanding of cyber policies and the assumption that cyber risk is covered by traditional property and liability insurance.

site_title: China's drinkers love a fine wine. As long as it's not Chinese
summary: China's wine industry is seeking to improve its reputation with the production of high-quality, domestically-made wines. Despite its history of producing mediocre wines, China's young, middle-class drinkers are increasingly interested in quality wine, with demand projected to grow to $17.3 billion by 2021. European wine houses, such as Domaines Barons de Rothschild Lafite, are investing in Chinese vineyards, with the goal of transforming China's wine-growing regions into the next Napa Valley. However, Chinese consumers remain skeptical, and the industry faces an uphill battle in changing perceptions.

images.alt_text: As China celebrated the 70th birthday of the Communist Party with a parade in Beijing last month, alongside the obligatory displays of tanks and nuclear missiles was a showcase of its cultural treasures. Sandwiched between elaborate floats featuring giant pandas and dancing women in local costumes was an entry from the northern Ningxia province adorned with grapes and wine barrels - to represent the region's premium vineyards.

site_title: Oil gains 1% as China pushes Trump for more tariff rollbacks
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Tuesday, driven by hopes for a US-China trade agreement and optimism over potential tariff rollbacks. Brent crude futures rose 83 cents to $62.96 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 69 cents to $57.23 a barrel. China is pushing US President Trump to remove more tariffs imposed in September as part of a Phase 1 trade deal. The potential agreement would ease the economic impact of the trade dispute between the world's two biggest oil consumers.

site_title: Making the right choices for a new digital payments ecosystem
summary: Retailers and tech companies are pushing banks to create seamless digital payment experiences, citing success in South-east Asia where high mobile penetration and unbanked populations make it ideal for customer acquisition. Non-bank tech companies offer differentiated services with technological innovations, such as e-wallets and digital payment methods, in their proprietary ecosystems. This trend highlights the need for banks to innovate and simplify their services to compete.

site_title: Workspace for the modern workforce
summary: Companies must adapt to Industry 4.0 by embracing agility, efficiency, and flexibility to thrive. A results-oriented work environment prioritizes outcome over time spent, allowing workers to choose their workspace and work style. Well-designed offices can improve productivity and profitability, as seen at Google. Physical offices offer benefits such as creativity stimulation, individuality celebration, serendipity encouragement, and multifaceted spaces catering to different needs. Companies should adopt a forward-thinking mindset, incorporating features like indoor greenery, ergonomic furniture, and smart office technologies to create an empowering and productive work environment.

site_title: Incentives tied to axed Dyson electric car project will not be granted
summary: Dyson scrapped plans to build electric vehicles in Singapore, and as a result, government incentives tied to the project will not be granted. Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Chee Hong Tat stated that the incentives have not been given due to the project not taking place and investments not being made. Dyson will continue to operate in Singapore, focusing on its core business, including battery technology development and research and development in areas like sensors, robotics, and artificial intelligence.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Everbright Water is winding up its subsidiary, True Global Limited, as part of internal restructuring. Perennial Real Estate Holdings posted a net loss of S$9.9 million in the third quarter, despite a 74% revenue increase. Debao Property Development has recorded consecutive pre-tax losses and may be placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch-list. Bukit Sembawang Estates' net profit remained steady despite higher finance costs, with revenue and gross profit increasing 21%.

site_title: SIA's Q2 profit jumps 68% to S$94m on better showing by associates, JVs
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 68% jump in Q2 net profit to S$94 million, driven by better performances from associates and joint ventures. Higher net finance charges partially offset the gain, while operating performance across the group was mixed. SIA's parent airline firm and SilkAir's profitability remained largely unchanged, while SIA Engineering saw a 73% jump in operating profit. The group's revenue rose 5.3% to S$8.3 billion, with passenger revenue growing 7.5% and cargo revenue declining 16.3%. SIA declared an interim dividend of eight Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Sibor begins long-awaited slide; slips to 1.8% after hovering at 1.9-2% the past 10 months
summary: Singapore's key short-term interest rate, Sibor, has finally begun its long-awaited slide, dropping to 1.8% after the US Federal Reserve cut interest rates. The more reactive three-month SOR or Singapore swap offer rate has also tumbled to 1.46%. Experts attribute the rate cut to a weak US dollar and a perceived pause in the Fed's rate-cutting cycle. While Sibor has fallen, home buyers should not expect a significant decrease, as the rate remains high relative to other benchmarks. Experts predict further rate cuts in 2020, with forecasts ranging from 1.6% to 1.8% by the end of the year.

site_title: Alpha Energy off to brisk trot on Mustang's first oil
summary: Alpha Energy Holdings, a loss-making firm, has achieved a significant milestone with its core asset, the Mustang well in Alaska's North Slope, striking "first oil" in production and sales under an offtake pact with an oil major. This breakthrough is seen as a positive development for the company, providing a much-needed injection of revenue.

site_title: Fintech startup abandons plans to bid for Singapore digital banking licence
summary: Nium, a fintech startup, has withdrawn from the contest for a Singapore digital wholesale banking licence, choosing instead to focus on its global business-to-business payments platform. The company, backed by investors including Temasek Holdings, cited the entrenched nature of Singaporean banks as a reason for its decision. Nium will continue to serve businesses in over 40 markets and is seeking new electronic money institution licences in Mexico and Brazil.

site_title: In Internet of Things, think small to go big
summary: Developing countries can leverage the Internet of Things (IoT) to drive smart city initiatives without breaking the bank. Traditional IoT solutions often require high volumes of data transmission, which can be costly. However, smaller-scale IoT applications, such as tracking shipping containers or monitoring fire hydrants, can be more efficient and cost-effective. The 0G network technology, designed for low-bandwidth and low-power devices, offers a low-cost solution for IoT deployments. By segmenting business needs and using 0G networks, developing countries can access IoT-enabled insights and drive informed business decisions, despite limited infrastructure and budget constraints.

site_title: Cheddar cheese row chef named as an immortal of French cuisine
summary: French celebrity chef Marc Veyrat was named one of the 10 immortals of haute cuisine by the Gault & Millau guide. He was recognized alongside other French culinary legends for his contributions to the country's cuisine. Veyrat gained international attention for suing the Michelin guide over a soufflé recipe, which included cheddar cheese. The honor is part of the "Golden Toque" academy, a permanent recognition of culinary excellence. Veyrat's inclusion highlights his enduring influence on French cuisine.

site_title: China and US: Friends or foes?
summary: The US-China relationship is increasingly competitive and conflictual, with Americans becoming more pessimistic about the relationship. A Pew Research Center survey found that 60% of Americans hold unfavorable views of China, while 26% have favorable views. However, the relationship is not destined to become enemies, as both countries continue to admire and learn from each other. Despite structural conflicts and differences, the two countries are joined at the hip, with 17,000 people traveling between them daily. The US and China will continue to cooperate on various issues while competing at bilateral, regional, and global levels, with a majority of Americans (68%) supporting a policy of friendly cooperation and engagement.

site_title: StarHub gunning for 5G licence, cuts revenue outlook
summary: StarHub, a Singaporean telco, is considering a joint 5G bid with another mobile network operator, according to CEO Peter Kaliaropoulos. The company is also pushing into the enterprise market, identified as a growth area. StarHub has cut its revenue outlook, citing a challenging market environment. The move is part of the company's efforts to adapt to the changing telecommunications landscape and capitalize on emerging opportunities.

site_title: Swelling trade hopes lift Asian markets
summary: Asian markets ended higher on Tuesday, following a record-setting US session, as the US and China near a trade war truce. The "phase one" deal is expected to forestall December 15 tariffs, and the Trump administration may drop September-imposed tariffs. Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.38%, while Japan and South Korea also gained. Markets in Australia, New Zealand, China, Hong Kong, and Malaysia ended higher, following a 5-day rally.

site_title: From starting up to scaling up
summary: E-commerce platforms are powering the growth of small businesses in South-east Asia, with the market expected to hit US$150 billion by 2025. Small businesses can leverage on established platforms like Shopee and Amazon to tap into existing infrastructure, customer base, and AI technology, such as recommendation engines. Integrating entertainment and social engagement, like live streaming and augmented reality, can drive talkability and sales. E-commerce platforms are also providing training and upskilling programs to equip small businesses with the necessary know-how to stay relevant in the rapidly growing e-commerce industry.

site_title: Strategic thinking by shipping leaders
summary: Shipping industry executives gathered at the Global Maritime Forum's second Annual Summit in Singapore to discuss major challenges facing the industry, including zero emission fuels and decarbonisation. The industry is shifting towards accepting a carbon levy rather than emissions trading, with the International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) supporting a fuel levy per tonne of fuel. The ICS aims to accelerate research and development and ensure that support for this is at the heart of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) greenhouse gas strategy. The industry recognizes the need to improve efficiency and reduce waste through collaboration and data sharing.

site_title: Xi pledges wider market access, free-trade deals
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping pledged to further open China's economy, declaring the world must "knock down walls" and reduce trade barriers. In a speech at the Shanghai import exhibition, Xi urged the world to oppose protectionism and unilateralism, and to continue to reduce trade barriers. He also hinted at potential free-trade deals with other countries, including the EU and Japan, but did not provide specifics. The move is seen as an effort to address criticism that China's economy is too protected.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping (second from right) with his wife Peng Liyuan (right), French President Emmanuel Macron and his wife Brigitte after a state dinner at the Yu Garden in Shanghai.

site_title: Chicago ranked the greenest place to work in the US
summary: Chicago ranks as the greenest place to work in the US, with 71.1% of certified green office space, according to an annual ranking by CBRE Group and Maastricht University. The city aims to achieve 100% renewable energy in all city-run properties by 2025. This ranking surpasses cities like San Francisco and Atlanta, with 67.5% and 67.4% of green certified buildings, respectively. The trend towards sustainable office spaces is expected to continue, with cities aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and increase energy efficiency.
