site_title: US urged to invest more in AI; ex-Google CEO warns of China's progress
summary: The US government's funding for artificial intelligence (AI) has fallen short, and a government-commissioned panel led by Google's former CEO has urged the country to invest more in research, workforce development, and national security missions. The panel warned that China is investing more in AI and is making progress in face recognition surveillance and financial technology, but noted that the US is still ahead in original research. The commission recommended cooperation with China on promoting responsible AI use, while also addressing concerns about human rights and the potential for AI-powered surveillance.

images.alt_text: "China is ahead in two areas. One is in the face recognition surveillance area. And another one is in financial technology. This does not mean that they're ahead (in) AI overall," Eric Schmidt, the panel's chairman and one of several US tech industry executives on the commission, told reporters.

site_title: Boeing CEO's 737 Max testimony slammed by key lawmakers
summary: Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg's testimony on the 737 Max was criticized by key lawmakers, leaving "a lot of unanswered questions" in the ongoing congressional investigation. Representative Peter DeFazio and Representative Rick Larsen stated that Muilenburg's answers reflected a "culture of concealment and opaqueness" and immense pressure on Boeing employees during the jetliner's development. The investigation has a long way to go to provide the answers everyone deserves.

site_title: Oil rises on US-China hopes and improved outlook
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, driven by improved US jobs growth and market hopes for a preliminary US-China trade deal. Brent crude futures rose 44 cents to $62.13 a barrel, while US crude futures rose 34 cents to $56.54 a barrel. Market optimism propelled energy shares to record highs, with analysts citing better-than-expected economic data and the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut as contributing factors. A possible US-China trade deal and the weakening US dollar also lifted oil prices, with hedge funds rebuilding long positions in crude and fuels.

site_title: AA Reit DPU for Q2 flat at 2.5 S cents
summary: AIMS Apac Reit (AA Reit) reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.5 Singapore cents for its Q2, unchanged from the previous year. Gross revenue increased 4% to S$30.6 million, driven by rental contributions from its acquired property in Australia and higher recoveries from other properties.

site_title: OCBC Q3 profit dips 6% to S$1.17b on one-time charge
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 6% dip in net profit to S$1.17 billion for its third quarter, due to a one-time charge of S$91 million at its Indonesian banking unit. Excluding the charge, core net profit rose slightly to S$1.26 billion. Total income increased 4% to S$2.66 billion, with net interest income and non-interest income also rising. The bank's loan-to-deposit ratio decreased to 86.8%, while its non-performing loans ratio remained stable at 1.58%. OCBC's shares closed at S$11.07, up 0.5%.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, CapitaLand, AA Reit, China Everbright, Koufu, Challenger, POSH
summary: Singapore stocks to watch include OCBC, CapitaLand, AA Reit, China Everbright, Koufu, Challenger, and POSH. OCBC reported a 6% drop in net profit to S$1.17 billion due to a one-off charge, while CapitaLand's net profit dropped 7.8% to S$333.9 million. AA Reit maintained its distribution per unit at 2.5 cents, and Koufu posted a 52.3% increase in net earnings to S$7.1 million. Challenger's net profit dropped 5% to S$4.3 million, and POSH's shares rose 16.5% after a trading halt was lifted.

site_title: Lagarde stays tight-lipped in first ECB speech
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde delivered her first speech in Berlin, disappointing markets with a lack of hints on her monetary policy vision. She praised German parliamentary speaker Wolfgang Schaeuble for his role in steering the eurozone out of the sovereign debt crisis, calling for closer integration of the eurozone. Lagarde's speech was seen as a "roadmap for the ECB's monetary policy in the coming weeks" was not provided, instead focusing on laudatory remarks.

site_title: US: Stocks surge to records on optimism over trade
summary: US stocks surged to fresh records on Monday, with the Dow ending at an all-time high for the first time since July, driven by optimism over international trade talks and solid economic data. Analysts cited US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross's remarks that "phase one" of the US-China trade agreement was on track, and investors are heartened that the US and China have pulled back from new tariffs. The strong employment report and third-quarter earnings results also contributed to the positive momentum, with many investors feeling a "fear of missing out" on the rally.

site_title: Retirement Sum Scheme payouts capped at age 90
summary: The Retirement Sum Scheme (RSS) payouts in Singapore will be capped at age 90, down from 95, following feedback from members that the previous duration was too long. The change will allow for higher payouts for some, while no one will see their payouts reduced. Around 60,000 older members will see payouts increase as a result. The changes also include introducing a Contribute-as-you-Earn (CAYE) scheme for self-employed persons providing services directly to the government.

site_title: CapitaLand Q3 earnings drop 7.8% to S$333.9m
summary: CapitaLand, a major Asian real estate company, reported a 7.8% drop in its third-quarter net profit to S$333.9 million, mainly due to lower portfolio gains. Revenue jumped 37.1% to S$1.73 billion, driven by contributions from China development projects, Ascendas-Singbridge, and multifamily projects in the US. The completion of Ascendas-Singbridge's acquisition on June 28 contributed significantly to the group's earnings. CapitaLand's group CEO, Lee Chee Koon, attributed the boost to asset recycling and the first full-quarter contribution from Ascendas-Singbridge.

site_title: Impeaching Trump won't change anything
summary: US President Donald Trump was humiliated at the Washington Nationals' World Series victory, where he was not invited to throw the ceremonial first pitch and instead sat in the less prestigious executive suite. The crowd jeered and chanted "Lock him up!" as Trump's campaign ad flashed on the screen. This event coincided with the historic vote by the US House of Representatives to endorse the Democratic-led impeachment inquiry, which was sparked by revelations of Trump's pressure on Ukraine to investigate a political rival. The event highlights the deepening divide between Trump's supporters and the anti-Trump Resistance in Washington, DC.

site_title: Banking on golf to boost charity and image
summary: Banks in Singapore, including DBS and Citibank, are using golf as a platform to raise funds for charity and enhance their image. Since 2005, DBS has sponsored the Singapore Open, while Citibank stages annual events like the Citi Golf Day and Citi Information Technology and Partners Charity Golf Day. These events aim to support financially disadvantaged youth and raise funds for various charities. Meanwhile, Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation sponsors the HSBC Women's World Championship.

site_title: Europe: Trade optimism propels shares to near 2-year highs
summary: European shares reached near two-year highs on Monday, driven by optimism over trade talks and strong earnings reports. The Stoxx 600 index rose 1% to its highest level since January 2018, with tariff-exposed miners and auto makers leading the gains. US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross hinted at a possible delay in fresh tariffs on European goods, boosting investor confidence. Additionally, a strong earnings report from Ryanair lifted Irish stocks to a one-year high, while a looming decision on US tariffs on European goods is expected to shape market sentiment.

site_title: EU foe Farage takes Brexit poll challenge to Johnson
summary: Nigel Farage, leader of the Brexit Party, announced plans to field hardline Brexit candidates across Britain in the upcoming election, despite fears it could deny Prime Minister Boris Johnson a majority. Farage, who has called Johnson's Brexit deal a "sellout," is seeking a "non-aggression pact" with the Conservatives, but Johnson has ruled out a collaboration. Farage's party is expected to target pro-Brexit voters who traditionally support Labour, but analysts doubt they will win more than a handful of seats.

site_title: US accuses Beijing of 'intimidation' in South China Sea
summary: The US has accused China of "intimidation" in the South China Sea, with US National Security Adviser Robert O'Brien saying Beijing has used intimidation to stop Southeast Asian nations from exploiting their offshore resources. The US has also released a report criticizing China's basis for its claims in the region, known as the "nine-dash line," calling it "unfounded, unlawful and unreasonable." China has responded by accusing the US of meddling in the region, with its deputy foreign minister saying some countries "cannot live with calm waters" in the South China Sea.

site_title: Euro dips before Lagarde speaks
summary: The euro decreased on Monday as investors awaited European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde's first speech, but remained near its highest level in weeks due to hopes the US may not impose tariffs on auto imports. Markets expect Lagarde to maintain the ECB's easy policy stance, following her predecessor Mario Draghi's approach.

site_title: Drones used in crime fly under the law's radar
summary: In Washington Township, Pennsylvania, a series of explosions occurred in a suburban neighborhood, with homemade bombs and nails raining down from the sky. The police were baffled, unable to identify the bomber or find any physical evidence. The mystery remained unsolved.

site_title: RCEP conclusion without India still a 'major step forward': PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed hope that India will join the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) despite being the sole holdout, calling the remaining 15 countries' agreement a "major step forward." Lee stated that India's concerns, which include not achieving the prime minister's objectives, will take time to overcome. However, he remains optimistic that India could still be part of the RCEP when it signs the pact next year.

site_title: Money FM podcast: LeftRight CEO on their social initiatives
summary: LeftRight CEO discusses their social initiatives on the Money FM podcast. No specific details on the initiatives are mentioned in the provided articles. However, LeftRight has been involved in various projects, including Thevar 2.0, a mod-Indian cuisine show, and The Social Kitchen, a community kitchen at Bank of Singapore. The company has also partnered with organizations such as CMC Markets and Sophia Women to drive financial literacy and community engagement.

site_title: HK's property demand remains strong despite protests
summary: Hong Kong's property demand remains strong despite ongoing protests, with over 75% of units sold in a weekend sales event. The city's real estate sector shows resilience, despite the economy entering recession. Analysts predict home prices will rise due to policy changes, including increased borrowing limits, which could unleash pent-up demand. However, rising prices will be a concern for Hong Kong's younger generation, many of whom struggle to afford homes.

site_title: 'Silicon Saxony' stands on East Germany foundations
summary: Silicon Saxony, a state-backed initiative in East Germany, has fostered the growth of the microelectronics industry. In the late 1990s, AMD sent 200 local engineers to its Texas factory for training, where they quickly surpassed their counterparts in explaining chip innards. This initiative has contributed to the development of the industry, with companies like Globalfoundries now operating in the region. The success of Silicon Saxony highlights the potential of investing in local expertise and research, leading to significant economic growth and industry development.

site_title: Compulsory registration for drones from Jan 2 next year
summary: Singapore will require compulsory registration for drones weighing more than 250g starting January 2, 2020, under the Air Navigation (Amendment) Bill passed by Parliament. Penalties for drone-related offenses will also increase. This move aims to enhance safety and regulation in the use of unmanned aircraft in the country.

site_title: Terminator tops Joker in battle for box office supremacy
summary: The Terminator: Dark Fate opened with an estimated US$29 million at the North American box office, but fell short of expectations due to a high production cost of US$185 million. The film was outranked by Joker, which took in US$13.9 million for its fifth week, and Disney's Maleficent: Mistress of Evil, which earned US$12.2 million. New biopic Harriet also surprised analysts with a fourth-place finish, earning US$12 million.

site_title: Startups in a jam as brakes pulled on e-scooters
summary: Singapore has banned e-scooters from footpaths, restricting their use to cycling paths, amid concerns over safety following high-profile accidents. The ban will impact startups and businesses relying on e-scooters for operations, with food delivery firms, such as Grab and Deliveroo, expected to feel the hardest hit. Some startups, like Anywheel, are shifting their focus to other markets, while Grab plans to propose alternative conditions for responsible e-scooter riders to continue using the service. The ban is seen as a significant setback for the sharing economy in Singapore.

site_title: As a private company, FEO has more options for Chancery Court
summary: Far East Organization (FEO), a private company, has decided not to redevelop its Chancery Court site in Singapore's District 11 for the time being. Instead, the company plans to renovate the existing development and rent out the units, a highly unusual approach for a Singapore residential developer. FEO, led by Philip Ng, has more leeway to take a longer-term approach due to its private status. The decision comes after the group paid additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) on the site purchase and is not subject to any deadlines on completion or sales.

site_title: Perils of a new East-West crisis in Europe
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo addresses a major event commemorating the 30th anniversary of the Berlin Wall, highlighting the post-1989 ambition of ex-Communist nations to emulate the West, which has failed due to rising economic inequality and corruption. This has led to the growth of authoritarian anti-liberalism across Eastern and Central Europe, as liberalism is tarnished in the West by events like the 2008 financial crash, Brexit, and Donald Trump's election. The US and Europe are facing a potential "East-West rift" as the promises of Western liberalism to transform the former Eastern bloc have fallen flat.

site_title: SPH prices new perpetual at 4%
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) launched a new perpetual bond issue priced at 4% on Monday, with an order book exceeding S$600 million. The issue size was capped at S$300 million. The bond may be called after 5.5 years, and if not, the distribution rate will be reset based on the prevailing Singapore dollar five-year swap offer rate. SPH had previously priced a S$150 million 4.5% perpetual in May and a S$300 million 4.1% perpetual in August, both of which were oversubscribed.

site_title: Malaysia says country shielding 1MDB fugitive Jho Low refuses to cooperate
summary: Malaysia's police chief stated that fugitive Jho Low, wanted for a multibillion-dollar 1MDB scandal, is living in a country that refuses to cooperate on his extradition. Low has been charged in Malaysia and the US over the alleged theft of $4.5 billion from 1MDB, set up by former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak. Low's whereabouts are unknown, and the Malaysian government is seeking his cooperation to retrieve him.

site_title: Growing for good: Sustaining a volunteer culture
summary: Keppel Corporation and Carousell prioritize corporate social responsibility, integrating employees in their giving efforts. Keppel has a presence in various sectors and has been active in corporate giving for decades, committing up to 1% of annual net profits to worthy causes. The company's CSR projects extend globally, supporting localised programmes in China, the Philippines, and Vietnam. Meanwhile, Carousell has a culture of social responsibility, incorporating CSR practices into its business model, and has launched initiatives like the #Blessings Movement to encourage users to donate items to those in need.

site_title: Kuok Group makes offer for PACC Offshore at S$0.215 per share in cash
summary: Kuok Group has made a voluntary conditional cash offer to acquire PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) at S$0.215 per share, representing a 97.2% premium over the last traded price. The offeror has secured irrevocable undertakings from 75.03% of outstanding shares and is seeking 90% valid acceptances. POSH has reported wider losses and revenue decline due to challenges in the global offshore oil and gas sector, and the offeror believes privatising the company will provide more flexibility in managing its operational and funding requirements.

site_title: The monetarist era is over
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has concluded that the monetarist era is over, marking a shift towards Keynesian demand management. Despite a projected global growth rate of 3% for 2020, the IMF warns that the current benign economic conditions will deteriorate at some point. Central bankers now recognize the limitations of monetary policy, with many advocating for a more balanced policy mix that includes expansionary fiscal policy. This marks a significant paradigm shift, with many politicians and economists still clinging to outdated monetarist ideology, despite empirical evidence refuting its core tenets.

site_title: HK Exchange Fund's Q3 investment income drops; refutes talk of capital control
summary: The Hong Kong Exchange Fund reported a 55% drop in investment income to HK$20.2 billion in the third quarter, compared to the previous quarter and a year earlier. Despite the decline, the fund's overall investment income reached HK$198.6 billion for the first nine months of the year. HKMA chief executive Eddie Yue assured that the Hong Kong dollar's stability and the Linked Exchange Rate System would not change, and that there would be no capital and foreign exchange control implemented. The decline in investment income came amid Hong Kong's recession and pro-democracy protests.

site_title: 15 Asian countries agree to terms of RCEP free trade deal
summary: Fifteen Asian countries, including China, Japan, South Korea, and Australia, have agreed on the terms of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) free trade deal, concluding negotiations on all 20 chapters and market access issues. However, India has delayed its decision due to significant differences over tariffs and other issues, with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi stating that the current form of the agreement does not fully reflect the basic spirit and guiding principles of RCEP. The deal, which would account for a third of global GDP, is seen as a major step forward despite India's withdrawal.

site_title: Manulife US Reit posts 2% fall in Q3 DPU on enlarged unit base
summary: Manulife US Reit posted a 2% decline in Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.48 US cents, mainly due to an enlarged unit base following a placement and preferential offering to fund its US$198.8 million Sacramento acquisition. Gross revenue rose 13.3% to US$45.7 million, and net property income climbed 11.8% to US$28.1 million, driven by acquisitions in Virginia and Washington DC. The Reit's asset under management increased 20.4% year-over-year to US$2.1 billion.

site_title: Deutsche Bank chiefs urge CEO to cut responsibilities
summary: Deutsche Bank's top supervisors have urged CEO Christian Sewing to transfer investment bank oversight to someone else, allowing him to focus on his main role. The European Central Bank and Germany's BaFin raised the issue in informal talks, suggesting a possible handover next year. The lender has recently appointed Fabrizio Campelli as chief transformation officer to ease Sewing's workload, which was added after the ouster of Garth Ritchie in July. The regulators are not pushing for immediate change, and the bank has denied any plans to change management board responsibility.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust units hit fresh low as investors take flight
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) units plummeted by 11% to a fresh low of US$0.475 after investors expressed concerns over the Reit sponsor's past transactions and the value of its second-largest asset, the Queen Mary. The trust revealed that three substantial shareholders, including ASAP Holdings' Jerome Yuan, had undisclosed involvement in the IPO prospectus. The market is also concerned about Urban Commons' financial resources and the counterparty risk associated with the master lease agreements, which form the basis for EHT's valuations.

site_title: Sanguine markets ignore UK election risks but sentiment still highly fraught
summary: The UK's stock market and British pound have held firm, with investors betting on a Conservative victory in the upcoming general election, which is seen as business-friendly. However, polls indicate a narrow lead for the Conservatives, and experts warn of electoral shocks and voter volatility, particularly with the rise of the Brexit Party, which could split the vote and potentially harm the Tories. The Brexit Party leader, Nigel Farage, has been courting US President Donald Trump, who has expressed skepticism about the UK's Brexit deal, adding to the uncertainty surrounding the election outcome.

site_title: Australia's Westpac raising A$2.5b as profit slumps
summary: Westpac Banking Corp plans to raise A$2.5 billion from shareholders after reporting a 15% decline in full-year cash earnings and cutting its dividend for the first time in a decade. The bank aims to meet tougher capital requirements and anticipated legal action related to customer remediation issues. Westpac's operating conditions are expected to remain difficult, with weaker margins, flat lending volumes, and higher expenses. The capital raising is the largest by a bank since 2015 and will provide flexibility amid a subdued economic outlook.

site_title: Is now the right time for Singapore companies to expand abroad?
summary: Singapore companies are considering expanding abroad due to economic headwinds and global protectionism. A HSBC Navigator survey found 65% of Singapore businesses expect sales growth in the next 12 months, lower than global and Asia-Pacific counterparts. However, the survey also identified opportunities in Southeast Asia, particularly in Thailand, Vietnam, and Indonesia, with 81% of Asean firms projecting growth. Key macro trends driving opportunities include services, manufacturing, digital economy, and renewable energy. Companies should consider well-considered risk management strategies, including technology-enabled entry, to navigate the challenges of cross-border expansion.

site_title: No valuation done in disposal of UEL and WBL shares: Perennial
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings disposed of its stake in United Engineers Limited (UEL) and WBL Corporation for S$202 million, with no valuation conducted. The disposal price of S$2.60 per UEL share is 1.3% higher than the one-month preceding price, while there is no available market price for WBL shares due to its delisting in 2014. Perennial attributed the consideration to investment costs, cash, and liabilities. The divestment aims to alleviate debt and liquidity concerns, with analysts expecting it to help Perennial pare debt.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CHALLENGER Technologies posted a 5% drop in its third-quarter net profit to S$4.3 million due to flat revenue and increased staff costs. ABR Holdings subsidiary ABR Swensen's renewed its Swensen's franchise licence for 20 years. China Everbright Water secured two PPP projects, the Ji'nan Tangye New Area Waste Water Treatment and Zibo Northern Waste Water Treatment Plant Expansion Projects, with total investments of about S$76.3 million.

site_title: To build or buy? Investors eye hospitality assets as tourism, scarce supply prop up sector
summary: Investors in Singapore's hospitality sector are prioritizing development sites over existing hotels, driven by rising tourist arrivals and limited supply, resulting in S$4.2 billion in transactions in the first nine months of the year. High sale prices and asking prices for development sites, such as S$188 million for Katong Plaza, are attracting buyers, with Colliers International executive director Govinda Singh stating that building on a development site delivers a higher return.

site_title: 2 Leng Kee showrooms up for sale at guide prices of S$15m, S$23m
summary: Two industrial properties in Singapore's Leng Kee Road are up for sale via expression of interest, with guide prices of S$15 million and S$23 million. The properties, located along the car showroom belt, have a total of 3,204 sq m of floor area and 2,804 sq m of land area. The sale marks an opportunity for industrial users, particularly those in the automobile industry, to own a corporate building with a ready pool of labor. The expression of interest closes on December 3, 3pm.

site_title: Riverside Piazza up for en bloc sale with S$198m reserve price
summary: The Riverside Piazza in Singapore is up for collective sale via tender at a reserve price of S$198 million, with a land rate of S$2,606 psf ppr. The 64-unit development comprises 40 apartments and 24 commercial shops, with owners potentially receiving between S$2.23 million and S$9.47 million upon completion of the sale.

site_title: Delhi banishes some cars in hope of clearing the air
summary: New Delhi has implemented an "odd-even" system, banning cars with odd-numbered licence plates from the roads until Nov 15 to combat hazardous air pollution. The move follows a public health emergency declaration, with air quality index exceeding 500, indicating serious risks to heart and lung disease. Morning traffic was thin, with drivers obeying the rule. Ride-hailing services are exempt, and schools and construction work have been ordered to shut. Authorities aim to cut emissions, which contribute over 50% of Delhi's air pollution.

site_title: Koufu Q3 net earnings surge 52% on rising revenue
summary: Koufu, a Singapore-based food court and coffee shop operator, reported a 52.3% increase in net earnings to S$7.1 million for the third quarter, driven by a 6.6% increase in revenue to S$61.4 million. The company attributed the growth to new food courts and coffee shops, as well as higher revenue from existing outlets. Koufu plans to expand its F&B network and has secured new locations in Malaysia and Indonesia. The company's cash and cash equivalents stood at S$93.5 million as of September 30.

site_title: Thailand's Central Group plans to invest 20b baht overseas
summary: Thailand's Central Group plans to invest 20 billion baht (S$898.3 million) in projects in Vienna, Osaka, and Turin, capitalizing on the country's strong local currency. The investment is partly attributed to the strengthened baht, which has outperformed most major currencies.

site_title: US officials take hard stance against China's Belt and Road Initiative
summary: US officials have taken a hard stance against China's Belt and Road Initiative, warning it may isolate countries with resources of interest to China and undermine national sovereignty. Deputy Administrator Bonnie Glick described the initiative as a "debt trap" that specifically targets countries with valuable resources. This warning comes amid concerns over China's growing economic influence and debt accumulation.

site_title: Trade deal hopes boost Asian markets
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, boosted by optimism over a US-China trade deal, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing 0.22% higher at 3,236.40. Other regional markets, including Hong Kong, South Korea, and China, also gained ground. Agriculture plays and property developers were among the top performers on the STI. The gains were largely driven by positive comments from US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross on the trade deal, which lifted sentiment and lifted markets.

site_title: E-scooters banned from Singapore footpaths in addition to roads
summary: Singapore has banned e-scooters from footpaths, effective November 5, to address public safety concerns. Errant riders can be fined up to S$2,000 and/or jailed for up to 3 months if convicted. This measure follows previous restrictions on e-scooters on roads.

site_title: CPF Retirement Sum Scheme to be capped at age 90 for higher payouts
summary: Singapore's CPF Retirement Sum Scheme will be capped at age 90, down from 95, allowing for higher payouts for some members. The change, effective for those turning 65 from July 1, 2020, will use extra interest to increase payouts and extend duration. The move follows feedback and a review of the scheme, with no one's payouts expected to be reduced. The change will benefit around 60,000 older members, with some seeing increased payouts and a shorter duration.

site_title: Johnson's Conservatives have 7-point lead over Labour
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Conservatives have a 7-point lead over Labour ahead of the Dec 12 election, according to an ICM poll. The Conservatives are at 38% support, while Labour is at 31%, with the Liberal Democrats at 15% and the Brexit Party at 9%. This narrower gap compared to recent surveys suggests a possible shift in voter sentiment.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Conservatives have a seven percentage-point lead over the opposition Labour Party ahead of a Dec 12 election, according to an ICM poll published by Reuters on Monday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Time for vision and reform in official ranks
summary: China's Central Committee has pledged to improve Hong Kong's legal system and enforcement mechanism for safeguarding national security, but the move appears to be aimed at tightening Beijing's control over the former British colony. The "one country, two systems" model, which has governed Hong Kong since its handover from Britain in 1997, is expected to remain in place. However, the central government wants to exercise "full administrative power" over Hong Kong and extend patriotic education to government officials, sparking concerns about the erosion of autonomy.

site_title: Investors still in the dark over sale, valuation of Saudi Aramco blockbuster IPO
summary: Saudi Aramco's highly anticipated IPO remains shrouded in mystery, with investors uncertain about the sale's valuation and details. The state oil giant is reportedly considering offering 1-2% of its shares, potentially raising $20 billion to $40 billion. Analysts' valuations vary widely, ranging from $1.2 trillion to $2.3 trillion, with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman aiming for a $2 trillion valuation to diversify the Saudi economy. The IPO's pricing is expected to be announced around November 28, with the company's management to participate in investor meetings and roadshows in various locations.

site_title: Merkel cheers on VW's electric push as climate critique grows
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel visited a revamped Volkswagen AG electric-car plant in Zwickau, marking the production start of the ID.3, VW's first mass-market electric vehicle. The factory, which will produce up to 330,000 cars per year, is part of VW's effort to shift away from combustion engines and meet growing climate demands. Merkel's visit comes amid criticism of her government's slow progress on curbing greenhouse gas emissions, while VW boss Herbert Diess faces pressure to manage the expensive shift to electric vehicles.

site_title: OCBC to enter digital banking fray with Keppel, Vertex-backed Validus
summary: OCBC, Singapore's second-largest bank, is in talks with Keppel Corporation, Validus Capital, and Vertex Ventures to form a digital-bank consortium, aiming to secure one of the three wholesale digital banking licenses offered by the Singapore regulator. OCBC is expected to take an equity stake in the consortium, rather than offering direct lending. The move is seen as a strategic move to expand its presence in the small-and-medium enterprise (SME) lending segment and compete with its own digital entity.

site_title: Cebu Pacific places US$4.8b Airbus order
summary: Cebu Pacific, the Philippines' largest budget airline, has ordered 16 Airbus planes worth US$4.8 billion to expand its carrying capacity with larger, more fuel-efficient jets. The airline aims to lower per-seat costs and maximize existing airport slots. The new planes will be used for domestic routes, Asian destinations, and long-haul flights to Australia and the Middle East, where millions of Filipinos work overseas. This order is part of Cebu Pacific's strategy to increase its presence in the Asian market and improve its competitiveness.

site_title: Nordea Bank culls securities from market unit amid negative rates
summary: Nordea Bank, the largest bank in the Nordic region, is rethinking its market making service due to long-term negative interest rates. The bank will cull its inventory of securities and become more selective about holding products, aiming to free up capital for more profitable areas. This move comes as the bank struggles to steady itself after years of faltering profits and faces higher capital demands. The bank's head of wholesale banking, Martin Persson, says the goal is to adapt to the changing market environment and reduce the "buy-and-hold culture" that has become too costly.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC appointed Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, as its new CEO. MAS and PBOC are to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, and Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of lower-than-target H2 revenue and similar operating losses. OCBC announced its new CEO, Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. Singapore stocks rose for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data, while the US stock market opened lower following Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada.

site_title: Cairo delights at sweet candies as Muslim festival nears
summary: Cairo is preparing for the Muslim festival of "Al Mawlid Al Nabawi", celebrating the birthday of Prophet Mohammed, on November 9. The historic Bab al-Bahr street in Islamic Cairo is adorned with decorated sugar dolls, horse-shaped candies, and nut-filled treats. Egyptian dessert makers are preparing traditional sweets made from peanuts, sesame seeds, coconuts, and pistachios, which are available to both the poor and the rich. The festival has its roots in Egypt's Fatimid dynasty, which dates back over 1,000 years.

site_title: Emerging Asia's favoured South Korean bonds performed the worst in October
summary: South Korean government bonds experienced their worst monthly performance in November 2016, losing 2.1% in October, according to a Bloomberg Barclays index. This decline is attributed to easing external uncertainties and lower expectations for central bank easing, as well as increased concerns over government debt issuance. Foreign investors poured over $41 billion into Korean bonds this year, but signs of economic recovery and potential record debt sales led to a sell-off. The yield of 10-year Korean debt rose to 1.73%, with some analysts predicting it could break into a range between 2.5% and 3% if US-China trade talks progress.

site_title: Top lawyer declines to testify in impeachment inquiry
summary: Top lawyer John Eisenberg, a key figure in handling fallout from President Donald Trump's July call with Ukraine, declined to testify in an impeachment inquiry. Eisenberg's decision comes after the White House claimed he would invoke "constitutional immunity" and block his testimony. The move heightens the importance of a pending lawsuit filed by Trump's former deputy national security adviser, Charles Kupperman, who also faces a similar subpoena and Trump's instruction not to comply. The outcome of the lawsuit could have implications for other highly sought-after witnesses, including former national security adviser John Bolton.

site_title: UAE announces major new oil, gas discoveries
summary: The United Arab Emirates announced significant oil and gas discoveries, including 7 billion barrels of crude oil and 58 trillion cubic feet of natural gas, raising its crude oil reserves to 105 billion barrels. This overtook Kuwait's reserves, making the UAE the world's sixth-largest oil deposit holder. The new discoveries were made by the Supreme Petroleum Council, and a new pricing mechanism for Abu Dhabi's flagship Murban crude was also launched.

site_title: Podcast: SFF x Switch 2019 Ep 1: How Singapore blazed a trail in fintech
summary: Singapore's fintech scene is thriving, with the city-state creating 1,000 jobs annually and reaching a billion-dollar funding mark. In an interview, Monetary Authority of Singapore's managing director Ravi Menon highlights the importance of technology and innovation in Singapore's fintech ecosystem. The Singapore Fintech Festival x Singapore Week of Innovation and Technology will run from November 11-15, with plans to enable consumers to aggregate and share financial data next year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 10.22 points to 1,603.56. The index saw 452 gainers versus 360 losers, with a total trading volume of 2.6 billion lots worth RM1.9 billion.

site_title: Barclays faces SEC probe into sales of property-backed bonds
summary: US regulators are investigating Barclays Plc over its marketing practices for property-backed bonds, following a complaint from a former trader who alleged the bank engaged in securities fraud. The probe, which began in September 2018, is preliminary and may not lead to allegations of wrongdoing. Barclays has previously faced scrutiny over bond sales, including a $2 billion settlement with the Justice Department. The investigation is centered around a deal for bonds backed by hotels, which the former trader claimed was aggressively marketed and ignored basic risk management practices.

site_title: Challenger Tech posts 5% drop in Q3 net profit on flat revenue
summary: Challenger Technologies reported a 5% drop in Q3 net profit to S$4.3 million, driven by flat revenue of S$83.3 million. The slight revenue increase was attributed to improved performance from its IT products and services segment, but was partially offset by increased staff costs, higher rentals, and other expenses. The company plans to grow its footprint in Singapore and expand its "PIT.Money" concept store to tap into the pre-owned and demo IT products market.

site_title: Kuok Group makes offer for POSH at S$0.215 per share in cash
summary: Kuok Group's subsidiary, Quetzal Capital, has made a voluntary conditional cash offer for Pacc Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) at S$0.215 per share. The bid is part of the Kuok Group's diversified investments, which include commodities, hospitality, logistics, and shipping businesses. The offer is subject to certain conditions and is expected to be reviewed by relevant parties.

site_title: China Everbright inks 2 water treatment projects worth 396m yuan
summary: China Everbright Water has signed two water treatment projects in Shandong province worth approximately 396 million yuan. The projects include the Ji'nan Tangye New Area Waste Water Treatment PPP project and the Zibo Northern Waste Water Treatment Plant Expansion Project. The total designed daily wastewater treatment capacity for the projects is 65,000 cubic meters. The projects will be built and operated over a 30-year concession period, with Everbright Water holding a 99.9% stake in the project companies.

site_title: Singapore businesses far less upbeat compared with rest of Asean: survey
summary: Singapore businesses are less confident about their growth prospects compared to the rest of ASEAN, with only 65% expecting sales to grow in the next 12 months, lower than the 81% average for the region. The country's small, open economy makes it more vulnerable to global external factors and trade protectionism. Only 37% of Singapore respondents feel they gain more than they lose from protectionism, and 40% are pessimistic about their growth prospects, double the global average. Despite this, businesses are more optimistic about a trade resurgence over the medium term, particularly in the Asia-Pacific and ASEAN regions.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% higher on trade deal optimism
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.22% on Monday, following positive comments on a US-China trade deal, lifting market sentiment. US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross stated progress on the deal, and Asian markets, including Hong Kong and South Korea, also gained. Gainers outnumbered losers 240 to 175, with agriculture and property developers performing well. Rex International and Alpha Energy Holdings were the top gainers, while Pan Asian Holdings and Citic Envirotech called for trading halts.

site_title: US: Wall St opens at record high on US-China trade deal hopes
summary: Wall Street's three main indexes opened at record highs on Monday, driven by optimism over a US-China trade deal and an improving domestic economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 54.70 points, or 0.20%, to 27,402.06, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 12.05 and 59.11 points, respectively, at 3,078.96 and 8,445.50. This surge follows recent positive developments, including a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record-breaking Nasdaq Composite.

site_title: Apple pledges US$2.5b for affordable California housing
summary: Apple has pledged US$2.5 billion to help alleviate California's housing crisis, joining Facebook and Google in their efforts to combat skyrocketing housing costs in the Bay Area. The growth of tech companies like Apple has contributed to an imbalanced housing environment, leaving poor and middle-income residents with limited options. New housing hasn't kept up with demand, and the tech firms' deep pockets have driven up home prices, further pushing low-income residents out of the area.

images.alt_text: With the pledge Monday, the Cupertino, California-based iPhone maker follows Facebook Inc and Google, which have each committed US$1 billion to combat skyrocketing housing costs in the Bay Area.

site_title: Singapore factory outlook stays glum in October despite PMI edging up
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector remains in contraction, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) edging up to 49.6 in October, its sixth straight month in contractionary territory. Factory output returned to expansion, while inventory and employment saw faster growth. However, new orders and exports contracted, suggesting a slow recovery. Experts expect a negative manufacturing growth for the fourth straight quarter, with global trade uncertainties remaining a wildcard.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: 15 Asian countries agree to RCEP
summary: Fifteen Asian countries, including China, Japan, South Korea, and Australia, have agreed to terms for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), potentially the world's largest trade pact. India has delayed its decision due to significant differences over tariffs and other issues, citing concerns over the impact on local producers. The agreement aims to eliminate tariffs and promote market access, but India's final decision will depend on satisfactory resolution of its outstanding issues. The US-China trade war has driven the discussions, with India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi stating the current form of the agreement does not address its concerns.

site_title: Malaysia says country shielding 1MDB fugitive Jho Low refuses to cooperate
summary: Malaysian fugitive Jho Low, wanted for a multibillion-dollar scandal at state fund 1MDB, is living in a country that has refused to cooperate on efforts to retrieve him. Low, who has denied wrongdoing, has been offered asylum in an unidentified country, but Malaysian officials claim he is immune under the protection of the nation's authorities. The US Justice Department has struck a deal to recover $1 billion in funds allegedly looted from 1MDB, and Malaysia is seeking compensation from Goldman Sachs over the scandal.

site_title: UK construction slide barely slows in October - PMI
summary: UK construction activity shrank for the sixth consecutive month in October, with a PMI reading of 44.2, the third-lowest since 2009. Brexit worries and economic slowdown held back growth, with new work orders falling for the seventh straight month. Construction output rose 2.4% in the 12 months to August, but smaller housebuilders reported the weakest demand since 2013. The industry is positioning for an extended soft patch, with declines in purchasing volumes and workforce numbers.

site_title: Argentina's banks cut trading desk jobs after market plunge
summary: Argentina's banks have cut trading desk jobs due to the market plunge following the August primary election, which saw opposition leader Alberto Fernandez win with a wider margin than expected. The benchmark S&P Merval index almost halved in dollar terms, while bond spreads tripled. The moves come as foreign institutional investors shy away from local assets due to Argentina's high political risk. Since the currency crisis began in 2018, the financial system has shrunk by 2.4% or 2,500 jobs.

site_title: OCBC in talks with Keppel and Validus to form digital-bank consortium
summary: OCBC Bank is in talks with Keppel Corporation, Validus Capital, and Vertex Ventures to form a digital-bank consortium and apply for a digital wholesale banking licence in Singapore. OCBC is expected to take an equity stake and bolster its position in the small- and medium-enterprise (SME) lending space. The move could face competition from OCBC's virtual entity, but the bank's chief operating officer believes it can also compete. Applications for digital-banking licences must be submitted by the end of 2019.

site_title: Norway should tax salmon farming harder, says commission
summary: A Norwegian government-appointed commission recommends introducing a 40% natural-resource tax on salmon farming, which could generate around $1.04 billion in annual tax revenue. The tax would apply to farmers' profits, with the goal of increasing the state's share of the industry's profits. However, the proposal has faced opposition from most government parties, and its implementation is uncertain. This move could have a significant impact on the salmon farming industry, with major companies like Mowi ASA experiencing a decline in stock prices.

site_title: Mothercare files notice of intent to appoint administrators to UK business
summary: Mothercare, a UK-based baby products retailer, has filed a notice of intent to appoint administrators to its loss-making British business, putting hundreds of jobs at risk. The company blames intense competition from supermarkets and online retailers, as well as rising costs, for its struggles. The move gives the company protection from creditors for ten days before potentially entering administration. Mothercare's other subsidiaries are not affected and will continue to trade normally.

site_title: Microsoft rolls out new cloud tool for analysing business data
summary: Microsoft has unveiled the Azure Synapse system, a new cloud tool to help large businesses analyze their vast amounts of corporate data. The system aims to bridge the gap between old and new data systems, automating tasks and reducing work for programmers. It will allow companies to analyze data from various sources, such as customer databases and website monitoring tools, and make data-driven business decisions. Initial customers include Deutsch Bank and Unilever, with projects completing in a day instead of months, according to Microsoft corporate vice president Rohan Kumar.

site_title: Koufu Q3 net profit surges 52% on rise in revenue contribution
summary: Koufu, a food court and coffeeshop operator, reported a 52.3% increase in net earnings to S$7.1 million in its third quarter, driven by a 6.6% rise in revenue to S$61.4 million. Revenue from the outlet and mall management segment rose 6.2% due to new food courts and higher growth from existing outlets. The company plans to expand its F&B network and has secured new locations in Malaysia and Indonesia. As of September 30, Koufu had S$93.5 million in cash and cash equivalents.

site_title: Shoprite defies South African downturn as domestic sales surge
summary: Shoprite Holdings Ltd reported improved trading in its South African stores, with local supermarket sales rising 10% in the third quarter, compared to 1.7% a year ago. The company attributes the growth to an IT-system revamp and store openings. However, operations in the rest of Africa struggled, with sales falling 4.9% due to xenophobic attacks on stores in Nigeria. The company is assessing its performance and return on capital invested across the continent. Shoprite's Chairman Christo Wiese faces pressure from investors, with a shareholder proposal to replace him.

site_title: UK shale gas explorers' shares fall on fracking moratorium
summary: The UK government has imposed a moratorium on fracking due to concerns over local community disruption from earth tremors. Shares in shale gas explorers IGas and Egdon Resources fell 20% and 14% respectively. Cuadrilla, a leading shale gas explorer, was not available for comment. The moratorium comes as the UK aims to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. IGas estimates its gas reserves could satisfy the UK's gas demand for up to 19 years.

site_title: Govt pilots Contribute-as-you-Earn scheme for public sector's service providers
summary: The Singapore government has introduced a pilot "Contribute-as-you-Earn" (CAYE) scheme for self-employed persons (SEPs) who provide services directly to the public sector. Under the scheme, SEPs will have their Medisave contributions transferred by the government as they earn income, rather than making annual contributions. This aims to help SEPs "keep up with their Medisave contributions" and strengthen their protection against health shocks. The scheme affects about 6,000 SEPs and is part of a broader amendment to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) Act, which also allows for refunds in certain cases.

site_title: Ryanair growth to stall as MAX jets delayed until at least March
summary: Ryanair expects to fly 157 million passengers in the year to March 31, 2021, a 2.6% growth rate, but growth may stall due to Boeing MAX 737 delivery delays. The airline now expects 20 planes to be delivered by next summer, down from an initial estimate of 30, with a "real risk" of none being delivered. This could freeze growth, which has averaged 10% annually since 2014, and may impact Ryanair's target of 200 million passengers per year by March 2024.

site_title: Europe: Autos, miners push shares higher
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Monday, their highest level since January 2018, driven by gains in autos and miners. The US and China reported progress in trade talks, boosting the European autos sector 2% and miners 1.5%. Frankfurt shares rose 0.7% as Siemens Healthineers saw a 6% gain, driven by strong fourth-quarter growth expectations. The market awaits purchasing manager surveys later in the day.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore: The CPF Retirement Sum Scheme will be capped at age 90 for higher payouts, allowing for higher payouts without reducing existing members' benefits. OCBC is in talks to form a digital bank consortium with Keppel and Validus. The government is piloting the Contribute-as-you-Earn scheme for public sector service providers. SP Group sees opportunities for Singapore to trade power with neighboring countries. Singapore shares rose 0.22% on trade deal optimism, closing at 3,236.40. Internationally, Vietnam reacted to a US tariff announcement, while Malaysia's agency plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets.

site_title: Storage firm Vopak to focus on chemicals after oil terminal slowdown
summary: Dutch storage firm Vopak plans to shift focus from oil terminals to chemicals due to declining profitability. The company will develop a new joint venture terminal in southwest China and expand terminals in Belgium and Mexico. Vopak reported slightly below-consensus earnings in the third quarter, citing poor oil terminal performance and new marine fuel regulations. The company will invest 300-500 million euros in growth over the coming years, with a new industrial terminal in China and expansions in Belgium and Mexico.

site_title: Brexit Party's Farage says: We could be kingmakers in likely hung Parliament
summary: The Brexit Party's Nigel Farage suggests that a hung Parliament is likely in the next election, potentially making the party kingmakers. He notes that Theresa May's government relied on the DUP for support, and he aims to "hurt the opposition Labour Party in the most extraordinary way." Farage's party could influence the outcome, and he sees an opportunity to shape the UK's future.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.65% on Monday, driven by a strong US jobs report and optimism over China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index rose to 27,547.30, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.58% and 0.59%, respectively. The gains follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and come despite US President Trump's recent threats to extend his trade tariffs.

site_title: SPH launches new perpetual bond
summary: SPH launches a new perpetual bond with an initial price guidance of 4.25% and a non-callable period of 5.5 years. The perpetual notes will reset their distribution rate at the end of year 5.5 and every five years thereafter based on prevailing swap offer rates and a step-up margin. This is the second perpetual bond issued by SPH this year, following a S$150 million 4.5% perpetual note priced in May.

site_title: UK airline giant IAG agrees to buy Spain's Air Europa for 1b euros
summary: UK airline giant IAG has agreed to buy Spain's Air Europa for 1 billion euros, expanding routes to Latin America and the Caribbean and solidifying Madrid as a key hub. The deal aims to boost Iberia and Vueling, and generate significant savings in costs and sales. IAG will fund the deal with debt and anticipates it will create additional financial value for shareholders. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the second half of next year, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Airbus seizes on Boeing MAX ban with flurry of Asia orders
summary: Airbus has secured over 350 plane orders in Asia since August, surpassing rival Boeing as the US planemaker struggles to revive its grounded 737 MAX. Key orders include 300 A320neo jets from Indian budget carrier IndiGo and purchases from VietJet Aviation JSC and Cebu Air Inc. Boeing received only 16 orders in the past three months. The 737 MAX crisis continues, with Boeing upgrading software and awaiting FAA approval, while Airbus faces production challenges and potential engine issues with IndiGo's A320neo jets.

site_title: Japan raider favourite as Melbourne Cup faces image issues
summary: The Melbourne Cup, one of Australia's most iconic racing events, is facing image issues due to recent animal welfare concerns. The sport has been targeted by activists after a spate of fatalities, including Irish five-year-old The Cliffsofmoher, and thousands of retired horses being sent to abattoirs in secret. To address concerns, Racing Victoria has pledged Aus$25 million to improve welfare for retired horses, and 10% of ticket sales will go towards a new equine welfare fund. Favorites Mer De Glace and Constantinople are set to compete in the event, which has been declared a public holiday in Victoria.

site_title: American brands aren't getting any love in China's Singles' Day
summary: US brands may face a boycott on China's Singles' Day shopping event, with over three-quarters of Chinese consumers surveyed saying they'll reconsider buying from American companies due to the US-China trade war. More than half cited allegiance to their nation as the reason, amid growing nationalistic spending and scrutiny of Western firms for perceived cultural or sovereignty issues. This comes as Chinese consumers increasingly look to domestic brands, and US brands may face disruptions in sales, with over $30 billion in sales expected on the event last year.

site_title: Malaysia to issue bauxite mining licences by January after ban lifted
summary: Malaysia plans to issue bauxite mining licenses by December or January, after lifting a 2016 ban due to unregulated mining and water contamination. The government has implemented stricter standards, including capping monthly exports at 600,000 tonnes and creating buffer zones around mining sites. A six-month monitoring process will follow license issuance to ensure compliance with new regulations, with Pahang state considering applications from three local companies.

site_title: Analyst research gives wide range for Aramco valuation: sources
summary: Analysts have provided wide valuation estimates for Saudi Aramco, ranging between $1.2 trillion and $2.3 trillion, as the oil giant prepares for its initial public offering (IPO) on the local bourse. The estimates, based on research reports from Bank of America and EFG Hermes, challenge Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's initial valuation target of $2 trillion. The valuation ranges highlight the challenge in hitting the target, with some banks estimating Aramco's value could be around $1.5 trillion.

site_title: Venezuela's Maduro pledges funds for Argentine shipyard to finish PDVSA tankers
summary: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro pledged funds for a state-owned Argentine shipyard to finish two long-overdue tankers for Petroleos de Venezuela, a state oil company struggling with a diminished tanker fleet. Maduro blamed outgoing President Mauricio Macri for delaying the tankers' completion, accusing him of "sabotage." The pledge comes as Argentina's new President Alberto Fernandez prepares to take office, and Maduro sees this as an opportunity to revive the construction. Venezuela has not disclosed how much money it will provide or when it will be disbursed.

images.alt_text: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro on Sunday pledged funds for a state-owned Argentine shipyard to finish building two long- overdue tankers for state oil company Petroleos de Venezuela, which is struggling with a diminished tanker fleet.

site_title: US Commerce Secretary meets Chinese Premier Li as progress seen on trade
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross met Chinese Premier Li Keqiang at a Bangkok summit, discussing progress on a Phase One trade deal. Ross expressed optimism the agreement would be completed this month, with licenses for US firms to sell components to Huawei expected "very shortly." The Phase One deal includes increased Chinese purchases of US agriculture products and opening of financial services markets to American firms, in exchange for the US removing punitive tariffs. A comprehensive long-term trade deal remains uncertain, with Chinese officials questioning the removal of all punitive tariffs.

images.alt_text: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross met Chinese Premier Li Keqiang on Monday afternoon at a regional summit in Bangkok, a person familiar with the discussion said.

site_title: Asia's self-sustaining growth is shield against US tariffs
summary: Asia's self-sustaining growth shields it against US tariffs, with regional consumption and investment driving economic momentum. The region contributes two-thirds of global growth, making Western economies increasingly dependent on Asia. Asia's largest trading partners are now other Asian countries, with 54% of exports going to fellow Asian nations. This trend is expected to build momentum, as regional manufacturers and international corporations focus on Asian customers. Asia's ability to absorb tariff-affected demand is evident, with China's trade with the US dropping 9% year-on-year, but overall trade rising 3.9%.

site_title: Global equities buck October effect; STI posts 4% gain: SGX
summary: Global equities defied the "October effect," with the Straits Times Index (STI) posting a 4% monthly gain in October, according to the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The October effect typically sees investors rotating from equities to treasuries during the month. However, a tentative US-China trade deal and a rebound in the US dollar index contributed to the STI's gain. Asian markets also saw significant gains, with Taiwan's Taiex leading the region with a 5% gain, while Singapore stocks such as AEM Holdings and UMS Holdings rose 33% and 34% respectively.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks hit 4-month high on positive US data, trade deal hopes
summary: South Korean stocks reached a four-month high on Monday, rising 1.43% to 2,130.24, following positive US jobs data and optimism over Sino-US trade talks. This marks the benchmark index's biggest daily percentage gain since August 30 and its highest level since July 2. The gains extend a third consecutive session, boosting investor confidence in the region's market.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares touched a four-month high on Monday boosted by upbeat US jobs data and optimism over Sino-US trade talks.

site_title: India's Infosys says no prima facie evidence on whistleblower complaints
summary: Indian IT services major Infosys Ltd received no evidence to support whistleblower allegations that Chief Executive Salil Parekh instigated employees to bypass approvals for large deals. The allegations were made in a letter to the National Stock Exchange (NSE) in October, but Infosys said there was no supporting evidence to substantiate the claims. The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is still investigating the allegations, and Infosys is not obligated to disclose them as they were deemed non-material under Indian regulation. Infosys shares rose up to 6.5% in response to the news.

site_title: Saudis save up for Aramco share sale many see as one-way bet
summary: Saudi Arabia's Aramco is set to launch its highly anticipated initial public offering (IPO), with shares expected to start trading in December. The sale, which has been three years in the making, is seen as a chance for ordinary Saudis to buy into the world's largest oil company, but the process is complicated and the payoff is uncertain. The IPO is also a key part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's efforts to diversify the nation's economy, but it comes at a challenging time, following a drone and cruise missile attack that cut Saudi oil production in half.

site_title: Japanese markets closed for holiday
summary: Japanese financial markets closed on Monday due to a public holiday. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.4% on Thursday. In other news, eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion, and US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, edged towards fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Worker dies in crane collapse at Novena construction site of new TTSH rehab hub
summary: A worker died after a construction crane collapsed at a site in Novena, Singapore, on Monday. The 28-year-old Indian national was pronounced dead at the scene, while a 35-year-old Bangladeshi worker was taken to hospital with a slight injury. The incident occurred at a construction site for a new 500-bed rehabilitation complex, which is scheduled for completion in 2022. An investigation is underway, and the Ministry of Manpower and main contractor Kajima are looking into the cause of the collapse.

site_title: Indian airline IndiGo says systems down, likely to hit operations
summary: Indian airline IndiGo reported that its systems were down across its network since Monday morning, impacting airport operations. The airline's largest carrier, with a 50% share of the domestic market, attributed the issue to "all efforts being made to resolve the issue at the earliest." The outage coincided with hazardous air pollution in New Delhi, causing flight delays and cancellations. IndiGo's shares rose 0.3%, while rival airline SpiceJet's shares fell 2%.

site_title: Indian capital banishes some cars in hope of clearing the air
summary: India's capital, New Delhi, has implemented an "odd-even" system, banning cars with odd-numbered license plates until Nov 15 to combat hazardous air pollution. The US Embassy's air quality index exceeded 500, posing serious health risks. The city government has declared a public health emergency and imposed restrictions on private vehicles, with ride-hailing services exempt from surge pricing. This measure aims to reduce vehicular exhaust, which contributes to over 50% of Delhi's air pollution. The city also ordered schools to shut and construction work to stop.

site_title: HKMA says financial system strong; Exchange Fund Q3 investment income drops
summary: Hong Kong's financial system remains strong, according to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), despite months of violent protests. The HKMA dismissed rumors that the protests have undermined the city's financial stability. However, the Exchange Fund, which backs the Hong Kong dollar, posted a 55% drop in third-quarter investment income. The fund's investment income was HK$20.2 billion, down from HK$9.5 billion in the previous quarter. HKMA Chief Executive Eddie Yue stated that the dollar peg does not need to change and the system is committed to maintaining stability.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand shares end up on trade optimism; banks cap gains
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% to 6,686.90 on Monday, driven by trade optimism and gains in resources producers. The metals and mining index jumped 2.2%, led by BHP Group and Rio Tinto. However, banking stocks declined, with Westpac and ANZ falling 2.5% and 1.1%, respectively, due to disappointing earnings reports. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index also rose 0.4% on healthcare and utility stocks.

site_title: China dangles carrot to Taiwanese in battle for hearts and minds
summary: China has introduced 26 incentives for Taiwanese companies and individuals, including a level playing field in 5G and theme parks, to encourage unification with the democratically ruled island within a generation. The incentives were announced months before Taiwan's January presidential election, following President Xi Jinping's pledge to unify Beijing with Taiwan. The move aims to win over Taiwanese hearts and minds, with opportunities for students and athletes, and is seen as a significant step towards China's goal of reunification.

site_title: Tear gas and petrol bombs no match for Hong Kong property demand
summary: In Hong Kong, a surge in demand for apartments was observed despite months of anti-government protests, with nearly three-quarters of units sold at a sales center in Admiralty. The city's real estate sector remains strong, with Chief Executive Carrie Lam's recent policy changes expected to fuel price increases. Analysts predict that the loosening of mortgage lending rules will unleash pent-up demand, while young Hong Kong residents struggle to afford homes due to high prices and income caps.

site_title: Lone Bitcoin whale likely fuelled 2017 price surge, study says
summary: A 2017 study suggests a single "Bitcoin whale" on the Bitfinex exchange likely manipulated the cryptocurrency's price surge, sending prices higher when it fell below certain thresholds. The entity uses Tether, a widely used digital token, to move prices. According to University of Texas Professor John Griffin and Ohio State University's Amin Shams, it appears that one large investor, rather than thousands, was behind the misconduct, potentially costing investors billions.

site_title: Riverside Piazza near Clarke Quay for en bloc sale with S$198m reserve price
summary: The Riverside Piazza, a 99-year leasehold property in Singapore's prime District 1, is up for collective sale via tender at a reserve price of S$198 million. The site, spanning 2,940 sq m, comprises 40 apartments and 24 commercial shops, and is zoned for commercial and residential use. Developers are attracted to the site's prime location near the Singapore River, Chinatown, and the CBD, and the area is expected to be revitalized with the completion of nearby projects, including the State Court Towers.

site_title: Thai retailer Central Group plans 20 billion baht overseas investment
summary: Thailand's Central Group plans to invest 20 billion baht (S$899.8 million) in Vienna, Osaka, and Turin, capitalizing on a strong local currency. The investment includes a luxury mixed-used project in Vienna, a hotel in Osaka, and the re-launch of its Rinascente department store in Italy. This move follows a recent investment of 22 billion baht in new malls and store renovations in Thailand, aiming to expand globally amid a strong baht.

site_title: New Zealand PM announces upgrade of free trade deal with China
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced the upgrade of her country's free trade deal with China, which will make exporting to China easier and reduce compliance costs by millions of dollars annually. The agreement, under negotiation for three years, will grant nearly all New Zealand's wood and paper trade to China preferential access for the next 10 years. The upgrade also secures environmental protections and commitments from Beijing to avoid using environmental standards for trade protectionist purposes.

site_title: Hong Kong IPOs get away with a protest discount
summary: Hong Kong's IPO market is reopening after five months of anti-government protests, with warehouse operator ESR Cayman successfully raising over $1 billion in a US dollar offering. E-commerce giant Alibaba's secondary listing plans are also back on track. Despite a tepid investor welcome, bluechip companies like ESR and brewer AB InBev's Asian arm managed to price at a premium to peers, boding well for Alibaba's potential $15 billion Hong Kong listing. However, smaller companies may face a challenging market, with some struggling to recover from their debuts.

site_title: HK Exchange Fund's Q3 investment income slides 55%
summary: The Hong Kong Exchange Fund reported a 55% drop in investment income in the third quarter to HK$20.2 billion, compared to HK$9.5 billion in the previous quarter and an HK$33.6 billion loss in the fourth quarter of 2018. The fund, which backs the Hong Kong dollar, invests in equities, bonds, and foreign exchange. The decline in investment income is attributed to market fluctuations and economic conditions.

site_title: 'Silicon Saxony' stands on foundations laid under East Germany
summary: In the eastern German city of Dresden, a hub of microchip manufacturing has emerged, built on the foundations laid during the communist East Germany era. Despite de-industrialization and unemployment after reunification, Dresden's skilled workforce and streamlined bureaucracy attracted Western companies, including Globalfoundries and Infineon, which now employ around 65,000 people. The region's high-tech industry generates significant prosperity, with output per head exceeding the five eastern German states outside Berlin. However, concerns over a staff shortage and support for the far-right AfD party threaten the region's economic future.

site_title: E-scooters to be banned from Singapore footpaths from Nov 5
summary: Singapore will ban electric scooters from footpaths starting November 5, 2019. Riders will be confined to 440km of cycling paths instead of 5,500km of footpaths. Authorities will issue warning letters to errant riders until the end of the year, with a zero-tolerance approach from next year. The move aims to address safety concerns.

site_title: Hong Kong braces for protests as two critical after weekend clashes
summary: Hong Kong is bracing for protests after weekend clashes left two people in critical condition. Riot police stormed shopping malls and clashed with protesters, who are demanding an independent inquiry into police behavior and universal suffrage. Pro-democracy protesters, wearing banned Guy Fawkes masks, plan further demonstrations, including a planned mark on Guy Fawkes Day. China calls for a "tougher" stance to end the unrest, while Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam has invoked colonial-era emergency powers to ban face masks. The protests have divided society and undermined the economy.

site_title: FairPrice extends 'no plastic bag' drive to 25 outlets for one year from Nov 11
summary: FairPrice is extending its 'no plastic bag' drive to 25 outlets in Singapore for one year, starting from November 11. The move follows a successful month-long trial at seven outlets. The 25 participating outlets include 12 FairPrice supermarkets, five Cheers stores, and eight FairPrice Xpress stores, where customers will be charged for plastic bags.

site_title: Activists call for halt to US horse racing
summary: Animal rights groups are calling for a halt to US horse racing after the fatal injury of Mongolian Groom in the Breeders' Cup Classic at Santa Anita Park. The four-year-old gelding died after injuring his leg during the race, marking the 37th horse death at the track since December. The incident has sparked renewed calls for regulation and safety measures, with some groups demanding a suspension of racing nationwide until investigations are completed and measures are put in place to prevent future fatalities.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,235.15, up 0.18% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday afternoon, advancing 0.18% or 5.72 points to 3,235.15. Gainers outnumbered losers 196 to 130, with Rex International Holding, Golden Agri-Resources, and DBS Group Holdings leading the gains. Financials also opened stronger, with United Overseas Bank and OCBC Bank rising 0.3% and 0.4% respectively. Markets in the region continued to trade stronger on US-China trade deal optimism, with the Hang Seng index hitting a three-month high.

site_title: Palm oil jumps 1% on expectations of tightening supplies
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures jumped 1.1% to RM2,487 per tonne due to expectations of tightening supplies and strong demand led by biodiesel consumption. Analysts revised up their price outlook, citing reduced production and Indonesia's B30 biodiesel programme. World palm oil stocks are expected to fall by 2-3 million tonnes in the next 12 months, according to Thomas Mielke. This is partly due to dry weather and fertiliser cuts in 2020, which may also impact Indonesia's palm oil production.

site_title: Why Barbie, a blimp and a Wienermobile are posting on Airbnb
summary: Airbnb has partnered with several brands to create unique lodging experiences, including a Wienermobile, a Goodyear blimp, and a life-size version of Barbie's Malibu Dreamhouse. These collaborations aim to generate news coverage and create an aspirational experience for customers. The company's CEO, Brian Chesky, believes that brands need to make news, not just advertise, to stand out. The limited availability of these experiences has been effective in generating buzz and attracting media attention, with reports from major outlets such as The New York Times and CNN.

site_title: Moon, Abe back dialogue to resolve S Korea-Japan dispute
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe suggested high-level talks to resolve their countries' deepening dispute, which includes a wartime labor row and trade issues. The two leaders discussed the issue on the sidelines of an Asean meeting in Bangkok, reaffirming the importance of dialogue in resolving bilateral issues. They agreed to seek a resolution through all available means, with Moon offering higher-level talks if necessary. The meeting comes after a year without a summit between the two leaders, with tensions escalating over the wartime labor issue.

site_title: Australia flicks switch on first new power station in 7 years
summary: Australia's first new power station in 7 years, the Barker Inlet gas-fired power plant, began operations on November 4, 2019. The A$295 million facility has 210 megawatts of capacity and will help supplement renewables in South Australia. Its quick-start capability will back up fast-growing wind and solar generation, addressing the need for rapid responses to changes in renewable supply and demand. The plant is part of AGL's A$2 billion pipeline of infrastructure projects aimed at bolstering the grid, supporting Australia's growing renewable energy sector.

site_title: Koon Holdings names new chief operating officer
summary: Koon Holdings appoints Loo Woei Harng as chief operating officer, effective October 31, to oversee construction and precast operations. This is his second stint with the company, following a previous role from 2013 to 2014. The appointment comes as Koon Holdings shares remain suspended since August 30.

site_title: Vietnam to announce 25.4% upward GDP revision this month
summary: Vietnam is set to announce a 25.4% upward revision of its gross domestic product (GDP) for the 2011-2017 period, aiming to meet international norms and better reflect the economy's real size and structure. The revision was previously scheduled for August but has been delayed to allow for more time to calculate its impact on macroeconomic indicators. The upward revision will bring Vietnam's GDP growth rate for the period to 26.4% and is expected to be announced in November.

site_title: Sauna and oysters: Merkel recalls Berlin Wall fall
summary: Angela Merkel, then a 35-year-old physicist, relaxed in an East Berlin sauna on the night of Nov 9, 1989, as the Berlin Wall began to fall. She had just heard that East German citizens were free to cross the border and called her mother, making plans to eat oysters at a high-end hotel in the West, a family "in-joke". As the barriers opened, Merkel followed the crowd and found herself on the western side of Berlin, drinking her first Western beer and marking the beginning of a new era in German history.

site_title: Japanese-backed Australian LNG import project faces delay
