summary: A Japanese-backed Australian liquefied natural gas (LNG) import project has faced a delay due to struggles to lock in customers, including Australia's top gas retailer, Origin Energy. The A$250 million project, backed by JERA, Marubeni Corp, and Squadron Energy, was initially set to deliver gas in late 2020 but now risks missing its target. Industry observers attribute the delay to a drop in local gas prices, which has made manufacturers hesitant to commit to the project. The delay risks Australia's southeast gas shortage and could impact the country's energy security.

site_title: Oil edges down; eyes on data amid trade deal hopes
summary: Oil prices edged down on Monday as traders remained cautious ahead of fresh economic data from Europe and the US. Despite hopes for a resolution to the US-China trade row, prices fell 27 US cents to $61.42 a barrel for Brent crude futures. Traders are taking profits ahead of uncertainty around macro-economic data and US oil inventory reports. The European Union and US are set to announce manufacturing data on Monday, and a fall in the US rig count supported oil prices last week.

site_title: Japan enters rehab for cash addiction
summary: Japan's government has checked the country into a cash addiction clinic, aiming to ditch its reliance on banknotes and convert to digital payments. The move could boost economic activity and upgrade productivity, with a study estimating a $70 billion economic impact in major cities. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's administration seeks to double the cashless transaction rate to 40% by 2025, but faces challenges in convincing elderly consumers, merchants, and bankers to adopt new technology.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks hit 4-month high on trade optimism
summary: South Korea's stocks reached a four-month high on Monday, driven by optimism over US-China trade negotiations. The KOSPI index rose 1.17% to 2,124.84, with foreigners buying 65.7 billion won worth of shares. The US-China trade talks have lifted risk appetite, with US officials saying a deal could be signed this month. The South Korean won also gained, while bond yields rose. The KOSPI has advanced 4.11% this year, marking its best session since July 2.

site_title: 'Everyone started running': Berliner remembers crossing the Wall
summary: On November 9, 1989, Andreas Falge, a 61-year-old Berliner, crossed the East German border into the West, one of the first to do so after the Berlin Wall's sudden opening. Falge recalled the scene as a "human tide" with people shouting "Open the gate!" and East German border guards eventually relenting, allowing pedestrians and cars to pass through. Falge, who had never considered fleeing, was surprised to find the West was not so different from the East, and he returned to East Berlin the next day to celebrate with his friends at the Babylon cinema.

site_title: A US$100 jar of honey comes between two allies
summary: A bitter dispute between Australia and New Zealand has erupted over manuka honey, a high-priced nectar valued for its health benefits. New Zealand producers claim to be the only source of authentic manuka honey, while Australian producers argue that they can also produce it from a similar species of bush. The dispute has led to trademark battles and concerns over the impact on the honey industry, with New Zealand producers seeking to corner the market and increase prices. The issue has also sparked cultural and historical tensions, with the Maori people of New Zealand claiming the word "manuka" as their own.

site_title: Cairo delights at sweet candies as Muslim festival nears
summary: Cairo's historic Bab al-Bahr street is filled with sweet candies and decorations as the Muslim festival of "Al Mawlid Al Nabawi" approaches. The festival, celebrating Prophet Mohammed's birthday, has its roots in Egypt's Fatimid dynasty. Local dessert makers are preparing traditional sweets, including nut-filled treats and horse-shaped candies, which are available for both the poor and rich. The festivities, which take place on November 9, draw in crowds of children and adults alike, filling the air with the sweet smell of candies and creating a festive atmosphere.

images.alt_text: "We love to share this happy mood," said one stall-holder who was adorning a candy doll with glitter and coloured paper, drawing intense interest from a group of playful children.

site_title: Iron ore futures slip as Vale gets nod to resume major mine ops
summary: Vale, the world's largest iron ore miner, has received approval from Brazilian regulator ANM to resume operations at its Alegria mine, which was halted after a stress test failed to guarantee its stability. The resumption is expected to add 1 million tonnes to production volumes in 2019 and restore 8 million tonnes of lost capacity. As a result, iron ore futures in China and Singapore slipped, with Dalian Commodity Exchange's most-traded iron ore falling 1% to 616.50 yuan (S$119) a tonne and Singapore Exchange's front-month December contract falling 1.5% to US$80.52 a tonne.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.3% to 3,240.24
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.3% to 3,240.24. Gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 34, with notable gains from Rex International and other stocks. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid ongoing market positivity despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Japan switches to centralised stress tests on 5 banks: Nikkei
summary: Japan's government and central bank will conduct joint stress tests on five banks: MUFG Bank, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp, Mizuho Bank, Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Holdings, and Norinchukin Bank. The tests aim to gauge the banks' ability to absorb economic shocks, as expansion abroad leaves them more vulnerable to external risks. This marks a change from previous years when the details of stress tests were left to individual banks.

site_title: European asset managers care more about climate change: study
summary: European asset managers are more likely to prioritize climate change concerns than their US counterparts, according to a study by ShareAction. The organization found that the top 10 US asset managers voted down climate change resolutions, despite publicly backing climate action. In contrast, European asset managers were more active in addressing climate change issues, with the top performers including UBS Asset Management, Allianz Global Investors, and Aviva Investors. This highlights a "disconnect" between public statements and private actions, with ShareAction calling for investors to take responsibility for their climate impact.

site_title: Australia's Independence chases more nickel with A$312m bid for Panoramic
summary: IGO, an Australian nickel miner, launched a hostile A$312 million takeover bid for Panoramic Resources, offering 42% premium to the stock price. The bid aims to capitalize on growing demand for nickel in electric vehicles. IGO's CEO stated the acquisition aligns with the company's strategy of increasing nickel production and exposure to clean energy metals. Panoramic Resources advised shareholders to evaluate the offer, while IGO has reached out directly to shareholders to discuss the bid.

site_title: China approves first new Alzheimer's drug in 17 years
summary: China has approved the first new Alzheimer's treatment in 17 years, Oligomannate, a low molecular acid oligosaccharide compound extracted from marine brown algae. The drug, developed by Shanghai Green Valley Pharmaceuticals, statistically improved cognitive function in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's in trials. Approval allows the drug to be available in China by the end of 2019, with plans to apply for marketing authorization in selected countries and start global clinical trials early next year. This breakthrough may shift China's focus away from beta amyloid as a key to a cure and enhance its position as a global leader in medical research.

site_title: Newton-John's 'Grease' outfit sells for more than US$400,000
summary: Olivia Newton-John's iconic "Grease" outfit, worn in the 1978 film, sold for US$405,700 at a Beverly Hills auction, exceeding the pre-sale estimate by twice. The black leather jacket and high-waisted skin-tight pants were part of Newton-John's transformation into a sexy greaser girl. The sale proceeds will benefit the Olivia Newton-John center for cancer research, to which Newton-John has been donating since her 2018 cancer diagnosis. An auction of Newton-John's signed poster fetched US$64,000.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 0.73% to 27,299.88, following a forecast-beating US jobs report and optimism over a potential mini trade deal between Beijing and Washington. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also rose, with gains of 0.22% each. The positive start is attributed to market sentiment ahead of the US-China trade talks, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Citi drops off China property website Fangdd's US$78m US IPO after fee dispute: sources
summary: Citigroup dropped out of Fangdd Network Group's $78 million US IPO after a fee dispute, according to sources. The dispute occurred despite Citigroup being listed as the second bookrunner in the IPO document. The issue was not resolved until Thursday, and Citigroup did not appear in the press statement announcing the downsized IPO on Friday. The IPO was down-sized and is now expected to be priced at $78 million.

site_title: Asean summit: Talks on Asian trade deal 'conclusive', Thai minister says
summary: Thailand's Commerce Minister Jurin Laksanawisit announced that Asian countries have concluded talks on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), a 16-nation trade pact that could be the world's biggest. Despite India's last-minute demands, a provisional agreement is expected to be announced by the leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) today. The pact, which includes China, South Korea, Japan, and other countries, aims to boost regional economic growth and counter China's increasing regional might. A signing is expected for next year, with Thailand committing to sign the agreement in 2020.

images.alt_text: "The negotiation last night was conclusive," Thai Commerce Minister Jurin Laksanawisit told Reuters on Monday.

site_title: Louis CK looks to accelerate comeback admitting to sexual misconduct
summary: Louis CK is set to accelerate his comeback after admitting to sexual misconduct in 2017. He announced plans to tour and revive his website, which was previously inactive. The comedian's comeback comes after a year of being in comeback mode.

site_title: KPMG to cut 65 UK partners
summary: KPMG plans to cut approximately 65 of its 635 UK partners by Christmas, following a review of individual performance. The decision, announced by Chairman Bill Michael, aims to take a harsher approach to managing performance. The cuts are expected to affect partners across the business, with the audit practice least likely to see departures. The move comes amid increased scrutiny of the "Big Four" accounting firms, following criticism from parliament about the FRC's handling of investigations, including KPMG's audit of Carillion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares rise at Monday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.88 points to 1,598.22 at Monday's open, driven by a 200-37 gainer-to-loser ratio. The stock market opened higher despite global market uncertainty, with Asia's stocks extending their rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Under Armour faces federal probe over accounting practices
summary: Under Armour is under investigation by US federal law enforcement officials regarding its accounting practices. The company confirmed it is cooperating with the Justice Department and SEC, but denies any wrongdoing. The investigation centers on whether Under Armour shifted sales from quarter to quarter to appear financially healthier. The company has been restructuring its operations to compete with Nike and Adidas in the US market, where it has seen declining sales. Under Armour's CEO Kevin Plank is stepping down next year, and the company has cut its full-year revenue forecast.

site_title: Growth in China's LNG imports tumbles as economy slows
summary: China's growth in liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports is expected to slow sharply this year due to a slowing economy and record high coal imports. LNG demand in China is forecasted to grow 14-17% in 2019, down from 41-42% in 2018. The government's push to convert households to gas or electric heating from coal is being slowed by economic uncertainty, and competition from cheaper coal and a new Russia-China gas pipeline may squeeze out LNG imports in the longer term.

site_title: New grant for Singapore workplaces to promote active mobility
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore announced a new Active Commute Grant to encourage workplaces to promote active mobility. The grant will provide up to 80% of construction costs for end-of-trip facilities such as showers, lockers, and changing rooms. The grant is capped at S$80,000 per development, aiming to increase the number of people walking, running, or cycling to work. This initiative is part of Singapore's efforts to reduce its reliance on cars and promote a healthier lifestyle.

site_title: Asia-Pacific's 2nd-richest woman Gina Rinehart's wealth swells as family split lingers
summary: Australian mining magnate Gina Rinehart's fortune increased by US$2.1 billion after her company reported improved financial results, with revenue rising 39% and earnings increasing 90%. Her wealth now stands at US$17.9 billion, making her the second-richest woman in the Asia-Pacific region. Despite her growing wealth, a long-standing family dispute over a trust has hindered dividend payments, with the court deciding to hear the dispute behind closed doors.

site_title: Banks cap Australian shares after Westpac results; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by positive signs in US-China trade talks and stronger-than-expected economic data. However, the heavyweight banking sector declined due to weaker results from Westpac Banking Corp, which reported a 15% slide in full-year cash earnings and cut its dividend for the first time in a decade. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 6,685, while New Zealand's benchmark rose 0.7%.

site_title: Gold prices dip on trade deal optimism, strong US jobs data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,511.27 per ounce, amid optimism over a potential US-China trade deal and strong US job data. The US and China made progress in trade talks, with a deal possible this month, and economic data showed slower-than-expected job growth and a manufacturing index expansion. Investors sought riskier assets, reducing demand for gold.

site_title: China's proposed digital currency more about policing than progress
summary: China's proposed Digital Currency Electronic Payment (DCEP) project aims to control its cash economy, with the central bank planning to track transactions and supervise money flows. The digital currency, powered by blockchain technology, will be dispersed through digital wallets, providing Beijing with unprecedented oversight over money flows. While some experts see it as a testament to financial innovation, others view it as a means to preserve control and prevent illegal activities, such as money laundering. The project's launch timeline remains uncertain, but it is expected to be a significant move in China's efforts to regulate its economy.

site_title: Merkel wants Germany to have 1 million electric-car charging points by 2030
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel announced plans for Germany to have 1 million electric car charging points by 2030, a significant increase from the current 20,000 public charging points. The government aims to speed up the transition to low-emission battery-powered vehicles, with the car industry expected to participate in this effort. The goal is to address concerns that lack of fuel infrastructure is deterring potential buyers from switching to electric cars. The government also plans to explore hydrogen fuel cell alternatives and will share the cost of subsidies to attract buyers.

site_title: Singapore among worst hit by investment cutback after US tax reform
summary: US multinational corporations withdrew $51.4 billion in direct investments from Singapore in 2018, a 19% decrease from 2017, following the implementation of the US Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. This is the largest hit among major US investment destinations. Globally, US direct investments dropped 1% to $5.6 trillion, while foreign investments in the US rose 7.9% to $4.3 trillion. Despite this, Singapore remains among the top 10 locations for US direct investments, with $218.83 billion still invested in the country.

site_title: ISDN in Cambodian power plant JV, disposes stake in associate
summary: ISDN Holdings has taken a 33% stake in a joint venture to build an 80 megawatt hydroelectric power plant in Cambodia. The project, called SPHP Co Pte Ltd, will receive confirmation and guarantee from the Cambodian government for business rights and electricity sales. ISDN will invest US$500,000 in equity and US$2.5 million as a shareholder loan. The operating rights will be transferred to Cambodia Electric Power Corporation 35 years after plant operations start. This move aims to further penetrate Asia's renewable energy sector and alleviate blackouts in Cambodia.

site_title: Philippines' Cebu Air signs deal for US$4.8b Airbus aircraft
summary: Philippines' Cebu Air Inc has finalized the purchase of 16 long-range Airbus A330 neo jets worth US$4.8 billion at list prices. The budget carrier plans to deploy the aircraft on routes in the Philippines, Asia, Australia, and the Middle East, scheduled for delivery between 2021 and 2024. This move is part of Cebu Air's expansion efforts, despite limited slots at the main gateway in Manila. The new aircraft will be more fuel-efficient and will help the airline grow its operations.

site_title: Australia and China vow to work on repairing bilateral relationship
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison and Chinese Premier Li Keqiang agreed to work on repairing their bilateral relationship, strained by allegations of cyber-attacks and interference in domestic affairs. The two leaders met in Thailand ahead of the East Asia Summit, promising to improve the relationship worth over $180 billion in two-way trade. The meeting comes amid tensions over China's human rights record and allegations of hacking attacks, with Australian officials holding Beijing accountable for its actions. A trade deal on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership is also on the agenda.

site_title: CEO behind Occidental, Anadarko mega-deal faces investor scrutiny
summary: Vicki Hollub, CEO of Occidental Petroleum Corp, faces investor scrutiny after the company's $37 billion purchase of Anadarko Petroleum Corp. The stock has plummeted 37% since the deal was announced, and investors are concerned about the company's ability to service $22 billion in debt and $10 billion in preferred shares. Analysts expect Hollub to provide a clear plan for paying down debt and improving the balance sheet, particularly at lower crude prices. Key developments that could help rebuild trust include potential sales of Occidental's pipeline unit and progress toward annual cost savings of $3.5 billion.

site_title: Whistleblower offers Republicans testimony as Trump pushes to unmask
summary: A US whistleblower who filed a complaint leading to President Donald Trump's impeachment inquiry has offered to communicate directly with Republicans on the intelligence committee, in response to Republican efforts to unmask their identity. The whistleblower's lawyers claim this move aims to handle the complaint in a nonpartisan way. Trump has called for the whistleblower's identity to be revealed, calling them an "Obama guy" and a "fraud." The whistleblower's testimony, based on second-hand information, may not be the most crucial to the inquiry, which is nearing its sixth week and is expected to begin public hearings soon.

site_title: Flood of oil is coming, complicating efforts to fight global warming
summary: A surge of oil production is expected to hit the market in 2020 and 2021, adding nearly 1 million barrels a day, primarily from Brazil, Canada, Norway, and Guyana. This increase will likely push oil prices down, potentially damaging oil companies' profits and limiting new exploration and drilling. The new supply may complicate efforts to combat global warming, as lower oil prices could slow the adoption of electric vehicles. The influx of oil will also give Western policymakers a cushion in case of renewed attacks on oil tankers or facilities in the Persian Gulf, but may require Opec to extend and deepen production cuts to support prices.

site_title: US may not need to impose auto tariffs this month, says commerce secretary
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross says the country may not need to impose auto tariffs on imported vehicles later this month after holding "good conversations" with European, Japanese, and Korean automakers. The tariffs, which could be as high as 25%, were previously delayed once and could be again. Ross hopes negotiations with companies about their capital investment plans will lead to a resolution, but EU diplomats remain cautious, saying they could change their minds.

site_title: US court blocks another Trump immigration initiative
summary: A US federal judge has temporarily blocked a Trump administration initiative requiring immigrants to prove they have health insurance or can afford medical care. The ruling, issued by Judge Michael Simon, blocks a measure set to take effect on Monday. The measure was intended to reduce the financial burden on the US healthcare system. Immigration-defense groups argued it would unfairly favor wealthier countries and be particularly burdensome for low-income migrants. The White House decried the ruling as "wrong and unfair."

site_title: Hamilton seals his sixth F1 title at US Grand Prix
summary: Lewis Hamilton secured his sixth Formula One world championship at the US Grand Prix, finishing second behind teammate Valtteri Bottas. Hamilton's 34-year-old career is now the second-longest after Michael Schumacher's seven titles. The championship was all but sealed before the race, with Hamilton's second-place finish securing his title. Despite falling short of a seventh US Grand Prix victory, Hamilton expressed his gratitude and admiration for Bottas' performance.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Manulife US Reit, EHT, ISDN, SIA Engineering, SingPost, NetLink
summary:
Several Singapore stocks made notable developments on Monday, including:

- United Overseas Bank launched a QR-based payment solution.
- Manulife US Reit reported a 2% decline in third-quarter distribution per unit to 1.48 US cents.
- Eagle Hospitality Trust sold six hotels to its sponsor ahead of its IPO.
- ISDN Holdings took a 33% stake in a joint venture for a hydroelectric power plant in Cambodia.
- SIA Engineering posted a higher net profit of S$46 million for the second quarter.
- Singapore Post delivered a 10.3% higher net profit of S$27.7 million for the second quarter.
- NetLink NBN Trust reported a 24.1% increase in net profit for the second quarter.
- Mapletree Industrial Trust completed the acquisition of three hyperscale data centers in North America.
- Pacific Star Development expects to report a net loss for the first quarter due to tough market conditions.

site_title: It's a buyers' market for Manhattan's two-bedrooms
summary: In Manhattan's real estate market, a buyers' market has emerged for two-bedroom apartments, with a 17% drop in median prices for four-bedroom-and-up units and an 8% decline for two-bedrooms. The median sale price of a two-bedroom apartment reached $1.5 million, a significant discount from the same period last year. Income-restricted units and pre-war co-ops with deep discounts are attracting buyers, with prices ranging from $325,000 to $995,000. New developments, including luxury condos with unsold units, are also offering attractive deals, with buyers able to negotiate discounts on transfer taxes and other costs. Historically low interest rates and increasing options for first-time and move-up buyers are contributing to the shift towards a buyers' market.

site_title: Nigeria's border closure to last at least until end-Jan
summary: Nigeria has announced its land border closure will last until at least January 31, 2020. The closure, launched in August to combat smuggling, will continue in phases until its objectives are met. According to a customs memo, the operation has been deemed an "overwhelming success," but strategic objectives remain to be achieved. The closure aims to curb the smuggling of goods such as rice, and its duration is subject to review.

site_title: Saudi Arabia gives approval for Aramco IPO
summary: Saudi Arabia's Capital Market Authority approved Aramco's initial public offering (IPO), allowing the company to potentially list on the Saudi bourse by year-end. The move is part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's plan to overhaul the country's economy and reduce its reliance on oil exports. After being shelved three weeks prior, the plan has been revived, with shares expected to start trading in December. The IPO is considered the world's largest, and its success could be crucial to the Saudi government's economic reforms.

site_title: China gives conditional approval to self-developed Alzheimer's drug
summary: China has granted conditional approval to its first self-developed Alzheimer's treatment, Oligomannate, which uses marine brown algae extract. The treatment has shown statistically improved cognitive function in mild-to-moderate Alzheimer's patients as early as week 4. Despite theoretical uncertainties and high-profile failures, Oligomannate may become one of the best-selling drugs globally, offering a cheaper alternative to costly multinational pharmaceutical treatments. Further research is required to confirm its long-term safety and effectiveness.

site_title: Singapore-on-Thames? London's financial hub mulls post-Brexit future
summary: The UK's financial sector is considering its post-Brexit future, with some advocating for a highly deregulated "Singapore-on-Thames" model. Regulators, however, are cautious, with the Financial Conduct Authority stating that a review of regulations is needed. The Governor of the Bank of England, Mark Carney, has ruled out a "bonfire of financial regulation." Key areas of focus include fintech, insurance, and anti-corruption, with potential changes to regulations on bank bonuses, transaction traceability, and capital reserves.

site_title: Manulife US Reit posts 2% fall in Q3 DPU on enlarged unit base
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a 2% decline in Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.48 US cents, mainly due to an enlarged unit base following a placement and preferential offering. Gross revenue rose 13.3% to US$45.7 million, driven by acquisitions of two office towers in Virginia and a planned purchase of Centerpointe I & II in Fairfax, Virginia. Net property income increased 11.8% to US$28.1 million, while distributable income grew 7.8% to US$20.8 million. The Reit's AUM has increased 20.4% year-over-year to US$2.1 billion.

site_title: McDonald's fires CEO after relationship with employee
summary: McDonald's fired CEO Steve Easterbrook after he engaged in a consensual relationship with an employee that violated company policy. The board determined he demonstrated poor judgment and voted to terminate him. Easterbrook will be replaced by Chris Kempczinski, who previously served as president of McDonald's USA. Easterbrook acknowledged the mistake and agreed with the board's decision, citing the company's values. The move comes after Easterbrook turned around McDonald's after its 2015 financial struggles.

site_title: SP Group sees greener future for Singapore in trading power with neighbours
summary: Singapore's state-owned power grid operator, SP Group, aims to build connections to neighboring countries to tap into their renewable energy potential. CEO Wong Kim Yin believes that Malaysia and Indonesia have ample spare land for solar panels and wind turbines, which Singapore lacks. By building transmission lines and using renewable energy credits, Singapore can utilize clean power even if it can't produce it, reducing its reliance on imported energy. This strategy is seen as a way to build a greener future for the island nation.

site_title: President Halimah's visit to widen greater cooperation & opportunities
summary: Singapore President Halimah Yacob's State Visit to Saudi Arabia from Nov 5-8, 2019, marked the first by a Singapore President in the history of diplomatic relations between the two countries. The visit aimed to widen cooperation and opportunities in various fields, including investment, education, healthcare, and tourism. It coincided with Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030, a national development plan that promotes economic diversification and women's empowerment. The visit reflected the countries' aspirations to enhance bilateral relations and contribute to the Kingdom's development goals.

site_title: US housing market needs more than a rate cut
summary: The US housing market is unlikely to be significantly impacted by the Federal Reserve's latest interest-rate cut, with many economists skeptical about its effectiveness. Despite low interest rates, lending standards remain tight, and the sector is a smaller part of the economy than before the financial crisis. Affordability remains a major issue, with housing prices rising faster than wages in many areas, making it difficult for first-time homebuyers to enter the market. Experts predict that rates may not get much lower, and the Fed's policy could even lead to higher mortgage rates.

site_title: Norway's Ugland says nine crew abducted by pirates from vessel off Benin
summary: Norwegian shipping firm J.J. Ugland reported that its vessel, MV Bonita, was boarded by pirates while anchored off the coast of Benin, resulting in the abduction of nine crew members. The vessel docked at Cotonou port after notifying local authorities. This incident is part of a growing trend of piracy and armed robbery in West Africa's Gulf of Guinea, a high-risk area. Ugland's emergency response team is handling the situation, and the families of the kidnapped crew members have been contacted.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Minister Masagos on how Singapore can combat climate change
summary: Minister Masagos Zulkifli discussed Singapore's efforts to combat climate change on the Money FM podcast. The island nation faces rising sea levels due to climate change, threatening its shores. Masagos shared Singapore's initiatives, including increasing energy efficiency, promoting green transportation, and enhancing waste management. He also highlighted the importance of community engagement and education in addressing climate change. The conversation also touched on how Singapore's Malay/Muslim community has evolved in response to climate change, with Masagos emphasizing the need for collective action to mitigate its effects.

site_title: Delhi suffers most hazardous air for this year
summary: New Delhi experienced the worst air pollution levels this year, with an air quality index of over 900, posing a risk to the lungs of 40 million people. Authorities declared a public health emergency and closed schools, while the government is urging the federal government to take tougher action against farmers who burn crop stubble. The situation is expected to worsen for the next 24-48 hours, with no relief expected until then, according to weather forecasting agencies.

site_title: Huawei readies S-E Asia's 5G infrastructure
summary: Huawei is set to roll out 5G infrastructure across South-east Asia, despite US warnings that its technology could be used to spy on other countries. The Chinese firm has denied these accusations, saying it is the victim of tech envy. Thailand and the Philippines have welcomed Huawei, while Vietnam has sided with the US and plans to use alternative providers for 5G technology. Huawei has invested $5 billion in 5G trials in the region, and the company's vice-president, Edward Zhou, reiterated that there are no cybersecurity issues.

site_title: Teens love TikTok. Silicon Valley is trying to stage an intervention
summary: US tech companies are concerned about TikTok's rapid rise as a social media platform, downloaded over 750 million times in the past year. Competitors like Facebook, YouTube, and Snapchat are trying to copy its format, but so far, TikTok's popularity endures. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the US is reviewing ByteDance's acquisition of Musical.ly, which could lead to a government intervention. US tech executives believe TikTok's Chinese roots and censorship concerns make it a threat to their dominance, with some even criticizing its parent company, ByteDance, for allegedly exporting its vision of the internet to other countries.

site_title: Centurion aims to boost student, worker accommodation portfolio
summary: Centurion Corporation aims to expand its student accommodation portfolio in the UK, US, and Australia, while exploring opportunities in SE Asia for workers' housing. The company's CEO, Kong Chee Min, expects the UK, Australia, and US to remain key destinations for students, driven by the weaker pound and escalating US-China trade spat. Despite Brexit uncertainties, Centurion has seen no decline in international students from Europe. The company plans to boost its portfolio to 74,656 beds by FY21, with a focus on the worker accommodation segment.

images.alt_text: Centurion will remain selective when looking at opportunities for acquisitions or deals, Mr Kong says, as he believes that specialised accommodation assets remain more stable than most other sectors.

site_title: Athleisure a growing trend that's here to stay
summary: Athleisure, a fashion trend combining comfort and style for both exercise and everyday wear, is gaining popularity worldwide, including in Singapore. The trend is driven by consumers seeking multi-functional wardrobes. Meanwhile, various business news stories cover topics such as US shoemaker Levi's revenue growth, Adidas and Puma's plans to revive running shoes, and Merck's potential $10 billion deal for a lung therapy firm. In Singapore, news includes a public offer for NTT DC Reit, changes in CEO positions at OCBC, and insights into affluents' retirement needs.

site_title: Lam embarks on drive to help HK residents shift to China for work
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam is set to meet in Beijing on Tuesday to discuss making it easier for Hong Kong residents to live and work on the mainland, amid violent anti-China protests in the city. The meeting aims to attract "high-end talent" with tax breaks and encourage innovation and entrepreneurship. Lam has promoted the Greater Bay Area as a way to provide jobs and ease social tensions, as an increasing number of Hong Kong people are moving to the mainland. The protests, which have turned violent for the 22nd consecutive weekend, demand an independent probe into perceived police brutality.

site_title: Australia's Westpac looks to raise A$2.5b as profit slumps 15%
summary: Westpac Banking Corp is seeking to raise A$2.5 billion in capital from shareholders due to a 15% decline in full-year cash earnings. The Australian lender plans to use the funds to boost capital levels to meet tougher regulatory requirements. This move comes as the country's "Big Four" banks face increasing competition and a collective bill of A$8 billion in one-off charges related to wrongful practices. Westpac's first dividend cut in a decade is also part of its efforts to strengthen its financial position.

site_title: Pakistani train inferno was decades in the making
summary: A train fire in Pakistan killed at least 75 people and injured 43, with officials blaming passengers who used a prohibited gas stove. The incident occurred under Prime Minister Imran Khan, who has not improved Pakistan's train safety record despite promising transparency and governance. The country's train safety record has not improved since Khan took office, with 74 accidents in the year ended in July, compared to 67 the previous year. The government and Khan's administration are facing criticism for their handling of the disaster, with many demanding that the railway minister, Sheikh Rashid Ahmed, resign.

site_title: Spacetech firm Aliena secures S$1.5m, inks partnership with Northern Territory government
summary: Singapore-based startup Aliena has secured S$1.5 million in funding from Cap Vista, 500 Startups, and Paspalis Innovation Investment Fund. The investment will be used to develop and test Aliena's electric propulsion technology, which enables advanced satellite manoeuvres. The company aims to build a stable pipeline of customers for its technology, which could reduce space debris by allowing satellites to de-orbit. Aliena has partnered with the Northern Territory government to develop a collaborative platform for firms in the region to access turnkey solutions for space projects.

site_title: For theatres, the rise of streaming is a movie they've seen before
summary: Cinemas have a chance to survive as long as they provide an appealing experience and movie studios ensure new releases are shown on the big screen. Despite the rise of streaming, the number of movie screens in the US has risen by over 80% since 1987, while ticket sales have doubled to nearly $12 billion in 2018. Theatre owners attribute the industry's resilience to the communal experience and affordability of going to the movies, and some see streaming as a way to boost theatres by showcasing original content.

site_title: A busy week of data and earnings reports
summary: Asian markets are expected to benefit from the US market's strong finish last Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching record highs. The US economy added 128,000 jobs in October, beating forecasts. Meanwhile, investors will be watching the 14th East Asia Summit in Thailand and the US-China trade negotiations, with potential implications for global trade tensions and risk appetite. The Singapore market will also see corporate earnings releases, including CapitaLand and OCBC Bank, and manufacturing PMI data.

site_title: China committed to supporting Asean centrality: Premier Li
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang reaffirmed China's commitment to supporting Asean centrality in East Asian cooperation, citing strengthened political trust and progress on a code of conduct for the South China Sea. The code of conduct, aimed at addressing territorial claims, is expected to be concluded within three years. Premier Lee Hsien Loong welcomed the developments, emphasizing the need for effective and substantive cooperation, particularly in the face of global economic challenges.

site_title: Institutions build deemed interests in tech sector leaders
summary: In the Singapore stock market, the Straits Times Index gained 1.9% from Oct 25 to 31, with the Nikkei 225 Index, Hang Seng Index, and S&P/ASX 200 Index averaging a 0.6% gain. Share buybacks totaled S$4,947,979, with Keppel Reit, Stamford Land Corporation, and Global Investments leading the consideration tally. Notable director and substantial shareholder transactions included GuocoLand's acquisition by Guoco Group, Venture Corporation's increased deemed interest by Schroders, and AEM Holdings' increased deemed interest by UBS Group.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's weekly shipping market report shows the Capesize market closing the week at $24,637, slightly down from its opening price of $24,945. The market had initially risen before declining mid-week. No other significant market updates were provided in the article.

site_title: China, S-E Asia states push trade pact despite India doubts
summary: China and Southeast Asian states pushed for a swift agreement on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), but India's demands have raised doubts about reaching a provisional agreement by Monday. Despite this, Thailand's commerce minister said the deal could be signed by February 2020. The US-China trade war has increased regional economic growth, but India's concerns about Chinese imports have hindered progress. The 16 countries involved in the RCEP would account for a third of global GDP and nearly half the world's population, but a potential flood of Chinese imports has stalled negotiations.

site_title: KSA opens up for tourism
summary: Saudi Arabia has introduced a one-year, multiple entry visa for visitors from 49 nationalities, including Singapore, allowing up to 90 days in the country. The visa costs 440 SAR/S$160 and aims to diversify the economy and attract 100 million international and domestic visitors by 2030, creating a million jobs and generating significant foreign investment. This move is part of Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030, a plan to reduce dependence on oil and promote tourism and economic growth.

site_title: Pacific Star warns of net loss for Q1 FY20
summary: Pacific Star Development has warned of a net loss for the first quarter of FY20 due to tough market conditions and higher finance costs. The losses were mainly incurred from the sales of Puteri Cove Residences in Malaysia and a S$70 million facility obtained in Q2 FY19. This is the first warning from the company in FY20, citing challenging market conditions.

site_title: Google's Fitbit acquisition gets instant antitrust scrutiny
summary: Google's $2.1 billion acquisition of Fitbit Inc has drawn antitrust scrutiny from US lawmakers, raising concerns over the tech giant's dominance in the US market for fitness tracking devices and data. The deal is expected to face a protracted regulatory review amid current focus on competition and privacy issues in the tech industry. Google and Fitbit anticipate this regulatory attention, indicating the acquisition may have significant implications for the tech industry.

site_title: Speculators pare net long US dollar bets
summary: Speculators have reduced their net long US dollar bets to a nine-week low, with a value of $13.28 billion in the week ending Oct 29. This decrease comes as the US dollar's favorable position with investors has weakened amid easing trade tensions between the US and China. The dollar index fell 0.6% for the week, and the pound rose 5.3% against the dollar, its largest monthly gain in over a decade.

site_title: Pacific Star Development says it expects to post net loss for 1QFY20
summary: Pacific Star Development expects to report a net loss for the first quarter of FY20 due to challenging market conditions and higher finance costs. The losses stem from a decline in sales of Puteri Cove Residences in Malaysia, with sale-and-purchase agreements yet to meet revenue recognition criteria. The company is still finalizing its results, which will be released on or before November 14.

site_title: Where Jaws, the ride, lives forever
summary: A fan of Universal Studios Orlando's Jaws-themed ride captured the final moments of the attraction and uploaded it to YouTube, garnering over 160 million views. This phenomenon of "last-ride" videos, where park archivists document the final moments of closed attractions, has become a thriving genre. The nostalgia and longing for expired rides, as seen in the case of Jaws, have given rise to a cottage industry of podcasts, books, websites, and documentaries chronicling the rise and fall of former theme park attractions.

site_title: Henderson to lend brownfield land to govt for housing
summary: Henderson Land Development has agreed to lend 428,000 sq ft of brownfield land in Hong Kong to the government for seven years to build 2,000 transitional housing units. This move aims to tackle Hong Kong's housing shortage, where millions of protesters have taken to the streets. The agreement follows a request from the Hong Kong and Chinese governments for developers to contribute back to the community.

site_title: Companies raise over S$500,000 towards planting of 30,000 trees on Jurong Island
summary: Companies in Singapore's Jurong Island have raised over S$500,000 to plant 30,000 trees over the next three years, aiming to cool temperatures and enhance the ecosystem on the industrial estate. The initiative, led by the National Parks Board and JTC, has already seen 2,000 trees planted since March, with oil and gas company ExxonMobil and the Association of Process Industry contributing significantly. The project aims to create a more sustainable and attractive workspace for businesses and talent.

site_title: Fintech BondEvalue makes bond trading accessible through blockchain
summary: A Singapore-based fintech firm, BondEvalue, is launching a blockchain-based platform for fractional bond trading, making it possible for investors to buy bonds with a minimum investment of US$1,000, down from the current US$200,000. The platform aims to increase accessibility to the bond market, enabling over 25 million people in Asia to invest in wholesale bonds in the next three to five years. The platform will connect banks, wealth managers, and robo-advisors globally, offering transparency and efficient trade settlement.

site_title: An upward move for GBPUSD soon?
summary: The GBPUSD currency pair is showing signs of a potential upward move after the European Council agreed to a "flextension" allowing the UK more time to consider the Brexit deal, with a possible double top chart pattern forming. The price has broken through resistance at 1.2760 and reached a four-month high of 1.3013, but has since retraced to 1.2790 before bouncing back up to 1.2960. A double top pattern could lead to a 200-pip downward move, but higher highs and lows suggest the potential for further upward momentum.

site_title: SMEs paying more for talent to drive growth
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are increasing salaries to attract top talent, emulating the strategies of startups that have rapidly grown through skilled hires. A company in a niche sector offered a head of human resources a salary of S$300,000 per year, while another technology firm paid 15-25% more than the industry average for a senior finance professional. This trend is driven by the need to drive growth and stay competitive in the market.

site_title: Tesla battery fires catch attention of safety agency
summary: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is investigating possible battery defects in Tesla sedans and SUVs after some cars spontaneously caught fire. The agency is reviewing a petition to investigate defects in battery software updates in 2012-2019 Model S and X vehicles. NHTSA requested Tesla provide software update records and documents related to consumer complaints and car fires. This development raises safety concerns for Tesla, a high-profile electric vehicle manufacturer.

site_title: Beijing 'ready to work' with Asean on South China Sea rules
summary: China has expressed readiness to work with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) on a code of conduct for the South China Sea, a disputed waterway with significant shipping and resource interests. The agreement aims to establish guidelines for the sea and resolve conflicts among claimants, including China, Vietnam, the Philippines, and others. China's Premier Li Keqiang called the draft document a "very important landmark" and stated China's commitment to maintaining long-term peace and stability in the region. The agreement is set to be finalized by 2021.

site_title: Surge in exports to China a double-edged sword
summary: A surge in exports to China from emerging economies in Southeast Asia, particularly Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam, has benefited their development, but also makes them vulnerable to Chinese economic coercion. According to a regional studies expert, the growing trade with China is distinct for wealthier economies and poorer emerging economies. The US remains a significant trading partner, with its share of exports increasing for all 10 Southeast Asian economies. The expert concludes that China's growing importance as a trading partner is good for the region, despite concerns over trade deficits and US influence.

site_title: UOB goes digital to manage B2B cash-on-delivery risks
summary: UOB has launched a digital platform to manage B2B cash-on-delivery risks, targeting SMEs in Singapore. The model replaces traditional methods, such as cheques, which require manual reconciliation and pose risks. The digital platform aims to simplify and secure payment processes, providing a viable alternative to cash-on-delivery.

images.alt_text: United Overseas Bank has launched a QR-based collections solution to allow businesses to collect payments through PayNow at the point of delivery.

site_title: 216 units at Sengkang Grand Residences sold at launch
summary: CapitaLand and City Developments sold 216 of the 280 units at Sengkang Grand Residences at an average price of around S$1,700 per square foot, with 93% of buyers being Singaporeans. The 99-year leasehold development offers access to lifestyle and community options, and prices range from S$798,000 to S$2.1 million. The joint developers clinched the site for S$777.78 million in August 2018.

site_title: SM Tharman: More can be done together
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that more can be done to strengthen bilateral ties between Singapore and Saudi Arabia, building on their existing cooperation in areas such as education, urban planning, and security. He emphasized the complementarity of their economies and the potential for deeper ties in the years to come, citing the presence of over 50 Saudi companies in Singapore and many Singaporean companies in Saudi Arabia. Tharman looks forward to increasing cooperation and partnership, particularly with President Halimah Yacob's upcoming state visit to Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Southern California blaze sears homes, orchards, threatens oil fields
summary: A fast-moving scrub fire in Southern California's Santa Paula area threatened homes, orchards, and oil fields, displacing thousands of residents on November 1, 2019. The Maria fire, which spread across nearly 9,000 acres, posed a risk to citrus and avocado crops, high-voltage power lines, and oil industry infrastructure. Although winds helped firefighters gain control of other wildfires in the region, the Santa Paula fire remained a concern, with 10,800 people under evacuation orders and at least two homes destroyed.

site_title: MIT unit completes acquisition of stake in 3 N America data centres
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust's (MIT) unit completes the acquisition of an 80% stake in three North American data centers for US$810.6 million. MIT raised S$400 million through a private placement to fund the acquisition, while Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit completes the acquisition of an office complex in Irving, Texas, for US$101.5 million. Both deals aim to expand the companies' portfolios and offer new opportunities for growth.

site_title: EHT responds to SGX queries on Urban Commons' links to EHT's biggest investor
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding the sale of six hotels to its sponsor, Urban Commons, ahead of its initial public offering (IPO). EHT stated that asset management firm ASAP sold the hotels to the sponsor to gain transaction certainty independent of the IPO process. The sale was conducted prior to the IPO, and EHT acquired the hotels from the sponsor on its listing date. The relationship between ASAP and Urban Commons was not disclosed, but EHT clarified that ASAP is independent from the sponsor and the managers.

site_title: Bulls awaiting progress on trade agreement
summary: US stocks broke records for the first time since summer, driven by the jobs report, a US Federal Reserve rate cut, and solid corporate earnings results. However, progress on a US-China trade agreement is awaited, which has been a major point of concern for bulls. The phase one deal, unveiled by US President Donald Trump, has been met with mixed reactions, with some reports suggesting it may be a "skinny" or "mini" version of the comprehensive deal originally envisioned. Economists expect a tariff rollback to be essential for the market, and a non-deal or a cursory agreement could rattle market confidence.

site_title: Hong Kong braces for 'emergency' protest call for autonomy
summary: Hong Kong is bracing for a "global emergency call" as protesters, led by Joshua Wong, march on Saturday to demand autonomy for the Asian financial hub. The 22nd straight weekend of protests, which began five months ago, aims to raise awareness of perceived Chinese meddling with Hong Kong's freedoms. The protesters, who have clashed with police, are calling for 100,000 people to join the rally. The unrest has led to a recession, with retail sales falling 18.3% in September, and has sparked concerns about the future of Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: Asean summit: Leaders meet under trade war cloud; region must stick together, says Mahathir
summary: Southeast Asian leaders gathered for a regional summit in Bangkok, where they must navigate the trade war cloud cast by US President Donald Trump. Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad urged the 10-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) to stand together against the US-China tensions. Despite initial hopes to finalize the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), no significant progress was made, and the summit's main focus was on trade. The US delegation, led by Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, was downgraded, sparking concerns about Washington's diminished influence in the region.

site_title: 216 units at Sengkang Grand Residences sold over launch weekend
summary: 216 units at Sengkang Grand Residences were sold at an average price of S$1,700 per square foot within the launch weekend, with 93% of buyers being Singaporeans. The units, ranging from 474 to 1,324 square feet, were sold at prices starting from S$798,000 for a one-bedroom plus study unit. Co-developers CapitaLand and City Developments Limited attributed the strong sales to the project's attractive pricing, well-designed layout, and convenient location atop a transport hub and integrated community.

site_title: Makings of a leading-edge economy
summary: A highly competitive economy is characterized by a stable and trusted government, a highly skilled and diversified talent pool, and a keen embrace of game-changing technologies. Key attributes include openness to change, embracing automation and AI, building a vibrant entrepreneurship ecosystem, and fostering a culture of innovation, collaboration, and continuous learning. Countries like Singapore have demonstrated success by investing in talent development, embracing digital transformation, and providing a supportive regulatory environment. Ultimately, a highly competitive economy is one that drives innovation from the grassroots, promotes sustainable growth, and is characterized by a strong focus on human capital, technology, and entrepreneurship.

site_title: Toxic air in India declared public health emergency
summary: India's capital and suburbs have been declared a public health emergency due to severe air pollution, with readings reaching as high as 744 on Saturday. The toxic air, caused by factors like construction dust, vehicle emissions, and farm stubble burning, prompted school closures until November 5. The government has ordered a ban on construction and industrial activities, as well as the bursting of firecrackers, to mitigate the issue. The problem is exacerbated by the use of combine harvesters that leave 80% of stubble residue in fields, which is then burned.

site_title: OCBC Bank lets startups open business account immediately after incorporation
summary: OCBC Bank has introduced a new system allowing startups to open business accounts immediately after incorporation, rather than waiting a day. This is made possible through an API with Experian, which validates a startup's business profile. The move aims to strengthen the connections among startup ecosystem players and support businesses in their early stages. The bank notes that this streamlined process will benefit many businesses, with over 65,000 incorporated in the past year. This initiative reflects OCBC's role as a banker to more than half of Singapore's SMEs.

site_title: Pig deaths on Russian border suggest China's outbreak is spreading
summary: Russia reports nearly 60 outbreaks of African swine fever along its border with China, with infected wild boar potentially playing a role in the cross-border spread. The virus has been present in Russia for 12 years but has only recently started to spread actively in the Far East. Experts suggest that wild boar may be infected in northern China, raising concerns that the outbreak may be spreading.

site_title: Huawei moving on 5G while politics plays out
summary: Huawei is expanding its 5G network in China despite US regulators proposing rules to block the company from buying from Chinese tech companies. The new networks will offer economic and technological advantages, helping China close the technology gap with the US. US regulators aim to remove Huawei's equipment already in place and prevent new purchases. China's state telecom operators are rolling out the 5G advances, with the goal of staying competitive in the global market amid the ongoing trade war.

site_title: China's Fosun buys Thomas Cook brand for £11 million
summary: China's Fosun buys Thomas Cook brand for £11 million, weeks after the British travel group's bankruptcy, leaving hundreds of thousands of holidaymakers stranded abroad. The 178-year-old institution declared bankruptcy in September after failing to secure US$250 million from private investors. This purchase marks a significant move by Fosun to expand its presence in the travel industry, following Thomas Cook's demise.

site_title: Germany's Merkel renews push for free trade pact with India, pledges green funds
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel renewed efforts to finalize a free trade agreement with India, calling for a new attempt to restart talks. Merkel, who met with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, emphasized the need for a pact to benefit German companies operating in India, citing concerns over bureaucracy and uncertainty. Germany pledged €1 billion in green funds for India over the next five years to support environment-friendly projects, such as electric buses. The move comes amid India's air pollution crisis.

site_title: China effectively bans online sales of e-cigarettes
summary: China has effectively banned online sales of e-cigarettes, citing health concerns for minors, after a Chinese regulator and state tobacco monopoly urged manufacturers and sellers to shut down websites related to the marketing and sale of e-cigarettes. The move comes just two weeks before Singles Day, one of China's busiest online shopping days, and could shut off one of the biggest markets for the industry. Despite ambiguity, some online platforms and e-cigarette brands have removed products from their offerings, with RELX stating it will terminate all sales and advertising on the internet.

site_title: Ford is said to shift plans again for underused Mustang plant
summary: Ford is shifting production of a new model from its underutilized Mustang plant in Michigan to a factory in Ohio, where it will invest $900 million. The plant in Flat Rock will only assemble the Mustang and Lincoln Continental sedan. This change comes after Ford initially planned to build electric vehicles alongside Mustangs at the Michigan plant and add a second shift. The decision aims to keep the Michigan plant open, with Ford committing to explore future product opportunities over the next four years.

site_title: WhatsApp message promising workers S$6,500 is fake: Ministry of Manpower
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore issued a scam alert, debunking a fake WhatsApp message claiming employees could receive S$6,500 as an employment benefit. The message contained a fake website link, which has since been taken down. MOM advised the public to use the official website for information and transactions, and provided tips to identify and report fake websites and communications. The ministry will continue to monitor and bring down fake MOM websites to keep the official website and data safe.

site_title: Trump announces new acting US homeland security chief
summary: US President Donald Trump announced Friday that Chad Wolf, a senior department official, will become the nation's new acting homeland security chief. Wolf, currently a undersecretary, will replace Kevin McAleenan, who resigned three weeks ago. This marks the latest departure in a long list of top officials to leave Trump's administration.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump announced Friday that a senior department official, Chad Wolf, would become the nation's new acting homeland security chief, a role at the center of his crackdown on undocumented immigration.

site_title: Elon Musk says he is disconnecting from Twitter
summary: Elon Musk announced he's disconnecting from Twitter, citing it as "not good" and opting for Reddit instead. This decision comes after multiple run-ins with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) over his Twitter use, including a defamation lawsuit and charges of misleading investors. Musk had previously agreed to settle with the SEC, but his farewell tweet sparked thousands of replies, with many expressing sadness and urging him to reveal his next online platform. Musk has been sued for defamation and has faced SEC charges over his Twitter posts.

site_title: On eve of China import fair, EU warns of 'promise fatigue'
summary: The European Union warned China to make substantial improvements to its business environment ahead of China's import fair in Shanghai, citing "promise fatigue" due to past broken promises. China has faced criticism for unfair trade practices, including forced tech transfers and protectionist policies. The EU's comments come as China seeks to showcase its free trade credentials and follow the fair. Failure to deliver on promises could lead to further strain on EU-China relations.

site_title: Jungle hikes and Shark Tank teach Asia's young heirs to stay rich
summary: Asia's wealthy families are shifting their focus from traditional industries to startups, impact investing, and socially responsible investing, as their young heirs seek to make a difference. The Bank of Singapore's GenINFINITY Program and other institutions are adapting their summer schools to cater to this new generation, offering crash courses in entrepreneurship, leadership, and sustainability. The programs include Shark Tank-style competitions, AI discussions, and immersive experiences, such as hiking in Borneo to learn about sustainability. As the first generation of tycoons relinquishes control, institutions are investing in their next generation of clients, with some programs costing upwards of $600 million.

site_title: As 'streaming wars' rage, social networks create own TV series
summary: Social networks such as Facebook, YouTube, and Snapchat are creating their own original TV series to compete with streaming giants like Disney, HBO, and Apple. Despite charging subscriptions, these platforms offer free content to attract advertisers and align with top talent. YouTube's focus on quality over quantity has led to a slowdown in production, while Facebook's strategy emphasizes prestige content to boost its image. Snapchat, on the other hand, prioritizes quantity and short-form content to engage users on its platform.

site_title: Asean summit: India's Modi seeks more on services to complete trade deal
summary: Leaders from Asia gathered in Bangkok for the Asean summit, seeking a breakthrough in talks on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), a China-backed trade pact. India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi expressed desire for greater ambition on services, while AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes said the US-China trade battle is benefiting his business. A joint statement on RCEP is expected, with talks continuing despite last-minute requests from India. The deal would cover one-third of the global economy and has the potential to add $1 trillion to the Asean digital economy by 2025.

site_title: Tiffany & Co likely to play hard to get as LVMH awaits answer
summary: LVMH has proposed a US$14.5 billion takeover of Tiffany & Co, but the jeweler is expected to reject the offer as being too low. Tiffany's board is reviewing the proposal with the assistance of advisers, and its chairman Roger Farah has declined to comment. LVMH believes Tiffany should command a similar earnings multiple to its Bulgari acquisition, but analysts have set a target price of US$130 or more for Tiffany. The companies have not engaged in discussions since LVMH presented the offer in October.

site_title: Drug imports will not lower US prices, says Canadian ambassador
summary: Canada's acting ambassador, Kirsten Hillman, stated that importing prescription drugs from Canada would not significantly lower US prices due to the country's limited supply. A 2019 study found that if 40% of US prescriptions were filled from Canada, the Canadian supply would run out in 118 days. Hillman emphasized Canada's commitment to working with the US to improve citizens' health while ensuring a steady supply of medications at affordable prices for Canadians, which remains a priority.

site_title: Google buying Fitbit for US$2.1b in move into wearables, digital health
summary: Google has agreed to buy Fitbit for $2.1 billion, expanding its presence in the wearable technology space and challenging Apple's dominance. The deal gives Google a fresh entry into hardware, allowing it to bring together its best hardware, software, and AI to create more wearables. Fitbit's platform will remain platform-agnostic and compatible with both iOS and Android devices. The acquisition may also enable Google to expand into digital health, following Apple's partnerships with researchers and medical facilities. Google will protect user data and will not use Fitbit-generated data for ad targeting.

site_title: Improved regulations to create pro-enterprise environment for Singapore's food sector
summary: Singapore has introduced improved regulations to create a pro-enterprise environment for its food sector, aiming to reduce compliance costs and support innovation. Companies with a good track record can now have their halal certification renewed automatically and the period of cover doubled to two years, saving approximately 74,000 man-hours per annum. Additionally, food businesses can request joint inspections by the Singapore Civil Defence Force and Singapore Food Agency, reducing the need for separate appointments and allowing them to operate up to three weeks earlier.

site_title: US-China trade accord will require 3 phases: White House adviser
summary: The US and China are making progress toward a "phase one" trade agreement, with White House adviser Peter Navarro stating that three phases are needed to address China's "structural deadly sins." An enforcement mechanism is the linchpin of the agreement, allowing the US to impose tariffs without fear of retaliation. The first phase, expected to be completed soon, focuses on trade and investment, with future phases addressing intellectual property, financial services, and other issues. The agreement aims to alleviate the impact of nearly 16 months of tariffs on global growth.

site_title: US opens national security investigation into TikTok: sources
summary: The US government has launched a national security review of TikTok owner Beijing ByteDance Technology's acquisition of Musical.ly, a US social media app. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) has started to review the deal, citing concerns about censorship and data storage. US lawmakers have called for a probe, citing the potential risks of a Chinese company handling sensitive US user data. CFIUS is in talks with TikTok about measures to avoid divesting the Musical.ly assets, and the company has committed to working with Congress and regulators.

site_title: Fracking halted in England over earthquake fears: UK government
summary: The UK government has halted fracking in England due to concerns over triggering earthquakes. The decision comes after a report found it was not possible to accurately predict the risks of hydraulic fracturing. The move is seen as a victory for campaigners and environmentalists, who have long opposed the practice. The government will not issue any further Hydraulic Fracturing Consents unless new evidence is provided.

site_title: Ex-Citigroup currency trader testifies greed helped rig system
summary: A former Citigroup currency trader, Christopher Cummins, testified in Manhattan federal court that he and rivals at other banks plotted to rig currency trades, making more money while customers were misled into competing. Cummins, who pleaded guilty to conspiring to fix prices in 2017, is testifying for the government against former JPMorgan Chase trader Akshay Aiyer, who faces up to 10 years in prison and a $1 million fine if convicted. This case is part of a multi-year Justice Department probe that has resulted in over $10 billion in penalties for banks.

site_title: Aramco meets investors in last-minute bid to hit US$2 trillion IPO target
summary: Saudi Aramco officials are holding last-minute meetings with investors to achieve a US$2 trillion valuation ahead of the expected Sunday announcement of the state-owned oil giant's initial public offering (IPO). The valuation, considered too ambitious by some, may be closer to US$1.5 trillion. The IPO's success is crucial for Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's plans to diversify the Saudi economy and attract investment from sovereign wealth funds. The company will pay a base dividend of US$75 billion, with a valuation of US$2 trillion offering a 3.75% dividend yield.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records after strong US jobs data
summary: US stocks surged to fresh records, with the S&P 500, Nasdaq, and Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1.0%, 1.1%, and 1.1% respectively. The strong labor market, with 128,000 new jobs added last month, and positive comments on a partial trade deal with China, boosted markets. The S&P 500 reached a new high of 3,066.91, while the Nasdaq surpassed its all-time high of 8,386.40. These gains came despite ongoing trade uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: White House will look 'very carefully' at Peugeot, Fiat Chrysler deal
summary: The US administration, led by President Donald Trump, will closely examine the planned merger between Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot owner PSA. The 50-50 merger would create the world's fourth-largest automaker, with annual sales of nearly 9 million vehicles. The deal has raised concerns over Chinese ownership, with Dongfeng Motors holding a 12.2% stake in PSA. The White House will assess the potential impact on US employment and production, as well as the implications of Chinese investment in the US market.

site_title: Alibaba beats quarterly revenue estimates, shares rise
summary: Alibaba Group Holding reported a 40% rise in second-quarter revenue to 119.02 billion yuan (S$23 billion), beating analyst estimates. E-commerce sales rose 40% and cloud computing revenue jumped 64%. The company's shares rose over 2% to US$180.25, driven by strong growth in its e-commerce and cloud computing businesses. Alibaba gears up for its annual Single's Day shopping event, competing with Pinduoduo Inc for sales in China's smaller cities.

site_title: The need to disclose conflicts of interest
summary: Singapore's real estate and investment industries face issues with undisclosed conflicts of interest, leading to subpar outcomes for clients. A real estate agent was suspended for 12 months and fined for failing to disclose a conflict of interest in a 2017 transaction. A researcher was jailed for secretly inflating prices of laboratory products to her employer. To avoid such outcomes, disclosure of conflicts of interest is crucial, particularly in the investment profession. Investment management professionals must make full and fair disclosures of matters that could impair their independence and objectivity.

site_title: Democrat Beto O'Rourke quits 2020 White House race
summary: Democrat Beto O'Rourke has dropped out of the 2020 US presidential nomination race, citing stagnant polling numbers and dwindling finances. Despite being a frontrunner initially, O'Rourke failed to re-ignite enthusiasm, with recent polling showing only 2% support. He had been a fierce critic of President Donald Trump and had expressed anger towards him following a mass shooting in his hometown of El Paso. O'Rourke's campaign team ruled out another Senate run in Texas for now, and he will not be a candidate for the US Senate in 2020.

site_title: Four keys to post-retirement investing
summary: Retirees can effectively plan and invest for life by matching their investment approaches to relevant expense categories. Four key categories to consider are Living, Lifestyle, Contingency, and Legacy. A post-retirement plan should structure a mix of investments to meet each category's needs, such as minimizing market downturns and maximizing growth potential. Over-allocation to cash can undermine retirement outcomes, and shifting funds to assets with higher return characteristics can have material benefits. A tailored investment approach can help retirees achieve a sustainable income level and plan for unexpected life events.

site_title: Judge dismisses Uber lawsuit opposing New York vehicle licence caps
summary: A Manhattan judge has dismissed Uber's lawsuit against a New York City law limiting the number of ride-hailing service licences. The law, Local Law 147, was meant to give the city greater oversight of ride-hailing companies. The judge rejected Uber's argument that the law gave the Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC) excessive power and was not in conflict with the city's congestion pricing plan. The decision allows the cap on new licences to remain in effect, which was seen as a victory for drivers who would be impacted by the cap.

site_title: China, US hold 'constructive' call on trade mini-deal
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He spoke by telephone, describing their call as "constructive" and reiterating efforts to formalize a partial trade deal. Trump mentioned the possibility of meeting with Xi Jinping in Iowa, while details of the deal remain scarce. The conversation was similar to last week's, despite Trump announcing the partial deal on October 11.

site_title: Melons, potatoes were downfall of Cabinet ministers who resigned in Japan
summary: Two Japanese Cabinet ministers, Trade Minister Isshu Sugawara and Justice Minister Katsuyuki Kawai, have resigned in the past week amid accusations of giving luxury produce, such as cantaloupes and potatoes, to constituents as campaign gifts. The ministers denied wrongdoing but stepped down due to investigations. The swift exits reflect Japan's strict approach to following rules and its by-the-book culture, where even small gifts are seen as problematic. The country's emphasis on gift-giving, such as omiyage souvenirs, may have contributed to the ministers' downfall.

images.alt_text: The first to go was Isshu Sugawara, the trade minister, who was accused of sending cantaloupes and crab - luxury items that can be quite expensive in Japan - to constituents, as well as improperly paying about US$185 as a funeral condolence gift to a voter.

site_title: Impending sale could lead to rebranding for London's Ritz
summary: The Barclay brothers are selling London's iconic Ritz hotel, with a shortlist of potential buyers from the Middle East, Hong Kong, Singapore, and European and US families. The sale, brokered by Jones Lang LaSalle and Spartan Advisors, could fetch up to £800 million (S$1.4 billion), a 70% premium over the price of the Maybourne Hotel Group stake sold in 2015. The buyer will have the option to rebrand the hotel and potentially transform the adjacent casino into a private members' club or alternative use.

site_title: UOB Q3 results get boost from wealth management
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported an 8% rise in third-quarter net profit to S$1.12 billion, beating analysts' average estimate of S$1.07 billion. Wealth management income surged 38% to S$183 million, while trading and investment income grew 67% to S$310 million. Non-interest income rose 27% to S$922 million, driven by healthy loan growth. Despite a dip in net interest margin, the bank maintained growth momentum across revenue streams.

site_title: Mixed picture for China's October manufacturing sector
summary: China's October manufacturing sector survey showed a mixed picture, with the Caixin PMI rising to 51.7 for small and medium firms and the official PMI falling to 49.3 for larger state-owned firms. The Caixin survey indicated a pick-up in demand, led by new export orders, while the official survey showed continued weakness in demand. The mixed results make it difficult to gauge the Chinese economy's performance at the start of the fourth quarter, with analysts warning that the rebound could be short-lived due to ongoing trade tensions and deflationary risks.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Resources Prima Group's CFO, Thng Tien Lung, is leaving the company after serving a two-month notice period, citing other career opportunities. Lung, 48, was appointed CFO in February 2020 and will leave on December 7. Nico Steel has extended its property lease at 51 Loyang Way for 20 years, committing to developing the property and investing S$460,000 in machinery and equipment.

site_title: Second man charged over UK truck deaths, victims now thought to be Vietnamese
summary: A second man, Eamon Harrison, 23, from Northern Ireland, has been charged with 39 counts of manslaughter, human trafficking, and immigration offenses over the deaths of 39 people found in a truck container near London. The victims, initially believed to be Chinese, are now thought to be Vietnamese. Harrison appeared in Dublin's High Court for extradition proceedings, while British police continue to investigate and appeal for two men from Northern Ireland, Ronan and Christopher Hughes, who are suspected of involvement in the human trafficking case.

images.alt_text: A second man was charged with manslaughter over the deaths of 39 people found in the back of a truck near London, British police said on Friday, as they confirmed they now believe all the victims were Vietnamese.

site_title: Oil rises nearly 4% on US-China trade hopes, but sets weekly decline
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 4% on Friday, driven by signs of progress in US-China trade talks and stronger-than-expected economic data. Brent crude rose to $61.69 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $56.20 a barrel.
