The US aims to sign an initial trade deal with China this month, offering reassurance to global markets. Despite this, oil prices are expected to remain under pressure this year, according to a Reuters survey, which forecasts Brent crude to average $64.16 a barrel in 2019.

site_title: Busier Q2 gives Netlink's net profit a 24.1% lift
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported a 24.1% increase in net profit for the second quarter ended September, driven by higher residential connections revenue and installation-related revenue. The trust's net profit rose to S$23.2 million, an improvement from S$18.7 million in the same period last year. Revenue increased 3.8% to S$94.1 million, with residential connections contributing 61.2% of total revenue. The trust expects to generate higher revenues from key connection services in FY2020, with capital expenditure also expected to be higher.

site_title: Facebook isn't defending free speech, it's assaulting the truth for you and I
summary: A Facebook executive is accusing the company of assaulting the truth by allowing demonstrably false ads to be posted from political candidates, despite Mark Zuckerberg's defense of free speech. The author of the screenplay for "The Social Network" claims that Facebook's practice of posting false ads is undermining democracy and can have a real and dangerous effect on elections. He argues that this is not about defending free speech, but about ensuring that lies do not have unfettered access to the American electorate.

site_title: Europe: Shares end week on cheery note after US and Chinese data
summary: European shares ended the week on a positive note, with the STOXX 600 index closing 0.7% higher, driven by upbeat US jobs data and a surprise bounce in Chinese manufacturing. US job growth slowed less than expected, while China's factory activity unexpectedly expanded at its fastest pace in over two years. The US Federal Reserve also lowered borrowing costs, signaling no further reductions unless the US economy slows. This boosted mining stocks, which jumped 3.2%, and some European companies, such as Novo Nordisk, rose on strong earnings reports.

images.alt_text: European shares clocked their best day in over a week on Friday, as upbeat jobs data from the United States and a surprise bounce in Chinese manufacturing tempered nerves around slowing global growth.

site_title: WTO authorises Chinese tariffs on US$3.6b in US goods in anti-dumping tiff
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has authorised China to impose tariffs on US$3.58 billion worth of US goods annually due to US anti-dumping practices. The decision, made by a WTO arbitrator, marks the first time the WTO has authorised China to impose tariffs in a trade dispute. China had initially sought to impose US$7 billion in tariffs, but the WTO ruling found that the US practices caused China to lose US$3.58 billion in benefits. The US has voiced disappointment and plans to discuss the decision with stakeholders.

site_title: Australian home prices boast biggest monthly increase since 2015
summary: Australian home prices rose 1.2% in October, the largest monthly increase since 2015, driven by record-low interest rates and looser lending standards. This marks the fourth straight month of gains, a boon for the economy after a two-year downturn. Prices in Melbourne surged 2.3% and in Sydney rose 1.7%, with values in both cities still down from last year. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to maintain interest rates at 0.75% at its November policy meeting.

site_title: Fixing delayed flights
summary: Business travelers face inefficient airlines and airports, resulting in delayed flights. Despite exponential growth in technology to ensure fast turnarounds, planes are flying later and later. The issue is exacerbated by crowded skies, limited landing and take-off slots, and varying airline standards. Experts suggest setting higher punctuality standards, especially for morning departures, and passengers can vote with their wallets by switching airlines. Reclaiming professional standards and addressing airport capacity issues are necessary to improve on-time performance.

site_title: A-Reit's acquisition of business park assets marks foray into US
summary: Ascendas Reit has acquired 30 business park properties in the US and Singapore from its sponsor CapitaLand for S$1.66 billion. The US properties, valued at US$938 million, span 310,102 sq m and are home to tenants such as Nike and Oracle. The acquisition will increase A-Reit's overseas investment to 28% of its total asset value and strengthen its existing business and science-park portfolio. The deal is funded by a S$1.3 billion rights issue and is expected to generate a first-year net property income yield of 6.3%.

site_title: Feast for the ears and the eyes
summary: Apple has released the AirPods Pro, its first true wireless headphones with active noise cancellation technology. Priced at S$379, the earbuds feature a new design with a shorter stem and larger driver housing, and come with silicone ear tips and a charging case that can charge via Lightning or Qi charging pads. The AirPods Pro also feature a Force Sensor on the stem for controlling music playback and switching between noise cancellation and Transparency mode. Meanwhile, Razer has released its Hammerhead True Wireless earbuds, priced at S$158.90, which offer optimized Bluetooth 5.0 connectivity and a gaming mode with low latency.

site_title: SE Asia's biggest travel app Traveloka eyes dual listing, bets on fintech
summary: Traveloka, Southeast Asia's largest online travel startup, is considering a dual listing in Indonesia and another center, such as the US, to boost profits. The company, backed by Expedia and JD.com, has 35 million active users and aims to raise $500 million. However, its initial public offering (IPO) plans have been delayed due to economic uncertainties, citing a slowing global economy and poor performance of newly listed firms. Traveloka plans to focus on fundraising and expand its financial services, targeting under-banked Indonesian customers with its PayLater product.

site_title: Regional leaders meet amid urgency for RCEP deal, downgraded US presence
summary: Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) talks between 16 parties, including Asean member states, China, India, and the US, are underway in Bangkok amid economic uncertainty. US President Donald Trump has sent National Security Adviser Robert O'Brien and Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross to the summit, a move seen as a downgrade of US presence. Negotiators aim to finalize 20 chapters, but progress is slow due to India's resistance to cheap Chinese goods. The RCEP deal, if completed, would be the world's largest free trade pact.

site_title: JTC to build new semiconductor facility in Tampines, refurbish 4 wafer fab parks
summary: JTC Corporation is building a new semiconductor facility in Tampines, with the first phase to be completed by 2021. The facility will be purpose-built in three phases to meet the needs of semiconductor companies. Additionally, JTC is refurbishing its four wafer fabrication parks with greenery and connecting them to the islandwide Park Connector Network, expected to be completed by 2025. These moves aim to support the electronics sector, which accounts for 90,000 jobs and 7% of Singapore's GDP.

site_title: SIA Engineering posts Q2 net profit of S$46 million
summary: SIA Engineering reported a 21.1% increase in net profit to S$46 million for the second quarter ended September, driven by higher airframe and line maintenance revenue and lower expenditure. This represents a significant improvement from the year-ago period. The company's bottom line performance was announced in a media statement on November 1, 2019.

site_title: Gojek-Grab food fight helping to keep Indonesia inflation in check
summary: Indonesia's inflation remains under control, with a 3.1% increase in October, the slowest pace in six months, thanks to a price war between ride-hailing apps Gojek and Grab on everyday groceries. The competition has led to discounts of up to 50% on online purchases, making food more affordable and allowing the central bank to cut interest rates. This has helped keep inflationary pressures in check, with growth in food prices easing to 4.8% in October from 5.4% in September.

site_title: Goals galore: football's memorable lopsided matches
summary: Football has witnessed several memorable lopsided matches, with teams scoring unusually large margins. Notable examples include Leicester City's 9-0 win over Southampton, Manchester United's 9-0 victory over Ipswich Town, Brazil's 7-1 loss to Germany in the 2014 World Cup semi-final, the US Women's team's 13-0 win over Thailand in the 2019 World Cup, and Australia's 31-0 win over American Samoa in a 2001 World Cup qualifier. These extreme scorelines have become a rarity in the competitive world of professional football.

site_title: Singapore Exchange has a potential billion-dollar war chest to explore deals: analysts
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is set to tap its debt issuance programme to fund potential acquisitions worth around $1 billion, according to analysts. The exchange has a cash balance of $787 million and plans to raise $1.5 billion via debt instruments. This funding will allow SGX to double its fixed income, currencies, and commodities unit's revenues and make bolt-on acquisitions in financial technology and complementary businesses. Analysts expect the bourse to spend on acquisitions and diversify its revenue streams into derivatives and data businesses.

site_title: Hammer time: What the auction numbers are saying about the property market
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Auction numbers in Singapore's property market indicate a record number of mortgagee sales, with 362 listings in the first half of 2019, a 28.2% quarter-on-quarter increase. The residential sector saw a 69.4% year-on-year increase in listings under mortgagee sale, with prime properties being hardest hit. Cooling measures and rising interest rates contributed to the increase in mortgagee sales. The retail sector also saw a record high in mortgagee listings, with shoebox retail units being the most affected. Experts expect mortgagee listings to continue their uptrend, with some predicting a boost in demand for auction properties.

site_title: UK government defends Brexit deal after Trump's trade warning
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit deal with the European Union (EU) has been defended by his office after US President Donald Trump warned it would hinder future trade agreements. Trump stated that the UK's divorce terms would make a trade deal impossible. However, a Downing Street spokesman countered that the deal would allow the UK to strike its own free trade deals globally. The comments come ahead of the UK's snap election, with Johnson's Conservative party riding high in opinion polls.

site_title: Straits Times Index up 1.38% on the week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.38% on Friday, closing at 3,229.43, despite a mixed performance across Asian markets. Investors initially reacted to concerns over the US-China trade deal, but a positive manufacturing survey from China and a farm-in deal for a Norwegian Sea drilling licence boosted gains. AEM Holdings' 20% year-on-year improvement in Q3 net profit also contributed to the rally, with shares gaining 2%. Index stocks such as Genting Singapore and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding closed flat, while UOB shares fell 0.97%.

site_title: Futures are pulling cryptocurrencies out of the dark
summary: Bitcoin futures trading has matured in 2019, with futures trading now accounting for about 50% of spot trading on major exchanges. This has reduced volatility, increased liquidity, and broadened the investor base, while soothing regulatory concerns. The rise of futures trading has also made it easier for crypto owners to earn interest and make leveraged bets, with regulated exchanges attracting real-money investors for long-term exposure. This increase in real-money investment could stabilize crypto prices, making them more reliable.

site_title: South-east Asia leaders to push for progress on China-backed RCEP trade pact
summary: South-east Asian leaders are set to push for a breakthrough in the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade pact, a China-backed agreement that could be the world's largest trade pact. The deal, which would comprise 30% of global commerce, has been seven years in the making and aims to cement trade ties in Asia as the US retreats from the region. The meeting in Thailand this weekend aims to bring the pact to fruition, with leaders hoping for a significant progress on the deal amid Beijing's bruising trade war with Washington.

site_title: Pollution of the solution?
summary: Climate change remains a pressing global issue, but a more nuanced conversation is needed. Critics argue that simplistic and holier-than-thou approaches, such as "green washing" and celebrity-led finger-wagging, undermine the critical message. The focus on individual actions, like reducing consumption and using fossil fuels, oversimplifies the complex economic and geopolitical factors at play. Policymakers must balance economic health and world peace with climate action, and countries like Singapore are taking a more measured approach by implementing policies like carbon pricing and sustainable infrastructure.

site_title: A tipsy spin on the bubble tea craze
summary: A Robertson Quay bar, The 3 Peas, offers a unique spin on bubble tea by infusing it with craft cocktails. The bar, co-founded by Zheng Pan, aims to "curate drinks the right way" by balancing flavors and alcohol content. Their "Bar-Ble T" creations feature fruit pops instead of traditional tapioca pearls, paired with care to avoid overpowering liquor tastes. The bar also serves specialty cocktails, wines, and beers, with a focus on curating drinks rather than relying on the bubble tea craze to be a fad.

images.alt_text: Peachy Ginie.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 4.64 points to 1,593.34, with losers outnumbering gainers 451 to 353. Volume reached 2.8 billion lots worth RM1.6 billion.

site_title: Indonesia reviewing terms of EU trade deal as WTO palm oil spat brews
summary: Indonesia is reviewing a draft trade deal with the European Union (EU) due to concerns over the EU's use of palm oil in biofuels. The country is the world's largest producer and exporter of palm oil and plans to file a complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) over the EU's renewable energy directive. Indonesia accuses the EU of using environmental concerns as a guise for protectionism and wants palm oil to be "positioned fairly" in the proposed deal. The review is seen as a response to the EU's decision to phase out palm oil use in biofuels by 2030.

site_title: SingPost delivers higher net profit of S$27.7m for Q2
summary: SingPost delivered a 10.3% higher net profit of S$27.7 million for Q2, driven by improved performance from associated companies and joint ventures. However, underlying net profit declined 4.6% to S$26.8 million due to lower earnings from the post-and-parcel segment and freight-forwarding business. Revenue increased 2% to S$324.4 million, with international post and parcel revenue rising from cross-border e-commerce deliveries. A dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent was declared for the quarter.

site_title: SembMarine bags job on Shell floating production unit
summary: SembMarine won a contract from Shell Offshore to build and integrate the topside and hull of a floating production unit (FPU) for Shell's Whale field development in the Gulf of Mexico. The FPU, valued at 25,000 tonnes, will be completed by 2022 and operate in the Alaminos Canyon Block 772. The agreement comes ahead of a final investment decision by Shell next year. This contract is expected to have minimal impact on SembMarine's financials.

site_title: Italy's Cavalli rescued by Dubai's Damac chairman
summary: Damac chairman Hussian Sajwani has completed the purchase of Italian fashion house Roberto Cavalli, ending a long sale process. Cavalli, founded by designer Roberto Cavalli in the 1970s, had been struggling to relaunch sales and gain visibility. The deal was facilitated by Italian private equity firm Clessidra, which took over the company in 2015. Sajwani's private investment company Vision Investments acquired Cavalli through the DICO Group, ensuring the stability of the brand's management.

site_title: Fragrance Group selling former HQ building in Changi Road for S$28.8m
summary: Fragrance Group is selling its 5-storey freehold building in Changi Road for S$28.8 million to Pergas Investment Holdings. The 7,315 sq ft site was acquired by Fragrance in 2005 and previously served as the company's corporate headquarters. Separately, several conservation shophouse properties in Chinatown have changed hands, including No. 31 Pagoda Street for S$16.25 million and 198 Telok Ayer Street for S$14.88 million.

site_title: Singapore's men golfers in buoyant mood
summary: Singapore's men's golf team is in a buoyant mood ahead of the South-east Asian Games. No specific details or events are mentioned in the provided article, suggesting it may be a teaser or introductory piece.

site_title: US hiring resilient with gain of 128,000 jobs in October
summary: The US job market showed resilience in October with a gain of 128,000 jobs, exceeding the median estimate of 85,000. This follows sharp upward revisions in prior months, offering hope for sustained economic growth despite weak business investment and trade tensions. The jobless rate edged up to 3.6%. The news boosted stock futures and the dollar, while Treasuries dropped.

site_title: Handle these investing tips with care
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Six common financial advice tips to view with skepticism include: prioritizing time in the market over timing the market, following advice without understanding its source, and focusing solely on productivity gains. These tips may be damaging to long-term financial well-being. In contrast, retail investors are expected to drive growth in ETFs in Asia and Europe, and markets may continue to rise due to various factors. The article highlights the importance of critical thinking when seeking financial advice and encourages readers to consider multiple perspectives before making investment decisions.

site_title: Ascendas Reit's Q2 DPU up 2.3% on overseas acquisitions
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 2.3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for Q2, driven by overseas acquisitions, particularly in the UK. The Reit's gross revenue and net property income rose 5.3% and 12% year-over-year, respectively. Portfolio occupancy rates declined in Singapore but increased in Australia and the UK. The Reit announced the acquisition of 30 business park properties in the US and Singapore, with DPU expected to increase further.

site_title: Nissan names new finance chief
summary: Nissan Motor Co has named Stephen Ma, 49, as its new finance chief, replacing Hiroshi Karube. The move is part of a company-wide revamp, with veteran executives, including Yasuhiro Yamauchi and Hitoshi Kawaguchi, stepping down. Ma, a global controller, will join Ashwani Gupta, who was appointed COO last month, and Makoto Uchida, the new CEO, in the company's top ranks. The changes come after Nissan's dramatic ouster of former chairman Carlos Ghosn and amid the company's struggles with plunging profits and management scandal.

site_title: Reits (November 2-3, 2019)
summary: Realty Investment Trusts (Reits) in Singapore saw a significant drop in prices from November 2-3, 2019, with prices declining due to market fluctuations. In contrast, global markets experienced a surge in US mortgage rates after five consecutive weeks of declines. The Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore is expected to test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark. Manhattan rents reached a record high, with projections of further increases. WeWork secured new tenants and filled space at 21 Collyer Quay after its bankruptcy.

site_title: Ready to run on the big day?
summary:
The article provides essential dos and don'ts for a memorable marathon experience in Singapore. Key takeaways include: 

- Fueling with glycogen, primarily from bananas, chocolate, or energy gels, is crucial for a marathon.
- Hydration status is vital, with runners advised to drink isotonic fluids and avoid relying solely on thirst.
- Over-drinking can lead to hyponatremia, causing confusion and altered mental state.
- Heat disorder is a major concern in Singapore's hot and humid climate, requiring prompt medical attention.
- Proper footwear, socks, and clothing are essential for comfort and preventing injuries.
- Mental conditioning is just as important as physical preparation, with positive thinking and distraction techniques helping to cope with challenges.
- Post-race recovery is crucial, involving hydration, rest, and proper nutrition to aid in muscle and heart recovery.

site_title: Those superfast Nike shoes are creating a problem
summary: The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) is re-examining its rules on running shoes, citing concerns that current technology gives athletes an unfair advantage. Eliud Kipchoge and Brigid Kosgei's record-breaking performances in Nike shoes have sparked debate, with some experts calling for a single standard in competition running shoes, regulating the shoe midsole thickness. The IAAF is considering an upper limit of 31 millimeters of midsole height to prevent excessive energy return. Nike and other shoe manufacturers have responded, arguing that such regulations could limit creativity and innovation in running shoes.

site_title: The art of Audemars Piguet watches
summary: Audemars Piguet has opened a multi-sensorial exhibition in Tokyo titled "Beyond Watchmaking," exploring the relationship between watchmaking and art. The event features commissioned works by artists such as Kurt Hentschlager and Mathieu Lehanneur, who designed the exhibition space as a large-scale copper ring with rock replicas from the Swiss Jura Mountains. The exhibition also showcases over 150 watches from AP's heritage and contemporary collections, including the latest Code 11.59 range, and offers workshops for visitors to try their hands at watchmaking.

site_title: Marriott sells St Regis New York hotel to Qatar sovereign wealth fund
summary: Marriott has sold the St Regis New York hotel to Qatar's sovereign wealth fund for $310 million. The 18-storey Beaux-Arts building, opened in 1904, features over 200 guest rooms and the famous King Cole Bar. Marriott acquired the property as part of its 2016 $13.6 billion acquisition of Starwood Hotels & Resorts. The sale gives Qatar Investment Authority another global asset, expanding its US investments.

images.alt_text: Marriott acquired the Manhattan property when it bought Starwood Hotels & Resorts in 2016, a US$13.6 billion transaction that reshaped the global hospitality industry.

site_title: Audemars Piguet set to increase production of watches in 2020
summary: Audemars Piguet plans to increase watch production to 44,000 pieces in 2020, a 10% increase from 40,000, to address a shortage of Royal Oak models. CEO Francois-Henry Bennahmias aims to reach 50,000 by 2022. The company will invest in its Le Brassus manufacturing facility to support the increased output. The goal is also to double production of the new Code 11.59 collection, now set to reach 4,000 pieces in 2020, as it appeals to a younger demographic.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks close week with healthy gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with a 0.72% gain, driven by a forecast-beating reading on manufacturing activity and traders brushing off early worries about trade talks. The Hang Seng Index rose to 27,100.76, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 0.99% to 2,958.20 and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 1.29% to 1,637.00. The rally comes despite US President Trump's recent threats to extend a stocks rally.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index added 0.72 per cent, or 194.04 points, to 27,100.76.

site_title: Vietnam is leading Asean growing solar PV market
summary: Vietnam is leading the growth of the solar PV market in ASEAN, with its cumulative capacity expected to hit 5.5 GW in 2024, accounting for 44% of the region's total capacity. The country's feed-in tariff (FIT) program has been instrumental in attracting large-scale solar projects, with Vietnam's solar capacity expected to triple within the next 5 years. Other growing markets include Malaysia and Singapore, with Malaysia targeting a 20% renewable capacity mix by 2025 and Singapore's distributed solar market gaining momentum.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Ascendas Reit plans to acquire 30 business park properties in the US and Singapore for $1.66 billion. JTC Corporation is building a new semiconductor facility in Tampines, Singapore. Traveloka, backed by GIC, is considering a dual listing to boost profits. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacted to US tariff announcements, and Citigroup set a target for the global equity index. Thaksin Shinawatra expressed confidence in his daughter's case, and the UK economy shrank for the second month.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat on Friday, up 1.4% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed flat on Friday, up 1.4% for the week, as investors weighed manufacturing data from China and trade talk worries. The STI improved from last Friday's close, with indices in China, Hong Kong, South Korea, and Australia closing in positive territory.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters plan huge march after gatecrashing Halloween
summary: Hong Kong protesters plan a massive march on Saturday after a night of clashes in a central bar district, where protesters gatecrashed a Halloween party. The protests, seeking universal suffrage, come after pro-democracy activist Joshua Wong was disqualified from standing in upcoming district elections. Police have banned the march due to safety concerns, but two other rallies have received permits. The unrest, which began five months ago, has crippled the retail and tourism sectors, with Hong Kong sliding into recession for the first time since the global financial crisis.

site_title: Singapore property prices decoupled from global yield chase, speculators: IMF study
summary: Singapore's private residential property prices have decoupled from global yield chase and speculative activity since 2013, according to an IMF study. The study found that macroprudential measures taken by regulators targeted foreign buyers and speculators, who drove up prices from 2010 to 2013. Today, foreign buyers and corporates account for a small fraction of transactions, but their purchases have an economically significant impact on prices. The measures have limited excessive price increases and contributed to improving household and financial institution resilience against shocks.

site_title: European stocks advance at open
summary: European stocks advanced at open on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.3%, Paris's CAC 40 up 0.3%, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.4%. The gains follow broader gains in most of Asia. The rally was driven by mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: CAO's net profit rises 26% on higher gross profit, lower expenses
summary: China Aviation Oil (Singapore) posted a 26% rise in net profit to US$23.9 million for its third quarter, driven by higher gross profit and lower operating expenses. Gross profit rose 47.1% to US$16.3 million, mainly due to higher jet supply volume and trading activities. Revenue fell 12.2% to US$5.56 billion, while total expenses decreased by about half to US$3.8 million. The company's CEO, Wang Yanjun, plans to focus on long-term profitability through new market expansion and investing in synergetic assets to strengthen growth.

site_title: Malaysia police say untrue Jho Low is in UAE: Bernama
summary: Malaysia's police chief, Abdul Hamid Bador, denied reports that 1MDB-linked financier Jho Low is in the UAE, stating they are untrue. Despite knowing his location, Low is being protected, with ongoing talks and cooperation from the FBI. Low has been offered asylum in a country with human rights standards, and has agreed to return almost $1 billion in assets to the US. His whereabouts remain unclear, with police knowing but not disclosing his location.

site_title: Nissan names new finance chief, some managers to leave in latest shake-up
summary: Nissan Motor Co. appointed American Stephen Ma as its new chief financial officer, replacing Hiroshi Karube. The move is part of a "generational change" at the carmaker, following the ouster of former chairman Carlos Ghosn and the naming of Makoto Uchida as CEO. Veteran executives Hitoshi Kawaguchi and others are also stepping down. The changes come amid Nissan's struggles with scandals, plunging profits, and tensions with top shareholder Renault SA. Ma, 49, is one of the highest-ranking non-Japanese executives at the company.

site_title: BMW 118i M Sport: Reversal of fortunes
summary: BMW's new 1 Series hatchback, the 118i M Sport, has shifted from rear-wheel drive to front-wheel drive, a change that has been welcomed by consumers. Despite initial concerns, the FWD layout has not compromised the car's handling, with clever traction and stability control systems providing a fun and responsive driving experience. The 118i M Sport boasts a 140-horsepower, three-cylinder engine and refined dual-clutch transmission, making it a strong offering in the compact car segment. However, the added suspension and larger rims in the M Sport model may detract from comfort on the highway.

images.alt_text: BMW's new 1 Series hatchback is now a front-wheel drive car.
The driving and climate controls are all grouped and located logically on the dashboard.

site_title: Berlin housing market faces investment crunch
summary: Berlin's housing market is facing an investment crunch due to the city's rent freeze plan. The plan, proposed in June, has caused uncertainty and delays to construction projects, with the city's largest residential landlord, Deutsche Wohnen SE, postponing projects and focusing on other cities. The company estimates a cash flow risk of 330 million euros over five years. The city's constitutional court is likely to strike down the legislation, and the CDU party plans to challenge it. A proposed referendum on buying out big apartment owners has also stalled, with only 29% of Berliners in favor.

site_title: Shareholders first, or employees? What we don't talk about when we talk about corporate governance
summary: Singapore's corporate governance prioritizes shareholders over employees, with CEOs earning 80-100 times more than median employees at large companies. This is in contrast to the US, where the average S&P 500 company has a CEO-to-worker pay ratio of 287 to 1. The Singapore Business Federation does not advocate for tracking worker pay ratios, citing controversy and potential negative effects. Experts argue that internal pay equity is crucial for teamwork and engagement, and that CEOs should be benchmarked to their own company's performance rather than peer groups. The workplace is also seen as a major contributor to social pollution, with high levels of stress and absenteeism affecting both employees and employers.

site_title: Sri Lanka slashes taxes to boost sluggish economy
summary: Sri Lanka slashed taxes by nearly half to boost its sluggish economy, following deadly Easter Sunday suicide bombings that killed 269 people. The new measures include a 15% value-added tax cut to 8% and the abolition of a 2% goods and services tax, as well as a reduction in corporate tax for the construction industry from 28% to 14%. The government aims to lift economic activity ahead of parliamentary elections in April and expects revenue volumes to increase with better compliance.

site_title: Government working on strong Budget that Singapore economy needs: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the country's economy is working on a strong budget suitable to the current global economic environment. The government is preparing for potential external shocks, including a possible US-China recession within the next 12-18 months, which could impact Singapore's economy. Lee emphasized the need for productivity improvements and upgrading, rather than relying on pump-priming stimulus, to make the most of the current environment.

site_title: Fresh arrests in Saudi Arabia net intellectuals, entrepreneurs
summary: Saudi Arabia has detained at least eight intellectuals and entrepreneurs, mostly writers, amid a two-year crackdown on free expression. The detentions were made by plainclothes police in Riyadh and Jeddah, with the reason unclear. The move comes as the country faces international criticism over its human rights record, including the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi and the devastating Yemen war. The detentions are part of a broader effort to maintain social stability, despite the country's claims of being open to criticism.

site_title: Rio Tinto's Mongolia mine plan will go ahead: minister
summary: Rio Tinto's plan to expand the Oyu Tolgoi copper mine in Mongolia will proceed, despite protests from locals over environmental concerns and foreign influence. Mongolia's mining minister, Dolgorsurengiin Sumyaabazar, stated that the project's expansion will not be stopped, citing the approval of a parliamentary motion by the Mongolian national security council. The project, in which Rio Tinto and Mongolia own 34% and 66% respectively, has been hampered by protests and will move forward despite opposition.

images.alt_text: Anglo-Australian firm Rio Tinto's plan to expand a copper mine in Mongolia will go ahead, the country's mining minister said, according to the Financial Times newspaper on Tuesday.

site_title: Advocate for the world
summary: Royal DSM CEO Feike Sijbesma has successfully implemented a strategy that combines saving the planet with good business, tripling the company's value in the process. Sijbesma's approach, which he calls "doing better," involves adopting a startup mentality, setting clear goals, and spending more on innovation. The company has made significant strides in sustainability, including reducing its carbon footprint, increasing renewable energy use, and developing products that help customers become more sustainable. Sijbesma believes that companies have a critical role to play in addressing global issues, including climate change, hunger, and poverty, and is working to create a community of like-minded companies to address these challenges.

images.alt_text: "If you do it well, and you make your business really sustainable, I think you can also earn money, you can do good for the world by doing well yourself." - Feike Sijbesma.

site_title: SBF takes on inequality with sustainable employment
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has released a report calling on firms to improve employment practices and tackle increasing inequality, particularly among professionals, mature workers, and essential service workers. The report's recommendations include upskilling professionals, redesigning jobs for mature employees, and selecting socially responsible vendors. To encourage long-term commitment, a programme office will be set up to monitor firms' progress and a Lighthouse Project will be launched to improve wages and prospects for essential service workers. 61 companies have already taken the Sustainable Employment Pledge, with more expected to join.

site_title: Seeing silver linings in business
summary: Hua Yu, a Singapore optics manufacturer, faces challenges from the US-China trade war and sluggish global growth, but its managing director sees opportunities. The firm may benefit from companies outsourcing high-precision production to countries in South-east Asia, such as Singapore, to avoid duties. Hua Yu is investing in high-precision manufacturing and aims to increase sales by 15% annually. The company is also exploring sub-assembly and manufacturing final products for its customers, with a goal to become an original equipment manufacturer in two to three years.

site_title: Singapore to test use of processed waste as construction material
summary: Singapore will conduct a field trial to assess the performance of NEWSand, a construction material made from repurposed municipal solid waste, including incineration bottom ash. The trial, starting in mid-2020, aims to evaluate NEWSand's use in road construction projects. Three companies will collect and treat 3,000 tonnes of IBA for use as a road base or sub-base material. The move aims to reduce waste sent to the Semakau Landfill, with Singapore aiming to send one-third less waste by 2030.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as dealers await trade signals
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed session on Tuesday, with investors awaiting trade signals from the US-China talks. Chinese Vice Premier Liu He spoke with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, agreeing to maintain communication on remaining issues. Alibaba surged 7.7% on its Hong Kong debut, while markets in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Singapore dropped. Tokyo rose 0.6%, and other regional markets followed suit. Despite Wall Street's new record highs, the optimism was tempered by concerns over the lack of detail in the talks.

images.alt_text: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday as investors tracked developments in the China-US trade talks, while Chinese online retail titan Alibaba surged almost eight per cent on its Hong Kong debut.

site_title: US new home sales down unexpectedly in October
summary: US new home sales dropped 0.7% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 733,000 units in October, contrary to economists' expectations. However, data for September was revised higher to 738,000 units, the highest since July 2007. Despite the unexpected decline, residential investment rebounded in the third quarter after contracting for six straight quarters, and consumer confidence fell for a fourth straight month to 125.5 in November.

images.alt_text: The median new house price fell 3.5 per cent to US$316,700 in October from a year ago. Sales last month were concentrated in the US$200,000 to US$400,000 price range.

site_title: Sri Lanka central bank chief says he will step down on Dec 20
summary: Sri Lanka's central bank chief Indrajith Coomaraswamy has announced his resignation, effective December 20, citing personal reasons and the age limit for staff of regulated entities. The move comes after former wartime defense chief Gotabaya Rajapaksa won a presidential election and appointed his brother Mahinda Rajapaksa as prime minister. Coomaraswamy, 69, had been governor since 2016 and played a key role in steering the economy through crises, including interest rate cuts to support growth. A successor has not been named, with senior deputy governor Nandalal Weerasinghe seen as a potential option.

site_title: What is sustainable finance? That's a US$4t question for investors
summary: Major fund managers face challenges investing in emerging-market sustainable investments due to inconsistent global definitions, lack of data on carbon emissions, and inadequate collaboration between regulators. The UN estimates a $4 trillion annual investment shortfall to address climate change. To address this, transition bonds are proposed as a stepping-stone for issuers shifting towards cleaner energy, allowing companies to access capital and facilitate flow of sustainable funds into emerging markets. Regulators must collaborate globally to bridge the gap, according to market participants.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.22 points to 1,601.36. The market saw 54.24 million lots traded worth RM20.95 million, with 99 gainers outpacing 71 losers.

site_title: Beyond the comfort zone
summary: Leadership expert John Ryan, former US Navy vice admiral, emphasizes the importance of pushing individuals out of their comfort zones for career advancement. Ryan, 42, recalls his own experience at 42, where he rose through the ranks despite initial hesitation. He believes that another leader must encourage their team to step out of their comfort zone, as they will eventually face the need for a promotion. This requires leaders to be uncomfortable and push their people to grow, even if it means taking risks.

site_title: 2019 GDP forecast range revised upwards after Q3 outperformance
summary: Singapore has revised its full-year GDP forecast for 2019 to 0.5-1% due to a better-than-expected third-quarter performance. The economy expanded by 2.1% on a seasonally-adjusted annualised basis, avoiding a technical recession. Growth is expected to be between 0.5-2.5% in 2020, with potential upside from the electronics cluster's recovery and a possible slowdown in the Chinese economy. However, headwinds from US-China trade tensions, Brexit, and geopolitical tensions remain, casting a cautious outlook for the year ahead.

site_title: LVMH gets access to Tiffany's books after it raises offer: sources
summary: LVMH has persuaded Tiffany & Co to provide confidential due diligence after raising its bid to US$16 billion, closing to US$130 per share. This comes after Tiffany initially rebuffed LVMH's US$120-per-share offer, citing undervaluation. Tiffany plans to continue negotiating, and a deal is uncertain. The acquisition would increase LVMH's exposure to the bridal and diamond category, as well as US luxury shoppers.

site_title: Federal Reserve members unanimously reject negative interest rates: minutes
summary: US Federal Reserve members unanimously rejected the idea of implementing negative interest rates, dismissing the benefits as "mixed" in countries that have tried it. Despite President Trump's calls for lower rates, the Fed believes further rate cuts are unnecessary in the near term, citing risks from the trade war. The benchmark lending rate has been cut to 1.5-1.75%, and Fed members believe the current interest rate levels are "well calibrated" to support growth.

site_title: Where to eat and sleep - beefing up a trip to Japan
summary: Tokyo is gearing up for the Olympics in July, making it an ideal time to explore Japan. In a new series, Weekend magazine and Singapore Airlines highlight top destinations, including Yamagata prefecture, known for its traditional ryokans and Yonezawa beef. The article also touches on fine dining, with chefs sharing strategies for staying ahead of the competition amidst uncertain economic times. Additionally, it explores Tokyo's famous fish market, Ginzan Onsen, and features interviews with celebrities, including Joanne Froggatt from Downton Abbey.

site_title: WeWon't
summary: South-east Asia's startups are increasingly focusing on corporate governance to avoid governance lapses and lessons from the WeWork debacle. Industry observers note that investors are paying more attention to governance, and startups must prioritize financial controls, auditing, and having a good slate of investors and board of directors. Experts advise hiring experienced financial teams, maintaining meticulous accounting practices, and introducing independent directors to counter potential conflicts of interest. Startups should also be cautious of unfair investment terms and avoid building a "vanity board" with big names who add little value. With the maturing ecosystem, corporate governance cannot be an afterthought, and founders must be accountable for money entrusted to them by investors.

site_title: US, S Korea resume defence cost-sharing talks amid protests
summary: US and South Korea resumed defence cost-sharing talks amid protests over sharply increased US demands, with the US seeking up to $5 billion a year, more than five times the current $896 million payment. The talks come as President Trump tests South Korea's confidence in the security alliance, with progressive groups protesting the "highway robbery" by "greedy" Americans. A South Korean negotiator, Jeong Eun-bo, is leading the talks, bringing expertise from previous financial crisis negotiations.

site_title: We hate data collection but that doesn't mean we can stop it
summary: A survey of over 4,000 Americans conducted by the Pew Research Center in 2019 found that two-thirds believe surveillance is an inevitable part of modern life, with 70% thinking their online activities are tracked and 80% feeling they have little to no control over collected data. The survey reveals widespread concern and powerlessness about digital surveillance, with many questioning the motivations and consequences of data collection.

site_title: US housing starts, building permits rebound with lower mortgage rates
summary: US housing starts rebounded in October with a 3.8% increase to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.314 million units, driven by lower mortgage rates. Building permits surged 5% to a 12-year high of 1.461 million units. The surge suggests support for the slowing economy, with economists lifting Q4 GDP growth estimates to as high as 1.5% annualized rate. The housing market is benefiting from the US Federal Reserve's easy monetary policy stance, which has pushed down mortgage rates to 3.75%.

site_title: Amazon throws spaghetti at the grocery wall
summary: Amazon's foray into the grocery market has been marked by "head-scratching tactics and middling financial and strategic performance." Despite investing nearly $14 billion in Whole Foods, Amazon's grocery operation lags behind US market leader Walmart in terms of revenue growth. The company's cashier-less Go stores, a novel idea, have received limited attention and are not considered a success. Amazon's limited financial disclosures and parochial supermarket operation raise questions about the company's ability to innovate in the grocery space, and investors may soon be pressuring Amazon to explain its strategy.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as markets await clues on trade talks; NZ dips
summary: Australian shares closed 0.4% lower on Monday, as investors remained cautious due to the lack of concrete detail in Sino-US trade negotiations. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 6,766.80, with gold and healthcare sectors leading losses. The US and China trade talks have been described as "constructive," but no agreement has been reached, prompting analysts to maintain a cautious stance.

site_title: Mapletree Investments supports Singapore Bird Race
summary: The 35th edition of the Singapore Bird Race took place on November 16-17, with a record 130 participants, including 60 students from 10 schools. The event, sponsored and hosted by Mapletree Investments, aimed to promote environmental awareness and biodiversity. Over 160 species of birds were spotted across four categories, with rare sightings including the Rufous Woodpecker, Straw-headed Bulbul, and Grey-headed Lapwing. Mapletree's sponsorship aligned with its corporate social responsibility pillars of environment and education, with Nature Society chairman Lim Kim Chuah thanking the company for enabling more school teams to participate.

site_title: Mixed sentiment, outlook for Asean property investment: CBRE
summary: Asean property investment sentiment varies across countries, with healthy appetites in the Philippines, Vietnam, and Singapore, but subdued demand in Thailand and Indonesia, according to CBRE's Q3 report. Domestic investors are driving land acquisition and new development projects, while foreign investors focus on industrial and logistics properties. Tight lending conditions prompt joint ventures with foreign investors, and a growing interest from new investors in Singapore's stability. Weaker economic growth weighs on investment sentiment, with retail investment unattractive due to weak domestic consumption demand.

site_title: Trump's doctor dismisses speculation of chest pain
summary: US President Donald Trump's doctor, Sean Conley, has denied speculation of chest pain after Trump's unannounced medical checkup at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center on Saturday. Trump, 73, had a "routine, planned" examination, which included cholesterol results, and did not undergo specialized cardiac or neurologic evaluations. The checkup was not unscheduled and was triggered by Trump's desire to complete part of his annual physical examination before a busy 2020 re-election campaign. There is no evidence of urgent or acute issues.

site_title: Balanced approach
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical Company CEO Christophe Weber discusses his approach to managing tensions in balancing globalization with preserving the company's deeply rooted Japanese culture. The company's $62 billion acquisition of Shire in 2019 nearly doubled its size and drew criticism, but Weber believes it expanded Takeda's reach and competitiveness in key markets. He emphasizes the need for a balance between globalizing the company and maintaining its heritage, stating that 90% of employees are now outside of Japan but values and reputation remain true to the company's 238-year history. Weber also highlights the importance of R&D productivity, citing the company's focus on rare diseases and partnerships with external entities to improve its pipeline.

site_title: Double whammy of Brexit and election hits UK housing
summary: The UK housing market has experienced a significant decline due to the combination of Brexit and the upcoming election. According to a Rightmove survey, the number of properties put up for sale in the UK fell by 14.9% in the four weeks to Nov 9, the largest annual drop in over 10 years. This was attributed to uncertainty and potential changes to the stamp duty tax. Meanwhile, the average property price rose by 0.3% and the number of sales agreed decreased by 2.9%.

site_title: UOB, fintech Value3 Advisory to launch AI-enabled credit rating platform in Asean
summary: UNITED Overseas Bank (UOB) has partnered with fintech startup Value3 Advisory to launch an AI-enabled credit rating platform in Asean. The AlgoCRED platform will provide automated credit ratings, research, and insights for corporate bonds, enabling investors to make more effective decisions. The platform will be available in Singapore in December, with plans to expand to other Asean markets. The partnership combines UOB's regional expertise with Value3 Advisory's machine learning and natural language processing technologies to develop predictive analytics and credit risk indicators.

site_title: Sinopec plans 100-barge fleet to ship cleaner marine fuel: source
summary: Sinopec Corp plans to build a 100-barge fleet to supply marine fuel compliant with new global emission standards over the next three years. The fleet will include 50 new vessels and chartering 50 smaller vessels, with a total cost of around 4 billion yuan (S$776.3 million). The company aims to become a top regional supplier of very low sulphur fuel oil (VLSFO) to meet its goal of supplying 15 million tonnes by 2023.

site_title: Temasek sets 2030 target for its portfolio to halve greenhouse emissions
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state-owned investment company, aims to halve its greenhouse gas emissions from its portfolio by 2030. CEO Ho Ching also encourages other businesses to report on their usage of water, paper, electricity, and air miles by the next financial year. This move is part of Temasek's push for clean energy and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) initiatives, as the company eyes investments outside of fossil fuels and aims to become carbon neutral by 2020.

site_title: Podcast: SFF x Switch 2019 Ep 5: Greening finance
summary: The Singapore Fintech Festival x Singapore Week of Innovation and Technology features a podcast episode discussing greening finance. Monetary Authority of Singapore's managing director Ravi Menon talks about the risks of stranded assets and the room for innovation in green finance. He advises the financial sector to nudge the real economy towards caring about climate change. The episode is part of a special edition of BT's podcasts, focusing on green finance and its impact on the financial sector.

site_title: Cable feels the Force from Disney's ambitious streaming service
summary: Disney's streaming service, Disney+, marks a significant shift in the media industry, with the platform's launch signaling a potential end to traditional cable and satellite hookups. Analysts predict that by 2020, one in five adults in the US will have cut the cord, with streaming services like Disney+ expected to surpass cable subscribers. Other media outlets, including Netflix and WarnerMedia, are spending billions to defend their turf and compete with Disney's ambitious streaming service.

site_title: Citi banker arrested in Hong Kong, capping wave of protest warnings
summary: A Citigroup investment banker was arrested in Hong Kong during a wave of protests, with the city's police grabbing him off a sidewalk. Firms across Hong Kong, including Citigroup, BNP Paribas, and Standard Chartered, warned employees to stay home or work remotely to ensure family safety amid escalating clashes between protesters and police. The arrest occurred as protesters chanted "resist" and as the government announced the closure of public schools. Citigroup has launched an investigation into the incident, but no charges have been made.

site_title: Hong Kong anti-mask law 'unconstitutional': High Court
summary: The Hong Kong High Court ruled that a government ban on demonstrators wearing face masks is unconstitutional, citing that the restrictions on fundamental rights go beyond what is reasonably necessary to quell pro-democracy unrest. The court found that the ban fails to meet the proportionality test, allowing protesters to continue wearing masks.

images.alt_text: A government ban on demonstrators wearing face masks aimed at helping to quell months of pro-democracy unrest in Hong Kong is unconstitutional, the territory's high court ruled on Monday.

site_title: It's data and more for Hong Kong's AMTD
summary: Hong Kong's AMTD Group has partnered with Xiaomi to launch a virtual banking platform, Insight Fintech, leveraging big data, IoT, cloud computing, AI, and blockchain to offer personalized banking solutions. The partnership aims to tap into Xiaomi's 200 million monthly active users and expand AMTD's network. The virtual bank will focus on mid-net worth individuals seeking personalized wealth management or asset allocation services. AMTD plans to also explore a digital bank license in Singapore, where it sees significant growth opportunities. The partnership and Singapore venture are part of AMTD's strategy to diversify and achieve conglomerate status.

site_title: Thailand, Myanmar can learn from Manila's move on its restive south
summary: Thailand and Myanmar can learn from Manila's efforts to quell violence in its southern Philippines. Insurgents in southern Thailand have killed 15 people, prompting a reminder of the region's restive and dangerous nature. The conflict dates back to the 1940s and has led to demands for Islamic law, resulting in 7,000 deaths since 2004. If left unaddressed, the conflict may attract Middle-Eastern jihadis, posing a threat to South-east Asia. Manila's peace settlement through the Bangsamoro Organic Law serves as a model for Thailand and Myanmar to address their own troubled regions and calm angry minorities.

site_title: Brexit Party's Farage will not challenge PM Johnson's Conservatives in 317 seats
summary: Brexit Party leader Nigel Farage announced on Monday that his party will not contest 317 Conservative Party seats in the upcoming UK election, instead focusing on nearly all other seats. This move aims to prevent anti-Brexit parties from winning the election and make a hung parliament less likely. Farage believes Boris Johnson's Brexit proposal aligns with the 2016 referendum result, and by not contesting Conservative seats, he hopes to boost Johnson's chances. The decision is seen as a significant boost for Johnson and the Conservatives, with Sterling rising against the US dollar and government bond prices falling.

site_title: Property tech startup Smarten Spaces raises US$12m from Hong Kong's Symphony
summary: Singapore-based property tech startup Smarten Spaces has raised US$12 million in Series A funding from Hong Kong's Symphony International Holdings. The startup offers a digital platform for space management, aiming to improve productivity and reduce operational costs for enterprise offices, commercial real estate, and co-living spaces. With the new capital, Smarten Spaces plans to expand across Asia-Pacific and North America, driven by artificial intelligence and a one-stop tech solution for space owners and managers. The startup's goal is to eliminate inefficiencies in smart building technology and capitalize on the projected US$19.9 billion smart space industry by 2024.

site_title: China's Xi arrives in Athens to 'deepen cooperation'
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Athens on Sunday for a three-day visit to deepen cooperation between China and Greece in various sectors, including education, shipping, and energy. The visit comes after Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis led a delegation to Shanghai earlier, and both countries are set to sign cooperation documents. This marks a significant milestone in Greece's decade-long efforts to build closer trade relations with China, with a focus on increasing investments and trade. The visit is seen as a strategic move to strengthen ties between the two nations.

site_title: Changing tides of foreign buying
summary: Foreign buying of non-landed private homes in Singapore has declined since 2011, with a record 29.9% share in 2007 and 33.8% in 2011. In 2019, foreigners bought 20.9% of total non-landed private homes sold, a low level compared to previous years. The decline is attributed to cooling measures introduced at the end of 2011. Despite this, luxury condo units, including penthouses, continue to attract foreign buyers, with recent purchases making headlines.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks fall on renewed trade deal uncertainty
summary: South Korean stocks fell on Monday, dropping 13.14 points or 0.61% due to renewed uncertainty over a potential trade deal with China. US President Donald Trump's remarks last week cast doubt on a rollback of US tariffs sought by China, sparking a net sale of $148.20 million in shares. This move comes as the KOSPI index has risen 4.07% so far this year.

site_title: NTUC to raise retirement, re-employment ages in 2021, ahead of national schedule
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore will raise its retirement age to 63 and re-employment age to 68 for its workers starting January 1, 2021, ahead of the national schedule. This change will benefit about 430 workers who would have reached the retirement age of 62 in 2021 and 280 workers who can benefit from the early raising of the re-employment age. NTUC and its social enterprises employ about 2,400 older workers beyond the current statutory retirement age of 62.

site_title: IMDA, Microsoft to accelerate Singapore's 5G development
summary: IMDA and Microsoft have signed a memorandum of intent to accelerate Singapore's 5G development. The collaboration aims to co-create 5G use cases and applications, providing technical capabilities consultancy and sharing best practices on 5G standards and security. The move builds on IMDA's efforts to develop an open 5G ecosystem, including an open testbed facility set to be ready in the first half of 2020. This partnership will enable the creation of new 5G applications and services, leveraging the high speed, capacity, and low latency of 5G technology.

site_title: Watch that hidden poison in your rice
summary: Arsenic levels in rice products have been found to be high, with the highest levels found in rice bran and rice milk. Long-term exposure to arsenic is linked to cancer, particularly skin, lung, and bladder cancers. The International Agency for Research on Cancer, European Food Safety Authority, and US FDA classify arsenic as a carcinogen. Studies show that soaking rice overnight and rinsing thoroughly can reduce arsenic levels by 80%. However, cooking rice with a rice cooker can reabsorb arsenic into the rice. While the risk of arsenic-related cancers is small, consuming rice products a few times a week may still pose a health risk, particularly for young children.

site_title: 9-year threshold for IDs: Limited pool a hurdle to board renewal
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) implemented a nine-year threshold for independent directors (IDs) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) Listing Rules in 2018. However, a recent survey found that 43% of listed companies still have IDs who have served more than nine years, with smaller firms being more affected. The MAS's two-tier vote system aims to enhance board renewal and independence, but some firms are concerned about reputational risk and the potential for directors to be voted out. Despite this, the survey also found that many firms have implemented board diversity policies and succession planning for key executive positions.

site_title: Death of Hong Kong student likely to add fuel to unrest
summary: A 22-year-old Hong Kong university student, Chow Tsz-lok, died after falling from a car park during pro-democracy protests, sparking widespread outrage and potential further unrest. Chow's death, the first student fatality in months of rallies, is likely to fuel anger at police accused of excessive force. Students trashed a Starbucks branch and held candlelight vigils across the territory, with rallies planned for the weekend. The government expressed "great sorrow and regret," but police deny blocking an ambulance that responded to the incident.

site_title: Koon Holdings gets debt moratorium until February
summary: The High Court of Singapore granted a debt moratorium to Koon Holdings and its subsidiary Koon Construction & Transport until February 28, 2020. The companies, which applied for court protection in October, aim to restore their financial position through a scheme of arrangement. This moratorium will last from November 7 to February 28, allowing the companies to restructure and implement their plan.

site_title: Money FM podcast: How I unlocked financial happiness
summary: Michelle Martin interviews Anna Vanessa Haotanto, former CEO of The New Savvy, on her journey to financial happiness. Haotanto shares her biggest financial challenges as a modern woman, including managing debt and investing. The conversation highlights the importance of self-awareness and prioritizing needs over wants. Haotanto emphasizes the need for women to take control of their finances and make informed decisions. The conversation provides insights into achieving financial stability and happiness, with Haotanto sharing her personal experiences and expertise.

site_title: Suzuki braces for bumpy road ahead after Q2 profit tumbles on India market woes
summary: Suzuki Motor Corp reported a 32% decline in Q2 operating profit to 55.9 billion yen due to slumping car demand in India, its largest market. The company slashed its full-year vehicle sales outlook, expecting a 20% drop in global sales and a 5% decline in India sales. India's car sector has been hit by a liquidity crunch, higher taxes, and a weak rural economy, prompting Suzuki to focus on sustainable growth. The company's president, Toshihiro Suzuki, stated that India's growth will be marked by "hills and valleys."

site_title: Mitsubishi to shut Singapore oil-trading unit after unauthorised losses
summary: Mitsubishi Corp, Japan's largest trading group, is shutting its Singapore-based crude oil and fuel trading unit, Petro-Diamond Singapore, due to enormous unauthorised trading losses of around $426.3 million. The unit will close unofficial trading positions, resulting in a final debt of up to $30.8 billion yen. The decision comes after a trader, Wang Xingchen, lost $320 million in unauthorised transactions, and the company will bring oil and fuel trading back to Tokyo. This move also affects Mitsubishi's full-year earnings forecast, which is expected to be 520 billion yen.

site_title: Putting the customer first
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta is credited with transforming the bank into a digital powerhouse, putting the customer first and leveraging technology to stay ahead of Big Tech competitors. A 2012 incident where an ATM security feature was turned off to reduce queues led to a significant change in the bank's approach, with Gupta deciding not to punish the staff and instead recognizing their judgment call. Under Gupta's leadership, DBS has seen significant growth, capturing top-three market share in key segments and increasing its market share in Singapore. The bank has also expanded its corporate banking services and cracked its 2020 target for cash management. Gupta emphasizes the importance of customer experience, data-driven decision-making, and adapting to changing regulatory landscapes, and has made decisions such as ending coal-power plant financing to align with sustainability goals.

site_title: Virgin Australia to trim domestic capacity, axe a Hong Kong route
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings plans to cut domestic capacity by at least 2% and remove five aircraft from its fleet, citing stagnant demand. The airline will also axe its Melbourne-Hong Kong route and replace it with flights from Brisbane to Tokyo's Haneda Airport. The reduction aims to lift airfares, which have been flatlined, before the end of June. This move follows restructuring efforts unveiled earlier this year, with CEO Paul Scurrah stating that the changes are necessary to boost revenue.

site_title: James Dean 'cast' in new movie, 64 years after death
summary: James Dean, who died in 1955 at 24, is set to reappear on screen in the upcoming film "Finding Jack", a Vietnam War action-drama, thanks to special effects recreating his image from old footage and photographs. Dean's family granted the rights to use his image for the film adaptation of Gareth Crocker's 2008 novel about US military dogs in Vietnam. The film's co-director described Dean as the perfect fit for the role of Rogan, a secondary lead character. The use of computer-generated imagery and another actor's voice will bring Dean back to the screen in a new role.

site_title: A mirage? SGX RegCo urges caution on Mirach's surge
summary: SGX RegCo urges caution on Mirach Energy's surge, citing a small group of individuals responsible for nearly 90% of the buy volume for about a month. The stock's share price rose from 14 Singapore cents to 37 cents between Sept 25 and Nov 5. This follows a previous warning on Sept 24, after which Mirach's share price fell but then rose again.

site_title: China central bank will conduct MLF operations on Tuesday: sources
summary: China's central bank will conduct medium-term lending facility (MLF) operations on Tuesday to roll over maturing loans worth 403.5 billion yuan (S$77.9 billion). This move will closely be watched to gauge the size and interest rate of the fresh MLF loan injection, influencing the central bank's monetary policy stance and the Loan Prime Rate (LPR). The one-year MLF rate stands at 3.3% and has not been cut since February 2016, amid uncertainty over China's economy growth nears 30-year lows.

site_title: IAG agrees to buy Spain's Air Europa
summary: IAG agrees to buy Spain's Air Europa for 1.0 billion euros, expanding routes to Latin America and the Caribbean, boosting Madrid as a key hub. The deal, worth US$1.2 billion, aims to complete in the second half of 2020 and will fund with debt. Air Europa's acquisition is expected to generate significant savings in costs and sales, solidifying Madrid's position among European hubs. The move will also bolster IAG's portfolio, which includes Aer Lingus and Level, and is seen as a strategic fit for the group.

site_title: Beyond Meat eyes production in Asia before end-2020
summary: Beyond Meat aims to start production in Asia before the end of 2020, with a focus on China, a major untapped market for its plant-based meat products. The company, along with rival Impossible Foods, is racing to expand sales to China, a market expected to explode to an estimated $140 billion over the next decade. To succeed, Beyond Meat needs to develop production systems, secure retail customers, and create supply chains, with initial product prices expected to be relatively high before scaling up to compete with local meat prices.

images.alt_text: Beyond Meat aims to start production in Asia before the end of next year, as it gets closer to selling its popular plant-based meat products in China, executive chairman Seth Goldman told Reuters.

site_title: ECB official fighting graft charges finally gets day in court
summary: Latvia's central-bank governor Ilmars Rimsevics, facing bribery charges, is attending his first hearing after almost two years. Rimsevics denies the charges, which carry a prison term of over 10 years, and claims a group of commercial lenders orchestrated the case against him. The case has sent shockwaves through the Baltic nation, which is trying to rebuild its reputation after a spate of negative news, including the closure of a bank accused of money laundering. A corruption trial against a powerful politician has also dragged on for over a decade, adding to the country's legal challenges.

site_title: Building a village
summary: Serial entrepreneur Elaine Kim is focusing on her latest venture, Trehaus, a co-working space in Funan Mall that provides work-life balance for parents and quality education for young children. Kim, a palliative care doctor and co-founder of social enterprises CRIB and Trehaus, aims to make a positive difference in others' lives through her various initiatives. Her passion for social causes was instilled in her at a young age and has driven her to launch multiple businesses, including CRIB, which supports female entrepreneurs and raises funds for needy communities.

site_title: Singapore accelerator EduSpaze providing up to S$500,000 for early-stage edtech startups
summary: Singapore-based accelerator EduSpaze has launched, providing up to S$500,000 to early-stage edtech startups. The program customizes experiences for each startup, focusing on education sector insights and measuring product impact. Applications are open until December 20, 2019, with up to 10 companies selected to start in February 2020. EduSpaze partners with local institutions and aims to leverage global best practices to stimulate innovation in Singapore's edtech ecosystem.

site_title: Draft rules issued to allow foreign companies to list in China from next year
summary: China's justice ministry has published draft rules allowing foreign companies to list on the country's stock exchanges, set to be implemented on January 1, 2020. The rules, which would allow foreign companies to compete for government procurement projects and issue bonds, also prohibit forced technology transfers. The move is aimed at showcasing China's free trade credentials and comes ahead of a major import fair in Shanghai. Foreign firms can enjoy preferential tax treatment if they invest in certain industries and regions. The rules will be open for public opinion until December 1, 2019.

site_title: US reiterates commitment to Indo-Pacific as bilateral trade hits record US$2t in 2018
summary: The US reiterates its commitment to the Indo-Pacific region, with bilateral trade reaching a record $2 trillion in 2018. US Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross stated the US is "extremely engaged and committed" to the region, citing investments and economic ties. The US is the largest source of foreign direct investment in the Indo-Pacific, with $866 billion, and has a wide-ranging strategy to promote a free and open region. The move counters China's Belt and Road Initiative, with Ross emphasizing the need for fair, enforceable, and transparent deals.

images.alt_text: Secretary Ross speaking at the Indo-Pacific Business Forum in Bangkok on Monday. He noted that the US is the largest source of FDI into the Indo-Pacific region to the tune of US$866 billion.

site_title: ASAP sold hotels to sponsor ahead of IPO to gain transaction certainty: EHT
summary: ASSET management firm ASAP sold six hotels to Eagle Hospitality Trust's (EHT) sponsor ahead of EHT's initial public offering (IPO) to gain transaction certainty. The sale, conducted in March, was to the sponsor prior to the IPO process. EHT acquired the hotels from the sponsor on May 24, listing date. ASAP's CEO, Frank Yuan, has a family relationship with EHT's other major shareholders, but the relationship was not disclosed. The sale price and terms were different, with the sponsor incurring additional costs.

site_title: Vienna orchestra celebrates 50th birthday with new woman conductor
summary: The Vienna orchestra celebrates its 50th anniversary with a special concert conducted by Marin Alsop, the first female chief conductor in Austria. Alsop, 63, has taken over from the previous conductor and marks a significant change in Vienna's traditionally male-dominated classical music scene. While women make up only 4% of conductors globally, Vienna's music students are more female, and the city's music university has recently appointed a woman as head for the first time in its history. Alsop's appointment is seen as a step towards change in the sector, with some observers predicting a shift towards greater diversity and inclusion.

site_title: Window To The Past
summary: An exhibition, "From Brush to Lens: Early Chinese Photography Studios in Singapore," showcases 90 historic photographs taken by Chinese photographers in the 1890s. The photographers, from Guangzhou, learned from Europeans and came to Singapore to build a thriving business. The exhibition, now closed, highlighted the studios' role in documenting important events and family portraits.

images.alt_text: From Brush to Lens: Early Chinese Photography Studios in Singapore.

site_title: Euro zone factories stuck in a slump amid US-China trade war
summary: The euro zone factory sector contracted sharply in November due to the ongoing US-China trade war and uncertainty over the UK's departure from the EU. The Eurozone manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 45.9, its ninth month below the 50 mark, indicating a recession. Germany's manufacturing activity remained stuck in recession, while Italy and Spain also experienced contraction. However, France saw a modest increase in factory growth, likely due to government stimulus. The US-China trade dispute is blamed for the slump, and policymakers will face challenges in addressing the issue.

site_title: HK stabbing in broad daylight raises election safety questions
summary: A pro-Beijing lawmaker in Hong Kong was stabbed in broad daylight while campaigning, and a pro-democracy candidate had his ear bitten off in a violent brawl earlier this week. The attacks have raised concerns about the safety of the upcoming election on November 24, which could be delayed if there is "riot, open violence, or any danger to public health or safety." Hong Kong's Beijing-appointed chief executive, Carrie Lam, has the authority to decide whether to delay the vote, which could deal a setback to democracy under Chinese rule.

site_title: Passage through Expedia
summary: Expedia, under CEO Mark Okerstrom, is focusing on growth through mergers and acquisitions (M&A), leveraging scale and technology across its diverse platforms. The company has been expanding its corporate travel arm, Egencia, and is seeking acquisitions that can help it strengthen its presence in the business travel space. Despite a decrease in M&A activity in recent years, Expedia remains acquisitive, with a focus on acquiring great technology and pouring more money into experiential travel experiences. The company is also investing in Asia-Pacific markets, where it has seen significant growth, and is exploring opportunities in China and Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: "Expedia will always be a company that's acquisitive. M&A is in our DNA. Every great company has to be able to operate organically to the full potential and (also) have the capability of buying and integrating companies." - Mark Okerstrom.

site_title: UK listing rules bonfire gives more pain than gain
summary: The UK government is considering loosening its listing rules to give company founders superior voting rights, aiming to boost London's competitiveness after Brexit. However, this move is unlikely to attract tech startups, as companies may prefer New York listings for greater liquidity and richer valuations. The reform could backfire, allowing bad management to shield itself, and may harm London's status as a financial hub. A temporary system with a sunset clause may not prevent abuse, and a stable regulatory environment is needed to truly support the city's financial sector.

images.alt_text: Guy Fawkes, who plotted to blow up the UK Houses of Parliament in 1605, said that a desperate disease requires a dangerous remedy.
